name: Preşedinte. –
text: I declare open the 2015-2016 session of the European Parliament.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: I declare the hearing open and give the floor to Mr Richard Corbett for an indication of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I hope Members will not be puzzled if I wish everybody a Happy New Year because today, the second Tuesday of March, is the beginning of the annual parliamentary year under the Treaty. We have an annual session which begins on the second Tuesday of March. This annual session is divided into 12 monthly part-sessions which means, logically, that this week we have had one part—session finishing on the Monday, and another one starting today on the Tuesday.  In other words, this week is actually two part—sessions of Parliament, and I would ask the President and the Bureau of Parliament when looking at the calendar of sessions of Parliament to take this into account when it calculates the number of part-sessions held in Strasbourg, because it seems to me that this gives us the opportunity to adjust the number of times per year we come to Strasbourg, given that this week is actually two part—sessions.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: We will communicate this and I am sure that you will receive an appropriate response.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The first item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on Transport and Tourism on the Council's first reading position with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Directive 96/53/EC of the Establishment, for certain road vehicles travelling within the Community, the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weight in international traffic (11296/3/2014 - C8-0294/2014 - 2013/0105(COD)) (Rapporteur: Jörg Leichtfried) (A8-0032/2015).

name: Jörg Leichtfried
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. "Good thing sometimes takes a while," one says in Austria. This good thing that we are discussing today, namely the question of the weights and dimensions of lorries, has really taken a little longer. But we have come to a good end. I was very pleased that the proposal for this report for second reading was adopted unanimously in the Committee on Transport. That is not always the case, and it shows that we have worked very well together. It also shows that common solutions can be found if it is necessary and sensible. In terms of content, the European Parliament, together with the Council, has taken this Commission's proposal forward and changed it. We felt – and this is the first key point – that there was no need for any new legislation on the issue of cross-border journeys. Those who have so far crossed borders with larger, heavier and higher trucks can continue to do so. Those who do not want to do so do not need to do so, nor do they need to allow such lorries to pass through these countries. That has been the stand so far, and it is good that it has remained so. That is what we have decided. Otherwise, we have been very accommodating to the Commission and have taken up the ideas expressed in this proposal, because they were very useful. We have ensured that lorries become safer in the future, safer for drivers, but also and, above all, safer for other road users, for weaker road users, in particular by changing the shape of cabins, but also by improving the all-round visibility, because there are still a great many serious and also fatal accidents involving lorries, especially in urban traffic. We have also ensured that trucks become more environmentally friendly in the future, on the one hand by enabling other propulsion methods, more environmentally friendly propulsion methods, on the other hand also by changing the design of the trucks, at the back by introducing so-called rear flaps – I believe that the English term is almost the better one here – and at the front by the possibility of modifying the cabin shape. There are also facilitations for intermodal transport. This is also important because we have so many different transport situations in Europe. If you compare Central Europe with northern Europe, for example, the distances are quite different. That was also important. Another problem we have addressed is the issue of truck overloading. Drivers are held responsible if the truck is overloaded. Therefore, they must also be able to see if it is overloaded. We will ensure that this is the case in the future and we have ensured that this will be the case. Ladies and gentlemen, that is what I have to say in my introductory remarks. Once again, thank you very much for the extremely good cooperation. I look forward to a lively and interesting debate.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members of Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur Mr Jörg Leichtfried, for the excellent work they have done. The Commission is grateful for the amendments proposed and adopted by Parliament and for the constructive work carried out during the legislative process to reach a good compromise. All these efforts have contributed to the possibility of having safer and greener heavy goods vehicles on the roads in the future. The proposed revision of the Weights and Dimensions Directive will serve different EU transport policy objectives. First, it will contribute to road safety. This is for us one of the core objectives and we always try to find new solutions in order to achieve that: better road safety. It is good for vulnerable road users because the new cab design will give lorry drivers a better view of the road. On-board weighing systems linked to digital tachographs and weigh—in—motion stations on the main roads will allow for more consistent checks from country to country.  Second, it will encourage greener transport. With the use of low—carbon technologies it will make trucks more aerodynamic and therefore more fuel—efficient.  Third, it will promote innovation as has already been stated, and this will boost the competitiveness of the EU industry at a global level. It is enabling legislation which will allow European manufacturers to sell the truck of the future across the global markets.  Finally, intermodality. This promotes intermodular transport by cutting red tape to allow 45-foot containers to be shifted more easily between ship, rail and road.  This can be described as a win—win situation for society, with fewer emissions and casualties on our roads; for hauliers with lower fuel costs and additional incentives to renew their fleet; and for the industry, which will be able to produce new models with higher performance and to remain competitive on the global market for heavy goods vehicles. I am really looking forward to an interesting debate.

name: Markus Ferber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think that we have managed to achieve a very good result on the further development of the directive on dimensions and weights, both in our committee during the last parliamentary term and now, together with the Council in the trialogue, in negotiations that are not very easy. I would just like to pick out a few points; Key words have already been mentioned: I believe that the promotion of intermodal transport is a great step forward. I think it is a good point that we have solved the problem of not being able to transport 45-foot containers intermodally because of ten centimetres. The fact that we are getting more efficient commercial vehicles should also be mentioned. The fact that we are getting more road safety by allowing designs in the cab that improve the driver's field of vision is a significant step forward. However, I would also like to raise the issue of stricter controls in the event of overloading. The Commissioner also mentioned it in her speech. I think that this, too, is an important contribution to improving road safety, and also, of course, that we accept that new propulsion technologies require additional weight and dimensional requirements. All this shows that we are on a very sensible and right path. On the other hand, however, I would also like to say that, as far as the usable area itself is concerned, we have always made it clear that 25-metre lorries, 60-tonne lorries and the like are not on our agenda in cross-border traffic. And that is also a clear message that is being sent here by the European Parliament. What we have now permanently approved in Scandinavia for the Member States that have always done so in Scandinavia is not the introduction of long or 60 tonne lorries throughout the European Union – I would like to say this explicitly – but merely a confirmation of the status quo that we already have in other parts of Europe, but also creates the legal certainty there that would otherwise have been lost. That is why it is a very balanced compromise, which the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats will also agree to.

name: Ismail Ertug
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The legal framework for tomorrow's trucks is hereby set. I say 'of tomorrow', because, it has also been said, improved aerodynamics will make tomorrow's trucks more environmentally friendly, secondly, they will become safer and, thirdly, what is almost as important will mean more comfort for the driver in the cab. I would like to take this as an example – as has already been said– a larger windscreen will, of course, make a decisive contribution to the safety of those who are the weakest in traffic, namely pedestrians and bicyclists. This is part of the vision zero, namely zero road deaths by 2050. It is somewhat sad that the lobby has won in the Council in terms of introducing this new generation of lorries. That would not be the case until 2020 at the earliest. But all in all, that's a good thing. The fact that there is no general authorisation for the gigaliners across borders rounds it off. Many thanks to the rapporteur and those who have worked on it.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, today we are concluding a long dossier on sizes and weights. It is good that we have now reached an agreement and that modern-designed lorries now have an opportunity for the future: more environmental friendliness, better for road safety. In doing so, we are taking a step in the right direction. Yet I stand here with mixed feelings. We could do much more to make the road transport sector more environmentally friendly and road-safe, while at the same time reducing congestion on Europe's roads. I am referring, of course, to the ecocombi, the longer and heavier truck that we have known for a long time from the Dutch roads and on the Dutch roads. We see that the ecocombis drive around there to everyone's satisfaction. The environmental performance is better, there are fewer trucks on the road, there is no negative effect on infrastructure maintenance costs, nor does there is a negative impact on road safety. That's what all the studies on the ecocombi show. So you would expect Europe to take that opportunity and give the ecocombi ample access. Such an innovative concept, who would leave it behind? But unfortunately, what do we see? Unfounded prejudices and fear of innovation prevail here in this Parliament, and so the ecocombi does not have opportunities in Europe. As a result, we continue to be allowed depending on the good will of a Member State or an ecocombi. Fortunately, there is a back door, because we have known since 2012 that the European Commission is fine with the use of ecocombi across borders, provided that both countries on the border side allow the ecocombi nationally. Fortunately, there is that back door, but we missed an opportunity today. The ecocombi should have come to Europe.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr van Dalen, I appreciate the points you make. I am a little surprised that you are totally in favour of longer and larger lorries, particularly when there are really big issues around urban roads and the appropriateness of such lorries on urban roads. It is all very well in the Netherlands and Germany where they have adequate measures to stop longer vehicles using urban roads, but would you not agree that it would be inappropriate to extend this to all Member States when those measures simply are not in place and we know how dangerous these vehicles can be on urban roads?

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. – This is really a point that I say: take a look at the investigations. These trucks do not harm road safety, on the contrary. Nowhere has it been shown that road safety is getting worse, as all the studies show. I understand that these trucks in your country may be too heavy on certain bridges and the like. Well, then you shouldn't let them in there. These trucks are also not allowed on all roads in the Netherlands. It concerns a limited number of roads between large distribution centres and for the smaller roads within the cities there are other trucks. But we just have to give this truck opportunities in Europe, it's good!

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work on this I would like to begin by thanking our rapporteur, Jörg Leichtfried. He has really done a great job, because we have had very different positions in Parliament. He has managed to get this to a reasonable whole, which we all ultimately agreed to. We all agree with what we now have on the table. We all want more safety in lorries, it is more environmentally friendly, which we have already achieved through these aerodynamic attachments. That is all well and good. But I think that when Ismail Ertug says that we have now created something for the truck of the future, that is not quite right. We missed some chances. I think that is an explicit pity. It is .B that we do not have the extended semi-trailer in it. We do have the 45-foot container, but we have no options for the 48-foot container that is already on the world's oceans. Watching and watching tomorrow's traffic also means setting up the framework conditions for tomorrow's transport. Of course, it's true: not everything that is longer can drive anywhere, Lucy Anderson is right. It cannot be the case – and this is not the case in Germany either – that longer trucks, i.e. the really long ones, the 26-metre-long ones, drive into the cities. But there is infrastructure where possible. And that is exactly the case: I can fully understand, dear Jörg Leichtfried, that Austria says that we have tunnel systems, that there are no emergency stops in the tunnels where these long trucks can stop. We don't have the infrastructure, so they shouldn't drive with us. Totally ok! But I think that where it is possible to drive in Europe, we should also allow it. That is why I am very much looking forward to this revision clause, which comes from the Commission – hopefully before 2020. And one more thing: it is the case that, for example.B, in Germany North Rhine-Westphalia, the largest federal state, has agreed to take part in this field trial for long trucks – with a red-green government, of course – is something i welcome, because I think that is the right direction. Finally, Commissioner, one question, because there is confusion here: can the long lorries cross borders or not? Mr Leichtfried said yes, Mr Ertug said no. I think it's allowed.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Leichtfried, for his excellent and professional work on this long-running project, which has been challenging in many ways. We are happy to regard the outcome achieved as a good compromise, especially in view of the series of wishes and demands that we have dealt with in the Member States and in the various stakeholders. It is worth bearing in mind that the fact that this proposal will make Europe's heavy equipment more energy-efficient, safer and, above all, lower-emission, is easily drowned in a number of technical details. The introduction of new technologies always entails costs, it must be recognised and can also indirectly affect the competitive situation and division of labour between modes of transport. During the preparations, it became very clear that the so-called mega-trucks raise fears, and at least personally, I was sometimes very concerned about whether we would continue to be able to maintain the exceptions that preserve logistical cost-effectiveness and the possibility of transport and production in the Nordic countries too, in northern Europe. In Finland, traffic flows and infrastructure are significantly different from those in congested Central Europe, and it is therefore of the utmost importance that solutions that are perceived to be regionally sound can continue to be in place, as is the case now, for example. In Finland and Sweden and in traffic between us. Large and modern units best ensure the energy and cost-effectiveness of transport. If someone does not believe this, you can certainly come to both Finland and Sweden to get to know each other.

name: Keith Taylor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Leichtfried, for his hard work on this file. With strong support from our group he managed to neutralise the attempts to legalise cross—border use of gigaliners. Legalising mega-trucks throughout Europe in densely populated areas with high traffic volumes would have, we believe, devastating effects for road safety and for infrastructure investment costs and would counteract all the good efforts for a more sustainable and efficient use of transport modes. Furthermore, the gains we achieved on road safety and fuel efficiency aspects are positive. The introduction of a new and safer lorry cab design, including reduced blind spots, underrun protection and health and safety within cabs, will save lives on roads, notably those of cyclists. However, we felt that these proposals had been considerably watered down. We had hoped for much more, for example for direct vision improvements, as well as for the possibility to implement those changes much sooner than from 2021 onwards. In view of the continued ban on gigaliners across borders within the EU, we are happy to support this text, although the gains on safety and workers’ rights could clearly have been bigger. For one, we do not want to see drivers having to spend unreasonable hours, including their weekly rest, in the cabs of their lorries. Yet, unfortunately, this practice has become commonplace. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Taylor's speech is truly a textbook example of a speech based on unfounded prejudices and fear of renovation. You are telling you that the ecocombi is detrimental to road safety, is detrimental to the pressure on the infrastructure. In the Netherlands, one of the most populous countries in Europe, we have more than 10 years of experience with this truck. All reports show: no effect on road safety and if properly deployed on good routes, no effect on the infrastructure . And you proclaim hell and damnation here when it comes to that ecocombi. I find it really incomprehensible that you are spreading misinformation here in this way. So my question is, do you want to stop spreading this misinformation around?

name: Keith Taylor (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr van Dalen, I think what you actually said was prejudiced advice is alright if it is well-founded. I think the simple fact is that we have a different evidence base, and the evidence base is showing disproportionate damage. You can wave your hands as much as you like, Mr van Dalen, but you cannot hide from the truth. The disproportionate damage is being caused to our infrastructure, to our roads, by heavy trucks. In my life I have driven lorries, and I am telling you that is the case.

name: Peter Lundgren
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As a representative of a Eurosceptic group, it is clear that this is not the optimal solution for me. I would rather see a lot of this done at national level, but now it is as it is and there is good stuff in this, such as the blind spot – it is a major concern as a lorry driver, as I myself have been for 30 years. It is a very big concern that you do not see cyclists walking at the side of the truck close by. A now design can have great advantages, in fact, for the driver.  Weight control is also a good thing, because it is also the driver who is hanged. Every time you get stopped in a police check, it is the driver who bears ultimate responsibility for how much weight you have on the truck. So I see that as a good thing, too. Then I want to come to what they call "megatrucks". It is distressing to hear Mr Taylor stand and drive out pure hate speech against what we call 'megatrucks'. I'm from Sweden myself. We have a country that does not have such a terribly large railway. We are totally dependent on trucks, and the most environmentally friendly option is of course to have as much goods as possible on the truck. That it would destroy the infrastructure, yes, but you understand that it has to do with how many axles you have on the vehicle. If you allocate the weight of more shoulders, you also have no problems with road damage. And let me point out that the trucks we have problems with in Sweden during the winter period are not, for example, those called 'megatrucks'. It is the two-axle European haulers – small cars from Europe – who are the big concern, not the big trucks.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not share all the objectives of this text and, in particular, with my colleagues on the National Front, I regret above all that the protection of companies and employees is not in the motivations. Clearly, their fate is not of interest to the Commission, which is content with a strictly ideological vision that absolutizes competition. Often, in this Chamber, I feel a little alone with my colleagues in the National Front to defend those you mistreat in the name of a materialistic and liberal ideology. On the other hand, this text seems to me to be contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. Whether it is improving the aerodynamic performance of vehicles, their energy efficiency or the requirements of performance and safety, I do not see in which of these areas Member States would not be able to act effectively themselves.  As usual, the Commission tramples on the principle of subsidiarity in the name of reducing CO2 emissions, which are decidedly good. Finally, under the pretext of combating global warming, the Commission allows itself to intervene in all areas, in defiance of the treaties. Therefore, as at first reading, the Members of the National Front will vote against this text, which we consider too technocratic. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Dear Colleague, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, You have just said that you are against this proposal because it does not also take account of workers' rights. I am a little surprised and wonder if you are well aware of the proposal: it is precisely the fact that in this case the larger cab is good for the driver, and also the fact that the driver can see for himself what weight he has loaded so that he can really take responsibility is now re-regulated. The proposal contains various things that have not only always been from the driver's point of view, but we have also taken very much account of what the driver needs in order to have an improvement through this legislative proposal. I therefore do not quite understand why you are opposed to this.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. "Madam, yes, I said that we do not share all the objectives of this text. We believe, in particular, that the principle of subsidiarity must be respected, and in particular the protection of workers in each of the countries of the European Union, because, you see, we certainly sit, like you, in this Chamber, but we never forget that we are French Members of the European Parliament. We are therefore trying to defend the rights of French workers as a priority. I think each of us should be a little more concerned about the sovereignty of our country.

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: Mr President, firstly, I would like to thank Mr Leichtfried's team and also to my colleague Markus Ferber. They have managed to reach a reasonable compromise in a very difficult dossier. But I too am speaking here today with a double responsibility. On the one hand, I am the coordinator of the EPP Group and I support my shadow rapporteur in the result achieved, but on the other hand I am a Dutch MEP and we think very differently about the ecocombi's than most in this house. But I'll come back to that in a minute.  First of all, the larger truck combinations. They are good for sustainability, for road safety, less emissions, less environmental impact. The safety was also mentioned here by colleagues, namely better visibility. Unfortunately, we still have many accidents involving lorries in Europe and these proposals could cause 300 road deaths. The issue of containers has already been mentioned by Mrs Meissner. Those 45 foot containers are a good development.  I think the ecocombis are a missed opportunity. In the Netherlands, we have very good experience with ecocombi's: positive effects on road safety and better environmental performance. There are more and more reports from the German Government – i.e. Mr Ertug – saying that they are good for the environment. In the meantime, I fully understand that we are allowed to continue with the ecocombi in the alternative, bilaterally. So if we could soon make a compromise within the Benelux or with North Rhine-Westphalia, we will move forward. And I agree with everyone: no ecocombis in small German or Austrian villages. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – I generally agree with what Mr van de Camp said. And I have a question for you: what will be the effect of this regulation and possibly the tendency to increase the weight of mega-trucks in the market for rail transport? Everywhere we declare: priority for railways. What do you think?

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. This is a very astute question because we, as the European Parliament, are all working towards better intermodality. We do indeed want transport away from the air and away from the road, to the rail and into inland waterways. But at some point you see that it is easier, for example, to transport vegetables, fresh fruit, food, door to door quickly in large quantities while for example sand, steel, concrete, can continue to pass through the ship. Intermodality is therefore also co-modality, namely the different modalities side by side and that is where the ecocombi fits in.

name: Jens Nilsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In Sweden and Finland we allow 25.25 meters long truck section, in Norway and Denmark on some routes but in the rest of Europe only 18. That is why I and we were very concerned when the proposal came to be banned throughout Europe. I live in northern Sweden. It would have been devastating for the forest industry in northern Sweden and northern Finland. We need these vehicles for, above all, the transport of timber between Sweden and Norway and Sweden and Finland. Routes which cannot be replaced by rail. It is also the case that there are trials going on in Sweden with even longer and even heavier transport facilities, and this is done partly for environmental reasons. The more we load these cars, the fewer cars, the less emissions. I am therefore pleased that the rapporteur listened to us last spring and thank you for that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I listened to your speech with great interest; it is very interesting that you say how important these trucks are in your country.  Would you agree with me that perhaps this is one perfect example of when rules and regulations that come out from a superbody like this, a superstate if you like, across the EU, cannot possibly fit and suit everyone within it, and that is why national governments surely are the best people to make these decisions.

name: Jens Nilsson (S&D)
text: answer ("blue card"). We need common rules in Europe, but we should also be prepared for national adaptation where there are reasons for doing so. It does in Sweden because we have such long distances and we do not have rail everywhere. If forests as a resource are to be used, as the whole of Europe needs, then we also need sensible transport.

name: Jacqueline Foster (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Jörg Leichtfried. He has managed to keep unwarranted hysteria to a minimum, certainly on this issue of mega trucks.  Firstly, my delegation had a number of key political objectives. One was to ensure that the UK would retain the right to determine the use of mega trucks on British roads. Just for clarification, this has been established. So the agreement to operate cross-border is, in my view, as it should be. That should be determined; this is subsidiarity and that again has been the conclusion that has been reached. So I support my Swedish, Dutch and other colleagues too. It is not for me to determine what they choose to do in their Member State. Secondly, we were also successful in retaining the existing right of trucks which are higher than the permitted 4 metres to operate between the UK and the Republic of Ireland, thus protecting our local hauliers. Finally, in terms of safer cab design, we did successfully reach an agreement whereby new, safer and more streamlined cab design in lorries will be introduced following the Commission proposal on type-approval legislation which will be coming in the near future. So this will give our manufacturers sufficient time to improve those designs and this should eventually lead to safer vehicles, reducing the risk of death and injury to pedestrians and cyclists. So once again I would like to thank Mr Leichtfried. The ECR will supporting him in the vote today. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the Dear Jacqueline Foster, we know each other very well. And I know you are actually very much in favour of the European internal market. That surprised me a bit now. After all, the proposal that we had, which has now been rejected, was precisely that the Member States should be able to decide for themselves whether they say that my infrastructure is good enough to allow longer units on the roads. That is why I think it is a pity – and I thought you were on our side – that there is no corresponding regulation in this legislation now. Once again: there are, for example.B. extended semi-trailers in Germany, which now also fit on trains. That would be a way of even dealing with intermodal procedures better. Isthis not something we should fight for in the future?

name: Jacqueline Foster (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, we agree on many things and, yes, of course we support a single market. However, there are occasions when Member States need to determine what is best for them. I come from an island; it is not quite the same as crossing these great areas of mainland Europe. We determine again points raised by Mr van Dalen and others. These trucks have been in use for a long time and they should be allowed to continue along those lines. But in terms of where we are, we have made a decision that they are not appropriate – certainly on British roads – and that is where we are. So thank you for your intervention.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would also like to thank Mr Leichtfried first for his work. It was a long-term work. We've been working for a long time to bring this to a successful conclusion, and here we are. We have made a lot of effective progress in terms of real technical standards, more aerodynamic trucks, longer and heavier trucks that are allowed on the road, in order to bring a bit of environmental friendliness and safety into the system.  This is, of course, also a story of the internal market. If you set a number of standards, it is also logical that they should be applied in the same way throughout europe throughout the internal market. Especially in the transport market, it is very important to really commit to further integration. It is not for us to choose the best way of transport. The different modes have to work together, intermodal, co-modal, to finally find the best solution for the market, for the people who are active in the market. In the end, they choose what they are talking about.  In this respect, it is also important to allow innovation, to give new opportunities to ensure that transport can be carried out effectively in the most safe and environmentally friendly way, while also not losing sight of cost efficiency. In this respect, it seems quite bizarre to me that the text does not mention anywhere in countries that have pilot projects today or where it is allowed today to have longer trucks on the road. These trucks should also be able to cross the border. In an internal market, this is a normality. It is therefore quite bizarre that there are still Members today who believe that new barriers, new dams can be erected in the internal transport market.  We generally have a good compromise except for the last part of the internal market. There's still a little work to be done there. I therefore ask the Commission to be very attentive.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, once again the EU is driving towards a one—size—fits—all 28 Member States directive that will be totally unworkable. I refer to the size and weight of mega trucks, of longer and heavier vehicles. The fact that this issue has remained unresolved from when Directive 96/53/EC entered into force in 1996 shows how unworkable this issue is. Vehicles of a size laid down in that Directive create certain undeniable and fundamental issues which have not been addressed, such as the unsuitability of some highways infrastructure in certain Member States. More fundamental are the safety issues raised. While trials with longer and heavier trucks are carried out in some Member States, the EU talks about safety improvements and aerodynamic optimisation, but no realistic solution is found. This issue should be up to Member States to decide, especially where their trucks are more suitable. The cost of upgrading roads to cope with these vehicles and for repairing the damage they cause would amount to billions. Who would pay? The taxpayer, of course! (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jacqueline Foster (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to ask our colleague if she actually understands where we got to in the trialogue, because from what she said she has clearly been absent from the discussions.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I clearly understand where we are going.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Statistics show that more than 75% of European freight is carried out by road. It is therefore important that the revised rules have the expected effect of, inter alia, increasing safety, reducing energy consumption, reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the transport sector and adapting the rules to the realities of technical progress and the use of good technologies, including in particular alternative drives and improving the aerodynamic characteristics of vehicles.  I would like to draw attention to a number of issues that are extremely important for road infrastructure in the Countries of the European Union. I am pleased that special permits have been maintained which allow non-standard vehicles to move around the territory of a country. Indeed, not every road infrastructure in the Member States is adapted m.in to the traffic of such large and heavy vehicles, for example because of climatic conditions or road quality. Therefore, the prior consent of two countries to cross-border use of mega-vehicles, as well as the monitoring and evaluation of the traffic consequences of these vehicles, will certainly greatly improve safety and maintain the proper condition of the road infrastructure.  The next important issue is vehicle overload. I would like to draw attention to the need to strengthen controls in this area, as it is often cheaper to implement an effective pre-wedding measurement system than the sum of the expenditure incurred in modernising roads as a result of the movement of overloaded vehicles on them. Moreover, the European Commission's plans to introduce a new on-board truck weight control system for new vehicles, to install a current weighing system, are, from my point of view, a very good solution. I congratulate the rapporteur very warmly, and I am convinced that the agreement reached brings together the key, necessary and necessary elements.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I join in the congratulations expressed by Mrs Łukacijewska. Mr Jorg Leichtfried has done a very good job – this is evidenced, for example, by Commissioner Bulc. It is rare for the Commission, in its first words, to fully accept what has been worked out in Parliament.  Secondly, this is also confirmed by the debate or dispute between Mr van Dalen and Mr Taylor. This means that Mr. Leichtfried has found this golden mean and this golden mean is a matter of the cabin and all the advantages associated with it: elongation, but without loss for the load part. As far as mega trucks or gigaliners are concerned, it depends on what we want to call them, the matter is clearly resolved here, i.e. countries that want to have – they may have, in cross-border traffic – the issue of arrangements between countries. Thus, one State does not impose a state on the other State.  And the last very important aspect – savings. These are issues not so much the size of the car, but simply empty return runs. If this gigaliner comes back empty – that's just an economic downside.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The discussion about vehicles – those much longer and heavier than standard, so-called megatrucks – has been going on for decades. Today, we are working on a regulation that involves adapting the masses and dimensions of vehicles in order to correct the efficiency of road transport. We know that there were plans to allow these types of vehicles to be used without proper permits. However, we must bear in mind that in the European Union, including my own country, in Poland, we differ in terms of various economic, infrastructure, transport infrastructure development, transport accessibility, in short – allowing megatrucks to the full extent would require an improvement in the parameters of roads and bridges, and thus an increase in state budget expenditure for additional road repairs and reconstruction. I am therefore pleased that in Parliament we have managed to reach such an agreement with the participation of the European Parliament, a position that upholds the current legal situation and takes into account an important issue for Polish, namely preventing cross-border movement of vehicles of non-standard mass without additional authorisations.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I have a question for our colleague, Mr Poręba, who was talking about a compromise, considering the licences that would have to be issued to big lorries and trucks, especially in Central and Eastern Europe – which is where we are from – versus a better, reliable infrastructure. What, in his opinion, might this compromise involve?

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". – Mr President, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Schwab In my opinion, this regulation, this document, in a very sensible, good, coherent way, seeks to find solutions that take into account the specificities of countries such as Finland, Sweden or the United Kingdom, but also takes into account the arguments that I have said in my speech with regard to the countries of eastern Europe, so I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the ECR Group will support this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, truck road transport is certainly very important for the economy of individual Member States, and it is therefore important that barriers are removed so that there are no very different rules in different countries.  I understand this directive, which determines the weight of lorries, their length, but I do not understand why the European Union directive should address such details as the shape of the cab and the size of the glass. I think that even without the Directives of the European Union, this would be possible. If we want to facilitate the movement of vehicles, let us not deal with such details here. On the other hand, things are happening, such as the German Government ing its own rules on drivers from different EU countries, such as the German minimum wage, which actually hinders the movement of lorries much more. So let's solve what's really important. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – First of all, I agree with the report, it is good that a negotiation has been reached and I congratulate the rapporteur. I want to ask you, however, because it was not clear to me: do you disagree with the proposal made and negotiated by the rapporteur? Is it not necessary to have an amendment to the directive? Because, on the one hand, you said that you agreed, on the other hand, you said that certain things are not necessary. As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I believe that we must ensure that these details exist for the protection of people.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - I'll wait for the rest of the debate.  I understand that extending the length by 15 cm can mean expanding the possibilities for truck transport, increasing the efficiency of operation, on the other hand, if such details as various automatic systems, weighing and cab size are addressed, it can complicate the situation for many companies.  I am not sure now how I will vote in favour of this directive.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: - Respect, Commissioner. First of all, I would also like to thank the reporter for his work and to gather my insights into three points on the report 'The size and weight of vehicles in the community': The first and perhaps most important aspect that we had to take into account when drawing up the draft legislation is safety. I believe that we have managed to reach unity on this issue and to move this issue in the right direction. It is hoped that the expected positive effects will be released after the application has started.  Secondly, I would like to point out that we have succeeded in promoting intermodality and giving us the opportunity to combine different types of freight transport, taking into account environmental conditions, economy and environmental aspects.  Finally, however, I must add that it is a breath of fresh air for many of us that the legislation has been drafted in a way that has protected our road network from megakamions.  Make no mistake, I fully accept and consider it reasonable, for example, to use megakamions in scandinavian countries. After all, over the past years and decades, infrastructure has been fully conformed to this form of freight transport and has also made a significant contribution to reducing pollution and safety risks. At the same time, it would have been wrong to extend these vehicles in a uniform way, while ignoring the specificities of some Member States and the impact of megakamions. After all, we can unanimously conclude that this type of traffic is not for densely populated areas of Central and Eastern Europe, for incomplete motorway systems and, above all, for road networks with limited capacity. Thank you!

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, let me thank our rapporteur, Jörg Leichtfried, for the difficult work that has resulted in the compromise reached.  By approving this proposal, we will contribute to the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from transport, improving road safety and improving the working environment for drivers. It allows truck manufacturers to move forward with modernization. The aerodynamic characteristics of vehicles will be improved and we will create better conditions for combined transport. The improved cab shape will make drivers more comfortable and safer. Measures to control the weight of vehicles are very important, which is related to the effort to reduce exceeding the maximum permissible mass, which causes faster road wear and increases the risk of road accidents. I also welcome the fact that oversized vehicles will not normally be operated across Europe. I therefore agree with the rapporteur's proposal and thank everyone once again for the work done.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for EU regulations on the maximum weight and dimensions of heavy goods vehicles are designed to protect road infrastructure and contribute to increasing the level of safety of road users in the Member States. Of course, over time, the limits adopted need to be reviewed and (if necessary) adapted to the new conditions. One such conditions is the desire for such vehicles to reduce their carbon emissions. The main objective of the current amendment is therefore to increase the permissible weight and dimensions limits for heavy goods vehicles, but only to allow manufacturers to create eco-friendly structures and install emission control devices in them. Changes that go beyond this precisely defined objective, and in particular the possibility of cross-border traffic throughout the Union of so-called mega-heavyweights, would be a denial of the meaning of this directive and could therefore not be accepted by the European Parliament. Such vehicles have a negative impact, as has already been mentioned here, on the state of road infrastructure. I therefore believe that the changes made as a result of the compromise to the limit on the dimensions and weight of heavy goods vehicles are appropriate and will not have a negative impact on the basic objectives of this directive.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I have waited for years for the revision of the directive on the maximum permissible dimensions and weights for heavy goods vehicles and buses. That is why I welcome even the small steps that are now under way, especially as they all point in the right direction. The future permissible deviations from the current upper limits on vehicle dimensions are a contribution to making road transport safer, more environmentally friendly and more energy-efficient. They have not succeeded in making road freight transport more economical and future-proof. Of course, improving the aerodynamics of the vehicles in the front and rear areas without compromising the loading area capacity will increase efficiency. With a moderate extension of the semi-trailer combination by 1.3 meters, even better compatibility with 48-foot containers and rail traffic would be achievable. Changing the shape of the cab will reduce the blind spot in the driver's field of vision, taking into account in particular the concerns of vulnerable road users such as pedestrians and cyclists. However, in order to ensure genuine protection for these road users, I call for the introduction of driver assistance systems such as cameras or radar systems, which are mandatory by law. The most common violation of traffic regulations is the overloading of lorries. Overcharging has serious consequences, from damage to infrastructure to increased risk of accidents and distortion of competition between transport companies. I therefore welcome the fact that a review of the maximum permissible weight is now envisaged, either by means of a weighing device integrated into the road infrastructure or by means of on-board measuring instruments. Finally, despite my support for this good report, I would also like to express my disappointment at the fact that once again an important opportunity has been missed to finally ensure legal certainty regarding the cross-border use of long-distance trucks.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this has been an excellent debate, and the fact that there have been a number of blue cards shows that the issues are complicated and often politically difficult. But when we talk about evidence we should bear in mind that HGVs have a higher mortality rate per billion kilometres travelled than other vehicles and that most of those killed in HGV accidents are other road users, not drivers. Obviously not all freight can be carried by rail but, for me, safety must be absolutely critical. So I welcome the reviews that will come as a result of this measure. I would say that subsidiarity may have to take a back seat in the future for built-up areas, because unfortunately we cannot all follow what colleagues have highlighted in the Netherlands and the measures are not being taken in built-up areas that should be taken to protect other road users from HGVs. In London alone, four cyclists have been killed by lorries since the beginning of the year and this is something that is becoming a very major issue on our roads. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: question ("blue card"). I would like to ask Mrs Andersson a question. It's a massive criticism of what they call "megatrucks". Let me say once again: I am from Sweden. I've been working for 30 years in a truck cab as a truck driver. It is not the big trucks we have concerns about in terms of mortality – it is your small cars from Europe, as I would call them. Your 40-ton cars, two-axle European haulers that don't really work on our road team. As far as road damage is concerned, I would like to say: count now a little and understand what this is all about. A 60-tonne car with 26 tyres and seven axles has a ground pressure of 2,300 kilos. A 40-tonne car has 12 tyres, five axles and a ground pressure of 3,300 kilos, i.e. one tonne more in ground pressure per tyre. Which car do you think is doing the most damage to the infrastructure?

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Lundgren, thank you for that question. I was emphasising in my speech that I was talking about mainly policies on HGVs in general across the board, not just mega trucks. I do accept that there are difficult issues involved regarding the balance between environmentally-friendly trucks and moving freight, and all of the other issues that we have been discussing. So I take your point; I am just saying that we have not got the balance right in built—up urban areas and that is something that needs further action and, probably at this stage, Community—wide action.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would also like to thank the negotiators for agreeing and moving forward on this issue. Each Member State has its own tradition of what size of trucks there are in traffic, and as long as transport is within a Member State, it does not cause problems, but when we talk about international transport, we aim to form a European community, a common area where goods, services, people, capital can move across borders. And then it is also important that we have certain common provisions on the size of trucks that can operate across borders. From a Finnish perspective, it was important for us that it will continue to be possible to cross the border with these large trucks once both member states have approved these large trucks. It has already come to light many times here that we use a lot of these large trucks in traffic between Finland and Sweden, we have had good experiences of it, we have long distances in the north, and from the point of view of road safety, for example, we have not seen problems such as those referred to here by many members. These large trucks are completely safe and are also environmentally friendly, because otherwise we would have to take many more trucks into traffic. In other hand, it is really important that these large trucks continue to operate between these countries, where both countries have approved these trucks. It is important for business and the environment.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: Thank you very much. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. My S&D colleague Mr Leichtfried has done an excellent job. This is also a good example of the current debate and the unanimous support of the Committee on Transport. Environmental protection, safer transport, and I myself consulted with professional organizations at home. Their support is an important signal to us. I would like to draw attention to two things that we have only partially touched on in the Commission or in the current debate: One issue is the development of the road network. It has been said by my colleague Deli Andor that in many places in Central and Eastern Europe the road network – and I am not necessarily talking about motorways, but about secondary and third-order roads – is no longer prepared for the normal quality of transport in Western Europe.  The second aspect that I would like to indicate to The Commissioner is that if we establish new rules on the design of cabs or on other issues, let us tell the other colleagues in the Commission to prepare European industry for this. Because this is an opportunity for European industry to act within new industries, even creating jobs, along the lines of new standards. In this, I would ask for cooperation within the Commission. Thank you very much!

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: Mr. President, I want to thank Mr. Leichtfried and Mr. Ferber for running this business well and who have come to a certain agreement. On this directive we come to see what the heterogeousness of the European Union is, what the difference is between Finland and the far south, but it is for us to achieve uniform standards, the single market, and that is why I welcome this agreement that has been reached after many years. What makes me particularly happy, being a member of the Environmental Protection Committee, is that we will achieve significant savings and we will protect the environment. Knowing that 70% of road transport is in the European Union, then this is a big step forward. Of course, it is not easy to come to unity given the diversity of our economies and the different degree of our economy and the different infrastructure, but our goal is to achieve unity, achieve cross-borderness.  I am committed to new technologies, to innovation, and most of all to traffic safety. I am sorry that it will not take effect until 2020, but until then I believe that we will be able to achieve adaptation.  In any case, I would like to welcome Mrs Bulc and thank you for coming to the plenary session.  (The Speaker agrees to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Rules of Procedure))

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, You have just said that you are very much in favour of innovation in road transport, and that is what I am. We are talking about very long trucks. But I wanted to talk again about the extended saddle-trailer. Unfortunately, this is not included in our regulation now. It is a good one metre longer than 45-foot container, is used extensively in Germany and is compatible with the railway. It can travel by ship and also by flight. So it would really be a good option. Do you not agree that, in the revision that will come from Parliament, we should be very careful that anything innovative is possible if the Member States so wish?

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. Mrs. Meissner, I'm advocating for graduality. So, to gradually see what the infrastructure is like in which country and how it is possible. So member states should decide this, because I don't think all countries are equally infrastructure-ready - one is a rural area, the other is an urban area.  So, for graduality I stand for and believe that we will somewhat reach one unique and common European solution.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, gan dabht ar bith tá sábháilteacht ar na bóithre an-tábhachtach mar maraítear agus gortaítear an iomarca daoine gach uile bhliain. Ag an am céanna, tá a fhios againn go bhfuil an cúlú eacnamaíochta beagnach thart, buíochas le Dia, agus beidh níos mó taistil ar siúl ar na bóithre maidir le gluaisteáin agus go háirithe leoraithe ollmhóra ag tabhairt earraí trasna na mór-roinne. Dá bhrí sin tá sé tábhachtach go mbeadh teorainn againn ar mhéid, meáchan agus luas na dtrucailí móra seo. Is dóigh liom go bhfuil jab maith déanta ag an rapóirtéir agus a chomhghleacaithe mar tá difríochtaí móra idir na bóithre, mar shampla, i mo thír féin Oileán na hÉireann agus na bóithre sa mhór-roinn agus tá sé sin le feiceáil ins na rúin atá anseo. Dá bhrí sin is dóigh liom go bhfuil jab maith déanta acu agus molaim iad.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I believe that we need robust legislation on the size of trucks, responding to new technological developments. I believe that amending the legislation to accommodate exceptions on authorised dimensions and weights for lorries is welcome and is part of a wider debate in my view on the definition of the future European transport policy. The latest technological developments in truck design will allow us to have state-of-the-art vehicles with alternative, aerodynamically improved propulsion systems with low energy consumption and helping to improve road safety. The best developed infrastructure, together with the commercial motor vehicle sector, can play a very important role in accelerating intermodal transport and achieving the White Paper's objectives in terms of making the most efficient use of means of transport and reducing carbon emissions. The interminable interinstitutional discussions on this subject have caused the most important image or the general picture to be lost, namely that we need to review what has been achieved so far and set new and achievable targets in the field of transport.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the issue of international transport is crucial for economic development. At the same time, however, we all know that lorries are responsible for thousands of fatal accidents in the European Union. It is therefore necessary to design and build trucks to ensure safe driving and this can contribute to the rounder bodywork that increases the field of vision.  At the same time, the new standards for trucks contribute to strengthening the new concept of combined transport, enhancing competitiveness and environmental protection. However, Member States should step up checks to identify vehicles likely to exceed the relevant weight limits. Finally, the new standards on the dimensions and weights of lorries should not in future lead to the exclusion of small transport undertakings from road transport, under the pretext of extending these new specifications to all lorries in general.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, it has been really good for me, as someone who respects and enjoys national sovereignties and all the diverse, different countries that are represented here, to see people speaking often on behalf of their own countries and highlighting the differences between the different structures and frameworks in those countries. It brings home to someone like me, with my own view about national sovereignty, that really, surely, it is always better for the local authorities, free of guidelines from here, always to make the decisions about what is best for their infrastructure, best for their economy and best for their people.  It is so nice to see some people here delighted that they have negotiated a little bit of freedom – ‘Oh, we are not going to have this imposed, have we not done well?’ Well, the truth is – and this is something the British Conservatives need to understand – that if we were not here in the first place, we would not have to worry about that. But I wish you all in your own countries great success with this, and let us hope that all our economies boom.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I support the idea of such proposals being made in relation to various environmental initiatives and considerations, but they raise more questions than give answers than they give permissions. For example, I cannot support the proposals made to amend the maximum permissible dimensions and masses in international traffic. I believe that some of the proposals are premature and others are factually unfeasible.  First, the reduction of the lower overload limit, then stopped from moving the load vehicle, is unrealistically low. It is proposed to be 2%, which is impossible. On the other hand, the idea of reducing the distance for road transport in combined transport from 300 to 150 km in one direction is impractical because there are sections and cases where this is not possible. Separately, I would point out that I do not accept the fact that 'intermodal' and 'combined' transport are concepts that fully coincide. It is also appropriate to refine the term 'traffic stop', as it is clearly a temporary traffic stop rather than a permanent one. It is necessary to specify explicitly that this would lead to problems in transposing these rules in some Member States.  In conclusion, I believe that we should not deal with these details, but with the social dumping that non-EU countries are having on our sector.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this really lovely debate. It clearly shows that the proposal is important and that the compromise text strikes a good balance. This is why I would encourage you to adopt the report today. Citizens, road hauliers and European truck manufacturers are all waiting for it.  Let me also briefly refer to the longer trucks, or modular concepts as they are referred to in the Directive. The Commission is particularly satisfied that a compromise could be found on this political point. We all recognise that a particular type of service needs to be adjusted based on the available infrastructure and local characteristics.  The compromise maintains the status quo of the current directive, meaning that its Member States have competence to decide either to introduce longer trucks on a trial basis or not to do so. Member States can also decide which roads longer trucks are allowed to drive on, in order to minimise safety risks and impact on infrastructure. These are concrete examples of implementation of the subsidiarity principle.  So Member States already allowing longer trucks can continue to use them and those Member States which do not wish to have longer trucks can decide against them.  Let me be very clear on the clarification issue. At the request of the legislators, the Commission clarified during the interinstitutional negotiations its interpretation of this existing text through a statement. The statement says that longer vehicles may cross only one border between two countries, both of which allow longer trucks.  I am looking forward to your support and a positive outcome of the vote.

name: Jörg Leichtfried
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The difficulties we have had with this report have been enormous. I listened with great interest. If you only hear the different views of Mr van Dalen and Mr Taylor, for example, Mr van Dalen, who would like to flatroll Europe, pave asphalt and put monster trucks everywhere; on the other hand, Mr Taylor, who wants to see green meadows everywhere. It is, of course, difficult to reach a compromise. But I think we have succeeded. I ask both of them to forgive me for overdrawing, but I think it was better suited to represent it. A very interesting issue was the issue of subsidiarity, which was raised at the end by Mrs Arnautu, Mrs Seymour, Mr Lundgren and Mr Etheridge. Yes, subsidiarity is a good thing. But we live in an internal market. If each country in this internal market were to adopt different technical specifications for lorries, what would be the situation? A country .B allows these flaps, the next country in which this truck wants to continue does not allow them. Do you now have to reload the truck at the border? That's not how it works! There must be certain rules that apply to the whole of the internal market, particularly in the transport sector. Otherwise, this transport industry would not work. You have to see that. Of course, British trucks can also travel to Europe, to the continent and vice versa. This is possible because we have the same rules. It is good that we have the same rules here. My final point is that Mrs Arnautu of the National Front said that she was in favour of workers' rights and that we did not. Where has Mrs Arnautu been in recent years when we were working? Where was the National Front when we were working? Just chatting around and getting upset afterwards that something doesn't fit, that's not enough for me. If I want something, I also work with it! Mrs Arnautu is paid high enough to cooperate and not just to say something every two years, with the feeling that she has not even read the text. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your cooperation, thank you very much for your support. I am very curious about the outcome of the vote.

name: n/a
text: – The debate has been closed. The vote will take place today at 11.30. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Far too many lives have been lost on our roads due to unsafe lorry designs. Heavy goods vehicles (HGVs) are involved in nearly a quarter of all cycling fatalities in the UK but make up less than 5 % of road traffic. This cannot continue. Relaxing length restrictions for lorries in the EU will enable lorry manufacturers to design safer and more aerodynamic vehicles, including through rounded cab fronts, crumple zones and improved visibility. These are small changes but they will make an enormous difference to safety on our roads. The Commission has been tasked with coming up with details of the safer design requirements by the end of 2016. This could see the introduction of safer lorries by 2020 if the legislation is fast-tracked through the EU decision-making process. The pressure now has to be kept up to ensure that these safer designs are proposed and implemented as soon as possible.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The revision of the "weight and dimensions" directive for HGVs dating back to 1996 was more than necessary. Although this new text does not put an end to mega-trucks, those giga-liners that pose risks to road safety, road maintenance and the environment, it is necessary to support this revision which brings several major positive points such as the reaffirmation of the ban for trucks over 40 tons to pass from one country to another, as well as the generalization of the system of control boxes allowing better monitoring of heavy weights.  Another key point of the review is the strengthening of the safety and well-being of road workers through a change in cabin design.  Finally, improving truck aerodynamics and developing low-carbon engines are equally critical issues in a goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. But the battle must continue and this revision must only be one step towards the end of mega-trucks on our European roads.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. I would like to give my full support to this text, which was the subject of difficult negotiations during the last mandate, and which results in a balanced agreement. The aim of this text is to encourage investment in more secure and less CO2-consuming lorries. I can only support those provisions.  It also aims to ensure better control of the weight of these vehicles; we know the many frauds as to the maximum volume that a LGV can drive on our roads, and it is imperative that European rules are respected.  I am particularly pleased that there is no longer any question of opening up to free movement on European roads the movement of 'mega-camions', these giant lorries which are currently only the subject of local use in certain countries of the Union, and which in my opinion have no place in a Europe geared towards the sustainable economy, and therefore logically towards the mode of postponement.  Since the european Commission's initial proposals on this subject have been withdrawn, I will vote in favour of this text.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I support the draft directive because I believe that its application will improve road safety and reduce environmental pollution. The Directive will allow for better profiling of drivers' cabs, which will increase their field of vision and facilitate the visibility of other road users. The new shape of the driver's cabs also reduces impact energy in the event of a collision. Solutions that reduce fuel consumption and emissions are also worth supporting. I am in favour of giving the Member States 2 years to implement the directive after the entry into force of the directive. Similarly, I support the idea that, after 3 years of applying these solutions, their effectiveness should be assessed.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on the supplementary report by Alain Lamassoure, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European Long-Term Investment Funds (COM(2013)0462 - C7-0209/2013 - 2013/0214(COD)) (A8-0021/2015).

name: Alain Lamassoure
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, the creation of the European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) is the first concrete step in redirecting financial resources towards the real economy and, in particular, towards long-term investment.  In recent weeks, we have seen that all the engines of growth are returning to Europe. We are benefiting from the collapse in the price of a barrel, a significant fall in the euro, the particularly accommodative policy recently launched by the European Central Bank and, finally, the launch of the Juncker plan.  We must consolidate these fundamental elements of growth: by first retaining the global liquidity that is now returning to Europe spontaneously. Naturally, by strengthening financial stability across all dimensions of the banking union and by clearing the obstacles to investment that remain between the Member States, together with our partners. That is the whole point of the banking union and the union of capital markets. ELTIF is a much-anticipated first investment for this purpose. We started from a worrying observation with the Commission. Large amounts of money are available around the world, but very few are moving towards long-term financing and very few are moving to Europe for these financings. Governments themselves are constrained by significant debt and fiscal reforms to be implemented. Large companies adopt conservative investment strategies or, in turn, they invest outside Europe and the banks - weakened ones - still too often depend on state aid. Moreover, insurance companies and pension funds wishing to invest in long-term assets do not always have the resources to independently mobilise sufficient funds, and there is no European pooling mechanism, such as investment funds, that would facilitate this type of action.  So we had to respond to a market need. The creation of the new investment vehicle aims to encourage them to invest in assets such as unlisted companies looking for long-term capital, some listed SMEs, as well as the European venture capital funds and European social entrepreneurship funds that we created some time ago. These categories of funds require investors to agree to lock in their investments for a period of time in exchange for a bonus, unlike other funds that allow investors to recoup their investment at any time but for less pay. To be LABELLED ELTIF, funds will need to invest at least 70% of their capital in certain types of assets, be marketed only by managers - the Alternative Investment Fund Managers Directive sets out strict rules and stringent requirements for fund managers - and finally be managed for a fixed period during which investors are not allowed to recoup their investment , except in certain circumstances to be clearly specified from the outset. We have tried to create as flexible a status as possible to appeal to sovereign wealth funds, hedge funds, pension funds, but also wealthy individuals. ELTTTs mainly target professional investors such as local or corporate pension funds, municipalities, insurance companies. They will also be available to some retail investors. This is how we propose to consolidate the investment toolkit in Europe, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. Its entry into force will coincide with the effective start of the Juncker Plan and will have the same objective: to boost growth and competitiveness throughout the Union.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission very much welcomes the constructive approach to this important file both under the current rapporteur Mr Lamassoure and under Mrs Kratsa—Tsaragopoulou in the previous Parliament. In particular, we are very thankful for Parliament’s willingness to compromise on issues such as the European investment quota to ensure that the European Long-term Investment Funds are in place and in a form that is both attractive for potential managers and investors. The European Long—term Investment Funds will invest in a wide range of underlying assets – infrastructure, real assets and other long-term projects, unlisted companies, listed small and medium—sized enterprises capitalised up to EUR 500 million and intellectual property. It is a unique opportunity for asset managers to give investors access to a far wider range of assets than has hitherto been available, in a robustly regulated legal framework. As such, it is a key component in our work on the financial markets union to increase the amounts of market financing going into the real economy.  This regulation is one of the first concrete expressions of our work with capital markets. At the moment, private investors interested in committing money for the long term face a set of fragmented national markets which can make it hard for them to invest in one single Member State or across borders within the Union. This in turn restricts the amount of private investment for jobs and growth. The European Long-term Investment Funds are designed to solve this problem, creating a uniform set of rules that allows all types of investors to invest in SMEs, long-term projects and companies. This makes it a first mover in a true capital markets union as it creates a robust and reliable framework for investors who want to make long—term commitments of capital.  Members probably know even better than me that there is a pressing need to do exactly that. As Mr Lamassoure has just pointed out, the winds are a little milder these days with the euro going down and with energy pricing being more favourable to growth but, at the same time, we need investment. The estimated investment is about EUR 1 500 billion to EUR 2 000 billion by the year 2020 to finance infrastructure projects which are so keenly needed. The European Long-term Investments Funds have a role to play here and in other parts of the economy where long-term committed capital is needed. Our commitment to market-based financing, channelled through these funds, does not exclude the role that banks can play in long-term financing. Banks continue to play a very important role in financing long-term businesses and projects in many Member States. The European Long-term Investment Funds are therefore complementary to this activity. Parliament and the Council have always agreed that SMEs are crucially important to the European economy and so their inclusion as an asset within this is key. I would like to pay tribute to Parliament’s farsightedness in including intellectual, as well as physical, property within these Funds. Research and development play a vital role in our economies and they are as much in need of financing as physical infrastructures for example. Ensuring that all types of investors – retail investors as well as major institutions such as insurance companies and pension funds – can access our European Long-term Investment Funds has always been a key element of the Commission proposal. Parliament’s support for retail access has proven vital in ensuring that this remains the case in the final result. I also commend the House’s willingness to accept the extra safeguards proposed, such as only allowing investors with less than EUR 500 million in assets to invest and not to put more than 10% of their savings into these funds.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
