text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, for years both private and public investment has been in decline in Europe, and today linking finance and the need for growth is crucial.  That is why, in this House, we are sparing no effort to move the Juncker plan as quickly as possible from idea to reality; that is why Alain and colleagues are working with a sense of urgency towards creating the European Long—term Investment Funds; that is why we must also ensure that the capital markets union will develop into a synergy that harnesses financial markets and services to produce growth through long—term investment.  Of course, to get money where growth is, it is important to have the right framework in place. For years we have been building on financial stability; now we need to ensure that growth is possible under financial stability. But it is rather unlikely that crowding—in private investment can happen overnight. Creating an investment climate is essential and in order to create an investment climate, remaining regulatory barriers – including those that might have been generated by recent additions to the financial regulatory framework like Solvency II – as well as imperfections in capital markets, will have to be eliminated promptly.  The message seems to me to be clear: delivering long—term finance will require a well—orchestrated effort from all the important players on the regulatory side, on the supply side, on the intermediation side and on the users’ side.

name: Jeppe Kofod
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, as the S&D shadow on this report, my main objective was to ensure that we created a type of fund that would benefit the real economy and I think we actually achieved that. The long economic crisis and huge investment gap in Europe shows that there is a great need for investment to ensure growth, employment and an improved economy. For that reason, Mr Juncker presented an investment plan, and the European Long-term Investment Fund (ELTIF) was part of that much—needed plan to get Europe back on track.  What these funds can do is function as an investment vehicle that can contribute to the financing of the real economy in the EU. This is useful, for example, for insurance companies and pension funds which need a pooling mechanism to facilitate the financing of long—term investments. The ELTIF will give them that. The aim is that the ELTIF will contribute to financing smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in Europe. That is essential because we need a Europe that is economically stable to once again experience investment and growth. My hope is that the ELTIF will be used by many to help facilitate investment but, most of all, my hope is that the ELTIF will be much used for green and sustainable investment that will not only contribute to growth but also have a positive impact socially, environmentally and economically for Europe as a whole. We need a Europe that takes the lead on investment in the green and sustainable economy to ensure that we move forward. We need green growth to ensure that we do not just pass the environmental bill to the next generation. We need investment that will benefit every Europe citizen for years to come. So I will encourage all – both professional investors and retail investors – to use this important new instrument.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I believe that the European Commission rightly wants to encourage investors to invest capital in the long term. I am pleased that the capital would be invested throughout the Union and be available to investors wherever they live. The funds would ultimately stimulate growth through the creation of infrastructure, technical facilities and results in the field of education and research.  Through European long-term investment funds, pension funds, insurance companies, professional and even retail investors would have the opportunity to invest capital in their country, throughout the European Union and beyond. I am pleased that the text gives investors a margin of flexibility, which is very important at a time when investment in Europe is so low.

name: Philippe De Backer
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Lamassoure and colleagues and also the Council and the Commission for bringing this file to a good end.  I think in the end we have reached a compromise which is workable in the market; that is important. The capital markets union – which we are talking about today and also will be in the coming weeks – is all about creating diversity both for investors and companies which are in need of finance. I think that today we have given them a piece of the puzzle where we say: look for investors, especially institutional investors, and we can create a fund; we have a label here which allows you to invest in the long term, not only in infrastructure projects, but also in non—listed companies and in SMEs which also need a stable shareholding base. I think it is important that with this label we give investors the diversity that they need.  This is also a new tool for companies to raise money and to look for new investments in their companies which are looking for a stable shareholding base. It is important also for the small— to mid—cap companies to allow this.  Of course, the work is not finished. The proof of the pudding is in the eating, and pension funds, insurance companies and banks, even some high—net—worth retail investors, will have to come in to provide the necessary finance. We will have to continue to reform our economies to make them more competitive and to make sure that there are projects available for these funds to invest in. It is also important that we continue on this road to make sure that the whole capital markets union gets a more solid base. This can only work in a well—functioning capital market where there is a level playing field on tax, insolvency law and other things. I think Commissioner Hill has put forward a proposal and will work in the coming weeks and months to make this happen.  I hope that what we have created here, this European long—term investment fund, this label, will attract the necessary people to look at the longer term and bring about more financing options and more diversity in our economy because I think that is what we need: more investment, more growth and, ultimately, more jobs for improving the well—being of the people in Europe.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the investment plan presented by the Commission aims to operate the miracle of the multiplication of breads and fish, seeking to leverage only 21 billion public money up to a total of 315 billion private investment. Among its flagship products are European long-term investment funds that will be able to market both institutions and individuals. However, the Regulation before us does not lay down appropriate guarantees, guarantees protecting the purpose of the saver's contribution. There are too many open doors for the participation and management of vulture funds and venture capital. We cannot jeopardize people's savings and put them at the service of a failed macroeconomic policy. In my country we have fun examples, such as the "preferred", where small savers invested in products that were presented as promising but whose opacity and risk have ended up ruining tens of thousands of people.  Ladies and gentlemen, on the one hand, the ambition of this false European New Deal known as the Juncker Plan is frankly derisory to revive an absolutely anemic Community economy by neoliberal policies. But also, trusting that products like FILPEs can rent in just three years is not credible. Let us not feed casino capitalism again from institutions, let us not fan again a new bubble of financial speculation by playing with people's savings, let us not hypothesite the future of our citizens.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is a rich continent, not only in its history and diversity but financially rich. And yet Europe is failing to invest, to project itself into the future. But God knows whether our continent needs to invest, that is, to devote human, material and financial resources in a way that is both sustained and patient.  Investing in the energy transition - we talk a lot about it these days with the energy union - investing in education, research, innovation in the conditions of European competitiveness, investing in the restoration of our natural resources, restoring our social cohesion, is a matter of survival for our European Union.  Yet these investments do not materialize. What for? Because for the past twenty years, the dogma that reigns supreme has been that of dictatorship and the maximization of short-term profit. Twenty years of financial deregulation, of financialization of everything and everything in the logic of profit, of maximizing it, of immediate return for the investor. How dare we call investors banks, investment funds, insurance companies, individuals who "invest" in companies for a microsecond? How can you still talk about investors when the most conservative insurers tell you that they do not want to hold a stock or bond for more than five years? So that's the question we have to answer.  What can I do? This text, Mr Lamassoure, is a step in the right direction but a step of total modesty. It is an attempt to attract investors to investment funds whose purpose will be to work in the long term. But I am surprised, in any case, that the Council has refused - and Mrs Vestager has pointed out - the quota for European investment. We were very modest, we said that, in order to receive the label of European long-term investment funds, 60% of the investments of these investor funds had to be invested in Europe. The Commission considered that this was an impossible red line to cross. What does the Council want? Does it want to encourage investors or encourage investment in Europe? By refusing the quota, I think the Council has shown which side it is on.  We will nevertheless vote for this text, but we believe that if we really want to revive long-term investment in Europe, other measures are needed.  First, retail banks should be separated from reputable investment banks. When you force the banks that collect the savings to do only one thing, which is to lend the money to the real economy, and you close the casino to them, the entirety of the European savings will ipso facto go to the real economy.  Second, we must have the courage to tackle a series of financial products, the sole purpose of which is to squeeze the lemon of the planet and the lemon of our societies to extract maximum profit in the short term.  Finally, a genuine European investment plan must also be put in place. In this regard, I would like to bring two figures closer: 13 billion is the public money that the Juncker plan promises to mobilise, it is one hundredth of tax evasion and evasion in Europe. If we were serious about the fight against tax evasion and evasion, EUR 1 trillion would join the public coffers.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting. You always do, and with good grace, so I thank you for that. Your speech is very much about state capital and public investment. I wonder whether you would agree – I know you have some critique of private profits and the drive for it – that, without private wealth creation and private profit, the very funds that you are looking for to invest outwards from the state surely would not exist.  Would you not agree with me that perhaps we need to encourage private wealth creation as well, maybe with lower taxes in some areas?

name: Philippe Lamberts (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – It is becoming a habit for us to dialogue in this room.  Yes, I agree. I do not believe that 100% of the economy should be driven by public investment. Public investment is needed, and that was the last of my three points.  The first point was about the separation of banks, and why is that? Well, because we want private savings. Here I am speaking about private savings; we want them to be funnelled to the real economy.  We need private investment. But what I have witnessed in my 22 years’ career in the private sector is that the time horizon of private investors has become ever shorter, not even for a quarter, but for a month or a week or a microsecond. I do not call that investment.  So yes, I want private money to be invested, and private profits are legitimate as long as they result from value creation for society.

name: Steven Woolfe
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there is an English poet, by the name of Joseph Addison, who once said ‘The fear of Death often proves Mortal, and sets People on Methods to save their Lives, which infallibly destroy them’. Well, fear stalks this Chamber – fear that Greece may leave and bring the euro down, and fear that low growth across the economy may make people see that the European Union is a failure after all and that it is a bad idea whose time has passed.  So this fear has set the EU on a system of creating something that I believe will eventually help to destroy it, namely the Long-term Investment Fund strategy. There is – seemingly – a belief in this Chamber that central bankers can steer economics – and do so as well – hence the reason that the ECB is allowing quantitative easing, which will eventually make people poorer and also ensure that you pay more in the future for what you are paying now. When we look at our phones, most of us will not say that governments should design or make phones. Our computers should not be designed by our own governments or parliamentarians, but here in this Chamber there seems to be an idea that parliamentarians and Commissioners can create pension funds and be private equity investors. That is what this particular product is all about. Let me tell you all that there are many talented people in the investment world who have failed, and you will fail once more yourselves.

name: Steeve Briois (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, European long-term investment funds have common sense provisions. They are intended to support SME/SMEs in projects that structure our territories. However, the relevance of the European level for the implementation of these funds is not demonstrated. Indeed, it will depend on the degree of integration of the banking union and the convergence of common rules on regulation. Moreover, the supplementary report states: "ELTTTs are a first step towards the creation of an integrated internal market for raising capital that can be channelled towards long-term investments in the European economy." However, on what basis will we converge at European level?  As you know, our financial market regulatory models and tax and social legislation are very divergent across the many states. Finally, by placing this fund under the control of the European Securities and Markets Authority and the Commission, you are giving an umpteenth snub to the sovereignty of the States, which will have no say in the management of these funds, which are so strategic for them.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I believe that one of our tasks is to make our European financial sector better, less fragmented, more robust and also more European, not because I believe in Europe but because we should make sure that the money will reach the investments that are needed for our future. From this point of view, I believe that the European Long—term Investment Fund (ELTIF) is a good initiative. Together with other pieces like the Juncker plan, this can gradually change the picture and help to improve our long—term economic growth. But let me state here that financial regulation is not by far the only obstacle to supporting the long—term investments vital for our future. First of all, there is significant uncertainty concerning the reforms in some states – the reforms that are needed to get the countries on a sustainable path. As the countries have not reached a sustainable path, there is significant uncertainty about the future of economic actions which is undermining the investment. Secondly, instability of regulation and insufficient stability of the legal system is another obstacle which goes against people’s willingness to make a long—term investment. Last, but not least, the unfinished single market is also an important component, because a functioning single market is vital for a larger multinational project. Let me say here that I guess we have passed the first test. We are improving regulation of the financial system but, without dealing with other obstacles, we are still a long way from the end. I hope we will tackle the other issues as effectively as Mr Lamassoure did with this project.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are dealing here with a report which, in essence, should have come much earlier, when in 2007 the crisis erupted at European level and everyone was aware that this was a crisis of speculation and a diversion of long-term financing from the real economy.  Since then, we have taken a long time to stabilise financial markets and to save the banks, but at the end of the day very little is being done to ensure the essentials, namely the long-term financing of the economy so that the European Union can face its challenges: climate change, the demographic challenge and what else do I know. So this is good news and, perhaps tomorrow, the European long-term investment funds, the ELTIF, will become this new label, much like the UCITS have been a demonstration that Europe knew how to invent financial markets or financial products useful for financing the economy. This will be true if these funds allow investments outside of speculation, outside of tax havens and in particular in compliance with OECD conventions. This will be true if it does, indeed, help to create jobs here in Europe through these strategic investments or allows individuals to contribute to these funds as well.  We must also learn from the lessons: the trilogue on this issue was concluded on the day of the launch of the Juncker Plan. There's a signal. We need to encourage these long-term investments over and over again, and I would like this to serve as a common thread when we look at Commissioner Hill's plan for a European capital market, which must not be just about resuming securitisation but about financing the real economy.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which Long-term capital is lacking in Europe, says Commission President Juncker. He talks about an investment gap, and this new European long-term investment fund, ELTIF, is now to plug this. Let us look back: as long as the euro seemed to be doing well, investment was also made. Today we know that this was a huge straw fire. The foreseeable crisis of the euro and the breach of the law to save it have created enormous political uncertainty, including for investors. Companies are at the mercy of policy decisions and, in these conditions and in this political climate, are no longer interested in investing in the long term. The ELTIF will not fill the investment gap. It does not eliminate the uncertainty, the real reason for the investment gap. The euro is not working, and the attempts to save it are only making things worse. We do not need new funds, we must finally take note of the reality that the euro is stifling Europe. When we finally take note of this, we can look forward again and shape the future.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, no doubt, if ten years ago we had this report, we could have discussed long-term investments in the social field and their viability, we would have had a challenge. However, this report is still welcome today, on one condition, namely to be implemented very quickly by the Commission, which still has, on the basis of the Regulation, a number of acts to be carried out and by the supervisory authority ESMA, which will have to be very careful about how this project is carried out. Of course, the European Investment Bank will use the resources it has. Other resources are also needed, in my opinion, for the fund to become effective and viable in economic reality, especially in small communities, where I see a great potential for support for growth, development and jobs. However, the regulation provides for the possibility that some investors may receive royalties earlier when they agree to block their capital in the long term. We understand this need for stimulus, but we must make sure that it does not transform for the basic purpose of these funds and does not create a system in which investors choose only quick royalties, then find ways to withdraw their private capital, because otherwise it would mean blocking the efficiency of this fund.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are discussing a key issue here today, which is that of European investment in the long term. It is an essential issue, but we do not touch on that issue, because we continue to bet on the dogmatic model, which was the one that brought us to the situation we are in.  There are two fundamental dogmas in this proposal. The first dogma is that the Capital Markets Union has to play a bigger role in channeling funding into the real economy. And I ask: do we really need to multiply and extend the casino model, which was ultimately the one that led us to adjustment programmes during the crisis years? Do we really need to multiply this model, or do we need to work on this model and reverse it completely?  The second dogma is what says that we need to create new investment vehicles, which says that if there are no new investment vehicles, there is no way to finance small and medium-sized enterprises and other organizations. They even say that without a capital market there is no alternative financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. And I ask you, isn't there? So what is made of the traditional relationship between banks and economics? What is made of public investment? Why do we only multiply the instruments that aggravate the systemic risk of the European economy?  And yet, the fundamental prolema is not worked. And they can continue to try to inject trillions of euros into the European economy, and until the fundamental problem of demand is solved, nothing is solved. That is the fundamental problem: look. What we need is to increase aggregate demand. Ending austerity, that is the fundamental problem.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this was supposed to be an opportunity to give a strong and decisive signal to the real economy, but it will prove to be another failure. Long-term investment funds will benefit speculators, multinationals and major infrastructures and will once again forget about savers and SMEs, the real ones, those who do not have the opportunity to raise finance on the capital markets. SMEs represent the beating heart and identity of Europe, the very Europe that is slowly abandoning them. All the proposals launched by the EU in recent years do not relaunch traditional credit, do not put the credit system before its social role but, on the contrary, leverage the capital market, where speculation reigns supreme and the dangers to savers are very high. The continuing carelessness of the productive fabric that has driven European countries for years is part of a clear path, decided by brussels bureaucrats. We are running, to my great regret, towards a precise globalised American model, in which the real economy is in danger of succumbing to small businesses abandoned to their fate.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, I think that the initiative we are discussing is very positive and complements a development puzzle, which is of course of great importance to the European Union. Slowly things are getting better, we are solving specific problems, such as financing long-term investments, and I think that over time the picture changes and the outlook improves.  For example, we have the stabilisation of the banking system and its consolidation, we have a significant reduction in borrowing costs - both for businesses and for the public sector - particularly in the so-called 'region countries', although I do not quite accept this wording, but in any case the fall in borrowing costs, for example in Ireland and Portugal, makes debt more manageable and frees up resources for development and social reasons. We are also retreating the euro to realistic levels and we have very positive investment initiatives, such as the Juncker plan and the initiative of Mr Lamassoure and those who worked with him.  So the picture changes and I see a kind of embarrassment, both on the part of the left, which tends to predict the disaster that is not coming, and on the part, I would say, of the far right, the Eurosceptics or the anti-Europeans, who fail to realize that over time we are doing better and not worse. It is no coincidence, I think, that forecasts for the European economy are changing for the better, that is to say from all international organisations, and there are Member States which can show their own 'success stories' from Poland to Ireland, which of course are not free from economic and social problems.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioners, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Lamassoure on his work on this report, which I believe opens the door to a new avenue of funding to recover the effective demand we so desperately need in this Europe. And this new stage in which Europe is emphasizing growth and investment must also not make us forget the last years of adjustments, cuts and an absolutely narrow view of economic policy which, as Mrs Beres has pointed out, has prevented Europe from regaining growth, investment and job creation. In any case, we welcome European long-term investment funds. We welcome this project, which has to go hand in hand with the European Fund for Strategic Investments, known as the Juncker Plan, so that we can get growth and investment first from Europe, and channel the large amount of savings, the large amount of liquidity that the ECB is putting on the market, to put it to work in the real economy. And let us go hand in hand with the Commission's project also to boost the union of the capital market, so that among all these elements we are able to boost growth in Europe, let us be able to put investment, demand and job creation first, and forget about the last legislature, of that legislature in which the conservative and neoliberal majority in this House was brutal , and put growth and job creation on its feet.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – The proposed report raises many questions. Long-term investment is an important tool for guiding the European economy towards sustainable and inclusive growth, which should be in line with the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 plan.  European long-term investment funds should provide funding for various infrastructure projects, for non-listed companies or for listed small and medium-sized enterprises for an extended period of time through equity or debt instruments. By financing these projects, long-term investment funds should contribute to the financing of the Union economy as well as in the implementation of its policies. However, European long-term investment funds will also invest in illiquid assets that are difficult to buy and sell. Furthermore, businesses need certainty that they will be able to have the funds invested in them for the entire duration they have requested to investors and investors themselves will not be able to withdraw their funds before the specified end date of the investment. Rather, attention should be paid to short-term funding opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, I think the key word for our exit from the crisis is synergy. Only by synergy of all mechanisms can we pull Europe out of this state. Many Member States are already in crisis, but there are also those that are still failing to emerge from the crisis. The synergy between public and private, but also the synergy of the Juncker Plan, cohesion policy, private capital, the long-term fund that I propose here and discuss - these are all elements of possible synergy. And we really have enough resources at our disposal, but we have to focus them really smartly.  That is why I am one of those who want to express their support in the belief that first of all these funds in the long-term fund will be completely open and easily accessible for medium and small businesses, because we must include them in this long-term fund as well.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we have a serious problem in the European Union that stems from the expectations of economic operators, who do not see prospects for growth at European Union level. We can talk about innovation, smart growth, we can use the rhetoric we want, we may even think that economic agents are blind, but it is enough to look at the world to understand that neoliberal policies based on free trade and non-intervention of states in the economy to understand the reluctance of agents to invest.  If the market does not work, if the agents do not invest, then we should not expect them to be market instruments that solve the problem. Look at the results of the banks' long-term refinancing operations carried out by the European Central Bank. As history teaches us, a recessive cycle will only be broken with new policies based on an ambitious public investment programme that will once again give states their central role in building development strategies.

name: Bernard Monot (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the capital market crash of 2008 was at the root of the crisis which is now weighing heavily on our economies, even though Mr Kyrtsos of the EPP thinks that everything is fine.  Since then, the fragile private banking system has hardly financed the traditional economy, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. After toxic products, it is therefore necessary to converge financial savings towards this traditional economy with a stable investment horizon and disconnected from speculation in world markets. Therefore, the creation of these ELTTTs to drain long-term savings towards SMEs must be welcomed. Nevertheless, the investment rules for these products would have benefited from being stricter and more controlled. For example, we believe that the 70% share of investment in long-term projects seems to us to be very insufficient. Where will the remaining 30% of these funds go to finance the economy? The other handicap is the contractual ability to exit the fund before the end of economic projects, which can distort these long-term investment funds. Most importantly, there are no rules against the creeping takeovers of rapacious investors. Indeed, ELTIF will allow an investor to enter the capital of an SME, even listed, without going through threshold declarations.  We will therefore remain very attentive to the details that will be made at level two and in the meantime, we will abstain.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I want to begin by welcoming Commissioner Vestager to the European Parliament, and I also want to congratulate Alain Lamassoure for his work on this proposal.  I think, together with the Juncker investment plan and the new funds for strategic investment, we are beginning to see Europe emerge from this appalling crisis – a crisis where effectively 20% of investment has been taken out of the EU—wide economy since the fall of Lehman Brothers in 2008. What we now need to do – and it is the key issue for me – is to provide certainty. There is a wall of funds within the pensions industry, within the insurance industry, that will invest in a long—term investment project. But they are looking for two things: they are looking for certainty, firstly that they will get their money back, and secondly they are looking for certainty in terms of the projects that they need to invest in. What Europe needs right now is that period of absolute certainty. The Commission itself has said that between now and 2020 we will need to boost investment somewhere between EUR 1 trillion and EUR 2 trillion. We need this instrument in place to give certainty to the markets to make sure that they can invest on a long—term basis in all of the things that we need to do. Finally, I will make this one point. As public budgets improve, as the situation develops, we will see further capital projects. We need to move quickly to the capital markets because that is the best way to give us the stability we need to see.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Hayes, I would like to thank Mr Hayes for his work, We currently have a great many projects with the banks from companies that cannot be realised because they are not feasible due to a lack of risk capital. Do you see here any possibility that projects that pay off, that have a return on investment, that provide employment but cannot be finalised due to lack of own and venture capital, could also be taken into account here in the corresponding Juncker plan?

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I absolutely agree that they could benefit from Juncker’s plan and, if there is one thing we need to learn from the United States of America in terms of venture capital, it is that they use venture capital in a much more strategic way than we do in Europe. Why is it the case that successful businesses in Europe are frequently bought by US venture capitalists and transformed into multiglobal businesses, and we lose out in Europe? So I do see venture capital funding as an absolutely crucial way that we can provoke the European-wide economy. I very much agree with you.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Long-term Investment Funds (ELTIFs) will be vital in channelling savings towards long—term investment projects. In particular, infrastructure and the link with investments under Horizon 2020 are a really positive step. For me, it is important that funds should be targeted towards projects to create jobs and growth, the real economy. Therefore, it is a pity that the Council did not support Parliament’s request for 60% of investments to go to European projects and there are not greater measures to protect the retail investors willing to invest in ELTIFs for a longer term. ELTIFs are also an important element mentioned in the Commission’s Green Paper on CMU, and we urgently need to develop and boost the right tools to stimulate financing of the European economy. One of the priorities of CMU in this respect is the revitalisation of the securitisation market. However, it must be clear that there should be full standardisation, transparency, adequate capital requirements and clear information to investors on the credit risk. I would like to congratulate Alain Lamassoure and the Italian Presidency. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European Union continues to insist on promoting the liberalisation of capital markets, when we are still suffering from the outbreak of the financial crisis. And it does so through a new type of European investment funds, a tool to allow large groups of anonymous investors to position themselves in the succulent investment market and public provision — the only one that can guarantee the long-term contracts that this initiative wants to feed on.  The tangle of national and international regulators becomes more complex, with a very high discretion in the use of funds; we even question the opportunity of the fund itself when the state or industrial banking could regularly finance such initiatives with greater control. Again, financial liberalization is moving hand in hand with a privatization agenda. But we do not want roads, hospitals, prisons or universities in the hands of renters outside the public interest, because our Europe is not that of finance, but that of workers.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As a member of the Committee on Budgets, it is, of course, my concern to show a willingness to negotiate in the area of commitments, commitments, but not in the area of payments. I believe that, of course, with front loading, we can make a difference and make the sum available accordingly. But it must be clear at the latest during the midterm review where fresh money comes from in order to be able to implement these plans accordingly. My proposal is that the Member States should, for example.B cross-border licensing. These licences, e.B. for mobile frequencies, could be put out to tender in all 28 Member States in one day. The sum raised here will be made available to the Member States to pay into the European Investment Bank, the European Investment Fund, as equity, as an increase in resources, so that it remains the property of the Member States. You can promote your own projects with European added value, or you can use the payments of the European Union. It would also be possible to generate returns from these investments for the use of the respective infrastructure, and thus to increase the European Union's own resources in the future and to achieve better solvency.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Lamassoure, your report deserves your support. I will certainly express this support.  Another point – we have heard about all sorts of obstacles here, that we cannot accept this because we either have an unfinished market, one way or another, or we have different fiscal or financial systems between Member States. I suggest that we do not focus on what makes us different. Let's try to focus on what we can do together. So we have to change these systems. We need to introduce more Community methods, i.e. I propose an approach: 'changing by doing investments, not complaining about not doing investments'. This would be the first such fundamental change. Our political group is in favour of investment in the real world, not speculative, and, as Mr Rübig has just said, I am in favour of us considering investment in infrastructure, including transport infrastructure. We have described the needs by 2030 – 400, maybe EUR 500 billion. We have a budget of EUR 36 billion by 2020. If we could cover this difference in any way from these funds using the project bonds method, I think it would be absolutely beneficial – and I am requesting it.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Lamassoure for a good report. Long-term European investment funds can play an important role in financing infrastructure, growth and also in accessing finance for SMEs.  Personally, however, I believe that such investment funds are, in any case, a complementary form, as if a form of loans, compared to bank financing, which is, however, the main way in which companies still receive funding. That is why it is also important for us in the European Parliament to assess the level of banking regulation. In recent years, banks have been subject to a great deal of new obligations on this subject, but we must ensure that the banking sector in Europe is able to function in a healthy way.  At present, access to finance for SMEs is also at a reasonable level. More than 70% of euro area loan applications are accepted. Interest rates are 2.78% on average, which means that the banking sector does work in that sense, but more attention must now be paid to ensuring that Europe is an interesting investment destination in the European Parliament as well. And that is what we can do first and foremost through better regulation – by making Europe a destination where businesses and innovative people want to come and invest here in the future.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: "Thank you very much, Mr. President, for the floor. I am not one of the Eurosceptics who want to tear apart, to tear apart our common Europe. I am sitting here among the Social Democrats, who believe in the unity of Europe, but we do not want to bury our heads in the sand because we see the problems. We therefore want to change Europe. And a stronger Europe is not without long-term investment. Have we recognised that there are more than 5.5 million young people out of work in Europe? Do you know what it means to a country, such as mine, where hundreds of thousands of my contemporaries go to Western Europe to work because there is no long-term predictable work and security at home? That is why I ask whether we believe that a united Europe is more competitive in the global world economy, that the reind into industrialisation of Europe is essential, because otherwise we will fall behind and believe that we need long-term investment. I do, I believe it, because we need a strong economy to eradicate unemployment, to provide social security.  I therefore demand, on the subject under discussion, that the money invested be used mainly in Europe, that it should be real investments and not speculative investments, and that the Central and Eastern European region be thought of separately, because we cannot break Europe up again into rich and poorer ones. Let's plant this fruit tree together so there'll be fruit. Thank you very much! (The speaker agreed to answer a question marked with a blue card in accordance with Article 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Ujhelyi, you talked about the problem of youth unemployment, about the need to reindustrialize Europe.  I ask you, do you agree with me that tourism is one of the sectors that requires long-term investment. We have already talked once on this topic and I would like my colleagues to hear, because we talk too little about tourism, and youth unemployment is especially high in Mediterranean tourist countries. I'd like to hear your opinion.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card answer. "My Croatian colleague asked the perfect question. Thank you very much, because I know, too, and many people in this house, that tourism requires long-term investment, but it can help small and medium-sized enterprises permanently and can provide stable jobs for many millions of people in the service sector. Moreover, Europe lags behind in global tourism competition if it does not have long-term investments. I therefore criticise the Juncker Cabinet for not using tourism as an expression in almost any of its materials. I demand that you think about getting into the long-term goals. Thank you very much!

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in order to remain competitive in an increasingly globalised world, the European Union needs measures that can ensure the long-term financing of the real European economy, on the one hand, and the use of market liquidity, on the other. There are liquidity reserves in Europe at the moment, but they are not effectively channelled into long-term investments because of the crisis of confidence of potential investors. The great challenge is therefore to reconnect private investment to attractive projects. To achieve this, Europe must take risks to encourage project promoters to launch long-term investments in infrastructure, such as transport, communications, energy or education, real estate assets, social infrastructure, innovation and climate protection. The effect will be simple and visible: by multiplying investment, Europe will be more prosperous and create more jobs. On the other hand, I welcome the Commission's proposal for the creation of a cross-border product framework for long-term investment, because Europe without internal borders is and must remain an attractive market for such projects that are beneficial to European citizens in cross-border areas and beyond.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D).
text: – Mr President, allow me also to welcome this very important initiative of the European Long-term Investment Funds and to express my faith that this investment vehicle for alternative investments is really suitable for the financing needs of Europe in growth assets, contrary to the Juncker plan which is more counter—cyclical in nature and overlooks the effects of deleveraging. We expect that there is potential to achieve a higher investment multiplier in the real economy, and also a more balanced view to include a higher focus on the supply. Maybe it would be more effective. Among the asset classes, this fund tends towards finance. The most important areas are the private equity schemes and the SMEs, and at this point I think we need to consider as fast as possible the facilitation of these financing options and pay considerable attention to the portfolio allocation of these kinds of investment opportunities, not only by focusing on the scope of the SMEs, but also on the geographic factors, without bias in investment, and the legal structures of the European south.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: Mr President, I thank Mr Lamassoure for his report, which shows that this long-term investment fund is a proposal for a new financing framework allowing private companies to invest in the real economy of the European Union and thus create jobs through growth. This can of course be a good thing, although I would also like to reiterate the importance that we in the group of public investments in combating deflation and financing strategic investment policies, because public capital should not only be used as collateral for private sector risk-taking.  Going back to the ELTIF, I would like to take a certain course of action by emphasizing the importance of avoiding speculative investments and the use of a capital market that would be insufficiently controlled. Similarly, we need a clear definition of what is called infrastructure when we talk about private funding through this program. For me, it is obviously important that this new long-term fund invest in productive infrastructure and not in non-productive assets, where there is no shortage of financing, such as residential real estate, for example, which can lead to speculative bubbles and which would not contribute to the objectives of growth and job creation. Finally, I will conclude with a condition that is imperative: it is obviously the location of the portfolio, which cannot be established in a country that does not meet the requirements for combating tax havens.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Long—term Investment Fund was to finance a new financial vehicle that will enable private investments to be channelled into the European economy. Long—term finance is a crucial tool for putting the European economy on the right path of sustainable growth in accordance with the EU 2020 Strategy, to promote high employment and competitiveness. I am very satisfied with the outcome of our Group’s effort to avoid speculation and tax havens and to ensure that investments take into account the European Union 2020 Strategy on employment and social targets. This report will have a very productive result because it targets the real economy of the European Union countries. Moreover, the report guarantees the possibility for small investors to participate in the fund with the necessary protection, such as the early ticket and the early redemption clause. I therefore support the conclusion of this agreement in the plenary session.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the main problem of modern economic operation is the financialisation of the economy and the operation of a 'casino economy', which invests in derivatives and stock markets and not in the real economy. And that's because funds make super profits. That is why trillions of funds are circulating and changing countries and hands in a few hours, while the armies of the unemployed and global poverty are increasing.  In order to put an end to this situation, it is necessary in the first instance to establish a new Glass–Steagall Act, which prohibits banks from being a key driver of the 'casino economy', a legislative act that separates commercial and investment banks. Only in this way can there be funds for long-term investments in infrastructure and in small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, 2,300 years ago Menandros had stated that the loans were "slaves to the people" and after 400 years Plutarch said it in harsher language. Borrowing insanity and.  The financial capital crisis in Greece has fatally hit our country. They ripped off the people, grabbed anything to save the banks. Unemployment, malnutrition, the closure of businesses and shops, the migration of young people, suicides are the current problem of our country. Where will these European, long-term investment funds be given to the banks or the people? So let the Greek people arrange their fortunes as they please!

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá ainm an Uasail Lamassoure leis an tuarascáil seo agus nuair a bhíonn ainm an Uasail Lamassoure le haon tuarascáil, bíonn sé go maith; agus is amhlaidh don tuarascáil seo faoi chistí infheistíochta fadtéarmaí Eorpacha. Gan dabht ar bith, tá an cúlú eacnamaíochta ag cúlú uainn, buíochas le Dia, agus dá bhrí sin, tá sé an-tábhachtach go mbeadh infheistíocht i gcúrsaí san Eoraip go háirithe in áiteanna a mbeidh buntáiste eacnamaíochta ag baint leo. Táim ag smaoineamh go háirithe ar fhuinneamh. Tá géarghá le hidirnascairí maidir le leictreachas agus gás agus b’fhéidir críochfort gáis leachtaigh agus mar sin de.  Luadh freisin turasóireacht, agus dar ndóigh d’fhéadfaimis i bhfad níos mó a dhéanamh chun an tionscal sin a chothú mar tá sé ins gach áit timpeall na hEorpa agus is fiú infheistíocht a dhéanamh i gcúrsaí turasóireachta chomh maith.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I begin by saying that I appreciate the work of the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs because, yes, they have tried to make some improvements to the rules of Parliament and the Council. But - because today, Commissioner, as yesterday, you have often heard the word 'SMEs' - I cannot help but wonder: will SMEs still be able to have access to this investment fund created specifically as an alternative to banks? I have had a sad experience in other situations with investment funds, which have used almost the same criteria as banks. That is why I personally would have thought that a certain amount should be given to SMEs in this special investment fund, otherwise we will find that all funds are concentrated in certain directions and SMEs will be left without support. Moreover, all the funds so far, COSME and everything that has been created for SMEs, are absolutely theoretical and in practice almost nothing happens. I hope, Commissioner, that by what you do, you will still find solutions to finance SMEs.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Lamassoure, who has once again done an important job for us. I support his thesis that investment does not follow any better economic indicators in the EU and that action must therefore be taken. The legislative resolution on long-term investment funds will further strengthen the much-needed so-called Juncker Plan, thus increasing the resources for long-term investment in the European economy. It is good that these funds will direct funding towards long-term projects with a focus on sectors that are important in the long term, such as infrastructure. Infrastructure development is of paramount importance for the whole of the Union and especially for countries such as Slovenia, which are not properly developed in infrastructure and have difficulty in rebuilding logistics centres, railways, roads and the like. In short, with long-term investment funds, we are building up the European Capital Union and strengthening the European economy, which will not depend on the ability of the banks.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – I would like to thank you all for your comments. We, of course, on the Commission side are committed to ensuring that the Long—term Investment Funds are available to be used as soon as possible. As many of you have stressed, we need long—term investment now. To do that we will be working closely with the European Securities and Markets Authority to formulate clear and workable implementation rules which fully reflect the intention of the text you have been debating today. Of course we hope for, and count on, your continuing cooperation to make this work a success. The European Long—term Investment Fund is one of the first concrete steps we are taking to make the vision of a Capital Markets Union a reality. We need a diverse, well—functioning, dynamic capital single market in order to support the real economy for SMEs and businesses to thrive. Together we have created a robust framework that offers certainty to investors that their money will be used to fund smart, sustainable growth in the real economy. The projects and companies, large and small, receiving this much—needed financing will have the confidence that they can rely on this capital being in place for the long term. As many have mentioned, this is complimentary; we will also have public investments, bank—lending and other funds to rely on. We will have restrictions too because the regulation prohibits investment in third countries which are identified as high—risk or non—cooperative jurisdictions by the financial action task force. Third countries must also comply with the OECD model tax convention on income and capital. The European venture capital and European Social Entrepreneurship Fund regulations have the same requirements; I think that is important. Another important thing is that investment in commercial property or housing is only allowed when it is a true part of long-term investment.  Finally, of course – as many of you have done – I would like once more to thank the rapporteur Mr Lamassoure and the shadow rapporteurs for their commitment to making this important piece of legislation a practical working reality that we can count on for now.

name: Alain Lamassoure
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to make my own the Commissioner's excellent conclusions and thank all the colleagues who have supported us, in particular the shadow rapporteurs, the European Commission and the Italian Presidency, who have been very effective in concluding the dialogues. If Mr Lamberts were still present, I would have reassured him that, of course, the solution of a 60% quota of compulsory investments in Europe has not been accepted. But that is all the better because, as a result, we have such a drafting that it is not 60% but 100% of the investments that will be spent on European projects. If our colleague, Mrs Matias, had been there again, I would have reassured her that with these long-term investment funds, the opposite of the "casino" economy that we are going to encourage - because she feared the "casino" economy. The idea is to take the money where it is and spend it on jobs and competitiveness through long-term investments. If Mr Monot were still here, I would also reassure him that, contrary to what he has indicated and what he fears, the banks have continued, particularly in our country, France, to finance small and medium-sized enterprises at the rate of previous years, but this is not enough to boost investment throughout the Union. Finally, I will end with a recommendation by addressing the Member States. It goes without saying that these funds will only attract if they are made a little sexy - if I may say so - by making them benefit from the most tax-favoured savings clause in each of our countries. We need these kinds of incentives to make these funds successful, and today's discussion has shown abundantly how much we need it.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, 10 March, at 11.30 a.m. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. The European economy is suffering from a worrying shortage of both public and private investment. In order to reverse this negative trend, the European institutions are making the revival of investment their workhorse. The creation of the European Long-term Investment Funds is an indication that reinforces the plan for a firm commitment to stimulate the revival of the real economy at European level.  It is a significant coincidence that the ELTIF trialogue ended positively, also thanks to the determination of the Italian Presidency, on the same day that the Juncker Plan was launched. This is a new opportunity for SMEs, research and infrastructure to find finance, a complementary opportunity to the efforts already made by banks in these sectors. This is about involving pension funds, insurance companies, and retail investors who will want to invest in the medium to long term, against advantageous returns.  I think it is important for Parliament to emphasise that these funds will not be able to invest in speculative activities and that all individual investors will have to be properly informed and protected. This new instrument not only strengthens the EFSI's commitment but also represents an interesting step in the direction of the single capital market.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. – The architecture of long-term European investments aims to mobilise financial capital in order to increase the competitiveness of Member States' economies, close the gap between regions and create new jobs. The stability of the European economic climate is an essential condition for attracting private capital to public projects. At the same time, there is a need for the establishment of an easy, red-tape framework and a uniform level of rules across all Member States. The added value of projects should take into account the combined benefits of long-term investment, more than its strictly economic benefits. There must also be instruments to guarantee public investment in order to make them as attractive as possible. Last but not least, I stress that the success of long-term investments depends to a large extent on their continuity, so clear regulations should be put in place that limit the possibility for investors to withdraw their allocations at any time. I am convinced that long-term investment will deliver measurable results in terms of smart growth by supporting the digital economy and creating integrated networks within the Single Market, increasing employment, facilitating the mobility of citizens and businesses and sustainable development, by exploiting the potential of the green economy.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. I believe that long-term financing can be an important tool for helping the European economy to grow and for stimulating competitiveness and employment. Long-term European funds are therefore welcome, and I hope that they will be able to finance the EU's real economy successfully, increasing the capital available for long-term projects. I think it is very important that these funds are put into the context of the Europe 2020 strategy. Investment in long-term activities should also play a key role in promoting smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. In addition, progress in achieving the objectives of this strategy could make higher volumes of capital available. However, the pooling of capital through European long-term funds, especially in the case of cross-border projects, could be hampered by the diversity of tax regimes between Member States and the fragmentation of the European long-term investment market.  In this respect, the Commission must take action to remove obstacles to the cross-border raising of long-term capital by promoting the creation of an integrated internal market for raising capital for long-term investment.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. – Infrastructure, transport and sustainable energy are the main sectors in which we have decided to focus our attention during our work on ELTIF: European long-term investment funds. Thanks to this instrument, we have built a favourable framework for investment in Europe. It is a balanced text that rewards virtuous investors of un listed small and medium-sized enterprises who decide to invest in real estate and infrastructure projects. In addition, the investors concerned are mainly institutional investors, represented by pension funds, insurance companies and private investors who have the opportunity to commit their savings for a longer period. In fact, these types of assets manage to ensure stable returns. We have decided to give priority to those projects that have the greatest impact on the territory, and that guarantee a greater impact on job creation. For these reasons, it is a fundamental instrument for reviving growth and employment in Europe. In fact, thanks to the expansionary measures of the European Central Bank and the new legislative measures on investments, we are able to emerge from the economic and financial crisis.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Union needs instruments to stimulate long-term investment, including for major infrastructure projects. Nevertheless, from the outset, the Commission's legislative proposal for European long-term investment funds raised legitimate doubts. First of all, it was alleged that the Commission's public consultation was sketchy and did not take into account all stakeholders. The main complaint was that the draft regulation submitted was imprecise and confusing. The proposed amendments appear to have removed these doubts. Another important complaint was that the ban on the redemption of shares before the end of the investment could have reduced the attractiveness of the funds, particularly among retail investors. The proposed changes seem to be going in the right direction. On the one hand, the ban continues to apply – which ensures the sustainability of funding and planning with these funds – and on the other hand, the possibility of redeeming shares is allowed if the fund manager establishes a specific redemption policy that takes into account the interests of all parties. Unfortunately, another serious problem concerning the maturity matching principle introduced in the Regulation has not been resolved. Many experts point out that this can reduce the profitability and thus the attractiveness of funds, primarily due to the risk of unsatisfactory investors reaching prices. It is highly likely that this will compensate for the expected interest on the loans granted, thereby increasing the investment costs.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. – With the Long-Term Investment Fund, we must, above all, ensure that we strengthen the real economy. I hope that we have all learned from the mistakes of the years before the crisis and we need to reduce speculative investment. Only in the real economy will good jobs be created with decent incomes, social and economic protection and, above all, a future perspective. In implementing all measures, it is now necessary to ensure that private and public budgets are strengthened. This can only be done through decent pay and the associated social security contributions. This strengthens domestic demand and public budgets. If eu-EU budgets are stable again, then we will once again be an attractive market for investment. Let us use this fund, together with the other instruments of active economic policy, to create and secure good jobs in sustainable sectors. The Fund creates the opportunity to change course in Europe and create sustainable investments.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union needs to relaunch investment, and the draft regulation meets this requirement. A unified legal framework is created at European level for the establishment and functioning of European long-term investment funds. These funds will be able to attract resources from institutional investors interested in long-term investments, such as pension funds, life insurance companies, and so on. The legal framework provides the necessary flexibility for these funds, but at the same time contains the prudential measures they must follow in order to avoid speculative investments and the lack of diversification of the asset portfolio. We welcome the adoption of this legal framework for European long-term investment funds which will also contribute to the implementation of the European Commission's investment plan through the European Strategic Investment Fund.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – A sustainable resolution of the consequences of the economic and financial crisis in Europe is unthinkable without investment. Funding opportunities, although available, are often insufficient or targeted at short-term objectives. Long-term financing of the real economy in Europe is therefore a priority and must be ensured.  The European Long-Term Investment Funds (EIF) are that instrument that can ensure smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the European economy by mobilising and channeling private funds for long-term investment. THE STIF are part of the idea of creating a single market for capital, implementing the Investment Plan for Europe. They can provide a steady stream of revenue for pension funds, insurance companies, professional and retail investors who are willing to invest long-term at least EUR 10 000 in one or more EIF for the implementation of projects with a positive effect on the European economy. The implementation of this new investment facility will allow financing of projects with a long-term perspective in the field of transport and social infrastructure (housing or hospitals), sustainable energy, education, research, small and medium-sized enterprises. The successful implementation of the EIF will help to close the investment gap in projects that are important to the EU and contribute to the sustainable growth of the European economy.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Long-term investment funds, beyond appearances, are a means of paving the way for financial speculation and the uncontrolled privatisation of the commons, rather than a smart tool for relaunching a model of finance serving the real economy and society.  The way IN which ELTIFs are structured does not offer investors the right incentives to channel capital towards long-term productive investment, in support of SMEs suffocated by the crisis. The funds designed by the Commission are by definition hedge funds, i.e. hedge funds, bound to invest 70% of the capital in long-term investments that can generate constant profits.  These are investments in financial instruments of companies or other funds and in real activities, even unproductive ones such as infrastructure, buildings, ships and aircraft. It is clear that this means once again endorsing the inefficient and clienteling use of financial resources that could instead be channelled towards the financing of innovative projects and productive enterprises.  Unfortunately, with this umpteenth squash, for-profit investments in public services, such as water and waste management infrastructure, or roads, schools and hospitals, are being brought through the window, but without making too much noise.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls Voting Time. (For voting results and other details about them: see minutes)

name: La Présidente. –
text: This closes Voting Time. The explanations for the vote will take place after the formal sitting.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for your excellent work. Majesty! On behalf of the Members of the European Parliament, I warmly welcome you to this House in Strasbourg. Your fourth visit to us, which is now our home, honours us as a sign of your appreciation, trust and friendship with this House and with the citizens of our European Union. Your delegation is also very welcome. I particularly welcome the two Presidents of the Chambers of the Jordanian Parliament, my colleagues, the President of the Senate and the President of the House of Representatives. It is a particular pleasure for us to welcome nine young Jordanian students who you brought with you in your delegation to our gallery today. Welcome to all of us. (Applause) Her Majesty, on behalf of Parliament, I repeat what I have already done, but I must also repeat in your presence, we would like to express our deepest condolences and sympathy for the terrible murder of your air force lieutenant, Moaz-al-Kasaesbeh. We are all in our thoughts with the loved ones to whom we desire strength, comfort and assistance. We have seen with great horror these terrible news and pictures of the murder of this young pilot. It exceeds our imagination that people are capable of such cruel acts. The criminal and barbaric crimes of the so-called Islamic State fill us all with disgust. These hordes of terror act outside of all the values and norms that unite us. Fleeing the atrocities of the terrorists and the civil war in neighboring Syria, well over a million Syrian refugees have so far found shelter in Jordan. We here in the European Parliament admire the generosity and generosity of the Jordanian people and are aware of the challenges this poses for your country. (Applause) Allow me to assure you and your people – the applause shows it – of our full support and solidarity with your country in these difficult times. We also want to support Jordan on the road to political and economic reform. You, Her Majesty, have embarked on this course of reform, responding to your people's desire for change. They have recognised that reforms can bring peace and respect for human rights to the region. Jordan and the European Union are also partners in the international alliance against the so-called Islamic State. We want the Jordanian people to be able to live with dignity and in a safe environment. For many years, Her Majesty has been making a decisive contribution to ensuring that this security is returned to the region. And even these days, your country is leading the way in providing parole to the terrorist militias on the ground. The determination with which you oppose the spread of hatred and extremism requires our utmost respect. In these difficult times for minorities throughout the region, Jordan continues to be a tolerant country where people can live together peacefully, regardless of their faith. Your participation in the commemorative march in Paris for the victims of the Charlie Hebdo attack was therefore a strong signal for which I thank you from the heart, certainly on behalf of the whole House. (Applause) With this signal, you have shown that Jordan is once again standing up to terrorism and to the side of tolerance, respect and peace. Finally, Her Majesty – we have just had the opportunity to talk about this – your tireless commitment to a peaceful solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict shows that you share with us, that we share the same values and norms with you. We want to be guided by these norms and values in order to meet the challenges together in these difficult times. True friends can be recognized in difficult times. We Europeans are proud to have a real friend in Jordan and in its king. Her Majesty, welcome to the European Parliament. You have the floor. (Applause)

name: King Abdullah II
text: King of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. – Bismillah ar-Rahman ar-Rahim. Mr President, distinguished Members, Jordan treasures its long ties of friendship with this great institution, and I appreciate your invitation to speak here today. Permettez-moi aussi de remercier les citoyens de Strasbourg pour leur hospitalité chaleureuse. Cette ville représente toujours un symbole du passage de la guerre à la paix, un symbole de la réconciliation et de l'unité de l'Europe. (L'Assemblée, debout, applaudit l'orateur) My friends, people thrive where there is mutual respect. Civilisation is built on it and futures are better for it, but co-existence must be made, and made again, in every generation. The common good is defended only by vigilance and action, and this means more than security measures. Humanity must arm itself with ideas, with justice, and with economic and social inclusion.  Today these challenges have a special importance. Our world faces an assault by terrorists with ruthless ambition. The motive is not faith: it is power pursued by ripping countries and communities apart in sectarian conflicts and inflicting suffering across the world. (Applause) The savage murder by Daesh of Jordan’s hero pilot outraged all Jordanians and horrified the world. Jordan’s response has been swift, serious and determined, and our fight will continue. (Applause) We and other Arab and Muslim states defend not only our people but our faith. This is a fight that has to be carried out by Muslim nations first and foremost. (Applause) This is a fight within Islam. At the same time, the danger of extremism must be seen for what it is: global. The threat is not only in Syria and in Iraq. It has struck Libya, Yemen, Sinai, Mali, Nigeria, the Horn of Africa, Asia, the Americas and Australia. Europe has suffered despicable attacks and shown unbeatable courage. Your friends are with you. In January, Rania and I joined millions of people in France who marched, united, against violence and intimidation. My friends, there are those living in Europe today who remember the ravages that struck the continent in the late 1930s and the world war that followed, because of an aggressive, expansionist ideology based on hatred and disregard for the very essence of humanity. Europe’s war became the world’s war. Today we are fighting a similar war, a war against an expansionist ideology that feeds on hate, that is committing murder in the name of God and religion, to justify evil actions that no religion tolerates – a war against terrorists who disrespect Islam’s values and humanity’s values. Our victory now depends on our unity and Europe’s role is vital. Only by cooperation can our regions shut down the sources of terrorist support and defeat their purposes. And it is also essential that our regions renew the source of our great strength: the mutual respect that binds and sustains us. Young people especially must be inspired by values that reject violence, create peace and build inclusive societies. (Applause) Let me suggest three areas of importance. The first is meaningful interfaith outreach, engaging people where they live. A dialogue of respect is the rock—bed of all societies. Attacking and excluding others, insulting other peoples and their faith and their convictions – this is no way forward. The future lies in unity and respect, not division and stereotypes. (Applause) Europe is an important partner in this effort, especially in helping to stop the global rise of Islamophobia. This poison is based on false ideas and helps play into the hands of these extremists. This is why it is important to clarify what it really means to be a Muslim. I and countless other Muslims have been taught from our earliest years that our religion demanded respect and caring for others. The Prophet Mohammad, peace and blessings be upon him, said: ‘None of you has faith until you love for your neighbour what you love for yourself.’ This is what it means to be a Muslim. Among the very names of God we hear the Compassionate, the All-Merciful. All my life, every day, I have heard and used the greeting Assalamu aleikum – a wish for the other to be blessed with peace. This is what it means to be a Muslim.  (Applause) More than a thousand years ago, before the Geneva Conventions, Muslim soldiers were ordered not to kill a child, a woman or an old person, not to destroy a tree, not to harm a priest, not to destroy a church. These are the same values of Islam we were taught in school as children: not to destroy or desecrate a place where God is worshipped, not a mosque, not a church, not a synagogue. (Applause) This is what it means to be a Muslim. These are the values I teach my children and that they will hand on to theirs. My friends, I am outraged and grieved by the recent attacks in some countries against Christian and minority communities. This is an offence against humanity as well as Islam. Arab Christians are an integral part of our region’s past, present and future. (Applause) Jordan is a Muslim country with a deeply—rooted Christian community. Together the Jordanian people make up an indivisible society – friends and partners in building our country. The world’s Muslims have a critical role in global understanding. Our faith, like yours, commands mercy, peace and tolerance. It upholds, as yours does, the equal human dignity of every person – men and women, neighbours and strangers. Those outlaws of Islam who deny these truths are vastly outnumbered by the ocean of believers – 1.6 billion Muslims worldwide. In fact these terrorists have made the world’s Muslims their greatest target. We will not allow them to hijack our faith. (Applause) My friends, the second area key to global harmony is an international system that gives all people the respect they want and deserve. Again and again I hear the question: why does the world not defend Palestinian rights? Time after time the peace process has stalled. Let me say what the situation looks like in reality – more Israeli settlement-building, less respect for the occupied Palestinians. This failure sends a dangerous message. It erodes trust in international law and community. It threatens a pillar of world peace: that conflict must be solved by political means, not by force, not by violence, and it has given the extremists a powerful rallying cry. They exploit the injustices and the lingering conflict, to build legitimacy and recruit foreign fighters across Europe and the world. (Applause) It is time to think about the future and how this ongoing conflict will breed further hate, violence and terror across the world. How can we fight the ideological battle if we do not chart the way forward towards Palestinian—Israeli peace? Our countries, united, must provide the momentum and chart the way forward towards a final comprehensive settlement. (Applause) Ladies and Gentlemen, a third critical effort is creating deeper hope. Radicalisation thrives on economic insecurity and exclusion. To create stakeholders in a peaceful world, people need opportunities to fulfil their potential and build good lives. Helping them is a powerful message of respect. The European Parliament has recognised the importance of creating social and economic opportunities in naming 2015 the Year of Development. For Jordan, development is a priority and despite all the regional challenges we have pressed forward to meet urgent needs, to grow jobs, to improve the quality of life through continued reforms and partnerships such as yours.
