Jordan values our strong partnership with the European Union and its Member States. We are committed, with your support, to work together towards more advanced levels of partnership. (Applause) Jordan also takes seriously our moral obligations to others. Despite scarce resources, the people of Jordan have opened their arms to refugees fleeing regional violence. As the President mentioned earlier, Jordan has taken in thousands of Iraqi Christians over the past year. This in addition to giving shelter to 1.4 million Syrian refugees, which is 20% of the population, over the past few years. (Applause) This is more than the equivalent of France hosting the entire population of Belgium. Our small country is now the world’s third largest refugee host and I thank all of you who are helping us to uphold this global responsibility. (Applause) My friends, your support sends a message, not only to my people but to all those who seek to move forward in peace and moderation. Europe is with you. Our regions, our people, can find no better partners and neighbours than each other. History, geography and future bind us. Let no one separate us because together we can create pillars of mutual respect that will support the common good for generations to come. (Loud and sustained applause) (The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Majesty, you have to endure the applause. They might not want to be applauded for so long, but I had the impression, Majesty, that the House would have applauded for much longer. I do not think we have heard such an encouraging speech in this House for a long time. I would like to thank you very much. You are always a welcome guest to us, and I believe that colleagues have applauded the fact that you have spoken from the heart of many of us with what you have said about your country, about your region, but also about your personal ideas. Thank you for this great speech! (Applause)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the redundancies that took place in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers due to the abolition of production operations and the restructuring of the Zachem corporation, classified in division 20 of NACE Revision 2 ('Manufacture of chemicals' and substances' in the NUTS 2 region of Kuyavia-Pomerania province. 404 of the 615 dismissed workers registered as unemployed at the Employment Office in Bydgoszcz district, and redundancies occurred during the reference period from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013 and are attributable to a loss of market share of the Union chemical industry. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving Poland's application EGF/2013/009 PL/Zachem for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which the Polish authorities had requested from the EU in the wake of the redundancies at the company and with two Zachem suppliers.  This fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Fund finances individually adapted measures for the reintegration of jobseekers, promotes self-employment and business start-ups, and grants mobility allowances and allowances for disadvantaged or older workers. The enormous redundancy rate was unpredictable for the company due to its main supplier of the market with TDI (toluoldiisoyanate). However, low-cost production and cheap transport can be interpreted as the reason for the 615 redundancies.  It is therefore gratifying that the EU has accepted Poland's request and is providing funds to support the redundant workers, in the hope of helping them to achieve lasting, long-term and therefore stable employment through the measures taken.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. Poland has applied for assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies of 615 employees at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem between 31 March and 31 July 2013.  These layoffs are the result of the cessation of activities and the restructuring of the Zachem company, located in the Vojvodina of Couïavie-Pomerania. They are due to the decline in the European Union's market share in the chemical industry. From 1992 to 2012, the EU's share of the global chemical market increased from 35.2% to 17.8% in 2012. During the same period, China's share of the chemical market increased from 8.7% to 30.5%.  The collapse of the European chemical industry is therefore due to the thoughtless liberalisation of trade which has allowed Asian competitors to oust Europeans from this sector. I voted in favour of this EUR 115,205 aid to Poland because it will help victims of the european Union's globalist and ultra-liberal policy by supporting the reintegration of laid-off workers into the labour market.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Poland, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, although I have some reservations about the relevance of the timetable for the implementation of this tool, I support its primary vocation. For my part, the adjustment to globalization should be achieved upstream or at the beginning of the company's financial problems rather than at the time of accounting for the number of licensees.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Polish purposes in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Zachem operating in the chemical industry. The EU has lost significant market share and a leading position in the chemical industry in global chemicals trade. Between 1992 and 2012, the EU's share of the world chemicals market fell sharply from 35.2% in 1992 to 17.8% in 2012. The EGF is intended to provide a total amount of EUR 115 205 for 615 redundancies. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training, and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, knowing that this 'adjustment fund' is only a bad thing: if it really wants to combat the deleterious effects of globalisation, the European Union must renounce the dogma of the free movement of goods and people and no longer stand in the way of the implementation of protectionist measures.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Over the past 20 years, the global chemical industry has been following a migration trend to Asia. In the face of very high competition, the European Union has seen its position in the sector decline sharply. In this context, 615 workers from Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem in Poland were laid off as part of a sudden restructuring. The EGF's support of EUR 115,205 to support the reintegration into the labour market of the fifty most disadvantaged people among these graduates is certainly justified.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to alleviate the problems arising after the layoffs in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two of its suppliers due to the abolition of production operations and the restructuring of Zachem Corporation, a chemical company. Poland is entitled to access to such aid which I hope will alleviate the situation of workers.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Poland has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following 615 redundancies at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two of its suppliers due to the cessation of production and the restructuring of Zachem, a chemical company located in couïavie-Pomerania. The requested aid is EUR 115,205 and I therefore voted in favour of this mobilization of the EGF.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to support 615 Polish workers who have lost their jobs in the manufacture of substances and chemicals. The EGF, which is concrete and indispensable for supporting companies and workers affected by the crisis, needs to simplify the bureaucratic process for its activation, so that it can have a positive impact on the lives of citizens.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 115 205 of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 615 workers who have lost their jobs at the Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem plant, in Poland's Kuyavia-Pomerania province for the manufacture of substances and chemicals, due to the abolition of production operations and the restructuring of the Zachem corporation , as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The customized services to be financed from the EGF include recruitment incentive activities and intervention work for the 50 most disadvantaged workers. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the European chemical sector due to the tendency to move chemical manufacturing to Asia, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers concerned.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to support workers made redundant from the Polish company Zachem. According to the data provided by the Polish authorities, the EU has lost significant market share and a leading position in the global chemical trade. According to trends in recent years, chemical production has been transferred to Asia, in particular to China. Increasing sales in emerging markets in China have led to a rapid increase in the production of chemicals. Production levels in Asian countries are also driven by lower labour costs, market access, subsidies, taxes and regulation. Thus, the Polish company Zachem did not withstood the competition and fired its employees. In addition, the region had the highest unemployment rate in the country and Zachem was the largest employer in the field. Thus, poland's application fully complies with all the conditions of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and should receive EU support from this Fund.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in global trade flows and to help reintegrate into the labour market and Poland meets the prescribed conditions, I support the EP Decision.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Adjustment Fund for Zachem because I think that we need to help our companies on European soil to cope with the challenges of globalisation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Poland has submitted the EGF/2013/009 application to obtain the contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following 615 redundancies at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem. The European Parliament recognises that redundancies are directly related to a decline in the EU's market share in the chemical industry, from 35.2% in 1992 to 17.8% in 2012.  At the same time, Asia and especially China are experiencing a significant increase in production due in large part to their wage costs, much more flexible regulation, and government subsidies to support the sector. These dismissals are therefore the result of a free trade policy open to all the winds of savage globalisation that now affect the Eastern Member States of the Union, which are supposed to be more resistant to international competition.  Rather than unlocking funds to put out the social fire, an economic policy should be implemented that protects our industries from unfair competition upstream. However, I voted to grant this Fund to help these workers who are victims of the excesses of globalization.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic problems caused by the crisis are also felt in the chemical industry. The case of Zahem in Poland is an illustrative one. It had to lay off 615 workers due to losses. The chemical sector experienced a significant decline, so that while in 1992 the EU's market share on the world chemical market was 35.2%, it experienced losses, and in 2012 the EU market share was 17.8%. This is caused by the migration of chemical production to other economically attractive areas, such as China. It is good to know that Zahem is an important development engine in the area where it operates, being the largest employer in the region, and the lay-off of these workers is a real problem, meaning 60% of the total unemployed registered in that area. It is essential that the coordinated package of services of EUR 115 205 for the 50 most severely affected persons is granted in order to remedy the precarious economic situation. I voted in favour of this report because support measures for redundant employees are absolutely necessary in order to integrate them into the labour market.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Zachem in Poland. The amount of aid amounts to EUR 115,205. Dismissed workers will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. The request from Poland justifies an intervention by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund given the decline of the European chemical industry in the face of Asian and particularly Chinese competition.  I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which refers to the application made by Poland on 9 October 2013 for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies of Zachem and two suppliers in Poland. Poland's application concerns 615 redundancies in 3 chemical companies. In order to establish the link between redundancies and major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, Poland argues that the EU has suffered a significant reduction in its market share in the chemical industry, losing the world record in the sale of chemicals. The EU's share of the world chemicals market has indeed fallen dramatically, from 35.2% in 1992 to 17.8% in 2012. The link between redundancies and structural changes in world trade due to globalisation is therefore clear. That is why I voted in favour of this measure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 50 out of 615 workers who have been made redundant in the manufacturing sector.  This is a particularly important issue for me as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local Bose factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community as a whole. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be made in this instance but adequate support for the workers in retraining and upskilling must be provided in any case.  The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as a justification for making workers redundant.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following a positive assessment by the Commission of the application presented by Poland to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the Commission has now presented Parliament with a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Poland to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. According to point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, in order to activate the Fund the Commission, in the event of an application receiving a positive assessment, presents a proposal for mobilisation of the Fund to the budgetary authority and, at the same time, a corresponding request for transfer. In the event of disagreement, a trilogue shall be initiated. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The interruption of production and the corporate reorganization of Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem (which concerns the latter and two suppliers, all operating in the chemical sector) are at the origin of 615 redundancies. The reference sector is suffering greatly from Chinese competition, which has led to a sharp decline in the Union's market share over the last twenty years.  Zachem was the largest employer in the region, which already had the highest unemployment rate in the country. EGF interventions are aimed at the 50 workers at the greatest disadvantage and include recruitment incentives and targeted interventions.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is right that workers in the Member States of the European Union who are suffering the full brunt of the crisis and the austerity policy imposed by that union should receive compensation. In this case, the 615 redundancies at Zachem and two of its suppliers have hit Polish workers hard. Poland's request was also justified, in the sense that companies within the European Union have suffered particularly, in recent years, competition from China, particularly in the chemical industry: from 1992 to 2012, the EU's share of the global chemical market fell sharply, from 35.2% in 1992 to 30.5% in 2002 and 17.8% in 2012. In view of these facts, it seemed important to me that Zachem's employees receive compensation, however light.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of this measure because the European Fund set up provides support for workers who are suffering from structural changes in world trade. The Fund may not exceed the annual ceiling of EUR 150 million (at 2011 prices). The amounts required shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a provision. The procedures that will be used to obtain the transfer of funding seem to me to be good and efficient.  The dialogue between the Commission and the Authority should ensure the success of the procedural agreement, see the Zachem Poland case, which is going through a dark period given the shift in production of chemicals to Asia, with an incision on the higher production cost due to high labour costs. The intervention of the European Fund is a positive and decisive procedure aimed at supporting and defending individual European workers.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this application, which refers to the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Poland, and which aims to compensate 615 redundant workers working at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem, which specialises in the manufacture of substances and chemicals. Indeed, these redundancies are the result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation.  In particular, China's market share in this sector has increased significantly due to lower labour costs. I therefore consider the intervention of the European Fund to be a positive and decisive procedure aimed at defending European workers affected by structural changes in world trade.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 115 205 for Poland with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of the 615 workers made redundant in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two of its suppliers.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF on Poland's request for financial assistance following the redundancies of Zachem and two other suppliers in the manufacture of chemicals and substances. The company has suffered strong competition from Asian producers, which has led to a sharp reduction in its market share. In particular, the production of ECH (Epichlorohydrin) has become inconvenient, both because of the increase in production costs in Europe and because of the unexpected increase in ECH's supply from Asia.  Zachem's subsequent decision to discontinue production operations and to start internal reorganization has also had immediate repercussions on its suppliers and has expanded its effects. In addition, the region affected by the redundancies had an unemployment rate of around 17% during the reference period, the highest in Poland, mainly as a direct or indirect consequence of the difficulties experienced by Zachem. The EGF allocation will be used to co-finance personalized services in order to reintegrate – I hope quickly and appropriately – those made redundant into the world of work.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The redundancies of 615 workers working in the ʽmanufacture of chemicals and chemical productsʼ sector are linked to a decline in the European Unionʼs market share of the chemical industry. Fifty redundant workers in the most disadvantaged situation will be targeted by the European Globalisation Fund measures which include hiring incentives and intervention works. I have therefore voted in favour of this report to support the reintegration of disadvantaged workers in the labour market.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Poland has requested the mobilisation of the EGF following the 615 redundancies at a chemical factory and two of its suppliers. The redundancies took place from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013 and are linked to a decrease in the market share of the Union chemical industry. The total contribution requested amounts to 115,205 euros. It should be pointed out that the measures supported by the EGF are aimed at fifty workers who are at a disadvantage. In essence, recruitment incentives and investments are co-financed. In addition, it should be noted that the factory in question was the largest employer in the region and that during the reference period, workers made redundant, directly or indirectly by Zachem, accounted for 60% of all newly registered unemployed persons at the district employment office in Bydgoszcz. Given the importance of improving the employability of all workers through appropriate training and the recognition of skills and competences acquired during a worker's professional career, I believe that Poland is entitled to a financial contribution under this regulation.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR)
text: in writing. – I voted for this resolution because it supports people, from an employment institution that has been closed. It also affects a Polish employment institution called Zachem. It is a good decision taken by the European Parliament. Unfortunately, there are sad implications: we are rescuing only four employment institutions in Belgium. But one in Poland.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in the Kujawsko-Pomorskie Province, Poland. The application relates to 615 redundancies in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and to two suppliers, operating in the NACE 2 Division 20 manufacture of chemicals and chemical products, during the reference period from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013. The EGAF funding provides assistance for the reintegration of 50 redundant workers into employment. Since the report aims to help workers who need support to re-enter the work-market I voted in favour.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 615 employees of Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two of its suppliers in the chemical industry, Poland has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support people who have lost their jobs and to help them find work or start their own businesses. The aid provided amounts to EUR 115,205 and covers 50% of the cost of the projects that will be offered to these employees.  Since the request of the Republic of Poland corresponds to the criteria for the mobilization of the EGF, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. - Aimed at supporting employees suffering the consequences of globalisation, Poland has requested the activation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the redundancies of 615 employees of the company "Zachem" and its two suppliers active in the chemical industry. As the region's largest employer, these job losses caused by the migration of the chemical industry to Asia have contributed to the worsening economic and social situation in a region already marked by the country's highest unemployment rate.  The INTERVENTION of the WEF will ensure the financing of a set of personalized services to ensure the reintegration of workers into the workforce. In this regard, it is to be welcomed that, according to provisional data, 36 people have so far found employment as a result of their participation in the services offered.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade.  I supported the proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of Poland, because it proposes the reintegration into the labour market of 615 workers made redundant at Zachem Poland, a company that has suffered a significant reduction in its market share in the chemical industry due to the significant changes in world trade due to globalisation.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 21 January 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Poland to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade. According to the data cited by the Polish authorities, the Union has suffered a significant loss of market share in chemical products, losing its former leading position in the sale of chemical products.  The redundancies at Zachem were not foreseeable as the market supply of its main product, TDI (toloul diisocyanate), increased sharply. Investments in other parts of the world to reap the benefits of economies of scale and further integrate the supply chain have enabled these producers to produce at lower average costs, resulting in an oversupply of 30 %. As a result of this and the low transport costs combined, Zachem was not competitive in this environment.  A coordinated package of personalised services co-financed by the Fund will be addressed to the 50 most disadvantaged persons and will include two measures: recruitment incentives and intervention measures.  The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. Poland has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the dismissals of 615 employees at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem between 31 March 2013 and 31 July 2013. The company had ceased operations and then began a restructuring due to the decline in the European Union's market share in the chemical industry.  Between 1992 and 2012, the EU's share of the global chemical market rose from 35.2% to 17.8%. While China's share rose from 8.7% to 30.5%. Trade liberalization, the absence of protectionism, have led to the collapse of our chemical industry. I voted in favour of this EUR 115,205 aid to Poland in order to help, for example by facilitating the reclassification of these Polish employees, victims of the ultra-liberal policy of the European Union.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they have lost their jobs as a result of changing global trade patterns, e.g. when a large company shuts down or a factory is moved to outside the EU, or the global financial and economic crisis. Negotiations on the renewal of the Fund concluded under the Multiannual Financial Framework Agreement and a new EGF Regulation is now in place. There are six EGF applications to be voted on from Poland, Germany and Belgium.  The ECR is opposed in principle to the use of this Fund and voted against the proposals.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as I believe that this mechanism is wrongly designed and money is being wasted. With this money, we support companies that are facing closure or even bankruptcy, but not in order to return to the market and create new jobs, but to help redundant workers be re-integrated into the labour market. I fully support the idea of professional reintegration of workers, but this should be the responsibility of the social services in the country where these workers paid their social security and taxes. Why should all European taxpayers pay for this, for this social policy? For 708 workers made redundant in Belgium, the fund will pay EUR 981956 and for Polish 615 – 115205 euros. On top of that, this money will be paid out years after the application has been submitted, and I don't think the redundant workers will wait 3, 4 or 5 years to start looking for a new job. The longer a person is unemployed, the harder it will be for them to get a job. That is why I believe that before we continue to mobilise funds, we need to completely review and reconstruct this mechanism.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as I believe that the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that provides support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to provide assistance to redundant workers as soon as possible. This was the case with PL/Zachem, which operates in the chemical sector, which saw the EU's share of the global chemicals market decrease dramatically, from 35.2% in 1992 to 17.8% in 2012. At the same time, there was a migration of the chemical industry to Asia, where there was a very sharp increase in the manufacture of chemicals, from a share of 8.7 % in 2002 to 30.5% in 2012. The difficulties in that company are related to important structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the eligibility conditions of the eGF support application have been verified. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to improve the employability of all workers through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career. This support should be complementary to the company's responsibility under national law.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, in the light of the recent analysis by the Swedish National Audit Office, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EGF was created to provide additional support for redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis, and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take action to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The Polish authorities submitted the Application EGF/2013/009 PL/Zachem following 615 redundancies at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers, redundancies related to the suspension of production and the reorganisation of Zachem. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Established more than 50 years ago, Zachem S.A. was one of the most important chemical companies in Poland and one of the largest companies in the northwest part of the country.  From 1989, with the arguments of greater efficiency and flexibility to survive in the new competitive environment, several changes were made both in management and in the division of the company.  In 2006, Warsaw-based Ciech increased its chemical portfolio when it acquired Zachem and Organika Sarzyna. With increased competition from the Asian market, Poland's only producer saw its market share dramatically decrease from 30.5% in 2002 to 17.8% in 2012. After the sale of TDI assets to BASF, Ciech, with the consent of the Polish government, decided to discontinue Zachem's core activities and to divest or liquidate all remaining assets. Some 615 workers have lost their jobs in the region with the highest unemployment rate in the country. We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising to support those targeted by the consequences of the liberalisation of world trade, and further reaffirmour criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of neoliberal policies which have once again led to this outcome.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this call for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in order to provide additional support to Polish Zachem workers who have been affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission has decided to mobilise funds from the EGF in favour of Poland after 615 workers lost their jobs as a result of the Significant Loss of the European Union's market share in the chemical industry and lost its global leadership in the sale of chemicals. Following the closure of the company in question, unemployment in the region has increased and the old age and low education of the redundancies make it impossible for them to find adequate employment. The amount of funding should be EUR 115 205.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of granting the fund € 115,205 (50% of the total) for the 615 redundancies in the manufacture of substances and chemicals in Poland

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mobilisation report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - application EGF/2013/009 PL/Zachem, Poland, because the money from the adjustment fund should be given basically to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I am against the use of these funds as they do not respect the principle of subsidiarity. Unemployment benefit, training and education are Member State competencies. It is not up to the European Union to pay redundancy money when businesses close.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Accompanying measures were implemented after the announcement of lay-offs in consultation with the social partners and in partnership with the regional public employment services. In the process we pleaded with Commissioners Thyssen and Malmström for greater coordination to ensure that international trade agreements do not damage European industrial employment. I therefore voted in favour of this mobilisation of funds.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization that, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation (e.g. closure of large enterprises or relocation of production outside the EU) or the global economic and financial crisis. That is why I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2013/009 PL/Zachem)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). Specifically, THE EGF funding amounts to EUR 115 205 and relates to 615 redundancies in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers, operating in the substance and chemical manufacturing sector. The layoffs were because of major structural changes in global trade patterns and the migration of chemical manufacturing to Asia, and China in particular.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. By unblocking the contributions provided for by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union is giving a concrete sign of support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, thus making it easier for them to re-enter the labour market. I therefore welcome the adoption of Mr Olbrycht's report on the case of the reorganisation of Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem's company.  In this case, as in many other cases, Europe intervenes only to cover the declines in competitiveness and to provide companies and workers with new tools for the conversion of skills and skills. These are certainly decisive instruments: the hope is that the efforts of new productive momentum that the EU has undertaken with the new Juncker Plan will gradually make EU companies finally stronger on the global market, thus reversing the trend of decline that part of our industrial sector has suffered in recent years.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I am very pleased to receive the proposal by an overwhelming majority and congratulate Mr Olbrycht on another report that has been drawn up fairly. This proposal is one of the last two proposals to be considered under the 2006 EGF Regulation and therefore welcomes the positive result of the vote. Zachem was the largest employer in the Kuyavia-Pomeranian region. Employees dismissed directly or indirectly from zachem accounted for 60% of all newly registered unemployed at the District Labour Office in Bydgoszcz. The region as a whole, on the other hand, has the highest unemployment rate in the country, reaching 17.4% in July 2013, despite the economic expansion enjoyed by the region. The final product of the factory was so specific that it required specialized knowledge. Therefore, the retraining of redundant workers is very difficult.  The financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund amounts to EUR 115 205. This aid is aimed at 50 vulnerable workers and is implemented through employment subsidies and intervention work.  The largest part of the funds for personalised services will be allocated to employment subsidies, which will include 45 employees and will provide incentives for employers who choose to employ these workers for at least 24 months. Support is provided to a lesser extent to 5 redundant workers over 50 to pay their social security contributions. This age group is at risk of long-term unemployment and exclusion from the labour market.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Olbrycht report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it fully complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGAF Regulation. I welcome that the EGAF funding of EUR 115 205 shall contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 50 redundant workers into employment.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. Poland has requested assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the layoffs of 615 employees at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem in 2013. These layoffs are the result of the restructuring of the Zachem company, located in the Couïavie-Pomerania voivody. They are due to the decline in the European Union's market share in the chemical industry, to the benefit of our Asian competitors. From 1992 to 2012, the EU's share of the global chemical market increased from 35.2% to 17.8% in 2012. During the same period, China's share of the chemical market increased from 8.7% to 30.5%.  I voted in favour of this EUR 115,205 aid to Poland because it aims to help victims of the european Union's globalist and ultra-liberal policy by supporting the reintegration of laid-off workers into their labour market. However, I express doubts about the actual application of the REACH Directive on the assessment of chemical risks, in principle applied to imports: can the European Chemicals Agency and the Customs of the Member States really control the exponential flow of goods from Asia?

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund for the Zachem company in Poland, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series even if in this case it is only 50 workers and the sum is the lowest amount required of this fund.  However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to offer assistance in the Kujawsko-Pomorskie Province, Poland, following 615 redundancies in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem. The funding of EUR 115 205 will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 50 redundant workers into employment.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, because the purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This case of a chemical industry in Poland where 615 people have lost their jobs is a consequence of globalisation. The European Union has a responsibility to help people in this Member State.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Today, a vote was taken on applications aimed at attracting European taxpayers to subsidise distressed firms. These came from Poland (1), Belgium(3) and Germany. Among other things, a steel company, a distressed solar company and the subsidiary of a North American company are to be protected from "the consequences of globalisation". This is a massive violation of European, democratic and market principles. In the EU, 'subsidiarity' is preached, but the exact opposite is increasingly being practised. If a Member State thinks that it has to help its companies through state intervention, then that country must take responsibility and the costs for it itself. Above all, the respective government must account for this subsidy to its voters. We can see that fundamental principles of democracy are also tolerated here by the Commission's presumptuous intervention. After all, these subsidies also violate the most basic laws of the market economy. It is often the same Members who are upset loudly about the privatisation of profits and the socialisation of the losses of companies, who are now adopting this unspeakable subsidy policy. There is no question that I had to vote against this.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for the Zachem company in Poland, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the series of associated aid even if in this case there are only 50 workers and the sum is the lowest amount required of this fund.  However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as part of the redundancies of 615 workers at the Foundationy Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers on the basis that I strongly support support for workers affected by global structural changes.  This way, concretely helps to reintegrate them in a labour market that is facing globalisation flows; in a concrete example, the Union's share of the chemicals market has fallen significantly over the past ten years and has steered towards Asia. In this context, it is important to ensure that assistance is dynamic and accessible as quickly as possible in order to prevent further deterioration of the situation of redundancy workers.  Therefore, I support this proposal because Zachem was the largest employer in the Kujavsko-Pomeranian Duchy, which will surely feel the negative consequences of redundancies and the additional rise in the unemployment rate.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Poland has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the dismissals of 615 employees at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem between 31 March 2013 and 31 July 2013. The company had ceased operations and then began a restructuring due to the decline in the European Union's market share in the chemical industry. Between 1992 and 2012, the EU's share of the global chemical market rose from 35.2% to 17.8%. While China's share rose from 8.7% to 30.5%. Trade liberalization, the absence of protectionism, have led to the collapse of our chemical industry. I voted in favour of this EUR 115,205 aid to Poland in order to help, for example by facilitating the reclassification of these Polish employees, victims of the ultra-liberal policy of the European Union.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Kuyavia-Pomeranian Voivodeship is one of the regions with the highest unemployment levels. The dismissal of more than a few hundred workers by the largest employer was a huge tragedy for the area. 60% of the new unemployed were former employees of Zachem and his co-workers. The deterioration of the company's financial condition was directly due to globalisation processes and the relocation of chemical production to Asia. In ten years, the share of European companies in the chemicals sector has fallen from 30% to nearly 18%.  The Polish State has taken a number of measures to help redunded people find a new job. To a large extent, they have been successful. Of the more than 600 exempted, only fifty require more support co-financed by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. These are the most disadvantaged people who, because of their age and competence, have great difficulty finding a new job. The case of zachem's former employees therefore requires the mobilisation of money from the fund. Finally, I wanted to draw attention to an extremely important issue. Since the proposal was submitted, the Commission has taken more than a year to prepare a draft decision – this has taken far too long. Given that, due to the specificities of the aid, the Globalisation Adjustment Fund was supposed to act very quickly, this is an important problem. It is becoming increasingly clear that the procedures in force are too time-consuming and it is worth considering improving them.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jan Olbrycht's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Zachem in Poland. The fund will provide EUR 115,205 for the 615 sacked employees of Zachem, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on Poland's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in connection with redundancies at Zachem, as well as at two suppliers and producers.  This fund was created to provide additional assistance to workers who have been made redundant due to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization and to help them re-enter the labour market. I am the the the city of EUR 115,205 to adopt this aid.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as I believe it is a major move to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade while facilitating their reintegration into the labour market quickly and effectively.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. After the termination of 615 employees at the Zakladi Chemizne Zachem plant and two suppliers as well as the downstream manufacturers Zachem Ucr Sp. z.o.o. and METALKO Sp z.o.o., Poland applied for support from the EGF. These job losses were the result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, in particular due to the declining global market share of European companies in the chemical industry. The measures concern about about 50 employees who have the greatest difficulty in finding new jobs. I support the proposal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made by Zachem. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Zachem was the biggest employer in the Kujawsko-Pomorskie Province of Poland and the 615 redundancies which have resulted from its closure, have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to the local economy and support the workers affected.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Olbrycht report. It provides for the reintegration into the labour market of 615 workers made redundant by Zachem Poland.  Through the EGF, we are trying to ensure a system of reintegration into the labour market for employees affected by the economic crisis, highlighting, once again, the key role that Europe has and must continue to play in this time of crisis.  I would also like to stress that today's mobilisation concerns Polish workers who are unfortunately in difficulty and that we will be able to help by mobilising these resources.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. As I had already done in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, I renewed my vote in favour of the Olbrycht report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 615 sacked employees of the Polish company Zaklady Chemizne Zachem. The EGF will fund EUR 115,205 in aid, mainly through counselling, guidance and training, under the national project "Back to the Labour Market III - a New Career". In the face of mass unemployment, the EGF is once again proving to be an effective tool to support the victims of globalization in a concrete and sustainable way.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union, through its active participation in the process of globalisation and its passive trade policies, is largely responsible for the economic weakening of nations and the downgrading of our productive apparatus. Considering that the allocation of these funds constitutes a just, albeit modest, reparation for the prejudices suffered by the peoples, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The application relates to 615 redundancies at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers, operating in the chemical and substance manufacturing sector, during the reference period from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013. The layoffs were because of major structural changes in global trade patterns and the migration of chemical manufacturing to Asia, and China in particular. The financing of the EGF amounts to EUR 115 205 to help the labour conversion of the sector and workers, something we agree with.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the redundancies that took place in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers due to the abolition of production operations and the restructuring of the Zachem corporation, classified in division 20 of NACE Revision 2 ('Manufacture of chemicals') in NUTS 2 region of Kuyavia Province. 404 of the 615 dismissed workers registered as unemployed at the Employment Office in Bydgoszcz district, and redundancies occurred during the reference period from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013 and there is a loss of market share of the Union chemical industry. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. With regard to Poland's financial contribution to budgetary matters and good financial management of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I consider that the duration of the procedure has been relatively long given that the objective of this Fund is to provide rapid assistance to workers.  Therefore, because the manufacture of chemicals has recently moved to Asia, which has led to numerous layoffs in Zachem, FEAG will provide aid to the 50 most disadvantaged workers and encourage job recruitment in this region. In addition to this, it will also focus its performance on workers over the age of 50 who have been laid off taking into account their difficulty of re-entering the labour market. I believe that the role of the EGF, together with the complementary actions of the Structural Funds, is providing an improvement in the labour market and its prospects, while promoting and promoting equality between men and women.  That is why I approve of the decision on that resolution.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Globalization provides the opportunity to trade on the global market and for the customer the opportunity to obtain the cheapest available goods. Due to the different labour prices and production costs, some products are worthwhile to produce in regions other than Europe. However, this cannot be addressed by taking money from one company or the EU and handing it over to another, which is harder to cope with globalisation. The solution is the opposite of the current system, namely to cut taxes, simplify administration, and abolish regulations that do not burden companies outside Europe.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Due to the effects of the economic crisis, Poland had a large loss in the market share of the chemical industry and lost its leading position in the sale of chemicals due to the cheaper chemical market of Asian countries, especially China. The report refers to the Chemiczne Zachem Foundation, which was a Polish manufacturer of semi-finished and organic and inorganic chemical products for a large number of industries, until its closure in December 2012. The closure of their facilities has had negative impacts on the local community, which has the highest unemployment rate in Poland. As a solution, the Report proposed a contribution from the EGF for a coordinated package of personalized services in the amount of 115 000 euros, which represents 50% of the total cost related to the surplus of 615 workers in the company Of The Foundation Chemiczne Zachem and its suppliers Zachem Urc Sp z.o.o. and Metalko Sp z.o.o.  I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which aims to re-integrate redundant workers, provide incentives for potential employers and provide an educator's interview on the specific knowledge and skills that employers require.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour with my political group because I believe that a good political compromise has been reached. The vote required a qualified majority (3/5 of all members in the Chamber) that had been reached.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 ZACHEM is the largest employer in the Polish Kujavsko-Pomeranian Duchy. The redundancies of the 615 employees of this company and its suppliers have a major impact on employment in the region. For the effective effectiveness of the decisions and measures taken, it is crucial that they are taken in a timely manner or within a reasonable period of time. Only in this way can the measures fulfil their purpose. At the same time, it is important that measures are sought to support redundant workers over 50 years of age, because it is this group of employees that is most at risk from the point of view of further employment. It is therefore important that clearly defined procedures are adopted without delay, with clearly defined deadlines for the examination of specific applications, so that the aid granted is expediable and that the impacts resulting from it can be assessed in advance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013, between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, because as confirmed by the Polish authorities , firstly, the financial contribution from the EGF does not replace measures which are the responsibility of undertakings under national legislation or collective agreements, secondly they have shown that the actions provide individual support to workers and will not be used to restructure companies or sectors, and thirdly they have confirmed that these eligible actions do not receive aid from other EU financial instruments.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this mobilization of the Fund, as I had done in the EMPL committee, because this fund helps to support workers laid off by their companies as a result of the economic crisis in Europe. Here this fund will support 615 licensees from the chemical manufacturing sector in Poland.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. The redundancies in Zachem were unforeseen because of the suddenness of the increase in market supply of its flagship product TDI (toluene di-isocyanate). The surplus supply of 30%, as a result of investments undertaken in other parts of the world to benefit from economies of scale and to further integrate the supply chain, enabled these producers to manufacture at a lower average cost. This together with low transport costs resulted in Zachem’s inability to compete in this environment. As far as the second source of revenue is concerned, the manufacture of ECH (Epichlorohydrin), its sale became unprofitable for the group due to the increase by around 160% of the prices of its raw material propylene.  The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded will be aimed at the 50 most disadvantaged persons and will include the following two measures: hiring incentives and intervention works.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Poland's request for a financial contribution, totalling EUR 115 205, under the EGF, following 615 redundancies due to the interruption of the company's production of Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem, a company operating in the field of "manufacture of substances and chemicals". Zachem's redundancies have proved unexpected due to the sudden increase in the supply of its main product, TDI. The EGF should be mobilised to provide financial as additional support to workers made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of trade.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The profound transformation of the international trading system, attributable to the advance of globalisation, and the economic and financial crisis, has led Poland into a situation of economic poverty, and social crisis.  The European Union must intervene in support of the country and its inhabitants, so that the burden of economic depression can diminish.   On this basis, I felt responsible to express my agreement with the Olbrycht report, which calls for the mobilisation of the EGF, for the benefit of 615 workers made redundant at Zachem Poland.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I received my positive vote on the request for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as the situation in the chemical sector has become extremely critical as a rising point from the move from Poland to China. It is important to consider measures that can strengthen this sector again. Among other things, workers made redundant as a result of globalisation as a result of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns should be supported in their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of retraining people who have lost their jobs after a Polish chemical industry company that did not erda in the Asian countries was forced to immediately cease and reorganise its activities. The funds are necessary to solve social problems as soon as possible and to return to the labour market as many as 615 people of working age who have been made redundant.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This case of the Globalization Fund proposes to help the 600 or so licensees of a Polish company specializing in the chemical industry. Chemical manufacturing in China increased from 8.7% in 2002 to 30.5% in 2012. European producers are suffering from this dumping, made possible by the European policy of free competition. This aid only brings a band-aid to a policy that has been defeated.  I am more in favour than ever of social and ecological protectionism, the only remedy and control to ensure public health and the development of a European sector of high know-how.  However, I abstain so as not to object to the financial support these workers will receive.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Poland to give this aid, who submitted the EGF/2013/009 PL/Zachem application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 615 redundancies at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers, redundancies related to the suspension of production and the reorganisation of Zachem, operating in division 20 (Chemical Manufacturing) of NACE Rev. 2, in nuts II-level Kujawsko-Pomorskie province.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the EU’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 404 workers in Poland due to the reduction in market share of the chemical industry.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund – application EGF/2013/009 PL/Zachem. The report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Kujawsko-Pomorskie Province, Poland. The application relates to 615 redundancies in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers, operating in the NACE 2 Division 20 ʽmanufacture of chemicals and chemical productsʼ, during the reference period from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013. The EGF funding of EUR 115 205 will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 50 redundant workers into employment.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was pleased to vote in favour of all the motions on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important institution of solidarity within the Union: it contributes to the early re-creation of workers in jobs that have been lost as a result of the globalisation process, with a lasting application in a competitive sector. It is an active employment policy instrument that shares the burden of returning to the labour market between the worker, the Member State concerned and the Union, and its outcome helps workers who are able to re-enter work, member states that are forced to deal with unemployment and the Union which is aiming to increase employment. I would also consider it necessary to establish a similar fund for the wage catch-up of workers in underdeveloped, crisis-hit regions.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  Following 615 redundancies at Zachem in Poland due to the significant reduction in market share in the chemical industry, I am in favour of mobilising EUR 115 205. I would also point out that redundancies at Zachem will immediately lead to an increase in the unemployment rate unless new jobs are created quickly. The workers fired by Zachem are mostly skilled, but have never worked in the areas where they have qualified.  Hence the importance of adopting professional requalification measures for workers to adapt initial qualifications to the new needs of the labour market.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. Once again, the European Union is playing the arsonist fireman by trying to put out the fire that it has started itself. It will thus partially compensate for the damage it causes by its ultraliberal ideology. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to shock anyone. I am voting for this aid to employees so as not to further penalise the victims of European ultra-liberalism.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation with the exception of two where the number of employees is lower than that specified in the regulation. There is a precedent for this and Parliament supports their applications.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of EUR 115,000 to support the reclassification of 615 employees laid off by Polish chemical manufacturer Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted five reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of its five reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release EUR 115,000 from this fund to 50 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem in Poland.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Poland, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of zachem workers, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade. According to the data cited by the Polish authorities, the European Union has seen its market share in the chemical sector drastically reduced and has therefore lost the lead in sales of chemicals worldwide. The trend in recent years has highlighted that chemical manufacturing has shifted to Asia, particularly China, which has seen an exceptional increase in chemical production, from 8.7% in 2002 to 30.5% in 2012, as a result of higher sales in emerging markets.  This European aid, in the form of recruitment incentives and targeted interventions, will be aimed at the 50 redundant workers and will be a valuable aid for their reintegration into work.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it proposes to compensate, through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, all the collateral victims of certain economic operations generated on a global scale. As such, I fully support all actions aimed at strengthening cohesion within our continent by protecting its workers and strengthening the social dimension of the European project.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The profound transformation of the international trading system, attributable to the advance of globalisation and the economic and financial crisis, has led Poland towards total economic asphyxiation. It is necessary for the European Union to intervene in support of the country and its inhabitants, so that the burden of economic depression is made bearable. That is why I felt it necessary to express my agreement with the Olbrycht report, which calls for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of 615 workers made redundant at Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the implementation of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - EGF PL/Zachem's request as special rapporteur of the Social Democratic Group in the European Parliament for EGF Funds.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the material and formal conditions for mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund are in place in this case and I hope that the promised financial resources will give the employees and workers concerned a view for the future. I therefore hope that there are also positive aspects to the economic prosperity of the region.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is essential. I support the proposal in this report to provide financial support to a Polish company. In particular, it is necessary to eliminate the negative effects on the labour market and to mitigate the negative consequences for redundant workers. They need to help find new jobs by various means and reintegrate into the labour market as soon as possible. Urgent and urgent support is therefore necessary for the people who have been made redundant. The EU must show solidarity with redundant workers at all times. It is essential that EU countries continue to have adequate access to this financial assistance and to implement measures to support workers who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to allocate EUR 115 205 to Poland from the EGF Fund, as it will help 615 people who became unemployed in a chemical and chemical production company. Unemployment is one of the most painful problems in the European Union. As a result of structural change and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a great deal of workers. With the EGF Fund, we can re-mobilise these people in the labour market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market; that Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission; that the request for assistance meets the eligibility conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation, I voted in favour.

name: Marit Paulsen (ALDE)
