text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, in the light of the recent analysis by the Swedish National Audit Office, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EU's share of the global chemicals market has fallen drastically from 35.2% in 1992 to 17.8% in 2012, proving the migration of chemical production towards Asia and China. Production levels in Asian economies are also driven by lower labour costs, access to markets, subsidies, taxes and regulations. The Foundationy Chemiczne Zachem was a Polish chemical products manufacturer based in Bydgoszcz. Zachem produced semi-finished products and finished organic and inorganic products for the automotive, chemical, construction and textile industries. The line was closed in December 2012.  The application states that 615 workers were made redundant in three companies as a result of the situation. Based on requests from Poland, the proposed EGF contribution to the coordinated personalised service package is €115,205, representing 50% of the total cost.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help Poland with a technological surplus in the chemical industry, an EGF contribution to a harmonised service package of €115,205, representing 50% of the total cost. With a view to establishing a link between redundancies and major structural changes in globalisation trade flows, Poland argues that the EU has suffered a significant loss of market share in the chemical industry and has lost its global leadership position. From 1992 to 2012, the EU's share of the global chemicals market fell drastically, from 35.2% in 1992 to 17.8% in 2012.  The trend in recent years shows the migration of chemical production towards Asia, especially China. Production levels in Asian economies are enhanced by lower labour costs, access to various markets, subsidies and taxes. Member states need to show solidarity towards each other when needed, and I am pleased that they have shown this today in this example.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At a time when Europe is facing a financial, economic and social crisis and unemployment as a key consequence, the European Union should use all means at its disposal to react, in particular as regards ensuring support for people who have lost their jobs. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. to find a new job. Poland applied to EGF/2013/003 PL/Zachem for a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 615 workers at The Foundationy Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers - Zachem Urc Sp z.o.o. and Metalko Sp z.o.o., which is linked to the interruption of production and the reorganization of Zachem.  Zachem was a Polish producer of semi-finished and organic and inorganic chemical products for a large number of industries and also the largest employer in the region, so the redundancies will have a negative impact on the Kujavo-Pomeranian Duchy, which had the highest unemployment rate in Poland, at 17.4% in July 203, despite the economic expansion experienced by the region.  I therefore support Rapporteur Jan Olbrycht's report on the mobilisation of €115 205, which is 50% of the total budget, as it aims to assist redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support workers in companies suffering from the negative economic situation and major structural changes in world trade. It is right to mobilise the fund for Poland, as per the Commission's decision, to help the reintegration into the labour market of those workers made redundant at Zachem Poland (a chemical manufacturing company). There are 615 workers made redundant, as we recall the minimum threshold required for its application is 500 workers. The coordinated package of tailor-made services to be co-financed will be aimed at the 50 most disadvantaged redundant workers and the following measures will be part of it: recruitment incentives and targeted interventions. I hope that the sums allocated to workers will best help them to re-enter the labour market and that all the principles of equal treatment will be respected.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Personally, I would like to welcome the fact that the funds from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund have also headed to the new Member State this time. This is rarely the case, but I believe that the number of such cases will increase. That is why this resolution has my support.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Globalisation, by opening up European markets to international competition, has had a direct impact on our businesses at the economic and structural level. The Union has thus created a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to limit the effects of globalisation on European economies, on our businesses and on our workers. The fund was requested in 2015 by Poland to support the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers in the chemical sector.  I found that this request was in accordance with the Fund's rules and expressed my support for this mobilization. It is important to encourage the reclassification and training of workers and this fund allows such actions.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this application, as it fulfils the required requirements, being related to the mitigation of the damage caused by the dismissal of 615 people in the reference period between 31 March 2013 and 31 July 2013. According to the figures reported by the Polish authorities, the EU has recorded a significant reduction in market share in the chemical industry, losing its position as the world leader in chemical sales. The trend in recent years points to the migration of the chemical industry to Asia, especially China, and the level of production in Asian economies has also been driven by lower labour costs, market access, subsidies, taxation and regulation. The redundancies at Zachem were unforeseen due to the sudden nature of the increase in supply in the tdi market (toluene diisocyanate), its main product.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of legislative and budgetary instruments to provide complementary support to the most diverse sectors has proved to be a positive measure in the transition and adjustment of Member States to the era of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool in that it can serve to reintegrate people and businesses into the global market. In this case, and in view of the situation presented, the aid provided to Poland is relevant.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 115 205 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 615 workers who have lost their jobs at the Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem plant, in Poland's Kuyavia-Pomerania province for the manufacture of substances and chemicals, due to the abolition of production operations and the restructuring of the Zachem corporation , as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The customized services to be financed from the EGF include recruitment incentive activities and intervention work for the 50 most disadvantaged workers. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the European chemical sector due to the tendency to move chemical manufacturing to Asia, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers concerned.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the redundancies at the Polish company Zachem, as these contributions are a valuable aid in enabling the retraining and reclassification of workers, thanks in particular to training tailored to the opportunities of the job market.  Nevertheless, the job losses in many sectors are a painful reminder that these aids are not a miracle cure and that it is essential to pursue a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. More broadly, Europe needs to put in place a real coordinated industrial policy focused on creating sustainable jobs in sectors of the future.  In addition, weASee procedures should be accelerated and simplified to enable laid-off workers to cope with difficulties as soon as they arise.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, amounting to EUR 115 205, for active labour market measures, with the aim of facilitating the reintegration of 615 workers made redundant in the chemical manufacturer Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem in Poland, by considering, like the rapporteur, that the essential requirements for the allocation of this Fund are met under Regulation No 1927/2006, which has the particularity of being the lowest amount requested in the history of the EGF and that it will contribute to the reintegration of these workers into the labour market.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which aims to unlock financial and professional assistance for the 615 employees of Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem in Poland. These were abruptly laid off as a result of the sudden increase in the supply of TDI market supplies and the fall in the cost of production in third countries as a result of structural changes in the market; these two factors led to a competitive deficit in Zachem that resulted in a large-scale social plan.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will provide 50% financial assistance, which will include support for adaptation and modernization processes in the region, as well as training.  Once again, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund proves its full usefulness, so I supported this report in order to continue our commitments to a fairer And closer Europe to the citizens.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the request made by Poland because I believe it is right that the Fund in question should help those countries that, while working so hard to grow and develop, need aid to provide to companies that do not always manage to support the global market.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of protecting chemical workers who have been unemployed as a result of competition from third countries.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which authorizes the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 115,205 to help the reintegration of 615 Polish workers made redundant because of the economic difficulties of their employer, the chemical company Zachem.  Between 1992 and 2012, the European Union's share of the global chemical market fell from 35.2% in 1992 to 17.8% in 2012. European companies are bearing the brunt of the rise of Chinese producers, who benefit from large subsidies, low-demand legislation and cheap labour. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up on the initiative of France to help workers who lose their jobs due to major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Poland's application complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It affects 615 unemployed people and the EU's market share of the global chemicals market has fallen sharply. The reduction in market share particularly affected Zachem's factories in the Kujawsko-Pomorskie region. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. We agree with this request for the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because in this case employment must be safeguarded. However, we note that the Union's recommendations do not go in the direction of a fair globalisation allowing States to protect their businesses and jobs as do other major powers.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the redundancies that took place in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers due to the abolition of production operations and the restructuring of the Zachem corporation, classified in division 20 of NACE Revision 2 ('Manufacture of chemicals') in NUTS 2 region of Kuyavia Province. 404 of the 615 dismissed workers registered as unemployed at the Employment Office in Bydgoszcz district, and redundancies occurred during the reference period from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013 and there is a loss of market share of the Union chemical industry. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for application EGF/2013/009.  Zachem Poland has been granted EGF aid to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant from Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers, linked to the discontinuation of production and the corporate reorganisation of Zachem, located in Kujawsko-Pomorskie Province. The 615 redundancies are linked to a decline in the European Unionʼs market share of the chemical industry. The Polish authorities argue that the impact of globalisation has been worsened by the effect of the financial crisis. Zachem was the biggest employer in the region and that in the given reference period, the workers dismissed directly or indirectly from Zachem amounted to 60 % of all newly registered unemployed persons in the district employment office in Bydgoszcz. The EUR 115 205 of EGF aid will pay for personalised services to support the reintegration of the affected workers into employment.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers receive none of this support therefore.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. With the adoption of the EGF Regulation, the criterion for the mobilisation of the Fund was reintroduced as a result of the crisis, the Union's financial contribution increased to 60 % of the total estimated costs of the proposed measures, and the inclusion of the self-employed and young people increased the circle of beneficiaries and incentives to set up their own businesses began to be financed. The application for a financial contribution submitted by Poland to the aid granted to Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem, in which 615 redundancies were made in 2013 as a result of the company's abandonment and reorganisation, fulfils the eligibility criteria. The redundancies, which were linked to the decrease in the Union's market share in the chemical industry, had a negative impact on the situation in the Kujavsko-Pomerania region, where unemployment is highest in the country. As the co-financed services package is tailored to the 50 most disadvantaged and is intended to complement a number of pre-existing redundancy measures and contains two important measures: an incentive for employment and intervention work, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \u2012 I support the restructuring of companies. At the same time, I am aware of the importance of the right economic policy that precedes such situations.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this resolution as Poland has submitted an EGF/2013/009 PL/Zachem application for an EGF financial contribution following the redundancies of 615 workers at the Chemiczne Zachem Foundation and two suppliers, which is linked to the cessation of production and the reorganisation of Zachem, which operates under Section 20 of the NACE 2 classification'.  The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation and Poland is entitled to a financial contribution under the Regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will mobilise resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – On 9 October 2013, Poland submitted a request to mobilise the EGF for redundancies of workers at Zachen, which until then was the largest employer in the region. This is evidenced by the fact that after the aforementioned layoffs, unemployment in the field office in Bydgoszcz increased and laid-off workers accounted for 60% of all newly registered workers.  I support this report because the request submitted by Poland fulfils all the necessary assumptions and by 16 June 2014 it has been complemented by updated data. Given that EGF contributions are intended to co-finance and apply active labour market measures, and that past practice has established that they also have a significant impact on the acquisition of workers' skills and abilities, I believe that the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be possible.  All of the above also supports the fact that the Polish Government itself started providing services tailored to the needs of workers before submitting this application itself.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I do not agree with the granting of this contribution. The motion for a resolution on this vote itself states that the EU's share of the global chemicals market fell from 35.2% to 17.8% between 1992 and 2012 as a result of globalisation. However, this decline was not caused by globalisation itself, but by the fact that the EU is not sufficiently competitive compared to the rest of the world. However, further redistribution does not solve the problem of competitiveness, but on the contrary deepens.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. 615 redundancies were made at the Polish company Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers linked to the abandonment of production and the reorganisation of Zachem. I supported the report on the mobilisation of the EGF, which provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. The Union's share of the world chemicals market decreased sharply between 1992 and 2012, from 35,2 % in 1992 to 17,8 % in 2012, and chemical production has moved to Asia in recent years, in particular China. In this context, I would like to point out that I welcome the fact that the EGF's actions are complemented by measures financed by the Structural Funds.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour! The support measures had been implemented as soon as the redundancies were announced in consultation with the social partners and in partnership with the regional public employment services. In the meantime, we have pleaded with Commissioners Thyssen and Malmstrom for greater coordination so that international trade agreements do not completely destroy European industrial employment.  These 5.2 million are important to the Walloon economic fabric. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves should not be the rule. It should be remembered that this aid was made indispensable because an international industrialist wanted to play with the destiny of workers, treating them with disdain and great disrespect. Europe must send a strong message to all the Lakshmi Mittals of the world that in Europe there are no castes or untouchables. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. Zachem was one of the biggest employers in its region and because the EU manufacture of chemicals is decreasing, it left 404 persons unemployed. This fund will allow the creation of incentives for job creation in the region and accompany existing actions undertaken by local companies. I believe it will set the path to durable and long-term employment in Kujawsko-Pomorskie Province.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The chemical industry in some subsectors and in some countries is facing major structural changes. The world trade patterns are changing for the vast majority of the population for good but there are a few who are suffering from it. This is why I am in favour of programmes that assist the reintegration into the labour market of the workers affected in these sectors.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European Globalisation Adjustment Funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultraliberal policies applied in this European Union, which are unable to defend neither the peoples who make up it nor the companies that support it.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is a financial instrument that allows money to be allocated to people who lose their jobs due to the economic and financial crisis or because of changes in the structure of world trade with globalisation. For the period 2014-2020, the budget allocated to the Fund is EUR 150 million.  Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem was a Polish manufacturer of chemicals that was the manufacture of semi-finished and finished chemicals for the chemical industry, paper industry, energy sector, etc. The changes caused by the economic crisis led to the suspension of the production of this company, and more than 600 employees were dismissed between March 2013 and July 2013. A request was therefore submitted to the European Commission for the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 115 205 from the Fund, which was approved by the Commission, with the adoption at the beginning of 2015 of a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Poland. The European Parliament's report found that all eligibility criteria have been met and therefore supports the granting of the required amount from the EGF. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising a financial contribution of over EUR 100 000 through the EGF to Poland, following the placement of 615 workers made redundant due to the interruption of production and the corporate reorganisation of two companies operating in the manufacture of substances and chemicals in the province of Cuiavia-Pomerania.  I have always supported the use of feg in all cases where workers lose their jobs due to the consequences of unfair international competition and the economic crisis. The sector involved, in particular, has suffered a sharp decline in market share throughout the European Union, while China has seen an increase from 8.7% in 2002 to 30.5% in 2012.  Although the EGF is not an appropriate instrument for dealing in the long term with the problem of downward competition, social dumping and unemployment, I wanted to support this additional emergency measure which will benefit workers.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the redundancies that took place in Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem and two suppliers due to the abolition of production operations and the restructuring of the Zachem corporation, classified in division 20 of NACE Revision 2 ('Manufacture of chemicals') in NUTS 2 region of Kuyavia Province. 404 of the 615 dismissed workers registered as unemployed at the Employment Office in Bydgoszcz district, and redundancies occurred during the reference period from 31 March 2013 to 31 July 2013 and there is a loss of market share of the Union chemical industry. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Poland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Due to the effects of the decrease in prices of its main products, TDI and ECH (epicloridrin), and increased competition in the Asian market, Zachem S.A, Poland's sole producer, saw its market share decrease dramatically from 30.5 % in 2002 to 17.8 % in 2012. Some 615 workers have lost their jobs in the region's main employer, the region with the highest unemployment rate in the country. The Polish authorities then applied to the EGF, where they asked for EUR 115,250 to support 50 of these disadvantaged workers with measures to encourage employment and intervention work. It should also be noted that this is the lowest amount requested in the history of the EGF. We agree with the mobilisation, but we also reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of neoliberal policies which have once again led to this outcome.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. This request was supported by me, as the situation in the chemical sector has become extremely precarious with the move from Poland to China. Nevertheless, we need to consider what measures need to be taken to strengthen this sector again.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The Globalisation Fund was set up to help with short-term emergencies due to mismanagement, globalisation or the financial and moral crisis in the Member States. Support includes training, business start-up grants, coaching and outplacement of redundant workers. The Globalisation Fund co-finances these job creation measures at 50% or 65%, with the balance being provided by the Member State concerned. This makes the EU Commission a gigantic labour market agency. Nevertheless, the European Court of Auditors said in a special audit report that this "globalisation fund" provides only limited EU added value and should be replaced by a more efficient regime. It was explicitly stated that this Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support. And yet the EU is continuing the policy, which has been shown to be inefficient. I cannot therefore agree with this mobilisation.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, in the light of the recent analysis by the Swedish National Audit Office, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Experience shows us that, at European level, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EAFG) has proven to be a successful tool for the reintegration into the labour market of thousands of redundant workers. I voted on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund with a view to allocating EUR 115 205 to redundant workers from Zachem, a major producer of chemicals in Poland. I welcome the adoption of this report and i hope that the allocated amount will be used effectively for the reintegration into the labour market of the laid-off persons.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 With this proposal, which I supported, the European Parliament approves the financial assistance of redundant workers and suppliers, the Polish chemical company Zachem S.A., through the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The EGF is established to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of global structural changes in trade, and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. This case concerns a request by Poland to support dismissed persons and fulfils the eligibility conditions as laid down in the relevant Regulation. The Polish authorities submitted the request on 9 October 2013 and the Commission notified its assessment on 21 January 2015. The total amount amounts to EUR 115 205, while the redundancies took place in 2013, and are linked to a decrease in the Union market share in the chemical industry.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of granting former employees of Zachem and two of his suppliers funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This form of compensation for lost jobs is, of course, only a small aid, but any form of financial support that can be offered to redundant workers in the face of the liquidation of their workplace should be used. The EGF is a tool that can only mitigate the effects of adverse processes in the European economy. In theory, this fund is intended to help retrain redunded workers, but in practice it is an admission of a failure to protect jobs in the EU. Globalisation is, on the one hand, an inevitable process, but on the other hand it is the task of the Member States to take all necessary measures to mitigate its negative effects. The protection of jobs should be the first responsibility of both national authorities and the eu's entire administrative machine. Indeed, it is easier to prevent capital outflows and relocations of production to developing countries than to recreate these jobs later, creating complex and dubiously effective special investment funds. I hope that any mobilisation of the EGF will not only be a form of support for redunduted workers, but also a remorse for those in power, a reminder of the defeat in the fight for jobs in Europe.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Established more than 50 years ago, Zachem S.A. was one of the most important chemical companies in Poland and one of the largest companies in the northwest part of the country.  Since 1989, Zachem S.A. has applied measures of greater flexibility to try to survive in the new competitive environment and several changes have been made, both in management and in the division of the company.  In 2006, Warsaw-based Ciech increased its chemical portfolio when it acquired Zachem and Organika Sarzyna in December. Ciech's TDI, which was produced by its subsidiary Zachem, saw its market share decrease dramatically from 30.5% in 2002 to 17.8% in 2012. Following the sale of TDI assets to BASF, Ciech, with the consent of the Polish government, decided to discontinue Zachem's core activities and divest or liquidate all of Zachem's remaining assets. Some 615 workers lost their jobs at the region's main employer. We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising to support those targeted by the consequences of the liberalisation of world trade, and further reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of the neoliberal policies that have once again led to this outcome.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in the case of the Polish company Zaklady Chemiczne Zachem, because this company was the largest employer in its region and because as much as 60 % of all new applications for unemployment between 31 March and 31 July 2013 were the result of redundancies in Zachem and two of its suppliers. This had a negative impact on the situation in the Kujavsko-Pomerania region, where unemployment stood at 17.4% despite economic growth in July 2013 and was the highest in Poland. Zachem was mainly involved in the production of chemical products; between 1992 and 2012, the EU's share of the sector fell drastically compared to the rest of the world (from 35.2% to 17.8%) due to the relocation of industry to Asia, in particular To China. It is good that the EGF's actions are also complementary to a number of programmes co-financed by the European Social Fund.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 657 redundancies, 390 of them at Aleo Solar AG, a company operating in division 26 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacturing of computer, electronic and optical products', and 267 in its two subsidiaries, with 476 people expected to take action. These redundancies occurred during the reference period from 7 March to 7 July 2014 and after that period, due to a decrease in the Union's market share in the solar energy sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Germany, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving Germany's application EGF/2014/014 DE/Aleo Solar to mobilise funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which the German authorities had requested in the wake of the redundancies at Aleo Solar AG and two of its subsidiaries. This fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Fund finances individually adapted measures for the reintegration of jobseekers, promotes self-employment and business start-ups, and grants mobility allowances and allowances for disadvantaged or older workers. China has built up enormous overcapacity in solar modules that cannot be absorbed by its own consumers or by the world market. Together with the global decline in demand, this has led to a fall in prices. Since China exports about 80% of its production to Europe at cheap prices, the demand for China products was greater than that of the German company Aleo Solar. This explains the 615 redundancies made by the consortium and two of its subsidiaries. It is therefore gratifying that the EU has accepted Germany's request and is providing funds to support the redundant workers, in the hope of helping them to achieve lasting, long-term and therefore stable employment through the measures taken.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. Germany has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 657 employees at Aleo Solar.  These layoffs are the result of the decline in the European Union's market share in the solar sector.  This decrease is due in large part to China's unfair competition in the field of solar modules. Between 2005 and 2011, China's share of revenue rose from 11 per cent to 45 per cent, while Germany's fell from 64 per cent to 21 per cent. Germany itself refused to allow Brussels to take sanctions in the field of photovoltaics, betting that unfair Chinese competition would weaken its other European competitors. This bet, the Germans lost since the Chinese industrialists ended up ruining the entire European solar sector, including the German solar sector. I have therefore abstained on this report, because I cannot endorse the attitude of the German authorities on this issue.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Germany, but I am not best placed to judge. I have an additional concern in this case, as it appears that the workers may not have actually been made redundant when the company was taken over. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, although I have some reservations about the relevance of the timetable for the implementation of this tool, I support its primary vocation. For my part, the adjustment to globalization should be achieved upstream or at the beginning of the company's financial problems rather than at the time of accounting for the number of licensees.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for German purposes in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Aleo Solar, which operates in the field of solar power production. Aleo Solar is just one of many European solar companies that have become insolvent over the last few years, have ceased its solar business, completely or partially ceased production, or sold to Chinese investors. Between 2005 and 2011, China's share of income increased from 11% to 45%, while Germany's share of income fell from 64% to 21%. The EGF is intended to provide a total amount of EUR 1 094 760 to 657 redundant workers. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I generally vote in favour of mobilizing this fund, although I condemn the perverse logic of giving painkillers rather than treating evil.  Unusually, I chose to abstain because Germany strongly opposed the introduction of anti-dumping measures on Chinese solar panels. In Angela Merkel's country, there are no less than 10,000 companies in the photovoltaic sector, 350 of which produce solar panels. The rest is responsible for resale and installation and thus benefits from low Chinese costs. This is how Germany has clearly chosen "services" against industrial production... but now proposes to the European Union to pay the bill for this policy.  It is therefore up to Germany to bear the consequences of its irresponsible policy which harms European producers.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the face of aggressive competition, particularly Chinese overproduction in photovoltaics, Germany saw its market share fall sharply from 64% to 21%. In this context, the German company Aleo Solar suddenly had to close its doors in 2014, laying off 657 workers. The EGF's assistance of EUR 1,094,760 is perfectly justified in implementing a major action and service plan to promote the reintegration of laid-off workers into the labour market.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to alleviate the problems arising from 657 redundancies, 390 of them in Aleo Solar AG, 2 'Manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products', and 267 in its two subsidiaries, which occurred during the reference period from 7 March to 7 July 2014 and after that period , due to a decline in the Union's market share in the solar energy sector. It is expected that 476 people will take action and I hope that the EGF will serve to improve their situation.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Germany applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following 657 redundancies, including 390 at Aleo Solar AG, a company under the Manufacture of Computer, Electronic and Optical Products, and 267 in two of its subsidiaries, of which 476 people are expected to participate in the measures. We are asked for EUR 1,094,760 in aid from the WEF.  I abstained on this report on the basis that the measures taken are insufficient and that the European Union has not taken effective measures against the international unfair competition that we denounce in this sector.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote to mobilise the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, for the 657 German workers made redundant in the photovoltaic panel processing sector. I believe that we have reached this point because of europe's short-sighted climate policy, which has pushed the sector to the extreme, without taking into account the long-term effects and the foreseeable fall in the prices of this technology.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 094 760 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 657 workers who have lost their jobs in Aleo Solar, dedicated to the manufacture of solar modules in the Prenzlau/Brandenburg region of Germany, due to a decline in the Union's market share in the solar energy sector. Aleo Solar is one of many European solar energy companies that have declared the sector insolvent, abandoned the sector, ceased production in whole or in part, or sold their facilities to Chinese investors in recent years. The growth in Chinese production that enjoys financial support under China's current five-year plan (2011-2015) has led to a huge excess of capacity of solar modules, which neither its own consumers nor the global market can absorb. This is joined by a decline in global demand, which has led to the collapse of prices.  The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include vocational training activities, professional advice and guidance, business-building guidance or interregional mobility advice.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to support workers made redundant from Aleo Solar in Germany. According to the data provided by the German authorities, Aleo Solar is just one of many European solar companies that have become insolvent in the last few years (since 2010), have ceased its solar business, completely or partially ceased production or have been sold to Chinese investors. China has created a huge overcapacity of solar modules that can not be absorbed by its users or by the world market. In addition, demand has fallen worldwide, leading to a fall in prices. Despite various efforts to restructure and increase efficiency, the company failed to become profitable again, resulting in its liquidation, closure and sales of its facilities.  The European Globalisation Fund should be supported by redundant workers in order to reintegrat into the labour market through measures such as vocational training, career counselling and career guidance, groups and workshops of workers with similar qualifications, entrepreneurship advice, interregional advice on mobility, job search by a professional jobseeker, further mentoring activities for workers who have found new jobs but who may need advice on maintaining this job.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who have ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation trade flows. On 29 July 2014, Germany applied for egf mobilisation in relation to redundancies at Aleo Solar AG and its two subsidiaries in Germany. Since they meet all the requirements, I will support the EP's decision.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Aleo Solar because I think that we need to help our companies on European soil to cope with the challenges of globalisation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Germany submitted the EGF/2014/014DE/Aleo Solar application for a contribution from the European Fund to Globalisation because of 657 redundancies, including 390 at Aleo Solar, a company specialising in the manufacture of photovoltaic panels.  The European Parliament considers that these redundancies are directly related to "changes in the global trade structure", i.e. the sharp decline in the share of revenues of German companies in the sector, from 64% to 21% between 2005 and 2011. Despite multiple attempts at restructuring, Aleo Solar has never been able to regain competitiveness against the Chinese.  These dismissals first demonstrate that the crisis is affecting all EU Member States, including those deemed not to be affected by Chinese competition. Most importantly, the demand comes after Germany opposed the introduction of anti-dumping duties on Chinese panels in 2013, which were supposed to protect the European photovoltaic industry from Chinese production. If this decision is a matter of its sovereign choice, it is not for European taxpayers to pay the price. That is why I abstained exceptionally on this vote.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Solar energy, one of the most effective solutions to combat global warming, is being compromised at European level due to the effects of the economic crisis. Between 2005 and 2011, German companies registered a 43% decrease, while the Chinese increased by 34 percent because Asians produce more than they can use, so they have to export. This has affected production within the Union, as well as demand and consumption. The German company Aleo Solar is just one of the European companies in this sector that have gone bankrupt. Last year, over the course of just five months, 657 people were laid off. The company is now asking for EUR 1 094 760 for the reintegration into the labour market of these laid-off workers. I agree that this amount should go to the Germans, because I believe that the engine of the European economy must continue to operate, especially in the context of simmering conflicts that threaten stability in the area. In addition, solar energy produces electricity without polluting, and I believe that the money invested in this area can lead to more jobs than those invested in coal or natural gas.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Parliament has decided to accept The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request to intervene from Germany to help employees of Aleo Solar in Germany who have been greatly affected by the employment consequences of globalisation. Dismissed employees will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. The amount of aid amounts to EUR 1,094,760.  The demand is justified given the very high global competition in the solar module sector, with China being one of the main competitors. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which refers to the application made by Germany concerning 657 workers made redundant at Aleo Solar, a company operating in the manufacture of computers and electronics and optical products. Between 2005 and 2011, China's market share in this sector increased from 11% to 45%, while Germany's fell from 64% to 21%. The link between redundancies and major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation is therefore clear.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 476 out of 657 workers in the solar manufacturing sector in the German Federal State of Brandenburg who have been made redundant.  This is a particularly important issue for me as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local Bose factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community as a whole. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be made in this instance but adequate support for the workers in retraining and upskilling must be provided in any case.  The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as a justification for making workers redundant.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission has concluded that the application by the German authorities meets the conditions for deploying the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund set out in Article 4(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013. It is interesting to note that the coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded includes a number of useful measures such as vocational training, careers advice and guidance for the reintegration of 476 redundant workers into employment at a very difficult point in time. It is worrying to note that this company is just one of many other European solar enterprises that have become insolvent, quit the solar business, shut down production wholly or partially, or sold out to Chinese investors over the past few years (since 2010). I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This mobilisation of the EGF supports 476 redundant workers from the German company Aleo Solar AG, which was operating in the manufacture of computers and electronics and optical products. Upstream of the company's economic difficulties is Chinese competition for solar modules which, despite the EU's introduction of additional duties and a minimum price in 2013, manages to sell at prices below the production costs of German producers.  The coordinated package of tailor-made services to be co-financed aims at the occupational reintegration of workers; the redundancies in question have a particularly negative impact on the regional economy of Prenzlau/Brandenburg, an area already with a per capita income well below the national average and with the highest unemployment rates in Germany.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this text. Certainly, I support the 657 employees of Aleo Solar, currently in a situation of great economic distress. However, this situation could have been avoided if Germany had not made the choice to sell its industry to the benefit of Chinese production and to the detriment of its workers. Indeed, in 2013, Germany opposed the introduction of anti-dumping duties on Chinese solar panels. Out of 10,000 German companies in the sector, only 350 actually produce these panels, the others having dedicated themselves to the resale of Chinese products. Germany is now asking other Member States to partially correct its mistake, even though it has preferred to sell off its industry, especially for fear of Chinese sanctions on its exports. I do not consider that it is up to Aleo Solar employees to foot the bill; but in this particular case, I also do not consider it up to the taxpayers of the Member States, particularly the French taxpayers, to do so.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of this measure because the European Fund set up provides support for workers who are suffering from structural changes in world trade. The Fund may not exceed the annual ceiling of EUR 150 million (at 2011 prices). The amounts required shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a provision. The procedures that will be used to obtain the transfer of funding seem to me to be good and efficient.  The dialogue between the Commission and the Authority should ensure the success of the procedural agreement, see the Case of Aleo Solar, operating in the solar energy sector, which has finished its activity in view of the losses suffered in recent years, due to the strong release into the world market of structures from Asia and the high and incisive cost of labour. The intervention of the European Fund is a positive and decisive procedure aimed at supporting and defending individual European workers placed in the redundancy fund.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this question, which refers to the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Germany. In fact, while we manage to obtain the same products at lower prices thanks to globalisation, on the other hand we must specialise in sectors that are less affected by Asian competition.  In the adjustment phase, it is correct to redistribute some of these savings to those who are victims of this mechanism. I therefore consider the intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to be a correct procedure.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 1 094 760 in favour of Germany with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of the 657 workers made redundant, 390 of whom are in Aleo Solar AG.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in relation to Germany's application for the occupational reintegration of workers made redundant by Aleo Solar, a company specialising in the manufacture of optical products. Changes in the structure of world trade and falling demand in Europe have led to a drastic reduction in German market share for this product in recent years, and restructuring efforts have not been enough to prevent the company from having to make huge losses either. Aleo Solar's subsequent decision to close its German plant therefore poses the problem of re-employing the 476 redundant workers. The granting of co-financing from the EGF will help to implement a series of services to the person which, together with the actions implemented by the German authorities, it is hoped will lead to the rapid reintegration into the market of redundant workers.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments in order to provide additional support to workers who have been affected by the consequences of major structural shifts in world trade patterns and to support the reintegration of the same workers back into the labour market. The report states that 657 workers previously operating in the manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products have been made redundant. European Globalisation Adjustment Fund measures will target 476 redundant workers, to seek their reintegration in the labour market. Personalised services will include vocational training, careers advice and guidance, peer groups/workshops, entrepreneurship advice, inter-regional advice for mobility and job search by a professional job searcher. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it will provide additional opportunities and support to the workers (and their families) affected by these redundancies.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The German authorities submitted their request for financial assistance from the EGF, following the 657 redundancies, of which 390 were made by Aleo Solar AG, a company active in the production of computers, electronics and optical products, and 267 by its two subsidiaries.  I welcomed the fact that, in order to provide workers with rapid assistance, the German authorities decided to start carrying out personalised services to the workers concerned on 11 April 2014, well before the decision on the granting of EGF support. The redundancies at Aleo Solar AG are linked to major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. Photo Favorably the coordinated package of personalized services that co-finances measures for the reintegration of 476 redundant workers.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Germany, in the area of Prenzlau in the German Federal State of Brandenburg. The application relates to 657 redundancies of two sites of Aleo Solar AG, operating in the solar module manufacturing sector, during the reference period from 7 March 2014 to 7 July 2014. The EGAF funding provides assistance for the reintegration of 476 redundant workers into employment. As the report aims to help workers who need support to re-enter the work market, I voted in favour.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 390 employees at Aleo Solar AG and 267 employees in two of its subsidiaries in the solar panel sector, Germany has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support people who have lost their jobs and to help them find work or start their own businesses. The aid granted amounts to EUR 1,094,760 and covers 50% of the cost of the conversion projects that will be offered to these employees.  Since the request of the Federal Republic of Germany corresponds to the criteria for the mobilization of the EGF, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The solar module industry is experiencing profound difficulties in Europe, in particular due to competition from China. Subsidies to China's solar module production sector have created significant overcapacity causing prices to fall sharply. Today, more than 90% of China's production is exported, 80% of which is to the European Union.  In this context, the German company Aleo Solar and two of its subsidiaries laid off 657 employees in a region of Germany with a degraded social climate. Per capita income is well below the national average and the unemployment rate is 15.5%, one of the highest rates in Germany.  The intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is also an additional factor in supporting the actions already taken to help laid-off employees get back to work as quickly as possible. To do this, the funding from the EGF, to the tune of EUR 1,094,760, or 60% of the total cost of the proposed actions, will enable, among other things, to provide vocational training, facilitate inter-regional mobility, or to individualise support.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The German company Aleo Solar is one of several European solar energy companies to have been affected by major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation.  I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it will allow the reintegration into the labour market of the 657 workers made redundant at Aleo Solar.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted on 10 March 2015 to award a share of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to Aleo Solar.  Despite all efforts to restructure and become more efficient, the German company Aleo Solar, which specializes in photovoltaics, has failed to cope with the low production costs of Chinese companies and has therefore gone into liquidation. The assistance provided by this fund is thus necessary to help the workers of this company to find a job or take a new training.  Environmentalists point out that renewable energy must finally become a clear priority for the Union to ensure that these closures do not happen again.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 16 December 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Germany to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade.  According to the data referred to by the German authorities, Aleo Solar is only one of several European solar panel companies that have become insolvent in the last few years (since 2010), have ceased business in this area, partially or completely ceased production or sold the company to Chinese investors. Between 2005 and 2011, china's revenue increased from 11 % to 45 %, while Germany's fell from 64 % to 21 %. Personalised services should be co-financed, its coordinated package includes the following measures to reintegration 476 redundant workers: vocational training, career advice and career guidance, business advice, interregiocial mobility advice, job search with the help of a job search expert, follow-up mentoring for new workers who may need counselling to keep the job or who need to move elsewhere for the job, and training support equivalent to 60 % of the employee's previous net income.  The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. Germany has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 657 employees at Aleo Solar. China's dumping on the solar industry has forced many companies to lay off, due to declining market share in the European Union.  China's global revenues rose from 11% to 45% between 2005 and 2011, while Germany's revenues fell from 64% to 21% over the same period. Brussels has not taken the necessary measures to protect the Union's industries on time and watched them fail, to the benefit of our Asian competitors. Nevertheless, the German authorities and industrialists have a responsibility since they refused to let the European Union take such measures, thinking that it could, by using Chinese dumping, get rid of their competitors. That is why I abstained on this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they have lost their jobs as a result of changing global trade patterns, e.g. when a large company shuts down or a factory is moved to outside the EU, or the global financial and economic crisis. Negotiations on the renewal of the Fund concluded under the Multiannual Financial Framework Agreement and a new EGF Regulation is now in place. There are six EGF applications to be voted on from Poland, Germany and Belgium. The ECR is opposed in principle to the use of this fund and voted against the proposals.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the approach taken by the Commission and Parliament on these issues is completely wrong. Indeed, as evidenced by both the procedure and the legal bases, the problem is that the Union is losing markets and becoming increasingly uncompetitive internationally. An even bigger problem is that the internal market suffers from this imbalance and products are entering Europe en masse that are killing our own production. However, I do not see any serious steps to address these challenges. The EGF is an anachronism because the aid that is granted will neither solve the problems nor compensate workers who have lost their jobs. We need investment to increase jobs and increase growth, not hand out handouts and welfare benefits. The current model is wrong. I would add that my principled position as a member of the EQF Group is that this fund was fundamentally mistaken as a mechanism and I am opposed to such ineffective instruments. We need investment leading to growth, new jobs and increasing the qualification of workers, not social benefits.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I remain convinced that the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that provides support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to provide assistance to redundant workers as soon as possible. This was the case of the company Aleo Solar, of manufacture of solar panels. Aleo Solar is one of many European companies in the sector that in recent years (since 2010) have gone into insolvency, abandoned production, shut down production in whole or in part or sold the facilities to Chinese investors. Between 2005 and 2011, China's share of profits rose from 11% to 45%, while Germany's fell from 64% to 21%. The difficulties in that company are related to important structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the eligibility conditions of the eGF support application have been verified. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to improve the employability of all workers through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, on equal terms of treatment.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EGF was created to provide additional support to workers made redundant following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. In this context, I voted in favour of approving the German candidacy 'EGF/2014/014 DE/Aleo Solar', following 657 redundancies, 390 of which were in Aleo Solar AG, a company operating in the manufacturing sector of computer equipment, communication equipment, electronic and optical products'), and 267 at two of its subsidiaries, and 476 people are expected to participate in the measures, during and after the reference period, from 7 March 2014 to 7 July 2014.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again, the solar module manufacturing industry is again requesting the mobilisation of the EGF. In this case, we are facing the impact of the sale of a unit of components for solar panels, such as computer equipment, communication equipment and electronic and optical products to a Chinese consortium, which resulted in the maintenance of only 200 jobs, mainly linked to commercial and marketing areas, leaving 657 more workers without a job. Despite the company's continued success as a distributor of solar modules, it has lost market share in its production. In the two cities, Oldenburg and Prenzlau, per capita income is well below the national average and unemployment rates are the highest in Germany, with the prospect of specialised employment being almost absent, and there are no potential employers due to low population density, with a more aggravated risk of long-term unemployment.  Germany is therefore applying for EGF support to support the reintegration into the labour market of 476 redundant workers. In fact, this fund only represents limited immediate support for workers, in no way helping to address the consequences of the continued liberalisation of world trade and neoliberal policies continuously followed by the EU.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide additional support to workers in a German solar energy company.  Aleo Solar has gone into crisis due to Chinese production causing solar module prices to plummet. In 2013, the European Union approved additional duties on these products, but the price of Chinese solar modules remains lower than those produced by the German company.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission has decided to mobilise the EGF in favour of Germany after 657 workers lost their jobs as a result of a significant loss of market sales of Aleo Solar products. Between 2005 and 2011, China's share of income increased to 45 % and Germany's share fell to 21 %. Following the closure of the company in question, unemployment in the region has increased and the old age and low education of the redundancies make it impossible for them to find adequate employment. The amount of funding should be EUR 1 094 760.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of granting €1,094,760 for 657 redundancies in the photovoltaic panel manufacturing sector under the EGF due to the decrease in EU market shares. China's share has risen from 11% to 45%, while Germany's has fallen from 64% to 21%. It is one of the effects of the bursting of the photovoltaic bubble inflated by the EU due to its climate policy.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mobilisation report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - application EGF/2014/014 DE/Aleo Solar - Germany, because the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given basically to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The deployment of EUR 1 094 760 by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will enable assistance in looking for jobs, professional training, support in the creation of enterprises and other programmes for 476 German employees who have been made redundant by Aleo Solar, a company in the renewable energy sector. I therefore supported the deployment of these funds in the plenary vote.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization that, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation (e.g. closure of large enterprises or relocation of production outside the EU) or the global economic and financial crisis. That is why I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF/2014/014 DE/Aleo Solar application)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (FEAG) in Germany, in the Prenzlau area of the State of Brandenburg for an amount of EUR 1 094 760 for the application for 657 redundancies from two Plants of Aleo Solar AG, which operates in the solar module manufacturing sector. The layoffs were caused by major structural changes in global trade patterns: Aleo solar is one of many European companies operating in the field of solar energy that have been affected by China's strong position in that market sector.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. By unblocking the contributions provided for by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union is giving a concrete sign of support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, thus making it easier for them to re-enter the labour market. I therefore welcome the approval of the report on the case of the corporate reorganization of ALEO SOLAR.  In this case, as in many other cases, Europe intervenes only to cover the declines in competitiveness and to provide companies and workers with new tools for the conversion of skills and skills. These are certainly decisive instruments: the hope is that the efforts of new productive momentum that the EU has undertaken with the new Juncker Plan will gradually make EU companies finally stronger in the global market, thus reversing the decline that part of our industrial sector has suffered in recent years.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Hoffmann report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it fully complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGAF Regulation. I welcome that the The EGAF funding of EUR 1 094 760 shall contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 476 redundant workers into employment.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. Germany has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 657 employees at Aleo Solar.  These layoffs are the result of the loss of competitiveness of EU companies in the solar sector.  This is a result of much of China's dumping in the field of solar modules. Between 2005 and 2011, the market share of Chinese companies increased from 11 to 45%, while those of German companies fell from 64% to 21%. However, Germany itself refused in 2013 that Brussels take sanctions in the field of photovoltaics, making the cynical bet that Chinese dumping would rid it of its other European competitors.  This bet, the Germans lost, since the Chinese industrialists ended up ruining the entire European solar sector, including the German solar sector.   I have therefore abstained on this report, because I cannot endorse the attitude of the German authorities on this issue.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for the aleo Solar company in Germany, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the 657 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation particularly in the solar industry sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to offer assistance in Germany, in the area of Prenzlau in the German Federal State of Brandenburg, following 657 redundancies at two sites of Aleo Solar AG, operating in the solar module manufacturing sector. The funding of EUR 1 094 760 will contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 476 redundant workers into employment.
