The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, because this case in Germany fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation to receive the financial support. Redundancies were a consequence of globalisation and the help has to be provided.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for the aleo Solar company in Germany, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the 657 dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation, particularly in the solar industry sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a resolution by the European Parliament on a proposal by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the benefit of Germany's Aleo Solar AG and its two branches on the fact that they are affected by global globalisation developments that directly affect business workers and affect the prosperity of individual provinces.  Germany's share of solar modules has fallen over the past seven years from 64% to 21%, affecting Aleo Solar AG's sharp decline in turnover, and these layoffs will further worsen per capita income and unemployment rates in the city of Prenzlau, or brandenburg province.  I consider it positive to undertake a package of services tailored to the needs of workers, which will implement measures aimed at reinvolving workers in the labour market, and I support the recognition of workers' abilities and skills and tailored training programmes. In such cases, an active Union contribution is important, which can certainly support and encourage the reintegration of redundancy workers.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Germany has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 657 employees at Aleo Solar. China's dumping on the solar industry has forced many companies to lay off, due to declining market share in the European Union. China's global revenues rose from 11% to 45% between 2005 and 2011, while Germany's revenues fell from 64% to 21% over the same period. Brussels has not taken the necessary measures to protect the Union's industries on time and watched them fail, to the benefit of our Asian competitors. Nevertheless, the German authorities and industrialists have a responsibility since they refused to let the European Union take such measures, thinking that it could, by using Chinese dumping, get rid of their competitors. They lost that bet and the German solar sector is just the residue of what it was. That is why I abstained on this report.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Iris Hoffman's report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Aleo Solar in Germany.  The fund will provide EUR 1,094,760 for the 657 sacked employees of Aleo Solar, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on Germany's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for redundancies at Aleo Solar AG and two of its subsidiaries in Germany. The fund was created to support laid-off and self-employed workers who are out of work due to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization or the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis. I am the the fore, the case for the adoption of this aid, amounting to EUR 1,094,760.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as I believe it is a major move to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade while facilitating their reintegration into the labour market quickly and effectively.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The European Commission has proposed to provide Germany with EUR 1 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFG) to help 476 former employees of Aleo Solar AG and two subsidiaries find new jobs. These redundancies were the result of structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, in particular the declining share of European companies in the global solar module market. Since the disbursements are not a form of additional unemployment benefit, but measures for the reintegration of those affected into the labour market, I agree with the request.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made by Aleo Solar. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Aleo Solar was a large employer in the Prenzlau/Brandenburg region of Germany and the 657 redundancies which have resulted from its closure, have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy, which was already struggling with high unemployment. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to the local economy and support the workers affected.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers back into the labour market who have been made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In my vote, I supported Mr McDerman's report. Hoffmann because I regard the decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Germany as a concrete signal of aid, capable of encouraging the reintegration into the labour market of 657 redundancies declared by the Aleo Solar plant.  In a context of economic crisis such as the one we are experiencing, we have repeatedly had the opportunity to stress the importance and effectiveness of an instrument such as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. After having already done so in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of the Hoffmann report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 476 sacked employees of Aleo Solar and two of its subsidiaries (Germany). The EGF will fund vocational training activities, career counselling, peer groups and workshops supplemented by a training allowance, business start-up assistance, inter-regional assistance and post-employment follow-up to the TUNE of EUR 1,094,760. The WEF is once again demonstrating its usefulness in supporting sectors challenged by globalization and vectors of mass unemployment that is difficult to contain.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The payment of European funds to the German photovoltaic equipment production sector questions the relevance of Germany's opposition in 2013 to the implementation of protection measures in this sector vis-à-vis China. The refusal to allow the EU to raise specific tariffs was motivated by Germany's national strategy to defend the services of the sector rather than the industrial production of solar panels in particular.  If I support the protection of national interests, it is not acceptable for a Member State to benefit double from its influence through European funds. That's why I abstained.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. Germany has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 657 employees at Aleo Solar and its subsidiaries. China's unfair competition in the solar industry, aided by the European Union's free trade policy, has led many European companies to lay off workers.  However, the German authorities and industrialists have a responsibility because they refused to protect them when this protection was in the best interests of these companies. That is why I abstained on this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Germany, in the Prenzlau area of the State of Brandenburg. The application concerns 657 redundancies from two plants of Aleo Solar AG, which operates in the solar module manufacturing sector, during the reference period from 7 March 2014 to 7 July 2014. The layoffs were caused by major structural changes in global trade patterns: Aleo Solar is one of many European companies operating in the field of solar energy that have been affected by China's strong position in that market sector. The EGF funding amounts to EUR 1 094 760 and will serve for the conversion of the sector and workers, with which we agree.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 657 redundancies, 390 of them at Aleo Solar AG, a company operating in division 26 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacturing of computer, electronic and optical products', and 267 in its two subsidiaries, with 476 people expected to take action. These redundancies occurred during the reference period from 7 March to 7 July 2014 and after that period, due to a decrease in the Union's market share in the solar energy sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Germany, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. As regards Germany's financial contribution on budgetary matters and sound financial management of the EGF, on the basis of the reports submitted, I believe that the operations carried out by Germany in advance in favour of the workers concerned are appropriate. Due to the change in the world trade model, increasing China's revenues in solar modules and thus reducing those of Germany, there have been sharp increases in the unemployment of Germany, specifically affecting Aleo Solar AG in the Prenzlau region of Brandenburg. This Fund will therefore provide a reintegration into the labour market for the 476 dismissed workers along with many other aid, especially in vocational training. It must also be taken into account that long-term unemployment is a fact and that workers will therefore have to accept jobs in other regions. Along with this, specialized measures will be carried out aimed at workers in a situation riskier by their age. I therefore conclude that due to the important role of this Fund in achieving improvements in Germany's labour market due to the impact of globalisation, that EGF Decision must be adopted.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report on the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of the German solar energy company "Aleo Solar" which was forced to lay off 657 employees from March 2014 to July 2014 due to the impact of the economic crisis. The layoffs were due to a large drop in prices in the solar energy market due to china overproduction. The numbers confirming this are the decline of the German share of income in this market from 64% to 21% between 2005 and 2011, while in the same period China's share of revenues rose from 11% to 45%. In 2013, The European Union has approved additional duties on solar energy imported from China, however it is still below the production costs of German producers. In December 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of almost €1.1 million (which is 60% of the total resources needed to implement the plan) for the German company. Of the 657 laid-offs, 467 former employees will participate in the scheme, of which 214 are women and 332 people belonging to the 30-54 age group.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour with the other 465 Members, and the Hoffman report was adopted.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Aleo Solar AG's case is an example of the European Union's need to focus constantly on increasing competitiveness and taking measures to do so. It is always necessary to be one step ahead of such situations. The means that will be used to mitigate the impacts would be better used to find innovative solutions that will not lead to job losses, but on the contrary. It should be appreciated that a significant part of the support provided will be directed towards contributions and incentives aimed at training redundant workers in order to avoid long-term unemployment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, because as the European Parliament notes in this Report , the coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes measures for the reintegration into the labour market of 476 redundant persons such as vocational training, vocational guidance, business advice, interregional advice, job search by a job specialist and subsequent guidance for workers who have found new work.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this German request for the solar panel industry. Indeed, in 2013 Germany chose to develop services rather than industrial production of these panels, which now results in the closure of Aleo Solar. Germany now decides to make Europe, and therefore the other Member States, pay the consequences of its choice. It was therefore impossible to support this proposal.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. Aleo Solar in 2010 had a turnover of EUR 550 million and a profit of EUR 43 million; this declined rapidly from 2011, and by 2013 had reached losses of EUR 92 million. Despite various efforts to restructure and improve efficiency, it did not manage to return to profitability, and went into liquidation and closed or sold off its facilities, while some other German solar companies struggling with losses moved production to the Far East, e.g. Malaysia.  The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded includes following measures for the reintegration of 476 redundant workers into employment: vocational training, careers advice and guidance, peer groups/workshops, entrepreneurship advice, inter-regional advice for mobility, job search by a professional job searcher, follow-up mentoring for workers who have found a new job but might need advice to secure this job or because it involves resettling, a training allowance of 60% of the worker's previous net income.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, presented by Germany, for a financial contribution of EUR 1 094 760, following 657 redundancies, 390 of which at Aleo Solar AG – of two of its subsidiaries in Germany – a company operating in the manufacture of computers and electronics and optical products. I consider it of the utmost importance to protect redundant workers and to enable them to benefit from EGF financial measures as an incentive for their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to changes in the structure of world trade due to the advance of globalisation between 2005 and 2011, Germany's share of revenue fell from 64%, to 21%. My agreement with the report signed by Mr Hoffmann reflects the conviction that, the EGF, must be mobilised promptly to cope with the redundancies of 657 workers at Aleo Solar, located in the Brandenburg region, which has some of the highest unemployment rates in Germany.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion, as we need to take measures to cushion the damage to the German economy in recent years. This damage was caused by the shift in world trade patterns, by overproduction and by the saturation of the market. Workers suffering the consequences of structural changes must be supported in addition.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of retraining people who have lost their jobs after failing to err in Asian competition, and forced a significant reduction in the scope of its activities by one of the largest employers in the German Prenclau and Brandenburg region, Aleo Solar AG. Unemployment rates in the region are among the highest in Germany. The funds are necessary to solve social problems as soon as possible and to return to the labour market as many as 657 people of working age who have been made redundant.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The case of this globalization aid fund is exemplary. This aid helps the laid-off workers of a solar module company, victims of the hypocritical policy of the German-led Union. On the one hand, free and undistorted competition and relocations are encouraged, on the other, a miserable remedy is created with the "potential negative consequences" of this policy. Since the plant was purchased by a Chinese company, some of the employees will be rehired. The Fund is therefore used here to finance a restructuring of the plant.  I vote against it to disagree with Merkel's policy of destroying jobs and entire families.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to the German that submitted the EGF/2014/014 DE/Aleo Solar application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 657 redundancies, 390 of which were in Aleo Solar AG, a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 26 ('Manufacture of computer equipment, communication equipment, electronic and optical products') of NACE Rev. 2, and 267 in two of its subsidiaries.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the EU’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise the EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 476 workers in Germany due to the downward shift amongst solar module companies.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report giving the green light for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Germany, in the area of Prenzlau in the German Federal State of Brandenburg. The application relates to 657 redundancies at two sites of Aleo Solar AG, which operates in the solar module manufacturing sector, during the reference period from 7 March 2014 to 7 July 2014.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  This application to the EGF concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 094 760 in favour of Germany, with respect to 657 redundancies in the reference period from 7 March 2014 to 7 July 2014. I am voting in favour of mobilising the funds in question, due to the fact that Aleo Solar was one of the many European solar panel manufacturing companies that, in recent years (since 2010), have entered into insolvency, abandoned the activity, shut down all or part of production or sold the facilities to Chinese investors.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. In this report, we are asked to cover the damage caused by the ultra-liberal policy pursued by Brussels. Once again, the European Union is playing the arsonist fireman by trying to put out the fire that it has lit itself. It will thus try to partially compensate for the damage it causes by its ultraliberal ideology. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to shock anyone.  I abstained for this assistance to employees, believing that the measures taken were insufficient and the report was not explicit.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation with the exception of two where the number of employees is lower than that specified in the regulation. There is a precedent for this and Parliament supports their applications.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of 1.1 million euros to support the reclassification of 657 employees laid off by Aleo Solar and its subsidiaries in the Brandenburg and Weser-Ems regions. These companies operate in the manufacturing of computer, electronic and optical products.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted five reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of its five reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release 1 million euros from this fund to 476 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of Aleo Solar in Germany.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Germany, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of aleo solar workers, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade.  According to the information provided by the German authorities, Aleo Solar is one of several European solar energy companies that have been declared insolvent, that it has closed its solar energy business, that it has ceased production, in part or in full, or that it has sold the company to Chinese investors in recent years. All this due to the growing presence on the world market of Chinese industry: China has acquired huge overcapacity in solar modules, which neither its consumers nor the world market are able to absorb; This, together with falling demand worldwide, has led to a fall in prices.  This European aid package will be used to reintegrate 476 redundant workers into the labour market through vocational training, counselling and vocational guidance measures.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it proposes to compensate, through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, all the collateral victims of certain economic operations generated on a global scale. As such, I fully support all actions aimed at strengthening cohesion within our continent by protecting its workers and strengthening the social dimension of the European project.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This application relates to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, totalling EUR 1 094 760, in favour of Germany. My vote in favour of mr Hoffmann's report stems from the conviction that the 657 workers made redundant at Aleo Solar, a company operating in the manufacture of computers and electronics and optical products, have the right to be adequately supported by the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the implementation of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - the request of EGF DE/Aleo Solar as special rapporteur of the Social Democratic Group in the European Parliament for egf Funds.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the material and formal conditions for mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund are in place in this case and I hope that the promised financial resources will give the employees and workers concerned a view for the future. I therefore hope that there are also positive aspects to the economic prosperity of the region.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution to allocate EUR 1 094 760 from the EGF fund to Germany, which will allow 657 people who were unemployed as a result of redundancy. Unemployment in the European Union increased dramatically as a result of the economic crisis. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the European Union has put in place appropriate legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market; that Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission; having regard to the adoption of the new EGF Regulation, reflecting the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the reintroduction of the mobilisation criterion following the crisis; Given that the request for assistance meets the eligibility conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 In the time period from 2005 to 2011, the solar modules business sector increased from $21 billion to $36 billion, increasing by 79%. However, Chinese and Taiwanese companies have faster and higher revenue growth than those of German and American companies. Between 2005 and 2011, China's share of revenues rose from 11% to 45% while in Germany revenues fell from 64% to 21%. Aleo Solar in 2010 had a turnover of 550 million euros and profits of 43 million euros. This has been weakening since 2011, with losses of €92 million by 2013. Employment at the company fell from 995 workers (2011) to 740 (2013). Aleo Solar goes into liquidation, and closes or sells its facilities. The application concerns 390 technology surplus workers at Aleo Solar AG during the reference period of four months and 267 technology surplus workers from their subsidiaries during the same period observed. The Commission therefore proposes to mobilise the EGF by €1 094 760, representing 60% of the total cost of the proposed measures in order to ensure a financial contribution for application.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help Germany with a technological surplus in the solar module manufacturing industry with EUR 1 094 760, representing 60% of the total cost of the proposed measures. Member States need to show solidarity towards each other when needed and I am pleased that they have shown this today in this example. Aleo Solar AG generated a turnover of EUR 550 million in 2010 and a profit of EUR 43 million, while since 2011 there has been a sharp decline and losses of EUR 92 million in 2013. The layoffs at Aleo Solar AG will have a negative impact on the city of Prenzlau and the province of Brandenburg, where per capita income is far below the national average and unemployment rates of 15.5% and 16.4%, the highest in Germany. Renewables are Europe's future, so we should do everything we can to encourage their development and help them when they find themselves in difficulty.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At a time when Europe is facing a financial, economic and social crisis and unemployment as a key consequence, the European Union should use all means at its disposal to react, in particular as regards ensuring support for people who have lost their jobs.  Germany applied to EGF/2014/014 DE/Aleo Solar for financial contributions from the EGF as a result of the dismissal of 657 persons, of which 390 were from Aleo Solar AG, which deals with activities – the production of computers and electronic and optical products, and 267 from their two subsidiaries.  Redundancies at the company are linked to major structural changes in global trade flows caused by globalisation, as between 2005 and 2011 China's share of revenues increased from 11% to 45%, while Germany's share fell from 64% to 21%. At the same time, the layoffs will have a profoundly negative impact on the city of Prenzlau and the province of Brandenburg, where per capita income is far below the national average and unemployment rates, which are 15.5% and 16.44%, the highest in Germany.  I therefore support Rapporteur Iris Hoffmann's report on the mobilisation of €1,094,760, which accounts for 60% of the total budget, as this will help redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At this time of global economic and financial crisis, it is right to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers made redundant by companies as a result of redundancies and terminations.  The demand made by Aleo Solar (a German solar energy company which has been put into liquidation) also stems from strong competition from Chinese production. Although the European Union approved additional duties on solar modules originating in China in 2013 and a minimum selling price, this was still lower than the German company's production costs.  In my vote in favour, I felt it was worth helping workers made redundant from this company who will benefit from measures co-financed by the EGF for reintegration into the labour market through a package of personalised services, such as vocational training measures, counselling and vocational guidance, entrepreneurship counselling, interregional counselling, job search accompanied by a job search professional , post-event tutoring and worker counselling.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Let me also comment on this report. However, the remark I want to make is also part of the reports by Mr Plankic, Mr Negresca and Mrs Jäätteenmäki. Once again, I want to express my doubts about whether almost all of the funds from this fund are to go to the so-called old Member States. I will support the reports despite these doubts, but I firmly believe that there will be a change in this regard.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The process of globalisation has opened Up European markets to international competition, leading to economic and structural changes for our companies. The EU has therefore set up a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to mitigate the effects of globalisation on European economies, but especially on workers. It is important to note that not all of our international trading partners apply the same competition laws, which can create distortions of competition and thus bankrupt some companies.  The fund was requested in 2015 by Germany to support a solar energy company. In the face of unfair Chinese competition, European companies in this sector have been severely weakened and many have gone bankrupt. I support this request and stress the importance of this fund in order to enable European companies in the solar energy sector to face increased international competition and to be able to retain their employees.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the activation of the EGF/2014/014DE/Aleo Solar, as this application meets the eligibility criteria. Whereas, between 2005 and 2011, China's production in this sector increased profits from 11 % to 45 %, while Germany fell from 64 % to 21 %, which shows, among other factors, the difficulty of this German company in competing in a market more globalised for the competition referred to in this document. At the same time, it is known that China has created surplus solar module production capacities, which neither its domestic market nor the international market can absorb, leading to a decline in prices.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of legislative and budgetary instruments to provide complementary support to the most diverse sectors has proved to be a positive measure in the transition and adjustment of Member States to the era of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool in that it can serve to reintegrate people and businesses into the global market. In this case, and in view of the situation presented, the aid provided to Germany is relevant.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 094 760 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 657 workers who have lost their jobs in Aleo Solar, dedicated to the manufacture of solar modules in the Prenzlau/Brandenburg region of Germany, due to a decline in the Union's market share in the solar energy sector. Aleo Solar is one of many European solar energy companies that have declared the sector insolvent, abandoned the sector, ceased production in whole or in part, or sold their facilities to Chinese investors in recent years. The growth in Chinese production that enjoys financial support under China's current five-year plan (2011-2015) has led to a huge excess of capacity of solar modules, which neither its own consumers nor the global market can absorb. This is joined by a decline in global demand, which has led to the collapse of prices.  The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include vocational training activities, professional advice and guidance, business-building guidance or interregional mobility advice.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the redundancies at the German company Aleo Solar, as these contributions are a valuable aid in enabling the retraining and reclassification of workers, thanks in particular to training tailored to the opportunities of the job market.  Nevertheless, the job losses in many sectors are a painful reminder that these aids are not a miracle cure and that it is essential to pursue a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. More broadly, Europe needs to put in place a real coordinated industrial policy focused on creating sustainable jobs in sectors of the future. In addition, weASee procedures should be accelerated and simplified to enable laid-off workers to cope with difficulties as soon as they arise.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of structural changes in international trade, it is important that the European economy is able to effectively implement the instruments to support workers who are affected in this way and thus empower them towards their reintegration into the labour market. Bearing this assumption, I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Germany, amounting to EUR 1 094 760, following redundancies at Aleo Solar AG and two subsidiaries. With this financial contribution from the EGF, it will be possible to co-finance active labour market measures leading to long-term and long-term employment, as well as to allocate self-employment grants, encouraging hiring and fostering entrepreneurship.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report in order to unlock financial and professional assistance for the 657 licensees of Aleo Solar in Germany. These layoffs followed market share losses and the development of overproduction of solar modules by China.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will contribute up to 50% of the financial aid provided through training activities.  Once again, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund proves its full usefulness, so I supported this report in order to continue our commitments to a fairer And closer Europe to the citizens.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of several ways in which the European Union is actually helping European citizens. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which can help German workers.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I abstained because, while I symact with those who have lost their jobs, I believe that the situation of these people depends to a large part not on the market but on the eu's wrong energy policies.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which authorizes the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for a total of EUR 1,094,760 to help reintegrate 476 German workers made redundant by their employer, the solar energy company Aleo Solar.  This company did not resist Chinese dumping on solar modules and was put into liquidation. In recent years, China has flooded the global solar panel market, causing a dramatic drop in prices for European industry.  The financial support provided by Chinese manufacturers has enabled them to sell their stocks cheaply. More than 90% of China's production is exported, 80% of which is to the EU. The European Commission has been slow to react to this unfair competition. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up on the initiative of France to help workers who lose their jobs due to major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Germany's application complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It affects 657 unemployed people. The EU's market share of the world solar panel market plummeted dramatically in 2011, by as much as 40%, as a result of dumping by Chinese suppliers. Aleo solar sought to adapt to the changed market situation through a number of measures, but despite these, a profit of more than EUR 40 million in 2010 had turned into a loss of more than EUR 90 million until 2013. The situation in Aleo Solar is strongly affected in the Prenzlau and Brandenburg regions, which have the highest unemployment rates in Germany. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. In this case, the use of the European Adjustment Fund does not appear to us to be justified because of a too distant relationship with the subject of globalisation.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 657 redundancies, 390 of them at Aleo Solar AG, a company operating in division 26 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacturing of computer, electronic and optical products', and 267 in its two subsidiaries, with 476 people expected to take action. These redundancies occurred during the reference period from 7 March to 7 July 2014 and after that period, due to a decrease in the Union's market share in the solar energy sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Germany, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Thanks to todayʼs vote Germany was granted aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant from Aleo Solar AG, a company operating in the NACE 2 Division 26 ʽManufacturing of computer, electronic and optical productsʼ.  The 657 redundancies, during and after the reference period from 7 March 2014 to 7 July 2014, are linked to a decline in the European Unionʼs market share in solar module companies. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded includes the following measures for the reintegration of 476 redundant workers into employment: vocational training, careers advice and guidance, peer groups/workshops, entrepreneurship advice, inter-regional advice for mobility and job search by a professional job searcher. The EGF will mobilise a total amount of EUR 1 094 760 for Germany. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers receive none of this support therefore.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. The application for a financial contribution submitted by Germany to aid to Aleo Solar AG, in which 657 redundancies were made in 2014, fulfils the eligibility criteria for the aid. The company's layoffs were the result of major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation, with China's market share increasing from 11 % to 45 % between 2005 and 2011 and Germany's market share declining from 64 % to 21 %. In addition, in 2011 the prices of solar modules fell below the production costs of Aleo Solar. Layoffs are likely to have major negative consequences in the Prenzlau/Brandenburg region, where the unemployment rate is highest in Germany and per capita income well below the national average. However, since it is possible that the German authorities will use all the funds received from this fund as compensation for training of 60% of the previous net income, which could have the sign of a passive social security measure, I abstained from the vote.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to support 476 German employees of Aleo Solar, a company operating in the solar module market. These redundancies, which took place between March and July last year, are a consequence of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation, in particular competition from countries such as China, which produces at lower production costs than Germany, leading to an overload in the solar module market that is not absorbed by the market. These redundancies have had a particularly negative impact on the economy of the Brandenburg region, which has one of the highest unemployment rates in Germany. The €1,094,760 aid provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help cover part of the costs of assistance and accompaniment in job search, vocational training, business creation support and other programmes aimed at reintegrating the 476 redundant workers into the labour market.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 I support the education of employees and young people in the affected region. At the same time, I am aware of the importance of the right economic policy that precedes such situations.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution as Germany has applied to EGF/2014/014 DE/Aleo Solar for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of the dismissal of 657 persons, 390 of them from Aleo Solar AG, engaged in activities under section 26 of the NACE 2 classification 'Computer manufacturing and electronic and optical products'. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation and Germany is entitled to a financial contribution under the Regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will mobilise resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - Given that the EU has put in place certain legislative and budgetary instruments adapted to assist workers as a result of major structural changes, union financial assistance to redundanised workers should be as effective as possible.  Germany applied for a financial contribution from the EGF due to the redundancies of a large number of employees from Aleo Solar AG, which produces computers and electronic and optical products, and in the application met all the necessary criteria. Also, the layoffs at Aleo Solar AG are directly related to changes in world trade flows caused by globalization and have a negative impact on the city of Prenzlau and the province of Brandenburg.  I support this report because the EGF does not exceed the maximum annual amount and I believe that mobilisation should be made possible in this case.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted against because I do not consider the granting of the allowance to be correct, also in view of the matters set out in the explanatory memorandum to this proposal. According to the report, the redundancies are due to 'the huge overcapacity of solar modules in China that cannot be absorbed by its own consumers or consumers on the world market'. This exists despite additional tariffs and minimum prices for solar modules approved by the EU in 2013. However, the inability to compete with global producers is mainly due to the EU's high regulatory burden, in this case probably mainly due to substantially higher electricity prices.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds for a financial contribution from the redundancies of workers from the German company Aleo Solar. In the last few years, many solar energy companies have become insolvent in Germany, so they have abandoned solar energy operations, closed all or part of production, or sold them to Chinese investors. I believe that we must help all Member States, and especially the people who have lost their jobs as a result of changes in world trade flows, to help as quickly and efficiently as possible so that we can get new jobs. In accordance with the European principle of solidarity, we will help the 476 workers made redundant to get out of the difficult situation they find themselves in as quickly as possible.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour! The support measures had been implemented as soon as the redundancies were announced in consultation with the social partners and in partnership with the regional public employment services. In the meantime, we have pleaded with Commissioners Thyssen and Malmstrom for greater coordination so that international trade agreements do not completely destroy European industrial employment.  These 5.2 million are important to the Walloon economic fabric. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves should not be the rule. It should be remembered that this aid was made indispensable because an international industrialist wanted to play with the destiny of workers, treating them with disdain and great disrespect. Europe must send a strong message to all the Lakshmi Mittals of the world that in Europe there are no castes or untouchables. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. Aleo Solar was a major employer in the Prenzlau/Brandenburg region and the increased competition with China on the solar modules market led to 657 redundancies. This fund will be used to develop appropriate training courses to reintegrate these workers in the job market. I believe it will set the path to durable and long-term employment in the region.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment for cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management to help the company Aleo Solar in Germany, to improve the training of its employees and thus ensure the viability of the company in the long term. Globalisation and Chinese competition mean that many companies have to adapt to continue competing.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The Delegation has a habit of systematically voting on the "European Globalisation Adjustment Funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultraliberal policies applied in this European Union unable to defend neither the peoples who make up it nor the companies that make it live. Nevertheless, the Delegation abstained on this particular issue because in 2013 Germany strongly opposed the introduction of anti-dumping duties on Chinese solar panels (although it was unsuccessful). Germany had therefore made a clear choice to favour the services sector over domestic industrial production (for fear of Chinese retaliation on its exports). To propose today to the Union to pay the bill is to make fun of the world.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is a financial instrument that allows money to be allocated to people who lose their jobs due to the economic and financial crisis or because of changes in the structure of world trade with globalisation. Unlike the Structural and Investment Funds, which target strategic, long-term projects, this fund provides time-limited, one-off and individual support. Aleo Solar is a German company that decided to close two production facilities in Germany. The closure of the two units led to the dismissal of 657 employees in 2014. The request submitted to the Commission envisages the allocation of a sum of EGF money to co-finance a coordinated package of personalised services for the reintegration into work of redundant workers. Following the analysis of the request, the Commission adopted in December 2014 the proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Germany to support the reintegration of redundant persons into the labour market. The European Parliament's report found that all eligibility criteria have been met and supports the allocation of the requested amount from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. As with the other requests for the activation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Germany, which applied for a financial contribution of EUR 1 million following 657 redundancies at Aleo Solar, which operates in the solar panel sector.  The sector has suffered greatly across Europe from fierce Chinese competition, posting huge losses in recent years, leaving many workers at home. As this is a central area for the implementation of the European strategy for sustainable growth, I believe, however, that the problem of protecting and reviving the solar panel sector must be addressed above all within the framework of more strategic and coordinated programmes.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following 657 redundancies, 390 of them at Aleo Solar AG, a company operating in division 26 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacturing of computer, electronic and optical products', and 267 in its two subsidiaries, with 476 people expected to take action. These redundancies occurred during the reference period from 7 March to 7 July 2014 and after that period, due to a decrease in the Union's market share in the solar energy sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Germany, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for the aleo Solar company in Germany, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the 657 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation particularly in the solar industry sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again, Aleo Solar AG, germany, faced with the impact of the sale of its unit of solar panel components, such as computer equipment, communication equipment and electronic and optical products, to a Chinese consortium, had to resort to the dismissal of workers. This resulted in the maintenance of only 200 jobs, mainly related to commercial and marketing areas, leaving 657 more workers without jobs.  In the two cities, Oldenburg and Prenzlau, where per capita income is well below the national average and unemployment rates are the highest in Germany, there are no potential employers due to low population density, with a more aggravated risk of long-term unemployment.  Germany is therefore applying for EGF support to support the reintegration into the labour market of 476 redundant workers through vocational training, advice and vocational guidance, entrepreneurship advice, among others. In fact, this fund is just a palliative that does nothing to address the consequences of the continued liberalisation of world trade and neoliberal policies continuously followed by the EU.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. This motion has also received my approval. By shifting world trade patterns and overproduction and saturation of the market, we must take measures to mitigate the damage this has caused to the German economy.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The Globalisation Fund was set up to help with short-term emergencies due to mismanagement, globalisation or the financial and moral crisis in the Member States. Support includes training, business start-up grants, coaching and outplacement of redundant workers. The Globalisation Fund co-finances these job creation measures at 50% or 65%, with the balance being provided by the Member State concerned. This makes the EU Commission a gigantic labour market agency. Nevertheless, the European Court of Auditors said in a special audit report that this "globalisation fund" provides only limited EU added value and should be replaced by a more efficient regime. It was explicitly stated that this Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support. And yet the EU is continuing the policy, which has been shown to be inefficient. This mobilisation in direct connection with the solar market crisis in Germany, caused by the grotesque EEG reform, must be rejected in its full terms. The EEG must be terminated. I cannot therefore agree with this mobilisation.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approves the financial support for redundant workers, the German company Aleo Solar AG, through the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which I voted for. The EGF is established to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of global structural changes in trade, and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. This case concerns a request by Germany to support dismissed persons and fulfils the eligibility conditions as laid down in the relevant regulation. The German authorities submitted the request on 29 July 2014 and the Commission notified its assessment on 16 December 2014. Aleo Solar AG, is active in the manufacturing of computer, electronic and optical products. The redundancies took place in 2014, and are an impact of competition with China in the production and trade of solar panels. This company had a turnover of EUR 550 million in 2010 and a profit of EUR 43 million, but fell sharply from 2011 and by 2013 had turned into losses of EUR 92 million.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Again, the solar module manufacturing industry is returning to ask for support after the dismissal of workers from Aleo Solar AG in Germany, and is expected not to be the last. In this case, it is about mitigating the impact of the sale of its unit of components for solar panels, such as computer equipment, communication equipment and electronic and optical products to a Chinese consortium, which resulted in the maintenance of only 200 jobs, mainly related to commercial and marketing areas, leaving 657 more workers without jobs. Despite the company's continued success as a distributor of solar modules, it has lost market share in its production and trade. It happened in two cities, Oldenburg and Prenzlau, where per capita income is well below the national average and unemployment rates are the highest in Germany.  Germany is therefore applying for EGF support to support the reintegration into the labour market of 476 workers made redundant through vocational training, advice and vocational guidance, entrepreneurship advice, among others. In fact, this fund only represents limited immediate support for workers, nothing to address the consequences of the continued liberalisation of world trade also followed by the EU.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of the German company Aleo Solar AG, as the redundancies in this company had a negative impact on the Prenzlau/Brandenburg region, where per capita income is well below the national average and the unemployment rate is 15.5% and 16.4% respectively in Germany. The redundancies of over-workers at Aleo Solar AG are linked to major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation – in particular China's capacity in this sector, which goes beyond the needs of both Chinese consumers and the global market. Between 2005 and 2011, China's market share in the computer, electronic and optical products sector increased from 11 % to 45 %, while Germany's market share decreased from 64 % to 21 %. In 2011 the prices of solar modules decreased by 40% compared to 2010 – below the production costs of Aleo Solar AG. In 2013, the EU granted additional duties on solar modules originating in China and a minimum price, which is still lower than the cost of production of the German producers.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 708 workers in two companies, related to the closure of Duferco and the reductions in staff in NLMK, operating in NACE Rev. 2, division 24 'Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products" and are located in La Louviare, in the province of Henao. These redundancies took place during the reference period from 22 January to 22 October 2013 and are related to the decrease in the Union's market share in the steel production sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU. These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving Belgium's application EGF/2013/007 BE/Hainaut Steel (Duferco-NLMK) for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by the Belgian authorities in the wake of the closure of Duferco and the reduction of staff at NLMK. This fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Fund finances individually adapted measures for the reintegration of jobseekers, promotes self-employment and business start-ups, and grants mobility allowances and allowances for disadvantaged or older workers. The redundancies and the subsequent closure of the two plants can be explained by the fact that the EU market share fell sharply, while the Chinese market increased during the same period. Similarly, the decline in demand for steel due to the economic crisis and the rise in production costs have affected the competitiveness of the steel industry in the EU. It is therefore gratifying that the EU has accepted Belgium's request and is providing funds to support the redundant workers, in the hope of helping them to achieve lasting, long-term and therefore stable employment through the measures taken.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 708 employees of the steel companies Duferco and NLMK, located in La Louvière. Duferco closed and NMLK reduced its staff.  These dismissals occurred between 22 January and 22 October 2013. Their origin is the decline in the market share of European industries in steel production. The opening of borders, particularly in the automotive sector, has weakened the European steel industry. Between 2006 and 2011, the share of raw steel in the European Union rose from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes. During the same period, world production increased from 1,249 million tonnes to 1,548.3 million tonnes.  As a result, European production fell from 16.5 per cent to 11.4 per cent of world production. The globalization of trade has mainly benefited China, whose market share in steel production has increased from 33.7% to 45%.  That is why I voted in favour of this EUR 981,956 aid to Belgium, to enable it to help the victims of the deindustrialisation desired by the European Union.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Belgium, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, although I have some reservations about the relevance of the timetable for the implementation of this tool, I support its primary vocation. For my part, the adjustment to globalization should be achieved upstream or at the beginning of the company's financial problems rather than at the time of accounting for the number of licensees.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for German purposes in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Aleo Solar, which operates in the field of solar power production. Aleo Solar is just one of many European solar companies that have become insolvent over the last few years, have ceased its solar business, completely or partially ceased production, or sold to Chinese investors. Between 2005 and 2011, China's share of income increased from 11% to 45%, while Germany's share of income fell from 64% to 21%. The EGF is intended to provide a total amount of EUR 1 094 760 to 657 redundant workers. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training, and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Opposed to this hypocritical system of the 'Globalisation Adjustment Fund', I nevertheless voted in favour of this report which proposes to unlock aid for the former Belgian employees of the steel companies Duferco and NLMK: since this fund exists, it may as well be used to help European workers in distress. But once again, instead of trying to mitigate the effects, it is the causes that should be tackled by protecting European employees from savage globalisation.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Belgium requested the support of the EGF after the layoffs at Duferco and NLMK in La Louvière, in particular following the decrease in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors. Europe has released almost 1 million euros to help more than 700 workers. Of course, I can only welcome this assistance, which will amplify the effort made in training and reorienting these workers in the field of vocational training and reorientation.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to alleviate the problems arising after the dismissal of 708 workers in two companies, in relation to the closure of Duferco and the reductions in staff in NLMK, 'manufacturing iron, steel and ferroalloy products', located in La Louviare, in Henao province; these redundancies took place between 22 January 2013 and 22 October 2013, and are related to the decrease in the Union's market share in the steel production sector.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following 708 redundancies in two companies following the closure of Duferco and staff reductions in NLMK, companies involved in the manufacture of base metals, in La Louvière (Belgian Hainaut). I therefore voted for the granting of AID from the EGF to the tune of EUR 981,956.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, with my vote, the mobilisation of the EGF worth EUR 981 956 in favour of 708 employees made redundant in Belgium in the steel sector. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an indispensable instrument for remedying the malfunctioning of the internal market, but I would also like to stress here that its activation process must be speeded up in order to support our citizens more strongly.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have today voted in favour of this report. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, globalisation is not the only reason why so many jobs have been lost in Europe. The EU itself has decided on the destructive austerity policy. It's got to stop. We need an expansive policy, with public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 981 956 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 708 workers who have lost their jobs in Duferco and NLMK, companies located in La Louviare, Belgium, and dedicated to steel production, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The steel manufacturing sector has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in EU market share, which has been exacerbated by other factors such as declining demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include different training and recycling needs for workers. While these aids are not in themselves capable of alleviating the drama of unemployment in the European steel sector, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to support 701 redundancies from The Belgian company Hainaut Steel and to re-enter the labour market, i.e. to provide them with individual job-search assistance, case management and general information services, training and retraining and promoting entrepreneurship. According to the data provided by the Belgian authorities, the crude steel sector experienced severe economic shocks between 2006 and 2011, in particular by rapidly decreased market share in the EU and the production of crude steel. In addition, the impact of these changes in the trading system has been reinforced by other factors, such as the reduction in steel demand in the automotive sector and construction sectors in the EU as a result of the economic crisis and the relatively increased production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental restrictions, etc.). These factors have affected the competitiveness of the EU steel industry, resulting in significant job losses in the steel industry in recent years as several European steel producers closed factories and were restructured. According to the Belgian authorities, the measures introduced constitute a balanced package of personalised services and are active labour market measures aimed at reintegrating workers into the labour market.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Redundancies at Duferco and NLMK will have adverse effects on the Hainaut region, formerly the mining and steel industry where employment depends heavily on traditional heavy industry and the public sector. The low level of education of job seekers (51% do not have a completed secondary school, compared to 47% in Wallonia) creates an additional barrier to finding a job. As the application meets EGF rules, I support the EP's decision.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Hainaut Steel because I think that we need to help our companies on European soil to cope with the challenges of globalisation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. On 27 September 2013, Belgium submitted a request for the mobilization of the EGF concerning 708 redundancies in the companies Duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louvière SA, which specialise in steel production.  The layoffs come as crude steel production in the EU fell sharply from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes between 2006 and 2011. However, globally, steel production increased from 1,249 tonnes to 1,518 million tonnes. The decline in the steel industry is due to the lack of a policy to protect and energize the industrial sector, of which steel is an indispensable element.  The recent Mittal/Arcelor case demonstrates that EU states are at the mercy of rapacious multinationals seeking to control the global steel market by limiting production. That is why, rather than soliciting European funds that are akin to real bandages on a wooden leg, States must take back control of their industrial policy in order to develop and preserve sectors vital to their economy. The steel industry is one of them.  I voted for the granting of the EGF to Belgium.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis has had many negative effects over time, and one of the most important has been job adjustment. At European level, the phenomenon has affected several countries, including Belgium. The steel production sector is among the most shaken. In Europe alone, from 2006 to 2011, production decreased by 14%, while worldwide increased by 26%. This has also happened, among other things, due to the decline in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors of the EU. For example, Hainaut Steel fired more than 700 people in the first ten months of 2013, a measure whose effects are still visible today. This company is asking for EUR 981 956 for the reintegration of redundant workers into the labour market. I believe that this must be supported because there are 700 people who can support 700 families, which means spending on their home, children and their education. I voted in favour of the report because, once supported and reintegrated, the laid-off workers will be able to perform better in the future, which will lead to increased productivity and the economy.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. MEPs voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of dismissed workers from Duferco-NLM in Hainaut, Belgium. The amount of aid amounts to EUR 981,956. More than 700 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job.  Demand is justified and necessary given the decline in steel sector productivity compared to the global trend. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF, established to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) referring to the application submitted by Belgium on 27 September 2013 to apply for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies linked to the closure of Duferco Belgim SA and staff reductions to NLMK La Louvière SA , companies operating in the metallurgical sector. Belgium's application relates to a total of 708 redundancies. In order to establish the link between redundancies and major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation. The Belgian authorities have pointed out that the steel production sector has suffered serious economic disturbances, due in particular to the decline in the EU's market share. Given that crude steel production in the EU fell by 14.1% between 2006 and 2011, while worldwide production increased by 21.6%, and therefore the link between redundancies and structural changes in world trade due to globalisation is demonstrated, I voted in favour of this measure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 701 out of 708 workers in the Belgian region of Hainaut who have been made redundant in the basic metals sector.  This is a particularly important issue for me as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local Bose factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community as a whole. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be made in this instance but adequate support for the workers in retraining and upskilling must be provided in any case.  The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as a justification for making workers redundant.

name: David Casa (PPE)
