text: in writing. ‒ The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an essential instrument to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I am glad to note that the coordinated package of personalised services, which was presented by the Belgian authorities in the case of Hainaut Steel (Duferco - NLMK) represents a number of active labour market measures with the aim of re-integrating the workers into the labour market. The Commission has now concluded that the application meets the conditions for deploying the EGF as set out in Article 2(b) of Regulation (EC) No 1927/2006. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European steel sector is suffering greatly from the crisis and globalisation and, as the frequent requests for mobilisation of European funds show, it needs coordinated action at European level.  In La Louvière, in the Hainaut region – where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry and the public sector – Duferco, a Belgian company operating in the sector, closed down, and the NLMK had to reduce its staff, both due to the narrowing of Europe's market share in steel production, resulting in a total of 708 redundancies.  The mobilisation of the EGF Fund is therefore intended to help redundant workers retrain in order to perform other tasks in different sectors.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. The redundancies following the closure of Duferco Belgium SA and staff reductions at NLMK La Louvière SA affected 708 people. 708 Belgian workers who, like other employees in Europe, are suffering the ravages of savage globalisation. According to the Belgian government, between 2006 and 2011, crude steel production in the EU-27 fell from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes (or - 14.1%; - 3.0% annual growth); while global production increased from 1,249.0 million tonnes to 1,518.3 million tonnes (up 21.6%; 4.0% annual growth). There is therefore no decline in steel demand, yet the European Union has lost 29.4% market share in this area, while China has increased its market share to 45%. Unfortunately, the employees of Duferco and NLMK are known to be subject to Chinese dumping, which can count on cheap labour and low safety standards. That is why I voted in favour of this report, since the measures provided by the EGF will relieve 701 of the 708 people concerned.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought I was voting in favour of this measure because the European Fund set up provides support for workers who are suffering from structural changes in world trade. The Fund may not exceed the annual ceiling of EUR 150 million (at 2011 prices).  The amounts required shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a provision. The procedures that will be used to obtain the transfer of funding seem to me to be good and efficient. The dialogue between the Commission and the Authority should ensure the success of the procedural agreement, see the Hainaut steel case, which has seen a significant drop in sales in recent years, due to the strong release into the world market of steel from Asia and the high and incisive cost of labour and the decrease in demand in the automotive and construction sectors.  The intervention of the European Fund is a positive and decisive procedure aimed at supporting and defending individual European workers placed in the redundancy fund.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support for workers who are suffering from structural changes in world trade. I believe that the 708 redundancies at Duferco and NLMK are linked to the changes in world trade due to globalisation, since the steel production sector has suffered serious economic disturbances. I voted in favour of this question concerning the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium, because the figures in the resolution have shown that crude steel production in the EU decreased between 2006 and 2011, while worldwide production increased; In particular, therefore, the sharp decline in the EU's market share was crucial for the two companies, determined not by competitive factors within the company but by wider issues relating to the whole EU. That is why I think it is right for the Fund to intervene.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 981 956 for Belgium with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of the 708 workers made redundant by the closure of the Duferco company and the reduction of staff in the NLMK company.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Belgium and in relation to the redundancies linked to the closure of Duferco Belgium SA and the staff reduction decided by NLMK La Louvière SA, both based in La Louvière and both operating in metallurgy.  Europe's share of the steel market has, in fact, been considerably reduced as a result of changes in international trade routes and a contraction in domestic demand, leading to job losses for many of those employed in the sector. The redundancies caused by the closure of the first and the downsizing of the second of the abovementioned enterprises lead to a deterioration in the socio-economic situation in an area with already high levels of unemployment. Mobilising the EGF for this cause will make it possible to co-finance key measures such as individual assistance in finding a new job, training and retraining courses and the promotion of entrepreneurship. The hope is that, thanks also to the support of the EGF, redundant workers will soon be able to find a new job, a prerequisite for restarting the economy in the area.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ A total of 708 personnel working in the manufacture of basic metals have been made redundant. Such redundancies are linked to a decline in the European Unionʼs market share in the steel production sector. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund measures recommended will seek the reintegration of 701 redundant workers into employment through individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, training and retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship. I have thus voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium applied to mobilise the EGF after 708 redundancies linked to the closure of Duferco and staff reductions in NLMK, both operating in the production of base metals, and both based in La Louvière in the Hainaut region. The redundancies took place during the reference period from 22 January 2013 to 22 October 2013 and are linked to a decrease in the Union's market share in the steel production sector. The nature of the redundancies will have a negative impact in the Hainaut region, a former coal mining and steel production area where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry and public sector investment. Just think that in 2012 the unemployment rate was 17.7%, compared to 15.8% of the average in Wallonia and 11.2% of the national average.  At present, 39% are observed for people aged 18 to 25 and there is a low level of qualification of job seekers, 51% have no upper secondary education. As the conditions of the EGF Regulation are being met, I am voting in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium. The application was submitted following the 708 redundancies in the enterprises Duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louvière SA operating in the steel sector, in the reference period from 22 January 2013 to 22 October 2013. The package includes measures such as individual job-search assistance, general information services, training, retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship. The report aims to help workers who need support to re-enter the work market, hence I voted in favour of such measures.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 708 employees in the steel industry, including 381 at Duferco and 327 at NLMK, Belgium has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support people who have lost their jobs and to help them find work or start their own businesses. The aid granted amounts to EUR 981,956 and covers 50% of the cost of the conversion projects that will be offered to these employees.  Since the kingdom of Belgium's request corresponds to the EGF's mobilization criteria, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Belgium faced a wave of layoffs in the steel industry in 2013, partly due to a sharp decline in the European Union's market share in steel production. This sector is particularly sensitive to the global crisis that we have been experiencing for several years now.  Thanks to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund that we voted for, Belgian sacked employees will be able to access a financial contribution as well as a coordinated set of personalised services to deal with this situation.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The steel production sector has suffered severe economic disruption and a sharp decline in the EU's market share in recent years. The effects of these changes in the structure of trade in the Union market have also been aggravated by other factors such as: the decrease in steel demand in the EU automotive and construction sector and a relative increase in production costs.  These factors have had a negative impact on the competitiveness of the European Union steel industry, leading to the loss of many jobs.  I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Belgium because it will support the reintegration into working life of 708 workers who have lost their jobs in the steel industry.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 708 employees of the steel companies Duferco and NLMK, located in La Louvière. The company was forced to lay off in 2013 due to the decline in steel production in the European Union, due to the opening of borders, particularly in the automotive sector.  European crude steel production in the EU fell by 30 million tonnes between 2006 and 2011 when Chinese production increased from 33.7% to 45% of world production, which had increased by 300 million tonnes over the same period. That is why I voted in favour of this EUR 981,956 aid to Belgium, to enable it to help the victims of the deindustrialisation caused by the economic policies of the European Union.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 9 December 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation. According to the data referred to by the Belgian authorities, the steel sector is suffering from serious economic turmoil, notably a rapidly declining MARKET SHARE in the EU. In the EU-27, production of crude steel fell from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes between 2006 and 2011 (−14.1%; −annual growth of 3.0%(5), while production worldwide increased from 1249.0 million tonnes to 1518.3 million tonnes (+21.6%; +4.0% annual growth). As a result, the EU-27's market share in global production of crude steel decreased from 16.6% to 11.7% between 2006 and 2011 (−29.4%; -6.7% annual growth). By comparison, over the same period, China's market share increased from 33.7% to 45.0% (+33.6%; +6.0% annual growth). The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes the following measures to reintegrate 701 redundant workers: individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, training and retraining, and entrepreneurship promotion.  The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they have lost their jobs as a result of changing global trade patterns, e.g. when a large company shuts down or a factory is moved to outside the EU, or the global financial and economic crisis. Negotiations on the renewal of the Fund concluded under the Multiannual Financial Framework Agreement and a new EGF Regulation is now in place. There are six EGF applications to be voted on from Poland, Germany and Belgium.  The ECR is opposed in principle to the use of this fund and voted against the proposals.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Only months ago we discussed possible measures for the development of steel making, and today we are already wondering how to save what has already happened unsaved. I stress that the EGF is an instrument that does not help to improve the situation, but tries to compensate somewhat for the deterioration of the situation as a result of global transformations in the economy. I would emphasise that the lack of an adequate growth policy, which in part leads to the creation of new jobs and, respectively, to the upskilling of workers and thus to their pay, cannot be replaced by the EGF. The collapse in steel production and in the metalworking sector in general is a fact, but it is mainly due to the fact that we are constantly losing markets and positions. The reason for this is that we introduce rules that make us uncompetitive. As a result, our businesses are losing out, workers are out of work, and we are dealing with this here: should we give them 100 euros per person or not? Forgive me, but this is not an approach oriented towards growth and employment growth.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series.  However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I remain convinced that the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that supports workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to assist redundant workers. This is the case of the company Hainaut steel, Duferco-NLMK in the steel sector. According to the Belgian authorities, there was a reduction in the EU-27 market share between 2006 and 20011 in crude steel production by -29.4 %, compared to 33.6 % in China over the same period, with an increase in China by 33.6 %. At the same time, there has been a decrease in demand for steel products in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU due to the economic crisis. The difficulties in that company are related to globalisation and the eligibility conditions for the application for EGF support have been verified. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to improve the employability of all workers through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, on equal terms of treatment. This support should be complementary to the company's responsibility under national law and not to be overtaken by other types of financial support by the Union.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to obtain their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The Belgian authorities submitted the eGF/2013/007 BE/Hainaut steel application following 708 redundancies relating to the closure of duferco and staff reductions in NLMK, both of which are active in the basic metallurgical industries sector. The total financial contribution requested amounts to EUR 981 956. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application referred to in this report relates to 708 redundancies in Duferco-NLMK. On the grounds of serious economic disturbances, with a decrease in market share and a decrease in production to justify the option of using a mass redundancy, Belgium's application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to mobilise the amount of EUR 981 956. Although the Belgian authorities ensure that the financial contribution will in no way replace the actions and responsibilities of companies under national law or collective agreements, an aspect that attempts to safeguard that funding is not used for the promotion of redundancies, what is necessary is the restitution of defunct jobs and compensation for the damage caused to the lives of these 708 workers and their families.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide additional support to workers in the Belgian hainaunt steel works. The crisis in the steel industry in Europe remains a very serious matter. The challenge facing the sector is very ambitious, in that it must combine, on the one hand, the protection of workers, pollution-related risks and, on the other, European companies from the competition that is pushing them back into the world stage and from the general decline in demand for steel due to the general reduction in investment.  Europe must therefore draw up a road map that will put the steel industry back at the centre of industrial policies and turn it into a sustainable and profitable sector.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission has decided to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium after 708 workers lost their jobs as a result of serious economic problems in the steel sector, in particular the rapid reduction of the European Union's market share. The number of people employed in the metallurgical industry fell by 20 % between 2008 and 2013. Following the closure of the company in question, unemployment in the region has increased and the old age and low education of the redundancies make it impossible for them to find adequate employment. The amount of funding should be EUR 981 956.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of granting the fund € 981,956 for 708 redundancies in the steel sector in Wallonia.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - application EGF/2013/007 BE/Hainaut Steel (Duferco-NLMK) - Belgium , because the money from the adjustment fund should be given basically to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report to support the reintegration of 701 workers at Duferco NLMK, an industry operating in the steel sector, back into the labour market.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization that, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation (e.g. closure of large enterprises or relocation of production outside the EU) or the global economic and financial crisis. That is why I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2013/007 BE/Hainaut Steel (Duferco-NLMK)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to laid-off workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalisation or the financial crisis and to help them find new jobs.  I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louviare SA (Belgium) operating in the steel sector.  In this case, EGF funding amounts to EUR 981 956 and the package includes measures such as individual job search assistance, general information services, training and promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. By unblocking the contributions provided for by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union is giving a concrete sign of support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, thus making it easier for them to re-enter the labour market. I therefore welcome the adoption of the report on the case of the reorganisation of Hainaut Steel's company.  In this case, as in many other cases, Europe intervenes only to cover the declines in competitiveness and to provide companies and workers with new tools for the conversion of skills and skills. These are certainly decisive instruments: the hope is that the efforts of new productive momentum that the EU has undertaken with the new Juncker Plan will gradually make EU companies finally stronger in the global market, thus reversing the decline that part of our industrial sector has suffered in recent years.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Plenkovic report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it fully complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGAF Regulation. I welcome that the EGF funding of EUR 981 956 shall contribute to the coordinated package of personalised services for the reintegration of 701 redundant workers into employment.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 708 employees of the steel companies Duferco and NLMK, located in La Louvière. Duferco closed and NMLK reduced its staff.  These dismissals occurred between 22 January and 22 October 2013. Their origin is the decline in the market share of European Union companies in the steel production sector. The opening of borders, particularly in the automotive sector, has weakened the European steel industry. Between 2006 and 2011, the share of raw steel in the European Union rose from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes. During the same period, world production increased from 1,249 million tonnes to 1,548.3 million tonnes. As a result, European production fell from 16.5 per cent to 11.4 per cent of world production. The globalization of trade has mainly benefited China, whose market share in steel production has increased from 33.7% to 45%.  That is why I voted in favour of this EUR 981,956 aid to Belgium, to enable it to help employees, victims of the deindustrialisation desired by the European Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilising this fund for companies in the metallurgical sector of Belgium's Hainaut region, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 708 dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series.  However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation particularly in the metallurgical sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to offer assistance in Belgium, following 708 redundancies in the enterprises Duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louvière SA operating in the steel sector The funding of EUR 981 956 will contribute to the coordinated package of personalised services for the reintegration of 701 redundant workers into employment. The package includes measures such as individual job-search assistance, general information services, training, retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this support for the steel industry in Belgium, which concerns more than 700 workers. This sector has faced globalisation and because of it, production of steel has undergone serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline of the EU’s market share.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilising this fund for companies in the metallurgical sector of the Hainaut region of Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 708 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation, particularly in the metallurgical sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the redundancies of Duferco and NLMK because it will have negative effects on belgium's Hainaut region where the unemployment rate is higher than the Walloon average and depends on heavy industry and the public sector.  I support the involvement of social partners and organisations in the process of coordinating and implementing support measures and a coordinated package of personalised services, as redundancies in the metallur industry lead to the necessary retraining of workers in order to be able to find work in other sectors.  I believe it is of utmost importance that the financial contribution of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund only co-finances measures leading to long-term employment and aimed at combating the negative globalisation flows of globalisation.  Therefore, I support these support measures concerning the steel sector, which has already been the subject of five similar requirements and is affected by the consequences of globalisation trends and the global financial crisis.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 708 employees of the steel companies Duferco and NLMK, located in La Louvière. The company was forced to lay off in 2013 due to the decline in steel production in the European Union, due to the opening of borders, particularly in the automotive sector. European crude steel production in the EU fell by 30 million tonnes between 2006 and 2011 when Chinese production increased from 33.7% to 45% of world production, which had increased by 300 million tonnes over the same period. That is why I voted in favour of this EUR 981,956 aid to Belgium, to enable it to help the victims of the deindustrialisation caused by the economic policies of the European Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrej Plenkovic's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Hainaut Steel in Belgium. The fund will provide EUR 981,956 for hainaut Steel's 708 laid-off employees, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Belgium concerning redundancies in the companies Duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louvière SA. This fund was created to provide additional assistance to workers who have been made redundant due to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization and to help them re-enter the labour market. I am the the the firm, the city, the fore, welcomed the adoption of EUR 981,956.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as I believe it is a major move to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade while facilitating their reintegration into the labour market quickly and effectively.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Belgium applied for assistance following the terminations from two producers of base metals (Duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louvice SA) in the Hainaut region. The redundancies in Hainaut were the result of a rapid decline in the market share of European companies in the production of crude steel at world level, combined with a decline in steel demand in the automotive and construction industries as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs. The measures would help 701 workers from the steel industry in Hainaut to find new jobs. I support this motion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made by Hainaut Steel (Duferco and NLMK). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Duferco and NLMK were large employers in the Hainaut region of Belgium and the 708 redundancies which have resulted from their closure, have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy. Many of those made redundant do not hold qualifications and will have to be retrained to find new employment. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to the local economy and support the workers affected by helping them re-enter the labour market.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers into the labour market who have been made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Andrej Plenković, who envisages support for some Belgian companies affected by the economic crisis. Specifically, the report provides for the allocation of resources necessary for the reintegration into the labour market of 708 redundancies in companies operating in the economic steel sector.  Europe is once again demonstrating its mission of solidarity and its concreteness in helping the people, the workers, who suffer most from the effects of a devastating economic crisis.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. After having already done so in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, I voted again in favour of the PLENKOVIC report. The adoption of this report means the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 701 former employees of the Belgian company Duferco NLMK. The EUR 981,956 granted under this fund will enable these workers to return to work through, among other things, reorientation, training and counselling. Once again, I am pleased that the European Union is taking charge of the difficulties of certain sectors, such as metallurgy, and being able to respond effectively to them.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union, through its active participation in the process of globalisation and its passive trade policies, is largely responsible for the economic weakening of nations and the downgrading of our productive apparatus. Considering that the allocation of these funds constitutes a just, albeit modest, reparation for the prejudices suffered by the peoples, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 708 employees of the steel companies Duferco and NLMK, located in La Louvière. Globalisation, the free movement of capital and goods, austerity policy and their promoters are responsible for this situation: while the European Union's share of the crude steel production market fell by 6.7% per year between 2006 and 2011, China's market share has increased by 6% per year. This is despite the increase in world production of 300 million tonnes over the same period.  I therefore voted in favour of this EUR 981,956 aid to Belgium, in favour of the victims of this forced deindustrialization.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is the first EGF mobilization in 2015.  The application was submitted after the 708 redundancies in duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louviare SA (Belgium) operating in the steel sector, during the reference period from 22 January 2013 to 22 October 2013. EGF funding amounts to EUR 981 956 and the package includes measures such as individual job search assistance, general information services, training and the promotion of entrepreneurship, with which we agree.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 708 workers in two companies, related to the closure of Duferco and the reductions in staff in NLMK, operating in NACE Rev. 2, division 24 'Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products" and are located in La Louviare, in the province of Henao. These redundancies took place during the reference period from 22 January to 22 October 2013 and are related to the decrease in the Union's market share in the steel production sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In view of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I agree with the personalized measures taken in advance of Belgium's decision, as the decision was taken after a year and a half of your request. The impact of globalization on Belgium's Steel Production Companies Duferco and NLMK, together with a decline in demand for this material in recent years, has led to a lot of unemployment and has made it necessary for these specialized measures to be carried out to adapt these workers to the current labour market, as working these in the steel sector many lack sufficient studies or experience to compete in the current labour market.  Therefore, and further because of the Fund's additional role in implementing greater equality between men and women at work and non-discrimination, I believe that this proposal must be approved in order to achieve a better employment situation in Belgium.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission adopted a proposal last year to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the amount of almost €1 million to help 708 redundanct workers in 2013 from Belgian companies Duferco and NLMK.  Both companies are engaged in the production of raw steel, an industry that saw a 15% drop in production in the Union member states between 2006 and 2011, while global production grew in the same period. This has also resulted in a drop in steel demand and harmed the competitiveness of EU Member States and led to a large number of jobs lost.  The requested amount is 50% of the total funds for implementing the plan to help laid-off employees. Through the job search process, they face problems due to the low level of qualifications, since more than 50% of them do not have completed secondary education. They are planned to be assisted through individual job search assistance, education and training for retraining purposes and through the promotion of self-employment.  I supported MeP Plenković's report and the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 708 redundanstrial Belgian citizens, as this will make it easier for them to find new employment, and employment growth will also have a positive impact on the standard of the entire Belgian region.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour, it was a nominal vote. The 534 Meps, together with colleagues from the S&D political group, supported the report by Me Andrei Plenkovic.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 For the measures to be effective, it is crucial that they are taken in a timely manner or within a reasonable time. Only in this way can they fulfil their purpose. It is therefore important that clearly defined procedures are adopted without delay, with clear deadlines for the examination of specific applications, so that the aid granted is efficient and that the impacts on employment can be assessed in advance. The aid granted must be targeted as a matter of priority to the staff most difficult to apply to the labour market, given their age and qualifications, and to take measures that will lead to sustainable employment.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, since the Belgian authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to affected workers on 1 June 2013 , well before the final decision on EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal to mobilise the EGF, which will support Hainaut Steel, a Belgian company in difficulty. I had already voted in favour of this request in the EMPL committee. 708 licensees from the Belgian steel industries will benefit here.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. According to data referred to by the Belgian authorities, the sector of the production of steel has undergone serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline of the EU’s market share. Moreover, the effects of these changes in trade patterns have been worsened by other factors such as a decrease in demand in steel in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU as a consequence of the economic crisis and a relative increase of production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental constraints, etc.). These factors have harmed the competiveness of the EU’s steel industry and have led to a high number of job losses in the steel sector in recent years. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded includes following measures for the reintegration of 701 redundant workers into employment: individual job-search assistance, case management and general information services, training and retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, concerning Belgium's request for a financial contribution of EUR 981 956, following 708 redundancies due to the closure of Duferco and the reduction of staff at NLMK, a company operating in the metallurgical sector. The steel production sector has suffered significant economic imbalances, in particular a sharp decline in the EU's market share, and the structure of world trade has been made more complex by certain factors, such as the decrease in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors. It is therefore necessary to protect workers who, as a result of the economic crisis, have lost their jobs and to ensure that the Fund supports their stable reintegration into the labour market.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The steel production sector has suffered serious economic losses as a result of market changes attributable to the unstoppable advance of the phenomenon of globalisation.  I voted in favour of the Plenković report, as I believe that the mobilisation of the EGF, in support of the reintegration into the labour market of 708 workers made redundant at Hainaut Steel, a Belgian metallurgical industry, is appropriate. It is necessary for the European Union, on the basis of the principle of solidarity between States, to act promptly in support of citizens in need.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. This motion received my positive vote, as companies suffering the consequences of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns and meeting the conditions for mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund must be supported. The relocation of the market structure to China and the declining demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU have resulted in the loss of many jobs. Those workers who suffer from the consequences of these structural changes must be additionally supported.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of retraining people who have lost their jobs after failing to maintain competition from Asian countries, one metal production plant in the Belgian province of Henne, while another significantly reduced the number of employees. The funds are necessary to solve social problems as quickly as possible, to retrain and return to the labour market as many as 708 people of working age who have been made redundant.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2013, 50% of staff were laid off in the case of these joint steel companies located at the La Louvière site in Belgium. Between 2006 and 2011, China's market share fell from 33.7% to 45%, while the European Union's market share fell by 5 points to 11.7% in 2011. Behind all these figures is a bitter reality for laid-off workers and a profound evil: no European industrial policy. I abstain so as not to deprive workers of this fund.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Belgium to give this aid to belgium, which submitted the EGF/2013/007 BE/Hainaut steel application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 708 redundancies related to the closure of duferco and staff reductions in NLMK, both with activity in the sector corresponding to division 24 of NACE Rev. 2 (basic metallurgical industries) and located in the locality of La Louvière, in the province of Hainaut.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the EU’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise the EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 708 workers in Belgium due to the decline in market share in the steel industry.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Duferco and NLMK, two Belgian companies active in the base metals manufacturing sector, have had to make 708 layoffs due to major changes in the structure of world trade causing a sharp decline in the European Union's market share in world markets, resulting in a decline in the competitiveness of the European steel industry and numerous job losses. However, it is imperative to help these crisis-affected workers find a job. The proposal to mobilise EUR 981,956 under the EGF, and thus allowing the conversion of 701 workers, is essential to support employment, given the current difficulties in the steel sector.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report giving the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Belgium. The application was submitted following the 708 redundancies in the enterprises Duferco Belgium SA and NLMK La Louvière SA operating in the steel sector, in the reference period from 22 January 2013 to 22 October 2013. The EGF funding will contribute to the coordinated package of personalised services for the reintegration of 701 redundant workers into employment.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  This is the first application examined under the 2015 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 981 956 from the EGF in favour of Belgium. The application concerns the dismissal of 708 persons in the reference period between 22 January 2013 and 22 October 2013. I am in favour of this report, pointing out that the financial contribution of the EGF does not replace actions which are the responsibility of undertakings under national law or collective agreements.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. In this report, we are asked to cover the damage caused by the ultra-liberal policy pursued by Brussels. Once again, the European Union is playing the arsonist fireman by trying to put out the fire that it has lit itself. It will thus partially compensate for the damage it causes by its ultraliberal ideology. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to shock anyone.  I am voting for this aid to employees so as not to further penalise the victims of European ultraliberalism.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation with the exception of two where the number of employees is lower than that specified in the regulation. There is a precedent for this and Parliament supports their applications.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of EUR 980,000 to support the reclassification of 708 employees made redundant following the closure of the Duferco company and the staff reductions at NLMK. These two Hainaut companies produce base metals.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted five reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these five reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release 1 million euros from this fund to 701 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of several metallurgical companies in the province of Hainaut in Belgium.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of hainaut steel workers, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade. According to data from the Belgian authorities, the steel production sector has suffered serious economic disturbances, in particular a sharp decline in the EU's market share. The effects of these changes in the structure of trade have been aggravated by other factors, such as the decrease in demand for steel in the EU automotive and construction sector as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental constraints, etc.). These factors have had a negative impact on the competitiveness of the European steel industry, leading to the loss of a large number of steel jobs in recent years as a result of the closure and restructuring of plants by various steel producers in Europe.  The European aid package approved today will serve to promote the reintegration into working life of 701 workers made redundant, through personalised assistance measures in the search for employment, training and retraining, and the promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it proposes to compensate, through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, all the collateral victims of certain economic operations generated on a global scale. As such, I fully support all actions aimed at strengthening cohesion within our continent by protecting its workers and strengthening the social dimension of the European project.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This application relates to the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 981 956 in favour of Belgium. The European Union's competences include support for workers who, as a result of major changes in world trade flows, lose their jobs. That is why I felt it was right to express my agreement with the report signed by Mr Plenković, which supports the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the benefit of 708 redundancies in two companies, Duferco and NLMK, operating in the metallurgical sector.  This appropriation, which will finance actions aimed at enhancing the professional skills of these workers, will help to offer them new employment opportunities.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the implementation of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - EGF BE/Hainaut steel's request as special rapporteur of the Social Democratic Group in the European Parliament for EGF Funds.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on demand from Belgium following 708 redundancies at two companies caused by the closure of Duferco and the staff reductions at NLMK, core metal processing companies. The redundancies took place between January and October 2013 and relate to the decrease in the Union's market share in the steel production sector. In the period 2006-2011, production of raw steel in the EU-27 decreased from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes (–14.1 %), while worldwide production increased from 1 249 million tonnes to 1 518.3 million tonnes (+21.6 %). This led to a decrease in the EU-27 market share in gross steel production and an increase in China's market share from 33.7% to 45% over the same period. Given that this is the fifth EGF application in the steel sector, as S&D coordinator for industry, research and energy, I support the need for a Union strategy in the field of base metal processing. I stress that an effective and coordinated approach at Union level is needed to combat steel unemployment.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the material and formal conditions for mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund are in place in this case and I hope that the promised financial resources will give the employees and workers concerned a view for the future. I therefore hope that there are also positive aspects to the economic prosperity of the region.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to allocate EUR 981 956 from the EGF fund to Belgium, as it will allow us to re-help 708 people who became unemployed in the steel-making sector. Unemployment is one of the most painful problems in the European Union. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market; that Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible; that the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013(4) reflects the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council on the reintroduction of the mobilisation criterion following the crisis, the increase in the Union's financial contribution to 60% of the estimated total costs of the proposed measures, the increase in the efficiency of the processing of EGF applications within the Commission and by Parliament and the Council, reducing the time taken to assess and approve them, the inclusion of the self-employed and young people in eligible actions and beneficiaries, and the financing of incentives for the creation of their own businesses; that the request for assistance meets the eligibility conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Belgian authorities claim that the steel production sector has experienced a serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in EU market share. Between 2006 and 2011, crude steel production in the EU-27 decreased by 14.1%, - 3.0% annual growth, while worldwide production increased by 21.6%, + 4.0% annual growth. This led to a decrease in EU-27 market shares in crude steel production, measured in terms of volume, from 16.6% in 2006 to 11.7% in 2011 (- 29.4%, - 6.7% annual growth). By comparison, over the same period, China increased market share from 33.7% to 45.0% (+ 33.6%, + 6.0% annual growth).  These factors have harmed the competitiveness of the EU steel industry, leading to a large number of jobs lost in the steel sector over the past few years due to plant closures and restructuring of several steel producers in Europe. The application concerns 708 workers laid off over a nine-month period from 22 January 2013 to 22 October 2013 (including 381 workers who were surplus to Duferco and 327 in the NLMK). The proposed EGF contribution to the coordinated personalised service package is EUR 981 956, representing 50% of the total cost.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help Belgium with a technological surplus in the steel sector with €981,956, representing 50% of the total cost. With a view to establishing a link between redundancies and major structural changes in globalisation trade flows, the Belgian authorities claim that the steelmaking sector has experienced a serious economic disruption characterised by a rapid decline in the EU's market share.  According to Belgian authorities, between 2006 and 2011, 100,000 people were killed and 1,000 injured. Since 2010, crude steel production in the EU-27 has decreased from 206.5 9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes (-14.1%, - 3.0% annual growth), while globally production increased from 1 249.0 million tonnes to 1 518.3 million tonnes (+ 21.6%; + 4.0% annual growth). This has led to a decrease in the EU-27 market share in crude steel production. The request relates to 708 dismissals over a nine-month period, from January to October 2013 (which includes 381 duferco cancellations and 327 cancellations in the NLMK). Duferco and NLMK operate in the same sector of economic activity (Metal production). Member States need to show solidarity towards each other when needed and I am pleased that they have shown this today in this example.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At a time when Europe is facing a financial, economic and social crisis and unemployment as a key consequence, the EU needs to use all the resources at its disposal to react, especially in terms of ensuring support for people who have lost their jobs. Belgium applied to EGF/2013/007 BE/Hainaut Steel for a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of the redundancies of 708 workers in the two companies' installations, namely following the closure of the Dufreco plant and staff reductions at the NLMK plant.  Globalisation in global trade flows in steel production has caused a serious economic disruption, primarily related to the sharp decline in the EU's market share. Layoffs at Dufreco and NMLK will cause adverse effects on the Hainaut region, formerly the mining and steel industry, where the unemployment rate was 17.7% and the low level of education of job seekers (51% do not have a high school completed) creates an additional obstacle to finding a job.  I therefore support the Mobilisation Report €981,956, which is 50% of the total budget, which will have a concrete impact on the multitude of workers who have become technologically redundant in the steel production sector in the Hainaut region.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The mobilisation of the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) is this time in belgium's favour for the reintegration into working life of redundant workers from Hainaut Steel, a steel production company, according to a proposal for a decision adopted by the Commission. The Belgian authorities have stated that the steel sector has suffered serious economic disturbances in recent years and the EU has lost a significant market share.  Crude steel production fell in the EU, with an annual change of -3% and a loss of market. The crisis in the motor vehicle and construction sectors, large steel users, has contributed to an increase in the crisis in the European steel industry and its consequences. I hope that the personalized services for the 701 redundant workers funded by the fund will help them retrain.  In this specific case, it is personalized assistance in job search, case management and general information services; training and retraining; promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The steel sector has experienced a sharp decline in Europe, with a drastic decline in steel production in the EU27 between 2006 and 2011, even as production has increased globally. While Chinese and Indian competition is one of the main reasons for this decline, the decline in steel demand in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU must also be taken into account. As a direct result, many production sites have been closed, particularly in Belgium.  In this context, I supported the Belgian request to mobilise the Globalization Adjustment Fund. This assistance will help to support laid-off workers to re-enter the labour market and move into other sectors.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this application for the closure of the Duferco company and the staff reductions in NLMK (FEG/2013/007 BE/Hainaut Steel) because it meets the requirements set out. Looking at the data between 2006 and 2011, crude steel production in Europe 27 decreased by 14.1 %, while globally it increased by 21.6%. Given that redundancies will have a negative impact on Hainut province, the economic situation and the number of redundancies in the metallurgical industry, Duferco-NLMK workers will have to convert professionally to find jobs in other professions and sectors. That is why this support is essential for these people.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Good news for the Walloon steel sector, the European Parliament today voted to activate retraining aid for the 708 laid-off workers of Duferco and NLMK companies, active in the base metal manufacturing sector. This eur 981,956 aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is the European participation of 50% of the needs needed to support former Duferco and NLMK employees in their job search and more broadly in their career reorientation. It will ensure a strong industrial policy in a region of Europe that is suffering the full brunt of the European Union's declining market share in the global steel production sector. This European retraining aid is therefore welcome for the families of these workers. On the other hand, it cannot supersede the establishment of a European industrial policy which should be a priority of the new Juncker Commission to preserve European know-how in many high-tech sectors.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of legislative and budgetary instruments to provide complementary support to the most diverse sectors has proved to be a positive measure in the transition and adjustment of Member States to the era of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool in that it can serve to reintegrate people and businesses into the global market. In this case, and in view of the situation presented, the aid provided to Belgium is relevant.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 981 956 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 708 workers who have lost their jobs in Duferco and NLMK, companies located in La Louviare, Belgium, and dedicated to steel production, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The steel manufacturing sector has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in EU market share, which has been exacerbated by other factors such as declining demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include different training and recycling needs for workers. While these aids are not in themselves capable of alleviating the drama of unemployment in the European steel sector, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the redundancies at Hainaut Steel Duferco-NLMK in La Louvière, as these contributions are a valuable aid in enabling the retraining and reclassification of workers, thanks in particular to training tailored to the opportunities of the job market.  Nevertheless, the job losses in many sectors are a painful reminder that these aids are not a miracle cure and that it is essential to pursue a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. More broadly, Europe needs to put in place a real coordinated industrial policy focused on creating sustainable jobs in sectors of the future.  In addition, weASee procedures should be accelerated and simplified to enable laid-off workers to cope with difficulties as soon as they arise.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The structural changes in world trade patterns resulting from globalization are now an unavoidable reality. And no country or company is immune to the effects of these transformations. As such, the European Commission has established a legislative instrument that can provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of the economic crisis and globalisation. In view of the fact that Belgium submitted a request for financial assistance to the EGF following 708 redundancies in Duferco and NLMK, which will have a negative impact on the province of Hainaut in the mining and steel production sector, I voted in favour of allocating this fund in the amount of EUR 981 956, which provides for the reintegration of these workers into the labour market.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report in order to unlock financial and professional assistance following the 708 redundancies in two companies, following the closure of the Duferco company and staff reductions in NLMK. The layoffs came as a result of a decline in the European Union's market share in the steel production sector.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will make a 50% contribution to cover the costs of job search assistance, training and retraining and entrepreneurship promotion.  Having always defended the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Even with the adoption of the report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help Belgian workers, the European Parliament is once again showing itself to be decisive and ready to always be on the side of its fellow citizens.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of protecting citizens who have lost their jobs.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for EUR 981,956 for employees who have been laid off in the steel industry in Belgium. This package will help to co-finance measures to help the reinstatement of 701 workers who have been made redundant as a result of severe economic disruptions in the steel production sector.  Between 2006 and 2011, crude steel production in the European Union decreased by 14.1%, while it increased worldwide by 21.6%. Europe has lost 30% market share to Chinese competitors in particular. In addition, other factors have exacerbated the crisis in the European steel industry: falling demand in the automotive and construction sectors and rising production costs (particularly due to environmental constraints and energy prices). These different constraints have caused European companies to lose their competitiveness. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up on the initiative of France to help workers who lose their jobs due to major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Belgium's application for unemployment effects of Duferco and NLMK complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It affects a total of 708 unemployed people. The EU's world market share of steel production has fallen sharply. Between 2006 and 2011, the EU-27 share decreased by 14.1%, while global output increased by 21.6%. This development has a strong impact in the Hainaut region of Belgium, where employment has traditionally focused on heavy industry and the public sector. Moreover, the situation is complicated by the fact that 51% of the unemployed have only the lowest level of education. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. I agree with this request for the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because in this case employment must be safeguarded. However, we note that the Union's recommendations do not go in the direction of a fair globalisation allowing States to protect their businesses and jobs as do other major powers.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 708 workers in two companies, related to the closure of Duferco and the reductions in staff in NLMK, operating in NACE Rev. 2, division 24 'Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products" and are located in La Louviare, in the province of Henao. These redundancies took place during the reference period from 22 January to 22 October 2013 and are related to the decrease in the Union's market share in the steel production sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Thanks to todayʼs vote Belgium was granted aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Duferco and NLMK, operating in the NACE 2 Division 24 ʽManufacturing of basic metalsʼ, both located in La Louvière in the Hainaut region. The financial contribution requested from the EGF amounts to EUR 981 956 and it will go towards the coordinated package of personalised services which is to be co-funded. This includes the following measures for the reintegration of 701 redundant workers into employment: individual job-search assistance, case management and general information services, training and retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers receive none of this support therefore.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. The application for a financial contribution submitted by Belgium for aid to Hainaut Steel, in which 708 redundancies were made in 2013, fulfils the eligibility criteria for the aid. The company's lay-offs were the result of major structural changes in global trade due to globalisation, as the steel production sector experienced serious economic disturbances due to the decline in steel demand in the automotive and construction industries (the eu-27 crude steel production decreased by 14,1 % between 2006 and 2011, while increasing globally by 21,6 %, resulting in a 21,6 % decline in the Union market share). Layoffs are likely to have major negative consequences in the Hainaut region, where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry and the unemployment rate is above the national average. As the co-financed services package covers three important areas: job search assistance, training and retraining and the promotion of entrepreneurship, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 701 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation at Duferco NLMK, a company operating in the steel production sector.  The rapid decrease in the European Union's market share in the steel production market in the period 2007-2013 forced Duferco to close and NLKM to reduce activity. As a result, 708 people lost their jobs in the province of Hainaut, once a major mining and steel basin, now hit by an unemployment rate of 17.7%.  The EUR 981,956 aid provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in addition to the funds already allocated by the Walloon region, will help to cover part of the costs of assistance and support in job search, vocational training, support for business creation and other programmes aimed at reintegrating 701 laid-off workers into the labour market.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution as Belgium has applied to EGF/2013/007 BE/Hainaut Steel for an EGF financial contribution following the redundancies of 708 plant workers of the two companies, due to the closure of the Duferco plant and the reduction of staff at the NLMK plant, engaged in activities under section 24 of the NACE 2 classification 'Metal production'. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation and Belgium is entitled to a financial contribution under the Regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will mobilise resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - Belgium has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF for the redundancies of 708 workers within two metals companies located in La Louviere, hainaut region.  These facts have led to a decline in the Union's market share in the steel production sector and Belgium should receive financial contributions under the EGF Regulation.  The Belgian authorities provided swift assistance to workers even before this request was made, and a number of the social partners and organisations of these companies participated in the general coordination and implementation of the measures. Also, trade unions are directly involved in the work of the department to find new jobs.  Taking into account the letters of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee and the Committee on Regional Development and the Report of the Committee on Budgets, I consider that the Belgian request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is justified and should be adopted, and I therefore support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ as it is an incorrect solution to the wrong problems. The two undertakings concerned are in the steel industry, which is one of the sectors with the highest levels of energy intensity. For businesses in this sector, today's high electricity prices in the EU are often prohibitionist, as they cannot compete with businesses, in countries with significantly lower electricity prices, such as China, India or even the US. Therefore, if the EU really wants to combat redundancies in this sector, it should fundamentally rethink its climate policy instead of ad hoc contributions.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds to lay off 708 redundancies at two companies linked to the closure of Duferco and the reduction of NLMK's employees in metal production. The number of redundancies in Duferco and NLMK is linked to major structural changes in world trade flows as a result of globalisation, as the steel production sector has experienced serious economic disturbances, in particular the rapid fall in the EU's market share; the economic crisis and the relative rise in production costs have exacerbated global trade flows, as well as other factors such as the decline in steel demand in the automotive and construction industries.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour! The support measures had been implemented as soon as the redundancies were announced in consultation with the social partners and in partnership with the regional public employment services. In the meantime, we have pleaded with Commissioners Thyssen and Malmstrom for greater coordination so that international trade agreements do not completely destroy European industrial employment.  These 5.2 million are important to the Walloon economic fabric. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves should not be the rule. It should be remembered that this aid was made indispensable because an international industrialist wanted to play with the destiny of workers, treating them with disdain and great disrespect. Europe must send a strong message to all the Lakshmi Mittals of the world that in Europe there are no castes or untouchables. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
