text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think that it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. Duferco and NLMK were major employers in the Hainaut region and because the steel production sector faced serious economic disruption, it led to 708 redundancies. This fund will be used to develop appropriate tools to reintegrate these workers into the job market, including individual job-search assistance, training and promotion of entrepreneurship. I believe it will set the path to durable and long-term employment in the region.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The speed at which the globalisation of trade is taking place is impressive. Hence, we need the tools necessary to make the process of trade openness smooth for those sectors more severely affected. We need to give the opportunity for those affected to get the time to get back to work in another sector.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European Globalisation Adjustment Funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultraliberal policies applied in this European Union, which are unable to defend neither the peoples who make up it nor the companies that support it.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following changes at global level in recent years, the European steel sector has been marked by severe economic disruptions. Thus, in the period 2006-2011, the production of raw steel in the EU-27 decreased from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes. As a result, the EU-27's market share in gross steel production has seen a significant decrease in volume. On 27 September 2013, Belgium submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) following redundancies linked to the closure of the Belgian company Duferco and the staff reductions made within the Belgian company NLMK. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is a financial instrument that allows money to be allocated to people who lose their jobs due to the economic and financial crisis or because of changes in the structure of world trade with globalisation. The European Commission analysed the eligibility conditions and approved the allocation of EUR 981 956 from the EGF in the form of commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. The European Parliament resolution supports the Commission's proposal, giving a favourable opinion on the allocation of that amount of money.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilising this fund for companies in the metallurgical sector of Belgium's Hainaut region, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 708 dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation, particularly in the metallurgical sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the activation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), which Belgium has requested to support the reintegration into employment of some 700 workers made redundant by Hainaut Steel, which operates in the steel production sector.  This sector has suffered a significant decline in market share throughout Europe as a result of changes in the structure of trade due to international competition and the economic and financial crisis. I therefore felt it was important to support this decision, which, although not in itself a real solution, nevertheless alleviates a serious emergency situation with a contribution of around EUR 980 000 to workers.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the dismissal of 708 workers in two companies, related to the closure of Duferco and the reductions in staff in NLMK, operating in NACE Rev. 2, division 24 'Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products" and are located in La Louviare, in the province of Henao. These redundancies took place during the reference period from 22 January to 22 October 2013 and are related to the decrease in the Union's market share in the steel production sector. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application relates to 708 redundancies in Duferco-NLMK. It alleges serious economic disturbances with a decrease in market share and a decrease in production and justifies the option of using a mass redundancy, belgium's application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to mobilise the amount of EUR 981 956. Although the Belgian authorities ensure that the financial contribution will in no way replace the actions and responsibilities of companies under national law or collective agreements, it is an aspect that attempts to safeguard that funding is not used to promote redundancies. What is necessary is the restitution of the defunct jobs and the compensation for the damage caused in the lives of these 708 workers and their families.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The declining demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors, as well as a shift in the market structure to China, led to mass redundancies at the above-mentioned company. Since all the criteria for mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund have been met, it is only to be supported. Nevertheless, we need to consider what measures need to be taken to strengthen this sector again.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. This is already the fifth EGF application for EU state aid in the steel sector. Three applications were justified by 'globalisation', one due to the global financial and economic crisis. Now the EU Labour Office is paying Brussels just under €1 million. Further applications from Belgium and in favour of the steel industry are not excluded. What if affected Member States were able to come up with an efficient and coordinated approach to finding solutions to unemployment in their own Member State through their own government? With each application to use the EGF, the EU Commission continues to develop into a gigantic labour market agency. I cannot agree with that, and that is why I voted against the motion.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for the European Parliament to approve the financial support for redundant workers, the Belgian companies Duferco and NLMK, through the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The EGF is established to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of global structural changes in trade, and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. This case concerns the support of 708 workers, where the EGF will contribute 50 % of the total cost, as foreseen. Duferco closed, while NLMK made staff reductions in 2013. Both are related to the production of basic metals, such as steel, and are located in the Hainaut region. The steel sector has suffered a serious economic downturn and the share of the European market is constantly declining. Production costs have increased while steel demand in key sectors such as automotive and construction has fallen.  The local economy in Hainaut relies heavily on heavy industry, so the decline of the two companies has a very negative impact on the local community.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The application referred to in this report relates to 708 redundancies in Duferco-NLMK. On the grounds that there are serious economic disturbances with a decrease in market share and a decrease in production to justify the option of using a mass redundancy, Belgium's application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to mobilise the amount of EUR 981 956. Although the Belgian authorities ensure that the financial contribution will in no way replace the actions and responsibilities of companies under national law or collective agreements, an aspect that attempts to safeguard that funding is not used for the promotion of redundancies, what is necessary is the restitution of defunct jobs and compensation for the damage caused to the lives of these 708 workers and their families.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds in the event of the closure of the Belgian company Duferco and the layoffs of workers at the Belgian company NLMKD, as the production of crude steel has experienced serious economic disturbances in relation to structural changes in global trade flows and globalisation. In the EU-27, steel production is expected to decrease from 206.9 million tonnes to 177.7 million tonnes between 2006 and 2011. Global steel trade has deteriorated as a result of the economic crisis, the relative rise in production costs and the decline in steel demand in the automotive and construction industries. The redundancies at Duferco and NLMK between 22 January and 22 October 2013 had a negative impact on the situation in the Belgian region of Hainaut, where the unemployment rate was 17.7 % in 2012, compared with an average of 15.8 % in Wallonia and 11.2 % nationally. Youth unemployment between the age of 18 and 25 has reached 39% in this former coal and steel area, where employment is heavily dependent on traditional heavy industry and the public sector. A further problem is the low qualification of jobseekers, with more than half having completed a high school.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization following the 1 285 redundancies in ArcelorMittal Lisge S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 24 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products') and which has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in the Union's market share. 910 people are expected to benefit from the measures, during and after the reference period from 1 January to 1 May 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving Belgium's application EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by the Belgian authorities in the wake of the 1285 redundancies of ArcelorMittal. This fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Fund finances individually adapted measures for the reintegration of jobseekers, promotes self-employment and business start-ups, and grants mobility allowances and allowances for disadvantaged or older workers. The redundancies of the company can be explained by the fact that the EU market share fell sharply, while the Asian market increased over the same period. Similarly, the decline in demand for steel due to the economic crisis and the rise in production costs have affected the competitiveness of the steel industry in the EU. It is therefore gratifying that the EU has accepted Belgium's request and is providing funds to support the redundant workers, in the hope of helping them to achieve lasting, long-term and therefore stable employment through the measures taken.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 1,285 employees at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. Of these, 910 are expected to benefit from the reclassification measures. These layoffs are the result of the opening of borders in the field of crude steel production.  Between 2007 and 2013, crude steel production in the EU fell from 210.1 million tonnes to 166.2 million tonnes. During the same period, world production increased from 1,348.1 million tonnes to 1,649.3 million tonnes. The report also notes that "the decline in the European Union's share of world steel production from 16% in 2007 to 10% in 2013 was greater than in the United States and Russia, while Asia experienced a very significant increase, from 56% to 67% of world production over the same period".  The globalization of trade has therefore benefited Asian competitors, particularly Chinese, to the detriment of European industries.  I therefore voted for this aid of EUR 1,591,486 to Belgium, in order to help reclassify employees who are victims of this deindustrialization.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Belgium, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, although I have some reservations about the relevance of the timetable for the implementation of this tool, I support its primary vocation. For my part, the adjustment to globalization should be achieved upstream or at the beginning of the company's financial problems rather than at the time of accounting for the number of licensees.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Belgian purposes in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from ArcelorMittal Liège operating in steel production. The steel-making sector, in which ArcelorMittal Liège S.A was active, suffered severe economic shocks, in particular, with a rapid decline in eu market share. Between 2007 and 2013, production of crude steel in the EU-27 decreased from 210,1 million tonnes in 2007 to 2013. up to EUR 166,2 million Tons. A total of EUR 1 591 486 is intended to be allocated to 752 redundant workers from the EGF. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the release of this aid, which, however critical in principle, will help the former Belgian employees of Arcelor Mittal.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Europe has provided EUR 1.59 million in aid here to help boost the retraining of 910 workers affected by the effects of unbridled liberalism.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to alleviate the problems arising from the 1,285 redundancies in ArcelorMittal Lisge S.A., a company operating in the economic sector of Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products' and which has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in the Union's market share; considering that 910 persons are expected to benefit from the measures, during and after the reference period from 1 January to 1 May 2014. I hope this will help alleviate the situation that workers are living in

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1,285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A., a "Base Metal Manufacturing" company, of which 910 people are expected to take part in the measures due to serious economic disruptions, including a sharp decline in the European Union's market share in the steel sector. The amount allocated to this request will be EUR 1,591,486 and I have voted in favour of supporting employees even though the Union is the main culprit in this situation, refusing common-sense measures such as intelligent border protection. I have also drafted and tabled a motion for a resolution in favour of support for the European steel industry.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the mobilisation of the EGF for EUR 1 591 486 in support of the 1 285 workers made redundant in the metallurgy sector in Belgium affected by the crisis. Europe should do more to support the internal market and protect it from competition from third countries, but the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, even if it still has too slow activation times, remains a key instrument for supporting workers and companies in difficulty.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have today voted in favour of this report. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, globalisation is not the only reason why so many jobs have been lost in Europe. The EU itself has decided on the destructive austerity policy. It's got to stop. We need an expansive policy, with public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 591 486 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 1 285 workers who have lost their jobs at the Arcelor Mittal plant based in Liege, Belgium, and engaged in steel production as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The steel manufacturing sector has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in EU market share, which has been exacerbated by other factors, such as declining demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include vocational reorientation, training and recycling activities for workers. While these aids are not in themselves capable of alleviating the drama of unemployment in the European steel sector, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in support of workers made redundant from ArcelorMittal in Belgium. According to the data provided by the Belgian authorities, the steel-making sector in which ArcelorMittal Liège S.A was active suffered significant economic shocks, in particular, the EU market share decreased rapidly. Over the period 2007-2013, the share of EU steel production decreased steadily. In Europe, the decrease in production is significantly higher than in the United States and Russia. Meanwhile, the share of Asia has grown very sharply. The impact of these changes in the trading system has also been reinforced by other factors, such as the reduction in steel demand in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU as a result of the economic crisis and the relatively increased production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental restrictions, etc.). These factors have affected the competitiveness of the EU steel industry, resulting in significant job losses in the steel industry in recent years as several European steel producers closed factories and were restructured.  The European Globalisation Fund should therefore support three main areas: training, retraining and entrepreneurship promotion.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Belgium applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies of 1,285 ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. workers and is expected to be covered by measures related to serious economic distortions, in particular a significant decrease in the Union's market share, during the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 1 May 2014. As the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I support the EP's decision to grant them the funds.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for ArcelorMittal because I think that we need to help our companies on European soil to cope with the challenges of the globalisation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium submitted the EGF/2014/012 BE/Arcelor Mittal application for a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to 1,285 redundancies at Arcelor Mittal Liège S.A. These layoffs are once again directly related to the decline in steel production in Europe, while it is increasing elsewhere in the world. The case of Arcelor Mittal is also symptomatic of the sluggish economic atony of the European Union of Member States, neutralised by Brussels directives that prohibit any form of economic patriotism and intelligent protectionism.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will not solve any of the major economic problems facing our old continent. For before helping laid-off workers to find work, the Member States of the Union should be re-industrialised in order to create jobs. Without enthusiasm, I voted for this text which supports the victims of the social disaster that struck Arcelor Mittal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Even though globalisation is viewed with good eyes by many people, it has also had negative effects especially on the economy. A concrete example is that of the steel sector in Belgium, which has suffered staff shortages due to economic problems. ArcelorMittal Liège best illustrates the negative effects of globalisation. In this case, the redundancies were driven by major structural changes in world trade as a result of globalisation, so that while there was a decrease in gross steel production at EU level between 2007 and 2013, worldwide, production increased by 22.3%. In view of the fact that the Liège region is heavily dependent on the steel sector and that the company's share of the local labour market is 78,9 %, it is all the more important to support such a measure with regard to the granting of financial aid of EUR 1 591,486 to almost 1,300 persons. I voted in favour of this measure because it supports the development of new skills and guidelines towards professional conversion.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has decided to approve the request to mobilise the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of former employees of ArcelorMittal in Belgium in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at the Liège site. The amount allocated amounts to EUR 1,591,486.  I voted in favour of this mobilization, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which refers to belgium's application for financial assistance from the EGF following the 1,285 workers made redundant by Arcelor Mittal Liège, a company operating in the metallurgy sector. According to data provided by the Belgian authorities, the EU's share of steel production steadily decreased over the period 2007-2013, with a particularly significant decline in Europe. By contrast, Asia increased its share from 56% to 67%. There is therefore a link between redundancies and structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. That is why I voted in favour of this measure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 910 out of 1 285 workers in the area of Liège in Belgium who have been made redundant in the steel production sector. This is a particularly important issue for me as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local Bose factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community as a whole. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be made in this instance but adequate support for the workers in retraining and upskilling must be provided in any case.  The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as a justification for making workers redundant.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current economic climate and in particular the serious economic disruptions facing the steel production sector across the EU has led the Belgian Authorities to request the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to provide a coordinated package of personalised services in three main areas: redeployment, training and retraining, and promotion of entrepreneurship. A decrease in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU due to the economic crisis and a relative increase of production costs has damaged the EUʼs competitiveness in this industry and consequently led to a number of job losses and plant closures or restructuring in this sector. After studying the information provided by the Belgian authority, the Commission concluded that this application meets the conditions to deploy the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This mobilisation of the EGF is the second authorised in the same days for former steel workers – central to the economy of the Liège region – which is a further sign of the crisis in the sector and the need for joint action at Union level (already initiated with the implementation of the Commission communication entitled "Action plan for a competitive and sustainable European steel industry" , of 11 June 2013).  ArcelorMittal Liège S.A has placed 1 285 people made redundant and the Fund is expected to finance measures benefiting 910 of them.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. 1285 people lost their jobs at ArcelorMittal. The Liège workers of this former metallurgical giant are also undergoing restructuring plans as a result of the changes produced by globalization in the steel industry. This is a real shipwreck that this industry is going through in Europe, and even if the drama cannot be measured by figures, some are particularly striking: for example, between 2008 and 2013, some 280,000 workers from the European Union of 27 lost their jobs in the metallurgical industry, whose workforce rose from 1.44 million to 1.16 million people (-19.4%). ArcelorMittal is particularly representative of this industrial disaster: in 2008, the group decided to permanently close ten of the 25 blast furnaces it held in Europe, as well as close several production units. In five years, nearly 33,000 jobs have been cut, or some 25% of the total workforce. It was therefore normal for me to vote in favour of this report which will allow the WEF to finance a meagre compensation for ArcelorMittal workers.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The prolonged economic crisis has had negative effects on different sectors of activity in almost all countries of the European Union. Crude steel production in Europe has fallen by about 20% since 2013, while Asia's production share has steadily increased from 56% to 67%.  Among the EU countries, Belgium has suffered most from the fall in production, to the extent that Arcelor Mittal in Liège is facing an redundancy of around 1 200 workers. I voted in favour of Belgium's request to the European Commission and also welcomed by the Council Budget Committee to mobilise EUR 1 591 486. This financial contribution will enable the company to cope with the effects of the crisis and, above all, to support the many workers who are now unemployed. The continued use by companies of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a clear and tangible sign of the crisis, for which solutions must soon be found at all levels of decision-making.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of this measure because the European Fund set up provides support for workers who are suffering from structural changes in world trade.  The Fund may not exceed the annual ceiling of EUR 150 million (at 2011 prices). The amounts required shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a provision. The procedures that will be used to obtain the transfer of funding seem to me to be good and efficient. The dialogue between the Commission and the Authority should ensure the success of the procedural agreement, see the case of ArcelorMittal Liège S.A, which operates in the crude steel sector, which has seen a significant decrease in sales in recent years, due to the strong placing on the world market of steel from Asia and the high and incisive cost of labour and the decrease in demand in the automotive and construction sectors.  I consider the EGF's intervention to be a positive and decisive procedure aimed at supporting and defending individual European workers placed in the redundancy fund.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this question, which refers to the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium, because it aims to support, at a time of extreme precariousness, 1 285 redundant workers, carried out by the company ArcelorMittal Liège S.A., operating in the production of crude steel. I therefore believe that the intervention of this fund is right, given that European workers are suffering from structural changes in world trade and not from their own demerits.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 1 591 486 for Belgium with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of the 910 workers of the 1 285 made redundant at ArcelorMittal Liége S.A.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in relation to Belgium's application for the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant by Arcelor Mittal Liège S.A., a company operating in the metallurgical sector. The European steel industry, while boasting important strengths, is facing serious economic disturbances, mainly due to the crisis, and problems such as the relative increase in production costs, which hamper its competitiveness. The consequences of the rapid reduction in the EU-27's market share from 16% to 10% from 2007 to 2013 affected European companies operating in the sector, resulting in the loss of a large number of jobs. In the specific case of the city of Liège, the metallurgical sector, which has already been contracted in recent years, is once again being hit by the downsizing of Arcelor Mittal, with a further increase in the already high level of unemployment. The EGF's aid will be used to co-finance some of the measures envisaged by the Belgian authorities, in particular tailor-made services for the relocation, training, retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship. With this vote, I hope to promote the process of training and reintegrating workers that is fundamental to the economic recovery of the region.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report states that 1 285 employees working in the ʽManufacture of basic metalsʼ have been made redundant due to the decline in production of crude steel which has undergone serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline of the EU’s market share. In total 910 persons will participate in the co-founded personalised services which will include redeployment, training and retraining, and promotion of entrepreneurship. I have thus voted in favour of this report which seeks to redress the situation.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium applied for financial assistance from the EGF following 1 285 redundancies in ArcelorMittal Liège SA, a company operating in the production of base metals. The redundancies are linked to a serious economic disturbance, in particular a rapid decline in the share of the European steel market.  It is expected that 910 people will benefit from the measures financed. I welcomed the fact that, in order to provide workers with rapid assistance, the Belgian authorities decided to start implementing personalised services to the workers concerned on 1 January 2014, well before the decision on granting EGF support for the proposed coordinated package. I note that the redundancies at ArcelorMittal SA Liège will have enormous negative impacts on the Liège region, a region heavily dependent on the engineering sector, where the impact of the downsizing of ArcelorMittal is important as it represents 78.9% employment in the engineering sector and 14.3% in the manufacturing sector. I am therefore voting in favour, in the hope that Europe will invest adequately in innovation in order to achieve the competitiveness of the European steel sector.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium. The application was submitted following 1 285 redundancies in Arcelor Mittal Liège S.A., a company operating in the manufacture of basic metals, during and after the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 1 May 2014. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded covers three main areas: redeployment, training, and promotion of entrepreneurship (including support for enterprise creation and collective projects). I voted in favour of such measures.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – I believe that an effective and coordinated approach at Union level and adequate and specific investments are needed in order to guarantee innovation, which is the main determinant of the overall competitiveness of the Union's steel sector and which provides guarantees of job retention in Europe. I therefore welcome the proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of global trade resulting from globalisation.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is full support for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the company ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. engaged in the metallurgical sector, as well as for the other mobilisations of the fund scheduled for today to be voted on. The economic consequences of structural changes in world trade, due to globalisation, have led to a decline in the European Union's market share in the world metallurgical sector or to the flight of companies to third countries, confirming the need for intelligent recourse to the Fund. The principle of solidarity must remain at the basis of the European Union's integration process and is essential in order to cope with the changes imposed by the world economy and the effects of the crisis. We must be aware of the temporary nature of the measures offered by the EGF and, of course, find other responses in order to achieve sustainable growth in the European Union. Only with a genuine industrial policy strategy will the European Union be able to become competitive again in the world.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 1,285 employees of ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. in the steel industry, Belgium has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support people who have lost their jobs and to help them find a job or start their own businesses. The aid granted amounts to EUR 1,591,486 and covers 50% of the cost of the conversion projects that will be offered to these employees.  Since the kingdom of Belgium's request corresponds to the EGF's mobilization criteria, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The steel sector has been hit hard by the global economic crisis. In Belgium, the Liège-based company ArcelorMittal suffered significant economic losses which led it to lay off a significant number of employees, in particular due to a drop in demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors in the European Union.  The mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for which I voted must thus help the 752 workers affected by these redundancies by making them receive a financial contribution and a personalised follow-up to help them find a job.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The steel production sector in which ArcelorMittal Liège S.A operates has suffered serious economic disturbances, in particular a rapid reduction in the EU's market share. The decline in the competitiveness of the steel industry has led to the redundancies of 752 workers in ArcelorMittal Liège S.A.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted on four requests for financial contributions through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help 2,498 Belgian workers who were the victims of mass layoffs in 2013-14 by several large companies operating in Belgium in the steel, glass, and construction machinery sectors. These dismissals included 1,285 former ArcelorMittal workers in Liège.  As a Belgian and as coordinator of the ALDE group for the European Parliament's Budgets Committee, the body responsible for such requests, I have followed very closely the progress of these European financial contributions and I am pleased to have been able to give my full support. Of course, they will not replace the jobs that all these workers have lost, but I hope they can help them cope with the difficulties they are going through. The priority now is to help these workers find their jobs through appropriate training and recognition of the skills and skills they have acquired throughout their professional careers. This is what the Globalization Adjustment Fund is contributing to.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 9 December 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation. According to the data referred to by the Belgian authorities, the steel sector in which ArcelorMittal Liège S.A operated is suffering from severe economic turmoil and the EU's market share is rapidly declining.  Between 2007 and 2013, production of crude steel in the EU-27 fell from 210.1 million tonnes to 166.2 million tonnes (−20.9%; −annual growth rate of 3.8%), while production worldwide increased from 1 348.1 million tonnes to 1 649.3 million tonnes (+22.3%; +3.4% annual growth rate). As a consequence, and according to the data mentioned by the Belgian authorities, the EU's share of steel production decreased steadily over the period 2007-2013 (in 2007 EU production amounted to 16% of total world production and only 10% in 2013). By contrast, production in Asia increased significantly over the same period, from 56% to 67%. The coordinated package of services covers three main areas: re-employment, training and retraining, and the promotion of entrepreneurship.   The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the layoffs of 1,285 employees at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. The opening of borders to facilitate the movement of capital and goods has particularly affected our heavy industry and steel production, which fell by 43 million tonnes between 2007 and 2013 , while world production increased sharply to 649.3 million tonnes.  Steel production in the EU also fell by 6% between 2007 and 2013, more than any other geographical area: Asia saw its production account for 67% of world production. It is our competitors who benefit from globalization and open borders, not our industries, let alone our workers.  I voted for this eur 1,591,486 aid to Belgium to facilitate the reclassification of former ArcelorMittal employees.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The EGF helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they have lost their jobs as a result of changing global trade patterns, e.g. when a large company shuts down or a factory is moved to outside the EU, or the global financial and economic crisis. Negotiations on the renewal of the Fund concluded under the Multiannual Financial Framework Agreement and a new EGF Regulation is now in place. There are six EGF applications to be voted on from Poland, Germany and Belgium.  The ECR is opposed in principle to the use of this fund and voted against the proposals.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Only months ago we discussed possible measures for the development of steel making, and today we are already wondering how to save what has already happened unsaved. I stress that the EGF is an instrument that does not help to improve the situation, but tries to compensate somewhat for the deterioration of the situation as a result of global transformations in the economy. I would emphasise that the lack of an adequate growth policy, which in part leads to the creation of new jobs and, respectively, to the upskilling of workers and thus to their pay, cannot be replaced by the EGF. The collapse in steel production and in the metalworking sector in general is a fact, but it is mainly due to the fact that we are constantly losing markets and positions. The reason for this is that we introduce rules that make us uncompetitive. As a result, our businesses are losing out, workers are out of work, and we are dealing with this here: should we give them 100 euros per person or not? Forgive me, but this is not an approach oriented towards growth and employment growth.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I remain convinced that the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that supports workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to assist redundant workers. This is the case of the company ArcelorMittal in the steel sector. According to the Belgian authorities, there was a reduction in the EU-27 market share between 2006 and 2011 in crude steel production by -29.4 %, compared to 33.6 % in China over the same period, with an increase in China by 33.6 %. At the same time, there has been a decrease in demand for steel products in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU due to the economic crisis. The difficulties in that company are related to globalisation and the eligibility conditions for the application for EGF support have been verified. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to improve the employability of all workers through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, on equal terms of treatment. This support should be complementary to the company's responsibility under national law and not to be overtaken by other types of financial support by the Union.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to obtain their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The Belgian authorities submitted the application EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal, following 1 285 redundancies in arcelorMittal Liège S.A., a company with activities in the economic sector of the basic metallurgical industries, and 910 people are expected to participate in the measures. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, amounting to EUR 1 591 486, to reintegrate the 910 workers into the labour market for a total of 1,285 workers made redundant in the area of Liège, Belgium, by ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. , given the decrease of around 20 % in gross steel production in the EU between 2007 and 2013, which consequently led to a reduction in jobs by more than 30 %. The struggle of workers in Belgium has grown as an expression of the response to the worsening exploitation of workers and the deterioration of working conditions in belgium. The mobilisation of the fund is important to help these workers to deal with the situation they are in, but it cannot be used at all as a palliative of the political options of mass firing. The EU increasingly reveals the interests it truly serves. Those of multinationals and big capital. Not the people's.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide additional support to workers in the Belgian steel works Arcelor Mittal. The crisis in the steel industry in Europe remains a very serious matter. The challenge facing the sector is a very ambitious one, in that it must combine, on the one hand, the protection of workers from pollution-related risks and, on the other, european companies from the competition that is set them back on the world stage and from the general decline in demand for steel due to the general reduction in investment. Europe must therefore draw up a road map that will put the steel industry back at the centre of industrial policies and turn it into a sustainable and profitable sector.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission has decided to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium after 752 workers lost their jobs as a result of serious economic problems in the steel sector, in particular the rapid reduction of the European Union's market share. The number of people employed in the metallurgical industry fell by 20 % between 2008 and 2013. The decrease in production in Europe was even more pronounced than in the USA or Russia. Following the closure of the company in question, unemployment in the region has increased and the old age and low education of the redundancies make it impossible for them to find adequate employment. The amount of funding should be EUR 1 591 486.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of granting the fund € 1,591,486 for 1,285 redundancies in the metallurgical sector in Wallonia.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mobilisation report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund application EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal - Belgium, because the money from the adjustment fund should be given basically to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ ArcelorMittal in Liège sustained great economic losses due to the drop in European Union steel market shares in the period 2007-2013, undermining its competitiveness. Today I voted in favour of this report to support reintegration in the labour market of 910 workers who have been made redundant at the ArcelorMittal steel industry subsidiary in Liège.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization that, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process, there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation (e.g. closure of large enterprises or relocation of production outside the EU) or the global economic and financial crisis. That is why I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal application)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) on the 1 285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal Lisge SA, a Belgian company operating in the manufacture of base metals. Layoffs are linked to major structural changes in global trade patterns due to globalization. EGF funding of EUR 1 591 486 may contribute to the costs of reintegration measures for laid-off workers covering three main areas: redistribution, training and promotion of entrepreneurship (including support for business and collective creation projects).

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. By unblocking the contributions provided for by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union is giving a concrete sign of support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, thus making it easier for them to re-enter the labour market. I therefore welcome the adoption of the report on the case of the reorganisation of Arcelor Mittal's company.  In this case, as in many other cases, Europe intervenes only to cover the declines in competitiveness and to provide companies and workers with new tools for the conversion of skills and skills. These are certainly decisive instruments: the hope is that the efforts of new productive momentum that the EU has undertaken with the new Juncker Plan will gradually make EU companies finally stronger in the global market, thus reversing the decline that part of our industrial sector has suffered in recent years.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for an EP and Council decision mobilising a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund contribution of EUR 1 591 486 in the case of ArcelorMittal Liège SA. The crisis, again the steel industry, still mass redundancies!  The redundancy of 1 285 workers by ArcelorMittal re-proposes the serious difficulties of the European steel industry in resisting changes in the world market and the economic crisis. From 2007 to 2013, European steel production fell by 20.9% with a 6% decrease in the industrial share, in contrast to competing producer countries.  We are faced with dramatic decisions which have devastating effects in the affected regions: the steel sector in Liège has seen its employment rate reduced by 32% in 6 years, and this is a new, very serious blow to the territory.  Production costs, falling demand in related sectors, competitiveness of the sector: issues that require a coordinated and efficient European approach. In the meantime, it is the workers who foot the bill: financing through the EGF personalised retraining, retraining and vocational training services is a necessary intervention in this as in other similar events.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Negrescu report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it fully complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGAF Regulation. I welcome the fact that the EGF funding of EUR 1 591 486 will contribute to the costs of measures for the reintegration of 910 redundant workers into employment.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 1,285 employees at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. Of these, 910 are expected to take part in the reclassification measures. These layoffs are the result of the opening of borders in the field of crude steel production.  Between 2007 and 2013, crude steel production in the European Union increased from 210.1 million tonnes to 166.2 million tonnes. During the same period, world production increased from 1,348.1 million tonnes to 1,649.3 million tonnes. The report also notes that "the decline in the European Union's share of world steel production from 16% in 2007 to 10% in 2013 was greater than in the United States and Russia, while Asia experienced a very significant increase, from 56% to 67% of world production over the same period".  The globalization of trade has therefore benefited our Asian competitors, particularly Chinese, at the expense of our own industries.  I therefore voted for this aid of EUR 1,591,486 to Belgium, in order to help reclassify employees who are victims of this deindustrialization.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund for the ArcelorMittal company in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 752 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation, particularly in the metallurgical sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to offer assistance in Belgium following 1 285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal. The funding of EUR 1 591 486 will contribute to the costs of measures for the reintegration of 910 redundant workers into employment. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded covers three main areas: redeployment, training, and promotion of entrepreneurship (including support for enterprise creation and collective projects). The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of supporting 752 workers who have lost their jobs because of the decline in competitiveness of the EU’s steel industry. I strongly support the fact that money from the EGF will be spent on redeployment, training and retraining, and promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for the ArcelorMittal company in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the 752 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation, particularly in the metallurgical sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the event of the redundancies of 1,285 workers of the Belgian company ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. as it will have major implications for the metallurgical sector gravitate around the city of Lièg.  I believe that it is necessary to raise the competitiveness of the European Union steel sector with an efficient and coordinated approach that will counter the significant decline in crude steel production in the Member States and changes in global trade flows.  It is important for redundancy workers, in order to quickly reintegrate into the labour market, to recognise the abilities and skills they have adopted during their professional careers, by providing concrete support and guidance measures.  I believe that the biggest driver of global competitiveness is innovation that needs to be further stimulated, strengthened and strengthened in the form of job preservation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the layoffs of 1,285 employees at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. The opening of borders to facilitate the movement of capital and goods has particularly affected heavy industry and steel production in France, which fell by 43 million tonnes between 2007 and 2013 , while world production increased sharply to 649.3 million tonnes. Steel production in the EU also fell by 6% between 2007 and 2013, more than any other geographical area: Asia saw its production account for 67% of world production.  I voted for this eur 1,591,486 aid to Belgium to facilitate the reclassification of former ArcelorMittal employees.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Victor Negrescu's report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Arcelor Mittal in Belgium. The fund will provide a total of 1.591 million euros for 752 sacked employees of Arcelor Mittal, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ Given that application EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal, from Belgium, fulfils the eligibility criteria and the need to help overcome the rough impact of the closing of this factory on the regional economy as well as to improve the employability of dismissed workers, I endorse the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in this case. However, it must be underlined that the crisis in the European steel sector should be addressed by European institutions in a comprehensive way, stressing strategies to increase competiveness through the technology factor instead of increasing it by precariousness of labour conditions, which is unfortunately what is mainly happening in all Europe, and in particular, in the Basque Country.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Belgium following 1,285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. The fund was created to support laid-off and self-employed workers who are out of work due to major changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization or the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis. I am the the fore, the case for the adoption of this aid, amounting to EUR 1,591,486.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The job losses at ArcelorMittal were the result of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns, i.e. a rapid decline in the market share of European companies in the production of crude steel. Complicating matters was a fall in demand for steel in the automotive and construction industries in the EU as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs. The measures co-financed by the EGF would help 630 Arcelor Mittal workers find new jobs. Instruments for this are active career guidance, job-search assistance, vocational training and retraining, promotion of entrepreneurship and contributions to collective projects. The importance of these projects for those affected should not be underestimated. That is why I support this motion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made by ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. ArcelorMittal was a large employer in the Liège region of Belgium and the 1285 redundancies which have resulted from its downsizing have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to the local economy and support the workers affected.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market who have been made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. After having already done so in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, I reiterated my vote in favour of the NEGRESCU report. The EGF will provide financial support of EUR 1,591,486 to provide personalised services to laid-off workers in ArcelorMittal (Belgium) such as retraining aids, contacts with potential employers and vocational training modules. This plan will allow these laid-off employees to return to work in the steel production sector or give them the tools to adapt their skills to the new needs of the market.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union, through its active participation in the process of globalisation and its passive trade policies, is largely responsible for the economic weakening of nations and the downgrading of our productive apparatus. Considering that the allocation of these funds constitutes a just, albeit modest, reparation for the prejudices suffered by the peoples, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the layoffs of 1,285 employees at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. Globalisation, the free movement of capital and goods and their promoters are responsible for this situation: while crude steel production in the European Union fell by 20.9% between 2007 and 2013 , world production increased by 22.3%. Moreover, while the European Union's share of world steel production fell by 6% between 2007 and 2013, Asia's share rose by a very large 12%.  I would also like to point out that ArcelorMittal's share of employment in the Liège region is 78.9% in the metallurgical sector and 14.3% in the manufacturing sector. It will therefore become a disaster-stricken region.  As a result, I voted for this aid in favour of former ArcelorMittal employees. But I want to stress that the European Union is largely responsible for what happens to them.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 Application concerning the 1,285 redundancies at Arcelor Mittal Lisge SA, a Belgian company operating in the manufacture of base metals, during and after the reference period between 1 January 2014 and 1 May 2014. Layoffs are linked to major structural changes in global trade patterns due to globalization. EGF funding of EUR 1 591 486 may contribute to the costs of reintegration measures for laid-off workers covering three main areas: redistribution, training and promotion of entrepreneurship (including support for business and collective creation projects).

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization following the 1 285 redundancies in ArcelorMittal Lisge S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 24 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products') and which has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in the Union's market share. 910 people are expected to benefit from the measures, during and after the reference period from 1 January to 1 May 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. As regards the financial contribution of the Commission of Belgium on budgetary matters and good financial management of the EGF, I consider that the operations that Belgium carried out in advance of the evaluation in order to obtain rapid assistance for workers are appropriate because of their urgent nature.  The impact of globalization has made this Fund necessary, especially for the company Arcerlor Mittal Lisge S.A. in Belgium, which has suffered numerous layoffs. This phenomenon of globalisation has caused steel production in the EU to decline, in contrast to increased production of the same material in Asia. In addition, demand for steel has declined in the EU. All this has led to a loss of competitiveness in the steel sector, which the fund aims to combat, with adequate investments and measures. Actions will thus be taken aimed essentially at vocational training, entrepreneurship promotion and recycling.  In accordance with the above, and together with the special assistance given to young people without training or job competition for their better insertion into the current labour market, I believe that this proposal should be approved.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒this Report refers to the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of the Belgian company ArcelorMittal Liège, which is one of many in the steel industry with a large decline in the Share of the European Union market as a result of the financial and economic crisis. At the same time, the US and Asian countries have seen an increase in shares in the steel industry due to cheaper raw materials and labour. This resulted in a large number of redundate workers: 752 between 1 January and 1 May 2014 and a further 533 after that period.  The company's request relates to the mobilisation of almost EUR 1.6 million. The Coordinated Package of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is intended to co-finance active measures divided into three groups: redeployment, training and retraining, and the promotion of self-employment, with a view to re-integrating workers into the labour market. In this case, the number of people to be covered by the measures is 910, of which 803 are in the 30-54 age group. I support the Mobilisation Report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as it aims to co-finance measures that are of utmost releasm for the steel industry, as workers are trained for a narrow area where they can no longer find employment as production facilities are shutting down.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I could not support this Negrescu report, as it went into the package with previous reports on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Reducing the share of STEEL produced in the EU on world markets from 16% in 2007 to 10% in 2013, while steel production in the world has increased from 1,348.1 million tonnes to 1,649.3 million tonnes, is a clear signal that the European Union is not taking sufficient measures to increase its competitiveness. Although the granting of subsidies and contributions to the impacts of this is a useful aid, it is not a systemic solution, but only to save the negative situation that has arisen. However, the people of the EU need job security for a full life, so the EU-wide focus on increasing competitiveness must be constantly focused.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, since the Belgian authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to the affected workers on 1 January 2014 , well before the final decision on EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for it. This mobilization of the Fund will support 1,285 licensees of the metal industry in Belgium because of the economic crisis.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal and welcome that the resolution ‘stresses the need for an efficient and coordinated approach at Union level in order to reverse the decrease in competitiveness of the Union’s steel sector; emphasises the need for proper and targeted investments with the aim of ensuring innovation as the main driver for global competitiveness of the Union’s steel sector and a guarantee of keeping the jobs in Europe’.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the EGF is to facilitate the rapid reintegration of redundant workers through personalised accompanying actions such as information sessions, counselling and guidance, skills assessment, vocational training, as well as recruitment incentives. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the EGF to the total amount of EUR 1 591 486 in favour of Belgium and the 1 285 workers of Arcelor Mittal, a company operating in the metallurgical sector.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The need to ensure the overall competitiveness of the sector, as well as the desire to contribute to the preservation of jobs in Europe, has led me to welcome the Negrescu report, which calls for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of 752 workers made redundant at ArcelorMittal, a Belgian metallurgical industry.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. Due to the fact that the steel industry has been exposed to serious disruptions to economic activity and a rapid decline in the EU's market share, there have been major structural changes in world trade patterns and, as a result, numerous redundancies in this sector. As all the criteria for mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund are met, this motion received my positive vote. Nevertheless, we need to consider what measures need to be taken to strengthen this sector again.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of retraining people who have lost their jobs after failing to withstand competition from Asian countries, the Belgian steel company ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. has laid off 1 285 employees. The funds are necessary to solve social problems as quickly as possible, to retrain and return to the labour market of people of working age.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Belgium continues to suffer the full brunt of the European Union's lack of an industrial strategy. After France, Arcelor Mittal laid off nearly half of its employees last year at its Liège site before closing completely by 2017. It provided more than 78% of local jobs in the steel sector. However, the Liège site made 1.39 billion euros in profits in 2010, for example.  This globalization aid fund plays its destructive role. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. When will we see the beginning of the start of safeguarding the European steel industry? I am voting against this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Belgium to give this aid to belgium, which submitted the EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 1 285 redundancies in ArcelorMittal Liège S.A., a company with activities in the economic sector classified in division 24 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Basic metallurgical industries'), with participation in the measures of 910 persons expected during and after the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 1 May 2014.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the EU’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 910 workers in Belgium due to the decline in market share in the manufacture of base metals industry.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I applaud the adoption of the decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In fact, nearly 1.6 million euros have been allocated to finance the retraining, training and upgrading of entrepreneurship. This sum is intended for 752 people whose dismissal occurred between 1 January 2014 and 1 May 2014 due to a decrease in steel production in Europe, mainly due to the general increase in world production and a decrease in demand (particularly in the automotive sector).

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for Belgium. The application was submitted following 1 285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A., a company operating in the manufacture of basic metals, during and after the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 1 May 2014.
