The EGF funding will contribute to the costs of measures for the reintegration of 910 redundant workers into employment.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  I am voting in favour of this report on the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 591 486 from the EGF in favour of Belgium. It concerns 752 redundancies during the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 1 May 2014 and 533 after that period. I would also point out that, according to data reported by the Belgian authorities, the steel production sector in which ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. operates has suffered serious economic disruptions, in particular an accelerated decline in the EU's market share, thus deserving the best attention of the EGF.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. Once again, the European Union is playing the arsonist fireman by trying to put out the fire that it has started itself. It will thus partially compensate for the damage it causes by its ultraliberal ideology. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to shock anyone.  I am voting for this aid to employees so as not to further penalise the victims of European ultraliberalism.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation with the exception of two where the number of employees is lower than that specified in the Regulation. There is a precedent for this and Parliament supports their applications.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of 1.6 million euros to support the reclassification of 1,285 employees laid off by ArcelorMittal Be in the Liège region due to the brutal crisis in the steel industry (steel production fell by 20% in Europe between 2007 and 2013, while it increased by 22% globally over the same period).

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted five reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these five reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release 1.6 million euros from this fund to 910 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of Arcelor Mittal in Belgium.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers of the company Arcelor Mittal, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade. According to the data indicated by the Belgian authorities, the steel production sector in which Arcelor Mittal Liège S.A operates has suffered serious economic disturbances, in particular a rapid reduction in the EU's market share. The effects of these changes in trade flows have been aggravated by other factors, such as the decrease in steel demand in the EU automotive and construction sectors as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental constraints, etc.). These factors have undermined the competitiveness of the EU steel industry and have led to the loss of a large number of steel jobs in recent years due to the closure and restructuring of factories by various steel producers in Europe. The European aid approved today will be used to co-finance three main sectors: retraining, training and retraining, and the promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it proposes to compensate, through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, all the collateral victims of certain economic operations generated on a global scale. As such, I fully support all actions aimed at strengthening cohesion within our continent by protecting its workers and strengthening the social dimension of the European project.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This application relates to the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 1 591 486 in favour of Belgium.  Given that the European Union has a duty to provide legislative and budgetary instruments providing additional support to workers affected by market changes due to globalisation, I felt it appropriate to express my agreement with the Negrescu report, which calls for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of 1 285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A., a company operating in the metallurgical sector.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the implementation of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - EGF BE/ArcelorMittal's request as rapporteur in the European Parliament. The implementation of this project will enable the identification and facilitation of the reintegration of a significant number of workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic crisis.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on demand from Belgium following the redundancy of 1,285 workers from ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. The redundancies took place during the reference period January to May 2014 as a result of serious economic disturbances, in particular the rapid decline in the Union's market share. The competitiveness of the Union's steel industry has been affected by declining demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors in the EU, as a consequence of the economic crisis and the relative increase in production costs (raw materials, energy, environmental requirements, etc.). These factors have led to the loss of a large number of jobs in this sector in recent years as a result of the closure of plants and the restructuring of several steel producers in Europe. An effective and coordinated approach at Union level is needed to reverse the trend of decreasing the competitiveness of the Union steel sector. As the S&D coordinator for industry, research and energy, I stress the need for a Union strategy on European industry. Viable solutions are needed for both the steel industry and the metal products sector in order to maintain competitiveness and jobs across the EU.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the material and formal conditions for mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund are in place in this case and I hope that the promised financial resources will give the employees and workers concerned a view for the future. I therefore hope that there are also positive aspects to the economic prosperity of the region.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution to allocate EUR 1 591 486 from the EGF to Belgium, which will allow the reintegration of 1 285 people who became unemployed as a result of redundancy. Unemployment in the European Union increased dramatically as a result of the economic crisis. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market; that Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission; that the adoption of the EGF Regulation reflects the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the reintroduction of the crisis mobilisation criterion, the increase in the efficiency of the processing of applications for EGF assistance within the Commission and by Parliament and the Council obtained by reducing the time taken for evaluation and approval, the extension of eligible actions and beneficiaries to the self-employed and young people , as well as the financing of incentives for the creation of own businesses; that the request for assistance meets the eligibility conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Belgium claimed that the steel production sector, operated by ArcelorMittal Liège SA, experienced a serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in EU market share. Between 2007 and 2013, crude steel production in the EU-27 decreased by 20.9%, while globally production increased by 22.3%. As a result, between 2007 and 2013, the EU's share of steel production continued to decrease from 16% of global steel production in 2007 to 10% in 2013. On the other hand, there is a large increase in Asia's share over the same period, from 56% to 67%. Between 2008 and 2013, the number of workers employed in the metallurgy industry in the EU-27 decreased by 19.4%. The application applies to 1,285 workers who were a technological surplus in ArcelorMittal Liège SA who worked in the economic sector, and 752 workers who were technologically redundant in businesses during the four-month reference period. The proposed EGF contribution to the coordinated personalised service package is EUR 1 591 486, representing 60% of the total cost of the proposed measures to ensure a financial contribution for application.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help Belgium with a surplus in the steel sector with €1,591,486. Since the start of the EGF in 2007, four EGF applications for the steel sector have been registered. So far, industry has often been sacrificed at the expense of service and financial activities in Europe, and it is time for the industry to regain the support it deserves given the contribution it has to economic development. The application applies to 1 285 technology surplus workers in ArcelorMittal Liège SA who worked in the economic sector of NKD Division 24 ("Metal Production"). Member states need to show solidarity towards each other when needed, and I am pleased that they have shown this today in this example.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. find a new job. At a time when Europe is facing a financial, economic and social crisis and unemployment as a key consequence, the European Union should use all means at its disposal to react, in particular as regards ensuring support for people who have lost their jobs.  Belgium applied to EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal for a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 1,285 workers at ArcelorMittal Liege S.A. engaged in metal production activity. The redundancies in the company are linked to major structural changes in global trade flows due to globalisation, as crude steel production in the EU-27 decreased from 210.1 million tonnes to 1662.2 million tonnes between 2007 and 2013. The layoffs are also expected to have a very negative impact on liege province, which is highly dependent on the metallur sector.  I therefore support Rapporteur Victor Negrescu's report on the mobilisation of €1,591,486, helping redundant workers to train and retrain for new jobs in line with the real needs of the labour market in the affected region.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Also in the case of the application submitted for redundancies by ArcelorMittal, another Belgian steel production company, it is right to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers made redundant as a result of the crisis affecting this sector, as we have seen in the previous case. The service of personalized services to be cofinanced covers three main areas: retraining, training and retraining and the promotion of entrepreneurship. It is important to stress that the Belgian authorities have confirmed that the proposed actions will not receive any financial support from other Union funds or financial instruments and that any double funding will be prevented and that they will be complementary to actions financed by the Structural Funds.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The steel sector experienced a sharp decline in the European Union during the 2000s. The main causes are increasing international competition, the competitiveness of Chinese steel companies - much lower labour costs - and the sharp decline in steel demand in Europe. This context, to which can be added the repercussions of the economic crisis, has led to the closure of several production sites in Europe, and particularly in Belgium.  With this in mind, I support Belgium's request to mobilise the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I would also like to reiterate the importance of this European fund in maintaining the competitiveness of European workers by offering them the opportunity to reintegrate into the labour market and to be able to train in other sectors.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A., which operates in division 24 of NACE Rev. 2 (Basic Metallurgical Industries). According to the Commission, the application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is found, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as the Union's market share in the steel production sector fell from 16 % in 2007 to 10 % in 2013 and that there has been a reduction in demand for steel products in the automotive and automotive and construction in the EU and a relative increase in production costs, and, on the other hand, that such redundancies will have very negative repercussions in the Liège region, highly dependent on the metallurgical sector and, in particular, arcelorMittal, and the part of this company in local employment in the metallurgical sector is 78.9 % and 14.3 % in the processing sector. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favor of this application because it meets the required requirements. It relates to support for 752 redundancies during the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 1 May 2014 and 533 after that period. Between 2007 and 2013, crude steel production in the EU-27 decreased from 210.1 million tonnes to 166.2 million tonnes (− 20.9 %; annual growth rate of − 3.8 %), while worldwide production increased from 1 348.1 million tonnes to 1 649.3 million tonnes (+ 22.3 %; annual growth rate of + 3.4 %). The decrease in production was more significant in Europe than in the United States and Russia. On the other hand, there was a sharp increase in Asia's share from 56% to 67% over the same period. Several factors have undermined the competitiveness of the EU steel industry and led to the loss of a large number of jobs in the sector in recent years, due to the closure of production units and the implementation of restructuring measures carried out by several steel manufacturers in Europe.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. A Europe that is close to its citizens is also and above all a Europe that acts when they are directly affected by economic redundancy. This is the case today with the activation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) mobilisation mechanism voted by the European Parliament this lunchtime: 1,285 laid-off workers from Arcelor Mittal will receive a total of EUR 1,591,486 in aid. This fund is the European participation up to 60% of the needs needed to accompany former employees of Arcelor Mittal in their job search and more broadly in their career reorientation. It cannot be used to keep businesses in business, to help them modernize or to restructure.  As is the case in most economic layoffs, people working in a sector that is facing stiff global competition are affected.  A necessary but not enough boost for the preservation of European industrial policy, one of the main vectors of economic health of the Union from which every Member State and every citizen can benefit.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of legislative and budgetary instruments to provide complementary support to the most diverse sectors has proved to be a positive measure in the transition and adjustment of Member States to the era of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool in that it can serve to reintegrate people and businesses into the global market. In this case, and in view of the situation presented, the aid provided to Belgium is relevant.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 591 486 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 1 285 workers who have lost their jobs at the Arcelor Mittal plant based in Liege, Belgium, and engaged in steel production as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalisation and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  The steel manufacturing sector has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in EU market share, which has been exacerbated by other factors such as declining demand for steel in the automotive and construction sectors as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include vocational reorientation, training and recycling activities for workers. While these aids are not in themselves capable of alleviating the drama of unemployment in the European steel sector, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned into work.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the redundancies at ArcelorMittal in Liège, as these contributions are a valuable aid in enabling the retraining and reclassification of workers, thanks in particular to training tailored to the opportunities of the job market.  Nevertheless, the job losses in many sectors are a painful reminder that these aids are not a miracle cure and that it is essential to pursue a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. More broadly, Europe needs to put in place a real coordinated industrial policy focused on creating sustainable jobs in sectors of the future.  In addition, weASee procedures should be accelerated and simplified to enable laid-off workers to cope with difficulties as soon as they arise.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report in order to unlock financial and professional assistance following the 1,285 redundancies at Arcelor Mittal Liège S.A. due to serious economic disruptions, including a sharp decline in the European Union's market share in the steel sector. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will make a 60% contribution to retraining, training and promoting entrepreneurship. Once again, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund proves its full usefulness, so I voted for this report in order to continue our commitments to a fairer And closer Europe to the citizens.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Fund, which offers concrete help to several Belgian workers belonging to a company that is facing the challenges of the global market with difficulty.  This is also a united Europe.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns, in particular by supporting their reintegration into the labour market. Whereas Belgium has applied to the EGF following the dismissal of 1285 employees of ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. and that it meets the eligibility criteria, I am in favour of allocating this financial contribution from the EGF, amounting to EUR 1 591 486, as a means of minimising the harmful effects that this has on the level of unemployment and the economy of that country , especially in this steel production sector, which has been faced with a decrease in demand for steel products in the automotive and construction sectors.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of protecting workers.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which grants EUR 1,591,486 under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to help more than 1,000 workers laid off by Arcelor Mittal in Belgium. Arcelor Mittal, like other European steel industries, has had to deal with the severe economic disruptions in the steel production sector in recent years.  Between 2006 and 2011, crude steel production in the European Union decreased by 14.1%, while it increased worldwide by 21.6%. Europe has lost 30% market share to Chinese competitors in particular. In addition, other factors have exacerbated this industrial crisis: falling demand in the automotive and construction sectors and rising production costs (particularly due to environmental constraints and energy prices). These different constraints have caused European companies to lose their competitiveness. Belgium proposes to use this money to co-finance personalised services in three areas: retraining, training, and the enhancement of entrepreneurship.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Belgium's application to ArcelorMittal, which operated in the metal industry, complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. It affects a total of 1 285 unemployed persons. With regard to this report, I am particularly pleased that it stresses the importance of an effective and coordinated approach at EU level, particularly with regard to measures to increase the competitiveness of the EU. It is particularly important to invest in innovation, which is likely to increase competitiveness. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. I agree with this request for the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because in this case employment must be safeguarded. However, we note that the Union's recommendations do not go in the direction of a fair globalisation allowing States to protect their businesses and jobs as do other major powers.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization following the 1 285 redundancies in ArcelorMittal Lisge S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 24 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products') and which has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in the Union's market share. 910 people are expected to benefit from the measures, during and after the reference period from 1 January to 1 May 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for application EGF/2014/012. Belgium submitted their application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 1 285 redundancies at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. The company operates in the NACE 2 Division 24 ʽManufacture of basic metalsʼ and the redundancies are linked to serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in the Union’s market share.  This is the third application to be examined under the 2015 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 591 486 from the EGF for Belgium. It concerns 752 redundancies in the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 1 May 2014 and 533 after that period. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded covers three main areas: redeployment, training and retraining, and promotion of entrepreneurship. The UK has never made an application under this Fund. UK workers receive none of this support therefore.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. It is important that this assistance to redundant workers is dynamic and available as soon as possible and in the most efficient way possible. The application for a financial contribution submitted by Belgium to the aid to ArcelorMittal Liege SA, in which 1285 redundancies were made in 2014, fulfils the eligibility criteria. The company's layoffs were the result of major structural changes in global trade due to globalisation, with steel production falling by 20.9% between 2007 and 2013, while increasing globally by 22.3%, and also due to the decline in steel demand in the automotive and construction industries. The layoffs are likely to have major negative consequences in the Region, which is highly dependent on the metal processing industry. As the co-financed services package covers three important areas: over-employment, training and retraining and promoting entrepreneurship, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 910 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation at ArcelorMittal based in Liège, a subsidiary of the global ArcelorMittal group operating in the steel production sector.  The Liège site has had to deal in recent years with two announcements of the desire to close some production activities, in order to concentrate the site's activity on some strategic production lines. In fact, due to the rapid decrease in the European Union's market share in the steel production market in the period 2007-2013, the ArcelorMittal site in Liège suffered serious economic disturbances that compromised the competitiveness of the site. The aid of EUR 1 591 486 provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in addition to the funds already allocated by the Wallonia region, will help to cover part of the costs of assistance and support in job search, vocational training, support for business creation and other programmes aimed at reintegration into the labour market for 910 beneficiary workers.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution since Belgium applied to EGF/2014/012 BE/ArcelorMittal for an EGF financial contribution following the dismissal of 1,285 workers at ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. engaged in activities under section 24 of the NACE 2 classification 'Metal production'. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation and Belgium is entitled to a financial contribution under the Regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will mobilise resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - In accordance with point 13. As of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on cooperation on budgetary matters and on good financial management, Belgium applied for financial contributions from the EGF for the dismissal of 1,285 arcelor Mittal Liege S.A. workers, which are linked to changes at international level, and supplemented it with additional data.  I support this report because it is a situation envisaged by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund itself, which aims to enable redundante workers to reintegrate into the labour market if its cause is the protracted or new global financial and economic crisis foreseen in Regulation (EC) No 546/2009. The coordinated package of personalised services for which co-financing is requested includes redeployment of workers, training and retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship.  In view of this factual situation, I support the acceptance of the Belgian request for mobilisation in the case of ArcelorMittal.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because, as with the previous vote, there are redundancies in the steel industry for which european Union policy, which leads to drastically higher electricity prices, bears the unquestionable blame.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report because it provides a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, after 1285 redundancies were made redundant in the Belgian company ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. due to severe economic disturbances and a rapid decline in the Union market share. Redundancies are linked to major structural changes in global trade flows due to globalisation, with steel production in the EU declining between 2007 and 2013, while production has increased globally. The EU's share of steel production has thus fallen from 16 % of global production in 2007 to 10 % in 2013, which is considerably more than in the United States and Russia, while Asia's market share has grown sharply over the same period. I also supported the report because the package covers three main areas: over-employment, training and retraining and promoting entrepreneurship.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour! The support measures had been implemented as soon as the redundancies were announced in consultation with the social partners and in partnership with the regional public employment services. In the meantime, we have pleaded with Commissioners Thyssen and Malmstrom for greater coordination so that international trade agreements do not completely destroy European industrial employment.  These 5.2 million are important to the Walloon economic fabric. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves should not be the rule. It should be remembered that this aid was made indispensable because an international industrialist wanted to play with the destiny of workers, treating them with disdain and great disrespect. Europe must send a strong message to all the Lakshmi Mittals of the world that in Europe there are no castes or untouchables. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think that it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. ArcelorMittal was a major employer in the region and because the steel production sector faced serious economic disruption, this led to 1 285 redundancies. This fund will be used to develop appropriate tools to reintegrate these workers in the job market, including individual job-search assistance, training and promotion of entrepreneurship. I believe it will set the path to durable and long-term employment in the Walloon region.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Because of globalisation measures are needed to adapt workers to the labour market and therefore I support the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for cooperation budgetary matters and sound financial management to help the Belgian company ArcelorMittal, in order to improve the training of their employees and thus ensure the viability of the company in the long term.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European Globalisation Adjustment Funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultraliberal policies applied in this European Union, which are unable to defend neither the peoples who make up it nor the companies that support it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund for the ArcelorMittal company in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 752 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation, particularly in the metallurgical sector. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Belgium's request for financial aid following the placement of 1 285 redundant workers at ArcelorMittal Liège, a company operating in the steel sector. This sector has suffered a sharp decline in market share at European level as a result of major structural changes in international trade, aggravated by the repercussions of the economic crisis and rising energy costs. Although I am convinced that it is necessary to intervene with a long-term strategy in order to address the causes of the problems, rather than the symptoms, I wanted to support this measure, which will nevertheless facilitate the retraining and reintegration into working life of workers in difficulty.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization following the 1 285 redundancies in ArcelorMittal Lisge S.A., a company operating in the economic sector classified in division 24 of NACE Rev. 2 ('Metallurgy; manufacture of iron, steel and ferroalloy products') and which has suffered serious economic disruption, in particular a rapid decline in the Union's market share. 910 people are expected to benefit from the measures, during and after the reference period from 1 January to 1 May 2014. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose of this report is to assist the 910 workers with a total of 1285 workers made redundant in the Liège area of Belgium by ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. To this end, it proposes mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 591 486 for reintegration into the labour market. The report notes "major structural changes in global trade patterns resulting from globalisation", given the decrease of around 20% in gross steel production in the EU between 2007 and 2013, which has consequently led to a reduction in jobs by more than 30 %. The struggle of workers in Belgium has grown as an expression of the response to the worsening exploitation of workers and the deterioration of working conditions in belgium. The mobilisation of the fund is important to help these workers face the situation they are in, but it cannot be used at all as a palliative of the political options of mass firing.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. Since "ArcelorMittal" fulfils all the conditions for mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the application for the same must only be supported. The steel sector in particular has been hit hard by the crisis and the resulting declines in the sales markets of the automotive and construction sectors.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. By releasing this application, the EU Commission is transferring just over EUR 1.5 million to ArcelorMittal Belgium for the reference year 2014. On 7/11/2014, Handelsblatt writes about the profits of the company concerned: "The world's largest steel producer ArcelorMittal earned more in the third quarter, mainly thanks to a strong recovery in its European business. Earnings before taxes, interest, depreciation and amortization rose 11 percent year-on-year to 1.91 billion U.S. dollars (1.53 billion euros), the group said in Luxembourg. That was more than analysts expected. Revenues rose 2 percent to 20.1 billion dollars. The bottom line was a profit of 22 million dollars." These figures are likely to be much higher, as ArcelorMittal will also have benefited from the tax arrangements with Luxembourg. I am pleased with the profit development of the arcelorMittal steel group and find it incomprehensible that the EU is (again!) using the EGF in Belgium. I am voting against.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EAGGF) with a view to allocating EUR 1.5 million for the retraining of the 1,258 workers made redundant from the Arcelor Mittal plant in Liège, Belgium. The availability of these workers occurred as a result of the restructuring of the activity at the Liège plant, a process that took place due to major changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation.  I hope that the conversion programmes will be successful with the support of the EAGGF, a tool that has already proven its effectiveness.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in my vote on this report, concerning the financial support of workers, of the steel producer Arcelor Mittal Liège S.A. from Belgium. The EGF is established to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of global structural changes in trade, and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. This case concerns a request to support 1285 dismissed persons and fulfils the eligibility conditions laid down in the relevant Regulation. The competent authorities submitted the request on 22 July 2014 and the Commission notified its assessment on 9 December 2014. The redundancies at Arcelor Mittal Liège S.A are linked to major structural changes in the shape of world trade due to globalisation, as between 2007 and 2013 crude steel production in the EU decreased by 20,9 %, while worldwide production increased by 22,3 %.  In Liege alone, the contraction of metallurgy contributed to a 32 % reduction in employment in the sector.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report aims to mobilise an amount from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 1 591 486 to reintegrate the 910 workers into the labour market for a total of 1285 workers made redundant in the area of Liège, Belgium, by ArcelorMittal Liège S.A. , given the decrease of around 20 % in gross steel production in the EU between 2007 and 2013, which consequently led to a reduction in jobs by more than 30 %. The struggle of workers in Belgium has grown as an expression of the response to the worsening exploitation of workers and the deterioration of working conditions in belgium. Mobilising the EFSC is important to help these workers to deal with the situation they are in, but it cannot be used at all as a solution to the problems resulting from the political options of mass firing and the economic options for contraction of the market that inevitably lead to the slowdown of the economy.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of ArcelorMittal Liège S.A., as the redundancies in this company will have very unfavourable consequences for the whole region. The share of arcelormittal's local employment was 78.9% for the metal sector and 14.3% for the entire manufacturing sector. The Lieška region has traditionally been highly dependent on the metal processing industry, which has shrunk in recent years from 40 companies (6193 jobs) in 2007 to 35 enterprises (4187 jobs) in 2012. Employment in this sector decreased by 32 %. These are the consequences of major structural changes in global trade flows, including reduced steel demand in the automotive and construction sectors as a result of the economic crisis and the relative increase in production costs (materials, energy prices, environmental constraints...). Steel production in the EU-27 therefore decreased from 210.1 million tonnes to 166.2 million tonnes between 2007 and 2013. Steel production in Europe decreased significantly more than in the USA and Russia (from 16 % of world production in 2007 to 10 % in 2013), while Asia's market share increased sharply over the same period, from 56 % to 67 %.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the 1,030 redundancies in Caterpillar Belgium S.A., (company operating in division 28 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.c.o.p.) which took place during the reference period from 1 January to 30 April 2014 and after that period , due to a decline in demand in Europe. 630 people are expected to take action. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving Belgium's application EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar to mobilise funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by the Belgian authorities in the wake of the 1030 redundancies made by Caterpillar. This fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Fund finances individually adapted measures for the reintegration of jobseekers, promotes self-employment and business start-ups, and grants mobility allowances and allowances for disadvantaged or older workers. The redundancies of the company can be explained by the fact that the EU market share fell sharply, while the Asian market increased over the same period. Similarly, the decline in demand for steel due to the economic crisis and the rise in production costs have affected the competitiveness of the steel industry in the EU. It is therefore gratifying that the EU has accepted Belgium's request and is providing funds to support the redundant workers, in the hope of helping them to achieve lasting, long-term and therefore stable employment through the measures taken.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 1,030 employees at Caterpillar Belgium S.A.  These layoffs are not only caused by the drop in demand in Europe but above all by the company's relocations to countries where production costs are lower. These are the direct negative consequences of the call for foreign investment in the territory of the Union, the sole purpose of which is profitability, without any attachment to the territory and its people. I therefore voted in favour of this EUR 1,222,854 aid to Belgium, in order to help reclassify Caterpillar employees who are doubly victims of globalisation: on the one hand, they are subject to unfair competition from third countries; on the other hand, they are directly victims of relocations.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Belgium, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, although I have some reservations about the relevance of the timetable for the implementation of this tool, I support its primary vocation. For my part, the adjustment to globalization should be achieved upstream or at the beginning of the company's financial problems rather than at the time of accounting for the number of licensees.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Belgian purposes in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Caterpillar, which operates in steel production. Caterpillar has been hit hard by the declining demand for this type of product in Europe, which has led to a huge transfer of production capacity to third countries. A total of EUR 1 222 854 is intended to be allocated to 663 redundant workers from the EGF. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. If I voted in favour of the release of this aid for employees who are victims of ultraliberalism, I continue to denounce the inconsistency of this European Union, which behaves like an arsonist fireman.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested the support of the EGF after the dismissal of more than 1000 workers following the company's decision to relocate a significant part of the production. Europe has released 1.2 million euros to help 630 workers.  I can only welcome this aid, which somewhat offsets the effects of blind liberalism and the unfortunate strategic choices of management. These amounts will increase support for the training and socio-professional reintegration of laid-off workers.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to alleviate the problems arising from the 1,030 redundancies in Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which occurred during the reference period from 1 January to 30 April 2014 and after that period , due to a decline in demand in Europe. 630 people are expected to take action, and I hope this will help alleviate the situation.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following 1,030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A., a company under the "Manufacturing of Machinery and Equipment n.c.a.", of which 630 people are expected to participate in the measures. We are being asked to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to the tune of EUR 1 222 854, and I am therefore in favour of this request.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in favour of Caterpillar's 1,030 redundancies in Belgium.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have today voted in favour of this report. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, globalisation is not the only reason why so many jobs have been lost in Europe. The EU itself has decided on the destructive austerity policy. It's got to stop. We need an expansive policy, with public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 222 854 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 1 030 workers who have lost their jobs in Caterpillar Belgium S.A., based in Gosselines, Belgium, and dedicated to the manufacture of machinery and equipment, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  Caterpillar's Asian sales share has doubled between 2007 and 2013, while Caterpillar Gosselines' main market, which is the European Union, depends on public and private investments in infrastructure in Europe, which have declined in recent years. The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include vocational reorientation activities, training and recycling and promotion of entrepreneurship. While these aids alone are not able to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Belgian charleroi region, they do provide good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to support workers made redundant from Caterpillar in Belgium and to help them return to the labour market. Caterpillar has been hit hard by the declining demand for this type of product in Europe, which has led to a huge transfer of production capacity to third countries. Caterpillar Plant Gosselies specializes in the production of machinery assembly, components, soldered assemblies and structures. Its products are intended solely for the Construction and Mining sectors of Europe. This situation has led to changes in the plant in these sectors and has been influenced by fluctuations in production raw materials. Caterpillar's plants are close to their markets, which explains the link between the changes in the European and global markets and the reduction of the Gosselies plant workforce. Since 2007, caterpillar group has established factories in emerging economies Asia and Latin America and its growth is mainly linked to these markets.  The European Parliament supports the granting of support from the European Globalisation Fund to help workers integrate into the labour market.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The shutdown of Caterpillar will have an extremely negative effect on the Charleroi region. It will be difficult for laid-off workers to find a new job in unfavourable economic conditions as they are low-skilled. 18% of redundancy workers who will be covered by the measures will face the risk of exclusion from the labour market, as this is an age group of 55-64 years of age. That is why I support the EP's decision to approve EGF funding.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Caterpillar because I think that we need to help our companies on European soil to cope with the challenges of globalisation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium submitted the EGF/2014/011BE/Caterpillar application for a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the dismissal of 1,030 employees. These layoffs are directly related to the increase in imports of equipment products from Asia.  Caterpillar is also paying for the construction and mining crisis in Europe and the increasing difficulties of winning international markets against the Chinese and Americans. Located in the Charleroi region, which has the lowest employment rate in Belgium (52.26%), the Gosselies site was a structuring hub for the territory's employment pool. The layoffs will once again aggravate the social situation of the territory, which is already in the grip of very serious economic difficulties. Without much illusion, I voted in favour of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for sacked Caterpillar employees.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the onset of the economic crisis, Europeans have given up buying new cars. The main sectors that suffered were that of car production, but also that of manufacturing parts, assemblies and welded structures. An affected company is also the Caterpillar subsidiary in Gosselies, Belgium. The parent company has opened factories in Asia and Latin America, and the increases are due solely to these markets, but also to the global growth of Asian economies, especially China and India. By contrast, in Europe, things didn't go as well. Because there was no more investment in infrastructure, the market for Catepillal Gosselies declined dramatically, so 663 workers from this subsidiary were laid off. The company is requesting EUR 1 222 854 from the EDF for the reintegration into the labour market of these people. I voted in favour of this report because the amount requested represents an 'investment' in the 633 workers and in their chance to reintegrate and participate effectively in economic development.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. MEPs voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked Caterpillar employees in Belgium. The amount allocated is EUR 1,222,854. Dismissed workers will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job.  Belgium's request justifies an intervention by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund given the importance of Asian competition in the equipment manufacturing sector.  I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which refers to the question concerning 1030 workers made redundant by Caterpillar Belgium S.A., a company operating in the field of the manufacture of machinery and equipment. Due to considerably higher production costs in Europe than in Asia, Caterpillar has drawn up a business plan to reduce operations in Belgium, causing the loss of 1030 jobs and causing a direct negative impact on several downstream producers for which Caterpillar is the main supplier. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to make a financial contribution in response to the question.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 630 out of 1 030 workers in the Charleroi area in Belgium in the manufacture of machinery and equipment sector. This is a particularly important issue for me as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local Bose factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community as a whole. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be made in this instance but adequate support for the workers in retraining and upskilling must be provided in any case.  The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as a justification for making workers redundant.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad to note that the request by the Belgian authorities to mobilise funds under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) has met all the eligible criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation. Regretfully, the redundancies are expected to have a huge negative impact on the region. The region is already facing a very difficult labour market situation due to its over-reliance on traditional industrial employment and lack of new industries. The report stresses that in this particular environment, it is important that the coordinated package of personalised services improves the employability of all the workers by being adapted not only to the needs of the dismissed workers, but also to the actual business environment of the region. I am also glad to note that this report also highlights the need for the future use of the provisions of the EGF Regulation to support young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs) in this region. I believe that the emphasis on the employability of young people in the region is essential for a healthy and prosperous economic future of this region. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the Charleroi region, the unemployment rate is among the lowest in Wallonia and many of the unemployed are poorly qualified. This mobilisation of the Fund is in favour of 1 030 redundancies of Caterpillar Belgium S.A., operating in the manufacture of machinery and equipment n.c.a. (not otherwise classifiable), a declining market in Europe as a result of lower production costs of equipment manufacturing in Asia.  The 2009 crisis further weakened the European construction and mining sectors, i.e. Caterpillar's most important buyers, and the Charleroi area is particularly affected by its over-reliance on traditional industrial employment and the absence of new industries.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which offers a small compensation to the 1,030 Caterpillar employees who have undergone a devastating restructuring plan. Caterpillar is the world's leading manufacturer of machinery and accessories for the construction and operation of mines. However, this is a sector that has been hit hard by the decline in demand for this type of product in Europe, which has led to the relocation of a large part of production capacity to third countries.  Once again the myth of happy globalization is falling apart; Since 2007, the Caterpillar Group has established plants in emerging economies in Asia and Latin America, areas that are benefiting from the growth of the construction sector. On the other hand, this demand has fallen sharply in Europe, with orders falling by 40% in 2011 according to the Belgian authorities.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis has not spared even one of Caterpillar's most important locations in Europe, the one located in Gosselies in Belgium, a company that has seen a drastic and constant reduction in production volume since 2009: already in 2009 its production fell by 75%. The loss of competitiveness, mainly due to production costs, has led to an redundancy of 1 030 workers and the attempts made over the years by the company, whose crisis will unfortunately also have repercussions on companies operating in the related sector, have not been worth anything. If we in Europe want to maintain our productive fabric, we will have to rethink a more effective European industrial policy in order to preserve the industrial sector from competition from third countries with very low labour costs. I voted in favour of Belgium's request to the European Commission, and also welcomed by the Council's Budget Committee, to mobilise EUR 1 222 854.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of this measure because the European Fund set up provides support for workers who are suffering from structural changes in world trade. The Fund may not exceed the annual ceiling of EUR 150 million (at 2011 prices). The amounts required shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a provision. The procedures that will be used to obtain the transfer of funding seem to me to be good and efficient.  The dialogue between the Commission and the Authority should ensure the success of the procedural agreement: see the case of Caterpillar in Gosselies, which specialises in vehicle assembly, the production of welded components and structures, which has been severely affected by the decline in demand in Europe, which has led to the relocation of a significant part of production capacity to third countries.  According to the Belgian authorities, Caterpillar's production facilities are located close to their markets, which explains the reduction in Gosselies employees. Since 2007, caterpillar group has built plants in Asia and Latin America. Caterpillar's sales in Asia more than doubled. The intervention of the European Fund is a positive and decisive procedure aimed at supporting and defending individual European workers placed in the redundancy fund.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this application, which refers to the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium, with the aim of contributing to the 1 030 workers made redundant at the Gosselies production plant of Caterpillar Belgium S.A., a company specialising in engine construction. I also voted in favour for two further reasons: the first is that in the Charleroi region the employment rate (over 50%) it is among the lowest in the Walloon region, and the second is that a substantial proportion of redundant workers are at risk of exclusion from the labour market as they fall into the 55-64 age group.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 1 222 854 in favour of Belgium with the aim of supporting the reintegration into the labour market of the 630 workers of the 1 030 redundancies in Caterpillar Belgium S.A.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in relation to Belgium's application for the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant by Caterpillar Belgium S.A., a company operating in the manufacture of construction machinery and equipment. Falling demand and high production costs in Europe have led the company to invest in emerging countries in Asia and Africa, thereby reducing the capacity of plants in Europe. This decision has a negative impact on other producers of which Caterpillar is the main supplier and results in the loss of employment for a large number of employees of the company and of the subcontractors. The consequences are very serious, particularly in view of the already difficult labour market situation in the Charleroi area and its surrounding areas. The funding allocated by the EGF will be used to provide personalised assistance services to redundant workers such as: information and guidance for redeployment, training and retraining courses, support for entrepreneurial initiatives. I hope that this will help to contain the negative effects of Caterpillar's production downsizing plan and, in general, to reduce the problem of unemployment in the region.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In total, 1 030 persons working in the manufacture of machinery and equipment have been made redundant in the light of changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. Of these, 630 workers are expected to benefit from co-financed measures that lead to durable, long-term employment. Such personalised services will include redeployment, training and retraining, and promotion of entrepreneurship. I have thus voted in favour of this report to support the reintegration of workers into the labour market.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium has applied for financial assistance from the EGF, following 1030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium SA, a company operating in the manufacture of machinery and equipment n.c.a. (not otherwise classifiable): 630 people will benefit from aid in terms of social shock absorbers and training. Redundancies are linked to falling demand in Europe. Many of the unemployed in the Charleroi region are unskilled, 59% do not have upper secondary education, and 43% have been unemployed for more than 2 years. I note with regret that the employment rate in Charleroi is 52.26%, among the lowest in the Walloon region. Caterpillar's layoffs will have huge negative impacts on the Charleroi region, which is facing a very difficult labour market situation due to its over-reliance on traditional industrial work and the lack of opening up of new industries. I believe that the vote in favour is due.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote is regarding the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant, due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. According to data referred to by the Belgian authorities, state that Caterpillar has been strongly affected by declining demands for this type of products in Europe, which has led to the delocalisation to third countries of substantial production capacity. I voted in favour of this report since it aims to help workers who need support to re-enter the work market.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 663 Caterpillar employees in the machine tool industry, Belgium has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support these people who have lost their jobs and to help them find a job or start their own businesses. The aid granted amounts to EUR 1,222,854 and covers 50% of the cost of the conversion projects that will be offered to these employees. Since the kingdom of Belgium's request corresponds to the EGF's mobilization criteria, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The industrial crisis that the European Union has been facing for several years has hit the machine tool sector hard. Caterpillar in Belgium had to lay off 663 workers because of a decline in its activity in the face of relocation to third countries of production capacity. To help those who have been made redundant to find work, we voted for a mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, a relevant tool to combat unemployment that is still on the rise in the European Union.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Caterpillar Belgium S.A. has decided to reduce production activities in its European plants due to considerably higher production costs in Europe. The company has drawn up a business plan for the reduction of activities at their Gosselies plant which will result in the redundancy of 663 workers. I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it will support the re-ing of redundant workers at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. into the labour market.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 9 December 2014, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation. According to the data mentioned by the Belgian authorities, Caterpillar has been hit hard by the decline in demand for this type of product in Europe, which has led to it transfering a significant part of its production capacity to third countries.  According to the data referred to by the Belgian authorities, Caterpillar's production facilities are located close to their markets, which explains the link between developments in the European and global markets and the reduction of staff at the gosselies plant. Since 2007, the Caterpillar Group has established plants in emerging economies in Asia and Latin America, and its growth is primarily related to these markets. Caterpillar Gosselies' main market in the European Union depends on European infrastructure investments in the public and private sectors, which have recently been curtailed. The coordinated package of services covers three main areas: re-employment, training and retraining, and the promotion of entrepreneurship.  The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the layoffs of 1,030 employees at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. This company, by relocating its business to countries where production is much less expensive thanks to cheap labour, has put its employees out of work, pushing them into poverty. The European Union must help those it puts out of work with its ultra-liberal policies. I therefore voted in favour of this aid of EUR 1 222 854 to Belgium. These funds are intended to facilitate the reclassification of Caterpillar employees.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) helps workers find new jobs and develop new skills when they have lost their jobs as a result of changing global trade patterns, e.g. when a large company shuts down or a factory is moved to outside the EU, or the global financial and economic crisis. Negotiations on the renewal of the Fund concluded under the Multiannual Financial Framework Agreement and a new EGF Regulation is now in place. There are six EGF applications to be voted on from Poland, Germany and Belgium.  The ECR is opposed in principle to the use of this fund and voted against the proposals.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 EGF for me is an ineffective and conceptually wrong instrument. As evidenced by previous reports, it has a compensatory mechanism. Its effect is more than doubtful – it does not lead to an increase in production or employment. Our fundamental problem – in both steel and heavy machinery production – is the strong pressure of imports from third countries. I am aware of the situation because years ago Bulgaria was in the same situation. As a result, our production was destroyed. We have become too liberal towards dumping taking place on our market by suppliers from China, Turkey and other Asian countries. They are at the heart of the problem, they are killing our businesses. We should think about it. In summary, our goal should be how to protect our own market, increase growth in economies, increase employment, how to enter new markets.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I remain convinced that the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that supports workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to assist redundant workers. This is the case of the Caterpillar company that operates in the manufacture of machinery and equipment. Its products are exclusively for the mining and construction sectors in Europe. The plant is therefore exposed to the specific changes in these sectors and is also affected by fluctuations in production factors. Its growth is related to that of asian economies, especially China and India, and the construction industry in these countries. The difficulties in that company in Europe are related to globalisation and the eligibility conditions for the eGF support application have been verified. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to improve the employability of all workers through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, on equal terms of treatment. This support should be complementary to the company's responsibility under national law and not to be overtaken by other types of financial support by the Union.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to obtain their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The Belgian authorities submitted an EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar application following 1,030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which operates in the area of machinery and equipment manufacturing, with 630 people expected to participate in the measures.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the destruction of the metallurgical sector in Europe, with the weakening of the construction sector, and mining, several companies have seen demand for their products decline and competition from emerging countries increasing. As a result of this and its relocation, Caterpillar, in the Liège area of Belgium, has fired more than 1,030 workers. Once again, the regions with the highest unemployment rates, the lowest levels of qualifications and the highest long-term unemployment rates are hit again with the consequences of the deregulation and liberalisation of world trade and neoliberal EU policies.  This report refers to Belgium's application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support 630 of these workers in training and job search measures. This support, if necessary, is not without further criticism of the policies that continue to generate such situations and in which the EU continues to insist, instead of chilling its way.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission has decided to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium after 1030 workers lost their jobs as a result of decreasing demand for Caterpillar products in Europe, which led to the relocation of a significant part of production to third countries. Public and private investment in infrastructure has recently been reduced in Europe. Following the relocation of a significant part of the production of the undertaking in question, unemployment in the region has increased and the high age and low education of the dismissed employees make it impossible for them to find adequate employment. The amount of funding should amount to EUR 1 222 854.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
