text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of granting the fund EUR 1 222 854 (60% of the total) for 1 030 redundancies in the manufacture of machinery and equipment in Belgium.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the mobilisation report of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund application EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar - Belgium, because the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given basically to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to support the reintegration into the labour market of 630 workers at Caterpillar, a factory that operates in the industrial machine sector in Gosselies.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization that, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process, there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation (e.g. closure of large enterprises or relocation of production outside the EU) or the global economic and financial crisis. That is why I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar application)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in the Charleroi area (Belgium) amounting to EUR 1 222 854. The application relates to 1 030 layoffs at Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which operates in the manufacture of machinery and equipment. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to laid-off workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalisation or the financial crisis and to help them find new jobs.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. By unblocking the contributions provided for by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union is giving a concrete sign of support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, thus making it easier for them to re-enter the labour market. I therefore welcome the adoption of the report on the case of caterpillar's corporate reorganisation.  In this case, as in many other cases, Europe intervenes only to cover the declines in competitiveness and to provide companies and workers with new tools for the conversion of skills and skills. These are certainly decisive instruments: the hope is that the efforts of new productive momentum that the EU has undertaken with the new Juncker Plan will gradually make EU companies finally stronger in the global market, thus reversing the decline that part of our industrial sector has suffered in recent years.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Jäätteenmäki report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it sufficiently complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGAF Regulation. I welcome the support provided to reintegrating into employment redundant workers who have fallen victim to major structural changes in world trade patterns.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 1,030 employees at Caterpillar Belgium S.A.  These layoffs are not only caused by the drop in demand in Europe but also by the relocations by the American company, in countries where production costs are lower.  Here we see the negative consequences of calling foreign investments on our soil, whose sole purpose is profitability, without any attachment to the territory and its people.  I therefore voted in favour of this EUR 1,222,854 aid to Belgium, in order to help reclassify Caterpillar employees who are doubly victims of globalisation: on the one hand, they are subject to unfair competition from third countries; on the other hand, they are directly victims of relocations.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for Caterpillar in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 663 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to offer assistance in Belgium, following 1 030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A.  The funding of EUR 1 222 854 will contribute to the assistance package of services for the reintegration of redundant workers into employment.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for Caterpillar in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 663 dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund on the view that I believe as fast, effective and dynamic assistance as possible for redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. is needed to prevent, as far as possible, negative consequences in the Charleroi region.  I also welcome the fact that the Belgian authorities initiated the implementation of services tailored to the needs of affected workers before applying for financial assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in order to alleviate the difficult labour market situation in the region in particular.  It is also of utmost importance that the provisions of the EGF Regulation are directed towards young people who do not have training opportunities and who are unemployed in order to help them enter the labour market through concrete measures.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the layoffs of 1,030 employees at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. This company, by relocating its business to countries where production is much less expensive thanks to cheap labour, has knowingly put its employees out of work and pushed them into poverty. The European Union must help those it puts out of work because of its ultra-liberal policies. I therefore voted in favour of this aid of EUR 1 222 854 to Belgium. These funds are intended to facilitate the reclassification of Caterpillar employees.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Annali Jaateenmaki's report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Caterpillar in Belgium. The fund will provide a eur 1.22 million package for 500 sacked Caterpillar employees to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Belgium following 1,030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. This fund was created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from major changes in the structure of international trade, and to help them re-enter the labour market. I am the the fore, the case for the adoption of this aid, amounting to EUR 1 222 854.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Caterpillar's job losses were the result of major structural changes in world trade patterns, i.e. a rapid decline in the market share of European companies. Complicating matters was a fall in demand for machinery in the automotive and construction industries in the EU as a result of the economic crisis and a relative increase in production costs. The measures, which the EGF co-finances, would help 910 Caterpillar workers find new jobs. Instruments for this are active career guidance, job-search assistance, vocational training and retraining, promotion of entrepreneurship and contributions to collective projects. The importance of these projects for those affected should not be underestimated. That is why I support this motion.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made by Caterpillar Belgium S.A. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Caterpillar Belgium S.A. was a large employer in the Hainaut region of Belgium and the 1030 redundancies which have resulted from its closure have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy. In addition, many of those made redundant do not hold qualifications and will have to be retrained to find new employment. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to the local economy and support the workers affected by helping them re-enter the labour market.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market which have been made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Jäätteenmäki. As in the other cases put to the vote today, we have allocated resources to ensure that some redundant workers are reintegrated into the labour market. In this case, 663 employees of Caterpillar Belgium S.A. lost their jobs as a result of the global economic and financial crisis.  Unfortunately, the failure of several Belgian companies is leading to a process of loss of production capacity and social distress. In this respect, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be able to make a positive and concrete contribution.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. In the wake of my work in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I have renewed my vote in favour of the report for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 630 sacked employees of Caterpillar (Belgium). The EGF will fund EUR 1,222,854 for support, referral and reintegration projects for employees and job-search assistance. At the same time, integrated training and experience transfer will also be offered. The outcome of this election is once again a testament to the European Parliament's willingness to act for the victims of globalisation by offering them sustainable assistance.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union, through its active participation in the process of globalisation and its passive trade policies, is largely responsible for the economic weakening of nations and the downgrading of our productive apparatus. Considering that the allocation of these funds constitutes a just, albeit modest, reparation for the prejudices suffered by the peoples, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, following the redundancies of 1,030 employees at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. The relocation of the business to countries where production is much less expensive thanks to cheap labour and the ultra-liberal policy of the European Union are responsible for this massive redundancy plan.  I therefore voted in favour of this aid of EUR 1,222,854 for former Belgian caterpillar employees to compensate for this ultraliberal madness.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The report gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in the Charleroi area of Belgium for EUR 1 222 854. The application relates to 1 030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which operates in the manufacture of machinery and equipment, during the reference period from January 1, 2014 to April 30, 2014. And it will serve for the conversion of the sector and workers.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the 1,030 redundancies in Caterpillar Belgium S.A., (company operating in division 28 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.c.o.p.) which took place during the reference period from 1 January to 30 April 2014 and after that period , due to a decline in demand in Europe. 630 people are expected to take action. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. I consider that the measures carried out by Belgium, in advance of the Decision and even the application for EGF aid, were necessary because of the urgent nature of the situation of the workers. The layoffs at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. are the result of the effects of globalisation, because it is cheaper to produce equipment in Asia than in the EU. Along with these effects of globalization, the impact of the crisis has also led to a decrease in demand for its products. This has led to numerous layoffs in the Charleroi region, where many of these unemployed do not have sufficient training competition to re-enter the labour market. For this reason, this EGF will implement measures with the aim of improving this situation, focusing on improving employee training and the competitiveness of this sector. I therefore believe that this decision must be adopted, odd to the important role it has in improving the employment situation in the European Union.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This Report refers to the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of the Belgian steel industry, namely Caterpillar, which laid off 663 workers between 1 January and 30 April 2014 and another 367 after that period.  Caterpillar specializes in car assembly, component manufacturing and soldering assemblies and structures. Its products are exclusively focused on the construction and mining industries. Caterpillar opened its facilities in Asia and Latin America in 2007, although their main market is the European Union and they depended on public and private investments in Europe's infrastructure, which were reduced, so the drop in demand in 2011 was 40%. In the target group of 630 unemployed who will be helped, more than 65% belong to the 30-54 age group, and as many as 59% do not have completed secondary school. The required amount from the EGF is around 1.2 million euros and is intended for activities to assist citizens in the recruitment process, education and training, entrepreneurship and self-employment.  I supported the Report, which aims to strengthen employment in the Walloon region where the unemployment rate is over 55% and to help citizens train for new jobs.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The situation at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. is one of the other examples of the lack of attention paid to increasing the competitiveness of the European Union. Consideration should be given to how effective the measures taken so far in this area are and to review them. At the same time, it is necessary to stress the need to check the use of the contributions granted and, on the basis of the findings, to prepare or insete the rules for granting such aid.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, since the Belgian authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to the affected workers on 1 April 2014 , long before the decision and indeed from the request for EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this mobilization of the WEF in favour of Caterpillar licensees in Belgium. This mobilization will support 1,030 licensees who lost their jobs as a result of the economic crisis.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. According to data referred to by the Belgian authorities, Caterpillar’s production sites are located close to their markets, which explains the link between the European and global market developments and the reduction in workforce at the site in Gosselies. Since 2007, the Caterpillar Group has established plants in emerging economies in Asia and Latin America, and its growth is mainly linked to these markets. In particular, Asia’s share of Caterpillar’s sales has more than doubled between 2007 and 2013. This is linked to the overall growth of the Asian economies, especially in China and India, and the construction industry in these countries. On the other hand, the main market for Caterpillar Gosselies, the European Union, is depending on public and private investments in infrastructure in Europe which have recently been reduced. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded covers three main areas: redeployment, training and retraining and promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the adoption of this report. I believe that the measures proposed by the Commission can provide adequate support for those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade. This is a support measure for the 1 030 redundancies of Caterpillar Belgium S.A, a company operating in the manufacture of machinery and equipment. I voted in favour of allocating the fund to Belgium.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Belgian region of Charleroi is experiencing an extremely difficult situation, due to the excessive dependence on employment in the industrial sector, and the low level of qualifications of its workers.  For these reasons, I felt it appropriate to express my agreement with the Jäätteenmäki report, which supports the mobilisation of the EGF in support of 663 workers made redundant at Caterpillar Belgium S.A.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion, as it is for the workers who are suffering from the consequences of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns and a shift in market share to Asia. Since 2007, the Caterpillar Group has opened plants in emerging markets in Asia and Latin America, and its growth is largely related to these markets. As a result, Caterpillar has been hit hard by falling demand for this type of product in Europe, which in turn has led to a shift of significant production capacity to third countries.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of retraining people who have lost their jobs after 1030 redundancies were made out of Caterpillar Belgium S.A. in the production of machinery and equipment due to a decline in demand in Europe. It is estimated that 630 people will benefit from the measures financed by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, thus addressing the social problems in the Charleroi region of Belgium, retraining and returning to the labour market for working-age people.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The American giant finds that Belgian employees are not working fast enough, destroys its sites in Europe and gradually relocates to Asia... and the European Union congratulates him. "The production and import of equipment from Asia to Europe has become cheaper for the company than producing in Europe in a declining market" notes the report with understanding. Caterpillar is therefore closing its site in Charleroi. The remaining 40% of staff must increase their work schedules on assembly lines, with no guarantee for 2015. The European Globalisation Fund plays its destructive role. Instead of helping workers, it encourages shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. I am voting against, not to associate myself with what is a real incentive to relocate.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Belgium, which submitted the EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 1 030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which operates in NACE 2 - Division 28 (Manufacture of machinery and equipment, n.e.), participation in the measures of 630 persons is expected during and after the reference period between 1 January 2014 and 30 April 2014.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the EU’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise the EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 630 workers in Belgium due to the decline in internal demand for the manufactured machinery and equipment produced by Caterpillar Belgium S.A.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for application EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar, which will contribute to the coordinated package of personalised services for the reintegration of redundant workers into employment.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  I am voting in favour of this report on the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 222 854 from the EGF in favour of Belgium. It concerns 663 redundancies, which occurred during the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 30 April 2014, and 367 redundancies made after that period. It should be noted that Caterpillar has been severely affected by the decrease in demand for this type of product in Europe, which has led to a relocation to third countries of substantial production capacity. The Caterpillar plant in Gosselies specializes in vehicle assembly and the production of components, welded assemblies, and structures.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. Again, the European Union is playing arsonist fireman by trying to put out the fire that it has started itself. It will thus partially compensate for the damage it causes by its ultraliberal dogma. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to shock anyone. I am voting for this aid to employees so as not to further penalise the victims of European ultraliberalism.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it fulfils the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation with the exception of two where the number of employees is lower than that specified in the regulation. There is a precedent for this and Parliament supports their applications.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of 1.2 million euros to support the reclassification of 1,030 employees laid off by Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which manufactured machinery and equipment in the Hainaut.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted five reports of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of each of these five reports. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release 1.2 million euros from this fund to 630 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of Caterpillar in Belgium.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of caterpillar workers, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade. According to data reported by the Belgian authorities, Caterpillar has been severely affected by the decline in demand for vehicle assembly products and components, intended exclusively for the European construction and mining sectors.  Since 2007, the Caterpillar Group has, in fact, decided to invest abroad, building plants in the emerging countries of Asia and Latin America. Therefore, today its growth is mainly linked to these markets: for example, Caterpillar's share of sales in Asia more than doubled from 2007 to 2013. This is due to the overall growth of Asian economies, especially in China and India, and to the construction industry in these countries. On the other hand, Caterpillar's main market in Gosselies, the European Union, is dependent on public and private investment in European infrastructure, which has recently been severely reduced. The European aid granted today will be active labour market measures aimed at reintegrating these redundant workers.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it proposes to compensate, through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, all the collateral victims of certain economic operations generated on a global scale. As such, I fully support all actions aimed at strengthening cohesion within our continent by protecting its workers and strengthening the social dimension of the European project.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The profound alteration of the international trading system, due to the advance of globalisation and the economic and financial crisis, has led Belgium towards total economic oppression. It is essential for the European Union to act in support of the country and its citizens so that the burden of economic depression is made bearable.  That is why I felt obliged to express my agreement with the Jäätteenmäki report, which calls for the EGF to be mobilised in favour of 1 030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the implementation of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - EGF BE/Caterpillar's request as special rapporteur of the Social Democratic Group in the European Parliament for EGF funds.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the material and formal conditions for mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund are in place in this case and I hope that the promised financial resources will give the employees and workers concerned a view for the future. I therefore hope that there are also positive aspects to the economic prosperity of the region.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to allocate EUR 1 222 854 from the EGF fund to Belgium, as it will allow us to re-enter the labour market for 1 030 people who became unemployed in the machinery and equipment manufacturing sector. Unemployment is one of the most painful problems in the European Union. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market; that Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission; that the adoption of the EGF Regulation reflects the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on the reintroduction of the mobilisation criterion following the crisis, the increase in the efficiency of the processing of applications for EGF assistance within the Commission and by the European Parliament and the Council obtained by reducing the time taken for evaluation and approval, the extension of eligible actions and beneficiaries to self-employed and young people , as well as the financing of incentives for the creation of own businesses; that the request for assistance meets the eligibility conditions laid down in the EGF Regulation, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Belgium states that Caterpillar has been hit hard by falling demand for this type of product in Europe, leading to the delocalisation of significant production capacity in third countries. Caterpillar Gosselies, the plant specializes in car assembly, manufacture of components, soldered assemblies and structures. Its products are exclusively focused on the European market and mining. Since 2007 Caterpillar Group has established plants in emerging economies, in Asia and Latin America, and its growth is mainly related to these markets. In particular, Caterpillar Group's Asian share of sales more than doubled between 2007 and 2013. This is linked to the overall growth of the Asian economy, especially in China and India, and construction in these countries. The amount of new orders decreased by 40% in 2011. The application relates to the indemnity of 663 workers who became redundant in the company during the reference period from 1 January 2014 to 30 April 2014. The proposed EGF contribution to the coordinated personalised service package is EUR 1 222 854, representing 60% of the total cost of the proposed measures to ensure a financial contribution for application.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help Belgium with a technological surplus in the machinery manufacturing sector with EUR 1 222 854, representing 60% of the total cost. With a view to establishing a link between redundancies, disruption of activities and global trade flows due to globalisation, Belgium states that Caterpillar has been hit hard by the decline in demand for this type of product in Europe, which has led to the delocalisation of significant production capacity to third countries. Caterpillar Gosseliesu specializes in car assembly, manufacture of components, assemblies and structures.  Until now, the industry has often been sacrificed at the expense of service and financial activities in Europe, and it is time for the industry to regain the support it deserves given the contribution it has to economic development.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. to find a new job. Belgium applied to EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar for an EGF financial contribution following the redundancies of 1,030 caterpillar belgium S.A. workers. Caterpillar specializes in car assembly, component manufacturing and soldering assemblies and structures. The redundancies are linked to major structural changes in globalisation's globalisation trade flows, as goods have become cheaper to produce in Asia and import than to produce them in Europe for a declining market. Also layoffs will have an extremely negative effect on the Charleroi region where the labour market situation is extremely difficult (the employment rate is among the lowest in the Wallonia region at 52.26%), and it is difficult for laid-off workers to find a new job in unfavourable economic conditions as they are low-skilled (59% do not have a completed secondary school).  I therefore support Rapporteur Anneli Jäätteenmäki's report on the mobilisation of €1,222,854, which accounts for 60% of the total budget, as it aims to assist redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As has been reiterated, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support workers in companies suffering from the negative economic situation and major structural changes in world trade, especially at this time of serious general crisis.  This is Caterpillar Belgium and, as the data have shown, all the major manufacturers of these products in Europe have suffered a sharp drop in demand and a relocation of a significant part of their production capacity to third countries. Given that this sector is linked to the economic situation in the construction and mining sector, we can easily see how, when the market in Europe shrinks, it is contrasted with an expansion of the market in emerging markets such as Latin America and Asia.  The reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers will be helped by personalised services such as: general training and retraining, vocational training, coaching, follow-up to reintegration into employment and entrepreneurship.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Belgium has mobilised the Globalization Adjustment Fund, but this time for the construction and equipment sector. I support this request and stress the need for this fund to mitigate the side effects of globalisation on European workers and help reclassify our workers to more buoyant and dynamic sectors.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application to obtain a financial contribution from the EGF following 1030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which operates in NACE 2 - Division 28 (Machinery and Equipment Manufacturing, n.e.), during and after the reference period between 1 January 2014 and 30 April 2014. According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is found, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as it has become cheaper for the company to manufacture and import equipment to Europe from Asia than to produce in Europe for a declining market , and, on the other hand, that such redundancies should have a huge negative impact on the Charleroi region, which is facing a very difficult labour market situation due to its excessive dependence on traditional industry and the lack of new industries. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this application, as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of major structural changes in world trade patterns. To this end, I support the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of structural changes in world trade patterns resulting from globalisation. This application refers to the 663 redundancies that occurred during the reference period from January 1, 2014 to April 30, 2014, and 367 redundancies made after this period at Caterpillar. This has been severely affected by the decrease in demand for its business in Europe, which has led to a relocation to third countries of substantial production capacity and subsequent redundancies of Belgian citizens.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Good news in the social grey sky, the European Parliament has this lunchtime given the final green light to the payment of aid for the conversion of the 1,030 workers of the Company Caterpillar. This aid of EUR 1,222,854 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) is the European participation of 60% of the needs needed to support former employees of Caterpillar, who are active in the machinery and equipment manufacturing sector, in their job search and more broadly in their career reorientation.  The Charleroi area affected by the redundancies is all the more in need of this assistance as 59% of the unemployed in this region are low-skilled. As is the case in most economic layoffs, people working in a sector that is facing stiff global competition are affected. This European retraining aid is therefore welcome for the families of these workers. On the other hand, it cannot supersede the establishment of a European industrial policy which should be a priority of the new Juncker Commission to preserve European know-how in many high-tech sectors.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of legislative and budgetary instruments to provide complementary support to the most diverse sectors has proved to be a positive measure in the transition and adjustment of Member States to the era of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool in that it can serve to reintegrate people and businesses into the global market. In this case, and in view of the situation presented, the aid provided to Belgium is relevant.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 222 854 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 1 030 workers who have lost their jobs in Caterpillar Belgium S.A., based in Gosselines, Belgium, and dedicated to the manufacture of machinery and equipment, as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  Caterpillar's Asian sales share has doubled between 2007 and 2013, while Caterpillar Gosselines' main market, which is the European Union, depends on public and private investments in infrastructure in Europe, which have declined in recent years. The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include vocational reorientation activities, training and recycling and promotion of entrepreneurship. While these aids alone are not able to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Belgian charleroi region, they do provide good assistance and training for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the layoffs at Caterpillar, as these contributions are a valuable aid in enabling the retraining and reclassification of workers, thanks in particular to training tailored to the opportunities of the labour market.  Nevertheless, the job losses in many sectors are a painful reminder that these aids are not a miracle cure and that it is essential to pursue a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. More broadly, Europe needs to put in place a real coordinated industrial policy focused on creating sustainable jobs in sectors of the future.  In addition, weASee procedures should be accelerated and simplified to enable laid-off workers to cope with difficulties as soon as they arise.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Like the favourable stance I took in other reports voted on in this plenary session on the same subject, I also voted in favour of this proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Union Solidarity Fund, amounting to EUR 1 222 854, in response to belgium's application for redundancies in Caterpillar Belgium S.A. We are facing situations related to structural changes in world trade patterns arising from globalisation, following which it has become cheaper for the company to manufacture and import equipment to Europe from Asia than to produce in Europe for a declining market. For this reason and under Article 13 of Regulation No 1309/2013, I agree with the proposal to mobilise within the scope of the Solidarity Fund.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report in order to unlock financial and professional assistance following the 1,030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A due to a decrease in demand in Europe. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will provide 60% financial assistance, which will cover, among other things, retraining, training and the enhancement of entrepreneurship. Having always defended the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Another request for help for a Belgian company. I believe that if Europe can do good, it must do so to all Member States and, above all, to the workers in the companies that need it most.  That is why I voted in favour of Mrs Jäätteenmäki's report.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of protecting workers affected by redundancies.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allocates EUR 1 222 854 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help more than 900 workers laid off by the company Caterpillar in Belgium. This assistance should enable the Belgian authorities to co-finance personalised services in three areas: retraining, training and retraining as well as the promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Belgium's application for unemployment effects of Caterpillar, which operated in the engineering industry, complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The application concerns 663 unemployed persons. The report shows that the reductions in the workforce in Caterpillar have been due to the impact of globalisation on the profitability of the engineering industry in Europe. Manufacturing parts in Asia and importing them from Asia is more profitable than manufacturing within the EU. According to the report, the situation is complicated by the fact that 59% of the unemployed have only the lowest level of education. In addition, 43% have been unemployed for more than two years and almost a fifth belong to the age group 55 to 64, which increases their risk of being definitively excluded from the labour market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. I agree with this request for the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because in this case employment must be safeguarded. However, we note that the Union's recommendations do not go in the direction of a fair globalisation allowing States to protect their businesses and jobs as do other major powers.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the 1,030 redundancies in Caterpillar Belgium S.A., (company operating in division 28 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.c.o.p.) which took place during the reference period from 1 January to 30 April 2014 and after that period , due to a decline in demand in Europe. 630 people are expected to take action. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for application EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar. Caterpillar Belgium S.A. has been granted EGF aid to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers following 1 030 redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. linked to a decline in demand in Europe. Of those affected, 630 are expected to participate in the measures.  The redundancies at Caterpillar are expected to have huge negative impacts on the Charleroi region, which is facing a very difficult labour market situation due to its over-reliance on traditional industrial employment and lack of new industries. It should be noted that 18 % of the targeted redundant workers expected to participate in the measures are threatened by labour market exclusion as they are part of the 55-64 age group.  A total amount of EUR 1 222 854 will be mobilised from the EGF for Belgium. The coordinated package of personalised services has been drawn up in consultation with the targeted beneficiaries and the social partners, taking into consideration the potential of the area and the business environment. The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers receive none of this support therefore.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  With the adoption of the EGF Regulation, the criterion for the mobilisation of the Fund was reintroduced as a result of the crisis, the Union's financial contribution increased to 60 % of the total estimated costs of the proposed measures, and the inclusion of the self-employed and young people increased the circle of beneficiaries and incentives to set up their own businesses began to be financed. The application for a financial contribution submitted by Belgium to aid to Caterpillar Belgium S.A, in which 1030 redundancies were made in 2014 due to lower demand in Europe, fulfils the eligibility criteria for the aid. The redundancies in this company are likely to have major negative consequences in the Charleroi region, which is facing a very difficult labour market situation, as it is highly dependent on traditional industrial employment. As the co-financed services package covers three important areas: over-employment, training and retraining and promoting entrepreneurship, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 630 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation at Caterpillar, a factory operating in the industrial machinery manufacturing sector based in Gosselies in the Charleroi region.  The decline in demand for its specialized products in Europe for the construction and mining sectors (vehicle assembly, production of welded components and structures) has led Caterpillar to relocate a large part of its production capacity to third countries, particularly Asia, where demand for these products is growing strongly. The reduction in European production has hit the Gosselies site hard, resulting in hundreds of redundancies, in a region with an unemployment rate of 52%.  The eur 1,222,854 aid provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in addition to the funds already allocated by the Walloon region, will help to cover part of the costs related to assistance and support in job search, vocational training, support for business creation and other programmes aimed at reintegration into the world of work for 630 beneficiary workers.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution as Belgium has applied to EGF/2014/011 BE/Caterpillar for an EGF financial contribution following the redundancies of 1,030 workers at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. engaged in activities under section 28 of the NACE 2 classification 'Machinery and appliance manufacturing, d.n.'. The application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation and Belgium is entitled to a financial contribution under the Regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will mobilise resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this report as it relates to a request for €1 222 854 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to Belgium, with a purpose of providing severance pay to Caterpillar workers.  Caterpillar's layoffs are the result of major structural changes in world trade caused by globalization, which has made the production and import of equipment from Asia to Europe significantly cheaper for the company. We also see that the demand for construction machinery has weakened as a result of smaller private and public investments in infrastructure, all as a result of a weakening global economy.  Most workers are low-skilled and therefore it is important to improve the employment of all workers through various trainings, recognition of skills and abilities acquired by the worker through his professional career.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I voted against the proposal in writing ‒ because I believe that this is not a real solution to the problems. The real solution to unemployment is to improve employment conditions and not to increase redistribution, which – as a result of the pressure to raise taxes – ultimately worsens employment conditions.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report, which provides a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund after 1030 redundancies were made in Europe due to lower demand in Europe from Caterpillar Belgium S.A., which operates in the economic sector manufacturing other machinery and equipment. The redundancies at Caterpillar Belgium S.A. are linked to major structural changes in global trade flows due to globalisation, as production in Asia and imports into Europe have become cheaper than production in Europe. The demand for construction machinery has declined due to the decrease in private and public investment in infrastructure.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour! The support measures had been implemented as soon as the redundancies were announced in consultation with the social partners and in partnership with the regional public employment services. In the meantime, we have pleaded with Commissioners Thyssen and Malmstrom for greater coordination so that international trade agreements do not completely destroy European industrial employment.  These 5.2 million are important to the Walloon economic fabric. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves should not be the rule. It should be remembered that this aid was made indispensable because an international industrialist wanted to play with the destiny of workers, treating them with disdain and great disrespect. Europe must send a strong message to all the Lakshmi Mittals of the world that in Europe there are no castes or untouchables. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think that it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. Caterpillar Belgium S.A. was a major employer in the region and because the steel and metal production sector faced serious economic disruption, it led to 1 030 redundancies. This fund will be used to develop appropriate tools to reintegrate these workers into the job market, including individual job-search assistance, training and promotion of entrepreneurship. I believe it will set the path to durable and long-term employment in the Charleroi region.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which is based on Belgium's request for a financial contribution of EUR 1 222 854, in order to support 663 redundanst caterpillar workers. In this case, the negative impact on the company is shown as a result of competition from growing economies, but I believe that it is in these cases that individual countries need to approach a genuine market liberalisation that, along with responsible fiscal policy, will enable companies to have a higher level of competitiveness and sustainable business. Therefore, I consider that such one-off measures relating to the training, retraining and management of individual cases do not constitute solutions that would affect the achievement of long-term growth and job creation, and can create an additional obstacle in further addressing the economic crisis.  I point out that, in particular, Member States are responsible for creating policies that will enable individual funding models to prevent businesses from closing or moving them to a market outside the EU.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though the effects of the crisis in some EU countries are decreasing, we are not yet at pre-crisis levels of employment. This is why measures to fight the adverse effects of globalisation in sectors such as this one are still needed.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European Globalisation Adjustment Funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultraliberal policies applied in this European Union, which are unable to defend neither the peoples who make up it nor the companies that support it.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Caterpillar in Gosselies, Belgium, specialises in the assembly of cars, the production of components, assemblies and welded structures, its products being exclusively intended for the European sectors of construction and mining. As a result of major structural changes in international trade practices and the decrease in demand for this type of product in Europe, the production of this undertaking was severely affected, which led to the relocation of substantial production capacity to third countries. This relocation resulted in the dismissal of 1,030 workers. The Belgian authorities have therefore submitted an application to the European Commission for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). The European Commission analysed the eligibility conditions and approved the allocation of a financial contribution of EUR 1 222 854 from the EGF.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for Caterpillar in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 663 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in favour of Belgium, aimed at supporting 630 redundancies at Caterpillar, a company operating in the machinery production sector, which at European level has suffered greatly not only from strong competition from emerging economies, but also from the economic and financial crisis.  The contribution of EUR 1.2 million is intended to facilitate the retraining and reintegration of workers into new business sectors, in a region, charleroi, which is characterised by a difficult working environment due to its dependence on employment in the industrial sector. I believe that the fund is a useful tool for alleviating in part the repercussions of international competition and the crisis on workers, but it cannot remain the only instrument to be entrusted with the management of the crisis, economic conversion and unemployment.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the 1,030 redundancies in Caterpillar Belgium S.A., (company operating in division 28 of NACE Rev. 2 'Manufacture of machinery and equipment n.c.o.p.) which took place during the reference period from 1 January to 30 April 2014 and after that period , due to a decline in demand in Europe. 630 people are expected to take action. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Several companies in the metallurgical sector in Europe have seen demand for their products drop and competition from emerging countries increased. As a result of this and its relocation, caterpillar in the Liège area of Belgium has fired more than 1,030 workers. Once again, it is the regions where unemployment rates occur, lowest levels of qualificationand the highest long-term unemployment rates that are hit again with the consequences of deregulation and liberalisation of world trade and neoliberal EU policies.  This report refers to Belgium's application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support 630 of these workers in training and job search measures.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. This request has received my approval. According to the data referred to by the Belgian authorities, Caterpillar's production facilities are close to their markets, which explains the link between developments in the European and world markets and staff reductions at the Gosselies site. As these have increasingly shifted to Latin America and Asia, workers who have become unemployed must, of course, receive support.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The world's largest construction equipment manufacturer Caterpillar generated a consolidated net income of EUR 3.5 billion due to shareholders during the period 2014 – apparently without covering the costs of redundancies in Belgium (already Belgium!) in 2014. This bill is now being paid by EU taxpayers, through the EU Commission: EUR 1.2 million of taxpayers' money. I certainly don't carry that with me!

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report, which I supported, concerns the financial contribution from the EGF to Caterpillar Belgium S.A. following the redundancies of 1030 employees in 2014. The company manufactures vehicles and machinery for the construction industry, a sector that has suffered a blow as the crisis in the global economy has resulted in a reduction in investment in infrastructure. At the same time, the production and import of cheaper equipment into the EU from Asia also contributed to the company's downward trend. European construction and mining companies, affected by both the economic crisis and competition with emerging economies, especially Asia, are Caterpillar's most important customers. Consequently, gradually, the company lost its momentum, resulting in staff reductions. The request concerns the Region of Charleroua in Belgium. The support is aimed at unemployed people where 59 % of them do not have upper secondary education and 43 % have been unemployed for more than 2 years. Finally, 18 % of the dismissed persons targeted by the measures and who are expected to participate in them face the spectre of exclusion from the labour market as they form part of the 55-64 age group.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the destruction of the metallurgical sector in Europe, with the weakening of the construction sector, and mining, several companies have seen demand for their products decline and competition from emerging countries increasing. As a result of this and its relocation, caterpillar in the Liége area of Belgium has fired more than 1030 workers. Once again, it is the regions where unemployment rates occur, lowest levels of qualificationand highest long-term unemployment rates, which are hit again by the consequences of the deregulation and liberalisation of World trade and neoliberal EU policies.  This report refers to Belgium's application to the European Globalisation Fund to support 630 of these workers in training and job-seeking measures.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds in the case of Caterpillar Belgium, as redundancies in the Hainaut region were the result of a crisis in the construction and mining sectors, from which Caterpillar's most important customers come. On the one hand, the European market was shrinking and, on the other hand, the production and imports of steel and metal products from Asia became cheaper than that in Europe. The fall in public and private investment in infrastructure has been the result of demand for construction mechanisation and for steel and metal products. 18% of workers made redundant are particularly at risk, as they belong to the 55-64 age group, many do not have completed upper secondary school and over 40% are unemployed for more than 2 years, which constitutes long-term unemployment. It is good that the European Parliament's report also emphasises the need to improve the employability of workers through additional education and training and the recognition of skills acquired over the course of their working lives.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this recommendation because, for the protection and safety of all, it is important that heavy goods vehicles and buses circulating within the Union comply with certain rules on weight, height, length and width. And it is always because of safety that it is right to grant derogations and allow producers to introduce new design means. Engineering and technology allow us to put vehicles on the road with a better field of view for the driver, with forms that improve, among other things, the impact in the event of collisions and technologies that reduce CO2 emissions. Road hauliers perform a fundamental service and carry out much of the much-cited free movement of goods, which is one of the symbols of a united Europe. So let us safeguard the category, improve their difficult working conditions and increase their safety and consequently ours too.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm vótáil ar son na tuarascála seo agus, dar ndóigh, le mo ghrúpa chomh maith mar bhíomar i bhfabhar na tuarascála. Tá sé an-tábhachtach mar a dúradh agus bhí an-díospóireacht againn ar an tuarascáil ar maidin. Go háirithe, tá sé ríthábhachtach go mbeadh ár mbóithre sábháilte do gach uile dhuine a úsáideann iad agus tá sé sin ráite sa tuarascáil.  Freisin, caithfimid díriú ar astaíochtaí a laghdú mar tá an méid sin tráchta ar na bóithre anois agus táimid ag déileáil leis an bhfadhb seo ó thaobh an chomhshaoil de go gcaithfimid díriú air ó thaobh taistil, go háirithe na feithiclí móra, na leoraithe agus na trucailí agus mar sin a úsáideann an bóthar. Ach is dóigh liom go bhfuil an bonneagar againn anois agus is féidir linn dul ar aghaidh ó seo.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it aims at a change in regulation with the aim of limiting pollution caused by trucks. In particular, it is proposed to extend the maximum length authorised by Council Directive 96/53/EC.  Technological evolution offers the possibility to add retractable or foldable devices to trucks, so that significant energy savings are achieved. That is why the maximum authorised dimensions and maximum authorised weights for those trucks operating within eu territory have been extended.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's Recommendation for second reading with a view to adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 96/53/EC on the fixing, for certain road vehicles in the Community, of the maximum permitted dimensions in national and international transport and the maximum permitted burdens on international transport, as I agree in principle

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome this compromise because it not only makes it possible to improve the safety of lorries, but also makes an important contribution to environmental protection thanks to aerodynamic attachments.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. I do not share some of the objectives of this text and regret that the protection of companies and employees are not included in the motivations, in favour of a strictly ideological vision that absolutizes competition.  On the other hand, this text seems to me to be contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. Whether it is improving the aerodynamic performance of vehicles, their energy efficiency or the requirements of performance and safety, I do not see in which of these areas Member States would not be able to act effectively. Under the pretext of combating global warming, the Commission allows itself to intervene in all areas, in defiance of the treaties.  So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose this measure, as it appears to be further EU standardisation which will be against the interests of business.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the directive allowing necessary derogations on the maximum weight and dimensions of heavy goods vehicles which incorporate technology to save energy or improve safety. This way we can keep the balance between undistorted competition, protection of road infrastructure and environmental performance. When it comes to energy saving, environmental protection and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions are among the EUʼs priorities. Therefore, it is important to increase vehiclesʼ efficiency by enabling the implementation of advanced aerodynamics or heavier powertrains for alternatively fuelled trucks. As far as road safety is concerned, I think that improving road safety is a solid reason to allow potential gains in vehiclesʼ dimensions resulting from additional safety measures such as alternative cabin profiles.  Nevertheless, we should take into account that such derogations, especially regarding vehicle weight, should be set only after carefully assessing the impact of additional pressure on the EUʼs road infrastructure and establishing adequate mechanisms to curb vehicle overload.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which provides for new rules that will enable vehicle manufacturers to develop safer and greener tractors. Since 1996, the European Parliament has been in formal agreement with the Council of the EU as early as December last year to adapt the rules in force which lay down specifications for heavy goods vehicles. They provide for rounding up the shape of cabs, which will increase the field of vision of drivers and reduce the risk of serious injury to pedestrians at low speeds. At the same time, improved aerodynamic properties of tractors will help to reduce fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Under the pretext of combating global warming, the Commission believes it is entitled to intervene in all areas, in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity supposed to be guaranteed by the treaties of the European Union. Moreover, according to liberal precepts, this text opens the road network to international competition: what will happen to our companies and their employees?  So I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The permitted size and weight of road vehicles should be regulated to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve road safety. This better regulation will also make it easier to adapt legislation to technological advances and market needs in general, but will also strengthen European standards to facilitate intermodal transport operations.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this agreement which we have negotiated for so long and I would like to thank the rapporteur for his impetus. Approval will allow manufacturers to use new technologies to improve truck design, particularly from an environmental point of view. Trucks will be safer, cleaner and more efficient.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support with my vote the Leichtfried report which analyses the size and weight of road vehicles circulating in the Union, since I consider the measure to be un balanced and more oriented towards feeding the interests of large companies than that of SMEs that in Italy and Veneto represent the backbone of our economy.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This text must improve the aerodynamic performance and fuel efficiency of vehicles in order to reduce CO2 emissions, while ensuring that they meet performance and safety requirements. This also includes facilitating intermodal transport.  Unfortunately, this text opens the road network to competition rather than protecting companies and employees. In addition, offences must instead be appropriate measures at Member State level and drivers must be able to dispose of the information recorded by the on-board devices. So I voted against it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. With this amendment to the Directive laying down the maximum weights and measures authorised for the international transport of certain goods and passenger vehicles, the door is closed so that vehicles exceeding 40 tonnes can make international journeys, in a decision which brings benefits for both safety and environmental protection. It will also make it easier for bus and truck cabins to have a less aggressive design to help prevent abuse while improving driver visibility by improving the size and placement of the front and side moons. Measures are also introduced to improve aerodynamics and thus reduce consumption and therefore CO2 emissions. To this end, exceptions to weights for buses with alternative propulsion systems to traditional combustion engines will be allowed to help reduce CO2 emissions. And to encourage combined transport, excess weights will be allowed for the transport of shipping containers when combined with sea or rail travel. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to adopt a directive enabling manufacturers to start producing new design trucks. Such trucks could exceed the current mass and length limits in order to improve the overall safety and environmental performance of heavy goods vehicles. The introduction of more rounded lorry cabs would increase the driver's field of vision so that it could spot vulnerable road users, such as cyclists, and reduce friction and reduce the impact of a collision in a curved form. The aerodynamic valves installed in the back of the truck would help reduce fuel consumption and pollution. In addition, in the case of alternative powertrains and/or engines, additional mass (maximum 1 tonne) could be allowed without reducing the load capacity of the vehicles. The current rules for larger trucks remain unchanged. Member States should take specific measures to identify vehicles likely to exceed the prescribed mass limits. The data of the in-vehicle weight sensor should also be accessible to the driver.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report adopted unanimously by the Committee. The new Directive will help reduce CO2, save fuel and most importantly, road safety. Improved aerodynamics of motor vehicle cabs allow for significant improvements in the energy performance of vehicles, and enabling vehicles to be equipped with a new cab design will contribute to improving road safety by reducing blind spots in the driver's field of vision. For all of the above, as well as the fact that an adjustment period of 24 months is given to member states, I support this report by Representative Leichtfried.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. HGVs and buses operating within the European Union must comply with a number of rules concerning their size, according to a directive. The revision of the latter aims to strengthen road safety and achieve energy savings, in parallel with the improvement of the ecological footprint. These vehicles account for about a quarter of greenhouse gas emissions. In April 2014, the European Parliament adopted a position at first reading. Last December, after inter-institutional negotiations, an agreement was reached and adopted in the Committee on Transport and Tourism. I voted against this text because it is a competence belonging to each Member State and therefore not a matter of intervention by the European Union. In addition, it opens the road network to competition instead of protecting transport companies and their employees.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The draft directive before us provides for a revision of the standards for certain road vehicles operating in the European Union. It may allow manufacturers to launch new truck models, whose weight and length could exceed current limits.  However, not demonstrating the value of entrusting the European Commission with the burden of legislating on these relatively technical issues, and specifying absolutely nothing about companies and employees linked to road transport, this text once again tramples on the sovereignty of the Member States and prepares the full opening up to competition of the Union's road infrastructure. In this text, neither the principle of subsidiarity nor the protection of road hauliers is respected. That is why I voted against this draft directive.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the size and weight of road vehicles travelling in the Community. This directive will strengthen road safety, better preserve the environment and encourage technological innovation. These are very important for the European Union and for the citizens.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the revised directive on the dimensions and weights of road vehicles, which would allow manufacturers to introduce newly designed trucks, which could exceed the current maximum limits on the length and weight of heavy goods vehicles in order to improve overall safety and environmental performance.  A more rounded cab would increase the driver's field of view by improving the ability to identify vulnerable road users, such as cyclists, and reduce drag, while a form that facilitates deflection would reduce the impact of collisions. The addition of aerodynamic ailerons on the back would also help reduce emissions and fuel consumption. Member States are required to adopt the relevant national provisions within two years of the entry into force of this revised Directive. It is essential for the Commission to revise the directive three years after the implementation of national rules, also taking into account certain market segments such as car carriers.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed amendments to Council Directive 96/53/EC lay down for certain road vehicles circulating within the European Union the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weights in international traffic.
