The amendments focus on the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, particularly carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, improve road safety, adapt the relevant legislation to technological developments and changing market needs, and to facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and protecting the road infrastructure. It should be noted that in order to avoid any distortions of competition and to ensure road safety Member States have the responsibility to ensure that infringements in relation to overloaded vehicles are properly addressed. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Jörg Leichtfried's report amending Council Directive 96/53/EC laying down, for certain road vehicles circulating in the Community, the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weights in international traffic. I believe that the objectives of improving road safety, energy efficiency and environmental performance in this specific transport sector are fully shareable.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which not only violates the freedom of Member States in terms of transport policy, but also puts road transport companies and their employees in a precarious situation. The draft directive as envisaged by the Council thus urges Member States to take surveillance measures against road vehicles by requiring the weight of vehicles to be checked using automatic surveillance systems. Moreover, Member States have no control over weighing systems as they are prohibited from imposing the installation of such systems on vehicles that are registered in another Member State. It is therefore devoting the impossibility for Member States to protect national companies, especially since they will now have the obligation to provide the Commission with information on the number of checks carried out in the previous two years, as well as the number of overloaded vehicles that have been detected. With this text, Member States are therefore being stripped of their ability to influence the daily lives of citizens, since Brussels now decides the content of national public policies.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure we are examining includes a new type of heavy goods vehicle that would minimise road accidents by improving the driver's field of view by giving a better ability to identify vulnerable road users, such as cyclists. The addition of aerodynamic accessories would contribute to the reduction of consumption and harmful gas emissions, thus safeguarding air and the environment. The organisational revolution in transport envisaged in the measure is far-sighted and futuristic. Each Member State will have to adapt according to its own needs to the provisions to be adopted, directing the protection of road safety as a prerogative through a structural improvement in the design of the heavy transport vehicle. For these prerogatives, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution lays down, for certain road vehicles circulating in the Community, the authorized dimensions and maximum weights, with the aim of improving the driver's field of vision, reducing dead corners of visibility, including those under the windscreen, and thus saving many lives of vulnerable users, such as pedestrians or cyclists.  In addition, the addition of aerodynamic accessories would contribute to the reduction of consumption and harmful gas emissions, thus safeguarding the air and the environment. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European road safety data show that, even today, the targets set with the launch of european safety action programmes have not yet been met. This involved halving road fatalities by 2010, an ambitious goal that must encourage us to find the courage to introduce ever higher standards.  The optimum implementation of the major road infrastructures provided for in the 'Connecting Europe' programme will certainly be a key aid.  However, they may not be sufficient if the safety of vehicles is not also taken. In addition, it should be stressed that improving intermodality at European level will make it possible to shorten journey times and, consequently, reduce CO2 dispersion, bringing closer the achievement of another valuable objective for Europe in terms of environmental protection.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The directive in question seeks to improve the general safety of vehicles, drivers and road users and enhance environmental performance by cutting fuel consumption and emissions. Such a directive would also eliminate unnecessary red tape in the case of a multi-modal transport operation. I have thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Committee on Transport and Tourism adopted the recommendation for second reading of the Jörg Leichtfried report on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of a European Parliament directive amending Directive 96/53/EC laying down, for certain road vehicles circulating in the Community, the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weights in international traffic. I am voting in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The new Directive referred to in this report would promote the use of alternative power trains and aerodynamic flaps thus contributing to reductions in CO2 emissions, fuel savings and road safety. The new rules also establish that manufactures may produce longer cabs if they are more energy efficient and safer. Member States will also be free to choose either infrastructure devices or on—board weighing devices to be used for pre—selections for checks. Such changes will potentially have a good effect both on the environment and on the industry itself, hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to ensure better control of the weight of certain road vehicles to combat the numerous frauds in the maximum volume that a HGV can drive on our roads. The text also aims to encourage investment in more secure and less CO2-consuming lorries, while thus strengthening EU rules for controlling the maximum dimensions allowed.  This balanced agreement was the subject of difficult negotiations during the last mandate and I am particularly pleased that there is no longer any question of opening up to free movement on European roads the movement of 'mega-camions', the giant lorries which are currently only subject to local use in some EU countries, and which in my opinion have no place in a Europe geared towards a sustainable economy. , and logically therefore towards modal deferral. As the original proposals of the European Commission on this subject have been withdrawn, I have voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The revision of Directive 96/53/EC on the maximum size and weight of trucks in international traffic was implemented at this plenary session of the European Parliament.  Proposed in April 2013 by the European Commission, this revision of the directive as amended by Parliament and the Council proposes a number of innovations. As a result, the size of the trucks is lengthened and the weight of the trucks will be increased in intermodal transport operations, i.e. combining the road with the rail or waterways. In addition, the revised directive will make improvements for more aerodynamics in both the design of the cabs and the rear of the vehicles.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This text will enable safer and cleaner trucks to be used on European roads in the future, and for their comfort to be improved for their drivers. Another very important point is that this text prohibits the circulation of "mega-camions", whose weight exceeds 60 tons. Not all of the infrastructure of the Member States of the Union is suitable for supporting such heavy vehicles. It was therefore essential that a limit of size and weight be placed.  These new rules are moving in the right direction. Member States will have a two-year period to integrate them. They will also need to ensure that manufacturers and users have the time and means to comply with new changes.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. On 10 March 2015, the European Parliament adopted a revision of the "weight and dimensions" directive on heavy goods vehicles dating back to 1996.  Although this new text does not put an end to mega-camions, those gigaliners that pose risks to road safety, maintenance and the environment, I voted in favour of this revision which includes several major positive points such as the reaffirmation of the ban on trucks over 40 tons from passing from one country to another, as well as the generalization of the system of control boxes allowing better monitoring of heavy goods vehicles. Another key point of the review is the strengthening of the safety and well-being of road workers through a change in cabin design.  Finally, improving truck aerodynamics and developing low-carbon engines are equally critical issues in a goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The aim is to amend Directive 96/53/EC to improve vehicle aerodynamics and fuel efficiency, while continuing to improve road safety. The proposal grants exemptions to the maximum dimensions of vehicles, authorizes the increase of one tonne in the weight of vehicles with electric or hybrid propulsion, aims to facilitate the development of intermodal transport, confirms that the cross-border use of longer vehicles is lawful for journeys crossing only one border, if the two Member States concerned already allow it, and finally adds new provisions to enable the supervisory authorities to better detect infringements and harmonize the administrative sanctions that apply to them.  Given that this proposal has no impact on the European Union budget and that it was essential to amend Directive 96/53/EC because of a number of shortcomings, I therefore decided to support this proposal and vote in favour.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. I do not share some of the objectives of this text and regret that the protection of companies and employees are not included in the motivations, in favour of a strictly ideological vision that absolutizes competition.  On the other hand, this text seems to me to be contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. Whether it is improving the aerodynamic performance of vehicles, their energy efficiency, or performance and safety requirements, I do not see in which of these areas Member States would not be able to act effectively. Under the pretext of combating global warming, the Commission allows itself to intervene in all areas, in defiance of the treaties. So I voted against it.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK had a number of key political objectives. Firstly, it was vital to ensure that the UK would retain the right to veto the entry of any so-called 60 tonne/80 foot long ʽmegatrucksʼ onto British roads. This has been secured, and such ʽmegatrucksʼ will only be permitted to operate across borders where there are bilateral agreements between Member States. Secondly, we were successful in retaining the existing right of trucks, higher than the permitted 4 metres, to operate between the UK and the Republic of Ireland. Finally, in terms of safer cab design, we successfully reached an agreement whereby new, safer, and more streamlined cab design in lorries will be introduced, following the agreement on the forthcoming Commission proposal on ‘type-approval’ legislation for lorries. This will give manufacturers a sufficient timeframe to improve their designs, which should eventually lead to safer vehicles, reducing the risk of death and injury to pedestrians and cyclists.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Recommendation because it is an initiative that aims to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas (CO2) emissions, adapt transport legislation to technological advances and changing market needs and facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and the protection of road infrastructure.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation, because while there are some amendments that move in the right lines, especially with regard to the impact of road transport on the environment, the new safety rules and the new technical specifications of lorries, it nevertheless fails to take into account the different level of infrastructure in the different countries of the Union, and also does not promote the interconnection of road transport with other means of mass transport.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of new rules on truck weights and design which will improve safety for drivers and other road users in Wales. I was opposed to the introduction of the huge ʽgigalinersʼ, which would be unacceptable on roads in Wales. They raise major safety and infrastructure concerns, as well as undermining the use of more environmentally-friendly rail for freight, for which we are working in Wales. I welcome the fact that gigaliners are not included in this report.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this legislative proposal which aims, on the one hand, to reduce the energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions of road vehicles, and on the other hand to adapt the legislation to the technological requirements of electric mobility, without harming the load capacity of vehicles. Iso will speed up the market introduction of more aerodynamic vehicles, or hybrid engine. The proposal also aims to improve the intermodality of cargo transport and the adoption of measures for greater road safety.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposed changes bring improvements not only in new truck models, but also in the safety of truckers and road users. Member States should, for example, take specific measures to identify vehicles likely to exceed the relevant weight limits, as well as implement appropriate national provisions within two years of the entry into force of the revision of the Directive.  It was also decided that the Commission should revise the Directive three years after the national provisions enter into force, taking into account certain market segments, in particular that of light vehicles.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report proposes derogations from Directive 96/53/EC, with the intention of setting new maximum dimensions and new maximum weights in national and international traffic for certain road vehicles in circulation within the European Union. It is important to know at the outhelasty whether the movement of vehicles of these sizes and weights is consistent with the road network of each Member State, in particular as to the resistance, maintenance and safety of roads. The prerogatives conferred on Member States in deciding on the type of vehicles they can drive on their road network are essential. It is recognised that certain technical aspects will result in improvements in mechanical and energy performance, comfort, safety and reduction of polluting gases, in particular greenhouse gases, from vehicles. For these reasons, we voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report to be voted on concerns the revision of Directive 96/53/EC on the dimensions and weights of road vehicles, a necessary revision in view of the technological progress made in this field in recent years. The improvements included in the proposal concern vehicle aerodynamics, energy efficiency and road safety. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ oversized trucks pose a significant safety problem for the European Union's road infrastructure. These oversized vehicles destroy infrastructure and cause problems for the inhabitants of individual regions as a result of their passage through small villages. There is no doubt that all sectors should contribute together to the transition to a sustainable economy and an energy union. However, in the case of lorries, which are responsible for up to 26% of emissions, this contraction does not occur and the economy of their operation has not improved in any fundamental way in the last 20 years. It is important that limits on the weight and size of such vehicles are clearly set in order to contribute to reducing road mortality in the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against the measure as future elongated vehicles could cause greater risks to driving, both for pedestrians and in creating traffic disruption in certain areas (especially in Italy).

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Recommendation, because while there are some amendments which run on the right lines, especially with regard to the impact of road transport on the environment, the new safety rules and the new technical specifications of lorries, it nevertheless fails to take into account the different level of infrastructure in the different countries of the Union, and also does not promote the interconnection of road transport with other means of mass transport.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the directive against the ʽmegatrucksʼ to ensure that their use, up until now limited to the Scandinavian countries, the United Kingdom and Ireland, is not extended to all European countries. Today 26 % of CO2 emissions from road transport in Europe come from this kind of heavy vehicle. A further spread of such means would have dangerous repercussions on pollution.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 The maximum authorised dimensions and weights for certain vehicles driving on EU roads is an aspect to be taken into account due to the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and changing market needs, which require adapting so as not to lose competitiveness in the international market. This is a measure that is not against anyone, as it simply aims to increase the competitiveness and effectiveness of European industry while considering the environmental aspect and greenhouse gas reduction targets.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. In view of the objective, set out in the 2011 White Paper, of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 60% compared with 1990, I am voting in favour of the proposal to revise Directive 96/53/EC with regard to the weights and dimensions of motor vehicles in order to limit their energy consumption, in the light of the new technologies acquired and the current requirements for road transport safety. To this end, I also consider it important that the directive can, in compliance with the guidelines contained in the document 'Towards a European Road Safety Area 2011-2020' and in accordance with the sustainability objectives set out in the Horizon 2020 programme, be subject to certain derogations aimed essentially at three objectives: exceptions on length, in favour of an increase in aerodynamics, on weight to facilitate the market for electric (batteries) or hybrid (double engine) cars and revised taking into account all measures aimed at promoting intermodal development.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Leichtfried report because I welcome the fact that the new Directive would promote the use of alternative power-trains and aerodynamic flaps and cabs, thus contributing to reductions in CO2 emissions, fuel savings and road safety. It is also crucial that this new legislation would not prevent more extensive road safety measures on safer lorries at local or regional level.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this recommendation because it is an initiative that aims to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas (CO2) emissions, adapt transport legislation to technological advances and changing market needs and facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and the protection of road infrastructure.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this balanced text on the maximum size and weight allowed for certain road vehicles, which encourages road hauliers to invest in more secure trucks for users, safer and less polluting, because they are less CO2-consuming. These vehicles will therefore have to meet higher safety and environmental standards, and I welcome that. In particular, I am pleased that, despite the pressures, this text does not address or allow, in Europe, the "mega trucks" or mega-trucks, these oversized trucks of 60 tons and 25 meters long. Indeed, "mega trucks" are too dangerous and unsuitable for our European infrastructure and roads. I will continue to oppose it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal which amends General Circulation Directive 96/53/EC, setting maximum weights and dimensions for vehicles circulating in the EU. It is aimed at authorising longer lorries, moreover it authorises new technologies for weight checks on vehicles in order to meet new diesel standards. I am also in favour of more extensive road safety measures on safer lorries at local and regional levels.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this directive, which will allow manufacturers to bring safer and more environmentally friendly trucks to market, while ensuring better protection of road infrastructure, through the introduction of specific controls on unauthorised overloads.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of certain road vehicles circulating within the Community, the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weights in international traffic, as I believe that those regulations will improve the general safety of vehicles.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it allows: • an increase in vehicle length to accommodate changes to the cab design of trucks to improve aerodynamics and road safety; • an increase in vehicle length to accommodate aerodynamic devices at the rear of vehicles which improve fuel consumption and reduce emissions; • an increase in vehicle length to accommodate 45ft containers used in intermodal transport; • an increase in vehicle weight (up to a maximum of one tonne) for alternatively fuelled vehicles; • improved inspection and enforcement related to checks on vehicle weights.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This legislation will go some way to making Europe’s roads safer, particularly for cyclists, and I accordingly voted in favour.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Recommendation because it is an initiative that aims to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas (CO2) emissions, adapt transport legislation to technological advances and changing market needs and facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and the protection of road infrastructure.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒in 2012 I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a directive from Parliament and the Council amending Directive 96/53/EC to establish the maximum permissible dimensions in internal and international traffic and the maximum permissible mass in international transport for certain road vehicles running within the Community, as this improves road safety.  I also support measures aimed at detecting vehicles that violate and exceed appropriate restrictions, adapting relevant legislation to technological developments and exchanging information.  In my view, effective coordination is needed to ensure compliance with the criteria and sanctions for breaches of the Directive.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Unfortunately, this text is not intended to protect companies and employees, since it is solely the result of an ideological vision of absolutisation of competition. States seem to have been forgotten in this report, since in the various areas mentioned (e.g. the aerodynamic performance of vehicles, their energy efficiency or performance and safety requirements), the States seem competent.  This text opposes the fundamental principle of subsidiarity. By using the pretext of global warming, the European institutions intend to intervene in all areas in defiance of the treaties. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the trilogue agreement on the new directive on the weights and dimensions of road vehicles. This directive should enable the launch of new truck models to improve safety on our roads as well as air quality, while leaving a reasonable period of time for manufacturers to adapt before the new standards are applied. This delay was necessary in order to ensure fair competition between manufacturers and to defend important industrial jobs throughout France.  I therefore welcome the adoption of this report, which is good news for jobs, security and the environment.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the report on the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive setting the maximum dimensions allowed in domestic and international traffic for certain road vehicles travelling in the Community and the maximum allowable weights for international traffic. These provisions will reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve road safety and facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and protecting road infrastructure.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. The report contains sensible measures with little to no additional costs to technically adapt the transport of goods on lorries to the 21st century. That is why I support this proposal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution to revise the maximum weights and dimensions of certain road vehicles, as larger and heavier trucks are a threat not only to road safety but also to the environment. This proposal will limit the size of heavy-good vehicles, promoting the shift from road to rail transportation and enhancing support for the development and use of low-carbon technologies. This will ensure that emissions are cut, helping us achieve our climate change goals, and will make the roads safer for all citizens.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the directive as it is much stronger than the weak proposal put forward by the Commission. All sectors should contribute to the transition to a sustainable economy and to an energy union. Heavy goods vehicles are responsible for about 26 % of road-transport CO2 emissions in Europe and their fuel efficiency has hardly improved over the last 20 years. I regret that the Transport Ministers insisted on delaying the introduction of the safer truck cabins until at least 2020. This directive however limits the size and weight of trucks on EU roads and promotes combined road-rail or road-ship transport operations for standard 45-foot containers.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I support Mr McDerman's report. Jörg Leichtfried, which concerns the adoption of the directive laying down the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic, as well as the maximum authorised weights in international traffic.  I believe that specific measures should be taken within the territory of the European Union to identify vehicles that could exceed their weight limits.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the directive to make trucks with longer driver's cabs, in order to improve safety. It will also make the next fleets of trucks more efficient by opening the door to the integration of less CO2-emitting technologies and devices that will increase the visibility of drivers, thereby improving pedestrian safety.  This text also introduces sufficient time for all industrialists to have time to prepare for the integration of these new standards and will thus preserve important industrial jobs throughout France.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. Under the guise of environmental requirements, in terms of greenhouse gas emissions and transport safety, the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive on the maximum allowable dimensions and maximum allowable weights for certain vehicles travelling in the Community is a step towards opening up European road networks to competition through enhanced harmonisation regulation.  In the previous Parliament, I had already opposed this text and the recommendation for second reading before us does not correct any defects but reinforces the control requirements on road vehicles and the standards imposed on states for the management of networks and tolls. I voted against this text, which focuses more on building a supranational regulatory system than on protecting businesses and employees in the road sector, threatened by the single market project and the liberalisation of the network.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it further opens the road network to international competition, which will increase the difficulties of French transport companies, and encourage social dumping. Of course, it also allows the manufacture of trucks with longer cabs, which should improve the safety of drivers in the event of a collision. And it sets a higher weight limit, which should encourage the boarding of cleaner carburetor systems. But these two advantages do not compensate for the over-exposed fundamental flaw of the text.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. Parliament denies Member States the possibility of imposing certain controls (on-board weighing system) and offences cannot be categorized according to their seriousness with adequate sanction. We also reject the Commission's supervisory role to which Member States will have to provide information on the number of checks carried out. We believe that this initiative will result in increased competition and therefore pose a danger to our companies and their employees.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it aims at a change in regulation with the aim of limiting pollution caused by trucks. In particular, it is proposed to extend the maximum length authorised by Council Directive 96/53/EC.  Technological evolution offers the possibility to add retractable or foldable devices to trucks, so that significant energy savings are achieved. That is why the maximum authorised dimensions and maximum authorised weights for those trucks operating within EU territory have been extended.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is not the optimal solution for me, I would prefer to be able to deal with this in a national way. But the fact is that we are now members of the EU and I have to decide based on that fact; there are some good things in this report and that is why I choose to support it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it a positive effort to allow carriers to operate trucks extended by an aerodynamic attachment that reduces consumption. However, I am concerned about the Union's efforts to determine the size of windows, etc. I cannot support further standardisation at the expense of the sovereignty of the Member States, which is why I voted against it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The proposed amendments to Directive 96/53/EC on the establishment of maximum permissible dimensions in internal and international traffic and the maximum permissible mass in international transport for certain road vehicles running within the Community will allow manufacturers to exceed the design of truck cabs to date with a view to increasing the safety and environmental performance of these vehicles.  The more aerodynamic shape of truck cabs would increase the field of vision for drivers and mitigate the consequences in the event of accidents. A more aerodynamic appearance would also reduce resistance to movement, reducing fuel consumption, which would have a positive impact on the environment. By amending this directive, an additional mass of trucks would allow manufacturers to install hybrid transmission systems to further reduce pollution to the environment and therefore I supported the Report on the dimensions and mass of road vehicles operating within the community.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This was not a final vote at second reading. The vote was in the bloc, without amendments, and concerns a major sector such as domestic and international road transport. I voted in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Directive 96/53/EC laying down, for certain road vehicles in circulation in the Community, the maximum permitted dimensions in national and international transport and the maximum permitted burdens on international transport, as emphasis should be placed on the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, in particular carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, improve road safety, adapt relevant legislation to technological developments and changing market needs, as well as facilitate intermodal transport, while ensuring a level playing field and protecting road infrastructure.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against it. Indeed, this decision and the management of these offences are the responsibility of the Member States and not that of the European Union and should therefore not be debated here. Moreover, this text opens the road network to competition rather than protecting European and therefore French companies and employees.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome Parliament adding to the legislative resolution the following ‘Infringements in relation to overloaded vehicles need to be addressed adequately by Member States in order to avoid any distortions of competition and to ensure road safety’.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Directive provides for derogations from the authorised dimensions and maximum weights of vehicles and combined vehicles laid down in Directive 96/53/EC. Member States should adequately address the problem of infringements of overloaded vehicles in order to improve and ensure better road safety. That is why I voted in favour of the recommendation on the dimensions and weights of road vehicles circulating in the Community.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Eu ropean Union Member States should implement specific measures to identify vehicles that may have exceeded the weight limits imposed on the specific category.  That is why I have chosen to support, with my vote in favour, the Leichtfried report, which calls for the implementation of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council which lays down, for certain road vehicles circulating in the Community, the authorized dimensions and maximum weights.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My support for the proposal put forward in the European Parliament on the maximum authorised dimensions and weights in international traffic, which will allow truck manufacturers to build vehicles of greater weight and length than current ones, but provided that they improve their environmental performance and safety measures. The aim is to introduce measures to ensure more efficient freight transport in the EU and greater possibility of action against carriers that do not meet the limits set for weight or safety.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. The revision of the present Directive is a sensible and welcome step towards adapting intermodal freight transport to the 21st century. That is why I was able to support this report without hesitation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Technological developments offer the possibility of adding retractable or foldable aerodynamic devices to the rear of vehicles, allowing for significant energy gains. However, these schemes would result in exceeding the maximum lengths allowed under the Council's Directive 96/53/EC. A derogation from the maximum lengths is therefore necessary, this is the purpose of this text. The proposal therefore aims to limit the pollution of buses and trucks.  Of course, these measures will remain a blow to the water until true ecological planning reduces road transport in favour of piggybacking. In this context, I abstain in order not to prevent these meagre advances while denouncing the Commission's lack of ambition to reduce greenhouse gases.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it essential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, in particular carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, to improve road safety, to adapt the legislation applicable to technological developments and to evolving market needs and to facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and protecting road infrastructure. That is why I am voting in favour of this document at second reading.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which has as its aim the introduction of newly designed lorries with improved overall safety and environmental performance.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the dimensions and weights of road vehicles circulating within the Community. The new directive would promote the use of alternative power-trains and aerodynamic flaps and cabs, thus contributing to reductions in CO2 emissions, fuel savings and road safety. The directive also reduces the administrative burden for use of 45—foot containers in intermodal transport.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Council Directive 96/53/EC limits the maximum permissible size and total weight of certain road vehicles. However, with advances in technology, it has been possible to substantially improve the aerodynamic characteristics of vehicles by means of a novel design of the cab and the installation of retractable/folding aerodynamic devices mounted on the rear of the vehicle. Alternative powertrains have also been developed to significantly reduce environmental pressures. This would increase the energy efficiency of vehicles, reduce their emissions, improve road safety and the safety and comfort of the driver, while at the same time increasing the length and total weight of the vehicle.  I consider it appropriate to propose an increase in the maximum size and overall mass permitted by the Directive in order to use these modern technological means, so as not to increase the previously limited payload capacity of motor vehicles.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Directive includes a number of important measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, increase road safety and adapt the sector to technological developments and the market.  As it improves the aerodynamics of the cab of motor vehicles, with energy efficiency advantages, it also allows for an increase in the load capacity of vehicles and maximum lengths. From now on, the movement of three- and/or two-axle vehicles with two- and/or three-axle semi-trailers up to a total weight of 44 and/42 tonnes is permitted. In order to ensure the application of this Directive, Member States should carry out annual checks on the weight of vehicles and devices used on board or others for weighing should also be made available to the driver. On the other hand, there should be a deepening of the exchange of information between Member States on their infringements and controls carried out.  I am in favour of the adoption of this document, as it allows for harmonisation of the rules on road transport, eliminating road blocks and obstructions to the internal market.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as this new legislation will not prevent more extensive road-safety measures on safer lorries at local/regional level.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which subjects truck manufacturers to new rules to manufacture vehicles with visibility-enhancing cabs and cleaner engines. Ultimately, this will help to increase safety on our roads and preserve the environment.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of this directive will allow manufacturers to introduce newly designed trucks, which could exceed the current maximum limits on the length and weight of heavy goods vehicles in order to improve overall safety and environmental performance. It will also eliminate the unnecessary bureaucracy faced by hauliers forced to apply for special permits to transport these containers.  We believe, however, that legislative action by the Member States is essential, both to facilitate regulatory approval in this area and to provide for specific measures to identify vehicles that may have exceeded their length and weight limits. This is a natural protection of road safety for European citizens.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I obviously voted for this directive because it is the result of bitter negotiations to preserve fair competition between manufacturers and to defend important industrial jobs throughout France. Thanks to this text, the European Union is contributing to safer roads, better air quality and the preservation of a very large number of jobs.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 96/53/EC on the dimensions and weights of road vehicles circulating in the Community has contributed for many years to the smooth functioning of the internal market in road transport, setting maximum dimensions and weights for vehicles carrying out national and international transport of goods and passengers. In the light of market developments and available technologies, the question now arises as to whether the choices made at the time of its adoption in 1996 are always relevant. In particular, the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and the consumption of oil products has become crucial in the transport sector. For these reasons, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour of the Leichtfried report, which stresses that a revision of the directive is necessary given that improving the efficiency and environmental performance of road transport is an essential objective of the common transport policy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the introduction of this recommendation on the Council's first reading position with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Directive 96/53/EC laying down, for certain road vehicles travelling within the Community, the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weight in international traffic.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because I believe it is important to adapt the legal standards for road vehicles to technical progress and also assume that the transport sector in particular is a crucial building block in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft to introduce maximum dimensions and maximum mass for certain vehicles, as this can improve the overall safety of vehicles. However, in order to avoid distortions of competition, each Member State must adequately address compliance checks and the reduction of infringements.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this recommendation. The proposal for a directive tabled is flexible. Furthermore, its implementation to improve the safety and environmental performance of heavy goods vehicles will not create a significant additional financial burden for Member States and businesses. It should be noted that delays in the adoption of this directive have a negative impact on both business and the environment. Another important aspect is that Member States are authorised to control the weight of tractors not only in one way by installing weight sensors, but are also allowed to implement other technological solutions. In view of this, I believe that it is appropriate to impose a ban on the State requiring the introduction of weight sensors from tractors registered in other countries as soon as they cross the territory of that Member State. It should be noted that it is in the interest of national and international carriers to make use of innovative cab designs, additional weights for alternative-fuel tractors and the possibility of more efficient intermodal transport as soon as possible.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve road safety, adapt legislation to technological developments and changing market needs and facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undestored competition and protecting road infrastructure; that technological developments offer the possibility of installing retractable or folding aerodynamic devices at the rear end of vehicles; that this Directive provides for derogations from the authorised dimensions and maximum weights of vehicles and combined vehicles laid down in Directive 96/53/EC, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support measures aimed at reducing carbon dioxide emissions as well as reducing fossil fuel consumption for transport by road transport. However, the question arises as to how much these aerodynamic devices that will be placed from the back or on the cab of the truck will cost in terms of buying and installing them, and what time it will take for them to be financially repaid in terms of reducing fuel consumption.  I support equipping vehicles with new cab construction to contribute to improving road safety by reducing blind corners in the driver's field of vision, which should help save the lives of many vulnerable road users such as pedestrians and cyclists. I support the introduction of alternative propulsion systems, which include hybrid propulsion systems, and whose mass will not be further factored in as part of the actual carrying capacity of the vehicle.  I welcome the need to prioritise public transport over private transport in the interests of better energy efficiency, which means that the former number of passengers on board bus transport needs to be re-reached, while also taking into account the increase in their mass and the mass of their luggage.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of changing the maximum permissible weight in road transport of vehicles is to reduce energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions, to adapt technological development legislation and to adapt to market needs and facilitate intermodal transport. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions as well as reducing the consumption of petroleum products in the field of transport has become crucial and even crucial for road transport, which accounts for 82% of energy consumption in the transport sector. Furthermore, rising fuel prices encourage the need to identify solutions to reduce vehicle fuel consumption and consequently reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  The White Paper on Transport has set a target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 60% by 2050 from 1990 levels. In this context, it announced a revision of the 1996 Directive with a view to bringing more energy-efficient vehicles to the EU market. Energy efficiency must be one of the priorities of the European Union, which is why I support my colleague Leichtfried's report and the objectives set by it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In order to protect the environment, increase energy efficiency and reduce fossil fuel consumption, the Council has accepted waste heat as one of the main sources of alternative fuel type.  The use of alternative sources reduces environmental pollution, but affects the increase in the overall mass of vehicles. In the intermodal transport of containers with a length of 45 feet, 15 cm longer trailers and semi-trailers for whose transport special permits were to be obtained are introduced.  For the best energy efficiency, motor vehicles are equipped with aerodynamic retractable or folding aerodynamic devices connected to the rear of the vehicle. The new cab design should have increased aerodynamic performance, which, along with the energy factor, greatly improve general vehicle safety on the road and driver comfort. All Member States should check vehicle masses annually either through mechanisms installed in road infrastructure or on-board equipment visible to the driver and competent authorities for data exchange as quickly and efficiently as possible. I therefore support colleague Leichtfried's report and the Directive and believe that technical adjustments should be made, fuel consumption, CO2 emissions, road infrastructure protection and smooth competition should be ensured.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support and welcome the European Parliament's decision on the maximum permissible dimensions for national and international traffic and the maximum permissible mass for international traffic, in which the European Parliament issued an imaginary 'stopwatch' proposal to adapt pan-European road infrastructure to the needs of oversized lorries (in the accompanying proposal up to 25 m long weighing up to 60 t). The directive adopted by the European Parliament goes much further than the european commission's original proposal, and I am pleased that Parliament has also found agreement with the Council, i.e. that the text adopted today will no longer be revised. Lorries cause about 26% of CO2 emissions on the roads and are making the slowest progress in terms of green transport. The directive adopted today not only limits the maximum dimensions and weight of lorries, but also encourages a combination with greener modes of transport, in particular rail and shipping. Last but not least, I am pleased that the Social Democrats have succeeded in pushing through the requirements for safer cabs for drivers with better aerodynamics and greater visibility, even though the last of these requirements will not come into force until after 2020.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is a fundamental objective to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles, adapting current legislation to continuous technological developments in the sector and to an ever-changing market, not forgetting to give priority to road safety.  For these reasons, I welcome this Directive of the European Parliament which modifies the maximum lengths of vehicles in order to give priority to new aerodynamic devices that allow considerable advantages over the energy performance of vehicles. In addition, a new profiling of vehicle cabs helps to improve road safety for all and improve driver comfort.  With regard to the weight of vehicles, I believe it is important for the competent authorities of the Member States to exchange information systematically in order to facilitate the carrying out of checks on their weight. It is also important for the European Parliament to be informed about the checks carried out on road traffic by the competent authorities, to see whether the rules are being applied and whether additional measures are needed.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. Technological developments make it possible to install retractable or folding aerodynamic devices at the rear of vehicles. Likewise, the use of alternative powertrain groups, which seek energy from consumable fuels and/or a battery, reduces pollution. Greenhouse gas emissions need to be reduced in order to improve road safety, to adapt the legislation applicable to technological developments and changing market needs and to facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and protecting road infrastructure. However, the installation of such devices would exceed the lengths and maximum weights authorised under Council Directive 96/53/EC. Provision should therefore be made for a derogation from the maximum authorised weights and dimensions of vehicles and sets of vehicles laid down in Directive 96/53/EC. The aim is for manufacturers to be able to introduce new truck models that exceed current weight and size limits in order to improve overall vehicle safety, energy efficiency and environmental performance. The purpose of this proposal for a Directive is precisely to have such amendments. I voted in favour.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. At the end of negotiations with the Council of the European Union and after the vote of MEPs in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, the European Parliament said no to mega-trucks in a plenary vote on the directive on the weights and dimensions of heavy vehicles. It is a victory for the protection of the quality of life of Europeans. Thanks to the vote of MEPs, our villages and towns will not be crossed by trucks 25 metres long weighing more than 60 tonnes!  This vote is also the culmination of a long struggle by Socialist MEPs against the Commission's proposal to allow cross-border movement of mega-trucks.  This vote is a positive signal for the reduction of CO2 emissions and the promotion of the modal deferral of road transport of goods to rail. The text also takes into account the safety of users and the preservation of the environment by incorporating provisions in favour of the promotion of alternative fuels and the aerodynamics of vehicles.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, improve road safety, adapt the legislation applicable to technological developments and market developments, protecting road infrastructure while ensuring undistorted competition. Technological developments allow the installation of retractable or folding aerodynamic devices at the rear of vehicles, thus reducing their strength and, consequently, their consumption. The installation of this device will cause vehicles to exceed the length limits, so it is necessary to derogate from the Regulation defining these limits. A new cabin profile would help improve road safety by reducing drivers' blind eye angles, saving many lives. A new cab profile would also allow the installation of collision energy absorption structures.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. More security, less greenhouse gas emissions. This is the ballot that European trucks should soon present following the European Parliament's vote this morning, approving changes to the European provisions on the design of heavy goods vehicles.  Two observations: trucks, buses and coaches produce about a quarter of the CO2 emissions of road transport in the UNION and some 5% of total greenhouse gas emissions and are often involved in serious traffic accidents, as today's news shows. These vehicles must meet strict size and weight rules to protect infrastructure and ensure road safety. Today, with technological change, these 1996 rules are obsolete.  The new provisions will allow manufacturers to design trucks that are more efficient, both in terms of the environment and safety, without reducing their loading capacity.  For example, better aerodynamics would reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by 7-10% and more rounded cabins would reduce dangerous blind spots. European trucks will soon be safer, cleaner and more efficient.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Making our trucks safer and more comfortable, more environmentally friendly and suitable for multimodal transport is the aim of the proposal submitted to us.  I therefore welcome its adoption, which brings European legislation in line with recent technological developments. Adjusting vehicle size standards will allow for the addition of aerodynamic devices, improved cabin profiling and improved energy absorption in the event of an accident. The increase in the average weight of passengers and their luggage as well as equipment with alternative propulsion systems (hydrogen, electricity, etc.) involving the addition of batteries or dual motorization was also taken into account.  Finally, I am pleased to see that, on the issue of the international circulation of mega-camions initially envisaged by the Commission, it has been decided to remain at the status quo. We are not prepared for that change. It is regrettable, however, that the new defined standards may not come into force until 2020 as a result of the action of some Member States, under pressure from their manufacturers. This is the same time during which citizens will not be able to benefit from advances in innovation on heavy goods vehicles.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the revision of the "weight and dimensions" directive on heavy goods vehicles dating back to 1996. Indeed, this new text makes significant improvements in road transport. In particular, it aims to modify the design of the cabs in order to enhance the safety of road users in the event of an accident, to ensure an increased well-being of the driver. It also improves aerodynamics with the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and their impact on the environment.  I regret, however, that this new text does not sign the end of mega-camions or "gigaliners". These vehicles weigh up to 60 tonnes raise major road and environmental safety concerns. Not least because they are diverting rail freight to the trucker when rail should be preferred. It also encourages the adoption of new standards for commercial trucks or buses equipped with low-carbon engines. This directive should also ensure better control of heavy goods vehicles by the generalisation of the system of control boxes still too little widespread in Europe.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the maximum dimensions and weights allowed for certain road vehicles.  In particular, this text aims to adapt the dimensions planned to take account of technological developments. For example, new aerodynamic devices generate many gains, but are added to the rear and, therefore, can lengthen vehicles.  In approving this amendment, our Assembly is emphasizing the imperative to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and in particular CO2, but also on strengthening safety on our roads. With a new profiling of vehicle cabs, drivers' blind spots can be reduced. This will save the lives of both vulnerable drivers and road users such as pedestrians and cyclists.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The change in the maximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic, as well as the maximum weights on certain vehicles on the same routes, is essential given the constant flow of transport and cargo existing in the Member States of the European Union. However, it is important and relevant to check compliance with the established standards and the amendment to the previous legislation on this subject.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. With this amendment to the Directive laying down the maximum weights and measures authorised for the international transport of certain goods and passenger vehicles, the door is closed so that vehicles exceeding 40 tonnes can make international journeys, in a decision which brings benefits for both safety and environmental protection. It will also make it easier for bus and truck cabins to have a less aggressive design to help prevent abuse while improving driver visibility by improving the size and placement of the front and side moons. Measures are also introduced to improve aerodynamics and thus reduce consumption and therefore CO2 emissions. To this end, exceptions to weights for buses with alternative propulsion systems to traditional combustion engines will be allowed to help reduce CO2 emissions. And to encourage combined transport, excess weights will be allowed for the transport of shipping containers when combined with sea or rail travel. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. We adopted yesterday, at second reading, the revision of Directive 96/53/EC on the maximum size and weight of trucks (also known as "mega-cars").  The text voted aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and improve road safety. It allows, on the one hand, to add retractable aerodynamic devices to the rear of vehicles as well as the installation of rounded driving cabs, which will now offer a better overview to the driver (which I am pleased because each year there are on average between 350 and 400 accidents between a truck and a weak user, of which about thirty are directly due to the blind spot). And, on the other hand, the new rules aim to make trucks greener. These new types of HGVs are expected to be in circulation from 2022.  It is now up to the Council to approve this text in April.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which allows the introduction of new and more efficient types of trucks with the integration of less CO2-emitting technologies, devices that will increase visibility for drivers and thus the safety of other users. A deadline has been reached to allow manufacturers time to prepare for these changes and the integration of these new standards.  It is also a question of better combating fraud relating to the maximum volume that a LGV can drive on European roads.  With this vote, we have strengthened road safety and defended industrial jobs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is the result of a long agreement between the Council and the European Parliament on the definition of the weight limits of alternatively powered vehicles and intermodal transport for certain containers. The aim of the report is to improve the aerodynamic aspects of commercial vehicles and their energy efficiency, in this way bringing greater road safety and greater respect for the environment.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted against because there is a risk that any future elongated vehicles could cause greater risks to driving, pedestrians and create disruption to the roads of many areas.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Recommendation because it is an initiative that aims to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas (CO2) emissions, adapt transport legislation to technological advances and changing market needs and facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and the protection of road infrastructure.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this directive, which will allow manufacturers to design safer and greener trucks. The next fleets of trucks will be more efficient: the new directive amends a 1996 text on the weight and dimensions of trucks in order to allow exemptions to current limits and to improve their environmental performance and safety. Parliament fought to introduce sufficient time for all manufacturers to have time to adapt to the new standards, thereby preserving fair competition between manufacturers for the benefit of employment.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it aims at a change in regulation with the aim of limiting pollution caused by trucks. In particular, it is proposed to extend the maximum length authorised by Council Directive 96/53/EC.  Technological evolution offers the possibility to add retractable or foldable devices to trucks, so that significant energy savings are achieved. That is why the maximum authorised dimensions and maximum authorised weights for those trucks operating within eu territory have been extended.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs today voted in favour of EU rules on large vehicles to encourage greener and safer buses, trucks and lorries.  This proposal amends General Circulation Directive 96/53/EC which sets maximum weights and dimensions for vehicles circulating in the EU. It will authorise longer lorries which is said to be justified on environmental grounds. Extra length on lorries would allow more aerodynamically designed cabs and rear flaps. It must be stressed that the new legislation will not prevent more extensive road—safety measures on safer lorries at local/regional level.  Labour MEPs will continue to call for further action at EU level to improve vehicle safety and environmental standards.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the dimension and mass of road vehicles running within the Community, as I consider it essential to highlight the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, in particular carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, and to improve road safety by adapting relevant legislation to technological developments and changing market needs. This has an impact on strengthening the sustainable growth of the whole Community. Although at first glance the dimensions and masses of road vehicles are not directly related to the aforementioned, the fact is that a better vehicle design will result in lower air resistance and therefore lower fuel consumption, which ultimately represents lower greenhouse gas emissions and less environmental pollution. If we take into account that the transition to an alternative propulsion system implies a system that for the purposes of mechanical propulsion draws energy from the battery or other electricity storage device, we will also see how their use in heavy goods vehicles or buses increases the mass of vehicles. In addition to environmental performance, I believe that the application of the Directive would also contribute to road safety, as the new design, such as rounded cabs, would increase the driver's visibility and make it easier to spot road users. For these effective opportunities, I call on Member States to cooperate effectively at international level in which the European institutions will be informed of the checks carried out by their competent authorities in road transport.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I supported the report on certain regulations in road transport. Anyone travelling across Europe must recognise that our road network is congested, overcrowded and any regulatory element that will help to shift part of the freight to the rail network is welcome. I understand that technological developments currently make it possible to fasten reeling or folding aerodynamic devices to the back of vehicles, but we must bear in mind, above all, that this act does not increase the maximum lengths of vehicles, does not increase their load capacity and, most importantly, that road safety is respected. I believe that, in order to address the derogations, the proposed directive creates such an option for derogations from the maximum authorised weights and dimensions of vehicles and vehicle combinations laid down in Directive 96/53/EC and is a sufficient compromise. I also consider it right to introduce weight limits for bus transport.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Road safety is very important and necessary and the EU must work to improve it at all times. It is therefore important that all fleet participants are well equipped and that the legislation is clear about what this equipment represents and covers. There is certainly a need to improve the difficult conditions and safety for lorry drivers, and he does also have the safety of citizens and all road users in the European Union. The presence of mega-trucks throughout the Union is not welcome and poses both a threat to road users and to a huge burden on the fleet. It is therefore good that the ban on the driving of mega-trucks between borders in the EU has not changed and remains. Nevertheless, positive changes covering the new rules for the weight and dimensions of lorries are welcome. Although this agreement is far from desired, it nevertheless represents a good improvement compared to the original proposal, especially if we take into account the environmental and safety aspects. Safe roads should be provided for all road users. In addition, it would also be appropriate to explore in the future the possibilities of reducing traffic, especially in the area of heavy vehicles such as lorries. I consider these aspects to be very important in the road transport regime, which is why I supported this amendment to the law in the European area.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the directive against so-called megatrucks, so that their use, currently limited to Scandinavian countries, the United Kingdom and Ireland, is not extended to all EU countries. To date, 26% of CO2 emissions from European road transport result from this type of heavy goods vehicle, and a further spread of these vehicles would have dangerous pollution consequences. For this reason too, this directive not only involves a weight limit and measures for means, but also encourages the use of combined transport, such as road and rail, or road and maritime transport, in order to ensure less use of road transport. Finally, the directive provides for the development of safer and greener cabs, thanks to aerodynamic improvements that will allow less consumption, and will allow drivers to have fewer blind corners, improving safety on European roads, which with more than 120 000 deaths per year is the leading cause of death in Europe.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA supports the new directive on vehicle dimensions and weights. The previous directive dates back to 1996 and was therefore in urgent need of revision. The updated directive aims to improve the safety of all road users and aims to achieve environmental benefits by focusing on the energy efficiency of vehicles. While the review certainly contains steps in the right direction, the N-VA regrets the continuing legal ambiguity for cross-border transport with ecocombis. These ecocombis were an important part of the Original Proposal of the European Commission, but were unfortunately deleted by a majority in the European Parliament and the Council. A missed opportunity. In Flanders, the first ecocombi took to the road at the beginning of this year. The N-VA remains fully committed to the pilot projects and remains committed to further cooperation with neighbouring countries such as the Netherlands.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution which aims to allow the installation of retracting aerodynamic devices or folding aerodynamic devices at the rear of the vehicle, which would allow for significant improvements in the energy performance of the vehicle.  Equipping vehicles with the new cab construction would contribute to improving road safety by reducing blind spots in the driver's field of vision, including those under the windscreen, and should help save the lives of many vulnerable road users such as pedestrians or cyclists. Road components of intermodal transport activities can currently only be carried out if both Member States and carriers carry out complex administrative procedures or if these containers have patented roped edges, which in creates extremely high costs.  By increasing the permissible length of vehicles carrying such containers by 15 cm, carriers could be exempted from these administrative procedures and could facilitate intermodal transport activities without compromising road infrastructure or other road users or harming that infrastructure or those participants.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on maximum weights and dimensions for vehicles circulating within the EU. In particular, the provisions amend the design of longer lorries, which will have a positive environmental impact and increase safety for drivers and pedestrians.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I support this report because it defines weight limits for alternative fuel vehicles.  The council accepted waste heat as a type of alternative fuel and extra weight for three-axle buses using alternative fuels. The treatment of transport carrying one or more containers or interchangeable crates up to a total maximum length of 45 feet is also defined. It is allowed to manufacture longer cabins if they are more energy efficient and safer.  The Commission will reassess the directive 3 years after it is implemented in national legislation.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ because it leads to the unification and streamlining of the current rules and, in particular, takes into account knowledge of application practice, which will allow the use of certain types of vehicles that are currently ridiculously prohibited.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Directive fixing the maximum permissible dimensions of certain road vehicles in the Community in national and international traffic and the maximum permissible weights in international traffic. In the European Union, 70% of road traffic takes place, which makes it very important to ensure that greenhouse gas emissions, in particular carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions are reduced, road safety is improved, the legislation in question is adapted to technological developments and changing market needs, and the facilitation of intermodal transport must be ensured, while ensuring undistingurecited competition and protection of road infrastructure. This recommendation is a concrete example of the implementation of the principle of subsidiarity in the European Union, as it is the responsibility of the Member States to allow longer lorries on the roads.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on the grounds that the new directive will lead to improved road safety. The new measures are also intended to significantly improve the aerodynamic characteristics of vehicles, bring fuel savings to a typical long-distance truck and significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Truck manufacturers will be able to introduce alternative propulsion systems without reducing the transport capacity of vehicles. The concept of new aerodynamic parts of trucks will provide opportunities for manufacturers to develop new models, which should support job creation and economic growth. Furthermore, the rules on the use of longer vehicles for the transport of containers in combined (road, rail and waterway) transport have been simplified. As regards congestion of lorries causing road damage, the new on-board systems will make it possible to inform drivers about the weight of lorries and, together with vehicle weighing stations while driving on major roads, will allow for more rigorous checks in individual countries.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The directive to be adopted should take into account the different level of infrastructure in the countries of the European Union, as well as promote the interconnection of roads with other means of mass transport.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The compromise report contributes to the protection of the environment and infrastructure at the same time. The adoption of the amendment to the Directive is an important step towards a safer European road traffic regulation, which also take into account the specificities of the Member States.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to protect the safety and health of my London constituents, it is important that we utilise the technological developments available to us in order to create safer road traffic vehicles. Developing safer road traffic vehicles will reduce the risk of death and injury to cyclists and pedestrians. Thus, I am happy that the proposal amending the existing Directive on the maximum authorised weights and dimensions of road traffic vehicles has passed. I am also pleased with the fact that the important political objectives I felt were necessary to protect the safety of UK citizens were included in the final piece of legislation. First, it was vital that the UK is allowed to retain the right to veto the entry of so-called ʽmegatrucksʼ onto British roads. Secondly, I am proud we were successful in retaining the existing rights of trucks higher than 4 metres to operate between the UK and the Republic of Ireland. The acceptance of these UK objectives into the amendment shows that the EU views the UK as an important member whose concerns it takes seriously. I am delighted that Parliament has listened to, acknowledged, and accepted the worries my nation had about this proposal, and allowed the UK to protect itself from these worries

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. We insist on the objective of deferring the transport of goods from the road to rail and river and we welcome the unanimous vote of the Committee on Transport. It is a "positive signal" for the fight against climate change. Mega-trucks are no longer relevant, except in very localized cases. In general, the text is of great concern for the safety of road users and takes into account the preservation of the environment, with the promotion of alternative fuels and the aerodynamics of vehicles. The road is still too important in the traffic of goods in Europe, but Parliament is sending a positive signal today for the fight against climate change!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text which updates the ʽMaximum authorised dimensions in national and international traffic and the maximum authorised weights in international traffic for certain road vehicles circulating within the Communityʼ. The current rules date back to the 1990s and did not allow enough flexibility in the design of lorries. The updated directive will now make it possible to improve the features of such vehicles to include, for example, aerodynamic cabs and devices. Consequently, European trucks will become more efficient, safer and increasingly environmentally efficient.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 96/53/EC to determine the dimensions and weight for certain road vehicles running within the Community.
