Adapting legislation to changing market needs as well as technological developments is necessary in order to effectively regulate the road transport sector and ensure its safety.  The proposal underlines the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, in particular carbon dioxide emissions, in order to contribute to achieving the objectives of the Transport White Play and ensuring energy efficiency. The proposal for a directive also highlights provisions aimed at improving workplace conditions, as well as protecting road users, all with a view to improving safety.  In my view, Member States should retain the right to create transport solutions that correspond to the conditions on their territory. I also support provisions highlighting the need for efficient and quality inspections to improve the energy efficiency and aerodynamics of vehicles, and to improve road safety.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Heavy goods vehicles transporting goods in Europe are needed and are fundamental for the European economy. The logistics sector is crucial and should be supported in an intelligent way. We do not need over-regulation but better regulation. We should push all actors to move as much as possible to greener ways of transport such as rail freight. However often the rail solution is not possible or is not a reliable option for the logistic sector for example because there is no guarantee when the trains will actually arrive. The 2011 White Paper on Transport provides that 30% of road freight carried over distances of more than 300 km should shift to other modes, such as rail or waterborne transport by 2030 and more than 50% by 2050, facilitated by efficient and green freight corridors. In order to meet this goal, appropriate infrastructure will need to be developed. Before such an optimum goal can be achieve, we must be pragmatic and adopt realistic solutions.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. At first reading (April 2014), the three FN MPs voted AGAINST this text, which was finally adopted by Parliament. This text amended the Commission's proposal, in particular with regard to checks and infringements. The amended text proposed a classification of offences based on their seriousness and the penalties for each of them.  The Council has partially integrated the European Parliament's proposal. The Council also does not follow the Commission with regard to the classification of offences into categories. It replaces it with an obligation on Member States to determine the regime of sanctions for violations under the directive. They are required to provide the Commission with information on the number of checks carried out in the previous two calendar years and the number of overloaded vehicles that have been detected. At second reading of the text, the entire delegation voted AGAINST this text which opens the road network to competition rather than protecting businesses and employees; offences fall under appropriate measures at the Level of the Member States.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The directive is much stronger than the original document that the Commission initiated. The right compromise was reached. This directive not only limits the size and weight of trucks on EU roads but also promotes combined road-rail or road-ship transport operations. It is very important that there will be no general EU-wide permission for the ‘gigaliners’ to circulate. The other big result is to set the framework for greener and safer truck cabins, and last but not least these new cabins will have a huge impact as we move towards the EU’s ambitious ‘vision zero’ (zero road fatalities) by 2050. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Recommendation because it is an initiative that aims to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas (CO2) emissions, adapt transport legislation to technological advances and changing market needs and facilitate intermodal transport operations, while ensuring undistorted competition and the protection of road infrastructure.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report in particular because of the changes in Article 4 of the cross-border use of 'gigaliners' (large trucks), as their intra-border use in the EU is prohibited. Despite this, we remain critical that only modest advances were made in safety, driver comfort and fuel efficiency.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it aims at a change in regulation with the aim of limiting pollution caused by trucks. In particular, it is proposed to extend the maximum length authorised by Council Directive 96/53/EC.  Technological evolution offers the possibility to add retractable or foldable devices to trucks, so that significant energy savings are achieved. That is why the maximum authorised dimensions and maximum authorised weights for those trucks operating within EU territory have been extended.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted alongside my Socialist colleagues in favour of this resolution because we have set the framework for greener and safer truck cabins. These cabins will not only reduce CO2 emissions through improved aerodynamics, but they will allow for a wider field of vision through the installation of bigger windshields, thus improving safety for drivers.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document proposes a set of derogations from Directive 96/53/EC, with the intention of setting new maximum and new maximum weights in national and international traffic for certain road vehicles in circulation within the European Union. It is necessary to know from the outthen whether the movement of vehicles of these dimensions and weights is in line with the road network of each Member State of the European Union, in particular as to the resistance, maintenance and safety of roads. Certain technical aspects of the diploma may result in improvements in mechanical and energy performance, comfort, safety and reduction of polluting gases from vehicles. That is why we voted in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. The revision of the present Directive is a sensible and welcome step towards adapting intermodal freight transport to the 21st century. That is why I was able to support this report without hesitation.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted alongside my Socialist colleagues in favour of this resolution because we have set the framework for greener and safer truck cabins. These cabins will not only reduce CO2 emissions through improved aerodynamics, but they will allow for a wider field of vision through the installation of bigger windshields, thus improving safety for drivers.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed amendments to the directive laying down the maximum dimensions and weight of heavy goods vehicles in international traffic within the European Union. The revision of these regulations in the compromise adopted has a specific objective: to adapt European legislation to the expectations of manufacturers and users of heavy goods vehicles, coaches and buses. The need to create environmentally friendly and safer structures for all road users requires the installation of equipment and body parts that ensure that the weight and dimensions of vehicles do not fall within the existing limits. In my opinion, it is right to revise these values in order to allow for these types of modifications. At the same time, the changes adopted will not allow so-called mega-heavyweights to be allowed to cross-border traffic in the EU. The presence of such vehicles on Polish roads would have a very negative impact on the state of the road infrastructure and the level of safety of other road users. Poland, as a transit country for road transport operations, would be particularly affected by the cross-border entry into service of LHV vehicles. Therefore, there is no justification for such far-reaching changes.  The current revision of the Directive on weight and dimensions sufficiently meets the requirements of reality for truck builders.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at this time of serious economic crisis from which it seems increasingly difficult to get out, an urgent priority is to lead the European Union to create jobs. Long-term investments could achieve this by financing both tangible and intangible assets, such as research and development, which are key sectors for growth. More importantly, long-term financing is a key tool for smart growth, so as to avoid new crises. The second point I would like to make is that european long-term investment funds can be a fundamental flow of income for all those who need long-term prospects, and I am thinking of municipalities and small and medium-sized enterprises.  If this system is to work, however, we must not forget the fiscal aspect. The Union should show all Member States a way to introduce tax relief, which mainly affects those who decide to invest in the long term.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Europe, along with structural reforms and fiscal consolidation, needs investments, primarily private investments that will increase the innovation and competitiveness of the European Union.  The European Commission, together with member states, is trying in various ways to stimulate investment and increase investment in projects: from union programmes through European funds to the new European Fund for Strategic Investments, and the regulation we have just supported on European long-term investment funds. This is all we need for further economic growth and development at European Union level.  European funds for long-term investments will channel additional funds from professional investors, but also local units and savers into long-term projects in the fields of research and development, energy, education and transport. SMEs will also be able to receive additional funding.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I voted against the report because this report preserves the structures and procedures that have led to the 'casino economy'. Thus, although EUR 1.6 trillion was given to rescue the banks, we still have 20 million unemployed in the European Union. The reason is that these funds were not provided by the banks to support small and medium-sized enterprises and the real economy. At the same time, while hundreds of billions were given to the countries of the Memorandum, debt eventually increased, including unemployment. In Greece, although EUR 214 billion was given to the European Investment Bank (EIB) in 2004, the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European In the end, we have thousands of people living in a humanitarian crisis and millions of unemployed. In order to invest in the real economy, therefore, the separation of commercial and investment banks must be extended by law. Let's have a new Glass-Steagall Act.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm tacaíocht a thabhairt don tuarascáil seo agus bhí díospóireacht an-mhaith againn ar maidin agus dar ndóigh rinne an tUasal Lamassoure an-jab leis an tuarascáil. Dar ndóigh, má táimid chun éalú as an gcúlú eacnamaíochta, caithfimid infheistíocht a dhéanamh go háirithe in áiteanna a bhfuil géarghá leis. Táim ag smaoineamh go háirithe ar bhonneagar d’fhuinneamh agus do thaisteal ach go háirithe agus tá sé sin luaite cheana féin. Freisin, is maith an rud é mar a dúradh ar maidin go bhfuil ár mbainc ag obair arís. Tá 70% de na daoine agus na gnóthaí atá ag lorg fiachaí á bhfáil anois agus tá siad á bhfáil ag uasráta cuíosach íseal. Chabhródh sé sin go mór linn agus má leanaimid leis an infheistíocht sin, éalóimid as an gcúlú eacnamaíochta seo agus beidh fás agus borradh san Eoraip arís.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I would like to wish the Commission success with regard to the approved package of long-term investment funds. Indeed, they are important precisely from the point of view that Europe needs new competitively sustainable growth, innovation, and, of course, it also needs to implement its cohesion policy.  It must be said that the economy is always conditioned by its cyclical development, with periods of downturn coming after periods of growth. I think that these funds can better prepare the European Union for the turbulent period that we have been through over the past decade. I therefore welcome the approval of these long-term investment funds, saying that it is only in a few years' time that we will be able to assess how important this moment was for Europe, its regions, entrepreneurs and citizens. I am glad that the Czech Minister for Regional Development, who was here today at my invitation to visit, was able to take part.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it develops a type of financial product aimed at entating large international capitals to finance the construction of large infrastructures. This report aims to give a boost to the real economy and employment when, in reality, it will only allow an increase in revenue for large construction consortia that have proved incapable of maintaining a boost to job creation. This type of funds, in the context of EFSI negotiations, is another way of rewarding international speculative capital with legal guarantees in order to invest in the infrastructure sector. Private capital has proven to be causing the current crisis and therefore cannot be part of the solution; our commitment to boosting the real economy is public investment and that is why we voted against this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report. The core idea that European long-term investment funds (ELTIFs) would support social and environmentally sustainable investments is a positive one. However, the Commission has failed to table adequate provisions in relation to this. The Commission’s proposal aims to provide investors with guaranteed security if investing long—term in infrastructure, education, the health industry or housing. The shadow rapporteurs equitable and exhaustive amendments were not included in the compromises, despite being focused on sustainable and viable alternatives.  My party are seeking improvements for the real economy and we will not endorse proposals which are designed to benefit certain vested financial interests. Moreover, related to this report is the Commission’s recent Green Paper on Long-term financing of the European Economy. I have a number of concerns with this green paper. It needs to be reiterated that the lack of bank lending is primarily because of austerity policies which eradicated credit demand as opposed to the repetitive claim that the problem is over-regulation of banks. The lack of investment is to do with austerity policies and the introduction of a capital markets union will have no tangible benefit if it is not combined with a rejection of austerity policies.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 European long-term investment funds (EMEKs) provide long-term financing to various infrastructure projects, to unlisted companies or to listed small and medium-sized enterprises, which issue share capital securities or debt securities for which there is no easily identifiable buyer. By providing funding for such projects, THEMS contribute to the financing of the real Union economy and the implementation of the EU's single policies. As the main objective of the proposed regulation is to stimulate long-term European investment in the real economy, I am voting in favour of the European Parliament's first reading. Long-term financing is a crucial tool, which can help address the lack of liquidity of small and medium-sized enterprises and put the Greek and European economy on a path of growth, high levels of employment and competitiveness

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. The aim of these long-term investment funds (ELTIFs) is to ensure smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in the European Union. These finance long-term projects to contribute to infrastructure or research projects outside banking.  The creation of this new set of rules is to be welcomed, because it protects both small and private investors and concerns the reticence of the banks. Society and the real economy benefit on both sides.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This report does not bring about the transformations expected on this essential subject for European economies. The revival of long-term investment is indeed one of the main channels of industrial recovery and job creation. European long-term investment funds are a laudable proposal and meet the financing needs of the real economy. Eligible investments, however, are not clearly defined by their impact and sectoral weight, which would respond, within the framework of a realistic and committed economic and industrial policy, to the definition of national priorities and strategies.  Although I agree with the original proposal, I abstained in view of the lack of clarity and visibility in the management of a national recovery.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This appears to extend the remit and authority of the ESMA; it is therefore consistent for a UKIP MEP to vote against it.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which provides for new rules that will enable vehicle manufacturers to develop safer and greener tractors. Since 1996, the European Parliament has been in formal agreement with the Council of the EU as early as December last year to adapt the rules in force which lay down specifications for heavy goods vehicles. They provide for rounding up the shape of cabs, which will increase the field of vision of drivers and reduce the risk of serious injury to pedestrians at low speeds. At the same time, improved aerodynamic properties of tractors will help to reduce fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I do not rule out that SMEs may eventually benefit from the establishment of these European Long-Term Investment Funds (EFTLs or ELTIFs), a new category of financial instruments that need to be created. But given the organised vagueness in Mr Lamassoure's report on the rules that are supposed to govern investments, the risk does not seem to me to be negligible and I preferred to abstain on this report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The Long-Term Investment Fund is a proposal for a new financing framework allowing private companies to invest in the real economy of the European Union and thus create jobs through growth. At present, reinvesting in productive investments is essential to boosting the economy and jobs. It is therefore essential that Europe acquires and promotes these projects, particularly within the framework of the Horizon/Europe 2020 objectives.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This supplementary report on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on European long-term investment funds lacks clarity as the forecasts put forward by Brussels to invest appear to be overvalued. It would also be better to focus on the establishment of a Small Business Act and thus give priority to SMEs in order to revive the European economy rather than disperse. Nevertheless, I abstained on this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Lamassoure report analyses Europe's long-term investment funds, a multiannual financial instrument whose aim would be to catalyse public and private investment in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Although I agree with some of the aims of the regulation, such as achieving a high employment rate, I abstained because I consider the text to be un balanced and I do not believe that, as they are structured, these funds will bring these funds closer to their objectives.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted against the report. Originally, the report was originally intended to support socially and environmentally sustainable investments, but unfortunately that line has been lost in the committee work and trilogy. The emphasis is now on private interests, including hedge funds, and public/private projects. As a result, the initial positive direction of the report has been lost.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of a new Regulation on European long-term investment funds. Long-term financing is an essential tool to be able to channel the European economy on a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in accordance with the Europe 2020 Strategy.  European long-term investment funds provide financing for different infrastructure projects, unlisted enterprises or durable listed SMEs that issue equity or debt instruments for which there is no easily identifiable buyer. By financing such projects, European long-term investment funds contribute to the financing of the Union's real economy and the implementation of its policies.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because long-term financing is a crucial tool for ensuring sustainable and stable growth in the European economy. The Europe 2020 strategy provides that high employment and competitiveness contribute to the creation of an economy in a way that is less exposed to systemic risk and more resilient. European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIFs) provide financing for a wide range of long-term infrastructure projects, OTC enterprises or listed small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) issuing equity or debt investment vehicles. Thus, the main objective of this Regulation is to promote Europe's long-term investment in the real economy. Long-term investments in projects, enterprises and infrastructure in third countries can also provide the capital of eltifs and thus benefit the European economy. Such investments should therefore be allowed. European long-term investment funds can ensure a stable flow of income for pension administrators, insurance companies, funds, municipalities and other entities with permanent and recurring liabilities and long-term returns in well-regulated structures.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ELIF is designed to expand the range of aid for businesses and to help projects in need of long-term capital. The proposal respects the geographical allocation of funds. The deal with the Council is not perfect, but it is acceptable.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. The purpose of this regulation is to create a new financial instrument, the ELTIF. Existing instruments are ill-suited to long-term savings. They are subject to prudential standards, the "prospectus" directive and non-professional investors are creditors of a strengthened advisory obligation. Making Europe a must-see financial centre can have advantages for France. Mediation would allow investors to diversify their portfolios and companies to access more sources of financing. I abstained on this text.  Indeed, caution is required for any new financial instrument. In addition, there is some uncertainty surrounding some investment rules. However, I welcome the fact that these instruments are intended for the long-term financing of SMEs that are the engine of our economy. But I criticise the fact that while the purpose of ELTIF is to finance long-term projects, they are only obliged to invest up to 70% in such projects. For the same reason, I have reservations about the possibility of an early exit. In addition, the fund may deviate from diversification obligations under fairly complex rules.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The core idea that European long-term investment funds (ELTIFs) would support social and environmentally sustainable investments is a positive one. However, the Commission have failed to table adequate provisions in relation to this. The Commission’s proposal aims to provide investors with guaranteed security if investing long term in infrastructure, education, health industry or housing. The shadow rapporteurs equitable and exhaustive amendments were not included in the compromises, despite being focused on sustainable and viable alternatives.  My party are seeking improvements for the real economy and we will not endorse proposals which are designed to benefit certain vested financial interests. Moreover, related to this report is the Commission’s recent Green Paper on Long-term financing of the European Economy.  I have a number of concerns with this green paper. It needs to be reiterated that the lack of bank lending is primarily because of austerity policies which eradicated credit demand as opposed to the repetitive claim that the problem is over-regulation of banks. The lack of investment is to do with austerity policies and the introduction of a capital markets union will have no tangible benefit if it is not combined with a rejection of austerity policies.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this supplementary report because I do think that we need a regulation in order to boost European long-term investments in the real economy.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The use of European long-term investment funds is one of the main factors stimulating sustainable growth in the European economy and also creates the prerequisites for the construction of the economy of the future in a manner more resilient to the risks of future economic and financial crises. The aim of this Regulation is to boost long-term investment in the real economy.  I support the European Parliament's proposal for a regulation for the use of European long-term investment funds in particular because of those arguments, and because such regulation at Union level can avoid the risk of divergent measures at national level which may cause distortions of competition caused by the various investment protection measures.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on European long-term investment funds. It is undeniable that this will encourage investors to invest in long-term projects. We desperately need it in Europe. This will enable, together with Jean-Claude Juncker's Commission's investment plan, to redress the rate of investment in the Union and thus boost growth and jobs in Europe. I congratulate my colleague Alain Lamassoure on this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the supplementary report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European long-term investment funds. I believe that long-term financing can be an important instrument for helping the European economy to grow and for stimulating competitiveness and employment.  Furthermore, I believe it is very important that these funds are placed in the context of the Europe 2020 strategy to promote smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Progress in achieving the objectives of this strategy could then make more capital available.  I therefore hope that european funds in the long term will make an important contribution to the financing of the Union's real economy and to the implementation of its policies.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The core idea that European long-term investment funds (ELTIFs) would support social and environmentally sustainable investments is a positive one. However, the Commission has failed to table adequate provisions in relation to this. The Commission’s proposal aims to provide investors with guaranteed security if investing long-term in infrastructure, education, the health industry or housing. The shadow rapporteursʼ equitable and exhaustive amendments were not included in the compromises, despite being focused on sustainable and viable alternatives.  My party are seeking improvements for the real economy and we will not endorse proposals which are designed to benefit certain vested financial interests. Moreover, related to this report is the Commission’s recent Green Paper on Long-term financing of the European Economy.  I have a number of concerns with this green paper. It needs to be reiterated that the lack of bank lending is primarily because of austerity policies which eradicated credit demand as opposed to the repetitive claim that the problem is over-regulation of banks. The lack of investment is to do with austerity policies and the introduction of a capital markets union will have no tangible benefit if it is not combined with a rejection of austerity policies.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the text as negotiated by Parliament and I voted in favour. Europe needs smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The focus of this regulation is to boost European long-term investments (ELTIF) in the real economy. Long-term finance is one of the vehicles to attain this aim through infrastructure projects, machinery and equipment, education and research results. ELTIF investors will have to be ready and able to make a long—term commitment, which by its very nature does not offer quick returns, but growth in the long-run. Parliament’s negotiators ensured that a number of provisions have been inserted in the draft proposal to ensure that long-term funds are really beneficial to the EUʼs economy and growth, they are not invested in speculative assets and that any retail investors in them are properly informed and protected.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 European long-term investment funds (ELTIF) provide long-term financing for infrastructure projects, un listed companies or listed small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that issue debt instruments for which there is no easily identifiable buyer. This proposal for a regulation could really be an opportunity to lay the foundations for giving a strong boost to the economy, but the text, as it has been drawn up, does not seem to meet real needs. The risk is that the main beneficiaries will be large infrastructure projects and multinational groups, while SMEs that do not have the opportunity to raise finance on the capital markets will actually be overlooked. These make up a major part of the Union's real economy, which is in danger of being second to speculative interests.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report. It is indeed a new financial instrument, on which we have no setbacks at the moment.  Of course, these funds are mainly focused on financing SMEs, which is a very good thing. They also favour long-term investment over speculative products, which is also very positive. However, some investment rules remain unclear: while the purpose of ELTTTS is to finance long-term projects, investors are only required to invest up to 70%; the remaining 30% may therefore be akin to liquidity, other shorter-term projects or alternative investments. On the other hand, I remain dubious about the possibility of an early exit provided by exemptions, even though the principle of the fund is that the investor is engaged until the project has come to an end.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competitiveness and growth, cornerstones of the Junker plan and ECB action, contrast with a European scenario characterised by an extremely fragmented market linked to national logic. More than a liquidity problem, there is a problem of the lack of guarantees for private investors who, for this reason too, have little interest in investing in Europe and, above all, in making long-term investments. It is necessary to put into practice the banking and economic union which, together with political union, would fully realise the European Union project and contribute to the 'loyalty' of global liquidity. In this respect, the contribution of instruments such as ELTIF investment funds, which can be used by both public and private investors and which can remove obstacles to investment, would be positive, allowing investors to count on a stable return. This instrument would also make it possible to invest in SMEs, opening up this sector – which has been severely affected by the economic crisis – to foreign investment. The report is pushing in this direction, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure, having analysed that long-term financing is a key activation tool for channelling the European economy on a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, and of high employment and competitiveness by proposing an economy less exposed to risks.  The central objective of this Regulation is to stimulate long-term European investment in the real economy (infrastructure, intellectual property, ships, equipment, machinery, aircraft or rolling stock and real estate). ELTIFs are the first step towards the creation of an integrated internal market for the raising of capital that can be channelled towards long-term investment in the European economy.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure because I believe that European long-term investment funds are a key tool for an intelligent growth path, so as to avoid new crises. I agree with the intention to make these funds a revenue stream for all those who need long-term prospects, such as municipalities or small and medium-sized enterprises. If we want this system to work, however, we must not forget the fiscal aspect: in my opinion, the Eu ropean Union should show all Member States a way of introducing relief for those who decide to invest in the long term.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation will increase the capital available for long—term investment in the economy of the European Union through a new form of fund vehicle to stimulate growth and generate more jobs. The European Long—term Investment Funds will channel funds for long-term projects that should drive growth in the long-run and generate durable, long-term employment. This regulation will create a regulatory framework for the vehicle to ensure that such funds are subject to consistent rules across the EU. I have thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for an ELTIF regulation aims to mobilise and channel, through alternative investment funds, such as hedge funds, private capital towards long-term investments in the real economy. In particular, ELTIFs are expected to invest at least 70% of the capital in financial instruments of un listed companies and listed SMEs, in shares or shares of other funds and in real assets worth more than TEN million euros such as infrastructure, real estate, ships and aircraft. They are also designed as a priority instrument for the implementation of the Juncker Plan and for EIB projects.  I vote against the many critical issues related to the design of these funds and doubts about their real economic and social usefulness. Despite being presented as a long-term financing instrument to support the real economy, ELTIFs are nevertheless allowed to invest in unproductive real assets such as real estate, ships and aircraft as well as in public infrastructure, including transport infrastructure such as roads, airports, public transport, but also energy, water or waste management, industrial plants, public housing.  In this way, the regulation facilitates access for hedge funds to the financing of the commons and, in fact, opens the way to privatisation.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The feeling of recovery that Europe is experiencing is struggling to mature and strengthen to the point of generating the conditions to start producing wealth and new jobs, reversing the trend of recent years. Certainly, among the factors that have led to the worsening of the crisis, turning it into a social crisis, the attitude of the banks, which have closed in on their selfishness, has played a decisive role, stifling a system of itself devoid of oxygen. Even today, it is still difficult to see a reversal of the trend in this direction.  From this point of view, the initiatives of the European institutions are becoming essential, in order to put in place instruments to support and finance the growth and development of companies and companies, putting them in a position to obtain the necessary capital. Long-term investment funds are all the more important because they impact high-risk projects that – just as ambitious – need a long time to make a profit. It will be important to specify Parliament's monitoring role, especially in relation to the selection of projects, giving priority to those potentially most capable of achieving effects on the labour market and on the achievement of the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report dealing with European Long-term investment Funds since this is a proposal for a new type of collective investment framework allowing investors to put money into companies and projects that need long-term capital. ELTIFs are designed to increase the amount of non-bank finance available for companies investing in the real economy of the European Union. I supported this agreement particularly since it attempts to ensure that investments mainly flow into the EU whilst making sure that there will be full transparency on the geographical location of the funds.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that long-term financing is an important tool for the European economy to move towards sustainable, smart and inclusive growth, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, for better competitiveness and employment and for building tomorrow's economy, so as to be less prone to systemic risks and more resilient. European Long-Term Investment Funds (EITLs) provide financing to a diverse range of infrastructure projects, unlisted companies or long-traded small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that issue equity and debt instruments for which there is no easy-to-identify buyer. That is why I believe that, by providing funding for such projects, the ELTIF contributes to the financing of the real economy and to the implementation of Union policies.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative proposal aims to increase the pool of capital available for long-term investments in the real economy of the European Union. To this end, the text creates a regulatory framework for a new form of financing vehicle, European long-term investment funds, in order to subject these funds to coherent EU-wide rules and allow investors to identify them throughout the UNION.  Considering that this proposal will facilitate the flow of capital to the real economy, in line with the European objectives for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Contrary to popular belief at present, the investment deficit in Europe is not new. Introduced in 2013, this legislation on European long-term investment funds is one of the instruments building the solution for a revival of investment in Europe and is consistent with the Juncker Plan. With this text, the European Union is developing a common regulatory framework that is easily identifiable for investors in order to ensure that the level of investment returns to its pre-crisis level.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Long-term financing, European long-term investment funds, can play an important role in achieving the Europe 2020 strategy's goals of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, promoting a high level of employment and strengthening competitiveness.  European long-term investment funds finance infrastructure projects, unlisted companies or listed small and medium-sized enterprises in a durable manner that do not have an easily defined buyer for their issued equity instruments or debt instruments. In the absence of common EU legislation, divergent measures may be taken at national level and divergent national requirements may lead to distortions of competition, different levels of investor protection, increased legal uncertainty and a loss of investor confidence. The smooth functioning of the internal market and the high level of investor protection call for the need for uniform EU rules.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Union needs structuring and innovative investments in order to return to sustainable growth. The adoption of this report on the creation of the European Long-Term Investment Fund is moving in the right direction, and will increase the long-term financing options for projects in research, innovation, infrastructure, or energy. This fund will be, in particular, one of the tools of the Commission's investment plan and a further step towards the union of markets and capital, which aims, among other things, to facilitate the financing of European SMEs.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The rapporteur's text does not bring about the transformations expected for a key issue for European economies. The revival of long-term investment is indeed one of the main channels of industrial recovery and job creation. European long-term investment funds are therefore a laudable proposal and meet the financing needs of the real economy. However, it appears that eligible investments are not clearly defined by their impact and sectoral weight, which would respond, within the framework of a realistic and committed economic and industrial policy, to the definition of national priorities and strategies.  Despite the good initial proposal, I abstained in view of the lack of clarity and visibility in the management of a national recovery.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of the proposal is to try and boost non-bank investment in the real economy across Europe. This was the first initiative of the capital markets union before it became the CMU (the ELTIF negotiations began in the previous mandate). I am generally happy with the political outcome, although whether there will be uptake for these funds will have to be seen.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this directive, the final outcome of the (trilogue) negotiations between the Commission, Parliament and the Council. The idea of channeling dispersed funds into investments of a lasting nature and of general interest is not in itself harmful, on the contrary. But this channeling should be carried out with alternative criteria: through independent professional management, under the public competition and management, with criteria that combine the saving purpose and the activity in which it is invested, with a guaranteeing public regulation and, of course, open to the improvement of these regulations and guarantees, and not putting floor cutters to the possibility of Member States deepening and advancing this regulation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the supplementary report, as these investment methods are nothing more than another way of serving large capital in its efforts to overcome national state obstacles and exploit the non-haves as well as the weaker economic classes.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this diploma, as this regulation leads to an increase in European long-term investment in the real economy, and this funding is "a key tool for enabling the European economy to enter a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth" (§1). Similarly, the European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) could be used for the financing of SME projects and for the leverage of funds by these companies with the private financial sector, in line with what have been the policies pursued for the achievement of the Europe 2020 SME strategy objectives (COSME, etc.), with the ultimate aim of contributing to the financing of the Real Economy of the Union.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Long-term financing is a key tool to enable the European economy to enter a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, high employment and competitiveness for building a future economy in a way that is less prone to systemic and more resilient risks.  The European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) provide the financing of various infrastructure projects, non-listed companies or small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) quoted for a long duration that issue equity or debt instruments for which there is no easily identifiable buyer. By providing funding for these projects, ELTIF contribute to the financing of the Real Economy of the Union and to the implementation of its policies. Funding projects such as transport infrastructure, sustainable energy production or distribution, social infrastructure (housing or hospitals), implementation of new technologies and systems that reduce resource and energy consumption, or continued growth of SMEs, may be scarce. ELTIF can play a key role in this area and can also mobilise capital by attracting investors from third countries.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation because its purpose is to boost long-term European investment in the real economy by mobilising and channelling private savings, in line with the Union's objective of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. This REGULATION on FILPEs can be an important complement to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (ESI), which is to be conceived as a permanent countercyclical instrument of the European Union, and must therefore be given legal personality and indefinite duration, so that it can issue debt securities and reinvest its profits. THEREFORE, EIE must be a lever to lead investments where they are most needed, and this task will remain relevant when the financial and economic crisis is overcome. THE EIE should concentrate investment in areas where economic growth and the employment rate fall suddenly. Hence, the so-called Investment Plan for Europe should not be a conjunctural but structural intervention. I also think it is important that EIE can issue government debt securities with the inclusion of a retail tranche for acquisition by citizens.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The rhetoric of more or less intelligent growth of innovation and investment does not hide the EU's persistence in a set of policies that block the implementation of any of these factors. The crisis of capitalism and its expression in the EU – marked by an over-accumulation of capital and the confirmation of the law of low profit rate - are still developing and deepening. In this particular case, if the market does not work, if the agents do not invest, then we should not expect them to be market instruments to solve the problem. Look at the results of the ECB's long-term bank refinancing operations. This instrument is more of the same. It doesn't even innovate. It does not even contain a clause in terms of guaranteeing the social and labour rights of the jobs that will be financed It does not contain any environmental guarantee.  As history teaches us, the recessive cycle will only be broken with new policies based on an ambitious public investment program that will once again give states their referential role in the economy and in building growth and development strategies.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The European economy must become more resilient but also less susceptible to systemic risks. European long-term investment funds contribute to the financing of the European Union's real economy and to the more effective implementation of its policies. The economic and financial crisis has clearly shown how difficult it can be to obtain funding for transport infrastructure, production or renewable projects. Uniform rules need to be adopted to ensure that the EDIF act as a product with a single and stable profile throughout the European Union.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining on the regulation governing European long-term investment funds. I agree with some of the aims of the regulation ( including achieving a high rate of employment) but I am very critical of the fact that the current European Commission is able to draw positive results from this type of operation in terms of wealth creation and/or development. Some observers have, however, pointed out that instruments that can deliver shorter-term results should be preferred.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the supplementary report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European long-term investment funds, because these investment methods are nothing more than another way of serving large capital in its efforts to overcome national state obstacles and exploit the non-haves as well as the weaker economic classes.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – The idea behind the European Long-term Investment Funds was to finance a new financial vehicle that will enable private investments to be channelled into the European economy. Long-term finance is a crucial tool for putting the European economy on the right path of sustainable growth in accordance with the Europe 2020 Strategy to promote high employment and competitiveness. I am very satisfied with the outcome of our Group’s efforts to avoid speculation and tax havens and to ensure that investments take into account the Europe 2020 Strategy on employment and social targets. This report will have a very productive result because it targets the real economy of European Union countries. Moreover, the report guarantees the possibility for small investors to participate in the funds with the necessary protection, such as the early ticket and the early redemption clause. I therefore supported the conclusion of this agreement in the plenary session.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. 2012 Long-term financing is undoubtedly an essential tool to be able to channel the European economy into a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in accordance with the Horizon 2020 Strategy, to ensure a high level of employment and to maintain and improve our competitiveness at the international level. Europe, especially some countries in the south of the continent, faces the problem of lack of funding, where European long-term investment funds can play a very important role in providing funding for infrastructure projects for unlisted companies or SMEs. We must not forget that by financing the projects of these companies we are helping to finance the real EU economy and therefore helping to create jobs.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With European long-term investment funds we have created a new tool made available to the EU to stimulate growth. These funds will help SMEs, individual and professional investors and insurance companies to invest in infrastructure, equipment, machinery, research and education projects and, in doing so, will provide chain benefits for the entire EU economy.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution with the conviction, however, that Parliament must continue to scrutinise this project so that the funds can really reach the citizens effectively without excessive red tape.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I congratulate Mr Lamassoure on the important adoption of the report on the European Investment Fund. For a few weeks now, Europe has finally embarked on a new path, that of growth and a new focus on the real economy. The European Investment Fund is only a first step towards a full recovery, but it is essential that all European institutions – starting with the Council and the contribution of individual Member States – do everything possible to give concrete form to the Juncker Plan and the new regulatory framework provided for by the Fund.  The European Parliament must continue to ensure that the new Plan is based on the objectives of genuine modernisation, making Europe attractive to investors and reactivating the productive and industrial capacities of our continent.  As you know, Mr President, many active sectors of research and the knowledge economy have raised concerns about the partial financing of the new Fund with a significant share coming from the Horizon 2020 programme and the Instrument for Connecting Europe. It would at least be desirable to ensure that these funds, although diverted from the multiannual budgetary commitment of such important programmes, could at least maintain a direct allocation – within the framework of the new investment plan projects – to the renewal of infrastructures essential for European competitiveness and research.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the report on the Long-Term European Investment Funds "ELTIF", which aim to contribute to the financing of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, and to finance the needs of the infrastructure project in Europe until 2020, because I am convinced that at the moment the EU needs innovative financial instruments that will foster growth and the creation of quality jobs , to put an end to the precariousness of entire generations of late. The crisis has highlighted the weakness of traditional sources of long-term financing, including insurance and pension funds. The creation of this new investment vehicle therefore aims to encourage professional investors (enterprises, municipalities, insurance) to invest in assets such as un listed companies, which require long-term capital, some listed SMEs, intellectual property assets. I particularly welcome the position strenuously defended by the European Parliament, which has fought for a compromise with the Council to ensure that ELTIFs contribute to the EU's real economy, that they are able to offer repayment rights under certain conditions, that they operate transparently and that they provide adequate information to investors.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European long-term investment funds because ELTIF can play a vital role in channelling savings towards long-term investments projects, in particular infrastructure, and the link with investments under Horizon 2020 is a crucial one. Most importantly, ELTIF should target funds towards projects to create jobs and growth. This will only be possible if we develop the right tools to stimulate market financing of the European economy. One of the priorities of the Capital Market Union in this respect is the revitalisation of the securitisation market. However, it must be clear that full standardisation, transparency, adequate capital requirements and clear information to investors on the credit risk should be key principles of all new legislation in this field. I congratulate the rapporteur and the three institutions who showed political will on all sides to find a solution on this file. I hope the current President in Council will show the same will for Money Market Funds.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this project of European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF). These funds may seem useful, as they are intended to finance the real economy, through long-term infrastructure.  Nevertheless, the exclusion of Member States in the management of these funds is harmful because it gives the European Union all the power to choose the beneficiaries of these funds. Therefore, it is illusory to think that the Eurocrats will stimulate the real economy. Large multinationals will be given the lion's share and small businesses will once again be defrauded.  Finally, ELTITs risk allowing the takeover of SMEs by indelicate investors, including allowing them to bypass the regulations on thresholds.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Directive, the final outcome of the (trilogue) negotiations between the Commission, Parliament and the Council. The idea of channeling dispersed funds into investments of a lasting nature and of general interest is not in itself harmful, on the contrary. But this channeling should be carried out with alternative criteria: through independent professional management, under the public competition and management, with criteria that combine the saving purpose and the activity in which it is invested, with a guaranteeing public regulation and, of course, open to the improvement of these regulations and guarantees, and not putting floor cutters to the possibility of Member States deepening and advancing this regulation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which contains a proposal for a new type of collective investment framework. This will allow investors to put their money into companies and projects that need long-term capital. These long-term investment funds are designed to increase the amount of non-bank finance available for companies investing in the real economy of the European Union and offer investors more opportunities and the necessary protection to participate in investment schemes in Europe, thereby making more investment capital available.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this because I see it as a crucial tool to put the EU economy on a sustainable growth path again. For me it is really important to see that European Long-term Investment Funds (ELTIFs) will provide finance for various projects and SMEs.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because this agreement between Parliament and Council signals the evolution of alternative forms of financing the real economy in the EU. The development of European long-term investment funds will help to provide private investors with steady and regular returns. In Europe our capital markets are not evenly developed and it is our task to ensure that capital markets can play a key role in the provision of long-term, sustainable and growth-enhancing finance for our future.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ European long-term investment funds will provide a useful tool in boosting Europe’s economy and I therefore voted for this report.  Importantly, the legislation specifically recognises the importance of investments which have a social benefit, such as education.  It is to be hoped that the ELTIFs are used for progressive purposes – and thereby undermine arguments that progressive politics amounts to a ‘something for nothing’ culture.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this directive, the final outcome of the (trilogue) negotiations between the Commission, Parliament and the Council. The idea of channeling dispersed funds into investments of a lasting nature and of general interest is not in itself harmful, on the contrary. But this channeling should be carried out with alternative criteria: through independent professional management, under the public competition and management, with criteria that combine the saving purpose and the activity in which it is invested, with a guaranteeing public regulation and, of course, open to the improvement of these regulations and guarantees, and not putting floor cutters to the possibility of Member States deepening and advancing this regulation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I supported the Resolution on European Funds for Long-Term Investments, as this is the first step in channelling the necessary funds into long-term investments in the real economy.  A single capital market needs to be created for a thriving European economy.  These financial instruments create an investment framework that crosses national borders. They should be open and easily accessible and create synergies with all other investment instruments such as the Juncker Plan, cohesion policy, public and private investment to stimulate the economic activities of SMEs, deliver economic growth and jobs.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. The rapporteur's text does not bring about the transformations expected for a key issue for European economies. Long-term investments are sorely lacking in our economy, even as they allow for economic recovery and industrial recovery. Unlocking funds for this purpose meets a real need for financing in the real economy. But the text presented does not specify what investments will be made, or what the overall economic strategy would be at the national level.  Despite the good initial proposal, the lack of vision and clarity of this text led me to abstain.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation because it aims to boost long-term European investment in the real economy. It is therefore a question of mobilizing and channeling capital towards such projects, in line with the Union's objective of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. FilPE, because of its portfolio profile and its orientation towards long-term asset categories, are designed to channel private savings into the European economy. FILPEs are also designed as investment vehicles through which the Group of the European Investment Bank (EI) can channel its financing from European infrastructures or SMEs. Therefore, such investments should not be prevented. On the contrary, this FILPE Regulation can be an important complement to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE). I think it is important to stress that the EIE must be conceived as a permanent instrument of an anti-cyclical nature of the European Union, so it must be characteried by legal personality and indefinite duration. I am concerned that so far there have been no expressions of interest in participating in this financial instrument by the Member States.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Alain Lamassoure's report establishing a regulation to increase the capital available for long-term investments in the European economy. These investments must necessarily benefit the European economy and growth and not fuel speculation, while providing comprehensive protection and information to investors. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on European long-term investment funds. Long-term financing is essential to enable the European economy to take the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. European long-term investment funds (ELTIF) provide long-term financing for various projects. ElTIFS thus contribute to the financing of the real economy and to the implementation of eu policies.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Europe needs strong and pro-competitive regulation for long-term investment funds so that private investors have the incentive to invest in long-term infrastructure projects. The proposal put forward here provides a good framework for a regulated introduction of long-term, regulated investments, framework conditions that are important for the development of European infrastructure measures and can make a significant contribution to economic recovery. That is why I support the proposal that has been tabled.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this regulation as I believe it will help put the European economy on a path of sustainable, smart and inclusive growth. The creation of European long-term investment funds (ELTIFs) will enable long-term finance to be provided to various infrastructure projects and companies, acting as a driver for growth by delivering infrastructure, machinery, education and research results. It will also ensure that funds are subject to consistent rules across the EU, so that a secure and equal standard is implemented in all Member States.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal as these funds could drive growth in the long-run by delivering infrastructure, intellectual property and research results, and by fostering the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Alain Lamassoure as it aims to stimulate long-term European investment in the real economy. I am convinced that the European Union must steer its economy towards an intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth path in order to promote employment and competitiveness.  We must now seriously reverse this trend, encourage and encourage the creation of new jobs, especially for our young people, attract new capital and support companies in order to create productive and effective investment.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of setting up a European long-term investment fund, for which Alain LAMASSOURE was rapporteur. This fund follows the strategy put in place by former Internal Market and Financial Services Commissioner Michel BARNIER to give the European economy the means to finance itself to return to growth.  The agreement is an excellent signal to the economic community as discussions continue on the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which is expected to finance the equivalent of EUR 315 billion in investment projects in Europe known as the Juncker Plan.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The rapporteur's text does not bring about the transformations expected for a key issue for European economies. The revival of long-term investment is indeed one of the main channels of industrial recovery and job creation. European long-term investment funds are therefore a laudable proposal and meet the financing needs of the real economy.  However, it appears that eligible investments are not clearly defined by their impact and sectoral weight, which would respond, within the framework of a realistic and committed economic and industrial policy, to the definition of national priorities and strategies.  Despite the good initial proposal, I abstained in view of the lack of clarity and visibility in the management of a national recovery.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it develops a type of financial product that does not meet the needs of Europe's workers, but rather to accompany the privatization processes of public management and infrastructure. In the context of EFSI's negotiation, these funds are another way to reward international speculative capital with legal guarantees in order to invest in sectors such as transport. Private capital has proven to be causing the current crisis and therefore cannot be part of the solution; our commitment to boosting the real economy is public investment and that is why we voted against this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. The solution to the crisis is not to constantly create funds, redistribute money from one to the other, or constantly intervene in the economy. On the contrary, the redistribution rate needs to be reduced, and the money managed by politicians and the institutions affected by them must be as little as possible.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Investment funds are a big and good tool for economic development. I supported both the Commission's amendment and the general vote in favour. The resolution is legislative in nature.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain. Some investment rules remain too vague to date and do not allow for certainty. Moreover, given the current economic situation, it seems surprising that the Commission can achieve positive results in terms of job creation or development. This text remains too vague for an informed pronouncer.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution. Long-term finance is a crucial enabling tool for putting the European economy on a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in accordance with the Europe 2020 strategy, high employment, and competitiveness for building tomorrow’s economy in a way that is less prone to systemic risks and is more resilient. European long-term investment funds (ELTIFs) provide finance to various infrastructure projects, unlisted companies, or listed small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) of lasting duration that issue equity or debt instruments for which there is no readily identifiable buyer. By providing finance to such projects, ELTIFs contribute to the financing of the Union’s real economy and the implementation of its policies.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the regulation on European long-term investment funds because it will be able to increase the capital available for long-term investment in the EU economy.  The regulation will create a rule structure with the aim of ensuring that long-term funds can really contribute to the growth of the economy, to the harmonisation of operating conditions for all "players" in the investment markets of funds and that they are not invested in speculative assets.  In addition, the proposal contains rules on eligible investment policies, such as rules on eligible investments, composition and diversification of portfolios, conflicts of interest, concentration and lending of money.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is to be hoped that the European Union will work more effectively with the aim of steering its economy towards smart, sustainable, inclusive growth that promotes employment and competitiveness. I have chosen to support the Lamassoure report because, on the basis of the principle that European long-term investment funds ensure greater mobilisation of capital markets, it proposes measures to stimulate its implementation.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Measures must be taken from the EU to ensure access to business credit in Europe so that they can deal strongly with the exit from crises and the expansion of their business. In this regard, my support for the proposal on European long-term investment funds, designed to benefit the real economy and society by channeling long-term non-bank funds to projects to provide infrastructure, intellectual property or research results.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the proposal on European Long-term Investment Funds (ELTIF), as these provide permanent funding for a wide range of infrastructure projects, thus contributing to the financing of the Union's real economy and the implementation of its policies. In addition, ELTIF will reduce investor information deficits and thus increase investor confidence. However, the blanket ban on the use of derivatives is not in the interests of investor protection.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because long-term financing is a crucial tool for ensuring that the European economy grows, is smart, competitive and has a faster job creation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Long-term financing is essential to support the European real economy. In June 2013, the Commission published a legislative proposal for the introduction of a framework for collective investments that would allow investors to put money into companies and projects requiring long-term capital. These European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) provide financing for various long-term infrastructure projects, unlisted companies and SMEs, which issue equity or debt instruments for which there is no easily identifiable buyer.  But attempts to direct these investments towards sustainable social and environmental investments have not been taken into account. In addition, the priority for investment is public-private partnerships and privatization. Thus this regulation fails completely to achieve the necessary objectives. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Long-term financing is a key tool for enabling the European economy to enter a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, high employment and competitiveness for building a future economy in a way that is less prone to systemic and more resilient risks. The European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) provide the financing of various infrastructure projects, non-listed companies or small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) quoted for a long duration that issue equity or debt instruments for which there is no easily identifiable buyer. By providing funding for these projects, ELTIF contribute to the financing of the Real Economy of the Union and to the implementation of its policies. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report confirmed that the proposed regulation will boost European long-term investments in the real economy. The current financial crisis has demonstrated that complementing bank financing with more diverse sources of financing may help narrow any gaps in financing. These long-term investments in projects, undertakings and infrastructure will benefit the EU economy. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report as such investments should be facilitated in order to be implemented as quickly as possible.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of provisions to address the reluctance of banks to lend to SMEs and certain research projects. SMEs are the engine of our European economy. They represent 99% of companies and employ more than 100 million Europeans. They need financing in order to remain competitive and innovative.  Through the creation of European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF), non-bank-origin funds will be used directly for the real economy, contributing to long-term projects, including infrastructure, intellectual property or research.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Long-term Investment Funds (ELTIFs) is a proposal for a new type of collective investment framework allowing investors to put money into companies and projects that need long-term capital. ELTIFs are designed to increase the amount of non-bank finance available for companies investing in the real economy of the European Union. I fully supported the outcome of the negotiations, which in my opinion will ensure that investments flow in the main into the EU.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an intelligent long-term private investment instrument with a legal basis to cross borders within the EU. It should be helpful for infrastructure and social projects, but investors should be careful not to put all their money into an ELTIF: they will not be able to get it back for quite a while. These are really long—term instruments, investing in companies that are themselves not listed, so not liquid.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 European long-term investment funds contribute to the long-term financing of the European economy, in particular for long-term infrastructure projects, unlisted companies or listed small and medium-sized enterprises, covering an area where bank financing has not always proved possible or fortunate.  They can also provide income to investors who prefer a lower but safe long-term return, such as pension payers, insurers, foundations and municipalities. European long-term investment funds can therefore contribute to meeting a demand that has not been sufficiently satisfied on the financial market as a complement to the banking system. Their single EU regulations can be an important step towards completion of the Banking Union. All this justified my vote in favour.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. Financial instruments that redirect savings to the real economy and long-term projects should be encouraged, not speculation. ELTIF have a card to play in this regard. These funds are based on long-term investments in SMEs, with no possibility of a pre-term exit. So the principle is good.  However, in its terms, the proposed regulation authorizes up to 30% of other investments and gives managers the opportunity to plan early exit from the fund. Second, these funds can be used as a screen for creeping equity investments, without statements of thresholds. Finally, there is no provision for investment to target European countries. For all these reasons, it is necessary to remain attentive to what will become of these instruments and to abstain on the report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has focused its political activity on fostering economic growth as well as on job creation, implementing concrete measures to boost investment in the European Union. I am voting in favour of this report to boost the long-term investments that should be made at European level, in particular that they contribute decisively to deepening the European single market and trans-European energy, transport or telecommunications networks. I also believe that the European Union should make a greater typology of investment funds available to support start-ups, thereby diversifying their financing opportunities which should be spent more than by the traditional bank lending granted by the financial system entities.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. I abstained on this supplementary report on the European Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on European long-term investment funds on the grounds that the forecasts put forward by Brussels seem to me to be overvalued. Again, the European Union lacks clarity.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as I believe that European Long-term Investment Funds will help to increase the amount of non-bank finance available for companies investing in the real economy in the European Union.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We support this proposal for a regulation, as we believe that long-term financing is a key activation tool for channelling the European economy on a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, as provided for in the Europe 2020 strategy. Ways must be found to give the European economy less risky and more resilient instruments: European long-term investment funds (ELTIF) will be able to have this objective, namely to provide funding for infrastructure projects of various kinds, unsized companies or long-listed small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which issue representative equity instruments or debt instruments for which there is no readily identifiable buyer. With this proposal, we therefore intend to stimulate all European long-term investments, whether they are intended for projects, businesses or infrastructures in third countries as well.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I obviously voted for this report because it proposes to boost long-term investment in the real economy through European long-term investment funds. The return of jobs in Europe requires these strategic investments and smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
