text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative proposal establishes a new regulatory framework to create Long-Term European Investment Funds (ELTIFs) to improve the real economy and society by channelling non-bank funds towards long-term projects. Long-term financing is a key activation tool to channel the European economy on a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, as well as high employment and competitiveness, to give the economy of the future a structure less exposed to systemic and more resilient risks. In this regard, I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Lamassoure's report because I believe it is essential to guarantee the real European economy long-term funding, given that funding is currently scarce and, even where it is, excessively focused on short-term objectives.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report on European long-term investment funds.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I believe that, despite slight doubts about one or the other form of the proposal on European Long-Term Investment Funds, the proposal as a whole is likely to provide impetus for long-term, regulated investment in the European economy. In particular, I hope that the proposal will also contribute to the economic recovery of the Union. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for long-term investment funds. Capital raising and directing to the real economy will help finance the growth of the EU economy and increase employment and competitiveness. In order to mitigate risks, these investments need to be diversified.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. In particular, it is necessary to ensure that the EU operates effectively in the single market for long-term investment vehicles. The Single Market will strengthen Europe's competitiveness and stimulate investment in order to create new jobs. It should be noted that a stable cross-border mechanism will stimulate long-term investment. European Long-Term Investment Funds will provide long-term and sufficient funding. This type of investment will ensure greater confidence, protection and choice for investors and businesses. In addition, investors will be encouraged to assume fixed asset liabilities. Another important aspect is that long-term investments also provide a stable and projected return to businesses and contribute to job creation.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that long-term financing is a key activation tool for channelling the European economy on a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, as well as high employment and competitiveness, to give the economy of the future a structure less exposed to systemic and more resilient risks. Given that long-term European investment funds provide funding for infrastructure projects of various kinds, un listed companies or long-listed small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that issue representative equity instruments or debt instruments for which there is no readily identifiable buyer. Given that by financing these projects, the ELTIFs contribute to the financing of the Union's real economy and to the implementation of its policies. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the opening of trilogue negotiations to speed up the process of establishing the EU Long—term Investment Funds (ELTIFs). After the banking union, which will balance the asymmetries of lending conditions across the euro area and bring stability to the banking system, the next logical step was to start consolidating the capital union. This will mean being able to offer a stable flow of investment capital for long—term growth projects, helping to achieve sustainable growth prospects for the EU. ELTIFs are definitely the first fundamental block, which will allow the still underdeveloped European equity financing model to be built and consolidated in order to move away from the exclusive lending model. I will keep supporting all proposals in this direction, while keeping an eye on consumer protection and fair competition.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ This agreement provides another tool in the fight to boost investment and growth in Europe. European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIFs) will make it easier for long-term projects and businesses wishing to expand with the access funds they need to do so. As an element in the Capital Markets Union, it will also contribute to the EU investment plan. ELTIFs will serve as a link between all types of investors willing to invest in projects and companies that need long-term. In this form, ELTIFs could also serve as an additional driver in public or public-private investments. In particular, I support a regulation strengthening the protection of retail investors, as it is envisaged that retail investors whose portfolio does not exceed EUR 500 000, the ELTIF manager or any distributor after the fitness test has been carried out and having provided adequate investment advice should ensure that the retail investor does not invest a total amount exceeding 10% of the ELTIF investor portfolio and that the initial amount invested in one or more ELTIFs is not less than EUR 10 000. Long-term funding is a key tool to enable the European economy to return to the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The formation of a new regulatory form for the European Long-Term Investment Fund will allow for the acquisition of the funds needed to invest in the Economy of the European Union. By setting concrete and clear rules, how the Fund will only finance long-term projects that will benefit the economy and enable the growth of the European Union, they instill confidence in fulfilling the purpose. An additional dimension of transparency and security gives this Fund that it would be managed by undertakings authorised under Directive 2011/61/EU. Funds raised from institutional and retail investors, which prevent the early withdrawal of funds according to standards developed by ESMA, ensure the stability of the financial construction and the finalisation of projects.  The ELTIF provides an opportunity for all Member States, including Croatia, to use the funds to finance sustainable production and infrastructure, education and research projects, which are a key tool in achieving sustainable growth, high employment and competitiveness. I therefore support the supplementary report of my colleague Alain Lamassoura and welcome any efforts by the Council, the Commission and Parliament.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that long-term financing is an important instrument that activates investment and helps the European economy to have systematic, sustainable and inclusive growth and, at the same time, promotes more employment and greater competitiveness. That is why I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on long-term European investment funds, the ELTIFs, which provide adequate funding for infrastructure projects of various kinds, un listed companies and small and medium-sized enterprises that are the backbone of our economy. This finances the real economy and helps the European Union to implement its policies. For this reason, we need an EU regulation governing THEFS, because if this were not the case, there would be a risk that divergent measures with different levels of investor protection could be taken at national level. The adoption of uniform rules eliminates distortions of competition and strengthens investor confidence in these funds.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rules adopted for European long-term investment funds, because I consider investment to be a key element of the healthy development of our economies. For this reason, I voted in favour of the report on European long-term investment funds.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. At a time when the key words of the new Juncker Commission are competitiveness and growth, it is necessary to regulate and regulate the different types of investments. The European Parliament has spoken on European long-term investment funds. I voted in favour of this text.  This funding is crucial to achieving the Europe 2020 targets for smart, sustainable and inclusive European growth. These funds are essential to enable the stakeholders involved, and in particular the regional and local authorities, to undertake future projects.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. 'u2012 Long-term financing is a key tool to enable the European economy to enter a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth and promote high employment and competitiveness. The European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) provide financing for various infrastructure projects, non-listed companies or long-term listed small and medium-sized enterprises that issue equity or debt instruments for which there is no easily identifiable buyer. ELTIF thus contributes to the financing of the Real Economy of the Union and the implementation of its policies. As the financial crisis has shown, to combat the lack of financing, it is important to complement bank financing with a wide range of funding sources that better mobilise capital markets. ELTIF can play a key role in this area by channelling private savings into the European economy and attracting investors from third countries. I therefore voted in favour of this legislative resolution on the draft regulation to define rules for a clear identification of the categories of assets eligible for investment by ELTIF.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of this report, as I believe that long-term financing is a key tool in enabling the European economy to enter a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in line with the EU2020 strategy, generating jobs and competitiveness, but in a regulated and transparent manner. The European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) provide the financing of various projects and infrastructures, non-listed companies or small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) listed, complementing bank financing in order to combat the possible lack of financing, mobilising capital and attracting investors from third countries. I also believe that it is necessary to regulate eltif rules in order to avoid market distortions.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Desperately seeking private capital: this could be summed up as the most popular activity currently in the European institutions.  In view of the drained state of public finances, combined with the difficulty of states in generating new revenue, a new path is emerging, the one chosen by the Commission and confirmed in the Lamassoure report: mobilising private capital through the creation of this new financing tool that is the European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF).  A fund that would invest, for example, in unlisted companies or European infrastructure projects. The Commission estimates that around EUR 2 billion of private investment will be needed to launch its policy on major works until 2020: a trans-European transport network by rail, road or canals, or projects on innovation and digital.  While potential investors, for whom ELTTTs can be a stable source of income, have been identified, such as pension management agencies, insurance companies, foundations and municipalities, the keys to success have yet to be invented. The Juncker Commission will have to be very persuasive in persuading these investors to block their stake for the European project for some time.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. Many projects, essential for Europe's economic recovery, require a long-term financial commitment: transport, energy and telecommunications infrastructure are an example. I therefore voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to create European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF).  By targeting players such as pension funds and insurance companies, this new tool should encourage non-bank investment in certain projects. In addition, this new collective investment framework is expected to create economies of scale and critical mass, while reducing market fragmentation and thus regulatory uncertainty.  It is now a question of articulating ELTTS with the proposal for the European Fund for Strategic Investments as presented in the Juncker Plan published last November.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. 'Long-term financing is a key tool for abandoning the path of austerity and enabling the European economy to enter a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy.  These funds provide financing for various infrastructure projects, as well as non-listed companies or small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), increasing employment and competitiveness.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of a new Regulation on European long-term investment funds. Long-term financing is an essential tool to be able to channel the European economy on a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, in accordance with the Europe 2020 Strategy.  European long-term investment funds provide financing for different infrastructure projects, unlisted enterprises or durable listed SMEs that issue equity or debt instruments for which there is no easily identifiable buyer. By financing such projects, European long-term investment funds contribute to the financing of the Union's real economy and the implementation of its policies.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of this supplementary report on the proposal for a Regulation on European long-term investment funds, precisely because I believe that it is an essential instrument for a path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy. This financial mechanism will be the kick-start to the creation of an integrated internal market for capital mobilisation, which can and should be channelled into long-term investments in the European economy. To this end and like the rapporteur, I think it is essential that the Commission can identify the main obstacles to the cross-border mobilisation of these capitals, as well as their tax treatment, so that the objectives set out in the Regulation ensure the uniformity of investment requirements and ensure conditions of activity of these funds throughout the Union.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported Alain Lamassoure's report, which allows the launch of a new and effective tool that will not only promote the financing of investments in the long term but will also help to build the union of capital markets. Given the current context of crisis and investment deficits, we must find a solution to boost economic growth, enable financial stability and remove barriers to cross-border investment while ensuring that consumers are protected.  The aim of these instruments is in particular to revive the activities of SMEs with the granting of loans thus encouraging their development and growth. For example, these European long-term investment funds will help professionals, insurance companies, pension funds and retail investors, who want to invest at least EUR 10,000 in the long term, to invest in projects provided they are used for the European economy.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation as it aims to increase the capital available for long-term investments, through the creation of a fund called EU Long Term Investment Funds which will operate by ensuring consistent rules across the EU and harmonising operating conditions for all stakeholders in the investment fund market. Following the agreement reached between Parliament and the Council, it was decided that this fund would only channel funds for long-term projects. There is a great need for this type of investment in Europe.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to abstain because I agree with some of the aims of the regulation (including achieving a high rate of employment), but I am sceptical that these funds will bring these funds closer to their objectives.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this directive, the final outcome of the (trilogue) negotiations between the Commission, Parliament and the Council. The idea of channeling dispersed funds into investments of a lasting nature and of general interest is not in itself harmful, on the contrary. But this channeling should be carried out with alternative criteria: through independent professional management, under the public competition and management, with criteria that combine the saving purpose and the activity in which it is invested, with a guaranteeing public regulation and, of course, open to the improvement of these regulations and guarantees, and not putting floor cutters to the possibility of Member States deepening and advancing this regulation.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report by my colleague Alain Lamassoure, which allows the creation of European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF) to redirect financial resources towards the real economy.  Indeed, many cash available, but investments have fallen by 15% since 2008. Very little of this capital is mobilized for long-term funding for infrastructure, equipment, educational centres or research. ElTIF will oversee the creation of new "investment vehicles" that will stabilize assets in exchange for attractive bonuses. The aim is to attract investment funds, pension funds and insurance companies through a flexible and attractive framework to boost the growth and competitiveness of our economies.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. The new financial products that are supposed to promote the long term and presented in this report, even if they may be a matter of fair intuition, do not seem to us to provide the necessary guarantees as to their possible diversion and the power of control that States should exercise over them.  On the other hand, there is a great risk of having profitable investments that are made only in northern countries that do not need them because of the lack of an investment agency promoting profitable long-term investments in sectors, such as energy savings or new energies (financing companies, artisanal sectors, companies selling equipment).  Therefore, I abstained.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it develops a type of financial product aimed at entating large international capitals to finance the construction of large infrastructures. This report aims to give a boost to the real economy and employment when, in reality, it will only allow an increase in revenue for large construction consortia, which have proved unable to maintain a boost to job creation. This type of funds, in the context of EFSI negotiations, is another way of rewarding international speculative capital with legal guarantees in order to invest in the infrastructure sector. Private capital has proven to be causing the current crisis and therefore cannot be part of the solution; our commitment to boosting the real economy is public investment and that is why we voted against this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the creation of European long-term investment funds (ELTIFs). Indeed, I believe that this new investment vehicle can make a decisive contribution to financing the EU's real economy by promoting its intelligent growth and competitiveness. The accessibility of ELTIFs, intended for investors willing to tie capital into long-term assets in exchange for a steady return, is of strategic importance in order to optimise the capital available to European companies and win the confidence of new public and private investors.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted alongside the Socialists and Democrats Group in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on European Long-term Investment Funds (ELTIFs). The proposal is for a new type of collective investment framework allowing investors to put money into companies and projects that need long-term capital. ELTIFs are designed to increase the amount of non-bank finance available for companies investing in the real economy of the European Union.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Aiming for sustainable and smart growth for the entire European economy, I supported the supplementary report on the European Funds for Long-Term Investments. The European Union has financial resources that can stimulate common economic growth but need to be properly deployed.  Selected investments should contribute to the objectives of the European growth model, i.e. improving social infrastructure, sustainable mobility, production and distribution of renewable energy, energy efficiency procedures and companies operating in sectors that foster the creation of solutions for society and the environment or that have high potential for innovation.  SMEs must be recognised as a potential that can provide the European Union, and thus Croatia, with a way out of the economic crisis. Therefore, I am of the opinion that these funds should have the focus of small and medium-sized enterprises. For this reason, I call on the competent authorities to monitor the allocation and implementation of funds from the Funds in order to ensure that retail investors have an equal position with respect to professional investors.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the creation and adoption of a European Long-Term Investment Fund, as this promotes long-term investment where more patience and time is needed to bring about positive change and improvement. This is an important instrument for growth and development. In fact, long-term investment has been declining since the 1980s, which is worrying, as these investments represent an important flow of resources for small and medium-sized enterprises, which are a pillar of the European economy. Through this, small and medium-sized enterprises will be given new funding opportunities, in particular innovation, development and research, which are crucial for progress and competitiveness in the global economy. Europe needs new competitive growth, and one way of achieving this is long-term investment funds. Moreover, the promotion of private capital in long-term investments reduces the economy's dependence on banks' loans, which is still a problem in these difficult financial times. In view of the positive aspects of this Proposal from the European Commission, I voted in favour of it.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the supplementary report on European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIF). ELTIFs are funds that enable investors to contribute financially to long-term projects, such as infrastructure construction. At the same time, this new instrument guarantees the protection of investors and that of the companies and projects covered by the investment. The aim of ELTIFs is to reduce dependence on the banking system and to facilitate the financing of the real economy by promoting recovery in the European Union. I believe that ELTIFs represent a positive innovation in the European financial system and I believe that they can contribute to a much-needed recovery in investment in Europe.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing ‒ I currently need to support investment for jobs in the EU. I welcome the activity towards setting up a fund for long-term investments, because building infrastructure in transport, energy and digitalisation has a long-term return, but without quality infrastructure we cannot improve the environment for job creation.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Long-term funding is a key tool to enable the European economy to return to the path of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, high employment and competitiveness rates, and to build tomorrow's economy in a way that is not so prone to systemic risks and is more resilient. European Long-Term Investment Funds (ELTIFs) provide long-term funding for various infrastructure projects, unlisted companies or listed SMEs issuing equity or debt instruments for which there is no immediate buyer. By providing funding for these projects, European funds for long-term investments contribute to financing the real economy in the Union and implementing its policies. The focus of this Regulation is on strengthening Europe's long-term investments in the real economy, and I therefore support it.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on a collective investment framework. The proposed European Long-term Investment Funds (ELTIFs) would increase the amount of non-bank finance that is available for investing in companies, which would in turn promote investment in the real economy of the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I support this report on capital raising for long-term investments with the creation of the ELTIF (European Long-Term Investment Funds). ELTIFs should comply with Directive 2011/61/EU, which is the legal framework governing the management and trading of alternative investment funds (AIFs) in the Union. By definition, ELTIFs are alternative EU investment funds managed by alternative investment fund managers (AIFMs) who have been authorised to operate under Directive 2011/61/EU.  The proposal contains two categories of possible investments; long-term investments and long-term investments whose successful development requires a long-term commitment of investors.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal as it aims to allow certain types of entities, such as pension funds or insurance companies, to expand the range of investments they can make. The proposal aims to strengthen long-term investment in the EU and, if this is to be achieved by reducing the administrative burden, this is clearly the right solution.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported an additional report by my colleague Lamassour on European long-term investment funds. The introduction of European long-term investment funds represents the first concrete step in changing investment in the EU, as we do not currently have any European instrument to ensure long-term investment. These funds require the investor to be required to invest for a certain period of time and to be reimbursed after a certain period of time. There are also strict rules in this regard as regards the managers of these funds, and there will also be strict supervision of fund managers. The EU needs to develop instruments that will provide funds for long-term investment. Long-term investments require the efforts of all relevant actors or stakeholders: from lawmakers to users. For all these reasons, I supported the additional report on Europe's long-term investment funds.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 These investment methods are an additional way of serving large capital leading to the exploitation of the weaker economic classes.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament and the Council's proposed regulation on Long-term European Investment Funds and followed the recommendation of my political group on this issue.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported Parliamentʼs position on the European Long-term Investment Funds (ELTIFs). This is a necessary tool to boost the EU real economy and put SMEs on the path of smart and sustainable growth. Improving access to finance for SMEs and start-ups is one of my priorities and ELTIFs will provide them with valuable alternative sources of funding. It sets up uniform rules to ensure the coherence and stability of long-term investments in the EU economy. The ELTIFs allow investments in, for example, infrastructure, transport and sustainable energy projects and will ensure that these investments are safe by spreading assets or imposing limits on the amount investors can borrow. To ensure the long-term funding for firms and projects, investors will only be able to withdraw money at a specified end date, except in certain cases; in return they will be rewarded with a regular income stream.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ European Long-Term Investment Funds are certainly a financing model that can effectively deliver long-term projects with smart, sustainable and inclusive growth goals. It is important to stress that investment in the real economy across Europe, as well as in individual Member States, can only be encouraged if favourable conditions are created and a stable investment climate will encourage entrepreneurs to take further steps towards economic and infrastructure objectives.  The rules on European funds for long-term investments should primarily encourage freedom of entrepreneurship, transparency and the development of a stable fiscal policy with minimal administrative burden to enable the recovery and revival of the economy.  The development of the economy therefore assumes that entrepreneurs can perform in a healthy business environment that will not be burdened by huge bureaucracy and regulation, but also the development of other funding models that will provide stability and predictability to businesses other than investment funds. In this way, companies and projects are provided with access to the funds needed to ensure their dissemination and further realisation. That's why I supported this report.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to today's vote, Europe is equipding itself with a new effective instrument that will not only give a greater boost to the financing of long-term investments, but will also help to build the Capital Markets Union. The lack of investment and the financial crisis have faced several challenges: maximising economic growth, increasing financial stability, removing obstacles to cross-border investment, ensuring consumer protection and at the same time strengthening competition.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European economy is in need of stronger capital markets that can channel more effectively savings towards long-term investments. In this sense, the approval of this report is a very welcome step forward in order to facilitate these kind of investments and reduce the European over-reliance on banks.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. We can be against markets for goods and services without borders while being in favour of deeper and unified capital markets.  For investors, this helps diversify the projects and companies in which they invest; companies, to find more financing. There are two arguments in favour of these funds. First, they are geared towards financing SMEs. Second, they are a long-term, unlike speculative, instrument. We are against the fact that Qatar can buy back our national heritage, without prohibiting everyone from investing in us, let alone in our SMEs. What needs to be combated are toxic, speculative products, developed with a view to immediate profits and which are a source of instability and diversion of savings in relation to the needs of the real economy. The French delegation of the FN therefore took a cautious position in voting on this new financial instrument, especially given the vagueness surrounding certain investment rules.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The long-term investment funds are the vehicles designed to boost non-bank investment in the real economy across Europe. This is an efficient new tool that will give a major boost to financing long-term investment, as supported by President Juncker’s plan. This new financial tool helps us to solve the complex economic situation we are faced with, achieving economic growth, increasing financial stability and ensuring consumer protection at the same time. I voted in favour, supporting this new tool.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently, there are investors in the market (pension funds, insurance companies) who want to invest in the long term if they are guaranteed a stable return or payment of a lump sum. The European Commission has therefore put forward a legislative proposal to meet these investors by creating the so-called European Long-Term Investment Funds (EITLs). At the moment, at European level, there are no uniform, clear and precise rules to regulate these funds. The adoption of an appropriate legislative framework will lead to a better functioning of the internal market and a higher level of investor protection and ensure that the ELTIF has a coherent and stable product profile across the Union. The European Parliament's report includes, inter alia, provisions to ensure that long-term funds do indeed contribute to economic growth, that they are not used for speculative purposes and that any retail investor is adequately informed and protected.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Directive, the final outcome of the (trilogue) negotiations between the Commission, Parliament and the Council. The idea of channeling dispersed funds into investments of a lasting nature and of general interest is not in itself harmful, on the contrary. But this channeling should be carried out with alternative criteria: through independent professional management, under the public competition and management, with criteria that combine the saving purpose and the activity in which it is invested, with a guaranteeing public regulation and, of course, open to the improvement of these regulations and guarantees, and not putting floor cutters to the possibility of Member States deepening and advancing this regulation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the LAMASSOURE report, as I welcome the creation of a European quality 'label' for long-term investment. By defining these funds, confidence in long-term investments can be promoted and more patient and accountable behaviors encouraged. Thus, the trend will be to flow towards projects that bear fruit in 10, 20 or 30 years (which prioritize social and environmental return to purely financial).

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – While the European economy as a whole is growing, there is often a lack of funding for major projects related to transport infrastructure, the production or distribution of sustainable energy, social infrastructures such as housing or hospitals, the introduction of new technologies, as well as the growth of SMEs. Moreover, banks are not always motivated to lend to such long-term projects. Long-term investment funds (ELTiFs) are therefore one of the alternatives in giving non-listed companies the choice of a wider range of sources of funding. At present, the regulation of the EU's long-term investment funds is the responsibility of the Member States, resulting in divergent investment protection measures, leading to distortions of competition.  I therefore support the rules for setting up long-term Investment Funds in the European Union aimed at increasing Europe's long-term investments in the real economy by laying down common rules for the operation of eltiFs as regards the composition of their portfolio and the investment instruments that they may use to engage in exposures to long-term assets. The new rules will enable major research, infrastructure .c projects to receive funding.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it develops a type of financial product aimed at entating large international capitals to finance the construction of large infrastructures. This report aims to give a boost to the real economy and employment when, in reality, it will only allow an increase in revenue for large construction consortia that have proved incapable of maintaining a boost to job creation. This type of funds, in the context of EFSI negotiations, is another way of rewarding international speculative capital with legal guarantees in order to invest in the infrastructure sector. Private capital has proven to be causing the current crisis and therefore cannot be part of the solution; our commitment to boosting the real economy is public investment and that is why we voted against this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We have a serious problem in the EU that stems from the expectations of economic actors who do not see prospects for growth at EU level. We can talk about innovation, smart growth, we can use the rhetoric we wanted. We may even think economic agents are blind. But it is enough to look at the world to understand that neoliberal policies based on free trade and the non-intervention of states in the economy to perceive the reticence of agents to invest. And if the market does not work, if the agents do not invest, then we should not expect them to be market instruments that solve the problem. See if the results of the ecb's long-term bank refinancing operations. This instrument is more of the same. It doesn't even innovate. It does not even contain a clause in terms of guaranteeing the social and labour rights of the jobs that will be financed Does not contain any guarantee in environmental terms. As history teaches us, the recessive cycle will only be broken with new policies based on an ambitious public investment program that will once again give states its central role in building growth and development strategies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, as the pan-European rules on funds that can be marketed under the name ELTIF will reduce information deficits among investors, thereby boosting investor confidence. However, the blanket ban on the use of derivatives is not in the interests of investor protection.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Lamassoure, as long-term financing is indeed a crucial tool and European long-term investment funds (SMEs) can contribute to the financing of the real Union economy and the implementation of European policies. As the economic crisis has shown, supplementing bank financing with a wider variety of sources of financing that better mobilise capital markets could help address funding gaps. EMEs can play a key role in this respect, and they can also mobilise capital by attracting investors from third countries. Uniform rules are needed, however, to ensure that EMEs have a stable and coherent form throughout the Union.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I believe that the right investment strategy will help the economic growth of Europe that we have long needed. However, we must not only talk about the amounts that we will invest, but above all we must focus on the efficiency of the money thus spent.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the rapporteur's long-term investment funds, as long-term funds will further strengthen the Juncker Investment Plan, increase resources for long-term investment in the European economy, build up the European Capital Union and strengthen the European economy, which will not depend on the investment capacity of banks. Funds must be channelled into projects with long-term importance, such as infrastructure, as it is of paramount importance for the union as a whole and especially for countries such as Slovenia, which are not adequately infrastructure-developed and have difficulties in rebuilding logistics centres, railways, roads, etc.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a series of positive steps for card users in the European Union. Different card types are one of the main means of payment in the different EU Member States; however, the lack of uniform legislation has allowed numerous abuses by many financial companies to the detriment of their clients. This report is aimed at harmonising payment systems to prevent this type of abuse and provide a stronger legal framework in payment transactions, whether domestic or international. As it is a proposal for a Regulation which can significantly improve the protection of users of this type of means of payment, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The situation to date has been that interchange fees for card-based payments, paid by the merchantʼs bank to the bank that issued the card, have not been transparent and they differ between EU countries, where they are subject in some cases to legislation and in others to decisions by national competition authorities. The positive vote means in practice that cross-border debit card transaction fees will now be capped at 0.2 % of the transaction value. For credit card transactions, a fee cap of 0.3 % of the transaction value will apply. Member States, including Ireland, can decide to impose a lower cap if they so wish.  These changes will be a positive development for customers and for Irish businesses operating on a cross-border basis. During discussions at preparatory meetings of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs my colleague Matt Carthy urged that the issue of cross-border transactions be included in any caps as this is particularly important in an Irish context where we need to break down all barriers in order to create an effective all-Ireland economy.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the supplementary report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card payment transactions, considering that the fragmentation of the internal market is detrimental to competitiveness, growth and employment within the Union and therefore achieving greater coherence of the single market for electronic payments is essential for the proper functioning of the internal market and consumer protection.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. This initiative is very welcome in the light of the benefits of reducing transaction costs for card payments to the EU's internal market and its consumers. I am also pleased with the consistent application of the competition rules on transfer fees.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The fees associated with bank card payments reveal the lack of interoperability between terminals and are an obstacle to better competition. The cap on commissions for debit or credit card payments proposed in this report is a commendable step forward to which I am in favour. I voted for this text which improves the conditions of competition, economic activities and transparency in the management of means of payment.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The idea of capping fees for card-based payments may be a noble one, but the law of unintended consequences applies here. Companies will simply find other ways to get their money, and consumers will be charged regardless.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to set a lower bank card fee. The new rules limit bank fees to companies for allowing customers to pay with bank cards. These rules aim to increase the transparency of the tax charged by banks, which would encourage competition and allow the most appropriate bank card payment scheme to be chosen. The new rules will also have to be followed by banks operating in Lithuania, which means that card payments in Lithuania will come cheap. In Lithuania, banks usually charge between 0.8% and 2% of the purchase value, which is usually included in the price of the product or service. According to the draft new regulation, the interchangeable credit card payment fee will not exceed 0.3% of the value of the purchase or service. Cross-border debit card payments will not be subject to an interchange fee of more than 0.2%. However, EU countries retain the right to calculate this threshold for another five years not from the price of a good or service, but from the average annual value of transactions in a separate card scheme. In addition, after that transitional period, a fee of up to EUR 5 per transaction may be charged for small amounts when paying by debit card.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it is in the interest of both the consumer and the merchants: too often still, some cards are refused, especially abroad, and some small merchants continue to refuse cards below a certain amount.   It is therefore necessary to reduce commissions for credit card payment transactions, and to facilitate the use of these, whatever the type, including for small amounts. The regulation will probably not solve these various problems, but it is a step in the right direction.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The fees that banks charge retailers to make customer payments will, as a result of this measure, be capped. The cap will apply to domestic and cross-border payments, and will result in lower costs for consumers. This measure is therefore good news both for the transparency of payment fees and for the consumer who will see his fees decrease.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This supplementary report on interchange fees for card-related payment transactions is a positive element as it goes in the direction of ever more security. It also reduces consumer costs by introducing caps (0.2% for cross-border transactions, 0.2% or EUR 0.05 for domestic transactions or 0.3% for credit card transactions). So I voted for this text.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Bidegain's report analysing the legislative proposal on interchange fees on credit card payment transactions. I consider this text to be extremely balanced, the legislative process has been long and the negotiating phases complex, but the end result is a widely acceptable legislative proposal that has put consumer needs first without imposing unsustainable market conditions for operators, as is often the case.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it represents a considerable improvement in the rights of credit card users. In particular, it makes progress in removing obstacles to the efficient functioning of the card market, including the scope of card payments and card-based mobile and online payments, determines that all debit and credit card-based payment transactions must be subject to a maximum exchange rate rate and clarifies the costs for transactions performed under so-called 'universal cards' , among others.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to adopt a regulation laying down uniform technical and operational requirements for card-based payment transactions in the European Union. In order for the efficient functioning of the internal market, the use of electronic payments should be encouraged and easier to use by traders and consumers. Cards and other electronic payments can be used in a more diverse way, including the availability of online payments to take advantage of the benefits of the internal market and e-commerce, and electronic payments give traders the potential for potentially secure payment. The use of card-based payment instead of cash could therefore benefit traders and consumers if the fees for using payment systems were cost-effective, while contributing to fair competition, innovation and market access for new entrants.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are around 760 million cards in circulation in the EU, an average of 1.5 cards per person, with an increase of 6% in 2013. However, payment with debit and credit cards has a cost for merchants who pay a fee for each transaction. A cost, estimated at a total of 10 billion a year, which is often passed on to the selling price. The EP is today voting on an agreement to limit the costs paid by merchants on debit and credit card transactions for domestic and transnational payments. With this proposal, fees will have a ceiling of 0.2% for debit card transactions and 0.3% for credit card transactions. This is an action that will have to lead to cascading savings in sales prices and it will be important to ensure that this does not result in a paradoxical increase in bank costs for consumers. The European Commission's estimates are encouraging and estimate a possible annual saving of EUR 6 billion for merchants and EUR 730 million for consumers.  My vote in favour is intended to support the developments in terms of transparency and competition in the sector that this measure aims to produce.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In the store, the average consumer is not even aware that the price of the product includes a fee for paying with credit cards. The fee limit will affect 95% of all card payments and mean savings to customers of just over €730 million a year. Also, lower product prices are expected, as traders have so far charged consumers the cost of paying with cards. This is very good news for consumers in Croatia, especially considering that in Croatia the card has twice as many inhabitants. Unlike Germans who pay a fee on card transactions of 1.8%, or Tributes who pay 0.1%, in Croatia the cost of card transactions reaches up to 5%. The final result will be greater consumer protection, lower prices for goods and services, and large savings for both consumers and retailers.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because its aim is to limit bank charges and to force networks to more competition by accepting different cards by the terminals.  While the regulation could go further, particularly on the interoperability of payment terminals, it is a step forward. Interchange fees are the fees charged by card issuers to merchants who offer card payment. These are, in practice, passed on to the selling prices.  This constitutes a restriction of competition, within the meaning of the treaties and the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice.  The report proposes a cap on the bank's commissions at 0.3% of the transaction amount for credit card payments and 0.2% for debit cards, with the possibility for Member States to set lower ceilings. The questioning of exclusivity clauses in the licensing agreements required by card providers, and the various technical mechanisms that limit the possibility of using different cards from the same payment terminal is to be welcomed.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The situation to date has been that interchange fees for card-based payments, paid by the merchantʼs bank to the bank that issued the card, have not been transparent and they differ between EU countries, where they are subject in some cases to legislation and in others to decisions by national competition authorities. The positive vote means in practice that cross-border debit card transaction fees will now be capped at 0.2 % of the transaction value. For credit card transactions, a fee cap of 0.3 % of the transaction value will apply. Member States, including Ireland, can decide to impose a lower cap if they so wish. These changes will be a positive development for customers and for Irish businesses operating on a cross-border basis. The issue of cross-border transactions is particularly important in an Irish context where we need to break down all barriers in order to create an effective all-Ireland economy.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this supplementary report on the interchange fees for card-based payment transactions because I think that we need legal clarity for EU citizens when they are paying with cards inside the European Union.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Interchange fees are fees charged by card issuers to companies that offer card payment. The cost of these commissions is directly passed on to the selling price to the consumer. These interchange fees encourage companies to refuse card payments below a certain amount and for products with very low value added (e.g. tobacco). Hence the cap on commissions at 0.3% of the transaction amount.  In addition, the proposed regulation intends to address the exclusivity clauses in the licensing agreements required by card providers, and the various technical mechanisms that limit the possibility of using different cards from the same payment terminal. This draft regulation is therefore a real step forward for the consumer as it will lead to control and even the reduction in sales rates in the transactions concerned.  Moreover, it seems that the adoption of such a regulation at European level is rather adapted in view of the interoperability of payment terminals. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on interchange fees for card-related payment transactions. This will ensure fair and transparent competition for card payments. Consumers will then be better informed about the cost of card transactions and will be able to make their choice based on this information. This type of measure is a first step towards greater transparency in the banking sector.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Interchange fees for card payments, paid by the merchant's bank to the bank that issued the card, are not transparent and differ between the different countries of the European Union. I have today voted in favour of this report to ensure that the fees that banks charge retailers when accepting card payments are subject to ceilings. The limit will apply to both cross-border and domestic payments in order to record lower costs for debit and credit card users. This legislation, together with the forthcoming Payment Services Directive, will create equal rules for all payments made in Europe. It should improve the transparency of fees, stimulate competition and allow retailers and users to choose their card payment system under the most advantageous conditions. In fact, with these new rules, retailers who choose a payment card circuit will only be able to accept those cards that, within that same circuit, comply with the ceilings. In that case, the fee limits will result in lower costs for both.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report for which I was shadow rapporteur. The situation to date has been that interchange fees for card-based payments, paid by the merchantʼs bank to the bank that issued the card, have not been transparent and they differ between EU countries, where they are subject in some cases to legislation and in others to decisions by national competition authorities. The positive vote means in practice that cross-border debit card transaction fees will now be capped at 0.2 % of the transaction value. For credit card transactions, a fee cap of 0.3 % of the transaction value will apply. Member States, including Ireland, can decide to impose a lower cap if they so wish. These changes will be a positive development for customers and for Irish businesses operating on a cross-border basis. During discussions at preparatory meetings of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs I urged that the issue of cross-border transactions be included in any caps as this is particularly important in an Irish context where we need to break down all barriers in order to create an effective all-Ireland economy.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation, combined with the proposed revised Payment Services Directive, will create common rules for interchange fees in the European Union by introducing maximum fees for transactions with payment cards that are widely used by consumers and thereby difficult to refuse or surcharge by retailers. The draft rules also aim to enhance fee transparency, so as to stimulate competition and enable both retailers and users to choose the card schemes that offer them the best terms. This is yet another measure that benefits the consumer. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation lays down uniform technical and commercial requirements within the Union for card payment transactions where both the payer's payment service provider and the payee's payment service provider are in the Union itself. The intentions are certainly acceptable, but the text does not allow a full assessment of the practical effects of the measures introduced, since it does not go far enough into the analysis of the consequences themselves. I have therefore chosen to abstain, so as to show an interest in a measure such as the one examined while maintaining reservations about the text.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which deals with a proposed regulation that will benefit the consumer, both in terms of purchasing power and in terms of transparency of information. The regulation stipulates that, in cross-border credit card transactions, the bank's commission would be capped at 0.3% of the transaction amount; for debit card transactions, the limit would be 0.2% of the transaction amount. Moreover, the framework of this regulation allows Member States to retain their competence in this area since they have the possibility of setting lower ceilings. This regulation also helps to settle the fact that, all too often still, some cards are refused abroad; consumer cards will now be more easily accepted, making it easier to pay for purchases. Good news for the purchasing power of the French.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – One of the ways merchants pass on the costs of these fees to consumers is by surcharging. Otherwise, including when surcharging is not legally allowed in a Member State jurisdiction, merchants raise prices overall, which passes on the cost to all consumers irrespective of the means of payment they use. Together with other legislation governing payments in the EU (such as the Payment Services Directive, under review, governing intra-EU payments in euro and EU currencies) this regulation aims at improving competition, transparency of fees and choice of card schemes by retailers and consumers. While it  may not be a breakthrough in a direct and immediate sense for consumers, it is a necessary step to address serious issues with our payment systems in Europe, and one which has great potential to bring down the invisible costs that consumers pay when they make retail payments.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of the measure as Directive 2007/64/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council provided the legal basis for the creation of an internal market for payments in the Union, as it substantially favoured the activity of service providers by providing for uniform rules in this area. Today, payment cards are the electronic tools commonly used for retail purchases. There is a need to remove obstacles to the efficient functioning of payment cards, including in the area of card-based payments and internet payments and card-based mobile devices. In addition to the uniform application of the competition rules to interchange fees, both the regulation of interchange fees would improve the functioning of the internal market and help to reduce the costs of transactions for consumers.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the removal of obstacles to the functioning of an integrated market for electronic payments is necessary for the proper functioning of the internal market, without distinction between national and cross-border payments. I therefore voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation because it imposes common rules on EU interchange fees, introducing a ceiling on payment card transactions. Payment cards have become the most commonly used electronic payment instruments for retail purchases, so I believe that regulating interchange fees will improve the functioning of the internal market and help reduce the costs of transactions for consumers.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. One of the major challenges of the European Union is the fight against fragmentation of the internal market in a number of areas, in particular obstacles to the smooth functioning of the integrated electronic payments market. I support the Bidegain report, as I believe that this new Regulation prevents the generalisation of excessive levels in the applicable rates and promotes the creation of a genuine European-wide payment market by setting a maximum interchange rate of 0.2 % of the value of the transaction for debit cards and 0.3 % for credit cards , whether cross-border operations or national operations. By establishing a secure, efficient and competitive electronic payment system, consumers, traders and businesses are gaining, and the savings obtained from this new regulation should be reflected in a drop in retail prices.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on interchange fees on card payment transactions. The adopted text establishes a cap on interchange fees for debit card and consumer credit card transactions (i.e. used by holders who are consumers at the same time), of 0.2% and 0.3% respectively, to be calculated on the value of the transaction. The aim of this proposal is to prevent an unjustified change in the size of these fees, given that they are included in the costs incurred by the merchant in the form of price increases, in order to receive debit or credit card payments. Therefore, by applying only to 4-party circuits, i.e. the most popular ones, it would, on the one hand, protect consumers through a reduction in prices and, on the other hand, it would obvious the establishment of barriers between national payment markets.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This regulation will create caps on fees that banks charge retailers for processing shoppers’ payments. This will reduce fees and introduce a maximum fee that banks and other payment service providers charge for payment with debit and credit cards. The regulation will also introduce transparency measures so that retailers and consumers can make better informed choices concerning payment instruments. I have thus voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of ending the cost of fees banks charge retailers when accepting card payments. They will be subject to ceilings, thanks to new rules that apply throughout the EU. The limit will apply to both cross-border and domestic payments and should reduce costs for debit and credit card users. Thanks to this vote and the Payment Services Directive, equal rules will be created for all payments made in Europe. It should improve the transparency of fees, encourage competition and allow merchants and customers to choose their card payment system under the most advantageous conditions.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposal sets a cap on multilateral interchange fees (MIFs) paid by a trader’s bank to the bank of a credit or debit card holder. In fact, lack of competition in this sector is a reason for high interchange fees which are finally paid by consumers. The cap would apply to both cross-border and domestic card-based payments and should cut costs for card users. The rules also aim to enhance fee transparency, so as to stimulate competition and enable both retailers and users to choose the card schemes that offer them the best terms. I voted in favour of this report because I consider it as an important consumer policy reform.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Through this text, the aim is to regulate interchange fees for card-related payment transactions. Because these interchange fees represent a significant part of the fees charged to merchants by the companies providing this service, their level affects the purchasing power of Europeans. Indeed, the fees charged to merchants are passed on to consumers.  By capping the fees levied by payment service providers, this text goes in the right direction, that of protecting the purchasing power of European citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this legislative proposal is to introduce common rules on interchange fees in the European Union, by capping such commissions for transactions carried out using payment cards. Considering that these payment cards are widely used by consumers and that the legislative proposal provides, in addition to the cap on fees, to strengthen transparency measures for retailers and consumers, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The number of non-cash transactions in the market is often considered as an indicator of a country's economic development. Today in this Chamber we have marked a step forward in the construction of the most developed international platform in this field. Together with the digital agenda, the regulation on interchange fees on card payment transactions is an indication of Parliament's focus on building an innovative European platform for a strengthened single market. In fact, we have removed those barriers that today prevented further market integration and this will help to have positive effects on our economy. We have also focused on the main problems associated with this market. Firstly, we have harmonised legislation at European level, preventing the creation of grey areas and national markets that are more competitive than others. Secondly, we have prevented high interchange fees from resulting in higher final prices for consumers, through a system of maximum and minimum thresholds. I therefore voted with conviction for this text because it protects not only our consumers, but also small retailers, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises in our territory.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Banks' fees for payments to retailers differ from one Member State to another and these transactions lack transparency. Capping these payments, whether transnational or national, will allow for a certain standardisation of European rules and therefore more transparency. This is in the interests of the European consumer, and his right to information.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed regulation limiting the fees charged by banks in credit and debit card transactions. Currently, merchants must accept all cards on the terms of the banks. The calculation of fees charged to merchants varies by country and bank. The whole system lacked transparency. From now on, new caps will be set by Europe: for credit card payments, commissions will be capped at 0.3% of the value of the transaction. For debit card purchases, these fees will be limited to 0.2% in a cross-border transaction. For domestic debit card transactions, a five-year transition period has been set. Beyond this period, commissions will be limited to 0.2% or EUR 0.05 per transaction. I supported at arm's length the compromise proposed by the rapporteur because the regulation is in the interests of consumers and traders. It should mainly benefit buyers as a result of lower transaction fees. However, merchants will be free to pass on to the sale price or not the decrease in payment fees resulting from these caps.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because the proposed caps on credit and debit card interchange fees are projected to save British business GBP 480 million. The caps mean that the costs of doing business will come down – and prices should fall too. This is exactly the kind of thing we should be tackling at a European level, and it shows what we can achieve when all 28 EU countries work together. It is clear that technology can often make the world easier: you can take a small piece of plastic with you on holiday and take money out of a Spanish ATM or pay for dinner in an Italian restaurant. But it can make the world less transparent as well, if we are not careful – we do not always know whether it is working in our interests. That is why I was pleased to vote for this measure which stands up against vested interests, and which is for the benefit of British businesses and British families. Thanks to this new law, UK shoppersʼ lives will be a little clearer, a little fairer and a lot cheaper.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this step to cap the fees that businesses and consumers may have to pay when they use their debit or credit card domestically or in a cross-border transaction. This is a move that goes some way to giving local consumers and businesses with the potential to expand in EU markets an incentive, and the capacity, to explore opportunities presented by e-commerce. It is right and proper that these transactions are secure, competitive and free of barriers in order to instil confidence in those enterprises and consumers that want embrace these new technologies and drive growth as a result. It is somewhat disheartening, however, in light of this positive and democratic decision to cap fees in this way, that the Council of Ministers have seen fit to delay the total abolition of costly mobile roaming charges across Europe until 2018. This overturns the decision reached by those in this Parliament, and serves to add further distress to those living in the border counties of my constituency, Northern Ireland, who face exorbitant charges as a result of this barrier. It is high time that national governments wake up to this reality.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The fees associated with card payments reveal the lack of interoperability between terminals and are an obstacle to better competition. The cap on commissions for proposed debit and credit card payments is also a laudable step forward and which I support. I voted in favour of the whole text, which improves the conditions for competition, economic activities and transparency in the management of means of payment.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The report concerns payments called multilateral interchange fees or MIFs, which are charges during transactions between the merchantʼs and the buyer’s banks. It sets maximum fee levels for transactions with payment cards that are used by consumers at 0.2 per cent for debit card transactions and 0.3 per cent for credit card transactions. For domestic transactions Member States can define a per transaction cap fee of less than 0.2 per cent or apply a per transaction fee of no more than 0.05 EUR/equivalent. There are also transparency measures for retailers and consumers to make more informed decisions about possible charges. Commercial cards are excluded from the scope as are payment cards issued by three party payment schemes. Reducing charges for using your card abroad is something I support.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Directive, which establishes for the first time a European regulation on the fees that consumers pay for credit card transactions. In a context where the means of payment are increasingly centralized under the control of an oligopoly of a few private companies, it was urgent to establish an international regulation that would put them at their level. The Directive sets a maximum cap on credit card payment fees, with the possibility for Member States to set smaller caps, with the lowest being the one to always be respected in the case of international transactions. While our position would have been to completely eliminate these rates, we still believe that this regulation goes in a positive sense to end certain abusive practices, and to protect small businesses and consumers.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the supplementary report as Greece has experienced first-hand the behaviour of banks when they are allowed to act freely, away from the control of the states.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This was an important vote of the Strasbourg session of March 2015. In order to combat the fragmentation of the internal market posed by direct and indirect obstacles to the proper functioning of an integrated electronic payments market, I voted in favour of European legislation to, on the one hand, resolve the distinctions between national payments and international payments by realising the European electronic payments market and, on the other hand, providing rules that allow electronic payments to be effectively 'safer' , efficient, competitive and innovative" (§6), something that is "crucial for consumers, traders and businesses to fully benefit from the advantages of the single market, especially as it evolves globally into e-commerce." (§6)

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Payment transactions associated with debit and credit cards will be subject to a maximum exchange fee in the EU within six months. The idea is to prevent the generalisation of excessive levels and promote the creation of an EU-wide payment market.  Currently, in most EU countries, the interchange fees paid by merchants to banks for the use of debit and credit cards are not subject to any legislation, but to the decisions of national authorities and their variation is marked between Member States, creating obstacles between national payment markets. The new Regulation aims to prevent the generalisation of excessive levels of these rates, increase transparency of these rates, ensure a level playing field and promote the creation of an EU-wide payment market. The ceilings are set at 0.3 % of the transaction value for credit cards and 0.2 % for debit cards, values that seem fair to me.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation because it is trying to fill a significant gap which called into question both the unity of the internal market and the rights of consumers, the imposition of different fees depending on whether the payment card transaction takes place within the Member State where it was contracted or in another Member State. This is yet another example of the financial fragmentation that exists in our Union and which must be thoroughly corrected by the so-called 'capital markets union' announced by the Commission, the Green Paper of which we have just known. This Regulation introduces a cap on so-called 'exchange fees' of 0.2% per transaction for debit cards and 0.3% for credit cards, irrespective of whether those payment transactions are domestic or cross-border, which is undoubtedly a major step forward.  This Regulation is also an important complement to Directive 2014/92/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 July 2014 on the comparability of related commissions to payment accounts, the transfer of payment accounts and access to basic payment accounts.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to a proposal to regulate, directly and indirectly, the interchange fees applied by companies and banks isising and marketing debit and credit cards. The report comes out of the trilogue procedure with positive aspects. These include the fact that payment and service providers cannot propose or demand interchange fees for each banking operation exceeding 0,2 % of the value of the transaction when it comes to debit cards. In national operations, Member States may set a lower than expected rate ceiling and impose a lump sum for the maximum rate as a limit on the amount of the resulting rate. They may also allow payment service providers to apply interchange fees per transaction of not more than EUR 0.05, revised every 5 years. As for credit cards, fees at European level are limited to levels of not more than 0.3 % of the value of the transaction. In this case, Member States may also set lower limits for national operations. Each Member State should define the system of penalties applicable to the infringement of this Regulation.  We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ consumers are increasingly using electronic payments in the world, but also in Europe, and it is therefore very important that they can fully reap the full benefits of the internal market and be protected from high charges by traders. The existing range of interchange fees and their amount prevents new entrants operating throughout the European Union from entering the market, who would be willing to operate at lower interchange fees or to abolish them altogether.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of a legislative proposal which, compared to what was initially presented by the European Commission, comes to the end of the much improved legislative path. After lengthy negotiations, a much more balanced solution has been found in which maximum values are set and the Member States are left to intervene with further cuts in domestic transactions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I disagree and vote against the supplementary report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card payment transactions, as Greece has first-hand experienced the behaviour of banks when they are allowed to act freely, away from the control of states.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a cap on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. Visa and MasterCard have an effective duopoly in this market. As competition is so limited I believe that regulation can be justified. At present small businesses face an unknown fee when a customer uses a card. This is unfair. A cap on fees will benefit every business that accepts card payments.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Safe, efficient, competitive and innovative electronic payments are essential to consumers, retailers and businesses. Since I support an integrated market for electronic payments, in which there is no distinction between domestic payments and cross-border payments, I voted in favour of this report. As global trade becomes electronic this regulation will allow citizens to enjoy fully the benefits of the internal market.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. The setting of the maximum limits on interchange fees applied to card payment transactions is a positive step towards greater European consumer protection. As consumers are often unaware of the existence of these exchange rates, their amount is each year for retailers and, lastly, for consumers, tens of billions of euros. Although payment cards are the most commonly used electronic payment instrument for retail purchases in the EU, the internal market is still far from integrated, so the approved measure represents a step forward in this regard.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
