text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has finally shown in today's vote that it can stand shoulder to shoulder with the citizens. Interchange fees for too long have been a hidden cost to consumers as well as traders, in breach of antitrust law, as was also established by last September's RULING of the EU Court of Justice. This regulation puts an end to the abuses of certain banks and places limits on them by introducing a more transparent mechanism that balances the needs of the free market with those of protecting the interests of consumers and traders. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal, in the hope that this regulation will represent a new beginning in the direction of a European Union that is increasingly at the side of citizens and protecting their interests.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation on interchange fees on payment transactions carried out by credit card, ATM, payments on the net or through telephone applications.  Therefore, in accordance with the opinions of the European Central Bank and the European Economic and Social Committee, given the problems that the fragmentation of the internal market can cause to competitiveness and how much a single, controlled, effective and secure regulation would be able to reassure merchants against the risks of excessively high commission payments on sales and at the same time encourage consumers to use electronic money for a physiological reduction in costs , I would like to express my support for setting a certain ceiling within the Union, harmonizing and monitoring interchange fees, with the necessary adjustment times for the Member States, for a pan-European market that is not limited by territorial restrictions, capable of technical interoperability between the different treatment systems in the Union and that is at the same time more open and also more stimulating for free purchase.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because it harmonises the rules for reducing transaction fees. Currently, interchange fees for card-based transactions vary between EU countries, where in some cases they are subject to law and in others by administrative decisions. Fees are levied by banks belonging to so-called "four party" schemes in which the issuing bank, the bank serving the fee merchant, the trader and the card user participate, and which together control a significant part of the market. Traders pay for each card transaction and add these costs to the prices of goods and services offered.  In favour of this report, I believe that the fees charged by banks for handling card payments at points of sale will be reduced throughout the EU. The ceiling imposed on fees applies to domestic and foreign payments, which should reduce the costs of payment card users. The new legislation should affect the transparency of fees, strengthen competition and allow not only traders but, above all, customers to choose the system offering the most favourable conditions.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Multilateral Interchange Fees Regulation because it will bring down costs for both consumers and retailers. For far too long, card schemes and banks have been able to increase the fees that we are all charged when we use our debit and credit cards, without any competition to bring these prices down. By imposing a clear maximum cap for debit and credit card transactions, this regulation will change that, and should make the purchases we make cheaper and the fees we are charged more transparent.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because the limitation of the fees charged by banks in the use of credit and debit cards will contribute to increased consumption and will particularly help SMEs. There will be a limit on bank fees on these transactions of 0.2% for debit cards and 0.3% for credit cards. This limit shall apply in the twenty-eight Member States and shall affect all card payments, both cross-border and national. For too long, we have been subject to vague and unpredictable bank fees. That is why I support this legislation, just and logical. In the current economic situation, we must promote consumption and reduce unnecessary barriers.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Directive, which establishes for the first time a European regulation on the fees that consumers pay for credit card transactions. In a context where the means of payment are increasingly centralized under the control of an oligopoly of a few private companies, it was urgent to establish an international regulation that would put them at their level. The Directive sets a maximum cap on credit card payment fees, with the possibility for Member States to set smaller caps, with the lowest being the one to always be respected in the case of international transactions. While our position would have been to completely eliminate these rates, we still believe that this regulation goes in a positive sense to end certain abusive practices, and to protect small businesses and consumers.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am very pleased to have voted for a cap on credit and debit card transaction fees, which will save British business an estimated GBP 480 million a year. For debit cards, this cap will be at 0.2 % of the overall value of the transaction, and for credit cards it will be 0.3 %. Currently British shopkeepers are having to pay up to six times that amount in order to process credit card transactions; the difference this will make is huge. In fact, the new rules are expected to benefit British business by a staggering GBP 480 million a year. Those savings will go directly to shopkeepers and retailers, who in turn can pass them on to consumers. The regulation contains several other measures designed to improve the functioning of this market as transparency requirements, and to strengthen consumer protection provisions. These provisions will bring down the cost of doing business, and make shoppersʼ lives clearer, fairer and cheaper.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive and see it as the best decision taken by the new European Parliament so far. This is essential for SMEs in Europe, especially the ones which are operating in a digital market, to better compete with the global players.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this project on interchange fees for card-related payment transactions. This project aims, in particular, to cap these commissions at a maximum of 0.2% of the value of the transaction for any credit card transaction. This cap will reduce merchant fees, which should also benefit consumers, as merchants pass on their costs to the price of their goods and services.  A reduction in the costs of interchange fees is therefore likely to lower the prices paid by consumers.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation because I believe it is good news for retailers and consumers in the EU that card-based transaction fees will be capped at 0.2% for debit card payments and 0.3% for credit card payments. The Commission estimates that the rules could result in approximately EUR 6 billion in annual savings for retailers. However, there needs to be proper enforcement and oversight of this regulation so that savings are passed on from retailers to consumers.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ As with the mobile phone operators, the duopoly of Mastercard and Visa have had consumers over a barrel for years and have shown an unwillingness to charge fair fees. The EU is right to step in to legislate in this area and today’s vote is a victory for Europe’s consumers and SMEs.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this Directive, which establishes for the first time a European regulation on the fees that consumers pay for credit card transactions. In a context where the means of payment are increasingly centralized under the control of an oligopoly of a few private companies, it was urgent to establish an international regulation that would put them at their level. The Directive sets a maximum cap on credit card payment fees, with the possibility for Member States to set smaller caps, with the lowest being the one to always be respected in the case of international transactions. While our position would have been to completely eliminate these rates, we still believe that this regulation goes in a positive sense to end certain abusive practices, and to protect small businesses and consumers.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. In favor of limiting the interbank fee for each payment made with a bank card; previously, the bank charged commerce an un limited fee.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted to adopt a position on the proposal for a Regulation between Parliament and the Council on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions, as I believe this contributes to removing barriers, further integrating the fragmented European market, and contributes to compliance with competition rules.  This process should cheapen business and thus contribute to a higher volume of transactions, ultimately contribute to increasing economic activities.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This text facilitates fair competition and transparency in the means of payment. It removes some barriers to interoperability between terminals, while advancing commission caps that I consider appreciable. So I voted for this text.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation because it is trying to fill a significant gap which called into question both the unity of the internal market and the rights of consumers, the imposition of different fees depending on whether the payment card transaction takes place within the Member State where it was contracted or in another Member State. This is yet another example of the financial fragmentation that exists in our Union and which must be thoroughly corrected by the so-called 'capital markets union' announced by the Commission, the Green Paper of which we have just known. This Regulation introduces a cap on so-called 'exchange fees' of 0.2% per transaction for debit cards and 0.3% for credit cards, irrespective of whether those payment transactions are domestic or cross-border, which is undoubtedly a major step forward. However, Member States are allowed to set lower limits for national transactions, which remains contradictory to the spirit of the Treaty, which is no longer just about a common market but a single market.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the further transparency of transaction fees which will ensure that card companies cannot get away with charging exorbitant amounts for processing payments. It is imperative that the savings retailers will make through this regulation be passed onto consumers. I hope and expect, therefore, that this regulation will lead to a reduction in the cost of goods in shops and online.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pablo Zalba Bidegain's report on interchange fees for card-related payment transactions. The text aims to reduce interchange fees (fees paid by financial institutions during credit and debit transactions), and aims at greater transparency (requiring banks to inform on applied rates, maximum of 0.3%) and mechanically to competition, and thus a reduction in the costs borne by consumers.  I welcome the adoption by a large majority of this report

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the regulation on interchange fees for card-related payment transactions. It aims to cap interchange fees and standardise the technical and commercial aspects of card payment transactions within the EU. Indeed, the wide variety of interchange fees that currently exists has led to a fragmentation of the market.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Card fees for domestic and foreign transactions can have a negative impact on household costs. Low card fees can reduce household costs. Similarly, the proposed fee reduction of 0.2% of sales on credit card transactions and 0.3% on ATM card transactions is an important step towards forcing cross-border transactions by individuals and expanding e-commerce. At the same time, the report deals with a strengthening of data protection. For these reasons, I can only vote in favour of the report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the potential benefits to consumers, I supported the proposal for a regulation on interbank commissions applicable to card-based payment transactions at the European Parliament's plenary session in Strasbourg. When you pay with bank payment cards, their users pay a commission fee. The high level of its high is determined by the markets by mutual agreement between the banks. The European Commission's investigation showed that there is insufficient competition for interbank payments for card use on the market and therefore prices are high and it was concluded that it was difficult for new companies to enter this market.  The law provides for a ceiling of 0.2% for debit cards and 0.3% for credit cards from the payment amount. According to the assessment of the developers of this law, these ceilings should be sufficient to reduce the cost of bank payment cards that would be felt by consumers. It is also in the opinion that banks will be forced to pass on costs to other services they provide, for which consumers will simply now have to pay more. Despite the banks' opposition, such legislation has also been introduced in the US, Australia and Switzerland. The real benefits will have to be assessed at a later stage, but the potential benefits - cheaper use of cards - are sufficient to support this regulation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the regulation as it promises to cut costs for card users by creating common rules for interchange fees in the European Union through the introduction of maximum fee levels of 0.2% for debit transactions and 0.3% for credit transactions on both cross-border and domestic card-based payments. It will also greatly enhance transparency, allowing retailers and consumers to make better informed choices of payment instruments.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation as it will bring down costs for both consumers and retailers. For far too long card schemes and banks have been able to increase the fees that we are all charged when we use our debit and credit cards, without any competition to bring these prices down. This regulation will change that, and should make the purchases we make cheaper and the fees we are charged more transparent.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 10 March 2015, I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. Under this directly applicable regulation, the fees charged by banks to merchants for processing card payments should be capped in the EU. And it must be said that it was time, because at present interchange fees for card payments are not transparent and vary widely between EU Member States. It was necessary to intervene to prevent traders and customers from being robbed of absurdly high fees, which served only to accumulate the huge profits of the banks that issued the credit card. This ceiling, which will apply to both cross-border and domestic payments, should ultimately lead to a reduction in the costs of payment card users and create a level playing field for payments across Europe. Since both traders and shoppers should benefit from lower fees, I decided to support this regulation in the vote.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Pablo Zalba Bidegain. The proposal for a regulation aims to improve the conditions for the functioning and development of the internal market in payments. In fact, the removal of direct and indirect obstacles to the functioning of an integrated market for electronic payments is necessary for the proper functioning of the European internal market.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of legislation to cap the fees charged by banks to merchants to process credit card payments made by their customers. This provision will lead to a concrete reduction in costs for consumers as well as for merchants.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The fees associated with card payments reveal the lack of interoperability between terminals and are an obstacle to better competition. The cap on commissions for proposed debit and credit card payments is also a laudable step forward and which I support. I voted in favour of the whole text, which improves the conditions for competition, economic activities and transparency in the management of means of payment.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it caps the cost of each cross-border transaction made by credit card at 0.2% of the value of the transaction. Within five years, the same cap will apply to domestic transactions. This text thus doubly protects the interests of consumers.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote for. Bank card issuers charge merchants a fee, interchange fees, passed on to selling prices. The aim of the regulation is to cap these fees, to make them more transparent, to tackle exclusivity clauses and various technical mechanisms that limit the possibility of using different cards from the same payment terminal.  This is in the interest of consumers and merchants as this will reduce commissions and make it easier to accept any type of card for the payment of purchases. Some cards are often refused, especially abroad, and some small merchants continue to refuse cards below a certain amount. The regulation improves the situation.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The legislative report has been agreed in trilogue with the Council, the result of which has been approved by a large majority and represents a significant improvement in the rights of credit card users.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a series of positive steps for card users in the European Union. Different card types are one of the main means of payment in the different EU Member States; however, the lack of uniform legislation has allowed numerous abuses by many financial companies to the detriment of their clients. This report is aimed at harmonising payment systems to prevent this type of abuse and provide a stronger legal framework in payment transactions, whether domestic or international. As it is a proposal for a Regulation which can significantly improve the protection of users of this type of means of payment, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU remains convinced that it can eliminate customer costs and force companies to provide something for nothing. A cap on card transaction fees may lead to a reduction in the number of banks offering free account management – according to some reports, similar changes in the US have been the main reason why banks have done just that. In addition, the banking sector will have to introduce a cross-subsidy for payment terminals if it cannot charge an appropriate price for the operation of this element of the payment system. This will make news, such as contactless payments, harder to finance. This will, as a result, suppress the competition instead of supporting it. That is why I voted against this proposal. The European Union would do better to stop burdening small businesses, including small banks, with disproportionate regulation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a regulation between the European Parliament and the Council on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. I believe that this Regulation will create an integrated and transparent market for cross-border and domestic card payments, thematically reducing the fragmentation of the internal market. In particular, this Regulation will present maximum limits on interchange fees for card payment transactions. A limit of 0.2% per transaction will be set for debit transactions, while a limit of 0.3% per transaction will be set for credit transactions. A three-way payment card system, such as American Express and Diners and commercial cards intended for business expenses, will be exempted from this Regulation. The presentation of the limit for interchange fees for card-based payment transactions will reduce costs for merchants of €6 billion year-on-year, reducing the cost to citizens.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the regulation voted today by an overwhelming majority, which establishes a ceiling on fees for bank card transactions. The fact is that in recent years more and more European Union citizens prefer card payments rather than cash. With the new legislation thus voted, the conditions for payment on the territory of all EU member states, including Bulgaria, will be aligned.  The maximum fee for debit card payments from now on will be 0.2% and for credit card transactions 0.3%. This is extremely good news for the growth and development of the EU economy, as this reduces costs for consumers and traders.  It is estimated that the cap thus voted on could save EU businesses around £6bn. eur 100 million per year. In addition, a requirement for more transparency is introduced when charging non-cash payments. The effect of all this will be stimulating competition.  We have an example of European legislation at supranational level, entirely in the service of citizens, which achieves such a degree of harmonisation as individual Member States could not reach one by one. This is the European Union in its most positive form – useful for both consumers and businesses!

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very pleased with today's vote on the report on interchange fees applicable to card-based payment transactions. This is a very important step that will help us gradually overcome the financial feudalism in the European Union, which is still a challenge for our citizens and entrepreneurs.  When we take the first step, we also need to think about the next one. For example, when European companies transfer money to their partners outside the European Union, the fee for this transfer is very high. Very often, the fee for transferring money in euro from the European Union to another country turns out to be higher than the transfer in dollars. In addition, most of this fees are charged by European Union banks. Such a high fee has no financial justification, there is only a desire to receive an inadequately high profit at the expense of others. This makes life difficult, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, which make small payments. Consequently, we still have a lot to do in this direction.  I would like to thank everyone who has worked with the report adopted today, and I would like to wish all of us to move in the right direction in the right direction.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Consumers are mostly unaware of the fees paid by merchants for the payment instrument they use. The various incentive practices applied by issuers (such as travel vouchers, bonuses, rebates, reverse transactions, free insurance, etc.) can encourage consumers to use payment instruments and thus generate high fee revenues. This must be avoided. The fees charged by banks to retailers for processing card payments need to have a clearly defined ceiling throughout the EU. Both cross-border and domestic card payments will be subject to limits. This will reduce costs for merchants and cardholders themselves.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Supplementary Report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card payment transactions, because the removal of direct and indirect obstacles to the proper functioning and completion of the single market for electronic payments, without discrimination between national and cross-border payments, is essential for the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted for this proposal because it is a step in the right direction to limit bank fees and force networks to compete more. In addition, this text gives Member States the right to intervene with further discounts on domestic transactions, and the fees for card transactions are officially increased: interchange fees for debit cards cannot exceed 0.2%, and 0.3% for credit cards.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal, which I regard as good for consumers and good for business, particularly small businesses.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Ladies and gentlemen, this Regulation, combined with the revised proposals of the Payment Services Directives, will create common rules for interchange costs in the European Union by introducing a minimum level of expenses for credit card payment transactions. It will also introduce transparency measures to enable retailers and consumers to choose their payment methods more clearly. With the introduction of this regulation, the fixed costs that banks impose on sellers to process payments will be limited. The proposed rules aim to increase transparency, stimulate competition and allow both sellers and customers to choose the card scheme that offers them the best conditions.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has seen a fragmentation of its internal market in recent years. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the European internal market, it is necessary to work with the aim of removing the direct and indirect obstacles that prevent the full efficiency of electronic payments. I voted in favour of the Bidegain report because it aims to improve the conditions for the functioning and development of the internal market in payments.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 It is necessary to put limits on the opaque commissions that citizens pay for payment by card and therefore my support for the new regulations, which will allow the fees that banks charge to merchants to process their buyers' payments to be limited, which will mean a reduction in costs for users.  With the new regulation, we establish more transparent rules on both cross-border and domestic payments, which is in the best interests of everyone, both retailers and buyers. This legislation, together with the forthcoming Payment Services Directive, will set a level playing field for payments across Europe and should substantially improve the transparency of commissions, stimulate competition and allow retailers and users to choose the card networks that offer them the best conditions.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I have received my support for the Regulation on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions, as I broadly support the MIF Regulation, which limits the level of interchange fees for card payments and prohibits anti-competitive business rules and practices.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because this Regulation lays down uniform technical and commercial requirements for card-based payment transactions in the Union where both the payer's payment service provider and the payee's payment service provider are located in the Union. This will help to reduce the prices of interbank operations for consumers.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it introduces a cap payment on card fees that banks charge retailers to process shoppers’ payments. This should result in lower costs for consumers as well as retailers.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to improve the functioning of the internal market for card payments. Indeed, one of the main practices hindering card payments is the widespread existence of interchange fees. Interchange fees are interbank fees applied between acquiring banks and card issuers. Every year, 9 billion euros of interchange fees are levied in the European Union.  Merchants, in turn, pass these card-related costs on to the price of their goods and services. In practice, competition between card systems is designed to convince as many payment service providers as possible to choose their cards, which generally results in higher costs (advertisements, ancillary benefits, etc.). In fact, it is a private consumption tax.  The regulation states that "payment service providers do not offer or charge an interchange fee per transaction of more than 0.2% of the transaction value for any debit card transaction [and] 0.3% for credit cards." Finally, it is a question of tackling (somewhat) the profits of banks to reduce the cost to consumers. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The fragmentation of the internal market undermines competitiveness, growth and job creation in the Union. With a view to the proper functioning of the internal market, it is necessary to remove direct and indirect obstacles to the smooth functioning and completion of an integrated market for electronic payments, without distinguishing between national and cross-border payments. I agree with the objectives of this proposal, hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as it will finally cap the high fees that are charged to retailers to process credit or debit card payments. This legislation should therefore result in savings for consumers and businesses alike across the EU.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Payment cards have gained widespread popularity of all ages of consumers across the EU in the last decade and are the most commonly used electronic payment instrument for purchases.  However, the payment card market in the Union is not yet sufficiently integrated, as there are many national barriers to many payment solutions and their providers, including preventing market entry.  In my opinion, the same rules must be laid down for payments throughout the EU, which will not only clarify the market situation for consumers and businesses, but will also lead to more dynamic competition in the internal market. Since my interest is to facilitate the effective functioning of the internal market and to facilitate the use of electronic payments for the benefit of traders and consumers, I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was really happy to vote in favour of the regulation on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. This regulation is an important consumer policy reform based on which consumers can look forward to saving EUR 730 million every year. The legislation will set caps for card payment fees that banks can charge retailers when a purchase is made via a debit or credit card. As retailers in turn usually pass on the fees to the customer, the new ceilings should lead to lower prices for goods and services.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Basically we have a maze of legal rules in Europe about and around the fees you pay on your card transactions. This proposal is aiming to unify that market and make sure we as consumers can avoid traps while paying. I have had a few painful personal experiences in this matter.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft regulation on interchangovernment fees for card-based payment transactions can contribute to the integration of the Union's internal market, the integration of money market transactions and fair and transparent competition in banking services, in particular cross-border payment transactions. Its adoption would be a step towards deepening European integration and would therefore be in line with the long-term vision of my party, the Democratic Coalition, the Creation of a United States of Europe, in addition to its practical benefits. The regulation can count on my support in the later stages of legislation.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. The proposed text makes two improvements that will benefit consumers and merchants. Reducing and capping interchange fees on bank cards, even on small amounts, contributes to lower consumer prices. By promoting the interoperability of payment terminals and by breaking down certain restrictions on the use of competing network cards, we are also taking a step towards wider acceptance of all bank cards. However, we should go even further, particularly by being more direct, but the measures proposed today are moving in the right direction.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this supplementary report on the european Parliament and Council's proposed regulation on interchange fees for card-related payment transactions. This text is indeed in the direction of more security, which appears to be a positive element.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Certain Member States have adopted or are drafting legislation to regulate, directly or indirectly, interchange fees, covering areas such as the ceilings applicable to interchange fees, merchant service fees or acceptance of all cards by the service provider. I am in favour of the definition of uniform technical and commercial requirements for payment transactions and there is no differentiation within the European Union. I am therefore in favour of the new rules which should enter into force within six months, stipulating a maximum amount for bank fees that should not exceed 0.3 % on the value of the transaction, in the case of credit card payments, and 0.2 % when the debit card is the chosen payment method.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the regulation is both consumer and business—friendly as it will bring down costs for consumers and retailers. For far too long, card schemes and banks have been able to increase the fees that we are all charged when we use our debit and credit cards, without any competition to bring these prices down. The regulation will change that, and should make the purchases we make cheaper and the fees we are charged more transparent.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which introduces more transparency in the area of interchange fees for transactions carried out with a payment card. These fees, which are paid by the merchant's bank to the bank that issued the customer's bank card, are not the same from one Member State to another.  The text I voted requires banks to communicate transparently on these commissions and caps them at 0.3% of the transaction. As merchants pass interchange fees on their prices, this text will restore purchasing power to consumers.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of this proposal is another tool aimed at removing direct and indirect obstacles to the functioning and completion of the EU internal market. In this case, our aim is to promote the creation of an integrated market for electronic payments, without any distinction between national and cross-border payments. Unfortunately, we are fully aware of how damaging the fragmentation of the internal market is to competitiveness, growth and job creation in the Union. In order for consumers, operators and businesses to enjoy the full benefits of the internal market, it is essential that the electronic payments they use are safe, efficient, competitive and innovative. In order to ensure greater legal certainty, as administrative decisions in force in some Member States often vary significantly from one member state to the other, ways of bringing interbank fee levels more into line need to be found. In addition to the uniform application of competition rules to interchange fees, regulating such fees would improve the functioning of the internal market and help reduce transaction costs for European consumers.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this supplementary report because it sets out rules on interchange fees for card-linked payment transactions in order to contribute to the establishment of an EU-wide payment market. As such, I am in favour of better harmonization of these practices in order to simplify and promote the trading regime on our continent.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when card payments are spreading more and more, a business model still prevails which favours the exosses of multilateral interchange fees (MIF) and which, by affecting the costs borne by retailers, ultimately affects the prices charged to consumers.  The regulation set out in the aforementioned report proposes to introduce ceilings for commissions charged to consumers on debit and credit card transactions and prohibits the application of increases for these types of cards. The increases are in common use, particularly in the purchase of air tickets. Thanks to the ceilings applied to interchange fees, the costs of card transactions charged to retailers will be significantly reduced and, therefore, the motivation behind the increases will be removed. Since the proposal for a regulation will improve the conditions for the functioning and development of the internal market in payments and will promote greater consumer protection, I have decided to support the report with a vote in favour.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the capping of interchange fees of 0.2% for debit payments and 0.3% for credit payments.  Internet payments are becoming cheaper and safer for retailers and consumers alike.  We are also succeeding in ending the imposition of excessively high tariffs and, more importantly, of misleading consumers.  Moreover, we ensure a level playing field for payment service providers, which will result in new players being helped to enter the market.  I think the regulation is beyond itself, because I hope it will encourage innovation. The introduction of new mobile and internet payment solutions would also improve the EU's competitiveness.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the regulation of interchange fees for card payment, it is far from certain that it will fulfil its intended purpose, i.e. to make goods or services cheaper for end customers. It deals with only one part of card payments, which is linked to the complicated system that ensures the financing and development of non-cash payments. The main chance is that the trend of increasing the use of cards will ensure that the increased use of payment cards will compensate for the decrease in the price per unit of the transaction and the development of non-cash payments will not stop. The main reason for supporting regulation for me was the situation where the past disputes between the Commission and card companies created a non-transparent environment that would make regulation more transparent. A lack of regulation would preserve today's situation, which would probably be worse. However, more than direct regulation, I would welcome greater transparency in fees, especially in view of the relatively high costs for small firms that want to accept payment cards. But regulation is unlikely to improve their situation.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The report promises a lot of positives. An example of this would be the reduction of hidden charges for private customers, which amounts to around EUR 6 billion a year, which is reduced as a result. It will also increase the transparency of card transactions and pave the way for the introduction of innovative payment technologies. I therefore voted in favour of the motion.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for card-based interchange fees, as this will contribute significantly to reducing costs in the long term. A situation where distinctions are made between national and cross-border payments hinders the functioning of the internal market and undermines competitiveness. The promotion, simplification and promotion of electronic payments will also help to combat the black market.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report because measures must be implemented as soon as possible in order to complete the integration of the payment card market and to remove obstacles to the effective functioning of the existing card market. The EU must be treated equally and legal certainty is ensured. It is therefore necessary to lay down uniform technical and commercial requirements for card-based payment transactions carried out in the Union. The measures envisaged would reduce costs for businesses and prices for payment service users. Another important aspect is to make the payment system more transparent, reliable, safer.  I believe that it is appropriate to set a maximum interchange fee for all debit and credit card-based payment transactions. The consistent application of competition rules to interchange fees and the regulation of such fees would improve the functioning of the internal market and help to reduce transaction prices for consumers.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the fragmentation of the internal market is detrimental to competitiveness, growth and job creation in the Union; Whereas the removal of direct and indirect obstacles to the proper functioning and completion of an integrated market for electronic payments, without distinction between national and cross-border payments, is necessary for the proper functioning of the internal market; Given that Directive 2007/64/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council (8) provided the legal basis for the creation of an internal market in Payments of the Union, as it substantially favoured the activity of payment service providers by providing for uniform rules on the provision of payment services, I therefore voted in favour.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is in order to protect consumers that I am in favour of adopting this resolution, which makes it possible to regulate interchange fees in a unified and coordinated manner at European level. In order for the internal market to function, we must ensure that direct and indirect obstacles to the functioning and completion of an integrated market for electronic payments are removed, removing the distinction between national and cross-border payments. Applying European competition rules for interchange fees will improve the functioning of the internal market but, above all, reduce the costs of transactions, to the benefit of all European citizens. It is also important for Member States to establish sanctions applicable to breaches of the regulation, ensuring that these sanctions are effective and dissuasive and are applied.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I fully support the limitation of interchange fees for card payments under which the debit card fee would be a maximum of 0.2% and for credit 0.3%. Existing administrative decisions vary considerably in some Member States.  Barriers to the efficient functioning of the card market, including in the area of card-based payments and mobile and online card-based payments, should be removed. Compared to the more developed countries of the European Union, such as France, Italy and the Netherlands, Croatia has significantly higher fees for interbank card transactions. The amounts of compensation for interbank card transactions in Croatia amounted to up to 5% of the total price of the product, while in Denmark they amounted to only 0.1%. In this way, consumer discrimination with regard to the place of purchase will be abolished. Since the average Croatian consumer uses an average of two cards, this is a very welcome provision for Croatian and European consumers.  Fragmentation of the internal market distorts competition, growth and job creation within the Union. Removing direct and indirect barriers to the proper functioning and establishment of an integrated market for electronic payments, without distinction between national and cross-border payments, is necessary for the proper functioning of the internal market.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support Colleague Bidegain's report because I believe this regulation will lead to the removal of direct and indirect barriers that fragment and prevent the establishment and proper functioning of the electronic payment market. As electronic payment cards are the most common payment instrument in retail, by introducing and applying regulatory measures such as a ceiling of 0.2%, calculated on the basis of the average annual transaction value of a single system, interchange fees will make the system consistent and help address mismatches on the road to full market integration. Allowing pan-European service providers to enter will result in more competition, affecting the quality of services and reducing prices, which will ultimately benefit end consumers the most. The obligation of payment service providers to report, in order to ensure the availability of all relevant information to the competent authorities, will make the system transparent. As this regulation seeks to equate fees for cross-border payments in euro with payments within Member States, the positive effects of this Regulation will be felt by all citizens of the European Union, including Croatia, through greater consumer protection and lower prices of fees.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the Eu ropean Union's internal market, it is important that there are no barriers to the smooth functioning of transactions carried out electronically, without distinguishing between national payments and cross-border payments, with uniform rules for the provision of payment services. Of course, all users of electronic payments in the single market, consumers, merchants and businesses must know that they can make them safely, efficiently and quickly, now that e-commerce is becoming more and more widespread. In order to facilitate the smooth functioning of the internal market and card-based payments, it is right that interchange fees should be uniform, whether they are minimal or at no cost. It would also be interesting for the Commission to provide a report studying the effects on the internal market of this Regulation and the benefits it brings to trade.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The capping of fees for card payments could be viewed as a restriction on the freedom to do business. In my opinion, however, this is not the case, because small consumers, sole traders and small businesses are standing here against strong banking entities that are capable of restricting the running of the free market. For this reason, on the contrary, clear rules need to be adopted in order to defend the single market. In my opinion, such rules have been brought about by the present report and have therefore received my support.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. EU citizens can move freely within the Schengen area, but borders reappear every time they make a credit card payment in another Member State. It is time to put an end to this obstacle and reduce the burden on European citizens.  The European Parliament has just adopted in plenary by a very large majority a text concerning the capping of interchange fees for card-related payment transactions. I am delighted to have voted in favour of this text. It is important that Parliament takes on the task of reducing as much as possible the obstacles and costs that come into the daily lives of European citizens.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The fragmentation of the internal market undermines competitiveness, growth and job creation in the Union. It is therefore necessary to remove direct and indirect barriers to the smooth functioning of an integrated market for secure and efficient electronic payments, without distinguishing between national and cross-border payments, so that consumers, traders and businesses can fully benefit from the advantages of the single market, especially as it evolves globally into e-commerce. Of course, obstacles to the efficient functioning of the card market, including in the area of card payments and internet and mobile payments associated with card transactions, need to be removed. Card-related payment transactions, rather than cash payments, could be advantageous for merchants and consumers, provided that the fees for using card payment systems are set at an economically efficient level, while contributing to fair competition, innovation and the entry of new entrants into the market. In view of this framework, this proposal for a Regulation shall subject payment transactions associated with debit and credit cards to a maximum interchange fee. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that all payment transactions associated with debit and credit cards should, at most, be subject to an interchange fee with a defined limit. The information resulting from the assessments made on this subject indicates that the ban on interchange fees for debit card transactions will be beneficial for the widespread acceptance and use of cards, for the development of the single market and will generate more benefits for merchants and consumers. I therefore believe that, in view of the current situation, a single maximum level of exchange fees should be imposed for both national and cross-border exchange fees for card transactions.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this new regulation on credit and debit card fees by banks because it will have a direct positive impact on both merchants and consumers.  Finally, these new rules address the problem of the lack of competition in the payment card industry, which forces merchants to accept excessive charges in order to offer this service to their customers.  It is therefore a concrete case of European legislation having a direct positive impact on people's daily lives. By reducing these costs by around 6 billion euros, this new regulation allows the profits of the Visa-MasterCard duopoly to be resized for the benefit of consumers who are generally passed on commission fees.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I support the cap on interchange fees for card-related payment transactions and have supported this report.   Each time a consumer makes a card payment, interchange fees are charged by the cardholder's bank to a retailer's bank. As the most frequently used payment instrument, these fees will affect millions of consumers without their ever-knowing.  We have thereby decided to cap commissions for credit card or debit card transactions to all Member States in order to converge the amounts applied. Through this text, we reduce the fragmentation of the internal market which is detrimental to Europe's growth and economic activity and establish a safe and effective framework for electronic payments for both consumers and merchants.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At a time when we have evolved globally into e-commerce, the existence of secure, efficient, competitive and innovative electronic payments is crucial for consumers, traders and businesses to fully benefit from the benefits of the single market. Creating uniform rules for electronic payment methods is a useful tool in eliminating any barrier to freedom in the provision of services.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it represents a considerable improvement in the rights of credit card users. In particular, it makes progress in removing obstacles to the efficient functioning of the card market, including the scope of card payments and card-based mobile and online payments, determines that all debit and credit card-based payment transactions must be subject to a maximum exchange rate rate and clarifies the costs for transactions performed under so-called 'universal cards' , among others.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today voted on the inter-institutional agreement on the regulation capping multilateral interchange fees (MICs) for immediate debit and credit card payments. As a reminder, MICs are paid by a merchant's bank to the bank of the cardholder of the payment card used for the transaction. Allowed in some Member States at different maximum levels (up to 1.5%), they are prohibited elsewhere. Consumer organizations are a reminder of how these MICs provide excessive revenue to the Mastercard and Visa networks and how they are ultimately passed on to the price of goods acquired by the consumer.  The vote in this report should therefore be a game-changer, and I welcome it because, in accordance with the new provisions, retailers who choose a card system will now have to accept only cards in this system which are subject to the ceiling provisions. By exercising this right, they could accept a reduced range of cards, but capped commissions would also have to result in lower costs for both retailers and customers (for example, for all credit card payments, the cap will now be set at 0.3% of the value of the transaction).

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because it is clear that until now the Commission and the national competition authorities have not succeeded in curbing the abuse of interchange fees. However, the situation should now improve at least slightly.  I am pleased that a maximum interchange fee of 0.2 per cent will apply to debit card payments in the near future and 0.3 per cent when paying with a credit card. Prices for services and goods are likely to remain the same. On the other hand, the lower tax will have some positive aspects. Firstly, the solution is important for small and medium-sized businesses, which, without wanting to pay excessive fees, have often been unable to offer customers bank card payments. I believe that, after the entry into force of this decision, there will also be a gradual increase in bank card payment places. Secondly, the tax reduction should encourage people to use bank cards more often, which will also contribute to the fight against the shadow economy.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Regulation on the creation of a ceiling for interchange fees for card-based payment transactions carried out within the European Union. Within 6 months, 0.2 % will be the rate set for debit card payments and 0.3% the percentage for credit card payments, with the exception of the 5-year transition period in national payment transactions. Until now, interchange fees have been the responsibility of national authorities, creating a sharp unevening in all Member States. This regulation was intended not only to prevent the generalisation of excessive levels of these rates, but also to increase transparency, ensure fair conditions of competition and to promote the creation of a European-wide payment market that benefits. This measure directly benefits traders who, in this way, reflect in their prices the decrease in the fees to be paid to banks and, likewise, indirectly benefits consumers, who enjoy this price reduction in the goods and services they purchase.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report will allow for the introduction of uniform rules for credit card payments in Europe. As a result, the fees charged by banks to merchants to make credit card payments to their customers will be capped and transparency measures for merchants and consumers will be increased. This cap on fees on credit card transactions could have a long-term impact, thereby reducing costs for both consumers and merchants. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome Mr McDerman's report. Zalba Bidegain because the purpose of this regulation is to improve the conditions for the functioning and development of the market in cases of card payments, all thanks to the creation of common rules and by setting ceilings for commission expenses. This means being closer to the citizens of Europe.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because the text, compared to the text initially presented by the European Commission, is more balanced, setting a threshold for interchange fees and leaving it to the Member States to intervene, further reducing them with regard to domestic transactions.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report, in favour of establishing for the first time a European regulation on the fees that consumers pay for credit card transactions. In a context where means of payment are increasingly centralized under the control of an oligopoly of a few private companies, it was urgent to establish an international regulation that would put a stand in place. The Directive sets a maximum cap on credit card payment fees, with the possibility for Member States to set smaller caps, with the lowest being the one to always be respected in the case of international transactions. While our position would have been to completely eliminate these rates, we still believe that this regulation goes in a positive sense to end certain abusive practices and protect small businesses and consumers.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which sets out provisions capping the fees charged by banks to retailers when paying credit cards. The aim is to regulate commission rates for national and cross-border card payments in order to reduce the final cost to users.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. This report seems to us to be in line with a reduction in interchange fees when using a payment card, thus facilitating transparency, which is a good thing for businesses. I voted for it.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the proposal for a regulation on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions, as card payments are becoming increasingly popular among consumers. If traders do not offer them, they usually indicate the amount of fees for these transactions as the reason.  The negotiated ceilings will lead to a real reduction in the costs of payment card users. The modification will allow merchants to choose the card providers that offer the most favourable terms. Rules within the EU internal market are also being harmonised, which is also important for online shopping from abroad. All of these facts will, I believe, also have an advantage for end consumers. Of course, it will also depend on the approach of specific traders.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a series of positive steps for card users in the European Union. Different card types are one of the main means of payment in the different EU Member States; however, the lack of uniform legislation has allowed numerous abuses by many financial companies to the detriment of their clients. This report is aimed at harmonising payment systems to prevent this type of abuse and provide a stronger legal framework in payment transactions, whether domestic or international. As it is a proposal for a Regulation which can significantly improve the protection of users of this type of means of payment, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the multilateral interchange fees regulation because it will bring down costs for both consumers and retailers. The cap on credit and debit card transaction fees will save British business an estimated GBP 480 million a year and will make shoppersʼ lives a little clearer, a little fairer and a lot cheaper. The caps will be applied from six months after the regulation comes into force and the rest of the measures will start to be applied after 12 months.  We support the measures to cap credit card transaction fees at 0.3 % and a cap of 0.2 % for debit card transaction fees. For far too long, card schemes and banks have been able to increase the fees that we are all charged when we use our debit and credit cards without any competition to bring these prices down.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation. However, it should be noted that the proposal to set a cap on fees wants to reduce them, but in practice it may mean the opposite. Several similar attempts in the past have not shown a direct benefit to the consumer. The consequence may be the exact opposite – an increase in fees. This is the right intention, but in regulation, the EU often spends its declared effort.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I supported the legislative proposal to determine that the fees that banks charge retailers for processing card payments will have a defined ceiling throughout the EU. The limits that will apply to both cross-border and domestic card payments will lead to a reduction in costs for both merchants and cardholders. This legislation, together with the future Payment Services Directive, will create the same rules for payments across Europe. It will contribute to greater transparency of charges, promote competition and enable retailers as well as users to choose the payment card regime that offers them the best conditions. At present, payment cards are the most commonly used electronic payment instrument for retail purchases, so secure, efficient, competitive and innovative electronic payments are essential if consumers, merchants and companies are to fully reap the benefits of the internal market, all the more so as e-commerce is increasingly used in the world.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ European Parliament has adopted new rules for interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. The new directive focuses on reducing existing over-transactions that consumers pay to banks. The amendment adopted will be particularly welcome for small and medium-sized enterprises and, of course, for all consumers. This vote and parliament's adoption of amendments have shown how the EU's legislatim can have a positive impact on the lives of the citizens of the European Union. The lack of competition in the card payment transactions sector has led to users paying too high costs in Europe. This change will have a direct impact on the reduction of fees by six billion euros, thus making Visi and Mastercard healthy. Especially taking into account the fact that commissions are a direct burden on consumers, which will further reduce their costs when paying for products and services online. Nevertheless, the final agreement still contains some shortcomings, mainly due to the very intensive and persistent lobbying of banks and credit companies. In any case, these shortcomings are nowhere to be firmly concreted and will be remedied over time for the good of EU consumers and citizens. For the reasons set out above, I supported and voted for the adopted new rules on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I voted with great conviction for this report. The EU is reducing the excessive cost of accepting payment cards. The agreement between Member States and Parliament to set a legal limit on the fees that banks and credit card companies can charge is a good thing.  Retailers in Europe pay €6 billion a year too much to accept payment cards because there is no healthy competition in the payment market. Consumers end up paying the price for that. This legislation will put an end to this. Visa and MasterCard currently have a duopoly on the European market. These companies and the banks that provide their cards make big money from this lack of competition at the expense of retailers who end up passing on higher prices to consumers. The intense lobbying of the payment industry has not been successful. Parliament has defended the interests of consumers rather than the excessive profits of these credit card giants. From now on, a maximum rate of 0.3% of the purchase amount for credit card transactions and 0.2% applies to payments that are deducted directly from the account (debit). However, Member States may also choose to set a fixed amount of up to 5 cents per transaction.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \u2012 There are areas where regulation is unnecessary because there is natural competition. The area of interchange fees is one such example, and excessive interference here can cause prices to rise for people.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In order to enable the internal market to function effectively, the use of electronic payments should be improved and facilitated for the benefit of merchants and consumers. Cards and other electronic payments can be used in a more varied way, including online payment options to take advantage of the internal market and e-commerce, while electronic payments also allow merchants potentially secure payments.  This Regulation lays down uniform technical and business conditions for card-based payment transactions made within the Union when both the payer's payment service provider and the payee's payment service provider are located in the Union. Interchange fees are a major part of the fees that acquiring payment service providers charge merchants for each card-based payment transaction.  In order to facilitate the smooth functioning of the internal market in the area of card-based payments and online and mobile card-based payments, for the benefit of consumers and merchants, this Regulation should apply to cross-border and domestic issuance and acceptance of card-based payment transactions, and therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that European Union citizens should not have to bear the burden of high interchange fees for card-based payment transactions, and so I voted in favour of this report. At present, card schemes and banks have the ability to increase the fees that we are charged for using our debit and credit cards, without any competition to bring these prices down. This regulation will change this, bringing more transparent fees and lower costs for both consumers and retailers.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I support this report, as this regulation, together with the proposed revised Payment Services Directive, should create common rules for cross-governments in the European Union by introducing maximum fees for card payment transactions whose use is widespread with consumers and are difficult to refuse or charge by merchants.  Regulation would thus introduce more transparency, while allowing both consumers and retailers to be better informed when choosing a payment method. The ceiling imposed for the cross-end will apply equally to domestic and cross-border card payments and should reduce the cost to cardholders.  For cross-border debit card transactions, the agreed ceiling is 0.2% of the transaction value. For domestic transactions , Member States may impose a limit of 0.2% of the annual pondned average of the transaction value of all total domestic transactions within the card system. For credit card transactions, the deal is 0.3% of the transaction value.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the additional report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions, as fragmentation of the internal market is damaging competitiveness, growth and job creation in the Union. If we want to improve the functioning of the internal market, we must remove direct and indirect barriers to proper functioning and establish an integrated market for electronic payments without distinguishing between national and cross-border payments. I also agree that safe, efficient, competitive and innovative electronic payments are key so that consumers, traders and businesses can reap the full benefits of the internal market, which is increasingly important in an increasingly e-commerce-oriented environment.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Banks should not be left free and independent to operate without the control of states.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchangovernment fees for card-based payments, since the smooth functioning of the internal market requires that they also complete an integrated market for electronic payments, which would also contribute to reducing transaction costs for consumers. The distinction between payment transactions at home and abroad should be avoided, as it adversely affects both traders, entrepreneurs and consumers.  Card-based payment transactions are an area which, by its very nature, must be managed at European level. The Commission's efforts to remove obstacles to the efficient functioning of card-based payments, and, in this context, mobile phone and internet payments based on card payments, are therefore to be welcomed. This and steps like this are what citizens expect of the European Union and which can really bring that Union closer to its people.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that protecting consumers from unfair bank fees is a key objective and a battle worth fighting. Thus, I was happy to vote yes on the report concerning payments known as multilateral interchange fees (MIFs), which are charges during transactions between merchants and the buyer’s banks. The report sets a maximum fee level for transactions with payment cards that are used by consumers at 0.2 % for debit cards and 0.3 % for credit card transactions. The report allows Member States to define transaction cap fees within a certain range for domestic transactions. It also includes transparency measures for retailers, which will allow consumers to make more informed decisions about possible charges. The differences between national MIFs have distorted the single market, so I have supported the objectives of this report.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of interchange fees has been on the EP agenda since 2013. The time has come to take an informed decision on reducing costs for European consumers who waste more than EUR 6 billion every year on uncontrollable interchange fees. By capping interchange fees on card transactions, we can contribute to a considerable increase in consumption in Europe and, at the same time, create quantifiable benefits for the SME sector in Europe. It is our duty to protect European consumers from banking products and services and to ensure a transparent environment, clear and predictable costs and fairness in their relationship with credit institutions and traders. At the same time, this draft legislation protects consumers from partial payment of fees that are still developing in an uncontrolled environment. Many Romanians have suffered in their relationship with creditors, becoming prisoners of ever-increasing monthly installments, from the lack of transparency and correct information on the risks taken at the time of signing contracts. I give this example to put into context the fact that my decision today is for the adoption of the Interbank Fees Regulation for card-based payment transactions.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text, convinced that safe, efficient, competitive and innovative electronic payments are essential if consumers, merchants and businesses are to fully enjoy the benefits of the internal market, especially as global trade becomes electronic.  The fragmentation of the internal market is detrimental to competitiveness, growth and job creation within the Union. In order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market, it is necessary to remove direct and indirect obstacles to the proper functioning and completion of an integrated electronic payments market, in which there is no distinction between national and cross-border payments.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text which increases transparency on transaction fees. If properly implemented, this regulation will lead to a reduction in the cost of goods in shops and online and that will be to the benefit of EU citizens and companies.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Report on the Interchange Fee Regulation for card-based payment transactions proposing transparent measures for merchants and consumers, but also for other undertakings, which ultimately contributes to the development of a regulatory and legislative framework that can overcome barriers to the establishment of an integrated card payment market.  Ensuring efficient and secure electronic payment methods is essential for the establishment of a stable internal market in the area of payment cards, as we are at a time when traditional forms of payment are increasingly being abandoned and the so-called e-commerce is being moved.  For this reason, I welcome the setting of a cap on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. I hope that traders will see such a cap set with consequent reductions in retail prices and that entities earning on the basis of unrealistic and unfounded fees will respect the spirit of this provision and will not attempt to compensate for this loss by increasing other charges or introducing new ones. As there are currently no rules governing interchange fees in the European Union, I call for enhanced scrutiny in the application of these rules.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. In all my speeches, I call for greater Union competitiveness and the removal of bureaucratic burdens in business. In order for the internal market for electronic payments to function properly, it is necessary to remove all direct and indirect barriers to card acceptance in cross-border trade. Although I have supported it, I have some reservations about the administrative setting of bank charges. In my opinion, this situation should be addressed by competition in the market. I'm afraid banks will charge these fees on other items.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Europe is finally adopting legislation which, together with the forthcoming Payment Services Directive, will create equal rules for all payments made in the 28 Member States. I am convinced that the new rules will help to improve the transparency of fees and stimulate competition, allowing retailers and users to choose their card payment system under the most advantageous conditions: an advantage for both consumers and millions of merchants.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the efforts of the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council to reach a deal that intends to lower the costs of using credit cards for European citizens. This is the reason why I have voted in favour of the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The sums brewed are colossal at the level of card suppliers, but relatively painless for the consumer. Nevertheless, the interest of both the consumer and the merchants is indeed to see the commissions decrease and to be able to accept more easily any type of card for the payment of his purchases.   All too often, some cards are refused, especially abroad, and some small merchants continue to refuse cards below a certain amount. The regulation will not necessarily resolve this last point, but it will improve it. While the regulation could go further, particularly on the interoperability of payment terminals, it is a step forward. So I voted FOR this text.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Directive, which establishes for the first time a European regulation on the fees that consumers pay for credit card transactions. In a context where means of payment are increasingly centralized under the control of an oligopoly of a few private companies, it was urgent to establish an international regulation that would put a stand in place. The Directive sets a maximum cap on credit card payment fees, with the possibility for Member States to set smaller caps, with the lowest being the one to always be respected in the case of international transactions. While our position would have been to completely eliminate these rates, we still believe that this regulation goes in a positive sense to end certain abusive practices, and to protect small businesses and consumers.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it was urgent to legislate against abuses by financial institutions in their credit card fees. This agreement sets a maximum rate of 0.3% for credit card transactions and 0.2% for debit card transactions. For domestic debit card transactions Member States may use a flat rate of no more than 5 cents as an alternative to the 0.2% cap, provided that it accounts for more than 0.2% of the total value of the transaction.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is part of a legislative process in which, together with the Financial Services Directive, it ensures a level playing field in the financial sector in Europe. It has a competitive effect and helps card users to choose the most advantageous card. The rate and ceiling of the interchangovernment fee are the same as the percentage required in Hungary. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the introduction of clear rules for more transparency and restrictions on the fees banks charge merchants and buyers for debit and credit card transactions, as I believe that such a measure will significantly reduce costs for cross-border and national card payments.  I believe that the unification of the conditions for card payments in the European Union will have a positive impact on competition, as it will enable merchants and consumers to choose those card payment schemes that offer them the best terms. This requires the introduction of a fee cap for cross-border and domestic payments.
