Under today's proposal for cross-border debit card transactions, the agreed limit will amount to 0.2% of the transaction value, and the same ceiling will enter into force after 5 years for domestic payments. For smaller national debit card transactions, Member States will be able to set a maximum flat fee of €0.05 per transaction. It is also envisaged that they will be able to set a lower fee for internal credit card payments. I am convinced that today's decision will lead to lower costs for both merchants and buyers, who are currently often obliged to accept all cards under the conditions set by the banks that issued them.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Uniform European Union rules on bank card fees charged by banks to retailers for processing customer payments are extremely important because they clearly define the ceiling for these payments. The new regulation sets them at 0.2% of the purchase amount for debit card payments and 0.3% for credit cards. Both traders - especially small and medium-sized enterprises and consumers - will benefit from these rules.  We consumers often do not suspect that part of the price of the goods is also made up of the seller's mandatory payment to the bank for servicing the card. In turn, the cost of this commission to the bank is transferred to the price of the final product, for which we pay from our wallets. I therefore hope that the new rules, which I supported in the vote, will provide an incentive for traders and service providers who have so far not accepted payments with bank cards precisely because of the high costs, which are now more willing to do so. In theory, the rules contained in the Regulation could also be a good reason for the price of retail goods and services.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The MIF regulation will introduce in Europe for the first time a ceiling on interchange fees paid to banks by merchants for payments made with credit and debit cards. The regulation has aroused a great deal of enthusiasm and actually hides some grey areas and some critical issues. Commercial cards, cash withdrawals and payments made through certain payment systems (such as American Express, Diners and PayPal) in which the service is managed by a single bank per consumer and merchant are excluded from the regulation. These derogations exclude a large part of the market in the regulation, making the legislation incomplete. In order to be effective and effective, it would have been appropriate to include all payment systems and all cards. In the long term, it is possible that these exemptions will have a boomerang effect on consumers. In fact, it is very likely that the losses that banks will suffer as a result of the introduction of the ceilings will be offset by increases in consumer prices. This hypothesis is supported by recent Spanish experience of introducing roofs at national level. The regulation was negotiated during the previous parliamentary term and therefore the M5S did not have sufficient room for manoeuvre to make significant changes.  That's why the M5S preferred to abstain.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a series of positive steps for card users in the European Union. Different card types are one of the main means of payment in the different EU member states; however, the lack of uniform legislation has allowed numerous abuses by many financial companies to the detriment of their clients. This report is aimed at harmonising payment systems to prevent this type of abuse and provide a stronger legal framework in payment transactions, whether domestic or international. As it is a proposal for a Regulation which can significantly improve the protection of users of this type of means of payment, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because every time we use our credit or debit card in a shop, the retailer is being charged for the privilege, the cost of which is added on to the purchases we make. It is not a transparent system as customers are not told how much of what they are paying is to cover these fees. What the European Parliament Labour Party voted for today was to cap the fee at 0.2 % of the overall transaction amount for debit cards and at 0.3 % for credit cards. Right now the fees charged are around six times as much as the capped amount will be and by saving retailers money these savings can be passed on to consumers.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After coming at first reading to the European Parliament, this report comes back after the trilogue with positive aspects. These include the fact that payment and service providers cannot propose or demand interchange fees for each banking operation exceeding 0,2 % of the value of the transaction when it comes to debit cards.  In national operations, Member States may set a lower percentage rate ceiling than expected and impose a lump sum for the maximum rate as a limit on the amount of the resulting rate. They may also allow payment service providers to apply interchange fees per transaction of not more than EUR 0.05, revised every 5 years. As for credit cards, fees at European level are limited to levels of not more than 0.3 % of the value of the transaction. In this case, Member States may also set lower limits for national operations. In the case of universal cards, the rule for debit card transactions follows. Each Member State should define the system of penalties applicable to the infringement of this Regulation.  In the defense of those consumed, it is unacceptable to overload with this type of fees, which represent more easy profit for banks and financial companies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I supported the regulation on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. I can broadly support the MIF Regulation, which limits the amount of interchange fees for card payments and prevents anti-competitive business rules and practices.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because every time we use our credit or debit card in a shop, the retailer is being charged for the privilege, the cost of which is added on to the purchases we make. It is not a transparent system as customers are not told how much of what they are paying is to cover these fees. What the European Parliament Labour Party voted for today was to cap the fee at 0.2 % of the overall transaction amount for debit cards and at 0.3 % for credit cards. Right now the fees charged are around six times as much as the capped amount will be and by saving retailers money these savings can be passed on to consumers.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on the regulation on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions. The report adopted today aims to remove measures taken at national level that could create significant obstacles to the completion of the internal market in the field of internet and mobile card payments and would therefore hinder the freedom to provide services. The rapporteur stressed that a coherent application of the competition rules to interchange fees would reduce the costs of operations for consumers and thus improve the functioning of the internal market. I also welcome the rapporteur's recommendation that all debit card transactions should have a maximum interchange fee of 0,2 %, and all credit card transactions should have a maximum interchange fee of 0,3 % in all Member States.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr President-in-Office of the Commission's report. Zalba on the new European regulation imposing a cap on fees charged by banks to retailers in order to process their customers' payments. The new regulation will enhance transparency in payment fees, and allow shopkeepers and users to choose credit card plans that offer them the best terms. It is very important that all debit and credit card payment transactions should be subject to a maximum rate of interbank commission.

name: Damiano Zoffoli (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much welcome today's vote on the proposal for a regulation on interchange fees on card payment transactions, with which the European Parliament has put an end to the opaque fees that are applied to this type of payment and which will benefit both retailers and buyers through a reduction in costs for both. The objective that Parliament ultimately pursues is to improve the transparency of committees, stimulate competition and allow retailers and users to choose their card payment system on the most advantageous terms. I expect Parliament to continue along this path and also to adopt the Payment Services Directive as soon as possible so as to complete the legislative framework for the benefit, in particular, of customers. Companies in several European countries are still forced to face excessive costs in making electronic forms of payment available to customers; Lower interchange fees will lead to a greater spread of electronic forms of payment, also being a useful tool to combat the black economy and tax evasion.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to a proposal to regulate, directly and indirectly, the interchange fees applied by companies and banks that issue and market debit and credit cards. After coming to the European Parliament at first reading, this report comes back after the positive trilogue. These include the fact that payment and service providers cannot propose or demand interchange fees for each banking operation exceeding 0.2 % of the value of the transaction when dealing with debit cards. In the protection of consumers, with regard to e-commerce, online sales and payments with this type of cards, it is unacceptable to burden with this type of fees, which are nothing more than easy profit for banks and financial companies.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions, as the current diversity of interchange fee rates leads to market fragmentation (which is estimated to cost around EUR 130 billion per year, i.e. more than 1% of EU GDP), prevents new pan-European entrants from entering the market, prevents innovation and harms the economy. The integration of the payment card market in the EU is far from complete, although payment cards are the most common electronic payment instrument for retail purchases, and obstacles to the effective functioning of the card market, including card payments and online and mobile card-based payments, need to be removed. E-commerce is increasingly important and in order for consumers, traders and businesses to benefit from the full benefits of the internal market, it is essential to ensure the security, efficiency, competitiveness and innovation of electronic payments. This regulation will benefit businesses and consumers, strengthen consumer protection and bring more transparency to the area of online payments.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the 257 redundancies linked to the closure of a plant in the Saint-Gobain Sekurit (SGS) group, located in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. These redundancies took place during and after the reference period from 31 August 2013 to 31 December 2013 and are related to the decrease in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry in the Union. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) application for Saint-Gobain Sekurit in Belgium, based on the intervention criteria of Article 2(c) under which, in exceptional circumstances, an application may be considered admissible even if other intervention criteria are not met, given that the redundancies have a serious impact on employment and the local economy. In my own constituency in the north of Ireland the closure of Gallahers in Ballymena, which is due to shut permanently by 2017 with the loss of 877 jobs, will have a serious impact on employment and the local economy. My hope is that the EGF can be mobilised in this instance to fund reintegration of these workers into the local labour market.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report approving Belgium's application EGF/2013/011 BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the granting of a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which the Belgian authorities have requested in the wake of the 257 redundancies of Saint-Gobain. This fund was set up to provide additional support to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Fund finances individually adapted measures for the reintegration of jobseekers, promotes self-employment and business start-ups, and grants mobility allowances and allowances for disadvantaged or older workers. The company's redundancies can be explained by the fact that the decline in car safety glass production in the EU and the increasing market share of competitors from outside the EU and their increasing imports into the EU have led to an increase in the number of workers in saint-gobain. It is therefore gratifying that the EU has accepted Belgium's request and is providing funds to support the redundant workers, in the hope of helping them to achieve lasting, long-term and therefore stable employment through the measures taken.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Belgium, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, although I have some reservations about the relevance of the timetable for the implementation of this tool, I support its primary vocation. For my part, support for globalization should be achieved upstream or at the beginning of the company's financial problems rather than when the number of licensees is counted.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Belgian purposes in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Saint-Gobain Sekurit operating in the automotive industry. According to the data provided by the Belgian authorities, the production sector for safety glass for the automotive industry has suffered severe economic shocks due to several factors, such as the decrease in the production of safety glass for the EU automotive industry, the increase in the market share of competitors from non-EU countries and the increase in imports of these products into the European Union. A total of EUR 1 339 928 is intended to be allocated to 257 redundant workers from the EGF. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, knowing that this 'adjustment fund' is only a bad thing: if it really wants to combat the deleterious effects of globalisation, the European Union must renounce the dogma of the free movement of goods and people and no longer stand in the way of the implementation of protectionist measures. I note that Belgium, the host country of most European institutions, is particularly affected by the irresponsible policies of the Eurocrats who are sacrificing Europe's industries on the altar of the sacrosanct free movement of goods, capital and people.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested the support of the EGF after the 257 redundancies at Saint Gobain Sekurit in Auvelais, which specialises in glass manufacturing for the automotive industry following the collapse of the glass market. Europe will release almost 1.34 million euros, which will help to strengthen support for workers in training and reintegration into the workforce. Another case on the glass sector will be filed soon. It concerns the assistance that will have to be provided to the 400 workers of AGC in Roux and Saint Gobain Glass in Auvelais. Europe could release EUR 1 million in the coming months and it goes without saying that I will be extremely attentive to the developments of the dossier.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF following 257 redundancies following the closure of a saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS) site in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. We are being asked to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 1,339,928.  I voted for this aid in order to support employees who are victims of globalisation and the consequences of the ultra-liberal policies that the European Union advocates.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, worth € 1,339,928 for 257 redundancies in the safety glass production sector for the automotive industry following the closure of the Auvelais plant in Belgium.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have today voted in favour of this report. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, globalisation is not the only reason why so many jobs have been lost in Europe. The EU itself has decided on the destructive austerity policy. It's got to stop. We need an expansive policy, with public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 339 928 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 257 workers who have lost their jobs due to the closure of a plant in the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), located in Auvelais ( Belgium) and engaged in the manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry , as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  In this case and, although the part of the intervention criteria relating to the minimum number of redundancies (500) during the reference period has not been met, an exception to the general rule has been approved due to the significant effects of redundancies. The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include individual search assistance activities, general information services, vocational training and recycling and entrepreneurship promotion. While these aids alone are not able to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Sneering region, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to support workers made redundant from The Saint-Gobain Sekurit in Belgium because the company has become out of profit. According to the data provided by the Belgian authorities, the production sector for safety glass for the automotive industry has suffered severe economic shocks due to several factors, such as the decrease in the production of safety glass for the EU automotive industry, the increase in the market share of competitors from non-EU countries and the increase in imports of these products into the European Union. SGS Benelux's activities were closely linked to trends in the production of the automotive industry and the production of this industry decreased between 2007 and 2012. In addition, the general tendency of car manufacturers and suppliers to shift production from one European Union country to another, i.e. from Western Europe (in particular France, Belgium and Spain) to Eastern Europe, has been monitored.  Thus, the European Parliament agrees with the Commission that this application fulfils the criteria of the European Globalisation Fund, so that Belgium is entitled to financial support in order to help those who are made redundant, to contribute to their training, to job search and career advice.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) application for Saint-Gobain Sekurit in Belgium, which was authored by fellow Sinn Féin MEP Liadh Ní Riada. The EGF is vitally important in reintegrating back into the labour market workers made redundant due to closures brought about by structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation. This is particularly the case in small open economies like Belgium, or Ireland for that matter. I support mobilisation of the fund based on the intervention criteria of Article 2(c) of the EGF Regulation, under which, in exceptional circumstances, an application may be considered admissible even if other intervention criteria are not met, given that the redundancies have a serious impact on the local economy.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Saint-Gobain  because I think that we need to help our companies on European soil to cope with the challenges of globalisation.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has submitted the EGF/2013/011 BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit application for financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following 257 redundancies related to the closure of a site belonging to the Saint-Gobain Group (SGS), which specialises in the production of safety glass for the automotive sector. The amount of the contribution requested by Belgium amounts to EUR 1,339,928, which is a considerable sum.  The closure of this site is a result of the crisis in the automotive industry that is hitting the European market. The report also points out that 83% of sacked employees have worker status, which will require a complete and therefore costly professional retraining. Given the state of the labour market, there is no reason to believe that the sums poured out by the Union will have any positive impact on the professional retraining of these 257 sacked employees. However, I voted in favour of the financial contribution of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The effects of the economic crisis are also felt in car production, which causes many of the adjacent sectors to suffer. One example is that of the automotive security window manufacturing sector. For example, the Belgian company Saint-Gobain Sekurit is facing problems involving the availability of many employees, mainly due to the decrease in the production of safety glazing for cars in the Union and the increase in imports of these products into the same space. The company's activity was directly dependent on the production of automobiles, which in the period 2007-2012 decreased from 21.9 million units to 19.5 million units, and then recorded an operating loss of EUR 20.46 million, which led to the dismissal of 507 workers. They are in a region where unemployment is relatively high, with the socio-economic context at their disadvantage. It is very important that the laid-off workers receive financial aid of EUR 1 339 928 through the EDF.  I voted in favour of the report because support measures for dismissed employees are absolutely necessary, being intermediate for their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Parliament has decided to accept the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request to intervene in order to help employees of Saint-Gobain Sekurit in Belgium, which is heavily affected by the employment consequences of globalisation. The amount of aid amounts to EUR 1,339,928. 257 laid-off employees will benefit from training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job.  Belgium's demand is justified given the significant global competition in the automotive industry's protective lenses sector. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity in the face of certain negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which refers to the request that Belgium submitted on 19 December 2013 for a financial contribution from the EGF following 257 redundancies linked to the closure of the production plant of Saint-Gobain Sekurit Benelux SA, a company engaged in the manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry. The Belgian authorities pointed out that the sector in which Saint-Gobain Sekurit is active suffered a serious economic disturbance due to a number of factors, including the decline in the production of safety glass for the car industry in the EU, the increase in the market shares of competitors from third countries and the increase in imports of these products from the Union, demonstrating the link between redundancies and the evolution of globalisation. I therefore voted in favour of this measure.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 257 workers who have been made redundant in the automotive safety glass sector. This is a particularly important issue for me as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local Bose factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community as a whole. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will be made in this instance but adequate support for the workers in retraining and upskilling must be provided in any case.  The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as a justification for making workers redundant.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the positive recommendation to activate mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following an application by the Belgian Authorities. The report underscores the relation between SGS Beneluxʼs activities in the manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry and production trends in the automotive industry, which saw the production of passenger cars in the EU decrease from 21.9 million units to 19.5 million units between 2007 and 2012. On the other hand, in the rest of the world, this increased from 47.5 million units to 60.6 million units during the same period. Another element which was detrimental to this sector was an increase in the market shares of competitors from non-EU countries and an increase in imports of these products into the Union. The reports notes that the redundancies at SGS mainly concern production-line workers. The dismissed workers will have to be retrained to find jobs in other occupations and/or other sectors. I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobilisation of the EGF Fund was requested for the first time in the glass manufacturing sector for the automotive industry, but in the past a number of applications have been submitted with reference to motor vehicle manufacturers and automotive equipment suppliers. The automotive manufacturing sector in general suffered a decline of more than 2 million units between 2007 and 2012, mainly due to massive relocation. The 257 redundancies linked to the closure of a plant in the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS) are largely attributable to these circumstances and, although the mobilisation of the fund is normally provided for a minimum number of 500 workers, support for workers is an important measure, in favour of which we have therefore chosen to vote.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Funds should help the 257 employees of Saint-Gobain Sekurit, who are suffering the full brunt of the crisis in the automotive industry. Indeed, GS Benelux was a manufacturer of original automotive safety glass equipment (windshields, side windows, etc.) supplying various automakers, implying that its activities were closely related to production trends in the automotive industry. According to data cited by the Belgian authorities, the production of passenger cars in the European Union of 27 between 2007 and 2012 increased from 21.9 million to 19.5 million units (up 11.3%; 2.4% annual growth), while in the rest of the world it increased from 47.5 million units to 60.6 million units (up 27.6%; up 5.0% annually). Saint-Gobain's employees are thus subject to full competition from Turkish and Chinese factories, which, as we know, are not subject to the same wage rules; they also have to deal with the massive relocations by car manufacturers. Further evidence of the harms of ultraliberal globalisation on European workers.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Another request for intervention to activate the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund submitted by Belgium: this time the economic sector affected is that of the production of safety glass for the automotive industry. The Belgian company has suffered a significant production contraction in the automotive sector, in addition to competition from third countries in the Union, which have very low labour costs. Saint-Gobain Sekurit was made redundant by 250 workers. I voted in favour of the request made by Belgium and welcomed by the European Commission and the Council Budget Committee to mobilise EUR 1 339 928 to support workers who are now unemployed.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt I was voting in favour of this measure because the European fund set up provides support for workers who are suffering from structural changes in world trade. The Fund may not exceed the annual ceiling of EUR 150 million (at 2011 prices). The amounts required shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a provision. The procedures that will be used to obtain the transfer of funding seem to me to be good and efficient, the dialogue between the committee and the authorities guarantee the success of the procedural agreement, see the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Benelux case, operating in the glass sector, which has seen a significant drop in sales in recent years, due to the sharp decrease in car production in Europe. There has also been a general tendency on the part of car manufacturers and suppliers to transfer production within the EU from Western Europe (in particular France, Belgium and Spain) to Eastern Europe. I believe that the intervention of the European Fund is a positive and decisive thing aimed at supporting and defending the individual European workers placed in the redundancy fund.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this case, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund seeks to help 257 workers who have become stuck in the mechanisms of global trade. Humanly, I can only show solidarity and, examining the cards and verifying compliance with the rules, voting in favour.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in relation to Belgium's application for the reintegration into working life of workers made redundant by SGS Benelux, a company engaged in the manufacture of safety glass. The reduction in car production in the European Union, due to the general reduction in consumption resulting from the crisis, has significantly damaged the mechanical parts and bodywork companies in which SGS Benelux also operates. In addition, there is the increase in imports of safety glass from non-European countries – which manage to produce at lower prices – and the transfer of production facilities within the EU to eastern European countries. Following the losses recorded between 2007 and 2012, the company decided to reduce the production of the Belgian plant, causing a significant number of redundancies, in an area where structural unemployment is in itself very high, aggravating the already difficult socio-economic environment. The Belgian authorities have taken steps to alleviate the uncomfortable situation and to encourage the re-use of the exuberant. Through the mobilisation of the EGF, the EU will co-finance the provision of key recovery services such as: personal assistance, training and retraining, promotion of entrepreneurship and granting of subsidies.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In total, 257 employees working in the manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry have been made redundant. This has been linked to the decline in the production of automotive safety glass in the European Union. The co-funded measures for the reintegration of the 257 redundant workers into employment will include individual job-search assistance, training and retraining, and promotion of entrepreneurship. I have thus voted in favour of this report to support the reintegration of the redundant workers into the labour market.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium requested a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 257 employees linked to the closure of a plant in the Sekurit Saint-Gobain group, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. The redundancies are linked to the fall in the production of automotive safety glass in the European Union. I welcome the fact that, in order to provide workers with rapid assistance, the Belgian authorities decided to start carrying out personalised services to the workers concerned on 31 August 2013, well before the decision on EGF support. Expressing concern about the duration of the procedure, I call on the Member States, especially Italy, to make the necessary efforts to improve the procedural and budgetary provisions in order to speed up the mobilisation of the EGF. It was noted that the sector of safety glass production for the automotive industry has suffered serious economic disturbances due to the decrease in the production of automotive safety glass in the Union, the increase in the market share of competitors from third countries and the increase in imports of these products into the Union. I agree that Belgium's application for financial assistance from the EGF is entitled to a financial contribution under the EGF Regulation.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that gives the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Belgium. The application relates to 257 redundancies made at SGS Benelux that is manufacturing safety glass for the automotive industry, before and during the reference period from 31 August 2013 to 31 December 2013. The EGF funding shall contribute to the costs of measures for the reintegration of redundant workers into employment: individual job-search assistance, case management and general information services; training and retraining, promotion of entrepreneurship, allowances (including the relocation allowance and recruitment incentive).

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Already hard hit by the difficulties of the steel industry, Belgium is experiencing the closure of a major production site which will undoubtedly result in the loss of a large number of jobs in the Lower Sambre region. Indeed, in addition to the 257 employees laid off, the closure of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Benelux production site will have an impact on subcontractors and overall on the entire economic activity of a region.  To address this, Belgium has called for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to ensure the co-financing of labour market reintegration measures. Thanks to the intervention of the EGF to the tune of EUR 1,339,928, which represents 50% of the total cost, employees will be offered individual support in their job search as well as training and retraining offers.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 260 employees at SGS Benelux and 300 employees at Saint-Gobain Glass Benelux in the security glass industry, Belgium has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support people who have lost their jobs and to help them find work or start their own businesses. The aid granted amounts to EUR 1,339,928 and covers 50% of the cost of the conversion projects that will be offered to these employees.  Since the kingdom of Belgium's request corresponds to the EGF's mobilization criteria, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry has suffered a serious economic disturbance due to several factors: the decline in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry in the European Union, the increase in the market shares of competitors from third countries and the increase in imports of these products into the EU. SGS Benelux, a company operating in the manufacture of safety glass, has also suffered greatly from the current economic crisis and has therefore been forced to lay off 257 workers. I supported the proposal to mobilise the EGF because it proposes the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant in the SGS Benelux company who have lost their jobs as a result of major changes in world trade due to globalisation.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 21 January 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade in the event of globalisation.  According to the data cited by the Belgian authorities, the automotive safety glass sector has suffered a major economic blow due to a number of factors.  SGS Benelux's activities were closely linked to production trends in the automotive industry, which fell from 21.9 million units to 19.5 million units between 2007 and 2012, while globally it increased from 47.5 million units to 60.6 million units.  As a result, according to data provided by the Belgian authorities, SGS Benelux made an operating loss of EUR 20,46 million between 2007 and 2012. As a result, SGS focused its activities on more profitable units, leading to redundancies at SGS Benelux. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes the following measures to reintegrate 257 redundant workers: individual job search assistance, case management and general information services, training and retraining, and business promotion. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies of 257 employees. The decline in automotive production and therefore of safety glass had caused a shutdown of activities, and then the closure of a site of the Saint-Gobain group in Auvelais. Vehicle production in the EU increased from 21.9 million to 19.5 million units between 2007 and 2012. During the same period, it increased by 13 million units in the rest of the world. The European Union's free trade policy has led to an increase in vehicle imports and a decline in our domestic production. I voted in favour of this aid of EUR 1,339,928 to Belgium so as not to abandon the victims of this globalisation encouraged by Brussels.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I can not agree with a text of the report that says that if you see, the productions that are exported to Eastern Europe lead to job losses in Belgium, France, Spain. The situation in the Eastern European Member States is no better. I remind you that we are in a free market and competition and such texts are inadmissible. It is fair to say that we are being crushed by imports from third countries – China, Turkey, India, etc. Instead, we are dealing with the allocation of funds for social programmes, and it is clear that they will neither bring growth to economies, nor improve production, nor open up new jobs. The EGF is a weak instrument and both I and my group do not support it in principle. On the contrary, efforts need to increase growth, access to new markets outside the EU and increase employment.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as I remain convinced that the money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies and the financing of the requested glazing sector does not offer a solution to the region's unemployment problem.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. This particular case shows the beneficial flexibility in the nature of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as the number of workers affected was below the criteria. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that supports workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to assist redundant workers. This is the case of the company Saint-Gobain Sekurit that operates in the manufacture of safety glasses for the automotive industry. The company's activities were closely linked to production trends in the automotive industry, which between 2007 and 2012 decreased from 21.9 to 19.5 million units, while in the rest of the world it increased from 47.5 to 60.6 million units. The difficulties in that company in Europe are related to globalisation and the eligibility conditions for the eGF support application have been verified. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to improve the employability of all workers through tailored training and the recognition of qualifications and skills acquired throughout their professional career, on equal terms of treatment. This support should be complementary to the company's responsibility under national law and not to be overtaken by other types of financial support by the Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In January 2015, the decision was adopted on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in favour of Belgium, amounting to EUR 1 339 928, due to the dismissal of 257 workers between August and December 2013 at Saint-Gobain Sekurit. A significant decrease in production between 2007 and 2012 at SGS Benelux, driven by a significant increase in production in the rest of the world, led to a loss of around EUR 20 million in this company. However, in the same group, profits were recorded in other companies on more profitable terms, with the group heading for the option of a lay-off of 257 workers. The use of this funding, the report states, aims to provide individual assistance in job search, case management and general information services, training and retraining. It is a shame that the EU's collusion with the Bedouin strategy of multinationals, which are based in a given place for a given place for large EU funds, and when it suits them, by mere criteria for maximising profits, they raise the tent and go to other stops, how often, with the always generous support of eu funds.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in order to provide additional support to Belgian workers in Saint-Gobain Sekurit who have been affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Commission decided to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium after 257 workers lost their jobs. The production of safety glass for the automotive industry has been subject to severe economic shocks. The company therefore experienced a decrease in production and a loss of EUR 20 million. Following the closure of the company in question, unemployment in the region has increased and the old age and low education of the redundancies make it impossible for them to find adequate employment. The amount of funding should be EUR 1 339 928.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of granting the fund € 1,339,928 (50% of the total) for the 257 redundancies in the glass production sector for the safety of the automotive industry due to the closure of the Auvelais plant in Belgium.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people. The financing of the requested glazing sector does not offer a solution to the region's unemployment problem. For the above reasons I am voting against the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - application EGF/2013/011 BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit, Belgium.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Saint-Gobain Sekurit had to close the Auvelais site due to the increase in imports of safety glass for the car industry and to the subsequent decrease in production in the European Union market. I voted in favour of this report to support reintegration of 257 workers into the labour market.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. Europe and the world are immersed in a profound process of globalization that, despite being a source of trade and wealth creation, can also carry risks to which we must be very attentive. As a result of this process there are sectors that are more exposed to international competition, so from the EU we must respond to those citizens who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports workers who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns, caused by globalisation (e.g. closure of large enterprises or relocation of production outside the EU) or the global economic and financial crisis. That is why I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF/2013/011 BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit application)

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. By unblocking the contributions provided for by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the European Union is giving a concrete sign of support to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, thus making it easier for them to re-enter the labour market. I therefore welcome the adoption of the report on the case of the reorganisation of the company in Saint Gobain Sekurit. In this case, as in many other cases, Europe intervenes only to cover the declines in competitiveness and to provide companies and workers with new tools for the conversion of skills and skills. These are certainly decisive instruments: the hope is that the efforts of new productive momentum that the EU has undertaken with the new Juncker Plan will gradually make EU companies finally stronger in the global market, thus reversing the decline that part of our industrial sector has suffered in recent years.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for an EP and Council decision mobilising a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund contribution of EUR 1,339,928 in connection with the redundancies of Saint-Gobain Sekurit Benelux SA.  The closure of the SGS's Auvelais plant resulted in the redundancies of 257 workers, mostly workers in the production line with the status of manual workers, who were difficult to relocate to a region with high unemployment and a large supply of similar professional profiles. The company is paying for the contraction in demand for safety glass for the car industry, due to the decline in car production (1.4 million units lost in 5 years), the increase in imports and the transfer of major production to Member States with lower costs. Workers are once again paying the price for the crisis in the glass sector in Europe.  The EGF's funding of tailor-made services of assistance in job search, retraining and vocational training and support for entrepreneurship is important and necessary, but it is not enough. The EU must go further and tackle the problems of the European glass industry as a whole, with a precise and effective strategy for reviving this sector in all Member States.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In spite of the fact that the part of intervention criteria relating to the minimum number of redundancies (500) during the reference period has not been met, I voted in favour of the Riada report on the mobilisation of the EGAF for Saint-Gobin Sekurit, given the significant effects of the redundancies in question. I welcome the fact that funding of EUR 1 339 928 will contribute to the costs of measures for the reintegration of redundant workers into employment.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies of 257 employees. The layoffs were the result of the closure of a saint-Gobain Sekurit group site in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry.  Their origin is a decline in the production of cars and therefore safety glass in the European Union. Vehicle production in the EU increased from 21.9 million to 19.5 million units between 2007 and 2012. During the same period, it rose from 47.5 million units to 60.6 million units in the rest of the world. Once again, the European Union's free trade policy has led to an increase in vehicle imports and a decline in our domestic production.  I voted in favour of this EUR 1,339,928 aid to Belgium, in order to help the victims of this globalist policy which accentuates the deindustrialisation of European countries, in particular Western European countries.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund for saint gobain in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the 257 dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to offer assistance in Belgium, following 257 redundancies at SGS Benelux which manufactures safety glass for the automotive industry. The funding of EUR 1 339 928 will contribute to the cost of measures for the reintegration of redundant workers into employment: individual job-search assistance, case management and general information services, training and retraining, promotion of entrepreneurship, and allowances (including the relocation allowance and recruitment incentive). The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of supporting 257 workers who have lost their jobs because of the general trend by manufacturers and suppliers in the automotive industry to transfer production within the EU, from western Europe to eastern Europe. I agree that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) has to help these redundant workers to reintegrate into labour market.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilizing this fund for saint gobain in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and legitimate expectation on the part of the 257 workers laid off to receive the associated aid series. However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution by the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Fund for Adaptive Globalisation in favour of closing the facilities of Saint-Gobain Sekurit group companies to ensure that workers are promptly responded to the unpredictable circumstances that have affected the redundance.  In this regard, simplification of procedures and reduction of assessment and implementation deadlines for the expansion of eligible beneficiaries, and accelerating the mobilisation of the Fund, play a key role.  I support the exchange of best practices with regard to national information networks on the EGF, and the involvement of local and regional social partners and stakeholders who can certainly contribute to the quality realisation of the EGF structure.  I also believe that the retraining of laid-off workers of Saint-Gobain Sekurit is needed to make their reintegration into the labour market as quick and without major complications.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. Belgium has requested assistance under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies of 257 employees. The decline in automotive production and therefore of safety glass had caused a shutdown of activities, and then the closure of a site of the Saint-Gobain group in Auvelais. Vehicle production in the EU increased from 21.9 million to 19.5 million units between 2007 and 2012. During the same period, it increased by 13 million units in the rest of the world. The European Union's free trade policy has led to an increase in vehicle imports and a decline in our domestic production. I voted in favour of this aid of EUR 1,339,928 to Belgium so as not to abandon the victims of this globalisation encouraged by Brussels.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Liadh N-Riada's report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Saint-Gobain in Belgium. The fund will provide a total of 1.34 million euros for 257 sacked employees of Saint-Gobain, which will be used to finance training, counselling or business start-up bonuses to help beneficiaries reintegrate into the labour market. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Belgium following 257 redundancies following the closure of a site of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), located in Auvelais. This fund was created to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade.  I am the the the firm, the city, which is worth EUR 1,339,928, to adopt.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Belgium applied for EUR 1.3 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help 257 former employees of Saint-Gobain Sekurit Benelux find new jobs. These job losses were the result of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, in particular the declining market share of European companies in the production of automotive safety glass. Since the employees were not themselves responsible for their dismissal and the allowances do not constitute additional unemployment benefit, I agree with the proposal.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made by Saint-Gobain Sekurit. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. SGS Benelux was gravely impacted by the decrease and shift in production of automotive safety glass, resulting in 257 redundancies. Those made redundant are mainly production line workers, who will need to retrain to find new employment. I therefore voted in favour of this report, as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable support to these workers by helping them re-enter the labour market.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today we have given a great signal of solidarity and concreteness to thousands of European workers in difficulty as a result of the crisis, through a package of requests for mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Mr President, I would like to make it very important that we get the commission to Liadh Ní Riada, in particular, concerns the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by 257 employees at the Saint-Gobain Sekurit production plant in Belgium. Once again, the European Parliament is allocating resources to support workers and companies in difficulty as a result of the economic crisis.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the NI RIADA report, which I had already supported in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee. The adoption of this report demonstrates the European Union's ability to respond effectively to the challenges and challenges posed by globalisation. In fact, 257 sacked employees of the Belgian company Saint-Gobain Sekurit will benefit from an envelope of EUR 1,339,928 allocated by the Union to help finance a reorientation and training plan. The plan will also allow these former glass workers to adapt their skills and know-how to new market needs so that they can quickly find a job.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union, through its active participation in the process of globalisation and its passive trade policies, is largely responsible for the economic weakening of nations and the downgrading of our productive apparatus. Considering that the allocation of these funds constitutes a just, albeit modest, reparation for the prejudices suffered by the peoples, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a report that gives the green light to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Belgium. The application relates to 257 redundancies made at SGS Benelux, a company engaged in the manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry, before and during the reference period between 31 August 2013 and 31 December 2013. In this case and, although the part of the intervention criteria on the minimum number of redundancies (500) during the reference period has not been met, an exception to the general rule has been approved due to the significant effects of redundancies.  EGF funding of EUR 1 339,928 may contribute to the costs of reintegration measures for laid-off workers: individual search assistance, general information services, vocational training and recycling and entrepreneurship promotion.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. In relation to Belgium's financial contribution on budgetary matters and good financial management of the EGF, I consider it positive that, in order to obtain rapid assistance for workers, actions have been taken by Belgium in advance of the decision and even the submission of the application. There have been numerous layoffs at SGS Benelux due to declining demand for car safety glass in Western Europe. This demand for glass has mostly moved to Eastern Europe, and has seen a general increase in the rest of the world. The context in which this occurs is difficult, as these unemployed workers will have to compete with many other unemployed people in Charleroi and Namur who have the same experience and training. For this reason, feAG provides training and recycling measures to alleviate this situation at the regional level.  This action follows coordination with other organizations to implement these measures and, moreover, the principle of equality and non-discrimination continues to apply to the measures carried out by the Fund. That is why I believe that this proposal should be approved.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 SGS Benelux manufactures safety glass for the automotive industry. This industry has experienced serious economic disruption due to production cuts in EU countries and an increase in imports of the same products into the Union and an increase in the market shares of competitors from non-member states, in particular Turkey and China. The industry is specific, so its employees are qualified for a narrow field, which makes it difficult for them to find new employment in other industries.  The application concerning the Belgian company SGS Benelux relates to assistance for over 250 redundanst employees in a short period of time. The amount requested from the EGF is around 1.3m euros to be used for planned job assistance activities. In addition to the costs of implementing the program itself, the amount is divided into 4 types of assistance: assistance to individuals in search of new employment, education, support for entrepreneurial projects of individuals or groups, and various fees. I supported a report aimed at provideing funding to help a large number of unemployed in the Belgian automotive industry. While the number of redundancies is no more than 500, there is the possibility of a new wave of redundancies that will result in an overall number of more than 550 redundancies, creating serious consequences for the unemployment rate and the local community.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the 257 redundancies linked to the closure of a plant in the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), located in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. These redundancies took place during and after the reference period from 31 August 2013 to 31 December 2013 and are related to the decrease in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry in the Union. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The GUE/NGL group proposal was not supported in the second paragraph, although I and our group voted in favour. But in general, the report was adopted, which can be ascertained, because the vote was nominative.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is primarily aimed at supporting and assisting in cases where, as a result of major structural changes caused by globalisation and the global financial and economic crisis, a large number of employees have been made redundant during the reference period, at least 500. Provision in other cases, as in the present case, must be thoroughly reviewed so that the EFG does not replace other assistance from the Funds and that Member States are also incentivise to seek their own measures and solutions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, since the Belgian authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to the affected workers on 31 August 2013 , well before the final decision on EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I am voting for this request to mobilise the EGF, which will support 257 licensees from Saint-Gobain, in the production of safety glass for automobiles, and affected by the closure of the Auvelais plant.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ According to data referred to by the Belgian authorities, the sector of the manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry has undergone serious economic disruption as a result of several factors, such as a decrease in the production of automotive safety glass in the EU, an increase of the market shares of competitors from non-EU countries and an increase in imports of these products into the EU. SGS Benelux’s activities were closely linked to production trends in the automotive industry, which saw the production of passenger cars decrease from 21.9 million units to 19.5 million units between 2007 and 2012, whereas, in the rest of the world, it increased from 47.5 million units to 60.6 million units. Moreover that there has been a general trend by manufacturers and suppliers in the automotive industry to transfer production within the EU, from Western Europe (in particular, France, Belgium, and Spain) to Eastern Europe.  As a result, according to data provided by the Belgian authorities, between 2007 and 2012, SGS Benelux recorded an operating loss of EUR 20.46 million. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded includes following measures for the reintegration of 257 redundant workers into employment.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is one of the most effective instruments considered by citizens: it allows all those workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic and financial crisis to be given a real hand. It is therefore appropriate to mobilise the EGF in order to make a financial contribution in relation to the application submitted by Belgium, following the 257 redundancies linked to the closure of a plant of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), based in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 21 January 2015, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Belgium, with the aim of supporting the reintegration into working life of 257 workers made redundant at Saint-Gobain Sekurit. The Ní Riada report explains why such funding is desirable. The European Union must take action to stem the damage caused to the economic and productive system by the phenomenon of globalisation. On this basis, I have decided to vote in favour of the document.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the request for the Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The production of safety glass for the automotive industry has been subject to serious disruptions to economic activity, resulting in numerous redundancies at SGS Benelux. It is important to support these redundant workers in their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of retraining people who have lost their jobs and helping them return to the labour market after the car sector in Belgium suffered severe economic shocks and one of the companies of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit (SGS) group, which produced this glass, was forced to lay off 257 workers. Redundancies at SGS mainly concern workers on the production line (83% of such workers have the status of worker), so that, in order to address emerging soclianes problems as soon as possible and in view of the labour market situation in the affected area, these redundancies are expected to be retrained in order to find jobs in other professions and/or work in other sectors. This is to be done by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The site in Belgium of the French group Saint-Gobain Sekurit is closed and the 300 or so employees are on the job. The report notes the industrial problem in Europe without drawing any lessons: "the general tendency of manufacturers and suppliers in the automotive industry to transfer production within the Union, Western Europe (notably France, Belgium and Spain) to Eastern Europe". Again the main recommended solution for sacked employees is to start their own business. What cynicism! These laid-off workers were able to benefit from this fund "aid to globalisation" thanks to the work of the Members of my group to circumvent the regulation which normally provides the minimum threshold of 500 licensees to benefit from it. I abstain so as not to deprive workers of this fund.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Belgium, which submitted the EGF/2013/011 BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 257 redundancies related to the closure of a production unit of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), located in Auvelais, which produced safety glasses for the automotive industry.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools at the EU’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 257 workers in Belgium due to the downward shift in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on a report giving the green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in Belgium. The application relates to 257 redundancies made at SGS Benelux which manufactures safety glass for the automotive industry, before and during the reference period from 31 August 2013 to 31 December 2013. Although the part of the intervention criteria relating to the minimum number of redundancies (500) during the reference period has not been met, due to the significant effects of the redundancies, derogation to the rule has been approved.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. Once again, the European Union is playing the arsonist fireman by trying to put out the fire that it has started itself. It will thus partially compensate for the damage it causes by its ultraliberal ideology. The inconsistency of such a policy does not seem to shock anyone.  I am voting for this aid to employees so as not to further penalise the victims of European ultraliberalism.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to mobilise the Fund to the tune of 1.3 million euros to support the reclassification of 257 employees made redundant following the closure of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit site in Auvelais. The site produced safety glass for the automotive industry.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, the European Parliament adopted a report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I have spoken in favour of this report. The aim of this fund is to enable employees who have been made redundant to have personalised training so that they can retrain professionally. On this issue, the European Parliament has agreed to release 1.3 million euros from this fund to 257 beneficiaries who are sacked employees of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Benelux company in Belgium.  In these difficult times, the mobilization of this fund is essential. It is imperative that personalised training be provided to those made redundant so that they can return to work as soon as possible. The European Parliament once again shows its commitment to one of the founding values of the European Union: solidarity.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Belgium, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers from saint-gobain sekurit, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade.  The manufacture of safety glass for the car industry has, in fact, suffered a serious economic disturbance due to a number of factors, such as the decline in the production of safety glass for the car industry in the EU, the increase in the market shares of competitors from third countries and the increase in imports of these products into the Union. In addition, the socio-economic situation of the region concerned and its neighbouring areas (Charleroi, Namur) is characterised by a relatively high level of structural unemployment, with a relatively high proportion of longterm unemployment and low levels of qualifications and skills. The European aid package adopted today will serve to reintegrate the 257 redundant workers, through personalised assistance measures in job search, training and retraining, as well as in promoting entrepreneurship in the area concerned.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report refers to the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) totalling EUR 1 339 928 in favour of Belgium. Specifically, the application concerns 257 redundancies linked to the closure of a plant of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), based in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the Ní Riada report because I believe that workers, victims of the economic and financial crisis and market imbalances attributable to the progress of globalisation, must have full support from the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the implementation of this European Globalisation Adjustment Fund - EGF BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit's request as special rapporteur of the Social Democratic Group in the European Parliament for EGF funds.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion because the material and formal conditions for mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund are in place in this case and I hope that the promised financial resources will give the employees and workers concerned a view for the future. I therefore hope that there are also positive aspects to the economic prosperity of the region.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a european Parliament resolution to allocate EUR 1 339 928 from the EGF to Belgium, which will allow the reintegration of 257 people who became unemployed as a result of redundancy. Unemployment in the European Union increased dramatically as a result of the economic crisis.
