As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can mobilise these people again in the labour market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Union has drawn up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional aid to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade, which are considerably aggravated by the economic, financial and social crisis, and to contribute to their reintegration into the labour market; whereas Union financial support for redundant workers should be adapted and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission; whereas this is the last question that will be dealt with in accordance with the 2006 Regulation. 31 December 2013 and are due to the decrease in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry in the EU; Given that the application falls into the category of exceptional circumstances allowing the mobilisation of the EGF, I voted in favour of it for these reasons.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The production of safety glass for the automotive industry, in which Saint-Gobain Sekurit (SGS) is active, has experienced serious economic disruption as a result of several factors such as a decrease in automotive safety glass production in the EU and an increase in the market shares of competitors from non-EU countries and an increase in imports of these products into the EU. Between 2007 and 2012, passenger car production in the EU-27 decreased by 11.3%, - 2.4% annual growth, while in the rest of the world, it increased by 27.6% + 5.0% annual growth.  Ford, Volvo and BMW which were the main immediate clients of SGS Benelux saw a significant decrease in sales. The effects of these changes in trade patterns are exacerbated by other factors such as high production costs, over-capacity due to declining production levels and low levels of productive investment.  As a result, between 2007 and 2013, the And in 2012, SGS Benelux recorded an operating loss of €20.46 million and therefore applies for the indemnity of the 250 workers they laid off over a four-month period from 31 August 2013 to 31 December 2013 and 7 workers they laid off before 31 August 2014.  The Commission proposed an EGF contribution to a coordinated personalised service package of EUR 1 339 928, representing 50% of the total cost of the action.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to help Belgium with a technological surplus in the production of safety glass for the auto industry for a harmonised package of services with €1 339 928.  Between 2007 and 2012, passenger car production in the EU-27 decreased from 21.9 million to 19.5 million vehicles (- 11.3%, - 2.4% annual growth) while in the rest of the world it increased from 47.5 million to 60.6 million vehicles (+ 27.6%; + 5.0% annual growth). This decrease in the level of car production in the EU, which is linked to a general decline in consumer demand (as a result of the economic crisis ), has led to a general decrease in demand for automotive equipment in the EU, hitting automotive suppliers hard.  In the case of SGS Benelux, for example, in the period leading up to the identification of the technological surplus (2011/2012), Ford, Volvo and BMW, which were the main immediate clients of SGS Benelux, saw a 12% decrease in sales, 10% and 2%, respectively. This amount will at least partially mitigate the financial consequences caused by such a decline in production and sales, which is why I want to express my support to him once again.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. find a new job. At a time when Europe is facing a financial, economic and social crisis and unemployment as a key consequence, the European Union should use all means at its disposal to react, in particular as regards ensuring support for people who have lost their jobs. Belgium applied to EGF/2013/011 BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit for a financial contribution from the EGF following 257 redundancies related to the closure of the facilities of the Auvelais-based Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group undertaking that produced safety glass for the automotive industry. This industry has experienced severe economic disruption due to production cuts in EU countries and an increase in imports of the same products into the Union and an increase in competition market shares from non-EU countries.  I therefore support rapporteur Liadh Ni Riada's report on the mobilisation of €1,339,928, which accounts for 50% of the total budget to support labour market reintegration of redundancy in Sait-Gobain Sekurit.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Here, too, the mobilisation of the EGF is in belgium's favour in order to facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at the Saint-Gobain Sekurit plant due to the crisis in the manufacture of safety glass for the car industry, particularly affected by a significant drop in production in the EU, an increase in the market shares of competitors from third countries and an increase in imports of these products into the EU. There are 257 workers made redundant, benefiting from the measures provided for in the EGF, and I believe that the services put in place, such as personalised assistance in job search, case management and general information services, training and retraining, the promotion of entrepreneurship, can definitely help them re-enter the labour market.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the face of increased competition from developing and emerging countries in the glass production sector, and declining demand for glass in the EU, European companies have had to close several production sites. Many workers have been laid off. With this in mind, Belgium has once again applied to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  I voted in favour of that request. On the one hand, it was in accordance with the Fund's regulations, and on the other hand, I believe it is important to support our markets, our businesses and our workers. This aid will mainly focus on the reintegration of these workers (economic aid, training).

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 257 redundancies related to the closure of a production unit of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), which produced safety glasses for the automotive industry, during the period from 31 August to 31 December 2013. According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is clear, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are related to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation, as the automotive safety glass manufacturing sector has suffered serious economic disruption as a result of a number of factors , such as falling production, increased market shares of third-country competitors and increased imports of these products and, on the other hand, redundancies in a difficult socio-economic context, characterised by a relatively high level of structural and long-term unemployment and low levels of qualifications and skills. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Belgium.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this application as it complies with the required requirements. This refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 1 339 928 from the EGF to mitigate the effects of the dismissal of 257 persons in the reference period between 31 August 2013 and 31 December 2013 in the automotive safety glass manufacturing sector. This sector has suffered serious economic disruption as a result of a number of factors, leading to a fall in the production of safety glass for cars in the Union caused by an increase in the market shares of third-country competitors and an increase in imports of these products. In addition, there has been a general trend among manufacturers and suppliers in the automotive industry to transfer production from Western Europe (in particular France, Belgium and Spain) to Eastern Europe. Furthermore, the coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes the following measures for the reintegration into the labour market of 257 redundant workers: individual job search assistance, case management and general information services; training and reconversion; promoting entrepreneurship.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Good news in the social grey sky, the European Parliament gave the final green light this afternoon to the payment of aid for the conversion of the 257 Walloon workers of the glass factory, Saint-Gobain Sekurit. This aid of EUR 1,339,928 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) constitutes 50% of European participation to support former Saint-Gobain employees in their job search and more broadly in their career reorientation. The area affected by the redundancies is located in Namur province and in particular in the Lower Sambre employment basin. As with many economic layoffs, people working in a sector that is facing stiff global competition are affected. In this case, the decline in the European Union's market share in the production of safety glass for the automotive sector is the cause. This European retraining aid is therefore welcome for the families of these workers. On the other hand, it cannot supersede the establishment of a European industrial policy, which should be a priority of the new Juncker Commission to preserve European know-how in many high-tech sectors.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of legislative and budgetary instruments to provide complementary support to the most diverse sectors has proved to be a positive measure in the transition and adjustment of Member States to the era of globalisation. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important tool in that it can serve to reintegrate people and businesses into the global market. In this case, and in view of the situation presented, the aid provided to Belgium is relevant.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 1 339 928 of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 257 workers who have lost their jobs due to the closure of a plant in the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), located in Auvelais, Belgium, engages in the manufacture of safety glass for the automotive industry , as a result of structural changes in world trade due to globalization and the impact of the economic and financial crisis.  In this case and, although the part of the intervention criteria relating to the minimum number of redundancies (500) during the reference period has not been met, an exception to the general rule has been approved due to the significant effects of redundancies. The personalized services to be financed from the EGF include individual search assistance activities, general information services, vocational training and recycling and entrepreneurship promotion. While these aids alone are not able to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Sneering region, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) following the redundancies at the Belgian company Saint-Gobain Sekurit, as these contributions are a valuable aid in enabling the retraining and reclassification of workers, thanks in particular to training tailored to the opportunities of the job market.  Nevertheless, the job losses in many sectors are a painful reminder that these aids are not a miracle cure and that it is essential to pursue a serious policy of prevention and anticipation of restructuring. More broadly, Europe needs to put in place a real coordinated industrial policy focused on creating sustainable jobs in sectors of the future.  In addition, weASee procedures should be accelerated and simplified to enable laid-off workers to cope with difficulties as soon as they arise.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report in order to unlock financial and professional assistance for the 257 employees of Saint-Gobain Sekurit in Belgium. These were made redundant as a result of the decrease in the production of safety glass for motor vehicles in the European Union and the increase in market shares of third-country competitors. In order to best adapt to these changes, the Saint-Gobain Group has put in place a series of strategies to strengthen competitiveness and profitability; resulting in various restructurings. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will provide 50% financial assistance covering individual job-seeking, training and retraining, entrepreneurship promotion and allowances.  Having always defended the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I believe it is essential to protect workers.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows the activation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 1.3 million euros for the sacked employees of the saint-Gobain Sekurit Benelux company. This company, which specialises in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry, has experienced serious economic disruptions, notably due to the decline in car sales in the EU and the relocation of production centres to Eastern Europe.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up on the initiative of France to help workers who lose their jobs due to major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Belgium's application for unemployment effects of Saint-Gobain Sekurit, which manufactured windscreens and window glasses for cars, complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund under Article 2c of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund Regulation, even though the application affects a total of only 257 unemployed people because of its serious impact on local employment and the economy. The sector represented by Saint-Gobain Sekurit has been subjected to market restructuring due to a number of reasons.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. I agree with this request for the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because in this case employment must be safeguarded. However, we note that the Union's recommendations do not go in the direction of a fair globalisation allowing States to protect their businesses and jobs as do other major powers.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Thanks to todayʼs vote Belgium was granted aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant at a plant belonging to the Saint-Gobain Sekurit (SGS) group, located in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. The 257 redundancies are linked to a decline in the production of automotive safety glass in the Union. The financial contribution requested from the EGF amounts to EUR 1 339 928. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded consists of several measures aimed at promoting the workers’ return to the labour market and helping them with administrative procedures, most of which are expected to support all the dismissed workers.  The UK has never made an application under this fund. UK workers receive none of this support therefore.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. Although the application for a financial contribution submitted by Belgium for aid to Saint-Gobain Sekurit, in which 257 redundancies were made in 2013, belgium does not fulfil certain eligibility criteria for the aid, but falls within the category of exceptional circumstances permitting the mobilisation of the EGF. The redundancies at this company were the result of the closure of a production facility producing safety glass for the automotive industry linked to the decrease in safety glass production in the Union. Redundancies are likely to have major negative consequences in the region concerned, characterised by high levels of structural unemployment and a low level of qualifications and skills. Laid-off workers have limited employment opportunities as they compete with many other workers with similar qualifications and experience. As the co-financed services package covers three important areas: job search assistance, training and retraining and the promotion of entrepreneurship, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 257 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation at Saint-Gobain Sekurit, a factory based in Auvelais in namur province active in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry. Saint-Gobain Sekurit had to close the Auvelais site due to increased imports of safety glass and corresponding decrease in demand for its products in the European Union market.  The aid of EUR 1 339 928 provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in addition to the funds already allocated by the Wallonia region, will help to cover part of the costs of assistance and support in job search, vocational training, business start-up support and other programmes aimed at reintegrating 257 beneficiary workers into the labour market.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution as Belgium has applied to EGF/2013/011 BE/Saint-Gobain Sekurit for egf financial contributions following 257 redundancies related to the closure of the facility of a Saint-Gobain Sekurit (SGS) company located in Auvelais that produced safety glass for the automotive industry. The application does not comply with the criteria set out in Article 2 (a) and (b) of the EGF Regulation, but falls into the category for exceptional circumstances, allowing the mobilisation of the EGF and belgium is entitled to a financial contribution under the Regulation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which will mobilise resources from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I support this report because the Belgian authorities have presented data on the safety glass production sector in the automotive industry and they point to a serious economic disruption, and are due to several factors, the most important of which are the reduction of production within the EU and the increase in imports of these products into the EU.  Also, the authorities confirmed that egf financial contributions will not replace measures that represent the responsibility of companies under national law, nor will they be used to restructure businesses or sectors. As regards management and control systems, the EGF financial contribution will be handled by the same authorities as for the ESF. Therefore, on 19 December 2013, they submitted an application under the EGF Regulation, which does not specify a deadline for examining applications.  I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the securing of €1,339,928 in commitment appropriations, in order to facilitate reintegration into the labour market in relation to redundancies at Saint-Gobain, Belgium.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which provides a financial contribution for 257 redundancies as a result of the closure of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit (SGS) production facility, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. The redundancies were due to a decrease in the union's production of automotive safety glass. In the report, I welcome the call on the Member States and all the institutions involved to take the necessary measures to improve procedural and budgetary arrangements in order to speed up the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I also support the report because the personalised services consist of a number of measures aimed at promoting the return of workers to the labour market and helping these workers in administrative procedures, most of which should support all workers made redundant.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed, and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I of course voted in favour! The support measures had been implemented as soon as the redundancies were announced in consultation with the social partners and in partnership with the regional public employment services. In the meantime, we have pleaded with Commissioners Thyssen and Malmstrom for greater coordination so that international trade agreements do not completely destroy European industrial employment.  These 5.2 million are important to the Walloon economic fabric. It is important to understand that the precariousness and competition of European employees among themselves should not be the rule. It should be remembered that this aid was made indispensable because an international industrialist wanted to play with the destiny of workers, treating them with disdain and great disrespect. Europe must send a strong message to all the Lakshmi Mittals of the world that in Europe there are no castes or untouchables. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. - I voted against the proposal for a decision to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund based on Belgium's request for a financial contribution of EUR 1 339 928 in order to support redundante workers following the closure of the Saint-Gobain Group company's installation. I believe that such one-off measures do not represent solutions that can create an additional obstacle in the face of the economic crisis to achieve long-term growth and job creation. Promoting SMEs, as well as supporting businesses facing difficulties due to structural changes caused by globalisation, growing competitive economies and severe social, economic and financial constraints can only be achieved through a thoughtful fiscal policy and effective public government that will support rather than brake on further investment. I believe that, in particular, Member States are responsible for creating policies that will enable other funding models to prevent businesses from closing or moving them to a market outside the EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European Globalisation Adjustment Funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultraliberal policies applied in this European Union, which are unable to defend neither the peoples who make up it nor the companies that support it.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is a financial instrument that allows money to be allocated to people who lose their jobs due to the economic and financial crisis or because of changes in the structure of world trade with globalisation. Unlike the Structural and Investment Funds, which target strategic, long-term projects, this fund provides time-limited, one-off and individual support. SGS Benelux was a manufacturer of original safety glass equipment for motor vehicles (windows, side windows, etc.) supplying various vehicle manufacturers, implying that its activities were closely linked to production trends in the automotive industry. Between 2007 and 2012, as a result of the global financial crisis, the company's activities were severely affected, with the company losing more than EUR 20,46 million. In January 2015, following belgium's call for the EGF mobilisation, the European Commission adopted a legislative proposal to allocate EUR 1 339 928 from the EGF in the form of commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. The European Parliament's report supports the allocation of the requested amount from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The DELEGATION of PODEMOS in the European Parliament voted in favour of mobilisation of this fund for saint gobain in Belgium, understanding that there is an objective need and a legitimate expectation on the part of the 257 dismissed workers to receive the associated aid series.  However, we consider the Globalization Adjustment Fund insufficient at the current economic situation. Industrial conversion and job easing processes make it more difficult to absorb a growing mass of workers and devalue workers' social rights.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Belgium to provide support for workers made redundant following the closure of a plant in the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group, which produced safety glass for the car industry, a sector affected by changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation and the global economic and financial crisis. The financial contribution, which amounts to more than EUR 1 million, is intended to facilitate the reintegration into employment of 257 redundancies in other jobs, possibly in other sectors, in a region that has long suffered from a high level of unemployment. I consider the EGF to be an absolutely necessary instrument for managing the unemployment crisis, but I would nevertheless like to stress that crisis management should include broader and longer-term economic measures.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of resources following the 257 redundancies linked to the closure of a plant in the Saint-Gobain Sekurit Group (SGS), located in Auvelais, which produced safety glass for the automotive industry. These redundancies took place during and after the reference period from 31 August 2013 to 31 December 2013 and are related to the decrease in the production of safety glass for the automotive industry in the Union. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Belgium, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. A significant decrease in production between 2007 and 2012 at SGS Benelux, driven by a significant increase in production in the rest of the world, led to a loss at Saint-Gobain (Belgium) Sekurit of around EUR 20 million.  However, in the same group there were profits in other companies under more profitable conditions, with the group heading for the option of a lay-off of 257 workers. The use of this funding, the report states, aims to provide individual assistance in job search, case management and general information services, training and retraining. The Belgian authorities have confirmed that the EGF contribution does not replace the actions of the company's responsibility under national law, and will not be used for restructuring operations.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. Although this application does not meet all eligibility guidelines, I supported it nonetheless. Saint-Gobain-Sekurit has been put in a predicament due to an extremely difficult market situation, the increasing import of safety glass into the EU and serious disruptions to economic events.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. This is the 4th EGF application from Belgium in a plenary week. I share the European Court of Auditors' criticism of the EGF: this 'globalisation fund' provides only limited EU added value because it explicitly responds to temporary labour market problems in a region, and is demonstrably inefficient. The Globalisation Fund is not the best way to provide much-needed specific support, which, of course, does not stop the Commission and Parliament from continuing the policy, which is considered inefficient.  That is why I am voting against. But I also have fundamental questions. What is the Belgian Government actually doing? Are labour market policy and economic development in the Kingdom not their first task? And: Why do comparatively many international companies and production facilities close in Belgium of all places? After all, this is already the fourth EGF motion in this plenary for Belgium. Everyone is blaming globalisation, and every time the Eu Commission intervenes. Is that really the reason?

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EAGGF) with a view to allocating EUR 1.3 million for the retraining of the 257 workers made redundant from Saint-Gobain Sekurit in Belgium. The availability of these workers was the result of the restructuring of the Saint-Gobain Sekurit business as a result of the changes in the global plan, but mainly due to the decline of the European market in the sector of secure glass production for means of transport. I welcome the adoption of this report and hope that, as the experience already gained at European level shows us and, in this case through the EAGGF, the reintegration into the labour market of redundant workers will be achieved.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In January 2015, the decision was adopted on the mobilisation of the EGF for Belgium in the amount of EUR 1 339 928 due to the dismissal of 257 workers between August and December 2013 at Saint-Gobain Sekurit. A significant decrease in production between 2007 and 2012 at SGS Benelux, driven by a significant increase in production in the rest of the world, led to a loss in this company of around EUR 20 million. However, in the same group, profits were recorded in other companies on more profitable terms, with the group heading for the option of a lay-off of 257 workers. The use of this funding, the report states, aims to provide individual assistance in job search, case management and general information services, training and retraining. The Belgian authorities have confirmed that the EGF contribution does not replace the actions of the company's responsibility under national law, and will not be used for restructuring operations. We voted in favour of mobilising finance, although the structural solution means regulation of markets by states, with obligations of companies, which safeguards jobs.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – I did not vote in favour of the final resolution on the Tarabella report on gender equality and I want to explain why.  I think we have missed the chance for the European Parliament to send a clear signal about how it en imagines supporting women, improving the position of women in the socio-economic field, improving their representation in political bodies. Unfortunately, the European Parliament resolution contains recommendations on the promotion of abortion. Abortions become essentially part of contraception under this provision.  In other words, Parliament has intervened in the protection of unborn life, and this is simply an unacceptable breach of the principle for me. On the other hand, Parliament has also infringed the principle of subsidiarity, because these are the issues that are reserved to the Member States for their adaptation.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – I supported this report on gender equality. I think that this is an important political issue, and if the European Parliament sees them as defenders of human rights, then the issue of gender equality is simply part of the issue.  The most debated was paragraph 45, i.e. the right of a woman to decide on her sexual and reproductive health, as well as the possibility of abortion.  I first supported the ECR proposal, which stated that these are issues which, according to the principle of subsidiarity, should be regulated by national law. This proposal did not pass, but I voted in favour of paragraph 45 remaining in the resolution because I believe that women's right to sexual and reproductive health is very important, as is the issue of contraception.  The topic of abortion is a very sensitive subject and needs to be adapted in national law and clear rules on when it can be applied.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to thank Mr Tarabella – and I obviously voted in favour of his report – for this rich report. Rich because there are many points addressed, the barriers to be broken down in order to achieve equality between men and women, the real one. There is not too much ideology, it is real life: parental leave, wage gaps, pension gap, employment and health.  No one is asking for services for women, there is no system of care for all those categories that women care for as mothers, wives, daughters, sisters. There is a lack of care services for children, for the elderly, for people in need of special care. So if we really want to do something for women, we need to remember to invest in welfare, efficient welfare, at the expense of the state, and therefore of everyone, not just women.  We cannot just think about flexibility and growth, because before and above them come people and their rights, especially those of women, so that they can carry out their profession without giving up and without regret, and so that society is women-friendly.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I voted against this report because I believe that it is downright perfidious to issue a right to abortion for all women as a human right. The fundamental human right is the right to life and physical integrity. This right also has unborn children. It is undisputed that there are conflict situations in which women have to decide according to their conscience. However, a blanket right to abortion is contrary to human rights and is therefore totally unacceptable as a decision by the European Parliament. I think it is almost inflam that an attempt is being made to violate a human right under the guise of human rights. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: Thank you very much. In my country, Hungary, I meet many tormented, dead tired women who are in physical health and mental health. They carry unbearable burdens because they bear all the burdens of childcare, caring for sick family members, elderly care and the household, and they also have to prove separately at work that, although they are women, they are full-fledged workers. They often do so for significantly less income than their male counterparts doing similar work. I voted in favour of all the parts of this document aimed at improving this shocking situation. However, I was unable to vote in favour of the proposal as a whole because it tells women that you have the right to an abortion, but it does not help them to prevent it or to side with them in a difficult situation.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcomed and therefore shared the cultural structure of Marc Tarabella's report. However, a frankly ideological approach still weighs on the debate. The level of civilisation is measured by the demandability of rights but above all by their declination in favour of the most vulnerable people and, of course, of women. The heart of our debate cannot but have a political profile, capable of overcoming any fundamentalism in a secular vision of the issues in question. Let us therefore try to decline our policies in support of civil and human rights, freeing up women's lives. We recognise their right to live their sexuality without prejudice, even when they are faced with the choice to give up a pregnancy and when they ask to be able to make the right to denied motherhood payable. Freeing women still means creating the conditions to enable them to exploit the extraordinary human capital of which they are the bearers, even in an idea of emancipated and reconciled work that generates wealth and not poverty.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – I could not support this report, even though it should have been progressive to some extent. However, its progressivity goes against the principle of subsidiarity. In my opinion, there are things that should remain in the member states, and sexual and reproductive rights are definitely among them.  As I have said several times, and I want to repeat this, the European Union and its legislation have their limits. Please, let's not forget that.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in line with my own values, I abstained on Mr Tarabella's resolution on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013. Although I have many positive points that we can fully support, there is a force in the text concerning the so-called right to abortion at European level, which has turned yesterday's debate and today's vote into a bit of a count on the tragedy of the possible voluntary termination of pregnancy. Too bad; it would have been enough to respect the principle of subsidiarity enshrined in the Treaties in these matters and for which the drafting and implementation of policies on sexual and reproductive health and rights is a matter for the Member States. Without this forcing, we would all be here today to highlight only the many positive aspects of the resolution that I do not list due to lack of adequate time. I repeat that for these reasons I voted to abstain on the resolution.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today's vote was an important one. This was a clear vote in favour of the Tarabella resolution, which partly remedyed the ugly figure of Parliament some time ago, the rejection of the Estrela resolution. I believe that the subject today is to put women's self-determination and freedom back at the centre of our debate and our project for Europe. choose and self-determine. That is why it is important to talk about pay gaps, about the insecurity of women's work; It is important to talk about a European observatory against gender-based violence, sexism in the media and, above all, the right to choose about our bodies and the right to choose in terms of pregnancy and reproductive health.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, last Sunday was International Women’s Day, which is useful but hardly sufficient if we want to achieve gender equality. One of the most outrageous phenomena which disproportionately targets women and young girls is trafficking in human beings – a practice that severely affects Member States from Central and Eastern Europe. I welcome the emphasis in this report on poverty alleviation through job creation for women. In making women more economically resilient, they are less likely to be the target of human trafficking. However, the quality of jobs should also be taken into account to ensure a structural solution. Another issue I find of great importance – that is also recognised in this report – is the economic empowerment of women through the provision of early childhood education and care services, an infrastructure which, despite the objectives formulated in 2002 at the Barcelona European Council, is still deficient in many Member States, including my country.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I did not support this report because I fear interference and regulation of any external factors in family relations. My personal belief, the belief of my political power, is that family matters, questions about relationships within the family must be traditional and should be as they have been for years. In my homeland, in Bulgaria, family is a traditional relationship between a man and a woman, and I strongly object to any supranational decisions, be it the Commission or Parliament, to take attitudes and to fit into these family relations. No one denies the right to self-determination, no one denies the right of every individual to make decisions related to his own life and health. But family relations, marriage issues, the issue of family should be a national relationship and should be relationships that are regulated by traditions as they have been for centuries.

name: Seán Kelly (
text: PPE). – A Uachtaráin, táim lán i bhfabhar cothromaíochta idir fir agus mná agus a luaithe a tharlaíonn sé san Eoraip is fearrde dúinn uile é. Ach ag an am céanna is trua an rud é go raibh moltaí sa tuarascáil seo, mar a dúirt Feisirí eile, ag baint le ginmhilleadh a chur ar fáil go forleathan trasna na hEorpa. Vótáil mé i gcoinne na moltaí sin mar ní aontaím le ginmhilleadh a chur ar fáil go forleathan. Ní aontaím gur cheart don Eoraip bheith ag déanamh rialacha faoi mar go mbaineann sé leis na stáit éagsúla agus dar ndóigh ní bhaineann sé le cothromaíocht idir fir agus mná mar ní féidir le fear ginmhilleadh a bheith aige. Dá bhrí sin, tá súil agam nuair a phléifimid an t-ábhar seo arís go gcloífimid leis an mbunábhar agus go ndéanfaimid ár ndícheall chun fíor-chothromaíocht a chruthú san Aontas idir fir agus mná agus a luaithe a tharlaíonn sé is fearrde dúinn é.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I voted against the adoption of this report because I stand for equality for all and equal chances for anything that this report does not promote. This report, in addition to having the word equality in its title, does not unfortunately track this title by its content. I am concerned that our citizens' time and money is being spent to make reports like this, which we know in advance are contrary to fundamental EU principles such as subsidiarity. Members of this Parliament, by drawing up and supporting such reports, undermine the principles and treaties they should protect, which leads us to legal uncertainty and violations of the rule of law. It worries me as it worries me and the non-recognition of the real problems that are a dangerous cause of galloping discrimination in society. It grieves me that a report meant to promote equality between men and women has turned into a report on the promotion of abortion. It's a shot at the heart of democracy, but it's also a shot at equality that we swear to and we're not ready to provide for everyone.

name: n/a
text: Written. Gender equality is fundamental to the functioning and development of society. The EU Charter of Fundamental Human Rights establishes the equal value of all people and prohibits discrimination based on sex. This should be respected by the Member States and is not negotiable.  However, views on gender equality policy differ between different ideologies and parties across the Union. I believe, for example, that, unlike the Belgian socialist Marc Tarabella, gender quotas are both a matter of fact and a violation of the principle of subsidiarity. Parental leave is affected in the report, although this is a matter for the Member States.  As far as the issue of abortion is concerned, I take the same view as my predecessor, Mr Svensson. An abortion is an ethical dilemma and an equality report such as this must also take into account the protective value of the foetus. An own-initiative report has no legal effect and is to be regarded as an opinion piece on the part of Parliament. However, we know that the European Commission refers regularly to EP resolutions in its legislative proposals. When the European Parliament signals a willingness to micromanage the member states' work on gender equality, it is legitimate to talk about a sloping plan.  The report is a catalogue of proposals that violate the ambition of decisions being taken as close to the citizens as possible; Subsidiarity principle. The Christian Democrats believe that issues of health policy, quotas and family policy do not belong at EU level. I have therefore chosen to vote against the report.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself a sclergy advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. The Tarabellla report addresses all these issues.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on progress in equality between women and men, as it is a policy document reiterating the importance of equality policies in the EU and Member States as a basic pillar to end inequalities in various areas such as labour and family reconciliation, the pay gap, stereotypes or the right to health. The report denounces non-compliance with the objectives of the European Commission's key gender equality document, the Equality Strategy 2010-2015, among other reasons for the withdrawal of the proposal for the Maternity Leave Directive. Moreover, while it is reiterated that health policies fall within the competence of Member States, it states that women should have control over their sexual and reproductive health and rights, in particular through easy access to contraception and abortion. However, I regret that there is no clear denunciation of how austerity measures promoted since the troika have precarious women's living conditions, further delving into the phenomenon of feminization of poverty.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – There are many positive aspects within this report which I would fully support. I am pleased that this report made reference to important aspects of gender equality including the worrying feminisation of poverty, the persistent gender pay gap and the importance of Member States acceding to the Istanbul Convention on violence against women, especially considering that Ireland is one of only six EU countries not to have signed this vital treaty.  However, I believe that the formulation and implementation of health policies, including sensitive positions taken on abortion services, are a competence of sovereign governments and I therefore, in line with Sinn Féin policy on the issue, abstained on the resolution overall.  Sinn Féin believe that in the case of rape, sexual abuse, incest, where a woman’s life is in danger, or in the case of fatal foetal abnormality the option of termination should be available. Sexual and reproductive health and rights cannot be reduced to mean abortion. Reproductive rights can refer to a range of services covering maternal, post-natal, menopausal, reproductive cancers and fertility treatments. It is my party’s and my own view that women should not be denied access to such services.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: In writing. Giving half of humanity its rightful place in social and political representation is a universal struggle that the Socialists have always carried.  I welcome the fact that, in the wake of International Women's Rights Day, our Parliament is voting on a report which highlights persistent discrimination in equality and proposes concrete measures to reverse them. It is part of this collective desire to work for the freedom and emancipation of women. There are many actions to be taken: increasing the employment rate and its quality, reducing the pay and pension gap, reducing the risk of poverty, combating stereotypes, promoting work-life balance, valuing the participation of fathers and mothers in family life, unlocking the maternity leave directive, combating violence against women , to promote sexual and reproductive rights, that is, the fundamental right of women to dispose of their bodies, which reactionary conservatives are constantly trying to challenge.  Equality is a daily struggle to be fought unabated. Advancing women's rights means wanting a fairer society and a more effective democracy. Mentalities still need to improve!

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this resolution since I believe that assessing the progress of equality between men and women is a key issue. The road to development depends on real gender equality.  It is urgent and necessary to promote women's participation in the labour market and to reduce the pay gap.  Finally, I believe that women should have control over their sexual and reproductive health, notably through easy access to contraception and abortion.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. As a whole, this report is to be welcomed, as it contains many important elements on the subject of equality. On the subject of abortion, I believe that this is and must remain less a European issue than a matter for the Member States.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The Tarabella report distorts the original objective of protecting women's rights for ideological and economic purposes, including by promoting gender ideology. He denies gender specificity and complementarity. He denies the otherness of the woman and the fact that a child first needs his mother. Creating non-transferable paternity leave will de facto take time off maternity leave.  Its objective is to have more people in the labour market, causing wages to fall. Thus, it leads to the deterioration of the lot of women by making men and women interchangeable, ignoring individualities and differences. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I support equality between men and women and therefore reluctantly abstained on a report which introduced various other unpalatable ideas: discriminatory quotas, and over-enthusiastic support for taxpayer-funded abortion. The tone of the report was such as to justify a negative vote, but given the positive nature of the subject matter I could not bring myself to vote against rather than abstain.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it goes in the direction of history. This text fully recognises the role of women in the European Union and strongly condemns all discrimination against them.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between men and women must be seen as one of the pillars of our society, and therefore the issues raised in this own-initiative report of the European Parliament are central to Europe. The work carried out by my colleague Marc Tarabella calls on the European Union and the Member States to take gender issues into account in the Europe 2020 strategy, as well as the development of an investment plan in social infrastructure, as it is estimated that this would have a positive effect on gross domestic product growth. Because of these and other issues raised in the report, such as the prevention of violence against women and the request to resume negotiations on the maternity directive, I will vote in favour of this text.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report on progress on gender equality in the EU in 2013.  This text underlines that women were the first victims of the crisis: almost one in four elderly women is at risk of poverty, a situation linked in particular to the persistent gender pay gap.  This report also looks at violence against women and calls on Member States to strengthen their national action plans for the elimination of domestic violence: it is fundamental that women's rights are no longer treated as a marginal issue at European level.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to measure the progress of equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013. The resolution draws attention to the consequences of inequalities between men and women: violence against women, different salaries and unequal career opportunities. According to the Commission, as many as 22% of older women and 35.5% of those who raise children alone are at risk of poverty in the EU. Although the employment rate of women has risen slightly since 2002, it has been affected by the crisis. Achieving the Europe 2020 targets requires not only the EU to achieve the employment rate of 75%, but also to improve the quality of work. If gender equality were to exist in the labour market, THE EU's GDP could increase by as much as 12%. The cost of care services continues to be a major obstacle to women's employment. It is therefore necessary for Member States to develop affordable and quality care services that are provided on a full-time basis. The fight against violence against women is also very important. I support the proposals that, first of all, the collection of comparable data on violence against women in all Member States must be carried out, and the work of the European Institute for Gender Equality is crucial in this respect.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. Once again, the aim is to promote the ideology of "gender" with its procession of ultra-minority communitarian demands. Among the measures recommended, the Socialist rapporteur calls for "inclusion of gender parity clauses in tenders for public procurement" and "welcomes the parity legislative systems and gender quotas put in place in some Member States". For my part, I believe in "meritocracy" and I strongly oppose the introduction of quotas and other discriminations described as "positive". Like the Panzeri report, the Tarabella report contravenes paragraph 7 of Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which stipulates that so-called reproductive or reproductive health policies fall within the competence of Member States. The European Union therefore does not have to impose its views on countries that have sovereignly chosen other paths, let alone in an area that falls solely within the competence of the Member States. I note in passing that the MEPs of the UMP voted enthusiastically in favour of this report, as they did two days later for the Panzeri report.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have obviously supported this text, which was carried by my colleague Marc Tarabella, which highlights a number of priorities for equality between women and men, such as increasing the employment rate of women, reducing pay differences, promoting a directive imposing ambitious maternity leave and, of course, deepening the fight against violence against women. Finally, this report wisely reminds women of the right to dispose of their bodies in relation to the right to abortion.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This report on progress on gender equality in the European Union in 2013 calls on European states and institutions to take into account the gender and women's rights perspective in budgetary procedures, to integrate gender equality into the Europe 2020 strategy and to develop a gender-differentiated investment plan to allegedly promote an increase in European GDP... Of course, the recommendations made in the report on the fight against women poverty or on the reduction of the gender pay gap can only be welcomed and are naturally laudable objectives, but the ultra-liberal policies of the Union and the large multinationals are in total contradiction with these objectives. Moreover, nothing is really done to accompany mothers who wish to raise children and to have or resume a professional activity.  I have therefore spoken out against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although there are passages that we can support in this report, I have found many contradictory and un balanced elements, for these reasons I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself a staunch advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. The Tarabellla report addresses all these issues.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because equality between women and men in the European Union is still a challenge, and the situation of lower women's salaries and pensions remains, discrimination against women in the labour market, women's participation in decision-making and politics, violence against women. The European Union is increasingly making progress in the area of gender equality, but it is too slow. According to the European Parliament's rapporteur, if we continue to move at this rate, we will not eliminate the gender pay gap by 2084. Women's employment is growing very slightly, for example, it has increased from 60% to 63% over a five-year period, but this is insufficient. Therefore, more attention needs to be paid to women's employment and the quality of jobs, as more and more women work part-time or under temporary contracts. As a result, women subsequently receive lower pensions and suffer poverty and social exclusion. Combating violence against women is one of the main priorities, and I therefore, together with other Parliamentarians, I ask the Commission to declare a European Year to address this problem. In this way, we could draw greater attention from the Member States and our citizens, because our society does not always want to talk about it out loud. It is also necessary to ratify the Istanbul Convention on Violence against Women.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I believe that economic equality is a basic precondition for gender equality. By holding back proposals concerning gender equality, the Council and the Commission tell half of the EU population that their fundamental human rights to equality can wait. It is the same as claiming that women want to be unemployed, do the whole of January and February free of charge compared to male counterparts, and in old age stay without a pension! With as many as 20 per cent more women gaining higher education, pretending that the current situation is satisfactory is absolutely insane.  At this rate, for example, equal wages for equal work will not be achieved until 2084. That is why I am proud that women's entrepreneurship is on the rise in Croatia. I'm also proud that we're introducing gender quotas in the parliamentary elections. Active and binding measures are the key to good change! Let's not repeat last year's disgrace. Let us show those who want to return Europe to the Middle Ages by trying to crash computer systems and disable the work of Europarlamentaries that they will fail. Tomorrow support women's fundamental rights, let's show we're here for them!

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. Article 19 of the FUE Treaty allows the European Union to combat discrimination between women and men. Last December, the European Commission gave the co-legislators six months to act. The previous Italian Presidency had suggested a flexibility clause. Last January, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality adopted a report on progress on gender equality in the EU in 2013, which is now before us. I voted against this text, which was part of a principle to which I agree, equality between men and women. But Mr. Tarabella couldn't help but give an ideological imprint to his report by mixing gender theory, paternity leave, abortion and even tax provisions. I regret the lack of observation on the major structural changes that threaten equality between men and women, in particular mass non-eu immigration, whose populations do not share the same values, and some of which demean women as objects.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are many positive aspects within this report which I would fully support. I am pleased that this report made reference to important aspects of gender equality including the worrying feminisation of poverty, the persistent gender pay gap and the importance of Member States acceding to the Istanbul Convention on violence against women, especially considering that Ireland is one of only six EU countries not to have signed this vital treaty. However, I believe that the formulation and implementation of health policies, including sensitive positions taken on abortion services, is a competence of sovereign governments and I therefore, in line with Sinn Féin policy on the issue, abstained on the resolution overall.  Sinn Féin believe that in the case of rape, sexual abuse or incest or where a woman’s life is in danger, or in the case of fatal foetal abnormality, the option of termination should be available.  Sexual and reproductive health and rights cannot be reduced to mean abortion. Reproductive rights can refer to a range of services covering maternal, post-natal, menopausal, reproductive cancers and fertility treatments. It is my party’s and my own view that women should not be denied access to such services.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on equality between women and men in 2013 because I think it is still absolutely necessary to urge the necessity for real equality between women and men in our European society.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Women and men are part of the same society. They are two wheels of the same bike: if one or the other is not in a position to turn properly, the bicycle does not take us anywhere. We must therefore take care of equality. We must work for full gender equality. Also because, as evidenced by the OECD report "Closing the gender gap - Act now" of December 2012, EU GDP could increase by 12% if there was real equality between women and men in the labour market.  In order to return to economic growth, it is therefore also necessary to proceed along the path of real equality. It is in our interest, but it is also our duty in terms of rights. If Europe is to be an example of civilisation and progress, it must first set a good example by translating its principles and values into reality. It is therefore a priority to pursue the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy: I am thinking, for example, of the 75% employment rate for women and of fairer representation in the political and managerial bodies of each State. In this context, it is easy to imagine how fundamental the role of the European institutions is, both those present in Brussels or Strasbourg and those in the smallest municipalities of Europe.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. On the face of it, the Tarabella report provides an overview of gender inequalities. In the end, it leads to the promotion of gender theory and the negation of male/female complementarity. It should be noted that no mention is made of the right to safety of women, which is rarely guaranteed in certain parts of European cities. Nor is there anything about the precariousness of young women who are single and with children, who do not benefit from a "parental income". No, this report does not respond to the legitimate need for an update on the dignity of women in our societies, but to the ideology of ultra-feminist minority lobbies, who are trying to bring their "moral order" to the European Parliament. That is why I voted against the Tarabella report.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Market radical instead of women-friendly – Tarabella report is proving to be a neo-liberal sham. The content mentions some very important demands for women's rights, but on closer inspection it reveals a great many shortcomings. I would like to comment here on the passages that led me to vote 'no'. In the report, women are seen only as an economic factor. However, the human rights of women and children are universal. In no case did I want to agree to a neoliberal growth policy that has everything to be subordinated to. However, i believe that this radical demand is hidden in the report cleverly packaged under the cloak of women's human rights. I am in favour of the important improvements in women's rights, but I believe that the report aims more at making women available to the labour market as an economic and growth factor as quickly as possible. According to surveys, however, parents want to spend much more time with their children. Too often, industry tries to subordinate the freedom of choice and the way of life of workers to economic growth.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report because there are so many issues in it that violate the principle of subsidiarity. In other words, Member States, under the Treaty of Lisbon, have the right to decide in certain areas independently, taking into account the culture, traditions and values specific to each society. Beyond any complaint, equality between men and women has been a major concern over the years. Gender discrimination is likely to cause disruption to any society, regardless of its degree of development. Member States must be concerned with the creation of a legal framework within which each individual can freely manifest himself according to his or her own conscience, in compliance with the legal provisions, the principle that no one is above the law, of good morality and, last but not least, of mutual tolerance, irrespective of race or ethnic origin, sex, nationality, religion or belief , disability, age and sexual orientation. The European Union as a whole must ensure that individual rights and freedoms are respected and, whenever it finds slippages, intervene firmly and unequivocally.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself a sclergy advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. The Tarabellla report addresses all these issues.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Equality between men and women is a fundamental principle. Unfortunately, it is far from being fully respected in Europe. However, the European Union should be a normative example for the rest of the world. We note that much progress remains to be made in this area. We must continue to fight for a woman to be paid as much as a man when she performs a similar task. We must also fight against sexism and violence against women. These are just a few of the many examples.  The position of women has changed in recent years. Let's not stop in such a good way. I have, of course, voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013.  Equality between women and men is a fundamental right enshrined in the Treaties and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. However, despite the fact that the European Union has already adopted numerous texts to ensure equal opportunities and treatment for men and women and to combat all forms of gender discrimination, the progress made remains insufficient and there are still many inequalities between men and women. I therefore hope that the report will encourage the EU institutions and the Member States to continue their efforts to develop policies that take account of gender issues, women's rights and equal opportunities in order to continue in the direction of a change of mentality, with the prohibition of any discrimination which - when not curbed - emphasises (rather than protects) the difficulties and precariousness linked to disabilities , motherhood, children, work and care for older women.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ There are many positive aspects within this report which I would fully support. I am pleased that this report made reference to important aspects of gender equality including the worrying feminisation of poverty, the persistent gender pay gap and the importance of Member States acceding to the Istanbul Convention on violence against women, especially considering that Ireland is one of only six EU countries not to have signed this vital treaty. However, I believe that the formulation and implementation of health policies, including sensitive positions taken on abortion services, is a competence of sovereign governments and I therefore, in line with Sinn Féin policy on the issue, abstained on the resolution overall.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 32 because we oppose calling for the EU to meddle with the UKʼs immigration system regarding undocumented migrants and telling countries that they cannot report cases to the authorities. However we absolutely condemn cases where women (whether migrant or not) have been subjected to abuse and would support criminal investigations no matter what the circumstances. The EU call for cases not to be reported to the authorities may help those perpetrating such crimes to avoid being brought to justice. UKIP abstained on paragraph 50 as we cannot support calling on the EU to interfere with the UKʼs immigration system regarding the right to residency. However it is perfectly reasonable for a migrant woman to be granted autonomous residency (meaning that residency is not subject to being part of the family unit she first entered with), especially in cases where the woman has been subjected to domestic violence.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very good report. It contains a number of fundamental questions and values which I support and endorse, although I still believe that there is still a lot of work that needs to be done in this area. The report draws up a scoresheet on the progress achieved in the area of gender equality in Europe in 2013. It highlights amongst others, a number of important elements to reach equality between both sexes: existing problems related to wage differences between female and male employees, the persistence of violence against women, female entrepreneurship, the Barcelona targets for gender equality, the promotion of work-life balance and combating gender stereotypes. On the other hand, the report also promotes ʽthe right to abortionʼ, which does not come under the EUʼs competence. I believe that the principle of subsidiarity, which is one of the founding principles of the EU, should be respected in this case. It is for this particular reason that I voted against this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between men and women should be one of the pillars of any society that wants to be modern. In order for this to be effective, however, it is absolutely necessary to provide for interventions that take account of the differences between the characteristics and needs of the two sexes. There is no discrimination greater, because it is more hidden, than that which results from treating different situations in the same way. In this sense, one of the major difficulties encountered by women is the reconciliation of professional and private life, to remedy which it is necessary to introduce specific social shock absorbers. Alongside this, sex education and the eradication of stereotypes about the respective roles of men and women in society are fundamental elements for raising citizens' awareness. The same applies to the self-determination of the woman's body, a fundamental and indispensable right that is not always adequately recognized. My vote in favour of the resolution, which deals with all the aspects mentioned, is absolutely convinced.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome this very balanced report which develops concrete actions towards a beneficial and indispensable adaptation to our current society.  Yes, the right to abortion must be considered a fundamental right.  Similarly, it is essential to take into account the need to adapt to new family structures.  But more than that, it is time to give an impetus to economic society by allowing women access to key positions in the corporate world and by eliminating the difference in pay between men and women.  Mr. Tarabella's work has been precisely concerned with these issues, and we must now persevere in this direction.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the report on the progress of gender equality, I abstained, even though the material contained a number of conclusions with which one can only agree. In my opinion, some issues should be clarified separately by each country, the solution should not come from Brussels. These include, for example, the introduction of quotas for women. There is a need to create more favourable conditions for the balance of women's family and working lives, and quotas alone will not solve the most pressing problems. I therefore consider it more important that women have sufficient background in childcare so that they do not have to choose between children and careers.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. The Tarabella report is just another expression of materialism, utilitarianism and egalitarianism in the European Parliament. The report urges women who have chosen to work part-time to do so full-time. Too bad for those who have made the free choice to focus on the future of their children, they clearly do not fit the definition of female dignity according to Mr. Tarabella. Worse, this report is a praise of the culture of death by the explicit support it gives to abortion, a real weapon of mass destruction against European demographics.  Her vision of women is a thousand miles away from what European women are in the long running of history: a strong woman who is one of the keys to the rapid progress of our civilization. So here she is, this strong woman of European civilization, according to Mr Tarabella's miserly vision, suddenly reduced to victim status, to a woman who would need quotas to arrive at responsibilities as if she could not, by her intrinsic qualities, rise to the same rank as man.  Because it is in fact a denial of the true dignity of women, I voted against this text.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Persisting gender inequalities are and will remain a great concern for many years to come. For example, we almost certainly will not be able to achieve equal pay any time before 2034 and womenʼs employment rate will not be comparable to menʼs until 2038. However, we have taken small steps to reduce this gender inequality gap. We did the right thing by pushing for the maternity leave directive to be unblocked by the EU Council of Ministers and to push for better paid paternity leave rights across the EU. We also want to see more financial support given by governments to make childcare systems more affordable, as it will give mothers increased opportunities to return to work. It is also important that, in every Member State, women have control over their sexual and reproductive health rights.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Among the objectives to be achieved under the Europe 2020 strategy is to increase the employment rate of women and men to 75%; an ambitious target made even more difficult by the continuing crisis, which has had an even more negative impact on women's employment. In addition, parttime work and fixed-term contracts have increased.  I voted in favour of this report because it highlights the remaining structural obstacles to the full achievement of equality in the labour market. More generally, however, gender disparities have deep roots and I hope that the report voted on today will help to encourage Member States to consider from a gender perspective the actions needed to bridge the gap in all sectors.
