name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. Denmark does not participate in judicial cooperation in the EU by virtue of the opt-out of legal policy cooperation and is therefore not directly affected by policies relating to residence permits and asylum. We recognise that other Member States have the right to deal with policies related to these issues, but since the issue does not have direct relevance to Danish rules, we refrain from taking a position on the points relating to these areas.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on this report has been much debated. On the one hand, those who persist in maintaining conservative positions, on the other hand those who take note of the reality of the world. I have sided with the latter in the conviction that morality must not take precedence over the freedom of human beings to live their lives according to their aspirations, convictions and attitudes.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013 is a report that was voted upon in Parliament on 10 March 2015. I welcome the elements of this report that deal with equality for women. The report referenced important issues like gender pay gaps, gender equality and violence against women. However, it is my view that the formulation and implementation of policies on abortion are a matter for each individual Member State and not the European Parliament. Parliament must not overstep its competence and must recognise the principle of subsidiarity, which is a founding principle of the EU. Therefore I voted to take out any reference to abortion from the report on equality. I felt that the report overall had merit and advocated for equality for women and as such, I was happy to support it.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the report calls for easier access to abortion. I believe that abortion is not a European issue, but a matter for the Member States. I am opposed to easier access to abortion; we must protect unborn life.  There is still much to be done in terms of equality between women and men in the Member States. Important issues are violence against women, forced prostitution, old-age poverty, the existing pay gap between men's and women's salaries or the reconciliation of family and work. But life issues such as abortion are not part of it: after years of debate, we in Germany have adopted a highly differentiated abortion law in which the protection of unborn life and the right of women to their physical integrity are carefully balanced. This decision on values must not be overturned by a European back door. Every year, the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality adopts a resolution assessing the progress of equality between women and men. This resolution is about 2013.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report. Equality between men and women is a matter of prime importance which must certainly be pursued with the utmost responsibility on the part of the national and European authorities. I do not believe, however, that this should or can go so far as to mortify certain values that I believe are fundamental to our civil society, such as the family. Furthermore, I firmly believe that full respect for the principle of subsidiarity is essential in these areas, since these are very sensitive national competences and decisions that can have a major impact on the future of social organisation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this own-initiative report which draws up a scoresheet of the progress achieved in the area of gender equality in Europe. The report highlights areas of progress in achieving gender equality. It emphasises the fact that the female employment rate is still low, that the gender pay gap stands at 16.4 % and it sheds light on several important criteria that still need to be fulfilled to reach equality. These include the elimination of wage differences between women and men, violence against women, the promotion of work-life balance, as well as the need to achieve the Barcelona targets in the European Pact for Gender Equality (2011-2020). I support and promote these fundamental values and actions. The report also calls for promoting a ʽright to abortionʼ, an issue that is not within the EUʼs competence and such a call for an EU policy on sexual and reproductive rights violates the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. As voted the report is contradictory in itself on this issue. It was for these reasons that I voted against the report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is balanced, while expressing innovative positions, which go in the direction of achieving real gender equality. A concrete equality, not only formal, which guarantees a balanced relationship between genders in all areas of daily life, starting with the world of work, where - as confirmed by the dramatic figures of the economic crisis - it is precisely women who pay the highest price. The work and professional dimension, of course, also has a decisive impact on personal relationships and private life. In this area too, important steps remain to be taken, starting with minimum rights, such as paid paternity leave of at least ten days, or more complex, such as the issue of the maternity leave directive. Finally, in the more private sphere, it was essential, after the defeat suffered in the vote on the Estrela report, that it was finally possible to reaffirm that the EU must have, while respecting the prerogatives of the States, a role in promoting best practice, including in the field of education and sexual and reproductive rights. Last but not least, we should welcome the recognition of women's right to control their own health, including through 'easy access to contraception and abortion'.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the progress made in the EU on equality between women and men in 2013 to be very useful and important, as it draws attention to the problems and inequalities that women face on a daily basis, including violence against women and discrimination. Traditional gender roles and stereotypes continue to have a strong impact on the division of responsibilities between women and men in households, workplaces and society in general, thereby limiting women's employment opportunities and personal and professional development and preventing them from fully developing as independent persons and economic operators.  The creation of equality between women and men is not only a moral task, but also an economic interest for all Member States and society, since, for example, the gender pay gap, which is currently stagnant at 16.4%, would increase economic growth by 0.1%.  In addition, the OECD forecasts that a fully equal participation rate in the labour market would result in a 12.4% increase in GDP per capita by 2030. Ignoring them is a luxury we cannot afford in the current economic climate. However, since the Tarabella report also wants to regulate an area which is entirely a member state competence, that Member States should ensure easy access to contraception and abortion, I voted against this report.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The Europe 2020 strategy aims to create a sustainable and inclusive smart economy, and this is only possible through policies implementing real equality between men and women. There is still much to be done to achieve a full affirmation of women's rights, including (and above all) in the field of sexual reproduction. I am totally opposed to banning abortion. A full affirmation of women's health rights (and not only) can only go through the possibility, in certain cases, of having access to abortion. In this sense, the law in Italy has some very positive aspects that could inspire European legislation, sometimes still too hesitant on this fundamental point.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which emphasises the need for equality between men and women; however I voted against all clauses related to abortion. I agree with the focus of the report on a number of important issues including the need to fight poverty, the need to have more women in high positions, boards and secure jobs, the need to have the maternity leave directive in place and to have paternity leave. The need for women and men to receive the same salaries for the same work they do and the need to address domestic violence in an effective manner. Whilst acknowledging that this is an important resolution, this does not in any way mean that I am in favour of abortion.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. The adoption of the Tarabella report, over and above the inevitable controversy raised by issues of sexual and reproductive rights, is an undeniable step forward for the protection of women. There is still too much discrimination and prejudice suffered by women. In Italy, gender equality is still a pipe point, but in Europe it is not. That is why I and most of my M5S colleagues have decided to support this proposal, including defining sexual and reproductive rights as human rights and making it clear that women should be solely responsible for them through easy access to contraception and abortion, as well as to all sexual and reproductive health services. This is not a report for or against abortion. But it is about equality and the right to decide, which is a fundamental right. At the same time, more and more women are in precarious or part-time jobs, and the pay gap is unacceptable in many EU countries.   In order to see real change, we need binding measures. Men and women are not and will never be equal, but they must have the same rights. This is true gender equality

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I firmly believe that the EC and the Member States must promote effective measures to guarantee equal opportunities for women in agriculture, which must be a central objective in all relevant Community policies at European level with a view to improving the quality of life of women living in rural areas by ensuring their easy access to education, social protection and vocational training , lifelong learning, effective and appropriate local public health services, infrastructure and services for children and families, in particular nurseries, kindergartens, schools, cultural centres and local markets.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Marc Tarabella's report is a report on progress on gender equality in the EU in 2013. I voted in favour of this text which calls on the European Union to actively combat violence against women, domestic violence and forced marriages, which have been my favourite for many years now. It also calls for real professional equality between men and women, by promoting women's participation in economic and political decision-making and by combating differences in pay.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to provide an assessment of progress on gender equality in the EU for 2013.  The report calls on the European institutions and Member States to integrate this issue more strongly into the development of their internal and external policies. It also raises the issue of equality between women and men in the areas of employment and decision-making, areas where progress remains to be made on equal pay and also to better address the difficulties of reconciling work and private life. As such, the report deplores the blocking of the Maternity Leave Directive in the Council.  In addition, issues of combating violence against women and gender stereotypes are discussed.  Finally, among a number of identified societal challenges, issues of sexual and reproductive rights and same-sex marriage are addressed. These issues are purely national and the European Union does not have to take legislative initiatives on these issues, which is why I voted against the associated paragraphs.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual (PPE)
text: in writing. In my own name and right and representing the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group as Secretary-General, we would like to state, in relation to Marc Tarabella's Report on Progress in Equality between Women and Men in 2013, that while we supported this report today in the final vote - because it is of great importance on key issues for equality between women and men , such as the fight against gender-based violence, the reduction of the pay gap or the reconciliation of working and family life - we do not agree and have therefore voted against recital Ae and paragraphs 44 and 45 of that report. These sections refer to abortion and sexual and reproductive health rights. These are very sensitive issues related to the right to life, a priority for our political formation, and on which we have been speaking unequivocally. Moreover, the European Union has no competence in this area.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Despite real progress, inequalities between men and women are still evident in European states. This is at a time when women make up more than half of the population and are now more likely than men to pursue higher education.  The European Union rightly defends women's rights in its external action. But it must also continue to act tirelessly within its borders. Violence against women, which is unbearable, must be vigorously combated. Women must have the choice to live the private and family life they desire, with no impact on their professional future. Real equality between men and women in the political and professional spheres is a fundamental right.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. Even today much remains to be done to achieve true equality between men and women in our society and that is why I voted in favour of the report on progress on gender equality in the Union in 2013. Indeed, this report is balanced, makes a clear and realistic observation of the situation, presents pragmatic proposals and recalls the struggles we still have to fight: reducing the wage and pension gaps, improving education and training for better access to employment, strengthening the fight against violence against women and stereotypes.  This report also mentions women's control over their sexual and reproductive health and rights, it is a subject within the competence of the Member States and that is why I voted in favour of an approach that respects the distribution of powers between The Member States and the European Union but also defends the principles developed in France by the Veil Act.

name: Karima Delli (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted a report on 10 March 2015 on progress on gender equality in the European Union in 2013. I voted in favour of this report, which recognises sexual and reproductive rights as fundamental rights.  In order for European women to have control over their health, sexual and reproductive rights, it is essential to increase access for both women and men to services such as contraception, abortion, family planning, prenatal and postnatal care, treatment of sexually transmitted diseases, etc. Similarly, there is also a need to ensure access to education, prevention and information on these same topics, for adolescents and adults alike, in order to ensure better use of health, sexual and reproductive rights services.  The report also highlights the continuing barriers to gender equality in the EU and lists areas where the EU and Member States must continue to take active action.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the Tarabella report on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013. This is because the report discusses many areas where urgent progress is required, and not least the need for women to be able to exercise control over their reproductive health, and for better and higher-quality access to information and services in the area of sexual and reproductive health. One of the articles of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union actually obliges the EU to protect and improve health protection within Europe. Sexual and reproductive health are an essential element of people’s overall well-being. This is particularly relevant in the UK where there is evidence that standards of sexual health are falling and insufficient progress is being made against communicable sexually-transmitted diseases.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ While there are good elements to this report, they are vastly overshadowed by a desire to violate the fundamental right to life of the unborn child.  My opposition to this is not just a moral objection, but also the principle of subsidiarity. The EU has no right to instruct national governments to provide sex education in a certain way or abortion on demand.  However, I welcome the focus on tackling violence against women in society, something which affects – or has affected – one in four in my constituency, Northern Ireland. In 30% of these cases, abuse starts during pregnancy, which is shocking. This issue needs to be tackled, and I support making 2016 a European Year for combating this crime. I also support action to end the scourge of female genital mutilation, as well as the desire to see more women equipped with the skills and confidence to enter the labour market, local decision-making or to generally gain a greater stake in society. Many grassroots women’s organisations already carry this work out in Northern Ireland, and I trust that the latest round of ESF funding will respect their importance to local communities.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The Tarabella report is a compilation of proposals that fall under the total subject. It all started from a principle of common sense, specific to Western philosophy and our Christian roots, that of equality between men and women.  This text mixes with gender theory and its procession of intellectual wanderings, paternity leave, abortion or even tax reform, while describing a grossly false view of the family proving that certain political forces of the European Parliament want the destruction of it. And it is above all women and children who will suffer attacks on this basic cell of European societies that is the family and which some perceive as retrograde or oppressive for women.  On the other hand, there is no mention of the structural changes taking place that threaten equality between women and men in Europe today, starting with cultural practices that are foreign to our civilization and nurtured by communitarianism and multiculturalism. I therefore voted against this report, which focuses more on an ideology than on the defence of women in Europe.

name: Damian Drăghici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is imperative to combat poverty among women, especially older women and single mothers, but also women who have been victims of gender-speaking violence, women with disabilities, migrant women and those belonging to minorities. Member States must respect the principle of equal pay and wage transparency and review their national legislation on equal treatment in order to modernise and simplify it with a view to eliminating, for example, cases where women do not receive the same salary even though they occupy the same jobs as men or of equal value. Financial independence is an essential means of ensuring equality, which is why entrepreneurship among women must be promoted and supported by facilitating access to credit, reducing red tape and other obstacles for women starting a business.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to keep access to abortion in the report but voted against the overall report as the EU has no remit for legislating in social issues such as childcare, taxation, education and housing.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of Podemos voted in favour of the Tarabella report on equality between women and men. We were particularly alarmed by the attempt by conservatives and extremists to degrade recommendations for equality and did not understand why we were trying to soften the worrying consequences of inequality in Europe. This report also integrates contextualisation of the worrying increase in inequality during the crisis, as well as supports at European level the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it supports, among other things, the legalisation of abortion as a means of ensuring sexual and reproductive health.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 32 because we oppose calling for the EU to meddle with the UKʼs immigration system regarding undocumented migrants and telling countries that they cannot report cases to the authorities. However we absolutely condemn cases where women (whether migrant or not) have been subjected to abuse and would support criminal investigations no matter what the circumstances. The EU call for cases not to be reported to the authorities may help those perpetrating such crimes to avoid being brought to justice.  UKIP abstained on paragraph 50 as we cannot support calling on the EU to interfere with the UKʼs immigration system regarding the right to residency. However it is perfectly reasonable for a migrant woman to be granted autonomous residency (meaning that residency is not subject to being part of the family unit she first entered with), especially in cases where the woman has been subjected to domestic violence.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As we all know, Europe has set itself virtuous objectives with the Europe 2020 strategy, but some of them will only be achievable with real equality between men and women; I am thinking, for example, of the target of 75% of employment, which can only be achieved in 2038, given that the growth in female employment since 2002 has only been 4%. These figures, among many other possible, show us a world of work still hostile to women, especially when we consider that they represent as many as 60% of European graduates and despite this receive a remuneration that is estimated to reach full equality with that of men only in 2084 (equality that would lead to an increase in EU GDP of as much as 12%) with drastic consequences also on their pensions, which we know are 39% lower than those of men. All this only by talking about the world of work, but in reality there are many others on which serious gender disparity can be highlighted; I therefore voted in favour of this text because it seems to be clearly stressed the importance that achieving true equality between men and women has in the growth, including economic growth, of Europe.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted positively for this report, first of all, for the need to give due importance to the role of women in the framework of the new policies of revitalization of the economy, ensuring that the gain that is removed from these policies effectively reverts to greater empowerment of women. And there is evidence of the need for this procedure: the increase in the employment rate of women remains quite slow, evolving from 58.1 % to 62.8 % in the last 10 years, an obviously tenuous and disappointing development. If the current trend continues, the Europe 2020 strategy target will not be achieved until 2038. It is therefore essential and urgent to promote women's participation in the labour market. Secondly, we observe the persistence of the wage gap between the two genders: "If the current trend continues, it will be necessary to wait until 2084 for women and men to earn equivalent salaries." It is therefore relevant to act on this issue in order to expedite the reduction of this difference.  Finally, these reasons are the need for a concerted EU response to poverty in older women (10 % higher than men) and the need for a strong political signal on the reform of the Maternity Leave Directive.

name: Fredrick Federley Marit Paulsen och Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. We voted in favour of this non-legislative resolution because it highlights, among other things, the importance of continued ambitious work on gender equality in the EU and the right of women to decide over their own bodies. We support that. However, we would like to stress that many of these issues are currently being decided – and should continue to be decided – at national level.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As the report points out, it is regrettable and we must step up the action to eradicate the fact that women do not earn the same salary as men in cases where they perform the same functions or functions of equal value. The one-percentage point reduction in the gender pay gap will lead to an increase in economic growth of 0.1 %, which gives the reduction of the gender pay gap a crucial importance in the current context of economic slowdown. Equal participation of men and women in the labour market could significantly increase the EU's economic potential. There are more women than men living in poverty and social exclusion, especially older women, whose pension is on average 39 % lower than men. It is urgent that the Council take a position on the Maternity Leave Directive, because the current Directive does not reflect the evolution of society. A comprehensive policy framework on gender-based violence should focus on prevention, prosecution against offenders, protecting victims, education for equality, and imposing sanctions on violent or discriminatory behaviour towards women.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and that is why it is important to insist on reports like this that I value very positively, in scourges such as gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society. I would also like to highlight the report's focus on other issues such as the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making.

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI)
text: In writing. Under the previous Parliament, Parliament had to consider the Estrela report, which was rejected. But once again, the European Union is applying its customary jurisprudence, which could be translated as: "when the people or their representatives vote badly, a new vote should be made". So today we have the Tarabella report.  At the same time, an exhibition of the courageous Jérôme Lejeune Foundation is being held in these buildings to help children suffering from Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). However, many in this House want to support the disabled but preferred not to see them by voting for this sad report.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. The adoption of the Tarabella report on equality between men and women in the EU, over and above the inevitable controversies raised by sexual and reproductive rights issues, is an undeniable step forward in terms of women's protection. It is regrettable to say that, unfortunately, there is still too much discrimination and prejudice suffered by women.  In order to combat the imbalance in relations between men and women, it must be reiterateed that the right to equality between the sexes depends on the recognition of certain priority demands, which are reflected in the report in question: - the right to equal treatment in the world of work, eliminating, among others, obstacles to women's participation in decision-making processes;  - the right to reconciling professional and private life through the recognition of parental leave for both parents;  - an effective and effective fight against violence against women, with severe penalties but also by promoting the training and information of citizens on these issues;  - the giving of women control over their own health and sexual and reproductive rights, while reaffirming the primacy of the Member States in the formulation of the relevant policies. These are the main reasons why I voted in favour of Mr Tarabella's report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report makes a reasonable diagnosis of the setbacks that women's rights have had in recent years, particularly in the last decade, although we do not agree with some statements when trying to make it believe that the European Semester can meet social objectives, which is impossible because it is contradictory. On the other hand, the report blames neither the EU nor governments for the policies that have led to the destruction of states' social functions, unemployment, falling incomes, pushing women into poverty, exploitation. We have proposed a number of amendments in this regard which have all been refused by the majority of Parliament, which is a great thing about its position in this area. In fact, there is no desire to identify the true causes of these setbacks. The reconciliation between personal and professional life has also deteriorated: working hours are more deregulated and more intense, making this conciliation difficult, and this is a manifest option for the EU and its governments. We also welcome this report to address sexual and reproductive rights from a fundamental human rights perspective, and that it recommends facilitated access to contraception and abortion, although we recognise that it is up to the Member States to define health policies. We voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ despite all the steps taken by the European institutions in the field of women's employment, the fact remains that since 2002 the employment rate for women has increased by only 4.7%, which is woefully low. Women increasingly have to worry about their jobs. Part-time work is increasing and women often have to settle for lower wages than their male counterparts. According to the latest reports, women do not cope with men's salaries until around 2084, which is undoubtedly very motivating and depressing in finding a job. It is clear that there are several reasons for the current outstanding pay situation. One of them is undoubtedly that the Member States are completely ignoring Directive 2006/54/EC on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation. Another factor is the outdated regulation of the Maternity Leave Directive, which does not reflect the actual state and does not provide sufficient support and protection for mothers. Women's rights have recently been marginalised and are becoming a secondary problem, which is undoubtedly unfortunate and unfair, because gender equality between men and women is an essential agenda that should be given due importance.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is another missed opportunity for Parliament and the rapporteur. It has turned an important issue such as equality between men and women into a manifest report that includes things that are absolutely unnecessary and politicised.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In the whole report my vote will be against the fact that it supports, among other things, the legalisation of abortion as a means of ensuring sexual and reproductive health.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. U2012 Equality between men and women is a right recognised in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights as well as a basic pillar that must govern the behaviour of our society. While we have made great steps in recent decades in this direction, there is still a long way to go to achieve the ultimate goal of achieving real equality. Among other aspects, European women today continue to have more trouble accessing the labour market and receiving a lower wage for the same job. It is unacceptable that these situations continue to exist in the EU of the 21st century, so we must work more hard to eradicate the scourge of any kind of discrimination in our society.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself a sclergy advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. The Tarabellla report addresses all these issues.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself an out-of-the-top advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making... and the Tarabellla report contains all these issues.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I was forced to vote no to a text, that of the Tarabella report, which contained many positive ideas. The overall goodness of the text, in the field of equality between men and women, has in fact been corrupted by the insertion of paragraphs that have nothing to do with the subject dealt with, let alone with EU competences. The final text is in fact contradictory: on the one hand, thanks to a PPE amendment, it rightly states what is enshrined in the Treaties (and already repeatedly stated by the Commission and Parliament), namely that competence in the field of abortion is only and exclusively national, on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity, on the other hand it attempts to introduce, an alleged 'right to abortion'.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to vote in favour of and support the adoption of the report on equality between men and women in the European Union presented by Mr Tarabella: a 360-degree programme of strong support for the equivalence of personal, social and professional rights, which enshrines and strengthens what has already been ratified in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, protecting more of its aspects of the treatment of women, which are unfortunately still not sufficiently acquired or guaranteed today. Even today, one third of older women in our countries are not entitled to a pension, and even those who have it are recognized on average 39% less than those of men. The same disproportion for women about the percentage of graduates: 60%, compared to the mere 33% we find in managerial roles and in any case with about 16% less pay than the salaries of male colleagues. Unfortunately, stereotypes and discrimination are still dangerously pervasive in our society. Europe, the guarantor of human rights, adopts every method at its possession to support the promotion of women's participation in the labour market by ensuring equal opportunities and treatment with real compliance with Directive 2006/54/EC still not applied in 26 countries. An OECD study in 2012 reveals that EU GDP could grow by 12% thanks to equal participation by women in the world of work: this means that an inclusive, open, equal and integrated market would mean growth and the fight against social exclusion for all of us. Europe is strengthening social and fiscal policies to protect the fragilities of older women, single mothers, victims of abuse, workers who have difficult access to minimum services or who do not have the right to motherhood recognised and all too often face precariousness, unemployment or the sad choice between motherhood and the possibility of continuing to live in dignity. Europe really is the guarantor of human dignity and equality.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the outcome of today's vote, which fully reflects the need for comprehensive measures to promote women's participation in the labour market.  Despite the efforts of the Commission and the Member States, the rate of increase in female employment remains unsatisfactory. It has changed from just 58.1% to 62.8% since 2002. If the current trend continues, the Europe 2020 target of 75% will not be achieved until 2038. If the 'gender' pay gap continues, women and men will not earn equally until 2084. Disparities are also evident in poverty, where 22% of older women are at risk compared to 16.3% of men.   After a period of drastic tightening of the belt in times of crisis, it is time to revive growth so that Europe becomes a strong and inclusive economy. In this context, priority will have to be given to measures to reconcile private and working life. Formal childcare services in Europe remain very expensive, preventing as many as 53% of women from working, according to research by the European Commission.  The report's proposal to introduce 10 days of paid paternity leave and to treat women's right to decide on reproductive plans on an equal footing with fundamental rights is positive. It remains for me to congratulate rapporteur Marc Tarabella on his excellent report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The vote on the Tarabella report has occupied many people very busy. In recent days, I have received thousands of messages from concerned citizens asking me to reject the proposal for a universal right to abortion. I share these concerns and have therefore decided to vote against the Tarabella report.  It is true that the Tarabella report contains good proposals to improve equality between women and men; Violence against women, forced prostitution, old-age poverty, the existing pay gap between men's and women's salaries or the reconciliation of family and work are important issues. Unfortunately, however, a substantial part of the report also concerned the demand for a general right to abortion. I am opposed to easier access to abortion; we must protect unborn life. I am not prepared to compromise on this issue. We have already debated the possibility of abortion intensively at national level. According to the principle of subsidiarity, the responsibility here lies solely with the Member States. Other groups have insisted on ensinuating the general right to abortion in the report. That is why I voted against the report. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have agreed on this before.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to the Tarabella report, which comes at a time when the advancement of gender equality, one of the EU founding values, is under severe threat. Too little has been done to reach key targets in the EU strategy for equality between women and men 2010-2015. The result is next to no progress on mainstreaming gender into policy-making and budget procedures; weak female participation in the labour market; gaps in the enforcement of the directive on equal opportunities and treatment in employment; and a blocked Maternity Leave Directive. Sadly, the UK Government seems keen to follow the EU trend. In the zero-hour contract economy set up under the current coalition government, a quarter of women are on low pay, while recent changes to legal aid for family law cases risks leaving women who have fallen victim to violence standing in the cold.  I hope this report will serve as a wake-up call to the Council and Commission. Because in 2015, equality between men and women should not be an issue that can be put before the ballot. It should be a reality.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. – The UK delegation recognises that equality between men and women is essential for the advancement of society as well as contributing to economic prosperity. A just and fair society is one that includes both genders and affords the same rights to girls and boys, men and women. The UK delegation strongly believes that men and women should be paid equally for work of equal value; we strongly believe that women should have the same opportunities as men when it comes to working in male dominated fields such as engineering, science and technology. The UK delegation condemns violence against women and we have continued to speak out against FGM. The UK delegation has always supported legislative directives aimed at strengthening and protecting women’s rights (European Protection Order, Combating Human Trafficking and Victim's Rights Package) and we have a track record of supporting the Daphne programme which tackles domestic violence at grass- roots level.  However, the Conservatives in the European Parliament want to see decisions made as close as possible to people and we are concerned that this report goes way beyond this Parliament’s competencies. This report extends into areas such as public procurement tenders, taxation, childcare, free healthcare, maternity and paternity leave, family reunification, sex education, abortion, gender quotas for women on company boards and political party lists and even housework.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the Tarabella report. As usual when Parliament addresses these issues, there is a perception that it is less about equality of rights, equality of treatment than about the denial of their obvious and happy differences. No, Mr Tarabella, men and women are not totally substitutable, interchangeable entities. No, their differences are not the perpetuation, since the Stone Age, of "gender stereotypes". They are subject to objective, natural, normal causes. Certainly, at work and equal skill level, women must have the same salary as men. Of course, young girls who have a taste for it must be able to access professional careers that are more reputedly male. And those who want to be able to access political responsibilities. My party has no lessons to learn on this point.  But it is also clear that the first service to be given to women is to recognize their uniqueness, to listen to them and to take into account their aspirations. And in particular to give financial autonomy to those who prefer to devote themselves to their families rather than become the "homo Europeus" you dream of: grey, asexual, a-cultur, economic agent before being a human being.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The Delegation of Podemos voted in favour of the Tarabella report on equality between women and men. We were particularly alarmed by the attempt by conservatives and extremists to degrade recommendations for equality and did not understand why we were trying to soften the worrying consequences of inequality in Europe.  This report also integrates contextualisation of the worrying increase in inequality during the crisis, as well as supports at European level the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I regret that the European Parliament adopted marc Tarabella's report on progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013. It is scandalous that Parliament is calling for abortion to be introduced throughout the Union. I would like to stress that world-view issues are a matter for the Member States. Abortion is not a fundamental human right, but a murder.   This document also undermines the model of traditional family as well as Christian values, promoting a new social system where there is no father or mother, and education blurs the gender identity of children.  I voted against this resolution because it encroaches on the competences of the Member States in violating the principle of subsidiarity. I firmly believe that the EU institutions should not put pressure on access to abortion. The European Parliament, as the only EU body derived from direct democratic elections, should listen to the voice of its citizens, and the vast majority of them do not wish to exert such pressure.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted strongly in favour of this report. While it is true that, as some have said and above all used as a pretext, the European Union has no direct competence in social policy, the Union has a real competence for the promotion and defence of gender equality and to combat all forms of discrimination on the basis of sex.  A few days before International Women's Day, it was important to support this well-balanced and fairly symbolic report, which stresses the road ahead for gender equality, highlights persistent obstacles and, above all, proposes several ways to reduce these inequalities.  In particular, I strongly support the provisions of the report on violence against women calling for a European year to combat violence against women in 2016, when the statistics on this subject are alarming!

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted last Tuesday in favour of a report to promote equality between men and women in the European Union. This text makes a clear and present observation from this one, strong and pragmatic proposals to make a positive change for women's rights in Europe. It is time to reduce the gender pay and pension gap, improve education and training for better access to employment, break stereotypes and strengthen our fight against violence against women.  Together with my colleagues from the French UMP delegation of the EPP group, we also wanted to reiterate our commitment to women's control over their sexual and reproductive health and rights in line with the principles developed in France by the Veil Law.  However, we are aware that the fight for equality between men and women must be done in accordance with the divisions of powers between States and the European Union. The principle of subsidiarity is a fundamental principle that must not be subject to any exceptions.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself a staunch advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. The Tarabellla report addresses all these issues.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Like most of my colleagues, I supported Marc Tarabella's report on gender equality in the European Union. Despite some progress, much remains to be done to reduce inequality. This report addresses the main political challenges: wage and pension gaps, women's position in political and economic decision-making, consequences of the economic crisis, work-private balance, child care systems, maternity and paternity leave, sexual and reproductive rights, including contraception and abortion, and the fight against violence against women.  The European Parliament calls on Member States to ensure the implementation of the Directive on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment in employment and work, to unblock legislation on women on boards of directors, to promote education policies encouraging women to move towards careers in the scientific sectors , technologies and ICT, to address the problem of women working in part-time, low-paid and insecure jobs, and to provide quality childcare facilities for children and other dependents.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the progress on equality between women and men in the EU. One of the Europe 2020 goals is to reach 75 % employment and without the progress in this sphere, this goal will not be reached. Since 2002 female employment increased only by 4.7 % (62.8 %). If no extra effort is put in, this number will not increase.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself a staunch advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. The Tarabellla report addresses all these issues.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Progress on Equality between Women and Men in the EU in 2013 is a report that was voted upon in the European Parliament on March 10th, 2015. I welcome the elements of this report that deal with equality for women. The report referenced important issues like gender pay gaps, gender equality and violence against women. However, it is my view that the formulation and implementation of policies on abortion are a matter for each individual Member State and not the European Parliament. The European Parliament must not overstep its competence and must recognise the principle of subsidiarity, which is a founding principle of the EU. Therefore I voted to take out any reference to abortion from the report on equality. I felt that the report overall had merit and advocated for equality for women and as such, I was happy to support it.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. There is much criticism of individual proposals in the "Tarabella Report". This was also eloquently presented by the AfD, among others, by Bernd Lucke and Frau von Storch. I made things quite simple today: most of the measures proposed by Tarabella have nothing, but nothing at all, to do with the EU. They belong to the competence of the countries. Europe's cultures, practices, religious attitudes are simply far too different to dictate in Brussels how men and women deal with each other in Riga, Palermo, Athens or London. It should be noted that there is no mention here of universal human rights. On the one hand, we cannot constantly praise diversity and subsidiarity in Europe and then practise simplicity and centralism. That is why I rejected this report en bloc.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. On this report, which was voted on Tuesday 10 March by the plenary, I would like to make a denial.  My vote on the right to abortion and my final vote on the report are technical errors that I corrected immediately in the minutes. While I do not share all the assertions contained in this report, I would like to reiterate that I am committed to equality between women and men as well as to the right to voluntary termination of pregnancy. However, I also consider abortion to be a highly sensitive subject that is far from an innocuous approach for women. That is why I understand that such a decision, which is a matter of the conscience of each, does not reach consensus in the European Parliament. I believe that such an issue, which is also linked to the family, cultural and religious traditions of each people, should not be raised in the European Parliament, where fatally, when there is a diversity of cultures, beliefs and ideologies, confrontation and misunderstanding arises but never the solution.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is appropriate that we vote on this report a few days after International Women's Day. Progress is being made in achieving equality between men and women but statistics show that women's ambitions are still too often stifled. We should be making concerted efforts, for example, to achieve gender balance on boards not just of companies but in the public and third sectors too. Unfortunately, women must still put up with misogynist behaviour such as was witnessed at last weekend’s Labour party conference in Scotland. These attitudes should be consigned to the past – along with the Labour party in Scotland.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of Podemos voted in favour of the Tarabella report on equality between women and men. We were particularly alarmed by the attempt by conservatives and extremists to degrade recommendations for equality and did not understand why we were trying to soften the worrying consequences of inequality in Europe.  This report also integrates contextualisation of the worrying increase in inequality during the crisis, as well as supports at European level the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution. However, I voted against in paragraphs 9 and I because the European Parliament does not have the power to take a position on the taxation of member states.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013, as this equality is one of Europe's key fundamental rights. Furthermore, equality between women and men is one of the key objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which, through innovative policies, should achieve genuine gender equality.  On the other hand, I condemn any type of violence and abuse against women and the horizontal gender-based division, which unfortunately still exists when it comes to the labour market. I believe that coordinated action by European and national and regional and local authorities is needed to further improve and strengthen equality between women and men in all segments, both in private and business, political and otherwise.  In this context, financial independence and education of both sexes, and women's entrepreneurship, which can certainly contribute to the growth and competitiveness of the Union, are important. I believe that the European Union can become a true example of global proportions in respect for human diversity, among which one of the most important is gender.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This report hijacks the desire to protect women's rights to serve ideological and economic causes, promoting gender ideology that denies the specificities of both sexes, and the resulting complementarity. He simply denies the need for each child to be with his mother since paternity leave will de facto take time off maternity leave. It is therefore a question of increasing the number of individuals in the labour market in order to be able to weigh down on wages. This leads to the deterioration of the lot of women since men and women would be interchangeable. So I voted against this report.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 32 because we oppose calling for the EU to meddle with the UKʼs immigration system regarding undocumented migrants and telling countries that they cannot report cases to the authorities. However we absolutely condemn cases where women (whether migrant or not) have been subjected to abuse and would support criminal investigations no matter what the circumstances. The EU call for cases not to be reported to the authorities may help those perpetrating such crimes to avoid being brought to justice. UKIP abstained on paragraph 50 as we cannot support calling on the EU to interfere with the UKʼs immigration system regarding the right to residency. However it is perfectly reasonable for a migrant woman to be granted autonomous residency (meaning that residency is not subject to being part of the family unit she first entered with), especially in cases where the woman has been subjected to domestic violence.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on progress on gender equality in the EU in 2013. I consider that this report addresses in a balanced way the key issues of combating violence against women, economic independence and equal pay. Equality between women and men is an ongoing struggle. That is why I welcome the adoption of the report, which stresses the need for action in many areas and proposes several relevant avenues for action for the future.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. Equality between men and women is essential to the smooth running of our societies and is at the heart of the EPP Group's priorities. This report contained elements essential to the pursuit of this objective, which I supported, such as promoting women's entrepreneurship, defending equal pay, combating stereotypes and against violence against women.  Unfortunately, the drafter of this report has chosen to include provisions under the strict competence of Member States such as the issue of gender, or others that merely unnecessarily make a pale copy of consolidated principles of French law. The texts voted by the European Parliament must, in accordance with our electoral commitments, focus on the general European interest and stop wanting to enact rules in all areas, in particular on social issues. For all these considerations, I have chosen to abstain on the final vote.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that equality between men and women is a fundamental right, because any form of gender discrimination is unacceptable and - finally - because I believe that all EU institutions should take gender equality into account when formulating their policies, promote and safeguard them.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution since the report focuses on several important aspects on which improvement is needed. Among them are the promotion and support of entrepreneurship among women, combating gender stereotypes, encouraging measures for a better work-life balance, equal opportunities in matters of employment as well as combating violence against women. When it comes to sexual and reproductive rights, not least by having ready access to contraception and abortion, I believe women must have control over their sexual and reproductive health and rights and different choices available. However, the legislation in this area is and should remain in the competence of the Member States.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. I am opposed to the report that has been presented. In my work as an MEP, I have always advocated equality between men and women, but I am not convinced by the report's systemic approach. Not only does it violate the principle of subsidiarity of the EU Treaties and call into question tried and tested regulations, such as the time-limit solution, in the Member States. In terms of content, the report is also in favour of quotas, a proposal which I cannot support either. I also believe that the funding of agencies and programmes that deal uncritically with gender studies does not help to achieve real equality between men and women.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the progress made in 2013 in ensuring equality between women and men in the European Parliament's plenary session in Strasbourg. I believe that ensuring gender equality and progress in this area are of paramount importance in guaranteeing the human rights of every citizen of the European Union and promoting the well-being of citizens. At the same time, the elimination of discrimination is also important to ensure sustainable social and economic development, and therefore it is essential to exploit the potential of every citizen, regardless of gender. Economic and social achievements and progress are only possible if everyone's participation in shaping people's achievements is equivalent. Both women and men have enormous potential to promote economic growth and prosperity, both in Latvia and in other Member States of the European Union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Progress on Equality between Women and Men in the EU in 2013 is a report that was voted upon in the European Parliament on March 10th, 2015. I welcome the elements of this report that deal with equality for women. The report referenced important issues like gender pay gaps, gender equality and violence against women. However, it is my view that the formulation and implementation of policies on abortion are a matter for each individual Member State and not the European Parliament. The European Parliament must not overstep its competence and must recognise the principle of subsidiarity, which is a founding principle of the EU. Therefore I voted to take out any reference to abortion from the report on equality. I felt that the report overall had merit and advocated for equality for women and, as such, I was happy to support it.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Much still remains to be done to reduce inequality between men and women. It will take until 2034 to achieve equal pay and until 2038 for the employment rate of women to be comparable to that of men. It is high time to go beyond just words. Gender equality must be an integral part of all policies of the European Union. We must progress towards equality, but also allow women to balance family and professional life, promote paid paternity leave, and combat violence against women.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on this report marks an extraordinarily important step forward on the issue of gender equality. With this resolution, the European Parliament is tackling the issue of equality between men and women with strength, determination, in a complete and hypocrisy-free manner. A great achievement for all of us, because, despite all the progress made over the years to bridge gender inequalities, much remains to be done. It is not acceptable that, today, in 2015, in the European Union, on equal terms, the difference in pay between men and women is 16.4% and that it is a mirage that can only be achieved in 2084. We must start from education, from schools, a point on which it is essential to take action to ensure that there is a real cultural change in society, especially in terms of preventing violence against women. That is why european legislative action is important to encourage and support Member States' action in preventing, prosecuting perpetrators and protecting victims, while at the same time introducing sanctions for discriminatory and violent behaviour against women. With this measure, this House has mapped out a clear path for the Union and its Member States.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on progress on gender equality in the European Union. This report, entrusted to our Belgian colleague Marc TARABELLA, received my support during the vote, as well as that of almost the entire French delegation of the EPP group. This support responds to our desire to remain mobilized to advance equality throughout the Union, on several fronts, subject by subject: equal pay and retirement, access to education and political and economic decision-making circles, the fight against all violence against women and against trafficking in human beings. There is still a lot of work to be done, either that we are seeing regressions or that progress is too slow and that we need to accelerate the pace.  The EPP Group also wished to reiterate its commitment to respecting the principle of subsidiarity and the competences of Member States, whether in matters of social, family or marital law. The goal of equality between men and women is enshrined in the Treaty of Rome of 1957. This is a fundamental principle of the European Union, so we must work towards its realization.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report outlines the efforts still needed to improve the position of women in our societies.  It supports all policies that could promote this equality: legislation in the boards of directors, the unblocking of the maternity leave directive, the creation of paternity leave to share the task with one's spouse and all the policies, including education, that broaden the spectrum of available careers.  It is also concerned about the economic situation of women who often occupy precarious positions, and are the first victims, along with young people, of economic crises.  It is also a report that systematically defends the right to contraception and abortion, which is frequently questioned and still banned in some countries.  It is therefore important to stand up for women's rights, which I have done in supporting this report.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The Tarabella report bears the mark of a masked ultraliberalism and declined at the heart of society, in the family, by making equal treatment between women and men the vector of an ideology that seeks to atomize society and isolate individuals. This report suggests that European societies and their traditions would be archaic, dangerous and harmful to women and their freedom, whereas the family is indeed the only strong protection for women. The rapporteur uses as a weapon a jumble of concepts and proposals unrelated to equality between women and men, such as taxation, abortion or gender theory. The proposed means are also based on labour market reforms and public policies led by the European Union, and this report is a justification for illegitimate supranational instruments that weigh on the freedoms of States. Equality between women and men cannot be a matter of heavy European regulation inspired by political ideologies. However, the amendments proposing to reaffirm the competence of the Member States alone were rejected by a majority of Members of Parliament, which is the additional reason why I voted against this report.

name: Gilles Lebreton (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it tries to promote the theory of gender to which I am opposed. In addition, it seeks to impose parity in all areas, for example by encouraging the inclusion of "gender parity clauses in tenders for public procurement". But I prefer republican equality, which distinguishes individuals only on the basis of their virtues and talents, to parity that encloses them in sexual categories.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. It is above all an ideological relationship that tends to call into question the physical reality, the difference between men and women and their complementarity. No decision in favour of motherhood has been made. On the contrary, it is the affirmation of the disposition of one's body that is hammered, an idea behind which we find the defence of abortion. By insisting on the return to the labour market and the free disposition of one's body, the report adopts, contrary to the stated aim, a position of commodification of the body that must remain "available". There is no desire to offer women a real choice of life between a professional career, a choice defended or even imposed by this text, and a life partly dedicated to the education of children through the establishment of a real parental income. This choice imposed by the European Parliament can only have a negative impact on the demographics of European populations.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. Every year, the European Commission publishes a report on the status of equality between men and women, improvements and persistent inequalities. The report highlights that, despite the progress made, many inequalities remain between men and women, whether in terms of women's rights, human rights, career prospects, employment and wage conditions, access to education and health services, participation in the economy and decision-making or political representativeness processes. It also addresses the representation of women in decision-making, which remains in deficit. Finally, there is a section dedicated to the fight against gender-based violence which once again calls for a binding legal instrument, a European observatory against gender-based violence and declared 2016 as the European year against violence against women.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on progress in equality between women and men, as it is a policy document reiterating the importance of equality policies in the EU and Member States as a basic pillar to end inequalities in various areas such as labour and family reconciliation, the pay gap, stereotypes or the right to health. The report denounces non-compliance with the objectives of the European Commission's key gender equality document, the Equality Strategy 2010-2015, among other reasons for the withdrawal of the proposal for the Maternity Leave Directive. Moreover, while it is reiterated that health policies fall within the competence of Member States, it states that women should have control over their sexual and reproductive health and rights, in particular through easy access to contraception and abortion. However, I regret that there is no clear denunciation of how austerity measures promoted since the troika have precarious women's living conditions, further delving into the phenomenon of feminization of poverty.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I firmly support the Istanbul Convention regarding the elimination of female genital mutilation (FGM), as well as the resolutionʼs call for Member States to prevent domestic and sexual violence against women and girls. Women must have control over their sexual and reproductive health; this includes the access to contraception and abortion, but this control must also apply to men. I acknowledge the importance of active prevention, education and information policies aimed at, amongst others, teenagers, but this must apply equally to young girls and young men.  However, I do not believe that Parliament should impose gender equality by using gender quotas or by promoting through campaigns that girls enter traditionally male careers. I want to underline that it is important for me that each family decides on its own work-life balance, family structure and parental leave sharing. Forcing children and young people to follow educational studies based on gender or making them fight so called ʽgender stereotypesʼ, as mentioned in the resolution is, from my point of view, a violation of each individualʼs right to choose his/her personal future.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on progress on gender equality in the European Union in 2013. In my opinion, the Commission is not to speak either in educational programmes (paragraph 41), in the proportion of women in television broadcasting (paragraph 42) or in family relations (paragraph 50). Equality does not mean equalness. Equality before the law must always apply, but uniformity cannot be ordered. Genders have differences and quotas, nor do other forms of regulation ensure any equality. On the contrary, such policies lead to discrimination, where various minorities are not equalized, but directly superior.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental rights of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, so various laws have been adopted to ensure equality. It is regrettable that almost 50 years since the signing of the Charter, there remains a major discrepancy between women and men in some areas, and I call on the European institutions and all Member States to step up their efforts to address these problems.  However, I do not support The Tarabella MP's motion for a resolution because the provisions governing women's sexual and reproductive rights are unacceptable. In addition to the fact that the provisions undermine the fundamental human right to life, such an attempt to regulate reproductive and right to life is against the principle of subsidiarity and sovereignty of the Member States of the Union, since, according to Article 168 of the Regulation, the treaty on the functioning of the European Union, these issues are within the competence of the Member States. The proposal for a resolution calls, inter alia, on the Council and the Commission to address the effectiveness of social policies, education, employment and wage policies, the fight against domestic violence and sex discrimination, and we are tasked with ensuring community awareness of gender equality.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Progress on equality between women and men in the European Union has been a topic of utmost importance, especially since the financial crisis. There is a positive dynamic in terms of gender equality, but the employment rate for women remains quite unsatisfactory. More efforts are needed to reach European targets in this area.   That's why I supported the Tarabella report. Gender equality is a permanent commitment of the Union, moreover - it is a fundamental right. On the other hand, inequality affects our society directly - it hinders employment, development, economic growth.  Unfortunately, in the 21st century, factors such as domestic violence and gender stereotypes are still preventing women from unleashing their potential. My personal belief is that more civic education and equal access to information are key factors in this regard.   I believe it is our commitment as MEPs to create the conditions for a better representation of women in business, universities and research centres. Changes do not happen automatically, more effort is needed at all levels for both women and men to participate fully in economic life.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. Denmark is not directly affected by policies relating to residence permits and asylum, by virtue of the opt-out, not in judicial cooperation in the EU. We therefore refrain from taking a position on the points relating to these areas, recognising the right of other Member States to deal with them, but at the same time stressing that the issues do not have a direct relevance to Danish rules.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. The ÖVP delegation has made its approval of this report conditional on paragraph 45, which calls for easy access to abortion and encourages Member States to take appropriate action.  Both the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and the ÖvP are in favour of equality for women if it takes place within a legally and socially correct and appropriate framework. However, we cannot accept abortion under the guise of women's sexual and reproductive health, either today or in the future, especially in official positions of the European Parliament.  The European Union has no competence in the field of family policy, which is entirely a matter for the Member States. This subsidiary arrangement makes sense and will continue to be defended by our delegation.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Controversial "Report on progress towards equality between women and men in the European Union – 2013" Marc Tarabella is not only recapitulative, but also strategic, as he sets key goals for gender equality. Equality between women and men is not only an essential element of social justice, enshrined in the Treaty on European Union (Article 2 and 3), but also a condition for stable and inclusive economic growth. The inequalities still present in the labour market between women and men limit the use of women's talents and competences, which the economy is losing, and undermine the constitutional principle of social justice. The accumulation of inequalities in the labour market results in a pension gap of 39%, which translates into poverty for women. Hence effective policies for reconciling professional and family roles, tackling labour market inequalities and gender mainstreaming are priorities for gender equality, which is one of the EU's key values. In order to express my support for equality, I voted in favour of the report, including gender budget analysis, quotas for women in decision-making positions, equality education, access to reproductive health and sex education services, the inclusion of the concept of violence against women and girls in Article 84 of the Treaty and other proposals in the strategy. The exception was the passage on abortion: I voted against free access to abortion by registered vote.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is one of the main achievements - achieving equality between men and women. However, I voted to abstain, for example, with regard to the amendments that concerned a woman's right to abortion. I did not accept Amendment 16 concerning section 42, which led media regulators to fight the mass media in the Member States by combating gender stereotypes. We have enough of our Latvian 'teleradiodomi' to spread this practice throughout the EU.
