I abstained by voting in favour of Amendments 12 and 17 of the ECR and EPP Groups against women's right to abortion. Although my whole group had a position to vote against. I was also not acceptable in the offer to protect abortion information in paragraph 45 (Amendment 11). The same was also the "split vote" in both parts on abortion and contraception. I had a similar position (after citation 47) in both the EPP and the ECR Group amendments, which were about reproductive rights. Overall, I supported this report by our Member, Tarabella, because it has good ideas in addition to abortion (which I consider to be a form of murder) to fight for the rights of women who have suffered violence, as well as for a wage that is equal to that of men. Because discrimination against women only on the grounds of sex can not!

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ Equalisation of women and men in all areas of private, professional, social, economic and social life is a topic that needs to be given close attention. It needs to be tackled responsibly and sensitively at the same time. It is important for a healthy and strong society that the work and energy devoted to raising children who will lead and manage this society in the future be appreciated. Childcare services must be affordable for all.  If the European Union wants to move forward, it must tackle the issue of equality between women and men effectively and effectively. It is essential that the Commission and the Member States take into account the solution to this problem when developing policies in all areas. Any discrimination in this area will be a brake on the development of society in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013, because the European Parliament is taking the initiative and is calling on the Council, the Commission and the Member States to incorporate a pillar for gender equality into the Europe 2020 strategy in order to assess progress in reducing the gender employment gap.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text without hesitation. This report runs counter to human dignity and women's right to choose: it considers imposing full-time work on women who have chosen not to work or working part-time, it suggests the use of quotas as if this is the only way for women to be hired, and it calls for abortion , which can only negatively affect European demographics.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which calls for the EU institutions and the Member States to mainstream the issues of gender, women’s rights and equal opportunities in their policy-making, budget procedures and the implementation of EU programmes and activities, by means of pro-active measures, especially in connection with stimulus packages, by carrying out gender impact analyses on a case-by-case basis.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although much progress has been made on gender equality since the signing of the Beijing Declaration on Women's Rights in 1995, the improvements made remain insufficient and many inequalities between women and men still persist. Equal opportunities for professional careers, narrowing the wage and pension gap, and women's shares on boards are the basis for bridging gender inequality and achieving equal treatment for women and men. Real equality between women and men is undoubtedly a prerequisite for a return to growth. For these reasons, I voted in favour of Mr Tarabella's report.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported mr Tarabella's report because I believe that it addresses the issue of gender equality in an appropriate and balanced way. Despite the efforts of many, the reluctance of many is hindering a real advance in equality between men and women in Europe, in terms of social, work and economic inclusion.  The increase in the employment rate of women, the increase in feminicides, as well as the persistent wage and social security disparity between the sexes, justify the need to propose measures aimed at unhinginging the still-continuing backwardness in the field of gender equality. The Tarabella report proposes truly applicable actions, which are necessary with a view to guaranteeing European women a leading role. The brief references to the health sector, exploited by someone for ideological purposes, do not in any way undermine the quality of a text of a proactive and cross-cutting nature that we can support.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report addresses important issues such as the pay gap, women's participation in the labour market, the impact of the crisis, poverty, the proposal for a Directive on maternity leave, currently blocked by Member States, and thus makes a good diagnosis of the hard work still to be done on women's rights. I essentially point out and deplore the fact that women do not earn the same salary in cases where they perform the same functions as men or functions of equal value. In the EU, the gender pay gap is 16.4 %. The policies of several governments that have reduced wages and withdrawn social rights and which lead so many women to live in poverty and social exclusion must be held accountable. Effective measures are also needed to prevent and punish violence against women.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. My support for Marc Tarabella's 2013 Report on Progress in Equality between Women and Men in the European Union, which introduces key issues for equality between women and men, such as combating gender-based violence, reducing the pay gap or reconciling working and family life. Despite my general support vote on the report, I am against the content of recital Ae and paragraphs 44 and 45 of that report, which refer to abortion and sexual and reproductive health rights.  These are very sensitive issues related to the right to life, a priority for our political formation and on which we have been speaking unequivocally. Moreover, the European Union has no competence in this area.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I declined to report. In particular, the attempted implementation of a human rights on abortion is in no way to be supported. This would violate much of the existing Western legal bases and create a variety of problems. Only Member States themselves are allowed to take action in this area, which was originally handed over to the state, and only if it is in line with the will of the population.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on this report as I believe that the matters covered in this report are subject to the subsidiarity principle.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Every year, the European Commission reports on progress on gender equality. This year's report includes a documented analysis of developments in Europe, and highlights the slow progress made in recent years. He is in favour of gender equality. The report calls for women to control their sexual and reproductive health and rights, including through "easy access to contraception and abortion." He points out that the ban on abortion has no effect on the abortion rate. I am voting to support this progressive report in the face of reactionary forces.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal. I believe that there are matters where the principle of subsidiarity must prevail and the Member States should decide on them.  Matters relating to quotas and free access to voluntary termination of pregnancy should also take another approach and be discussed in a broader context.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report regrettably included unacceptable references to abortion. Despite my full support for gender equality and my commitment to achieving this goal, I could not support this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. While the gender gap is gradually narrowing, considerable efforts are still needed to achieve gender equality. Indeed, progress is still timid, and above all, takes time. I therefore voted in favour of this report for two reasons. First of all, I have always made it a point of honour to promote gender equality in the most varied areas. Secondly, it was mainly a matter of sending back a strong message: gender equality must be a priority for all. It is therefore time to continue to address these inequalities, including through more innovative policies.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the 2012 Progress Report on Equality between Women and Men in the European Union in 2013 covers areas where the Union and thus the European Parliament does not have competence under the Constituent Treaties. This is, in particular, the regulation of abortion which lies with the Member States.  In this respect, I recall that no international human rights document or EU law recognised the right to abortion as a human right.  However, it should be recalled that the Charter of Fundamental Rights clearly enshrines the 'right of everyone to life', and this right is obliged not only to respect, but also to protect and promote in their recommendations, the EU institutions, including the EP.  I therefore consider it unacceptable that formulations encouraging easy access to contraception and abortion should appear periodically in ep own-initiative reports. For these reasons, I am voting against the adoption of this report.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Universal Declaration of Human Rights states that ‘All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights’. Voting on a report on equality between women and men in the EU, two days after International Women’s Day, is an excellent opportunity to highlight the progress in the respect of equal opportunities for women and men across Europe. Furthermore, the report evaluates the different areas where progress is lacking in equal treatment (gender pay, pension and poverty gaps), actions needed in the field of violence against women, labour market discrimination, women in decision making, stereotypes and media etc., with which I fully agree. However, I expressed my reservations and voted against the paragraphs calling on Member States to implement measures on abortion, sexual health and reproductive rights. The EU has no competences on abortion policy at national level and can therefore not interfere in Member States policies in this area, which we should fully respect.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I think it’s essential that Parliament express itself on the implementation of such an important strategy. We need to talk and debate about the slow progress in achieving gender equality in Europe concerning in particular sexual and reproductive health and rights, measures to increase women’s representation in decision making/business leadership and maternity leave in order to change the current situation.  This report underlines the fact that female employment rate is just at 63%, and the gender pay gap stands at 16.4%. Almost a third of employed women work part-time, compared to 8% of men. Women should no longer be a gender minority.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was particularly sensitive to single family difficulties, which affects mostly women. It is sometimes difficult for us as a two-parent family with one child to imagine how incredibly difficult it must be for a single working mother. Childcare availability is crucial to the normal life of parents, all the more so for single parents. The fact that we still have no equal pay for equal work in Europe is surreal. As President Obama said in the State of the Union Address this year (more or less): hello, this is 2015!

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly agreed with the tone of the report on progress in the field of equality between women and men in 2013, which is expressly dissatisfied with the outcome of the steps taken to promote gender equality. By voting in favour, I wanted to support the proposals contained in the report so that similar reports in the coming years could report much faster progress.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal is to analyse the progress made in the European Union on gender equality, and some proposals have been put forward with which I do not agree.  To this end, I voted against the adoption of "parity and gender quota systems introduced in some Member States" because I believe that all people should be in public or private office by competence and recognition of their work, to the detriment of gender quotas. In addition, I also voted against the proposal to have "facilitated access to abortion" because I argue that prevention measures, family planning should first be adopted and contraceptive methods should be made available to prevent pregnancy, thereby protecting the safeguarding of the human right. Finally, I voted in favour of the report because I believe that it is essential to continue to work actively in improving gender equality not only in the European Union, but also around the world. The report focuses on this important theme and not on fracturing issues that have unfortunately been brought into the European debate and are the strict competence of the Member States.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The Tarabella report on progress on gender equality in 2013 proposes to include the gender equality target in Europe 2020 in employment, as part of stimulus policies, as well as to develop a gender-based social infrastructure investment plan to increase GDP.  If the objective of gender equality is laudable, it should not be done in defiance of the principle of subsidiarity. This report constitutes interference in matters under the exclusive jurisdiction of The Member States and comes at odds with the European Parliament's resolution of 10 December 2013 on sexual and reproductive health and rights.  The other objectives, such as those relating to female poverty due to single parenthood or retirement, wage inequality in equivalent positions, are meritorious, but the Union and the Member States have legally organised their powerlessness in the face of large multinational groups and thus cannot exert any pressure. Nothing is offered for the support of mothers who have made the choice to raise their children while having or are considering to have a professional activity.  So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the report which outlines key priorities for the EU to enhance the participation of women in the labour market. It also states the importance of enforcing the directive dealing with equal opportunities and treatment in employment and calls on the Council to state its position on the maternity leave directive, which is crucial for the advancement of gender equality in Europe. The report also notes the importance of the sexual and reproductive rights of women, maintaining that the women should have full control over their bodies.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on progress on gender equality in the EU in 2013. The text recalls that there is still a long way to go to achieve the reduction of the wage and pension gaps, the overcoming of "glass ceilings" and a strengthening of the fight against violence against women. The report stresses the right of women to control their health, sexual and reproductive rights, including access to contraception and abortion.  I have supported amendments which stress that the fight for gender equality at European level must be carried out in accordance with the competences of the Member States under the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the Tarabella report because this annual initiative report on progress on gender equality in the European Union is rather balanced and well structured this time, as the ideological considerations of previous reports have finally been erased. It takes up crucial points, such as violence against women, gender pay gaps and the career-high glass ceiling, which we must fight against.  With regard to the issues on women's sexual rights and reproductive health and abortion, these issues are, according to the principle of subsidiarity, the responsibility of States and not of Europe. For my part, I am sticking to the application of the Veil law in France. Equality between women and men is an ongoing struggle. We would have to wait another 70 years to see the goals of equality succeed, we cannot afford it.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting with conviction for this report because I consider it to be an important instrument that the European institutions can equip themselves with in order to advance gender equality in the Union.  A modern and comprehensive report, which takes into account all the many facets related to the situation of women: from the need for a rebalancing in the distribution of domestic work to the demand for progress in so-called 'gender medicine', ensuring equal representation between men and women in clinical trials. Looking at the report as a whole, it is clear that an evolved society such as the European one should have already made the transition from 'gender policies' to the inclusion of gender perspectives in all public policies.  In particular, it is crucial to insist on the point of education: hence all the tools we give to our girls, or of which we deprive them. In contemporary society, this means above all encouraging the learning of scientific and technological skills and skills in the digital field. From this investment today we will be able to reap the benefits of a generation of independent women tomorrow, able to create and develop their business idea and to change the current situation in practice by becoming protagonists.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. In particular, the vote on the report addressed the issue of abortion under these terms: "insists that women must have control over their sexual and reproductive health and rights, including through easy access to contraception and abortion".   For my part, I voted in favour of Amendment 11, which dealt with this passage and which states that 'health and reproductive rights fall under the competence of the Member States'. In other words, I have spoken out in favour of the issue of abortion remaining at national level and that the European Union, which has no jurisdiction in this area, should not be involved.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between men and women is a fundamental right, a common value for the European Union and a necessary condition for achieving Europe's objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. The Union has made considerable progress towards gender equality through the legislation implemented in this area, but this is still not enough. In the light of the above, I have chosen to vote in favour of Mr Tarabella's report because it describes in detail in 51 points the situation of equality between women and men in the EU and highlights the fact that equality, the objective and value of the Union as enshrined in the Treaties, is far from being achieved in the field of employment, wage and pension gaps, top positions and full enjoyment of sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report on the progress made on gender equality in the European Union in 2013 and which makes recommendations on equal treatment for women and men in the European Union.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it represents an important landmark in the fight for true gender equality in the Union. We are still behind what should be true normality. Half of the population of Europe is still not fully represented, paid, protected and respected, and I believe that no effort should be spared in this fight.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. I have refused to endorse the report. Partly through the back door, and partly quite obviously, the report aims to introduce gender mainstreaming measures, devalue the traditional family and legalise abortion on a blanket basis. Furthermore, the report does not take account of the principle of subsidiarity, as it interferes with member state competences.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on equality between women and men. I consider it important for the European Union to address the gender pay gap and reduce violence against women in a consistent and systematic manner. Women's lower wages not only affect their current economic security, but future incomes, such as pensions, also depend on it. Women's lower wages also make them economically dependent on their partner.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – The issue of gender equality in the EU must be given great attention. The report on progress in 2013 in the field of gender equality in the European Union has been prepared in a very comprehensive and qualitative way and reflects the most pressing problems in this area. However, the implementation of the provision on the establishment of the European Observatory on Gender Violence at the European Institute for Gender Equality raises doubts about insufficient financial and human resources. This would be a new task for the Institute and additional funding should therefore be provided. Another important aspect is the right of women to end pregnancy. There are questions about whether the formal legalisation of abortion is compatible with the scale of values where the highest place is given to life. After all, human life is protected from taking up. So when we talk about abortion, we must correctly assess both sides of the coin: on one side there is a freedom of choice and self-determination of a woman, and on the other there is a human life, and his right to life. However, in all cases, measures must be taken, both in the EU and in individual Member States, to ensure the most effective protection of the right to life.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The report on the progress of equality between women and men in the EU addresses, by no means by chance, the demand for female empowerment and equality as "equality" in exploitation. It seeks greater participation of women in the labour market, to extract more capital gains for capitalists. In the name of the "combination of family and professional life" it promotes the intensity of the exploitation of women with part-time work, flexible working relationships, without rights and hunger wages.  "Gender equality" is used by the EU, civil governments and the capital to remove conquests of women who met women's particular biological needs, such as the 5-year difference in retirement age and the ban on night work. The report obscures the fact that wage inequality and the reversal of industrial relations at the expense of women is at the heart of EU policy and civil governments in its Member States to reduce the price of labour, in favour of the profitability of monopolies. The interest of the women of the popular families is the conflict with the EU and the power of monopolies, their struggle through a strong popular alliance for the conquest of power and the organization of the economy on the basis of meeting their modern needs and not profit.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted strongly in favour of this text. Much remains to be done to reduce gender inequality. It would take until 2034 to achieve equal pay and 2038 to have an employment rate for women comparable to that of men. It is therefore high time to go beyond the beautiful words. Gender equality must be an integral part of all EU policies. That is what this report reaffirms.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 32 because we oppose calling for the EU to meddle with the UKʼs immigration system regarding undocumented migrants and telling countries that they cannot report cases to the authorities. However we absolutely condemn cases where women (whether migrant or not) have been subjected to abuse and would support criminal investigations no matter what the circumstances. The EU call for cases not to be reported to the authorities may help those perpetrating such crimes to avoid being brought to justice. UKIP abstained on paragraph 50 as we cannot support calling on the EU to interfere with the UKʼs immigration system regarding the right to residency. However it is perfectly reasonable for a migrant woman to be granted autonomous residency (meaning that residency is not subject to being part of the family unit she first entered with), especially in cases where the woman has been subjected to domestic violence.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that equality between women and men is a fundamental right enshrined in the Treaties since the Treaty of Rome of 1957 and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, but that the progress made in the field of gender equality remains insufficient and many inequalities between men and women still persist; whereas the number of women living in poverty and exclusion is higher than that of men; that women work more often than part-time men for family reasons and that women's poverty is largely due to the precariousness of their work; whereas the unemployment rate for women is underestimated, as many women are not registered as unemployed; Whereas, at this rate, we should wait until 2038 to reach the target of an employment rate of 75% for women and that equal pay would become a reality in 2084, for these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. Due to an emergency absence, I did not vote on the Tarabelle report. If I had been there, I would have voted against it for ethical, legal and formal reasons. I am for gender equality and for the inviolability of human dignity. I have a problem when a political or ideological interest uses or abuses this noble purpose for goals that have no real connection with gender equality. So, I'm for gender equality, not for what is being interpreted after this vote as the right to abortion. I can see abortion as a legal emergency exit, but I can't see it as a cure. The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union also ruled in the Brüstle case on 18 October 2011 that it was a man and his dignity from conception onwards. So it's also about his rights. Firstly, for the right to dignity and life, which is enshrined at the very beginning of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights – which is part of the Treaty of Lisbon, that is to say, part of the EU acquis. I regret that we are so different and polarised on such an important issue. And that we have given the European public the impression that abortion is a matter of gender equality. An ethically flawed attitude towards life is one of the key challenges of today's EZ. I don't want any of the elected people to gain political points with a superficial attitude to the way they live.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 EU GDP could increase by 12% if there is real equality between women and men in the labour market, according to a 2012 OECD study. Real equality in working life is therefore a prerequisite for a return to growth after a period of austerity, relaunching Europe so that it truly becomes an intelligent, sustainable and inclusive economy. We must strive for equal pay for men and women, the gap between salaries is still too great and it also affects women's future pensions. Breaking down stereotypes that still undermine women's desires to reach a certain position or to do a certain job must also be our primary commitment through promoting the role of fathers in family life. We must also review the conditions of mothers and maternity policies which are still based on a 1992 directive and continue to combat violence against women. On the contrary, the issue of sexual and reproductive rights must be taken seriously by all Member States, since it is a question of respecting the fundamental right of self-determination and the free choice of women on their own bodies.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. –in 2012 Almost half of women with professional occupations perform 10 out of 130 occupations listed in the international classification of occupations of the International Labour Organization, and only 16% of female workers are in positions in professional sectors where the proportion of men and women is equal. Only 31% of entrepreneurs in the EU are women. The employment rate for women is 63%.  The pay gap is 16.4%. Women and girls make up the vast majority (80%) victims of trafficking in human beings in the EU. Of particular concern is the fact that 6 Member States have not yet signed the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence (Istanbul Convention), and that only eight countries have ratified it. The achievement of the objectives of the 2010-2015 Strategy for Women's and Men's Equality will soon prove unsuccessful and progress in 2013 is inadequate, in particular in relation to economic independence, including due to the withdrawal of the proposal for a maternity leave directive. The European Union must show greater accountability to half of its population, which by a number of parameters are not equal and develop a general investment plan for social infrastructure, as it has been estimated that, for example by introducing an investment plan that takes into account gender, Europe's gross domestic product (GDP) would gradually increase by 2.4% more by 2018 than it would have increased without this plan.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Societies in the Member States of the European Union must make every effort to ensure that women achieve full equality in society and public life. There can be no disputes about that. Equality between women and men is certainly undermined by problems that occur in everyday life, such as pay gaps, violence against women, lack of women in entrepreneurship, the problem of combating gender stereotypes and many others. These issues need to be worked on engagedly, and women's rights and their moral and professional integrity should be strengthened. No one must deprive women of the freedoms to which they have all the rights under natural law and civilizational achievements, but certain paragraphs have been entered in this Report that provoke controversies of an ideological and worldview nature.  The right to abortion, the right to contraception and the right to independent reproductive activity of women are in fact ethical issues and should be discussed within the framework provided for. The report is not the right way to legally edit this, as this would violate the principle of subsidiarity. Accordingly, these issues should be left to national legislative authorities to decide.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, I was forced to vote against the Tarabella report on progress on equality between women and men, despite the fact that it contained many parts with which I agree. Such as the fight against violence against women, a better quality of employment for women and less precariousness, and the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for women and men in the field of equality and employment. At the same time, it is important that there should be equal pension conditions, corrective mechanisms must be put in place, tax policies and compensation provisions reformed. My vote against is due to the inclusion in the report of paragraphs which distort its aims and which are not relevant to them, such as the so-called right to abortion, for which I am strongly opposed.  I would also remind you that the subject of abortion is the sole and exclusive national competence of the Member States.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Although the European Union has adopted a number of documents throughout its existence in order to ensure equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women, with the clear aim of combating all forms of discrimination on grounds of sex, the progress made remains insufficient and numerous inequalities between men and women remain. In my opinion, the report presented by my colleague Tarabella not only soberly assesses the past period, but quite rightly appeals to the EU institutions and the Member States to take gender, women's rights and equal opportunities into account when drafting their policies, in their budgetary procedures and in implementing EU programmes and activities through proactive measures, in particular in the context of stimulus packages, by carrying out gender impact analyses on a case-by-case basis. I personally agree with this procedure in its particular forms mentioned in the report itself, and i am voting in favour of it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, inequalities between women and men have been reduced considerably in Europe. Significant progress has been made, but much remains to be done. Issues of wage, pension and inequality in access to education are important obstacles to achieving true equality between women and men. I am determined to advance this fight. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this report. It shows that, at the European level, the Union is committed to the Member States to reduce these inequalities. I wanted to stress that I am particularly attached to the French values laid down by the Veil act: women must maintain control over their health and their sexual and reproductive rights. On this particular point, I will not compromise. However, by my vote, I would like to point out that the Commission must respect the principle of subsidiarity: these subjects must remain the domain of the States. Europe cannot, must not take care of everything. This is the clever balance we have found to make Europe as efficient as possible.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between women and men is a fundamental principle of the EU, enshrined in the Treaties since the Treaty of Rome of 1957, and in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  This resolution notes the progress made in 2013 towards full gender equality. It points out from the outthen that the increase in the employment rate of women remains quite slow. Indeed, since 2002, it has gone from 58.1% to 62.8% and suffered the impact of the crisis. Indeed, fiscal consolidation policies have mainly affected the public sector, where women are most represented, and have led to an increase in precarious jobs (32% for women compared to 8.2% for men). These conjuncture factors are due to structural problems related, inter alia, to gender pay gap.  It should be noted that, according to an OECD study of December 2012, the EU could see its GDP increase by 12% if there was genuine equality between men and women in the labour market. Therefore, while I disagree with some of the aspects raised in the report, particularly with regard to the defence of easier access to abortion, I voted in favour, given the relevance of this issue.

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome and fully support the inclusion in rural development programmes of strategies to stimulate the implementation of new job opportunities for women in rural areas, which already demonstrate a good entrepreneurial capacity in this sector. We need to lift the cultural, social and economic obstacles that women face in relation to men, and not just in this sector. Global studies show that women have the same entrepreneurial skills as men, which is why Europe must be at the forefront of their exploitation.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. One year after the rejection of the Estrela report on gender equality, because of the conservative and traditionalist right, the European Parliament this time voted overwhelmingly in favour of the report by my Belgian Socialist colleague Marc Tarabella, which takes stock of the remaining gender inequalities in Europe and also lists many proposals for the situation to be resolved. Sexual and reproductive rights, violence against women, inequalities in working conditions (wages, flexibility, etc.), political representation are all essential subjects that this report tackles head on. At a time when the Council still refuses to make progress on European maternity leave, as well as on the integration of at least 40% of women on the boards of directors, to name but two examples, the adoption of this report is a very positive signal which I welcome. The Council must hear the voices of the elected representatives of European citizens and finally treat gender issues with the importance they deserve. It is not only about our principles, but also about the cohesion of our societies!

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in general, because it is quite balanced, by soothing the concerns for a society with a true equality between men and women, at a time when Europe shows very strong signs of an economic recovery and'therefore exit from the crisis, leading to compliance with the Europe 2020 strategy. In order to comply with this plan, it is essential to improve the quality of work and combat gender inequalities, particularly in factors such as the wage gap for the performance of the same tasks, inequalities in access to the labour market, among others. At the same time, I also advocate the urgency of implementing measures that favour the reconciliation of private and professional life in order to combat the persistence of stereotypes.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Equality between men and women has been a slogan, a flag and a struggle for centuries in Europe, and especially since the beginning of the last century. We women come a long way, but while enormous progress has been made, inequality remains a reality in many cases. I am not going to list all these situations of blatant and culpable disparities between the treatment of men and women. Having said that, when I speak of treatment, I could start by mentioning it literally: with the same function and responsibility, it will take until 2084 for equal pay to become a reality. This is obviously unacceptable, and counterproductive to our economy. A series of other figures put forward in this non-binding resolution seem to me to be unserious, but our message deserved to be. In all respects, this debate is major, and cannot, as it often is, be paternalisticly confined to women's commissions or women's rights ministries. It is in this sense that I have given my support this afternoon.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I will support all measures aimed at promoting gender equality at all levels. Furthermore, this motion for a resolution also takes a position on the Maternity Leave Directive. As the rapporteur rightly points out, the directive currently in force (1992) does not reflect the evolution of society and does not sufficiently protect mothers. I believe that competition policy and competitiveness in general are vital to the health and success of the EU and that they should be at the top of our political agenda. However, we must always keep in mind that this must never overtake the rights of workers and the fundamental guarantees of every citizen.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I consider myself a sclergy advocate for women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore important to insist on such important issues as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. The Tarabellla report addresses all these issues.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on progress on gender equality in the European Union in 2013, as I support, among other things, the fight for equal pay, the fight against violence against women and guaranteed access to contraception and abortion. On employment, I call for the European Parliament to ensure gender equality for fair pay and pensions, for greater flexibility in working schemes, for better pay for part-time work or for legislation on women's attendance on boards.  Moreover, it is time for the Council to allow a favourable outcome to the problem of maternity leave, which has been blocked since 2010. It is also essential to promote women's scientific careers and ICT, where there are, moreover, real needs. The report points to progress, but also weaknesses that need to be addressed as soon as possible. Women are still particularly affected by poverty, and work-life balance remains a challenge in many ways. That is why, beyond European legislation, I encourage men and women to a better balance of professional and family responsibilities.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a set of amendments proposed to this report by the EPP, which focused on the progress made in the European Union on gender equality during 2013. Unfortunately, as the rapporteur points out, there have been not many progress and there is still a long way to go in the European Union. Having said that, although I agree with many considerations contained in the final report, it contained two articles on extremely fracturing matters (which the EPP amendments have failed to eliminate) relating to sexual and reproductive policies which are the sole responsibility of the Member States in accordance with the European Treaties and the application of the principle of subsidiarity, so I voted against this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on progress on gender equality in the European Union in 2013. This text shows the European Parliament's willingness to continue efforts to achieve true equality between men and women, as there is still a long way to go.   These include working to reduce pay and pension gaps, improving education and training for better access to employment, strengthening our fight against violence against women and stereotypes, and breaking the "glass ceilings" on career development.  Finally, I and the French EPP delegation reiterated our support for the principles-based approach developed in France by the Simone Veil Act.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against Mr McDerman's report. Tarabella because I maintain that the Christian Jewish roots of the European people must always be recognised and defended. I believe that this document is not only an abortionist, but above all that it goes in the direction of demolishing the backbone of our society, which is the natural family.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because the text appears, on the whole, to be vague and far removed from the specific needs of citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The delegation of Podemos vot in favour of the Tarabella report on equality between women and men. We are particularly alarmed by the attempt by conservatives and extremists to degrade recommendations for equality and did not understand why we are trying to soften the worrying consequences of inequality in Europe. This report also integrates contextualisation of the worrying increase in inequality during the crisis, as well as supports at European level the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which takes stock of the progress made on gender equality in the EU in 2013. Far from certain caricatures, the report takes up most of our priorities: reducing the wage and pension gap - 22% of older women are at risk of poverty, compared to 16.3% of men - promoting education and training, combating violence against women and against stereotypes.  However, I would like to reiterate that the promotion of gender equality must be done with full respect for the principle of subsidiarity and the competence of Member States in this area. The European Union does not have legislative power over certain aspects of sexual and reproductive rights and must leave these issues to the sovereignty of member states and their national assemblies.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Having regard to my positive vote on the report ‘Progress on equality between women and men in the EU in 2013’, I would like to clarify that such a vote excludes approval for those clauses which signify acceptance of abortion and against which I voted separately when roll call votes were called.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. This report, while dealing with important issues that are not debated, such as equality between men and women, tends to call into question by some of these amendments the complementarity between men and women in an ideological way and above all promotes an ideological vision contrary to natural law and the principle of subsidiarity. I voted against it.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Tarabella's 2013 report on progress on gender equality in the EU shows that, although there is a slight improvement in this area, progress is too slow. For example, the gender pay gap, which is up to 30% in some European Union countries, is perceived as one of the biggest inequalities between men and women by European citizens themselves. I agree that, in order to reduce this pay gap, the European Union should take more executive action – with current developments, wage equality would not occur until 2084. Reconciling family and working life remains problematic. I therefore support not only my colleague Tarabella's report, but also the call for 2016 to be declared the European Year for Combating Violence Against Women.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 32 because we oppose calling for the EU to meddle with the UKʼs immigration system regarding undocumented migrants and telling countries that they cannot report cases to the authorities. However we absolutely condemn cases where women (whether migrant or not) have been subjected to abuse and would support criminal investigations no matter what the circumstances. The EU call for cases not to be reported to the authorities may help those perpetrating such crimes to avoid being brought to justice. UKIP abstained on paragraph 50 as we cannot support calling on the EU to interfere with the UKʼs immigration system regarding the right to residency. However it is perfectly reasonable for a migrant woman to be granted autonomous residency (meaning that residency is not subject to being part of the family unit she first entered with), especially in cases where the woman has been subjected to domestic violence.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, Labour MEPs and the Socialists and Democrats Group voted in favour of the report on progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013. This is a yearly report from the Committee on Womenʼs Rights and Gender Equality to outline the advances that have been made.  Key priorities set out in this report include further mainstreaming of gender into policymaking and budget procedures, the urgent need to increase womenʼs participation in the labour market and enforcement of the directive dealing with equal opportunities and treatment in employment. In addition, the report highlights the need for the Council to state its position on the blocked maternity leave directive.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Tarabella report. Some issues in this report are exclusively the competence of the EU Member States, such as abortion and sexual and reproductive rights. In my opinion we need to focus more on subsidiarity.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒Given the importance and gravity of the issue of inequality between women and men and the need to reduce it, I supported the equality report on women and men within the European Union in 2013.  I would like to refer to the fact that among the poor and socially excluded, the greatest number are women. Also, despite women representing 60 per cent of university graduates, they are now paid 16 per cent less than men per hour of work. If we add to that the difference in the employment rate among women of 63 percent, compared to the same in the case of men reaching up to 75 percent, we should condemn and change the common division of male-female tasks in our society.  Croatia is also following the same European trend. It is interesting that 30 percent more female than male scientific novices move in Croatian social sciences and natural sciences, but later more men remain in science for the aforementioned reason of women's commitment to caring for the family. I would certainly also take this opportunity to commend progress in the legislative process of tackling this problem and to welcome the Commission's proposal for a Directive that would see as many as 40 per cent of non-executive directors on company boards represent the less represented sex by 2020.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I supported the report because I think it is a report on the basis of which we can not only assess the results achieved so far in this area, but can become a very good stepping stone in terms of the future for closing other shortcomings and weaknesses that the report discusses. I am glad that the EU and its Member States have recently adopted a number of legislative measures to protect women, which have created a good basis for phasing out gender discrimination. I come and live in the east of Slovakia, the region with the highest unemployment rate. In my frequent meetings with women, I get questions that point to limited opportunities for employment, to incomparable wages and pay between women and men, to the threat to the elderly group, etc. That is also why I expect both the Commission and the individual Member States to create even better conditions in the next evaluation period, which will ensure further progress in equality between women and men.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the report on progress towards equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013, as equality between women and men is a fundamental right recognised since the Treaty of Rome in 1957. Unfortunately, progress towards achieving gender equality is still too small and inequalities between men and women still exist, although the European Union has adopted a number of texts to ensure equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women and to combat all forms of gender discrimination. It is important to take into account the various and intertwining forms of discrimination felt by many women and girls in Europe, as well as the fact that the situation has unfortunately deteriorated in recent years. More women than men live in poverty and on the margins of society, especially older women whose pension is on average 39% lower than that of men, and for single mothers who work part-time or fixed-term jobs because of their families. Precarious employment, however, is the main reason for their poverty. Women are also disproportionately represented in senior and senior positions, even though almost 60% of graduates in the EU are women. The proportion of women among scientists and engineers is less than 33%.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following 8 March, International Women's Day, I voted in favour of the annual report on equality between women and men in the EU prepared by my colleague Marc Tarabella. The call for a fairer society reflects the value of the anniversary in favour of women's rights, but also of the commitment of the whole community to equality. The resolution addresses issues that are important for European politics and society, such as the need to reduce the pay gap between women and men, the implementation of proactive policies in favour of women's employment (promotion of female entrepreneurship, reintegration into the world of work) and greater presence in sectors considered 'male', such as science and new technologies, the implementation of fiscal and social policies that take account of the evolution of family structures , the urgent need to relaunch effective policies against female poverty. It is also proposed to declare 2016 the 'Year against Violence against Women', providing for the allocation of adequate funds for awareness-raising actions against this social scourge.  The vote in favour of the resolution therefore expresses my commitment as a citizen and as a politician to a battle of fairness and justice that affects the citizens of Europe.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. More than 100 years after the first International Women's Day, we are still discussing the same unresolved problems: equal pay for equal work, maternity leave, workers' rights, violence against women. It is time to make way for a society where everyone has equal rights and equal opportunities.  Every week we are confronted with news about gender inequality and prevailing stereotypes. An OECD study shows that girls outperform boys in secondary education, yet still do not progress enough in fields such as maths, natural or computer science, because parents and teachers unconsciously perpetuate gender inequality. In India, authorities are trying to ban the documentary 'India's Daughter', which interviewed one of the perpetrators of the gang rape on a bus in late 2012. This is a violation of freedom of expression and a denial of how violence against women is deeply rooted in society. The figures speak for themselves: women earn 16.4% less than men for equal work in 2012. Female employment has increased, but consists mainly of part-time jobs with adverse effects on social rights building and pension building . Therefore, all support for this Tarabella report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 It is our duty to create a level playing field for both men and women. Women deserve more attention, not just by quotas, but by improving pre-school facilities, by more flexible labour law and by supporting family policy. It is also important that ethical issues are left to the decision-making of nation states.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ While I support the wording of the Gender Equality Report, I voted against this resolution because, against the principle of subsidiarity, it promotes abortion within the European Union. This breach of the principle of subsidiarity has triggered a reaction from more than 168,000 European Union citizens who, through an online petition, asked MEPs to reject article 45 of the disputed article. I would certainly like to point out that I welcome gender equality with all its characteristics, but without violations of the right to life, which begins from conception.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am a strong supporter of gender equality, and so I voted in favour of the resolution. The report sets out priorities such as the enforcement of the Directive on equal opportunities and treatment in employment, and challenges the Council on the blocked Maternity Leave Directive. This will be important in promoting equality between men and women in the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I welcome mep Tarabella's report on the equality of men and women, which has made significant progress on equality, especially when it comes to the challenges we face all the time, such as low participation of women in the economy and continued violence against women.  The report contains excellent suggestions, sends a message about equal opportunities for women and men in the field of employment, but also other segments of life. However, since the principle of subsidiarity has been undermined and 153 000 citizens have responded with a petition in the last few days, requesting that the right to abortion be struck out of the report and that human life be protected as a basic human right, I did not vote for this report.  I personally find it unacceptable that sexual and reproductive rights are regulated by this report and this substantially violates the right of Member States to decide these issues themselves.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I do not agree with several of its objectives. For example, I do not agree with the recommendation that the Commission integrate a 'gender pillar' into the Europa 2020 strategy, a recommendation for further progress in quotas for women on company boards, a recommendation for the Commission to ensure that the language used on social networks is 'neutral' and so on. Apart from the fact that these and other proposals only distract from real problems (such as unemployment), it is possible to doubt whether they will actually help the women themselves.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 During the vote on this report, I supported those proposals aimed at promoting the principle of subsidiarity in the field of sexual and reproductive health and in the field of sex education. I believe that these areas are the responsibility of individual Member States, which have sufficient resources to adapt them. Moreover, I believe that these areas do not need to be discussed on the occasion of the 2013 report on progress on gender equality in the European Union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We are fighting for the expansion of women's conquests until full and meaningful gender parity is achieved. The Group of the European United Left has tabled a number of amendments which have helped to improve the Commission's report. Unfortunately, however, amendments we tabled on the negative impact of austerity measures on gender equality have been rejected. However, because of the positive elements contained in the text, we are voting in favour of this report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is unacceptable to try to legitimise abortion as a means of ensuring sexual and reproductive health.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution 'Progress in equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013'. In my opinion, it is important to be able to enforce the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women, to which this resolution contributes. I believe that further progress is also needed in the field of equal opportunities in order to reach the Europe 2020 targets.  For example, it is important not only to achieve a level of employment of 75% within the EU, but it is also important to improve the quality of employment and its proportion. If current trends continue, for example, women and men will not receive equal pay for equal work before 2084. I think it is important to remove barriers to women's careers and economic dependency, to improve work-life balance, to ensure the right to maternity leave and abortion, and to stand up to violence against women.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Tarabella report because in its final version (re)it affirms important principles which undersoe the achievement of equality between women and men and in which I firmly believe. (i) women's right to control their health and sexual and reproductive rights, in particular through easy access to contraception and voluntary termination of pregnancy; (ii) sexual and reproductive rights are fundamental rights and must be the responsibility of the EU and not subordinate to individual national regulations, with the consequent risk of having divergent and fragmented approaches within the EU; (iii) responsibility for health matters must remain with the Member States and not with the EU (thus avoiding direct interference by EU austerity policies on further cuts in health services); (iv) every woman, including a migrant, must be protected by the State and its institutions in the face of any episode of domestic violence; (v) Member States must facilitate the exercise of their father's right to family-work reconciliation by, among other things, taking paid paternity leave of at least 10 days.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Committee on Womenʼs Rights and Gender Equality annually adopts a report on progress made towards achieving gender equality, with regard to the European Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015. Despite evidence of some progress being made, the glass ceiling is far from being shattered as Europe still lags behind in several urgent areas, including gender-based violence, social exclusion and human trafficking. Nonetheless, I voted with my Group against the latest report.  One area I stand vehemently against is the proposal of mandatory quotas for women in boardrooms which undeniably undermine the status of women. Nowadays, few people disagree with the call for a stronger female representation and presence at the top of the corporate ladder. Research confirms that gender diversity on boards results in stronger corporate performance on every measure and that male-dominated cultures in the top echelons of the commercial world lead to excessive risk-taking. However, if we are to talk seriously about tackling the under-representation of women in the higher ranks, rather than introducing mandatory gender quotas we should advocate the implementation of corporate policies which encourage women to step forward; demonstrating that they are just as eligible for rising through the ranks as men. This would assist in promoting women without patronising them.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament voted on the report on the state of play for women's rights and gender equality in Europe. Through this text, we make a diagnosis on the equality of rights between men and women in Europe and highlight the progress of the various projects. The verdict is not very gratifying: the changes are too slow and women's rights suffer. But the majority vote on the report is a very strong symbol because it means that the European Parliament shares this view and intends to play with all its weight in favour of our struggles such as equal pay, the fight against violence against women, maternity leave or the right to abortion.  There are still far too many stereotypes when it comes to gender equality: unfair and retrograde stereotypes against women, but also against men who are willing to tackle these problems. Voting today is a strong symbol against the conservatism and obscurantism that are eating away at Europe! Women and men are not and will never be the same, but it is in everyone's interest that they have the same rights.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ While many useful political recommendations are formulated and challenges are identified, these issues should be addressed first of all at Member State level. I also deplore some unfortunate wordings which diminish the strength of these important social and political challenges. Finally I believe that the quota policy is not the most effective tool to achieve gender balance. For all these reasons I chose to abstain on the final vote on the report.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 When voting on my colleague Tarabella's report, I voted against it. Personally, I believe that no such directive will help women. I am opposed to states' calls for gender policy to be included in calls for tenders in public procurement. I also do not agree with the dismantling of the principle of subsidiarity of nation states not only on these issues.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to this resolution, Parliament calls for improved policies to achieve equality between women and men. Despite the progress made in recent years to bridge gender inequality, much remains to be done to reduce the pay gap, apply equal opportunities to professional careers, improve work-life balance.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Equality between men and women is a European value, contained in the Treaty of Rome in 1957. Since then, hundreds of texts have been approved to ensure equal opportunities and prevent discrimination against women in many aspects. I encourage therefore all institutions involved to continue working to make this equality possible and, above all, remain vigilant to combat gender violence and new methods of sexual harassment on the Internet, especially for girls.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The Tarabella report aims to take stock of gender inequalities. The report deliberately slips from the search for equal rights to the obligation of male/female substitutability, denying the natural differences and complementarity between them.  This report is a new negation of physical and natural reality, one that makes a woman different from a man and does not have the same aspirations.  This report highlights a "right to abortion" and the free disposition by women of their bodies. There are two points to be made on this subject: First, why are we not talking about the right to "reproduction"? In the name of the liberation of women, we have sacrificed the lives of millions of unborn children and thus an entire generation of Europeans. Reproduction is only addressed to find ways to prevent it. Oddly systematic.  Secondly, the real objective of promoting this text is also the maintenance of massive human capital in the labour market, which further weighs wages downwards.  I vote AGAINST this text with the entire FN delegation.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – I think it is very important that the achievements in equal opportunities between women and men are regularly debated and attention is drawn to the most important tasks. The report sets a target date for equal work to achieve equal pay. A specific strategy can be associated with this, which is why I supported the report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The delegation of Podemos vot in favour of the Tarabella report on equality between women and men. We are particularly alarmed by the attempt by conservatives and extremists to degrade recommendations for equality and did not understand why we are trying to soften the worrying consequences of inequality in Europe. This report also integrates contextualisation of the worrying increase in inequality during the crisis, as well as supports at European level the defence of women's sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report of which I have been shadow rapporteur; I consider particularly satisfactory the reference to the fact that sexual and reproductive rights are fundamental human rights and should be taken into account in the EU health action programme; and that it is in the interest that women should have control over their health and sexual and reproductive rights, including considered to have easy access to contraception and abortion, as they are decisions about their own bodies.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I am firmly committed to defending women's rights. Progress towards equality between women and men is slow and it is therefore essential to continue to insist, as this report requires, on such important issues as: the fight against gender-based violence - the most widespread human rights violation in the world and affecting all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on progress in equality between women and men as it is a policy document reiterating the importance of equality policies in the EU and Member States as a basic pillar to end inequalities in various areas such as labour and family reconciliation, the pay gap, stereotypes , or the right to health. The report denounces non-compliance with the objectives of the European Commission's key gender equality document, the Equality Strategy 2010-2015, among other reasons for the withdrawal of the proposal for the Maternity Leave Directive. Moreover, while it is reiterated that health policies fall within the competence of Member States, it states that women should have control over their sexual and reproductive health and rights, in particular through easy access to contraception and abortion. However, I regret that there is no clear denunciation of how austerity measures promoted since the troika have precarious women's living conditions, further delving into the phenomenon of feminization of poverty.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution alongside my European Parliament Labour Party colleagues because this report highlights areas where urgent action is needed if we are to achieve targets on gender equality, particularly in the area of womenʼs employment. Our economic recovery has been one of low wage, temporary and insecure work and this has hit women disproportionately hard. Persistent gender gaps in pay and pensions demonstrate there is still a very long way to go. What was at stake here is not just womenʼs economic empowerment but our investment in Europeʼs future.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'In fact, it is a shame that over the last 100 years we still face the same problems of equality between individuals, men or women: the fact that women are paid less for the same work as their male colleagues, maternity leave, violence against women, etc. . . . Every individual has equal rights and should be able to enjoy equal opportunities. We are seeing gender inequality both in Europe and around the world. How gruesome are the statements like "She should have gone through it if it hadn't been so bad" or "She asked to go to a nightclub"? I fully support this report by my male colleague Tarabella and look forward to the moment when such reports are no longer needed.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report is the European Parliament's annual report on women's rights for 2013. By its adoption by a large majority, it overshadows the rejection under the previous legislature of the reports of Mrs Estrella and Mrs Zuber. In particular, it calls for progress on equal pay to finally break the glass ceiling, but also in the fight against stereotypes, violence, discrimination and poverty. It therefore returns to its traditional positions on the rights of women to dispose of their bodies in terms of contraception and abortion. While the great hypocrisy of the votes on the right of the Chamber must be underlined, the FN is clear, it is against women's rights and especially the right to abortion. I have therefore voted in favour of this report, but I will remain vigilant. It is time for equal rights between women and men to finally be a reality. But it is clear that, especially in social matters, women's rights are declining since they are the first victims of austerity policies.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report, while well diagnosing the setbacks that women's rights have had in recent years, does not hold the European Commission and the policies of the various governments responsible for the policies implemented that are the cause of the destruction of states' social functions, unemployment and which push women into poverty, exploitation, and, in extreme cases, prostitution.  Our amendments have all been refused by the EP, which clearly demonstrates that the majority of the EP is not willing to identify the real causes of these setbacks.  It is good that this report addresses sexual and reproductive rights from a fundamental human rights perspective, and that it recommends facilitated access to contraception and abortion, although we recognise that it is up to the Member States to define health policies. We voted in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I rejected this report because, in particular, the attempted implementation of human rights on abortion is unsupported. This would violate almost all existing Western legal bases and would entail a large number of problems.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Tarabella report because I think it is essential for the European Union to pursue the path of equality, to combat discrimination in all its forms and manifestations and to work towards the development of defence strategies and directives that will mean total respect for and total self-determination of the woman's body. Furthermore, we believe, as an alliance of Socialists and Democrats, that the recovery and development of Europe will be achieved through full recognition of women's rights and full enhancement of its role within society.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 It is great to see that equality between women and men has progressed in Europe. However, change is very slow. Although the majority of university graduates are women in the EU, at the current rate of progress, the employment rate of 75% for women will not be realised until 2038. It may take another 70 years to achieve equal pay – it is predicted that it will not happen until 2084. Such a change is unacceptable. It needs to be speeded up. Member States must work resolutely to ensure that fathers take more responsibility for childcare and promote women's careers. We cannot afford to lose women's skills and input.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against this report. It is an incoherent succession of inhumane, patronising and ignorant monstrosities. The indifference with which my German colleagues from the CDU/CSU and fdp already accepted these stupidities in the Committee on Women's Affairs, if not actively supporting them, then indifferently, shows how hypocritical the rejection of this abstruse report by the members of the CDU/CSU and FDP was. According to this report, women who are mothers and take care of their children and families are not full-fledged people.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution alongside my European Parliament Labour Party colleagues because this report highlights areas where urgent action is needed if we are to achieve targets on gender equality, particularly in the area of womenʼs employment, women in entrepreneurship, and sexual and reproductive rights. Our economic recovery has been one of low wage, temporary and insecure work and this has hit women disproportionately hard. Persistent gender gaps in pay and pensions demonstrate there is still a very long way to go. Womenʼs rights to control their own bodies are a key element of achieving gender equality along with quotas for women on boards and increased visibility in public life, and have been part of the political struggle here. What was at stake was not just womenʼs economic empowerment, and our investment in Europeʼs future, but also a Europe of social justice.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. In the 21st century, women are not yet on an equal footing with men. Women earn less for the same work, women and girls are enslaved and abducted in many parts of the world, single mothers and female pensioners are among the most vulnerable groups. None of this is acceptable. We must do everything we can to achieve equality. Denying women the right to self-determination over their bodies is not only politically unacceptable, but misogynistic and disgusting. Two days ago was International Women's Day. Debates such as this one around the Tarabella report show how urgently this day is still urgently needed today. I am committed to a world in which no one is discriminated against on the basis of gender, ethnicity, sexuality, religion, etc. That is why I voted in favour of this report and I would like to thank the 440 Members who have done so, thereby showing that women's rights are human rights.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I firmly support the Istanbul Convention regarding the elimination of female genital mutilation (FGM), as well as the resolutionʼs call for the Member States to prevent domestic and sexual violence against women and girls. Women must have control over their sexual and reproductive health; this includes access to contraception and abortion, but this control must also apply to men. I do acknowledge that active prevention, education and information policies aimed at, amongst others, teenagers are of great importance, but they must target equally young girls and young men.  However, I do not believe that the EP should impose gender equality by using gender quotas or promoting through campaigns girls entering what are traditionally male careers. I want to underline that it is important for me that each family decides about its own work-life balance, family structure and parental leave sharing. Forcing children and young people to follow educational studies based on gender or making them fight so-called ʽgender stereotypesʼ, as mentioned in the resolution is, from my point of view, a violation of each individualʼs right to choose his/her personal future.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on paragraph 32 because we oppose calling for the EU to meddle with the UKʼs immigration system regarding undocumented migrants and telling countries that they cannot report cases to the authorities. However we absolutely condemn cases where women (whether migrant or not) have been subjected to abuse and would support criminal investigations no matter what the circumstances. The EU call for cases not to be reported to the authorities may help those perpetrating such crimes to avoid being brought to justice.
