UKIP abstained on paragraph 50 as we cannot support calling on the EU to interfere with the UKʼs immigration system regarding the right to residency. However it is perfectly reasonable for a migrant woman to be granted autonomous residency (meaning that residency is not subject to being part of the family unit she first entered with), especially in cases where the woman has been subjected to domestic violence.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The report on the progress of equality between women and men in the EU addresses, by no means by chance, the demand for female empowerment and equality as "equality" in exploitation. It seeks greater participation of women in the labour market, to extract more capital gains for capitalists. In the name of the "combination of family and professional life" it promotes the intensity of the exploitation of part-time women and flexible working relationships without rights and hunger wages. "Gender equality" is used by the EU, civil governments and the capital to remove conquests of women who met women's particular biological needs, such as the 5-year difference in retirement age and the ban on night work. The report obscures the fact that wage inequality and the reversal of industrial relations at the expense of women is at the heart of EU and urban governments' policy in its Member States to reduce labour force pay, in the interests of the profitability of monopolies. In the interests of the women of the people's families, it is the conflict with the EU and the power of monopolies, their struggle through a strong popular alliance for the conquest of power and the organization of the economy on the basis of meeting their modern needs and not profit.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ although the topic of equality between men and women is crucial for me, I did not support this report. I fully agree that it is important that women can be professionally implemented alongside their family. And that women who remain devoted to children or a disabled member of the household should not be exposed to poverty. I am also involved in a number of campaigns highlighting violence against women, and we are working with experts to address this particularly serious matter. However, this report also dealt with issues that are elocondedly within the competence of the Member States (sexual and reproductive rights), and I am in favour of respecting the principle of subsidiarity. Moreover, I think that the proposals on gender-balanced language on social networks put the whole issue of equality between women and men in absurd light and have nothing to do there.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013, primarily because the European Parliament is not the right institution to decide on progress and lines of action in areas which, in accordance with the spirit of the Treaties, are reserved to the Member States. This is contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. The reference in this document to the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence is evidence of a misunderstanding of the diversity of causes of violence and gender inequalities in the Member States. Generalising this phenomenon and blaming religion, culture and the traditional family model for it only moves us away from finding an effective solution to these problems. Passages on sexual and reproductive rights as fundamental rights are also unacceptable. In a euphemistic way, they are trying to include abortion as a tool that can improve the social and economic situation of women. Of course, it is necessary to promote the equal position of women and men in society, but by adequately funding instruments to combine professional and family roles, not an ideological offensive. Supporting the traditional family model, not denying it, is the only appropriate solution in this case.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Tarabella Report (A8-0015/2015), Progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013 because it indicates substantive progress on the path of gender equality and sets out priorities and principles that, if implemented, will allow significant progress in this area of social justice and modernity in the near future, making the EU a global benchmark in gender equality.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report clearly diagnoses the setbacks that women's rights have had in recent years, particularly in the last decade, although we do not agree with some statements when trying to make it believe that the European Semester can meet social objectives, which is impossible because it is contradictory. The report does not hold the European Commission and the policies of the various governments responsible for the policies implemented that have led to the destruction of states' social functions, unemployment, falling incomes, pushing women into poverty, exploitation, and, in extreme cases, prostitution. We have proposed a number of amendments in this regard, all of which have been refused by the EP, which clearly shows that the majority of the EP is not willing to identify the real causes of these setbacks. We also welcome the fact that this report addresses sexual and reproductive rights from a fundamental human rights perspective, and recommends easier access to contraception and abortion, although we recognise that it is up to the Member States to define health policies. We voted in favour.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. This report has addressed a number of issues related to the disparity between the sexes, particularly as regards the purely economic aspect, the protection of sexual and reproductive rights, which includes decision-making power over procreation, the autonomous choice of spouse, the voluntary determination of the number of children, the time at which they are conceived and the interval between births. Access to all the information and tools necessary to exercise a conscious choice, as well as the right to privacy and protection against sexual violence and coercation, must be guaranteed on this issue. These protections also include the right to abortion, where cases are even higher in countries where the procedure is prohibited than in countries where it is legal. The report therefore calls on the Member States to ensure easy access to contraception and abortion, supporting actions aimed at women's sexual and reproductive health, and a more effective information network. I, together with my colleagues in the 5-Star Movement, supported the rapporteur's position, guaranteeing the choice of each individual, and affirming the will of the people of the Italians who in two referendums have largely demonstrated their favor for a right synonymous with civilization.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained from the final vote on marco taabelle's proposal for progress towards equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013. The report advocates that the EU and the Member States take into account issues of equal rights and opportunities for women and men in the implementation of their activities and budgetary procedures. It highlights the issue of poverty among women, especially among the elderly and single mothers, the problem of victims of sexist violence and otherwise stigmatised. It advocates quality employment for women and equal opportunities to enter the labour market. I support all these aspects of the report. However, I voted against Article 45 of the report and paragraph Ae, mainly because they talk about 'easy' access to abortion and place it as fundamental rights. I do not believe that abortion can be placed between human rights or freedoms, because every life must be protected from conception to death and because I believe that abortion is a tragedy for every mother who makes it.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour because competitiveness is one of the recipes for getting out of the crisis. An effective competition policy will lead to the success of the European Union and, consequently, to the well-being of its citizens.  Important games are playing out in the coming years relating to the digital single market, the energy sector, the financial sectors, industry and transport. In particular, great attention must be paid to the great opportunity offered to us by the digital single market, without neglecting all the related issues that directly affect the lives of European citizens.  Competition policy must not be the only principle governing the creation and development of the market: I broadly agree with the rapporteur when he says that there is a need for coordination of initiatives. Competition must, however, be accompanied by employment and growth.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – (the beginning of the speech is not heard) ... as one of the most important generators of economic growth in the European Union. However, it is not even remotely regulated yet.  As many as 20% of consumers complain that they cannot shop online in another Member State of the European Union. Cross-border online commerce accounts for only 14% of all online commerce. I want to buy shoes from Estonia and the server says to me: No, it's not for you, it's for germans, Estonians, French. I buy a hat from France, shipping from Croatia for a shorter distance is many times more expensive than shipping within Hungary for a greater distance. I buy a subscription for digital content, I go to another country and I get blocked what I paid for fairly. These are the daily complaints of our citizens.  On the other hand, our traders are burdened with demands that traders outside the European Union do not have to meet, creating disloyal competition. We must be aware that there is still a lot of work ahead of us to reach the single market. Discrimination against consumers by place of residence is among the first problems we need to solve.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, conditional and conditional competition could lead to growth and job creation in the current phase of austerity and poverty in Europe. However, in order for competition to work properly, social dumping, which undermines labour rights, must be combated. Tax dumping practices such as the Juncker policy with the well-known Lux-leaks must also be condemned.  At the same time, the European Union must pay attention to mergers in order not to create oligopolistic conditions and prices rise. Finally, the principle of subsidiarity must be respected, unfair competition must be struck and the Powers of the European Parliament increased. As these thoughts are inherent in the report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Madam President, free competition is one of the main drivers of growth, development and innovation in the European Union. However, member states' different legislation and practices lead to fragmentation of the single market, often distorting competition and the emergence of monopolies. Monopolies make losses of €180 billion to €320 billion each year, which is 3% of the European Union's GDP.  We have to ask ourselves whether competition policy is strong enough to help small and medium-sized entrepreneurs and allow them to compete fairly. Some of the differences in the prices of products and services stem from member states' different approach when granting subsidies and tax benefits.  The way state aid is granted needs to be changed and modernised so that they are not an obstacle but an incentive for fair competition.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report by my colleague Messerschmidt because I share his view that stronger promotion of competition is a necessary precondition for growth in increasing employment, investment and global competitiveness of the European economy.  Accordingly, I would like to point out that I find it harmful to consider the fact that individual Member States' markets are liberalised only on paper and the dominant market position is occupied by public companies – former monopolists, who destroy private competition through price dumping or push it out of the market. Such a modus operandi leads us to a crazy situation in which the taxpayer seemingly enjoys a lower price of service, but then through high tax charges must repair the losses of public companies caused by such a price policy.  If we want to truly profit from the common market, we must ensure the same rules for all as soon as possible.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – As a Socialist MEMBER and shadow syra with the SD group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the annual competition report. I am pleased that, through this report, we have once again taken important steps towards a more socially balanced Europe, better protecting workers and strengthening public services.  In addition to the many achievements, however, I must underline that neither myself nor my group will ever support the Liberals or right-wing members to force any privatisation of the Railway, Air and Port sectors on the Member States. For our part, we would like to state that paragraph 85 of the report cannot be interpreted literally, but in our value judgment, in particular, as a call for privatisation. After all, that is why we were able to support the report nevertheless.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report despite containing very positive points because it maintains a worrying approach against public participation in the economy. This report contains many positive points, including the call to end public aid to banking by noting that they have not helped to increase the flow of credit to the real economy; the report condemns the Commission's action with regard to preferred holdings; it also requires that the territorial consequences of competition policy actions be contemplated, etc. All these positive points are at the same time as the neoliberal approach and contrary to the public sector's participation in the economy of many of the points we cannot share. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. Competition policy plays an important role in strengthening the approach to the internal market and addressing the economic, social and environmental challenges in Europe. I welcome the fact that the Commission is being asked to make improvements in various areas, such as .B social and labour impact on the people in the area of state aid and the needs of citizens.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report on EU competition policy fails to complete the conclusion that the objectives of pure and perfect competition within the single market have not been achieved in the goods and services sector. Abuses of dominance and cartels, against which the text suggests certain laudable measures, are evidence of a risk of abuse of market power in certain sectors characterized by the presence of oligopolies.  The report clearly calls for the continuation of plans to open up the network and energy industries to competition, thus aligning itself with the objectives of the Juncker plan.  Refusing to approve a failed single market project and large-scale liberalisation plans, I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I believe that matters such as competition should be the preserve of the Member States and therefore voted against accordingly.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report because it calls for many measures that would solve problems of obstruction of the internal market. I support the conclusions of this report which call on the Commission to implement rules on infringements of competition law, state aid and merger control in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and to enable social progress.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the report provides a constructive and balanced overview of the European Unionʼs competition policy. The European Unionʼs free and fair competition policy favouring the interests of consumers and SME’s and a climate of innovative competitiveness is one of the main prerequisites needed to boost the European Union’s importance worldwide and an essential tool to overcome the ongoing economic crisis, create quality employment and regain economic growth. Competition policy is a vital part of the digital single market and the energy union’s projects. I am glad that the rapporteur stressed in his report the importance of an inter-institutional dialogue between EU institutions and the role of Parliament as a forum representing the interests of EU consumers and other stakeholders. Parliament should be a contributor in shaping policies for a digital single market, the energy sector, transport and financial services. In addition, I remain convinced that it is equally important to ensure that market power is not being abused. We must make sure those mechanisms in charge of the enforcement of already existing rules, public procurement and monitoring of public procurement purchasing procedures and Member States’ tax ruling practices. These measures are most vital to ensure easy market access and steady income flow to states’ and the EU’s budget.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to evaluate the annual report on EU competition policy. It is important for the Commission to undertake to ensure impartial enforcement of EU competition rules, to respect the principle of subsidiarity and to respect the decisions of national courts in the field of competition policy, to combat cartels, to investigate the activities of companies with a monopoly or dominant position, to avoid abusing their market power, to cooperate closely with other authorities in third countries and international organisations in order to investigate alleged cases of misuse of tax advantages. I support the proposal that all these commitments be included in the Commission's strategic priorities for the next five years. It is also important that the EP has a greater impact on Union policy-making in the digital single market, the energy sector, financial services, industry and transport.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against Mr Messerschmidt's report because he refuses to acknowledge the stinging failure of The European competition policy, which has only exacerbated the constraints on SMEs without preventing the domination of a few monopolistic players. Worse, this policy makes most targeted state aid illegal and therefore does not allow for a policy of state-strategist, yet more necessary than ever. On the other hand, I believe that taxation cannot be within the competence of the Union, contrary to what this report claims four times.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report assesses the competition and competitiveness policy in the European Union, which is extremely important in the current crisis period. The report seeks to ensure fair competition and calls for a fight against dumping in the labour market. It also tackles fragmentation behaviour in the EU's digital market.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. 'I voted against paragraph 85, of course not because I am against fair competition, but because such general encouragement sometimes happens too far in practice. For port services, we must make a clear distinction between the economic activities of a port authority and the public tasks it carries out. The latter does not apply to the competition rules and we must therefore be able to explicitly monitor their public character.  Such general encouragement, such as this one in paragraph 85 to the Commission and the Member States, ignores the nuanced way in which we should apply competition rules and therefore could not count on my support.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This annual report on competition policy highlights the key role it plays in strengthening the European single market and thus increasingly federalism and leaking forward.  Thus, the European Union, under the guise of wanting to promote growth, innovation and social progress, intends to regulate even more the granting of state aid, to further harmonize tax rules and to complete the digital single market. The report also intends to identify imbalances that can create distortions of competition, but never mentions the so-called Detached Workers Directive, which creates unfair competition with our businesses and SMEs, or the Union's refusal to introduce intelligent protectionism at the borders. On the other hand, the report also stresses the need to "concretely respect the needs of citizens [...] placing their concerns at the centre of the decision-making process", which we could welcome if this technocratic and sprawling Union did not do the opposite of what it advocates.  The Union in its present form is a machine for crushing peoples on the altar of ultraliberalism and free and undistorted competition; I therefore voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. I voted against the Messerschmidt report on EU competition policy with respect, as I consider it unbalanced; In particular, in addition to references that I do not agree with on a harmonised European tax policy, there is a total lack of concrete references to the need to promote competition that becomes an effective instrument for combating unemployment and not for creating new ones, as it continues to do.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. - I've abstained. The report has improved during the committee's reading and I welcome the fact that, for example, it calls for the EU to 'also take action against social dumping and implement social and environmental legislation at Community level. calls on the Commission to consider the social and employment impact of its state aid interventions, in particular in those regions where unemployment is high, and to integrate that analysis into its decisions.' However, since the basic line is nevertheless an endorsement of the European Commission's market-liberal policies, with the belief, among other things, that competition will be put on in all areas of activity.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Competition policy is itself a tool for safeguarding European democracy, inso as it prevents excessive concentration of economic and financial power in a few hands, which would pose a risk to the independence of European political power from large industrial and banking groups; it is also a cornerstone of the European social market economy to ensure the proper functioning of a dynamic, efficient, sustainable and innovative internal market. This annual report on EU competition policy, which I voted for, sets out the main priorities of the Socialist Group, including ensuring fair competition and combating social dumping in the labour market, combating fragmentation in the EU digital market that ensures an open internet and ensures net neutrality and ending tax evasion and illegal practices by some Member States on agreements prosecutors with companies. In addition, it is important to carry out a comprehensive analysis of the tax provisions of each Member State in order to be able to present tax harmonisation measures that are advantageous to SMEs and ensure the competitiveness of the Member States.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because competition policy and competitiveness in general are essential for the state and success of the European Union as a whole and therefore for its citizens. Only by fostering a spirit of innovation and competitiveness can we finally end the financial crisis. Through effective competition policy, we can preserve and increase the EU's importance in the world. The resumption of the political mandate of the European Parliament must make the issue of competitiveness a priority on our political agenda. EU competition policy has been very useful in improving consumer welfare and has so far been an essential tool to remove obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital. The European Parliament would like to build on this fact and considers that competition policy remains an essential tool for preserving the single market and protecting consumers' interests. It is therefore necessary to assess the initiatives of current competition policy, followed by new proposals or amendments to the current rules to address the problems we face.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, some areas within the single market are divided by strong national barriers, resulting in higher costs and poorer services for European citizens. Effective competition is the sine qua non for stimulating effective investment and ensuring choices and prices that are advantageous to consumers. In order to get there, we need coherent and uniform policies in the various areas.  Among the sectors crucial to the development of the European economic model, I would mention energy and digital: in both, effective competition can make a difference in order to make projects already on the table at European level possible. In the energy sector, encouraging objectives that guarantee sustainability and security of supply and that support a fair and competitive market, including through diversification of sources and a fight against monopolistic practices. Instead of the digital single market, legal instruments in the field of competition need to be adapted to the needs of the new 'digital age'. With this resolution, which I support, Parliament has expressed its support for rapid and effective action by the authorities and regulatory bodies to deal with unfair competition practices.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒2012 As many as 25% of consumers complain that they cannot shop online in another EU country. Cross-border online shopping accounts for only 14% of all online shopping. When shopping online, shoppers complain that they are discriminated against by their place of residence. I want to buy shoes from Estonia and the server actually says to me "no, it's not for you, it's for germans, Estonians and French". I buy a hat from Hungary and shipping to Croatia for a shorter distance is many times more expensive than shipping within Hungary for a longer distance. I buy a subscription to a television channel, go to another country and lose access to content I paid for fairly. These are everyday complaints from EU citizens. As many as 25% of consumers complain that they cannot shop online in another EU country. Cross-border online shopping accounts for only 14% of all online shopping.  We must be aware that we still have a lot of work ahead of us to do to the single market, not to promise nice figures without a quality basis. Discrimination against consumers by place of residence is among the first problems we need to solve. The common market must not have a specific set of rules depending on who is billed.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Annual Report on the EU’s competition policy because I think that there is still some improvement needed in the competition policy of the European Union which could ameliorate the internal market and create growth.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The EU's competition policy is one of the pillars of the European Commission's policies. However, far from supporting the advent of a free market that would promote 'pure and perfect competition', the EU's competition policy has actually increased the normative pressure on SMEs/TPEs and local public services. It also supported the substitution of public monopolies by private monopolies trusted by rapacious multinationals. Through its state aid legislation, the Commission has obstructed any attempt on the part of States to implement a policy of economic patriotism aimed at these strategic sectors.  Finally, this report recommends giving the Union fiscal competence, which is akin to endorsing an additional leap into Euro-federalism. For all these reasons, I voted against the Messerschmidt report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition policy and competitiveness in general play a key role for the health and success of the EU as a whole and therefore for citizens. Through an effective competition policy, the European Union can strengthen and improve its global role. In this endeavour, the European Parliament plays an extremely important role, through the debate and development of competition policies, in full respect of the European Treaties. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Parliament must be an integral part of strengthening the competition dialogue, both with the European Commission and with the other institutions. EU competition policy has brought many benefits to consumer welfare and has been an essential tool to remove obstacles to the free movement of goods, people, services and capital. That is why I believe that a consumer policy can continue only with the active involvement of all the European institutions and, in particular, the European Parliament.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on European competition policy for 2013. I am very much in favour of competition on the condition that it is fair. Competition is a driver of economic growth and job creation, but it must be done in an environment in which each player has the same chance of success.  I have reaffirmed in this report my positions in favour of fiscal and social convergence within the European Union. We must fight against social dumping, which only widens the disparities between our different countries. If we open our borders and promote the mobility of workers, it is essential that we converge our social policies. The same applies to the convergence of member countries' tax policies. It is time to act and harmonize our tax policies to avoid these problems.  At the same time, I reiterate my intention to fight for this cause in my capacity as an alternate member of the special committee TAXE.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU's annual report on competition policy today.  Competition policy is an instrument for safeguarding European democracy, since it prevents the excessive concentration of economic and financial power in the hands of a few. Furthermore, competition is crucial to achieving the objectives of employment, growth, investment and the global competitiveness of the European economy, given that it is precisely sustainable and effective competition that favours investment and brings benefits for end-users, while giving the economy a boost. I therefore hope that the Commission and the Member States will be able to take appropriate measures in the field of competition, including through fiscal measures, to ensure that European industrial groups and SMEs have a level operating position in the internal market that also contributes to the challenges posed by globalisation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report did contain some positive aspects and it attempted to address some of the difficulties within EU competition law. However, its focus was primarily concerned with maintaining the current failed economic paradigm.  There was a particular emphasis on the functioning of the single market and providing priority for the liberalisation of public sectors and a number of other unacceptable provisions. And so while welcoming some aspects of this report, namely the need to guarantee the universality of public services, the need to bring alternatives to the workers of industries affected by sanctions and the focus on sustainability; I felt it necessary to abstain in this vote.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is Parliament’s response to the annual Commission 2013 report on EU competition policy, which outlines the Commission’s legislative activities, the application of state aid, antitrust and merger rules. It calls for a swift end to the state-aid crisis regime for the banking sector, as this has neither increased credit nor restored confidence. Regarding antitrust and cartels, the report underlines that the use of fines as the sole sanction tool available may not be effective enough and reiterates its call to the Commission to consider a general review of its 2006 Fining Guidelines and calls for the Fining Guidelines to be integrated into Regulation 1/2013. Another matter raised in the report is the misuse of Structural Funds. A rather important role in the report is devoted to fiscal state aid. The report stresses that fairer tax competition is indispensable for the integrity of the internal market and encourages the Commission to vigilantly enforce EU state-aid control rules, while keeping Parliament informed of the main progress in investigations to ensure they are being conducted in a transparent and independent manner. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The document presented expresses acceptable intentions, but, as is often the case, the risk is that they will be disregarded by the action of the Commission and the Member States, which are responsible for implementing competition policy. It would therefore be at least necessary, in order to try to put a stop to a policy which all too often has the real result of favouring the large multinational groups - which have particularly high resources and competences - that the texts adopted by Parliament should be very precise in every respect. I do not believe that this report, although it is of a good standard, meets this requirement and I have therefore abstained in this House.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which shows once again that dogmatism in the European Union is stronger than reality.  Competition policy is one of the biggest failures of the European Union: we were promised the end of monopolies? They have disappeared in favour of oligopolies twice as formidable for SMEs: just look at the Union's incompetence with Google. Were we assured of equal competition for access to public procurement? Yet regulation continues to favour large groups. This policy is equally disastrous in terms of protecting our strategic sectors. What is the solution of the Commission and its accomplices in Parliament to this? More European integration, no more single market!  Thus, the Commission calls for a new wave of liberalisation in the field of gas and electricity and calls for the aim of placing tax competition within the scope of European regulation. We are therefore reducing the scope for manoeuvre to the States a little more and, in the name of the ideology of reducing borders, we are promising the peoples of Europe an increasingly austere future.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote positively for the measure having always considered that thanks to the promotion of a good competitive and competitive culture you can get out of the financial crisis we are going through. It is important to put competitiveness first for the health and success of the EU and therefore as a reflection of all its citizens. The European Parliament must play a central role in this matter so that the process can be triggered and implemented. I believe that the European Union's competition policy has brought many benefits in terms of consumer welfare and has been an essential tool in removing obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, people and capital. I hope that we will carefully evaluate the current competition policy initiatives and, subsequently, new proposals or changes to the current rules, in order to address the challenges we face.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I am convinced that the Eu ropean Union's competition policy has brought many benefits in terms of consumer welfare, and that it is an essential tool for removing obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, people and capital. I hope that we will carefully evaluate the current competition initiatives in order to better address the challenges we face. Finally, I believe that we need to think more about certain areas where there seems to be a witch-hunt that is not justified by the fundamentals of the market. It is good that we continue to talk about this issue.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A healthy European Union Competition Policy is of extreme importance in the present day. Only through an innovative competitive policy that advocates an open market will we overcome the current financial crisis. EU Competition Policy has brought numerous benefits in terms of consumer welfare and has been an essential tool for removing barriers to the free movement of people, services, goods and capital and the preservation of a competitive Single Market. In particular, I welcome the adoption of the Anti-Trust Compensation Act as well as the ECJ judgment on anti-competitive commissions levied for the use of credit cards. Despite the successes achieved, I reiterate the need to further identify possible imbalances between Member States that could distort competition and pay attention to the phenomena of social dumping and misuse of Structural Funds used incorrectly to indirectly move services and production to other Member States.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on the European Union's competition policy because I believe that the prosperity of the European economy can be guaranteed through a fair and coherent competition policy and through a system of competitiveness based on the principles of free movement of goods, services, people and capital. I believe that the EU must promote a fair and transparent competition policy to ensure the well-being of consumers and SMEs.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Every year the Commission issues its report on competition policy which outlines both its legislative activities and application of state-aid, antitrust and merger rules. A reinforced focus on promoting competition is necessary for the achievement of objectives on jobs, growth and global competitiveness of the European economy. This report calls for competition policy focusing particularly on protecting consumers, improving consumer welfare, fostering innovation and stimulating economic growth. I support such a policy which could play a key role in reinforcing the holistic approach to the single market aimed at addressing Europe’s economic, social and environmental challenges which needs to be in full respect of national diversities. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Every year the European Parliament presents an own-initiative report analysing competition aspects in the EU. There are many ideas in the text that we broadly support, including the need to combat market concentrations, to ensure transparent public procurement, and to safeguard against abuses in the financial sector. Particular mention is also made of the necessary competition policies in the energy and transport sectors, and here too there are no points of contention. Interesting and worthy of support also the parts related to the agri-food and pharmaceutical sector, with references to the distorting power of large-scale distribution and the need for support for the development of the generic drug system. My abstention is justified by the presence of a paragraph calling for the inclusion of competition measures within TTIP.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as a whole since it stresses that a reinforced focus on promoting competition is necessary for the achievement of the ambitious objectives for jobs, growth, investment and the global competitiveness of the European economy, as it is sustainable and effective competition that drives investment and end-user benefits and fuels the economy. However I voted against clauses which refer to harmonisation of taxes. I believe that tax regimes are the competence of the individual Member States.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report focuses on the European Commission's 2013 Annual Report on EU Competition Policy to combat anti-competitive cartels and practices. In particular, the report notes the modernization work carried out in terms of state aid in many areas, such as the environment, energy, regional funds and research and innovation.  In the agricultural field, this report calls on the Commission, in its forthcoming revision of the CAP reform, to examine the potential effect of large supermarkets on competition in the food supply sector, both in Europe and in the developing world.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Union's competition policy is at the heart of European integration. It boosts business competitiveness, promotes the single market and gives consumers the fairest prices. That is why this report by the European Parliament encourages the European Commission to consider new tools to strengthen the repression of fraud in this area, beyond a simple policy of fines, sometimes not discouraging. It is worth remembering that agreements between large groups cause losses ranging from EUR 181 billion to EUR 320 billion, or about 3% of the Union's GDP, to the detriment of consumers' purchasing power.  The report also deplores the fact that, after four years of investigation, the Commission has no more results in its competition law infringement case against Google.  With this report, we wish to reaffirm our vigilance in the European Parliament to defend consumers, the engine of European growth.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition policy is an issue of fundamental importance to the European Union because only through the promotion of a competitive and effective competitive culture could we finally emerge from the financial crisis and strengthen the EU's importance throughout the world. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that competition policy has brought many benefits in terms of consumer welfare as well as being an essential instrument for removing obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, people and capital.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on Amendment 7. This is because, while I am strongly of the view that there is no need for ISDS provisions within trade agreements between democratic states (and have made this clear on many occasions), this report was meant to be focused on competition measures within the EU and therefore was not, in my opinion, the appropriate venue for Parliament to take a decision on this issue. (In contrast, it was, in my view, appropriate to attempt to incorporate in the report a condemnation of anti-competitive measures in the field of tax, given the impact that profit-shifting by multinational companies has on the competitive prospects of small and medium-sized domestic firms).

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the continued focus on ensuring that businesses and consumers across Europe are given the opportunity to compete within the Single Market in a way that is fair. In my own constituency, Northern Ireland, enterprises in the construction and quarry sectors were left in a state of limbo as the Commission investigated claims that the UK Aggregates Levy Rebate Scheme may have constituted illegal state aid. While the eventual outcome was a relief to those affected, we must ensure that such a situation never happens again. Better clarity on the rules must be given to remove this risk. I welcome the emphasis placed on enabling greater competition in areas such as the digital market, public procurement and the supply of energy. This is crucial to driving growth, job creation, and benefits for currently disengaged groups of society, including those living in rural areas. I also commend the focus on tackling alleged state aid abuses in sport, and would particularly draw attention to previous cases involving several Spanish clubs and Celtic Football Club. Regardless of the outcomes of these investigations, they have cast a shadow on the nature of financial contributions to clubs within the sport.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report on EU competition policy presented to Parliament fails to complete the conclusion that the objectives of pure and perfect competition in the single market have not been achieved in the goods and services sector. Abuses of dominance and cartels, against which the text suggests certain laudable measures, are evidence of a risk of market power in certain sectors characterized by the presence of oligopolies.  Moreover, the text clearly calls for the continuation of plans to open up the network and energy industries to competition, thus aligning itself with the objectives of the Juncker plan.  Refusing to approve a failed single market project and large-scale liberalisation plans, I voted against it.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report focuses on the essential role of competition policy enforcement for a well-functioning internal market. It highlights state-aid and services of general economic interest (SGEIs), antitrust and cartels, merger control, competition in specific sectors, the international dimension of competition policy, the role of Parliament, and the competition policy priorities of the Commission.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I want to commend Mr Messersmith for the tremendous work he has put in. The report is extremely accurate and objective. It is positive that Mr Messersmith pays great attention to protecting small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) from the competition of huge companies and cartels. However, these SMEs employ more than 65% of all employees in the EU, as well as over 55% of gross value added in the Community. It is right to note that in most cases SMEs are unequal to large consortia. Of course, with such a huge work, a few omissions and inaccuracies can be allowed, but they are not essential. The Commission needs to address the issues of different levels of interest on credit, not only for companies but also for individuals. In Bulgaria, interest and servicing costs of loans reach up to 50%, while in countries such as Germany they are no more than 15%. As regards social dumping and cabotage, I believe that these issues will be resolved when Europe ceases to move at two speeds and the 'big' and 'small' divide is eliminated. And once again, I want to commend Mr. Messersmith for the job well done.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report, presented by Mr Messerschmidt by the ECON Commission, on the report presented by the Competition Commissioner. The Resolution assumes the basic postulates of a liberal conception that promotes the free movement of capital and services, all within the framework of the TTIP.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as there is insufficient protection for individuals from support for the monopoly banking sector.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The framework for a competitive Europe focused on clear competition rules is the only one that allows a positive and constructive exit from the crisis. I believe that the fight against cartels, the abuse of a dominant market position or some State aid are elements that distort the internal market and therefore require close supervision by the Commission, especially in an ex-post-rescue framework for financial institutions by states and a growing need for a transparent policy of harmonisation of tax provisions throughout the EU. At the same time, I support the rapporteur's nomination for the creation and implementation of legislation promoting competition in the energy, digital, financial, industrial and transport sectors. If we want to credibility the Portuguese and European economy and turn the page on a new era of prosperity, it is necessary to closely monitor the competition dossier, so I voted in this particular case, positively to the statements of rapporteur Messerschmidt.

name: Fredrick Federley Marit Paulsen och Cecilia Wikström (ALDE)
text: Written. EU competition policy is a key tool for creating sustainable growth and fair conditions in the single market. Competition in itself is beneficial, even when it comes to taxes, but of course there are limits. We must take joint strong action against social dumping, even if social policy is essentially and should be the responsibility of the Member States. Nor can we accept unfair tax competition of the kind that has occurred in the so-called LuxLeaks scandal. We welcome the fact that these issues are also highlighted in the context of the negotiations on the new free trade agreement with the UNITED States, and have therefore, as a political signal, endorsed this report, even though in some respects – for example, through the call for 'neutral media coverage' and targeted tax measures to tackle globalisation – it is somewhat more restrictive than we as liberals and free trade friends normally consider appropriate.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. A competition policy based on a fair business plan in all sectors is an essential tool to ensure the proper functioning of a dynamic, sustainable and innovative internal market for economic growth and job creation, as well as to be competitive on the global stage. According to the report, competition does not work equally satisfactorily in all Member States. It should be noted that, due to the existence of cartels, there are losses between EUR 181 billion and EUR 320 billion. Tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens cost EU taxpayers around €1 billion a year in lost revenue, distorting competition in the Single Market between companies that pay and tax-free ones. Competition drives innovation, productivity, job creation and investment by all actors in the Single Market as a whole and all business models, including SMEs, with full respect for national diversity. For all this, I consider it important for the Commission to apply the rules on antitrust, State aid and merger control in order to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and social progress.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Regulation, even if I disagree with the inclusion of paragraph 85, in so far as it affirms the importance of competition policy in ensuring the efficient allocation of resources and promoting economic growth. In particular, I am pleased with the inclusion of two amendments promoted by me; one concerning the promotion of competition and the fight against monopolies and oligopolies as a safeguarding factor in the independence of European political power from large economic and financial conglomerates; and another on the need to monitor the unit of financial markets with regard to the loss of payment card service when the holder moves to another Member State, which, on the other hand, contraviates Article 15 of Directive 2014/92/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council, 23 July 2014 on the comparability of related commissions to payment accounts, the transfer of payment accounts and access to basic payment accounts, still in the transposition period, in addition to the relevant articles of the Treaties, i.e. Articles 63 and 169 TFEU, among others.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report analyses EU competition policy. As always, he praises the Single Market, the open market and the sacrosanct free competition. While it is punctuated here and there with aspects that we support and cannot be denied or hidden, such as criticism of state aid to the banking sector, tax fraud in the EU and its component in competition policy, the recognition of cartels and the need to combat them, it insists on pursuing the EU's competition policy and its consequences. This report even calls for further development of these policies in the EU, notably by calling for the liberalisation of sectors such as transport, health, industry and energy, calls for a chapter on competition rules in the TTIP, the digital single market, etc. More liberalisation is asked in more public and strategic sectors of the economy. Without addressing the consequences, such as creating difficulties for State intervention, and serious barriers to competition in other EU policy areas, such as the CAP in agriculture, where whole production is destroyed. Anapology for the role of competition policy as an instrument for preserving European democracy says much of the prevailing concept of democracy here.

name: Raffaele Fitto (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the aim is to promote a competitive European Union and to try to constantly improve competition policy. Fair and free competition is itself the best industrial policy. Preserving the single market and protecting the interests of consumers, I hope, are two priorities of the current parliamentary term.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ It is important that the commitments made by the Commissioner concerning the relationship with the European Parliament, the fight against cartels, the investigation of companies in a dominant position, that they do not use their market power disproportionately, but also open and transparent proceedings with external stakeholders are respected and respected. It is also very beneficial to holding regular meetings between the Commissioner and the European Parliament in order to intensify the dialogue on competition. The new European Commission must find the right answers in the fight against high unemployment, low growth, while at the same time finding a way to increase investment and increase competitiveness. The European Union must make full use of the competitive advantages in the area of production, such as highly qualified workers, a high share of domestic production in exports and high quality products. It is right that we want to follow the path of constant investment in the competitiveness of European industry, because only the necessary investments can ensure its high level. We must try to remove the uncertainty that European companies are in contact with the public administration, thus improving their growth prospects and removing all barriers that have a negative impact on competitiveness, which undoubtedly include high electricity and gas prices, which we have higher in the European Union than in other advanced economies.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the annual resolution of the ECON Committee on Competition within the Union. It is not convincing with regard to the analysis of tax systems and, moreover, the text contains few references to the needs of SMEs.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the whole report (which concerns the establishment-specialisation framework of fair competition rules within the EU) as there is insufficient protection for individuals from support for the monopoly banking sector.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. As a SPÖ-EU delegation, we voted unanimously against Mr Messerschmidt's report on EU competition policy. There are two main reasons for this: firstly, the report calls on the Commission to continue to tackle the dismantling of state-owned railway undertakings. This means further liberalisation and privatisation. We know from experience that this always happens to the detriment of customers. Nor will it bring "fairer competition," as is often claimed, but it will lead to private companies using the most profitable routes and siphoning off profits there. Remote areas will then have to continue to be used by state-affiliated companies to ensure basic services and infrastructure. At the same time, contrary to many claims, prices for customers will rise. Secondly, we wanted to note that the inclusion of investor-state dispute settlement procedures in free trade agreements (e.B. the ISDS procedure in the EU-US Free Trade Agreement (TTIP) deprives Member States of the democratic right to implement their own policies. There must therefore be no two-tier jurisdiction that gives more rights to international corporations than any other company and every citizen. These provisions are not in the interests of the citizens of Austria and Europe and the SPÖ-EU delegation has therefore rejected this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am very pleased with the outcome of negotiations on this report. I would like to underline the remarkable result of defending public services from being subject to a policy of competition: the possibility for the Member States to organise public services according to their own needs is a crucial point for our Socialist and Democrat group within Parliament. In the amendments I proposed, I defended a stronger role by Parliament in shaping our competition policy with the goal of increasing the level of market transparency, stability and growth. By means of this report, we are closer to achieving fundamental goals like ensuring fair competition and combating social dumping on the labour market, subjecting the services of general economic interest to the rules of competition, tackling fragmentation and anti-trust behaviour in the EU digital market, ending state-aid regimes to banks, and ending tax evasion and illegal corporate tax practices. Although I do not agree with the inclusion of private attacks on Google I do support, since the idea of the report was to put forward general rules, the adoption of the report in the plenary session.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. •u2012 Competition policy is of vital importance for the achievement of the objectives of the EU and its citizens. Europe must base its economic model on improving our competitiveness, in order to allow us to emerge from the economic crisis in a consolidated position relative to other global competitors. Commitments are needed at European and State level to establish medium- and long-term strategic priorities to benefit consumers, businesses and society as a whole. However, much remains to be done in a number of sectors to maximize benefits for consumer welfare and remove barriers to the free movement of goods, services, people and capital. It is also claimed that centrally managed airport and port networks (such as AENA and Ports of the State in Spain) will change models and open the up to free competition.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of a resolution calling on the Commission to take all available action to enforce both ex post and ex ante competition rules in order to avoid excessive market concentrations and abuses of a dominant position, thus protecting businesses and citizens.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I wholeheartedly supported Mr Messerschmidt's report on the EU's annual competition policy report. I think it is important to reiterate that the economic dimension of the Union is enshrined in the Treaties as an 'open market economy with free competition', aimed at achieving ambitious targets for employment, growth, investment and the global competitiveness of the economy. Competition policy must always aim to create a level of conditions conducive to productivity, innovation, job creation and investment, while fully respecting national differences. I would like to stress one point in particular: the Commission is careful in implementing the antitrust rules and the rules on State aid and merger control, because it is important to achieve a well-functioning internal market and to ensure social progress. At the same time, the hope is that the new Juncker Commission will be able to take appropriate fiscal and competition measures to help European industrial groups and SMEs cope with globalisation, precisely because competition policy cannot be divorced from the general objectives of economic and social recovery.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy because the EU has an important role to play in making sure that companies across Europe, large and small, can compete on a level playing field – while at the same time ensuring that services like healthcare are protected from a race to the bottom that comes along with privatisation. The report also showed, when referring to LuxLeaks, how multinational companies can act in a fundamentally anti-competitive way when they relocate and reduce their tax rates to almost nothing. We need to take action at a European level to stop that practice from happening and competition rules could be helpful here.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the Messerschmidt report on competition policy, despite some positive points, for example on unfair tax competition or support for banks without profit for the real economy. On the merits, I cannot congratulate myself with the rapporteur on the fact that the open market economy where competition is free is "anchored in the treaties" (paragraph 1). It is to deny the right of peoples to choose the rules that govern them, since they are imposed a model engraved in the European marble. It is also because this policy, applied strictly dogmatically, has largely missed its objectives: the disappearance of entire sectors of our industry; undermining public services; increasing prices and reducing the quality of services in many "liberalised" sectors - electricity, trains, postal services, etc.; eviction of SMEs from public procurement with collateral damage to local employment and increasing use of seconded workers; replacing public monopolies with uncontrollable private oligopolies by the political authorities; refusal of any support for the creation of national or European champions, in a context of highly unfair globalisation... The results are far from positive. This does not come from the inadequacies of competition policy, but from its abuses.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, presented by Mr Messerschmidt by the ECON Commission, on the report presented by the Competition Commissioner. The Resolution assumes the basic postulates of a liberal conception that promotes the free movement of capital and services, all within the framework of TTE.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy because the EU has an important role to play in making sure that companies across Europe, regardless of size, can compete on a level playing field - while at the same time ensuring that services like healthcare are protected from a race to the bottom that comes along with privatisation. The report also showed, when referring to LuxLeaks, how multinational companies can act in a fundamentally anti-competitive way when they relocate and reduce their tax rates to almost nothing. We need to take action at a European level to stop that practice from happening.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out the state of play for competition policy and the application of state aid in the European Union. I am pleased that the text adopted this year highlights the Google case, against which the European Union urgently needs to take action, as well as the need to address social dumping and the misuse of structural funds in the context of competition policy. Tax aspects are also essential and unfair practices in this area must be combated, in order to ensure fair and balanced competition between Member States.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU competition policy report. I strongly support the view of the rapporteur that competition policy and competitiveness in general is of vital importance to the health and success of the EU as a whole and therefore its citizens. Member States cannot compete with each other, we have to become a strong single market and compete with the rest of the world.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that Parliament has a strong input into competition policy in the EU. However, I do have concerns with some aspects of the text which aim to project undue influence on Member States’ national tax policies. The principle of subsidiarity allows Member States to keep taxation under national legislation and I think we need to recognise that.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. If the EU has a right to exist, it is in the deepening and enlargement of the internal market. Without this, the EU would be nothing, and it is a pity that in recent decades it has not concentrated on these areas. Instead, a 'internal market' has been constructed for all sorts of things: education, family policy, social policy. The most devastating decision was that for the 'single market of the currency', that is, for the single euro. Instead, competition policy must be promoted, competition between EU countries must be stimulated, and the economy must be further liberalised. I was happy to vote in favour of this report, drawn up by mr Morten Messerschmidt, a member of our group.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report rightly notes the importance of free competition in the economy, as established in the Treaties. That competition should not however be detrimental to social progress. The political situation in the UK unfortunately has too many parties who are opposed to social progress – the Conservative, Labour and Liberal Democratic parties all take a right-wing approach.  I voted in favour of this report and hope that the people of Scotland will vote against the UK’s right-wing alliance in this year’s election.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition policy is one of the main pillars for the establishment of an active single market and has always been at the heart of the European project. The gradual establishment of a European Single Market without internal borders has brought economic benefits to Europe and its trading partners. But in a rapidly changing environment of competition, new and new challenges arise that Europe must face.  The report on EU competition policy presented to us by the EC addresses the key challenges in this area and clearly shows that competition policy is moving in the right direction – towards expanding and developing the internal market. The report recognises the crucial importance of implementing competition policy and ensuring a level playing field within the single market. I call on the Commission to continue to monitor the independence, impartiality and objectivity of competition policy procedures, as they provide consumer and business confidence for Europe's development on the path of sustainable growth.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report, presented by Mr Messerschmidt by the ECON Commission, on the report presented by the Competition Commissioner. The Resolution assumes the basic postulates of a liberal conception that promotes the free movement of capital and services, all within the framework of TTE.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I think is important to underline the following points: we should have fair competition and combat social dumping on the labour market, an end to tax evasion and illegal corporate tax practices, and last but not least a co-decision right for Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the Competition Policy Report because of the importance of European competition policy. Failure to comply with European competition criteria loses major resources. Some estimates suggest that, for example, organising into cartels brings losses of 3% of the EU's GDP.  Competition policy ensures equality between economic operators and delivers consumer protection, boosting innovation and economic growth. There are a number of issues to look out for, particularly this was demonstrated by a survey last year by journalists that revealed problematic tax solutions by some states used by some companies (LuxLeaks).

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. This report highlights the unfultified objectives of fair competition in the single market, particularly in the area of goods and services. It also highlights abuses of dominant positions and cartels, against which the report proposes commendable, albeit timid, measures. The risk of oligopolies forming in certain sectors is particularly high, and the legislator will have to pay attention to them.  Finally, plans to open up the network and energy industries to competition are defended in this text, thus recalling the objectives of the Juncker plan. I therefore refuse to approve a text defending a single market project and liberalisation at the European level, in all sectors.  I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Morten Messerschmidt's report on the annual report on EU competition policy, presenting the legislative activities of the European Commission, in accord with the rules on state aid, cartels and mergers and acquisitions. In particular, the text calls on the Commission to review its guidelines on antitrust/cartel fines, which date back to 2006. The lack of concrete results in the Google survey is also regretted.  The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the annual report on EU competition policy. Competition policy plays a key role in implementing conditions for innovation, productivity, job creation and growth in Europe. The report calls on the Commission to implement a number of measures to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market, including the implementation of rules on competition law infringements, state aid and merger control. I welcome its adoption.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Writing. As a SPÖ-EU delegation, we voted unanimously against Mr Messerschmidt's report on EU competition policy. There are two main reasons for this: firstly, the report calls on the Commission to continue to tackle the dismantling of state-owned railway undertakings. This means further liberalisation and privatisation. We know from experience that this always happens to the detriment of customers. Nor will it bring "fairer competition," as is often claimed, but it will lead to private companies using the most profitable routes and siphoning off profits there. Remote areas will then have to continue to be used by state-affiliated companies to ensure basic services and infrastructure. Contrary to many claims, the prices for customers will certainly rise. Secondly, we wanted to note that the inclusion of investor-state dispute settlement procedures in free trade agreements (e.B. the ISDS procedure in the EU-US Free Trade Agreement (TTIP) deprives Member States of the democratic right to implement their own policies. Nor must there be a two-tier jurisdiction that gives more rights to international corporations than any other company and every citizen. These provisions are certainly not in the interests of the citizens of Austria and Europe, and that is why the SPÖ-EU delegation rejected this report.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Continued efforts to create a level playing field throughout the European Union are worthy of approval. The foundations of the Community's existence are the open market economy and free competition, as well as the single internal market, of which proper competition policy is an indispensable part.   Unfortunately, at present, despite the best efforts, the conditions of competition vary from one Member State to another. Each country has its own tax law, a separate business support system or its own social security system. We also remember recent reports that some countries are using unclean licks to attract investors. Many companies take advantage of the usual loopholes in the law, and some enjoy individual, incomprehensible privileges. There is also a lot of work to be done on competition policy in the area of fair access to energy raw materials. Unfortunately, as a result of political decisions, some countries are forced to pay a much higher price for gas than others. Nor does such an attitude allow a level playing field to be ed.  Another area is direct payments. The prices of fuels, fertilisers and agricultural machinery are similar throughout the Union. Yet there are still differences in the level of subsidies between countries.  There are plenty of similar examples. We must do everything we can to make the conditions on the European market more and more fair.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI)
text: Writing. Functioning competition is a prerequisite for the success of European businesses, job creation and the standard of living of citizens. Fair and open competition is a driver of innovation and an incentive for entrepreneurship, for growth and employment, i.e. for those economic factors that are crucial to getting out of the financial crisis. The task of politics is to create a framework in which these competition mechanisms also function.  The points that the rapporteur and Commissioner Vestager have made are extremely important, are supported by Parliament, in particular the ECON Committee, and must be taken into account in future legislation.  Competition policy has promoted the four freedoms, increased consumer protection and strengthened living standards and business freedoms. No one can deny that innovation is most effective when it emerges from healthy competition. I strongly support the report that has been presented.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on EU competition policy at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg because it supports ensuring fair competition in the European Union. I believe that fair competition in the European Union will make it easier for Latvian companies to acquire new export markets in the European Union. Competition is important both for industry and the business environment and for consumers. Competition requires businesses to give consumers the widest choice by satisfying consumer quality standards at their most favourable prices. Competition policy ensures the continued development of businesses, investment and innovation. It is important that the European Union's competition policy does not allow a monopolistic business environment when companies use a dominant position for malicious purposes. The European Union's competition policy therefore includes State aid rules for undertakings to ensure that the State does not provide aid to one undertaking more and less, thereby creating a competitive disadvantage and forcing potential competitors out of the market.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report raises valid points of note in response to the EU Commission’s annual report on its competition policy. Above all, the report stresses that fairer tax competition is needed to ensure the continued integrity of the internal market, in order to promote growth and competitiveness across the EU. It calls on the Commission to ensure the consistent implementation of EU state aid control rules and to keep the European Parliament informed of the progress of its investigations.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the EU has an important role to play in making sure that companies across Europe, large and small, can compete on a level playing field – while at the same time ensuring that services like healthcare are protected from a race to the bottom that comes along with privatisation. The report also showed, when referring to LuxLeaks, how multinational companies can act in a fundamentally anti-competitive way when they relocate and reduce their tax rates to almost nothing. We need to take action at a European level to stop that practice from happening.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. The report presented by Morten Messerschmidt contains a number of ambiguous proposals which can be interpreted in the east or west, depending on the political stand. For example, Morten Messerschmidt's report proposes that tax harmonisation measures should be 'presented', but it is never explained what it should be. Is it, for example, a common corporate tax base? In that case, we're in favor. But if it is a real common corporation tax or a joint reduction in corporation tax in the EU, then we are clearly opposed. We do not want to help open a charging gate for all-out tax harmonisation proposals from the Commission. The report also states that competition policy must not be used to enable tax interventions. Again, the report is imprecise. The LuxLeaks case is being investigated precisely on the basis of competition policy. The proposal could therefore be read as saying that, on the basis of Commissioner Vestager's investigation, action against tax evasion cannot be proposed. We are clearly opposed to that. In such important areas as competition policy and the fight against tax evasion, we want clear lines. There must be no doubt as to what is being voted 'yes' or 'no'. The Danish Social Democrats in the European Parliament have therefore chosen neither to vote 'yes' or 'no' to these ambiguous proposals, and we call for its proposals to be presented loud and clear in the future.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of Mr De Clercq's report. Morten Messerschmidt the european Union's objective is to promote free competition, which is positively reflected for the benefit of consumers, businesses and society as a whole. I believe that competition policy is of fundamental importance for the success of the European Union in that it encourages entrepreneurship and efficiency, increases consumer choice and contributes to lower prices and to improving quality.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report contains some interesting elements such as the abuse of Google's dominant position and the demand to strengthen investigations against tax aid. But as a whole this report takes up all the European doxa on the primacy of the construction of the single market and the virtues of competition. It is this approach that forces all public monopolies and defeats our public services one by one.  Therefore, I preferred to vote against this report rather than join this plea to the destructive logics of quality public services aimed at citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report on EU competition policy presented to Parliament fails to complete the conclusion that the objectives of pure and perfect competition in the single market have not been achieved in the goods and services sector.
