Abuses of dominance and cartels, against which the text suggests certain laudable measures, are evidence of a risk of market power in certain sectors characterized by the presence of oligopolies.  Moreover, the text clearly calls for the continuation of plans to open up the network and energy industries to competition, thus aligning itself with the objectives of the Juncker plan.  Refusing to approve a failed single market project and large-scale liberalisation plans, I voted against it.

name: Jörg Leichtfried (S&D)
text: Writing. As a SPÖ-EU delegation, we voted unanimously against Mr Messerschmidt's report on EU competition policy. There are two main reasons for this: firstly, the report calls on the Commission to continue to tackle the dismantling of state-owned railway undertakings. This means further liberalisation and privatisation. We know from experience that this always happens to the detriment of customers. Nor will it bring "fairer competition," as is often claimed, but it will lead to private companies using the most profitable routes and siphoning off profits there. Remote areas will then have to continue to be used by state-affiliated companies to ensure basic services and infrastructure. Contrary to many claims, the prices for customers will certainly rise. Secondly, we wanted to note that the inclusion of investor-state dispute settlement procedures in free trade agreements (e.B. the ISDS procedure in the EU-US Free Trade Agreement (TTIP) deprives Member States of the democratic right to implement their own policies. Nor must there be a two-tier jurisdiction that gives more rights to international corporations than any other company and every citizen. These provisions are certainly not in the interests of the citizens of Austria and Europe, and that is why the SPÖ-EU delegation rejected this report.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against. Competition policy is one of the dogmas of the European Union which obliges more open markets by removing all barriers to competition. The report considers that "competition prevents excessive concentration of economic and financial power in the hands of a few players, which in itself represents a risk to the independence of European political power vis-à-vis the major industrial and banking groups". This policy is therefore a failure because certain sectors have seen the emergence of oligopolies (banking sector, large distribution). Large retailers, often condemned for cartels, put a lot of pressure on suppliers via common purchasing centres. SMEs remain losers, disadvantaged by regulations that favour large groups, depriving them of public procurement. The state can no longer protect its strategic sectors and European competition policy pursues the aim of ending the last barriers to the single market. There is therefore no result of competition policy vis-à-vis the main monopolies, and incompatibility between the Commission's positions with a strategic state policy and the consequences for SMEs.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report despite containing very positive points because it maintains a worrying approach against public participation in the economy. While we find a rejection of public aid to banking (and it is noted that they have not helped to increase the flow of credit to the real economy) and the report condemns the Commission's action on preferred holdings or requires that the territorial consequences of competition policy actions be contemplated , etc. there is no clear denunciation of the Commission's neoliberal approach and its policy contrary to public sector participation. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Treaties state that, in the economic dimension, the EU is 'an open market economy with free competition'; However, greater focus is needed on promoting competition in order to achieve ambitious targets for employment, growth, investment and competitiveness at the global level of the European economy, as sustainable and effective competition encourages investment and the benefit of end-users and fuels the economy. It is worth noting the fundamental role of compliance with competition policy in creating a level playing field that promotes innovation, productivity, job creation and investment between all parties involved in the single market and all business models, including SMEs, while fully respecting national diversity. The creation of these powers also entails the fight against social dumping and the application of European social and environmental legislation. I voted in favour of asking the Commission to apply the rules on the defence of competition, on State aid and merger control, in order to achieve an internal market that is functioning properly and promotes social progress.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the whole annual report because I do not agree with Parliament's call on the Commission to take further action. In particular, I voted against paragraph 75, which calls for tax harmonisation, and against the PPE Group amendment on the same point, which calls for minimum taxes. On the contrary, I appreciated the amendments to paragraph 95 from the GUE/NGL Group, which criticises isds (Investor State Dispute Settlement), because I support the democratically expressed sovereignty of the Member States, and i therefore supported this amendment because it highlights the danger that this sovereignty will be weakened again because of ISDS.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The internal market, in which goods, services, capital and people move freely and in which European citizens freely develop their business, is impossible without the EU's competition policy. We need regulation at European level against monopoly practices, agreements between companies to set prices and share markets, illegal State aid, etc. Competition policy works successfully against abuse, and as a result we get more innovation and benefits for end users: lower prices, better quality and protection.  I support the European Parliament resolution on the annual report on EU competition policy. The text was adopted in plenary with a large majority: 526 votes in favour against 108 against. This is a clear political message from Parliament on one of the strongest policies of the Union's exclusive competence.  I would like to note that the report highlights important trends in the energy sector, namely that the European gas market should evolve towards a fair and stable energy union, improving the diversification of its energy sources and access to strategic infrastructures. Bulgaria has the unique chance to take advantage of the full coincidence of its national interest with the clear pan-European political line.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We did not know until the last minute whether our group's amendments to this report would go away or not. Since we left, we decided to vote in favour of the group, even in the Chamber. What I did, too.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 Although the most important tasks of the European Parliament include the control of the executive, in the field of EU competition policy, it is essential that the European Parliament, with a view to increasing consumer protection, also has a major influence on the adoption of legislative measures in this area. It is therefore necessary for the European Commission to increase its monitoring and control activities in the area of compliance with competition rules and, on the basis of its findings, to present proposals for measures to prevent discriminatory and illegal behaviour in this area.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. The higher efficiency of the market economy lies and is based on the level of competition that is truly existing. If it declines, not only does efficiency but also any glimpse of social justice. That is where I vote in favour of this report to ensure maximum European competence and to alert those elements that have been threatening it lately, such as covert state aid, tax privileges or social dumping.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. Vote against this report, which goes against the interests of Member States and their SMEs by increasing the pressure on SMEs without preventing the domination of a few players such as the major economic powers. The report also makes most targeted state aid illegal and lacks concrete references to the social consequences of certain policies.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report’s demand that ‘EU Structural Funds may not be used in a way that directly or indirectly supports the relocation of services or production to other Member States’.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. The EU's Annual Report on Competition Policy calls for a swift conclusion of the banking aid scheme of states in crisis, with reference to the fact that State aid to banking systems has not increased credit or restored confidence in eurozone countries. In the field of services of general economic interest, it reaffirms the importance of universal accessible services and underlines the Commission's responsibility to reassure that the compensation provided to services of general economic interest is compatible with State aid. It also points out that better competition in the form of taxes is essential for the integrity of the internal market and encourages the Commission to apply the state aid control rules carefully.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A coherent competition policy, and a system of competitiveness based on the principles of the free market, are prerogatives necessary to ensure the prosperity of the Community economy. My support for the Messerschmidt report stems from the conviction that the European Union must promote an effective competition policy, the sole objective of which is to bring benefits to consumers, businesses and the whole of Community society.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report includes some positive points relating to the violation of EU competition policies, such as: criticism of State aid granted to the banking sector; the case of Google and its lack of solution and the scale of tax fraud competition in the EU. But even so, the report maintains a very neoliberal focus on the functioning of the single market, giving priority to the liberalisation of the public sectors, so as to include a chapter of competition in the TTIP negotiations, and sees the new banking regulation as positive. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report, as competition policy and competitiveness in general are crucial to the well-being and success of the EU and its citizens. MEPs are elected to represent the interests and concerns of their electorate. Competition policy must benefit consumers, businesses and society as a whole. Thus, the proposal that the Commissioners responsible for competition policy hold meetings with MEPs in order to better understand and take into account the concerns of this electorate is only to be supported.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the application of the principles of competition law is primarily beneficial to the consumer. In addition, it is estimated that tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens cost EU taxpayers EUR 1 billion a year. This activity in the single market distorts competition between companies that pay taxes and companies that do not pay them. It is therefore necessary in this area for the Commission to ensure the enforcement of the competition rules and to take effective measures in the fight against monopolies and cartels.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The annual report on the Union's competition policy is based on the ideological assumption that only unlimited and barrier-free competition will enable Europe to emerge from the crisis and return to growth. It even learns that "competition policy is in itself a tool to safeguard European democracy". Once this is said, the usual catechism is recited: for example, it is a question of implementing "without delay" the "third package of measures to liberalize gas and electricity". Or to "continue to make progress towards the completion of the single transport market".  Unlimited competition is disastrous for the peoples of Europe. If the remedy kills the patient, it is not that the dose is insufficient but that it is bad. Therefore, it is not necessary to increase the dose but to change it. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It should be made clear to everyone that competition policy and competitiveness in general are vital to the health and success of the EU as a whole and therefore for its citizens. It is through fostering an innovative competitive culture that we may finally be able to emerge from the financial crisis. Through an effective competition policy, we can consolidate and strengthen the importance of the EU in the world.  Therefore, when a new political mandate begins, the term 'competitiveness' must be at the top of our political agenda. This report shows that much needs to be done to improve EU competition policy. Let's all work together to achieve the defined goals.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ An effective competition policy would increase the EU’s global economic importance. It is essential that the competition policy meets the demands of the digital age and that the goals of creating a Digital Single Market remain at the centre of the drive to increase employment levels across the Member States.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Competition policy is crucial in the current context in order to regain the european Union's competitiveness on the world stage. I fully support the words of Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager, when she insists on the need to strictly enforce competition rules, to fight cartels, to investigate abuses of dominant position, to observe the financial sector. It is vital to develop a competition policy with absolute respect for the treaties. It is about consumer welfare.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ I welcome the adoption of the annual report on EU competition policy because I consider it necessary to place emphasis on promoting competition, which allows the EU to achieve more ambitious targets in terms of employment, growth, investment and competitiveness of the European economy in the world.  Competition is a driver of the economy and is a cornerstone for ensuring the proper functioning of a dynamic and innovative internal market. I recall that the available estimates quantify the annual damage caused by cartels of EUR 181-320 billion, which represents about 3% of EU GDP. Further damage is caused by abuse of market dominance, inadequate State aid and poor application of public procurement rules. I also consider the misuse of the Structural Funds to be a worrying practice, which should be addressed, inter alia, in the context of competition. Finally, I join the call for Member States to introduce new EU rules on public procurement, including social, environmental and innovation characteristics, in a timely manner, allowing public authorities to make better choices.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the annual report on competition policy, which makes it clear that competition policy and competitiveness in general, is of vital importance to the health and success of the EU as a whole and therefore its citizens. The report tries to ensure fair competition and combat social dumping on the labour market, tackle fragmentation and anti-trust behaviour in the EU digital market. I agree with the line of the rapporteur that ‘competitiveness’ must be at the forefront of our political agenda. Having said that, however, I do not support some of the paragraphs in this report calling for a coordinated proposal on tax competition.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's draft resolution on the annual report on EU competition policy calls for the strict application of competition principles in EU markets in order to ensure the purity of competition and remove artificial barriers to competition; making anti-monopoly regulation more effective, in particular with regard to high-injury cartels; action against tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens; the elimination of market fragmentation; alleviating the credit crisis that often afflicts small and medium-sized enterprises and combating all forms of protectionism. This has an effect on the unification of the market and the deepening of the Union, so I supported the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union's competition policy has always regarded free market rules and pure and perfect competition as the guarantors of growth and employment. From this point of view, it has failed quite broadly.  Monopolies have succeeded equally predatory oligopolies. SMEs are too often deprived of access to large public markets. The privatization of the old public services of energy, transport or telecoms has mainly maximized the profits of a few players. The banking sector is getting considerable aid, with no benefit to the real economy. Finally, the Commission's control of public aid prohibits any policy of supporting strategic or troubled economic sectors by states, i.e. any sovereign economic policy.  An overly dogmatic competition policy is therefore counterproductive, while the freedom to undertake is often hampered by the weight of administrative and fiscal constraints.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Some sectors of the Single Market remain divided by national borders and artificial barriers, and there is sometimes an abuse of Structural Funds or tax aid that causes difficulties in the European Union's competition policy. I believe that competition policy is an instrument for preserving European economic democracy, as it prevents excessive concentration of economic and financial power in a few hands and increases the competitiveness of the various European sectors. In this regard, and because I believe that it is essential to improve the Single Market in the area of competition policy, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This annual report on EU competition policy praises the effect of the single market and competition policy on Member States' economies. It recommends further reducing the scope of services of general economic interest (SIEG) exempt from notifications such as social housing, as well as exemptions from state aid on sustainable energy. In the name of the sacrosanct principle of free and undistorted competition, he proposes to further break down national borders and artificial barriers, while worrying about social dumping practices, and eliminating monopolistic energy suppliers, even though the United States has come back on them. It is in an anti-protectionist dogmatism in the name of globalized free trade which nevertheless leads to massive deindustrialization.  Moreover, the report asserts that competition policy is in itself a means of safeguarding democracy, demonstrating here the ordoliberal ideology that underlies it.  The analysis on SMEs is flawed: it is above all the economic gloom maintained by austerity that takes credit.  Finally, there is no provision for the requirement for reciprocity of public procurement...  I therefore objected to the adoption of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy because the EU has an important role to play in making sure that companies across Europe, large and small, can compete on a level playing field – while at the same time ensuring that services like healthcare are protected from a race to the bottom that comes along with privatisation. The report also showed, when referring to LuxLeaks, how multinational companies can act in a fundamentally anti-competitive way when they relocate and reduce their tax rates to almost nothing. We need to take action at European level to stop that practice from happening.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the Commission's annual report outlining its activities to enforce the provisions of European competition policy. The text calls for a better fight against social dumping and the misuse of structural funds by some Member States. The text also reiterates the need to guarantee an open internet and to enshrine net neutrality in European law.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Competition policy and competitiveness in general are fundamental values for the success and functioning of the European Union as a whole. They have always been an essential instrument for removing obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital and thus for promoting the completion of the single market and the protection of the interests of European consumers.  We support this report because we wish to highlight the important role played by the European Parliament in recent years. We reiterate our commitment to strict and equitable application of EU competition and state aid rules; respect for the principle of subsidiarity and the decisions of national courts in the field of competition policy; the firm contrast of cartels, all dominant or monopoly positions, social dumping in the labour market; close cooperation with other third-country authorities and international organisations to investigate any suspected illegal uses of tax advantages and evasions.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report illustrates how competition policy and competitiveness in general are of fundamental importance for the success of the European Union as a whole. Free competition is, in fact, the cornerstone of an open market economy. It stimulates Europe's economic performance and offers consumers a wider choice of better quality products and services at more competitive prices.  In the light of the above, I have decided to support this report because it is only through the development of a competitive competitive culture that we can finally emerge from the financial crisis.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this annual report on EU competition policy which highlights the problems that exist at European level in this area, as well as the collective effort to resolve them.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it helps bring much needed focus to the way the Commission and Member States, more importantly, deal with competition policy. Competition can be the main source of market growth for the Union, as long as it is protected, but not overburdened, and stimulated, but not subsumed to national interests. I am also strongly in favour of the wide-ranging coverage of the text and I think we do need to ensure Member States coordinate properly to ensure a level playing field in competition policy.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. Sustainable framework conditions to boost economic growth and employment are imperative in Europe. We can only work together to boost competition in Europe and strengthen businesses. Together, we need to create benefits for consumers and invest targeted financial resources in the areas of research and development. Because of the need, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft because promoting competition promotes investment and stimulates the economy. Given that the damage caused by cartels amounts to 3% of the European Union's economy and that taxpayers are left with around a trillion euros a year for tax fraud and tax evasion, competition policy is central to strengthening the single market as a whole and creating a fair environment. At the same time, however, specific tax rates must take into account national differences (e.g. geographical distance, which has a deterrent effect on competition) and leave them to national governments.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I agree with the report submitted. Competition policy must be based on a level playing field in all sectors. It is the foundation of a European social market economy and a very important instrument for ensuring the functioning of a sustainable EU market, boosting growth and jobs.  I believe that the Commission should step up its efforts in the global context and link the Union's competition policy in Europe to the call for the opening of public procurement markets outside the EU. It is essential that the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership agreement includes a chapter on competition. In addition, measures are needed across the EU to ensure fair competition and better quality of services in the rail sector, as well as in the management of port and airport networks. I think it would be appropriate to assess the combined impact of corporate taxes and State aid.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EU's annual report on competition policy because I believe that this regulates important procedures that need to be implemented in order to ensure the proper functioning of a Single European Market characterised by healthy competition between the companies operating in it. Consumer protection must be our main interest and the more active involvement of the European Parliament in the decision-making stages of market policies would ensure greater democratic legitimacy for the latter, as decision-making processes would gain transparency and participation. In particular, a proper market policy must look at concrete problems such as social dumping or the misuse of the Structural Funds. European consumers have an imperative right to free access to all goods produced in the Union at the best possible price. The current financial crisis, which Europe is facing, cannot, under any circumstances, be seen as a pretext for disregarding precise and indispensable rules that limit the power of the large multinationals and guarantee social inclusion and homogeneity in rights. Only through dynamism, innovation and sustainability can economic growth be stimulated and the degree of competitiveness of our market can withstand global comparison.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it supports the liberalisation of the European rail sector at all costs. In the previous Parliament, I opposed this narrow liberalisation wanted by the European Conservatives and I still support the same position today. Liberalisation is not a sign of progress for rail transport.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that certain sectors within the single market are still divided by national borders and artificial barriers and that, at the same time, alarming practices such as social dumping or misuse of the Structural Funds should be addressed within the framework of the European Union's competition policy. Whereas competition policy is in itself an instrument for safeguarding European democracy; Whereas a competition policy based on uniform conditions in all sectors is the foundation of the European social market economy and an essential instrument for ensuring the proper functioning of a dynamic, efficient, sustainable and innovative internal market and whereas the economic and financial crisis should therefore not be a pretext for relaxing the application of the competition rules; Whereas tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens cost EU taxpayers an estimated EUR 100 billion a year in lost tax revenue, for these reasons I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Interest rates of 4% for investments in facilities seem small to Croatian peasants compared to the interest rates on other products offered by bankers (from 6% for the purchase of equipment up to 12% for repromaterials), while for the same banking product in western European countries, interest for production investments is about 1 - 2%, noting that the owners of banks operating in Croatia are mostly in Western Member States. There is a similar situation with network and wireless carriers. Prices of lower quality services are charged at the same or higher price, in a country that has an average per capita income 5-6 times lower than the countries of the headquarters of the parent companies of these operators.  The change in fuel prices is announced for several days in the central daily of national television so that oil companies do not even have to meet and negotiate in secret. Croatia is a small country by population (consumers), so such price arrangements at the border of cartel association, fruitful flower. And these are just some of the negative phenomena.  That is why I support this report, which calls on the Commission to ensure, through active monitoring and proposed measures, for respect and protection of competition throughout the European Union, for the benefit of all its citizens, workers, peasants and consumers.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Some sectors in the single market remain divided by national borders and artificial barriers, while practices such as social dumping or misuse of structural funds are a cause for concern. Competition policy itself is an instrument for protecting European democracy because it prevents excessive concentration of economic and financial power for the benefit of a small number of individuals. Tax evasion, tax fraud and tax havens are estimated to cost EU taxpayers €1 trillion in lost profits annually. Successful development of SMEs (representing 98% of businesses in the EU) in conditions of free competition is one of the basic preconditions for job creation, sustainable growth, innovation and investment in the European Union. Competition policy based on a level playing field in all sectors is a cornerstone of Europe's social market economy and a basic instrument that guarantees the proper functioning of the internal market, the launch of economic growth and job creation and competitiveness globally. The economic and financial crisis must therefore not be an excuse to mitigate the implementation of competition rules.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I am of the opinion that in the area of services of general economic interest, greater responsibility of the Commission will ensure that the fees granted comply with EU State aid rules. Particular attention should be paid to the banking sector, as State aid to the banking system has not increased trust, indicating the need to return to the traditional application of State aid control. Stressing the importance of fairer tax competition as a necessary factor to achieve the integrity of the internal market, the Commission's active participation in the implementation of State aid control rules, while constantly informing the EP of progress, will make the system more transparent and independent. Also, the Commission's continued participation in meetings of Parliament's relevant committees and working groups will contribute to the transparency of the system. Fostering a culture of innovative competition helps to achieve employment, economic growth, investment, and promote future-oriented sectors such as the digital economy and the energy sector. This ultimately leads to a faster exit from the financial crisis.  Competition and increasing competitiveness will affect all EU member states, including Croatia, and will force single market participants to specialise better and eliminate the possibility of monopolies, ultimately benefiting consumers the most. In support of MeP Morten Messerschmit's report, I welcome further efforts by the Commission and Parliament on the better functioning of competition policy.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am a strong supporter that a good competition and competitiveness policy is fundamental to any organisation and, as a result, the promotion of a competitive competitive culture can seriously help the European Union to consolidate and strengthen its position and presence in the world. It is important that competitiveness is put on the European Parliament's political agenda and that an EU competition policy is developed in accordance with the Treaties. It has already been seen in the past that the European Union's competition policy has brought many benefits in terms of consumer welfare and has made it possible to remove the various obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, people and capital. Competition policy must continue to be a fundamental instrument for protecting the single market and consumer interests. In addition, new competition policy initiatives must always be assessed in order to be ready to face the challenges facing an increasingly globalised market.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the final vote, I supported the motion for a resolution approving the report on the annual report on EU competition policy, as I consider its form to be satisfactory after the votes on the various amendments. After my trial, it has been achieved that the report has a balanced form, which I consider to be its greatest advantage. Where the EU's achievements in this area can be highlighted, the report does so, nor is it too unasuchable to draw attention to the difficulties that the Union still has to deal with.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. European competition policy is now at the centre of the new Juncker Commission's strategy to increase competitiveness and boost economic growth within the Union. However, this policy cannot be effective without strict compliance with the rules at European level. We insisted on these elements by voting yesterday on the annual report on EU competition policy. I am pleased to have spoken in favour.  This text underlines the importance of an effective and innovative policy, and underlines the need to combat questionable practices. Among them, I particularly hope that we will fight social dumping and tax war between European partners. Everyone has to play by the same rules of the game. These are real problems for our social and fiscal model.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. In the Single Market, some sectors remain divided by national borders and artificial barriers. On the other hand, we are witnessing practices such as social dumping and the misuse of Structural Funds, which pose difficulties that also have to be resolved in the framework of EU competition policy. Competition policy is an instrument for preserving European democracy in that it prevents excessive concentration of economic and financial power in few hands, which poses a risk to the independence of European political power from large industrial and banking groups.  On the other hand, as the report points out, competition policy is a cornerstone of the European social market economy, ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market, the development of SMEs and the protection of consumer interests. To this extent, it is important to highlight the commitment made by the new Commission to effectively implement competition rules in the fields of antitrust and cartels, mergers and State aid, the alignment of competition instruments with market developments, while also promoting an innovative culture of competition, both in the EU and globally. I voted in favour.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. As a SPÖ-EU delegation, we voted unanimously against Mr Messerschmidt's report on EU competition policy. There are two main reasons for this: firstly, the report calls on the Commission to continue to tackle the dismantling of state-owned railway undertakings. This means further liberalisation and privatisation. We know from experience that this always happens to the detriment of customers. Nor will it bring "fairer competition," as is often claimed, but it will lead to private companies using the most profitable routes and siphoning off profits there. Remote areas will then have to continue to be used by state-affiliated companies to ensure basic services and infrastructure. Contrary to many claims, the prices for customers will certainly rise. Secondly, we wanted to note that the inclusion of investor-state dispute settlement procedures in free trade agreements (e.B. the ISDS procedure in the EU-US Free Trade Agreement (TTIP) deprives Member States of the democratic right to implement their own policies. Nor must there be a two-tier jurisdiction that gives more rights to international corporations than any other company and every citizen. These provisions are certainly not in the interests of the citizens of Austria and Europe, and that is why the SPÖ-EU delegation rejected this report.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament today put to a vote the annual report on the European Union's competition policy, carried by a Conservative MP, Mr Messerschmidt.  In this text, the rapporteur sets out the classic vision of the right on the pre-eminence of competition over the general interest, the superiority of competitiveness over the quality of public services. Thus, in its transport component, the state's management of certain key sectors is called into question, while experience shows that, where transport is not cost-effective, public power is necessary to ensure the continuity of public service.  Once again, the conservative right seeks to weaken social cohesion to pave the way for deregulated liberalism. While compromises with the European right are sometimes useful in advancing our proposals, bland compromises only serve to dilute our message and our political positions, as would have been the case with this text.  In line with the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats, I have therefore decided to reject this report.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that on many occasions the market has suffered some distortions on the part of companies, thus hindering competitiveness in the European Union. Labour devaluation practices, state aid favouring companies for other, illegal competition practices, the negative impact of cartels and the monopolisation of certain sectors make healthy competitiveness difficult or even impossible, indispensable for economic growth and job creation. It also calls into question the EU's free market principle. I also support the need to ensure a level playing field for businesses in the internal market also involves combating dumping and implementing social and environmental legislation at European level.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. Without a free and effective competition policy, the European Union will not be able to print its model on the globalised economy, namely a level playing field for all economic actors and a significant share dedicated to SMEs, the main creators of innovation and jobs. This means the importance of a good application of competition rules in the Union, as the Messerschmidt report voted this lunchtime points out. A competition policy must benefit consumers, businesses and society as a whole. It is also important to stress that certain sectors occupy a strategic position and require an appropriate EU policy: the Digital Single Market, the energy sector, the industry and transport sectors. A logical focus on rapidly changing areas where, in terms of digital technology, American companies are in a quasi-monopoly situation and in more traditional industries (automotive, shipyards, steel or robotics), Asian companies occupy the pole position. If Europe is to go the extra mile, it must at the same time know which way to go. That is why the rapporteur's proposal to have current competition policy initiatives assessed to meet the challenges of globalisation is welcome.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. I believe that competition policy and competitiveness in general are vital to the health and success of the EU and should be at the top of our political agenda. However, we must always keep in mind that this must never overtake the rights of workers and the fundamental guarantees of every citizen.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. •u2012 Competition policy is itself a tool for safeguarding European democracy, inso as it prevents excessive concentration of economic and financial power in a few hands, which would pose a risk to the independence of European political power from large industrial and banking groups; it is also a cornerstone of the European social market economy, to ensure the proper functioning of a dynamic, efficient, sustainable and innovative internal market. This annual report on EU competition policy, which I voted for, sets out the main priorities of the Socialist Group, including ensuring fair competition and combating social dumping in the labour market, combating fragmentation in the EU digital market that ensures an open internet and ensures net neutrality and ending tax evasion and illegal practices by some Member States on agreements prosecutors with companies. In addition, it is important to carry out a comprehensive analysis of the tax provisions of each Member State in order to be able to present tax harmonisation measures that are advantageous to SMEs and ensure the competitiveness of the Member States.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament yesterday adopted by a large majority (526 votes in, 108 against and 59 abstentions) the report on the annual report on competition policy, which specifically targets the giant Google. The voted text regrets, among other things, that after four years of investigation and so many commitments on the part of the American giant, the EU executive has not achieved any tangible results to resolve the main concern that was concerned with the preferential treatment that Google reserves for its services in online search.  MEPs therefore stressed the urgent need to resolve this issue to ensure similar conditions of competition, including ensuring the credibility of the European Union's digital agenda. To that end, the European Commission has been called upon to take strong measures, based on the principle of non-discrimination, against barriers to competition.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. It is common place that we need to promote healthy, sustainable and effective competition towards the ambitious targets for jobs, growth, innovation, productivity and investment, to which the Union has set out for a more competitive European economy on a global scale. Overall, I agree with the proposals put forward by this Resolution on the EU's Annual Report on Competition Policy, so I voted in favour of it. I would also stress that the adoption of these proposals would be extremely beneficial for the implementation of the Single Market, especially those relating to greater protection of consumer rights and interests and by ensuring greater competitiveness to our common competition policy.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. This report outlines the European Union's competition policy and comments on the Commission's annual report.  I supported this text, which once again calls for an end to the state aid regime for the banking sector and underlines the lack of effect on bank lending, calls on the Commission to review its 2006 guidelines on antitrust fines and finally calls on the Commission to combat the problems of social dumping, a point on which we will remain uncompromising.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The analysis of the European Union's competition policy leads to appreciation in terms of consumer welfare but, at the same time, calls for the same policies to be updated in order to be more involved in reality, thus being able to face the new challenges that are becoming apparent in Europe and in the world. A single European market with genuine free movement of goods, people and services is a fundamental pillar of the European Union, will bring more and more benefits to consumers and will enable businesses to respond better to global challenges.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I voted against because, although the text touches on issues that we can support, it does not convince on several aspects, starting with the vagueness of the objectives inherent in the issue of different tax systems.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted against this report, presented by Mr Messerschmidt by the ECON Commission, on the report presented by the Competition Commissioner. The Resolution assumes the basic postulates of a liberal conception that promotes the free movement of capital and services, all within the framework of TTE.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes stock of competition policy in the Union, particularly in the energy, transport, public services and digital sectors. In particular, the report regrets that the proceedings against Google have still not been able to achieve any tangible results in its competition law infringement case, namely the preferential treatment granted by Google to its own services in displaying search query results.  Furthermore, I am pleased that Parliament rightly points out that worrying practices such as social dumping or the misuse of structural funds distort competition in the Union.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. The European Union's competition policy is the source of two injustices. It is a failure against large groups like Google and is incompatible with a state strategy promoting strategic sectors supported by SMEs and supporting them in return. I voted against it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report despite containing very positive points because it maintains a worrying approach against public participation in the economy. This report contains many positive points, including the call to end public aid to banking, noting that they have not helped to increase the flow of credit to the real economy, and a condemnation of the Commission's action on preferred holdings; it also requires that the territorial consequences of competition policy actions be contemplated, etc. All these positive points are at the same time as the neoliberal approach and contrary to the public sector's participation in the economy of many of the points we cannot share. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Competition policy and competitiveness alone are important for the sustainable development and overall well-being of the EU and its citizens. By stimulating an innovative competitive culture, the EU's chances of getting out of the financial crisis are increasing, which is why competitiveness occupies such an important place on our political agenda. An important role in this context is adopted by the European Parliament, which calls for important decisions to be taken in this area. It is important to ensure that EU rules are applied transparently and fairly. It is also necessary to respect the principle of subsidiarity and to respect the decisions of national courts in the field of competition policy. From a practical, national point of view, it is important to support measures to modernise State aid policy, combat cartels and to investigate whether dominant undertakings are not abusing their influence. The financial sector should be closely monitored, with particular regard to transparency at all meetings with external actors. The need to work closely with third-country authorities and international organisations to verify any suspicion of the illegal use of state aid-linked tax credits must not be forgotten. EU competition policy-making should also be carried out in full respect of the Treaties. In view of these expectations, particular attention should be paid to the dialogue that should be maintained between the Commissioner for Competitiveness and the European Parliament, as it is about achieving direct benefits for consumers, businesses and society as a whole.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Annual Report on Competition Policy. The European Union has a vital role to play in making sure that companies across Europe can compete on a level playing field. In addition, the EU must ensure that services like healthcare are protected from a race to the bottom that comes along with privatisation. In reference to the LuxLeaks scandal and multinational companies as a whole, companies can act in a fundamentally anti-competitive way when they relocate and reduce their tax rates to almost nothing. Action must be taken at European level to stop this from happening.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I support competition policy because I believe it represents an effective instrument for the protection of European democracy because it prevents excessive concentration of economic and financial power for the benefit of a small number of individual actors. I would draw particular attention to the European Union's energy market. Currently, the three largest entities still have a share of about 75 percent in the electricity market and more than 60 percent in the gas market.  Furthermore, profitability, sustainability and security should be key elements in addressing the current fragmentation of the market and increasing its competitiveness. Currently, in terms of energy costs, the Single European Market is less successful than the US, with a price dispersion of 31 per cent versus 22 per cent in the US.  In this regard, Croatia as a new member of the Union with its natural wealth of renewable energy resources can significantly contribute to improving the overall energy picture of the European Union. There are currently too little renewable power plants in operation in Croatia due to its natural wealth and potential.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: writing \ u2012 Healthy competition is important to improve competitiveness. In any situation, we must take into account the development of healthy competition, which will ultimately always translate into benefits for the end-user.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. I voted against the Messerschmidt report because I cannot argue that, under paragraph 95, we have not found clear words against out-of-court dispute resolution procedures. If we take the people of Europe seriously, we must take a clear stance in all the reports relating to trade agreements. Our legal systems are strong enough to settle and resolve disputes according to good democratic rules.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This report highlights the importance of profitability, sustainability and security in energy supply for the European economy and its competitiveness. It also stresses that competition policy must take into account this threefold objective in addressing the current market fragmentation, in the correct and timely implementation of the third gas and electricity liberalisation package, when encouraging the separation of wholesale services from retail ones in order to prevent uncompetitive treatment and to contribute to a favourable energy supply for households and businesses.  The regulation of state aid issues for sustainable energy sources should continue to be implemented, while taking into account the EU's 2030 climate and energy targets as well as national diversities. Due to the above facts, I support the annual report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on annual competition policy. The EU has an important role to play in ensuring that all companies in Europe can compete on a level playing field, while protecting services such as healthcare from privatisation. The report also showed, in the case of LuxLeaks, that it is possible for multinational companies to act in an anti-competitive way when they relocate and can virtually escape paying tax. It is important for the EU to take action against this.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: writing – Competition policy and competitiveness are extremely important for the success of the EU as a whole and thus its citizens. Through an effective competition policy, we can strengthen and improve the EU's relevance worldwide. This policy has improved consumer care in many respects, and it has also been an important tool for removing obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, people and capital. Competition policy is a beneficial policy for a healthy, competitive business environment, therefore State aid must also be allocated only in a way that does not distort competition, does not favour large companies over small and medium-sized enterprises, foreign investors over domestic ones. When granting State aid, clear criteria must be laid down, which must also be scrutinised consistently. I also supported the report's call for an uncompromising analysis of what constitutes a responsible national tax policy, particularly as regards unfair tax policies, tax agreements and anti-competitive exemptions.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Unfortunately, competition in all EU Member States does not work in an equally satisfying way. Some sectors within the single market still share national borders and artificial barriers. Worrying practices such as social dumping or misuse of structural funds raise concerns. Competition policy in itself is a means of protecting European democracy, as it prevents an excessive concentration of economic and financial power in the hands of a minority. It is also based on a level playing field in all sectors, but it is also the cornerstone of the European social market economy and is an essential tool to ensure the proper functioning of a dynamic, efficient, sustainable and innovative EU internal market. In order to ensure a fair playing field for businesses in the internal market, it is also necessary to combat social dumping and to implement European social and environmental legislation. Appropriate competitiveness and fiscal measures should support European industry groups and SMEs in order to be successful in a globalised world. The European Commission must take into account the needs of citizens, consumers and SMEs and focus on their problems in the decision-making process so that the competition policies it proposes have added value for European citizens. On the basis of the above reasons, I supported the report on EU competition policy.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the ANNUAL REPORT ON EU Competition Policy, the aim of which is to assess the progress made at European level in implementing policies that encourage free economic competition and the opening up of national markets. The draft legislation highlights the possible critical issues and further steps to be taken to stimulate an "open market economy in free competition". These include the need to avoid State aid (even implicit as in the case of football clubs), the harmonisation of rules on cartels and concentrations and the need for the European Commission's investigations in this field to be rapid and lead to certain penalties. In this sense, among the most debated passages in this dossier are those related to cases of greater public visibility, such as the Commission's google survey, explicitly mentioned in the text. Other topics include interesting references to the "collaborative consumer economy", the strong rise of which raises concerns about the possible distortion of competition. I welcome the analysis made in this report and believe that it is a good starting point for further progress on this issue.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. – I support this report, calls, for the fourth time in a row, for the immediate abolition of the State aid crisis system for the banking sector, and stresses that State aid to the banking system has not increased reputation or restored trust, reiterates its concern that the use of fines as the only types of penalties may not be sufficiently effective, reiterates its call on the Commission to consider the possibility of a general revision of the 2006 guidelines for fixing fines, and calls for these guidelines to be included in Regulation 1/2013.  The report also identifies how social dumping and misuse of structural funds raise concerns and how important the role in the report is devoted to fiscal state aid.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ I abstained when voting on the proposal, as I agree with the general spirit of the report, that is to say, the desire to promote competitiveness, just as I agree with many of the proposals presented, but there are also proposals in the report on which I have fundamental comments. These include, for example, the fight against 'social dumping', the call for action in the field of competition and taxation, that is to say, interference in member states' tax policies, as well as a call for action against alleged unfair behaviour by Google and so on.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the annual report on EU competition policy, as it is independent competition on the market that will ensure growth, employment, investment and global competitiveness. Fragmentation in the EU internal market is very high, and this undermines competition in the market. Monopolies are being created that result in 180 to 230 billion a year. We must ask ourselves whether competitiveness at EU level is strong enough for small and medium-sized enterprises to compete equally. I also supported the annual report on EU competition policy because it represents another step forward towards greater job protection.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report does not provide for adequate protection of individuals from support for the monopoly banking sector.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Competition policy is an integral part of the EU's genetic code. Established by the Treaty of Rome, the three instruments of competition policy aim to maintain a level playing field and an open and dynamic market. This encourages companies to seek success on their own merits (price, quality and innovation) in order to meet the needs, preferences and wishes of intermediate and end-users. The European market social economy would be unthinkable without competition. But I want to make it clear that this cannot be possible without strict respect for consumers and workers, respect for labour and human rights must prevail!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which touches upon important topics for the internal market such as fair competition, the digital single market and support for SMEs. These elements are essential if we want growth and innovation on our continent.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. This report includes a crucial aspect in terms of economic model: the necessary improvement of the centralist models of single and indivisible management, which leaves no room for another possible organization of logistics and transport activity in a State. On the other hand, we must propose appropriate models, preferably public and which have an ally in the principle of subsidiarity. We must also take into account municipalities when managing infrastructure such as ports and airports.

name: Giovanni Toti (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote underlines that competition policy and competitiveness in general are of fundamental importance for the health and success of the European Union as a whole and therefore of its citizens. It is through the promotion of a competitive competitive culture that we could finally emerge from the financial crisis, consolidating and strengthening the importance of the European Union throughout the world.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission really has a chance to make a difference in the fight against oligopolistic practices. In the Google antitrust case a lot of people forget that, among the dozens of complainants, there are several US companies. Some of them, like Yelp, have no problem going public; others do not want to attack Google openly, because they fear retaliation measures, such as demotion or exclusion by Google. We met several US companies who are victims of these practices, which explained how they simply disappear from a Google search for several days, which has a huge economic impact on them. I want to stress once again that this is not a European versus American company war! I am not ideologically against Google or any other US company. I am against monopolies.  Google has a 90% market share in some European countries and is the ‘de facto’ gatekeeper of the Internet for European SMEs and consumers.  The preferential treatment of Google’s own services is not fair practice: Google does not always have the best and the most pertinent choices for consumers. I am convinced that Google will only move with the threat of a fine, or with the threat of an unbundling regulation.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. European competition policy has failed its objectives by increasing pressure on SMEs without preventing the dominance of a few players. It therefore makes most targeted state aid illegal. I therefore voted AGAINST with the entire French delegation.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this report, presented by Mr Messerschmidt by the ECON Commission, on the report presented by the Competition Commissioner. The Resolution assumes the basic postulates of a liberal conception that promotes the free movement of capital and services, all within the framework of TTE.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which, despite not meeting my group's objectives, is some progress, especially in Articles 37 and 40, which highlights the importance of accessibility, sustainability and security of energy supply for the European economy and its competitiveness; obliges the notification of the fossil fuel reserve and potential CO2 emissions in listed companies and those applied for inclusion in the single market; and establishes environmental reporting to ensure a level playing field in the sustainable investment market.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The European political project is based on free movement (of goods, services, capital and people). This is only possible in free and open competition or competition. This policy of competition is at the service of businesses, consumers and society as a whole.  Only if it is efficient and free can it serve as a model for the rest of the world, thus contributing to a global free economy as a model of justice, sustainability and with a focus on SMEs, employment and innovation. I fully support the rapporteur in his proposal to have the current initiatives on competition policy evaluated in order to meet the challenges of globalisation.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This annual report on competition policy is in line with the reports of these predecessors adopted in recent years. As ever, it advocates even more openness to competition, calls for state aid, and calls for more liberalisation, with the aim of the methodical dismantling of what is left of our public services.  In its sights: transport, including rail services and the management of port and airport networks. We would have suspected ... The request for "universal and high quality public services" filed by the GUE/NGL was, of course, rejected in favour of a logic of maximum privatization of profits and socialization of losses. Competition is, by the very nature of the report, placed on a pedestal, described as a "tool to safeguard European democracy". You have to dare to say it and the Greeks among others will appreciate it. Unsurprisingly, I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Comprehensive and detailed report. In the section on transport and postal services, the group's position prevailed. I supported the competition report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The European Parliament has presented an own-initiative report analysing the competition aspects in the European Union.  There are many ideas in the text that the M5S broadly shares, including the need to combat market concentrations, ensure transparent public procurement, and protection against abuses in the financial sector. Particular mention is also made of the necessary competition policies in the energy and transport sectors. Interesting and worthy of support also the parties concerning the agri-food and pharmaceutical sector with references to the distorting power of large-scale distribution and the need for support for the development of the generic drug system.  But that is still not enough. I believe that much can still be done to improve competition at EU level. Further efforts are still needed to create the conditions for effective equality of competitive positions between European countries and to combat both fiscal and social dumping. Progress still needs to be made in the area of taxation, especially in order to ban tax planning and aggressive tax strategies that create distortions between Member States. Secret tax arrangements to shift financial flows by paying minimum taxes, such as the most recent LuxLeaks case, must be strongly denounced.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I have not been able to vote in favour of this report despite containing very positive points because it maintains a worrying approach against public participation in the economy. This report contains many positive points, including the call to end public aid to banking by noting that they have not helped to increase the flow of credit to the real economy; the report condemns the Commission's action with regard to preferred holdings and requires that the territorial consequences of competition policy proceedings be considered, etc. All these positive points are at the same time as the neoliberal approach and contrary to the public sector's participation in the economy of many of the points we cannot share. That is why we have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It was in the name of free competition that the liberalizations and privatizations of strategic sectors of the economy and the advancement of the market on growing spheres of social life were justified. The result was catastrophic. Public monopolies have been replaced by monopolies or private oligopolies. The promises of more competition, better quality and lower price are now a mirage. In the electricity sector, the liberalization and the end of vertical integration of production and distribution in public companies brought increases in energy bills for companies and families. To the same extent that profits and monopolistic rents increased. In transport the picture is similar, with the same public rents guaranteeing private profits. We therefore condemn this false argument of competition, which has only served to weaken national states and fill their pockets with them as always.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because the proposals and improvements it contains are very commendable. MEPs are elected to represent the interests and concerns of their electorate. Competition policy must benefit consumers, businesses and society as a whole. That is why the proposal, for example, that the Commissioners responsible for competition policy must meet meMEs in order to better understand and take account of the concerns of this electorate is only to be supported.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. As a SPÖ-EU delegation, we voted unanimously against Mr Messerschmidt's report on EU competition policy. There are two main reasons for this: firstly, the report calls on the Commission to continue to tackle the dismantling of state-owned railway undertakings. This means further liberalisation and privatisation. We know from experience that this always happens to the detriment of customers. Nor will it bring "fairer competition," as is often claimed, but it will lead to private companies using the most profitable routes and siphoning off profits there. Remote areas will then have to continue to be used by state-affiliated companies to ensure basic services and infrastructure. Contrary to many claims, the prices for customers will certainly rise. Secondly, we wanted to note that the inclusion of investor-state dispute settlement procedures in free trade agreements (e.B. the ISDS procedure in the EU-US Free Trade Agreement (TTIP) deprives Member States of the democratic right to implement their own policies. Nor must there be a two-tier jurisdiction that gives more rights to international corporations than any other company and every citizen. These provisions are certainly not in the interests of the citizens of Austria and Europe, and that is why the SPÖ-EU delegation rejected this report.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the annual report on competition policy in the European Union. In particular, I find the inclusion of a paragraph referring to social dumping very satisfactory, a long-term issue which must necessarily be addressed in order to ensure the proper functioning of the labour market. I will conclude by emphasising the need to fill the democratic deficit in competition policy in the Union by guaranteeing the European Parliament the power of codecision in these matters as soon as possible.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the vote, I supported Parliament's annual report on EU competition policy because it stresses that effective and innovation-based competitiveness contributes not only to the faster recovery of the entire European Union from the crisis, but also to strengthen its global and global market power. I also welcome the important role of the European Parliament in promoting competition policy, highlighted by the rapporteur. However, I would like to stress that I do not share the views expressed in a number of paragraphs of the report and the concerns about so-called 'social dumping', which distort the Single Market in the European Union. That is why, shortly in the Committee on Transport, we have initiated a debate with Theisseen and the Commissioner for Transport, Mr Tísoen, in the Committee on Transport, to explain together what everyone understands with this concept of social dumping and to analyse the real impact of social dumping on the single European market, where it is in fact often used as a universal argument for not opening up the market for services, in particular transport, to free competition. By excluding car carriers from other Member States of the European Union in one of the countries, a protectionist policy is essentially being developed that prevents not only the full potential of the European Union's internal market, but in fact the internal market is fragmented and facilitated by progress towards social fragmentation.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This annual report praises the Single Market, the open market and free competition. Although it is punctuated here and there with aspects that we support and which cannot be denied or hidden, such as criticism of state aid to the banking sector, tax fraud in the EU and its component in competition policy, the recognition of the existence of cartels and the need to combat them, which insists on pursuing the EU's competition policy with all its consequences. This report even calls for these policies to be deepened in the EU, notably by calling for the liberalisation of sectors such as transport, health, industry and energy, advocating for a chapter on competition rules in the TTIP in the digital single market. We voted against it.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I voted against the report of the European Central Bank because I do not believe that your actions deserve the defence and democratic legitimacy of this Parliament. The European Central Bank's mission should be to support States in their mission to relaunch the economy, supporting public debt issues and the stability of savers' deposits in markets. Instead, Mr Draghi feeds new financial bubbles with one hand while with the other he shuts down the credit tap on those States whose governments are fighting for the social rights of the working majority. The method is more discreet than Mr Trichet's letters, in which he called for cuts or tough labor reforms, but no less determined or brutal. With their votes today, the majority parties demonstrate, once again, that they prefer the closeness of finance to solidarity with the European people.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this report highlighted the aspects that have characterised the work and actions of the Central Bank in recent years. The unconventional monetary policy measures it has used are welcome. I believe that, in addition to price stability, objectives such as growth and employment must be one of the ECB's priorities.  Of course, all this is not enough: economic policy measures must of course be accompanied by structural reforms for investment. The publication of the Governing Council minutes also seems to me to be a positive sign: at a time when citizens are distrustful, if not bitterly, of the institutions, it was necessary to give a strong signal of transparency.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted against the ECB's 2013 annual report because the report accepts and welcomes the fact that the European Central Bank has now become a state in state. This is clearly shown in the case of Greece, as Draghi, in breach of the Treaty, has a blackmail policy towards the Greek people. At the same time, I would like to thank colleagues who voted in favour of the amendment I tabled en masse. By voting in favour of this amendment, the European Parliament is calling for an end to the conflict of interest that exists within the functioning of the European Central Bank, as it now considers that the ECB cannot be a member of the troika and at the same time carry out its duties as an independent monetary authority, and this development is an important step in order to throw the troika out of our country. , Greece, thus vindicating the vote of the Greek people in the elections of 25 January. The credit suffocation imposed by Draghi on Greece will not pass. The fight continues.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na moltaí go léir anseo le mo ghrúpa agus leis an tuarascáil agus bhí áthas orm é sin a dhéanamh mar bhí mé anseo an oíche a chuir an tUachtarán Draghi a thuarascáil bhliantúil s ár gcomhair. Is trua an rud é go raibh air imeacht leath slí tríd an tuarascáil sin agus an díospóireacht sin ach ag an am céanna caithfear creidiúint a thabhairt dó as ucht an dea-jab atá déanta aige. Labhair sé an oíche sin faoi éascú cainníochtúil. Tá sé sin tugtha isteach aige anois agus tá fáilte curtha roimis go forleathan agus is maith sin. Caithfidh mé a rá freisin go bhfuil capall ráis ag rith in Cheltenham an tseachtain seo darb ainm di Quantitiveeasing. Tá cúpla euro agam ar an gcapall sin. Tá súil agam go mbeidh an bua ag an gcapall, go mbeidh an bua ag Draghi le héascú cainníochtúil agus go bhfeabhsóidh rudaí san Aontas dá bharr.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I also wish my colleague to make an investment, but with regard to this report, which deals with the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report, I would like to take the opportunity to speak here to support the actions of the European Central Bank.  It has taken a rather bold course in trying to eliminate the huge risks that deflationary developments entail, which may indeed fall into a certain spiral, which would then be very, very difficult for the European Union and its monetary policy.  So, even though it is about pumping quite a huge amount of money into the economy, I, too, think that this kind of deflationary threat is so serious that these actions by the European Central Bank deserve support from all those who are serious about the European Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the positive view of this report on the activity of the European Central Bank, whose monetary policy is deepening the economic crisis and disparities between EU Member States. The ECB develops a policy that considers only the interests of large financial corporations and speculative capital, in the face of the unanswerable need for real expansion monetary policy to give a boost to the European economy. The ECB continues to develop, in a totally discretionary manner, a policy that increases disparities in the EU, without democratic control from which we will not be able to emerge from the crisis. This report continues along the line of the majority groups in the European Parliament that approve the bank's management and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: Writing. I welcome the ECB's rapid response in view of the serious situation and the fact that monetary policy has focused on reducing tensions in financial markets within the euro area and restoring investor confidence in the single currency.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)
text: In writing. This annual report does not focus on reshaping the role of the Central Bank, failing to criticize the legitimacy and effectiveness of its action. The ECB's response times to deflationary risk are not justifiable and the report does not describe any of the reasons for this. The overhaul of banking regulations in the euro area is also not being deepened, while European banks, having jeopardised national economies through their activities, their irresponsibility in the management of private funds and the risks taken in risky market transactions without solid levels of equity, are still not sufficiently involved in the refinancing of the real economy. Finally, the ECB's action is still so disconnected from national economic realities and supranational monetary policy does not meet the needs of the economy and the imperatives of reducing public debt. I voted against this report which proves the difficulties of the ECB in reforming itself and justifying the relevance of its strategies.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report encourages the ECB to support TEN-T; I consequently voted against it as a UKIP MEP. There was a case for abstaining (as the UK is not a member of the eurozone) but I did not do so because the UK is still affected by ECB actions.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because I agree with the conclusions of this report.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
