text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to evaluate the European Central Bank's annual report for 2013. The EU's unemployment rate reached a high level in 2013 and the eu's overall economic situation is still very difficult. The unemployment rate increased from 11.3% at the end of 2012 to 12.1% at the end of 2013. Despite the fiscal consolidation reforms undertaken by Member States to increase investor confidence, no changes in growth or employment have been observed. It is worrying that the social situation has deteriorated significantly in countries affected by the crisis. I support the proposals to enable Member States to revitalise public and private investment, to carry out appropriate structural reforms in order to restore a business-friendly environment. I believe that, in the context of the implementation of the European Commission's President, Mr President-C.- Juncker's proposed €300 billion investment stimulus package would make a significant contribution to the ECB's policy efforts to boost employment and growth in Europe.

name: Nicolas Bay (NI)
text: In writing. The very existence of the ECB is contrary to the principle of monetary sovereignty to which I am attached. The 2013 balance sheet is only a reflection of the policy of confiscating our monetary independence.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This text assessed the activity of the European Central Bank for 2013. During this period, unemployment in the euro area reached 12% and euro area GDP fell by 0.4%. An important point of this text is to recall the difficulty of SMEs in accessing credit, especially in the countries of southern Europe.   We are at a turning point, an economically low period with little inflation. The ECB must therefore put in place measures to revive the economy.  We must remain cautious because the recovery remains weak and will still be in 2015 and 2016. Inflation will remain below 2%.

name: Dominique Bilde (NI)
text: In writing. This ECB report, which is surprised at the sluggishness of the eurozone economy, aims to save the euro at all costs even if it means sacrificing the Member States.  Unfortunately, the rescue of the single currency is not without consequences for the fiscal policies of the States since it contributes to a cure of austerity and a risk of deflation by contracting domestic demand. The European Union must understand that the euro is a currency unsuitable for such different economies and can only lead people to ever more austerity and precariousness.  It is becoming more than urgent for nations to regain their national currencies in order to revive growth. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support with my vote the report on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2013. Having denied them for years, this report finally acknowledges some of the problems caused by the euro. However, instead of drawing the necessary conclusions and proposing a revision of this wrong currency, the rapporteur proposes solutions in the name of 'more Europe' and leaves the voices of 5 million young people who are out of work, families who do not arrive at the end of the month and businesses in crisis unheeded. The problem is economic and monetary union itself and I will continue to fight against it for our citizens and our territories.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution since the final report contains the amendments tabled by the Spanish Socialist delegation which note the serious economic situation in Europe, particularly worrying about unemployment, and support for the shift towards a more expansive monetary policy given by the European Central Bank, which has helped to build confidence in the euro area and the single currency. The economic situation remains worrying, due to the combination of flat growth and very low inflation, even with signs of deflation, hence the need to create conditions for an uptick in investment in the euro area, both public and private in order to cope with the lacerating unemployment figures, especially youth. In this regard, the ECB is encouraged to take into account in its balance sheet expansion policy the acquisition of obligations for the financing of EI projects, which cover some of the most productive investments in the euro area, in particular those relating to projects which, having undergone a cost-benefit analysis, have been selected by the Commission for providing European added value and projects related to the digital single market.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament assessed the Annual Report of the European Central Bank. The European Parliament welcomes the swift reaction of the European Central Bank, given the extremely difficult economic and financial circumstances, and the fact that monetary policy was aimed at reducing tensions in euro area financial markets and restoring investor confidence in the single currency. Parliament also welcomes the work of the European Central Bank for its readiness to do whatever it takes to preserve the euro currency and the euro area. It is to be hoped that credit provided by the European Central Bank to European banks will benefit the real economy and investing companies, i.e. that they will create stable and quality jobs and ensure a transition to a greener economy. The European Parliament considers monetary policy to be an important driver of the European Union's economy and should therefore be used by the European Central Bank to provide liquidity to the EU's real economy, increase demand, stimulate quality investment and create sustainable jobs.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The main message of this report is that the limits of the effectiveness of purely monetary measures in overcoming the crisis have been reached. The European Central Bank has conducted a highly expansionist policy over the past period, but a combination of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and public and private investment is needed to exit the crisis.  I welcome the ECB's swift response in very complex circumstances and the fact that monetary policy is aimed at reducing the level of stress in financial markets in the eurozone and restoring investor confidence in the single currency.  The good news is that there has been a positive general decline in yields from long-term domestic bonds, especially in the most indebted countries in the eurozone, to levels not seen since the crisis began. However, low yields have not led to job creation and growth and this poses a threat to financial stability.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report. Indeed, this institution is contrary to the principle of monetary sovereignty, the facts of which show us that it is paramount in this period of economic turmoil. The European Central Bank's 2013 annual report reflects the policy of confiscating our independence.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Central Bank Annual Report 2013 because I think that this is important to underline the necessity of continuing a policy which is supporting the European economy and consequently the growth in Europe, as it has been doing in 2013.

name: Steeve Briois (NI)
text: In writing. The European Central Bank's report reflects the European Union's inability to propose a lasting exit from the crisis. Indeed, the ECB has tapped into its last resources by deciding to lower its key interest rates to boost household and business borrowing and restore export competitiveness to our businesses.  Given the very limited effects of this policy, the criticism of the euro single currency has come out strengthened. Yes, the euro area is an area of macroeconomic divergence on the brink of deflation. That is why a concerted exit from the euro single currency with the creation of a common euro currency would restore monetary sovereignty to the Member States so that they adjust their key rates according to the economic conditions.  Finally, challenging the role played by the ECB, I obviously voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2013 because this report presents real and objectively the fact that economic activity continues to be slow, with weak GDP growth in the first three quarters of 2014, and with a high unemployment rate in euro area Member States, which has reached levels that threaten the stability of the euro area and undermine popular and political support for the European project.  The European Central Bank must take into account its expansion policy framework, the EIB project bond balance, which funds some of the more productive investment in the euro area, in particular those projects chosen by the Commission as having A European Added Value after a Cost-Benefit Analysis, in particular the TEN-T energy and transport project and Digital Market projects , but also to ensure that its policies are better adapted to the real economy, especially with regard to SMEs. Growth and public investment are beneficial in complementing the European Central Bank's political efforts to increase employment and economic growth in Europe.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Central Bank is a key institution in the European economic and financial system. The ECB's role is to ensure price stability and thus keep the inflation rate close to but below 2%.  In a context of very low economic growth, this task is extremely complicated. However, the ECB has succeeded in using innovative and unconventional practices to stabilise inflation in the European Union. I obviously welcome these efforts and encourage the ECB to continue in this way.  Good monetary policy like the one the ECB is pursuing is indeed necessary, but it will not be enough to turn around the economies of our countries. Every State must be aware that appropriate structural reforms are more than essential and that monetary policy alone will not be able to improve the economic situation in the Union.  I also welcome the ECB's new role as a banking supervisor. I believe that this decision will increase investor confidence in the European banking sector. This is in tandem with Jean-Claude Juncker's European Commission investment plan.  I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2013. The fragmentation of financial markets is still a fundamental problem holding back the development of the economy and SMEs. The cost to the real economy of these balances is no longer sustainable, as are the distortions of the single market. With explicit reference to financial stability, I welcome the new phase that has opened with the full operation, since November 2014, of the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) entrusted to the ECB. As far as monetary policy is concerned, I can only agree with the ECB's reactive impetus in the face of the critical environment. I am also pleased to note that the ECB is buying asset-backed securities (ABS) and covered bonds to support the effect of the OMRLT credit facilitation, stressing that the process is important for creating the conditions for a recovery in investment and the real economy.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as this report failed to address with any sincerity the impact that austerity policies have had on both Ireland and indeed across the EU. This report was concerned with the year 2013. The year 2013 was the year during which the Irish Government held the Presidency of the EU. It was also the year in which the Central Statistics Office recorded 250 people a day leaving Irish shores. This widespread emigration was as a direct result of the austerity policies championed by the ECB.  Despite the fact that Ireland makes up 0.9 per cent of the European population and 1.2 per cent of the EUʼs GDP, the Irish people have paid over 42 per cent of the European banking crisis. Every individual in Ireland will pay EUR 9 000 each. The average that citizens across the EU will pay is EUR 192 per capita. The ECB still continues to fail to acknowledge the role that it played in bailing out the Irish banks. It is simply not good enough to continue to abdicate responsibility. The Irish people need and deserve answers and so do other citizens across the EU.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report goes a long way in showing the very good job the European Central Bank is doing. We must also keep in mind, that despite the ECB’s best efforts at enhancing growth in the EU; this remains a great challenge that we must all persevere to overcome. This Annual Report clearly shows that the ECB is in touch with the needs of the banking sector, but this is not enough and much more needs to be done. One such measure that could go a long way to meeting this challenge is the capital markets union that is currently being discussed. Europe must advance from banking finance to private equity in order to support the creative ideas of entrepreneurship in Europe. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to develop a truly effective monetary policy, a complete restructuring of the banking system would be necessary, which separates credit activity from financial activity, in order to restore the system itself to its true function, namely to guarantee credit to the real economy. Fiscal harmonisation and economic governance, which is lacking, and which the ECB is trying to make up for, would also be necessary. However, its interventions to combat deflation are not enough in a context of austerity, in which asept fiscal constraints and financial stability continue to prevail over the real needs of the real economy and the citizens. The quantitative easing promoted at the last by the ECB is certainly not a sufficient measure in this respect and my vote on the annual report is therefore negative.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because I cannot endorse the results of an institution whose legitimacy I also dispute. Indeed, the very existence of the European Central Bank is an attack on the principle of monetary sovereignty. Beyond that, the ECB's 2013 balance sheet reflects the policy of confiscating our independence: the direction of our monetary policy is thus decided by a perfectly illegitimate Board of Governors, whose President, Mario Draghi, does not hesitate to affirm at the beginning of this annual report: "The realization by governments of further decisive progress in the establishment of a banking union will restore confidence in the financial system".  Like the other EU institutions, the ECB is therefore caught in the eyes of the ideology of the United States of Europe, even though the euro crisis has demonstrated the failure of forced monetary convergence. A report guided by dogmatism that every patriotic MEMBER had to oppose.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought I voted in favour of the measure, although I do not deny concerns about the continuing fall in the inflation rate that has been in place since 2011 and the various inflations between all Member States. Monetary policy aimed at reducing tensions in the various financial markets seeks to restore confidence among the various investors in the single currency. I have considered the ECB's reaction to such a critical context to be optimistic. The overall positive reduction in long-term national returns in the countries with the highest debt calls for a more dynamic economic recovery. The ecb's vision and positive actions in a situation of both low economic growth and continued inflation are to be taken into account and motivated to continue.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I do not deny my concern at the continued fall in the inflation rate in the euro area since 2011 and the differentials in inflation rates between Member States, I welcomed the ECB's rapid reaction to an extremely critical environment, such as the current one, as well as the fact that monetary policy has been geared towards reducing the level of tension in the euro area financial markets and restoring investor confidence in the euro area. the single currency. I am confident about the future economic recovery thanks to the overall reduction in long-term national returns, particularly in the most indebted countries in the euro area, which have fallen to unprecedented levels since the beginning of the crisis. I therefore voted in favour of the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report, especially in the hope that the quantitative easing programme that is taking place in recent weeks will bear fruit.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Central Bank's annual report for 2013 as it presents a comprehensive review of monetary policy actions aimed at trying to reduce the level of tension on the financial markets and seek to restore investor confidence. The fragmentation of financial markets and the high level of unemployment are still a fundamental problem to be eliminated by consolidating good governance. I believe that it is of the utmost importance to create a resumption of public and private investment, to encourage the introduction of liquids into the system and to promote a fiscal union in order to have less taxation and to have a more competitive market. All EU Member States must commit themselves to ising appropriate structural reforms in order to restore a growth-friendly environment, safeguard price stability, promote sustainable social and economic progress and full employment, improve inclusion and optimise business conditions.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which welcomes the actions of the European Central Bank (ECB) in a situation of low growth and inflation. On the other hand the report also warns of the need to remain vigilant about these policies. The report stresses the importance of having the right mix of policies between monetary policy, fiscal policies and structural reforms. The report has also expressed concern about the level of public and private investment in the euro area which has remained relatively low. Attention has also been drawn towards the social situation which has deteriorated sharply, especially in countries hit by the crisis.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Every year the European Parliament, through an own-initiative report, gives an assessment of the ECB's monetary policy. This report, which covers the 2013 ECB Annual Report, also introduces a section dedicated to financial stability, in the light of the ecb's new single supervisory function last November. The text contains many appreciations of the ECB's unconventional monetary policy interventions, in particular the LTRO programmes, the securitised assets purchase plan and the recent quantitative easing programme, as well as continuous references to the need to continue along the path of structural reforms and fiscal consolidation.  In committee, the M5S voted against the report because it was considered unbalanced in highlighting only the positive side to the work of the ECB and the current system of economic governance. I find unacceptable the total lack of critical reflection on the management of the eurozone crisis and an objective analysis of the insignificant impact that monetary policy interventions have had on the real economy. For the above reasons, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since its main message is that monetary policy alone is reaching its limits, even if we support the expansionary approach taken by the ECB. It also suggests that we need the right policy mix of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and public and private investments.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report looks at the European Central Bank's (ECB) annual report for 2013 and welcomes the ECB's determination to be pragmatic in saving the euro and its responsiveness in a particularly difficult context. It is worrying to note that economic activity in the euro area remains relatively apathetic and there is a real risk of deflation in the euro area. This situation, accompanied by high unemployment rates in many euro area Member States, threatens the stability of the euro area.  This validates the current political direction of the European Commission, which I support, namely the creation of the conditions for a revival of investment, both public and private, through structural reforms within the Member States and through the implementation of the Juncker plan. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Annual Report of the European Central Bank is an important opportunity for reflection on economic and monetary policy within the European institutions. With regard to monetary policy in 2013, the lowering of the reference rate and the start of unconventional monetary policies failed to revive growth on the continent. These measures have not led to the hoped-for increase in credit to households and businesses, not least because of austerity policies. Today, we have the opportunity to learn from this lesson, and we can overcome this model, through a new European policy that looks to growth. In order to achieve this objective, a greater commitment by the European institutions is needed to promote long-term investment in a social and environmentally friendly dimension. I therefore consider the report to be a balanced text, which emphasises the social dimension of the economy and the need for more growth in Europe.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The report on the European Central Bank's activity during 2013 focuses on monetary policy on the one hand and financial stability on the other. In a difficult economic context marked by sluggish growth, unemployment still at a high level and in the face of the risk of deflation, the report considers it crucial to create the conditions for a revival of both public and private investment in the euro area and welcomes the introduction of the new instruments - a single supervisory mechanism and a single resolution mechanism - to ensure greater financial stability.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While some amendments on the investment environment and financial stability of the banking union were adopted, my Group abstained during the committee vote due to concerns that the report welcomes the ECB’s readiness to ‘do whatever it takes to save the euro’ and called for the ECB to explore unconventional monetary policy measures in the event of an excessively lengthy period of low inflation, which could see the ECB over-stepping its remit. For that reason I abstained on the final vote.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report presented to the European Parliament does not seek to reshape the role of the Central Bank, failing to criticise the legitimacy and effectiveness of its action. The ECB's response times to deflationary risk are not justifiable and the report does not describe any of the reasons for this. The overhaul of banking regulations in the euro area is also not being deepened, while European banks, having jeopardised national economies through their activities, their irresponsibility in the management of private funds and the risks taken in risky market transactions without solid levels of equity, are still not sufficiently involved in the refinancing of the real economy. Finally, the ECB's action is still so disconnected from national economic realities and supranational monetary policy does not meet the needs of the economy and the imperatives of reducing public debt.  I voted against this report which proves the difficulties of the ECB in reforming itself and justifying the relevance of its strategies.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this motion for a resolution because I am against ecb-led policy. I'm against her way of participating in the threesome. I am against it because it does not conduct a policy driven by economic or financial decisions or arguments, but has become a political tool, which is far from its familiar role. I am opposed because ECB-led policy not only has not led to gdp growth, but quite the opposite – during this reporting period we have seen not growth, but a decline. I am against it because despite the ECB-led policy, unemployment is not falling, and on the contrary, we are seeing an increase not only in overall but also in youth unemployment. At the same time, we argue that it is a problem that we try with all allowed levers to solve. I am also opposed because it is this policy, plus the fall in the price of oil, that will lead all of our countries to deflation, from which we will come out very difficult and with great effort. The report is very nicely written, but the reality from the outside is different. And the ECB can be accused of being sympathetic to the problem, that it is part of the problem.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the granting of additional independence privileges granted to the ECB and its intended disengagement from control mechanisms (e.g. troika) will exacerbate arbitrariness in taking important (for the peoples of Europe) decisions.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report on the activities of the European Central Bank, noting with regret the lack of any critical reflection on the current economic crisis situation and therefore on the person responsible for the ECB's mismanagement. We know that even unconventional measures such as quantitative easing run the serious risk of not benefiting the thousands of European micro-enterprises and therefore the real economy, but rather in favour of the usual speculative finance lobbies.  I therefore believe that without a serious fight against speculation and without the intention to achieve fiscal harmonisation, but rather by pushing more and more on austerity policies, the goal of exiting the crisis is a long way off and the ecb's actions can only reveal it as the executioner of millions of European citizens.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report, which has been playing a key role in stabilising financial markets in the euro area, particularly in countries most exposed to over-indebtedness. I also support its action, which will be essential as a tool to control the deflationary trends that threaten the debt reduction programmes of several Member States and to create the conditions for the resumption of investment and economic growth in the euro area, in particular by making use of the flexibility in the provisions of the Stability and Growth Pact.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the ECB's action because it recognises the danger of deflation and supports monetary stimulus policy. In this regard, although the decision is subsequent to the reference period of the report, I welcome the expanded programme of purchase of assets, including public debt, announced by the ECB on 22 January 2015. However, monetary union is not sound in the long term if it is not accompanied by an economic, fiscal and budgetary union, capable of compensating for the macroeconomic shocks that occur in that union, which in turn requires a federal political union.  As Mr Draghi explained, integration based on common institutions, such as currency, is more effective than that structured through rules, such as the Stability and Growth Pact. Concrete steps must therefore be taken to create a tax capacity of the euro area, fueled by taxes such as the rate on international financial transactions, and with the capacity to sustain a Treasury issuing euro-denominated public debt, which in turn would contribute to increasing the liquidity and financial stability of the monetary union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the activity of the European Central Bank in 2013 represents full proof of the complete failure of the ECB's monetary policy. It failed in forecasts of economic growth and inflation. It has failed in all measures aimed at controlling inflation and injecting liquidity into the economy, whether in setting these interest rates or in the various bank refinancing operations. Nothing is said about the growing power of the ECB. No suggestion is made of the sense of questioning the legitimacy of this institution. We strongly disagree with the report's praise of ECB policy and particularly the Banking Union, which represents another step in amputating key portions of state sovereignty and concentrating power in the hands of large financial capital through institutions at its service, such as the ECB – which manages and oversees the financial sector in the EU at the same time.  We continue to advocate a profound change in the ECB's statutes, ensuring that states have political control and their presence on an equal footing in their direction. In the name of supposed independence, the ECB is entirely dependent on financial capital.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Central Bank has recently focused on reducing the level of tensions in financial markets and restoring investor confidence in the euro single currency. However, European economic activity is still weak and lacklustre and has seen negative GDP growth for the second year in a row, which is also linked to the continued decline in the inflation rate and the persistent diversities between Member States. However, it is encouraging that the European Central Bank confirms its readiness to use unconventional instruments within its mandate and to combat low inflation. The European Central Bank must continue to use its credibility to support the European banking system.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (NI)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report, which identifies only because some problems are now enormous and almost irreversible, but which always depend on the same macro problem, which we do not want to tackle here: economic and monetary union.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report as the granting of additional independence privileges granted through it to the ECB and its intended disengagement from control mechanisms (e.g. troika) will increase arbitrariness in taking important (for the people of Europe) decisions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECB Annual Report for 2013 is an instrument that expresses the accountability of the ECB to the European Parliament. The ECB is an independent institution but its actions are evaluated by Parliament through constant dialogue. The ECB’s actions prevented the collapse of the banking system and developed a climate of confidence in international markets with the consequent lowering of the cost of funding for the euro area. The report highlights these results and underlines the remaining challenges that characterise the euro area, such as low inflation and a high unemployment rate. For these reasons I voted in favour of the ECB Annual Report 2013.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. During 2014 we have witnessed a great deal of activity on the part of the ECB, which has helped to stabilize the European economy and avoid major ills. This institution must continue to help, more quickly, lay the foundations for sustainable and inclusive economic growth that will allow us to return to the path of growth and job creation. The ECB's start of monetary buying and selling operations (WTO) must in my view be seen as an element aimed at consolidating the economic recovery. However, States should not regard this instrument as an element that allows them to avoid the necessary structural reforms. Indeed, today more than ever the EU needs a balance between austerity policies and measures to promote economic activity and employment, an aspect in which the ECB can play a key role.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Economic data unfortunately cannot be welcomed, euro area GDP fell by 0.4% in 2013 and unemployment in the euro area rose from 11.3% at the end of 2012 to 11.9% at the end of 2013. However, when assessing the ECB's actions, we cannot fail to point out that, after a past in which too much has been expected to make bold choices, today, thanks to the use of innovative instruments and the announced quantitative easing plan, the data is changing and could be the first signs of a recovery expected for years.  With today's report, we have also sought to highlight two points in particular: our approval of the ecb's words in favour of existing flexibility within the rules on the Stability and Growth Pact, which could be used by Member State governments to express a more growth-friendly budgetary policy and to reduce the tax burden without affecting the budget. , as well as encouraging the ECB to ensure greater harmony of its policies with the real economy, in particular with regard to SMEs.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to vote in favour of the report on the ECB's annual report by my colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. I would particularly like to highlight an important point in the report that has just been adopted: the consolidation of good governance in banks fosters confidence in the banking sector and thus also contributes to financial stability.  It is important to remember this, because in recent years Europe, with the launch of the Banking Union and with the action of the ECB, has taken silent but valuable action aimed at consolidating the foundations of our economy, which we hope will soon also be able to find citizens, consumers and businesses in a tangible way. We now need the will of politics: the Juncker investment plan represents a great opportunity to make this path of new banking governance complementary to a plan for a new productive and social revival.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the ECB report for 2013 given that the main message of this report is that monetary policy alone is reaching its limits. I support the expansionary approach taken by the ECB, but it is crucial that the report stresses that we need to have the right policy mix of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and public and private investments. I furthermore welcome the fact that it underscores the need to have a clearer mandate as lender of last resort to foster growth and employment, instead of just price stability.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI)
text: In writing. The European Central Bank's continued decline in key interest rates since 2013, continued in 2014, is unprecedented. The refinancing rate of private banks has never been lower in Europe, much lower than in the United States. Despite all these facilities, private banks have not played the game: no increase in lending to households and businesses. Rates of these credits remain high compared to other economic indicators.  Another inconsistency of the ECB is that the intermediation between it and the Member States, entrusted to private banks, is borne by the States and therefore by the taxpayers. The report presented ignores a problem too important to remain silent: the european Union's incompetence in implementing a stimulus policy. Above all, it reveals that the policy pursued by the ECB since 2012 was mainly for the benefit of the banking sector. The rescue of the euro was really the rescue of the banks. By refusing to impose a proactive and coherent policy on these banks on credit and interest rates, the ECB has voluntarily prolonged the economic crisis in the euro area. That is why I voted against it.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the report on the European Central Bank for 2013. The ECB must present an annual report each year setting out the activities of the European System of Central Banks and monetary policy. The report highlights the message that monetary policy alone is reaching its limits and that we need the correct combination of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and public and private investments. A clearer mandate as lender of last resort is needed.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it underlines the crucial role of the European Central Bank and its action on the real economy in times of crisis. It stresses the need to ensure a good balance between the use of monetary, fiscal and structural reforms in order to return to the path of growth. The ECB has no silver bullet until the Member States, including France, have carried out the necessary structural reforms to make their economies more competitive.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Central Bank (ECB) should work on the model of the Deutsche Bundesbank. This was one of the conditions under which the Germans abandoned their Deutschmark. In the meantime, the ECB has degenerated into a copy of the "Banque de France". The political influence on the bank is great, it is fully under the control of the potential "recipient countries" that can easily over-vote the potential donor countries. Not only will the number of donor countries always outperform those of the recipient countries, each country will have the same voting rights in the ECB. Malta and Cyprus have as much to say as Germany and France. That alone makes it impossible to change the indirect redistributive policy that the ECB is now pursuing. Since the announcement by the President of the ECB, the Italian Mario Draghi, that it would buy government bonds on the secondary market at virtually unlimited levels, this institution has been engaged in monetary government financing of non-reformors or incapable states. This is another reason why AfD professors Lucke, Kruse, Starbatty and I announced on 13.2.2015 that they would sue the Federal Government before the Federal Constitutional Court within three months if they refused to take action against the ECB. It goes without saying that I have rejected this annual report.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE)
text: in writing. In favour of the importance, at European level, of the proposed stimulus measures.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Central Bank's annual report for 2013 taking into account the contribution to solving the economic crisis, although I believe that the measures used have primarily contributed to reflecting economic stability and there is still a shortage of new jobs, economic activity has slowed, there is a lack of investment both private and public.  The ECB has achieved price stability, but the low level of inflation does not allow growth. Monetary policy measures need to create a condition for the attractiveness of investment in the euro area. I support the ECB's role in safeguarding financial stability and transparency in the bank's decision-making.  Despite President Draghi's view that the existing rules of the Stability and Growth Pact are a sufficiently flexible framework for the application of recovery-boosting measures, I believe that given the economic situation to date, changes need to be made in this regard as well.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, refusing to support the central bank's monetary policy, since it does not criticise its legitimacy or effectiveness. Thus, the lack of reaction to deflationary risk is not explained, nor is the reform of banking regulation deepened. The irresponsible conduct of some European banks, particularly in the management of funds in risky investments, without relying on solid and real funds, is also not underlined. Banks are not required to make a concrete commitment to the real economy.  I voted against this text: the ECB is incapable of reforming itself, and of defining coherent strategies. It continues to be disconnected from national economic realities and supranational monetary policies, thus not meeting the imperatives of reducing public debt.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the ECB's action because it recognises the danger of deflation and supports monetary stimulus policy. Although the decision follows the report's reference period, I welcome the expanded asset purchase programme of approximately EUR 1.2 trillion, including public debt, announced by the ECB on 22 January 2015, which is already having positive effects by lowering the interest on the sovereign bonds of euro area Member States. I am less excited that most of these assets will be acquired by the Eurosystem and not by the ECB, that is, by the national central banks themselves, which puts the credibility and solidarity of monetary union in the solfacy. In any case, the ECB must estimate the profit that this institution and the Eurosystem will make from this transaction. The ECB should also explain the continued maintenance of the official interest rate at 0.05%, as there is scope to further reduce it, which could provide additional stimulus to economic growth and the fight against deflation.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Pablo Zalba Bidegain's report on the ECB's 2013 annual report, which calls on Member States to advance labour market reforms to improve competitiveness, increase potential growth, create new job opportunities, increase flexibility and maximise conditions for businesses to create jobs. In addition, the report notes that the trend towards reduced working hours appears to have reversed at the end of 2013, indicating a possible gradual improvement in the labour market.  This report was adopted by 461 votes, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the European Central Bank's (ECB) annual report for 2013. Among its recommendations, the report encourages the ECB to maintain favourable conditions for investment and economic activity, as well as to combat the risks of deflation in euro area countries. I welcome its adoption.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as amongst other things, it calls on the ECB to remain vigilant on its policies of low growth and inflation and to adopt the right mix of monetary policies, fiscal policies and structural reform. I support these actions and therefore support this report.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported Mr McDerman's report. Pablo Zalba Bidegain as I share the assessment of the measures and initiatives set out in the Annual Report of the European Central Bank. I would remind you, in fact, that in 2013 the ECB operated in a rather critical economic scenario, characterised by low growth and inflation. In this context, the ECB has worked well, implementing monetary and fiscal policies in the direction of the EU's exit from the crisis and economic growth.

name: Marine Le Pen (NI)
text: In writing. The annual report presented to the European Parliament does not reshape the role of the Central Bank, failing to criticise the legitimacy and effectiveness of its action. The ECB's response times to deflationary risk are not justifiable and the report does not describe any of the reasons for this. The overhaul of banking regulations in the euro area is also not being deepened, while European banks, having jeopardised national economies through their activities, their irresponsibility in the management of private funds and the risks taken in risky market transactions without solid levels of equity, are still not sufficiently involved in the refinancing of the real economy.  Finally, the ECB's action is still so disconnected from national economic realities and supranational monetary policy does not meet the needs of the economy and the imperatives of reducing public debt.  I voted against this report which proves the difficulties of the ECB in reforming itself and justifying the relevance of its strategies.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. As a full member of the Occupation Committee, I was shadow rapporteur of this Committee's Opinion on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank 2013. Although not all of our demands have been taken into account, joint work with the Committee on the Economy has highlighted with figures the difficult economic situation, as well as softening enthusiasm for so-called structural reforms as a growth factor, which has been reflected in the resolution's final commitments.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because of its positive view of the activity of the European Central Bank, whose monetary policy is deepening the economic crisis and disparities between EU Member States. The ECB develops a policy that only considers the interests of large financial corporations and speculative capital, in the face of the unanswerable need to support state funding to give a boost to the European economy. The ECB continues to develop, in a totally discretionary manner and beyond democratic control, a policy that favors financial bubbles while pushing for neoliberal reforms with the threat of closing the liquidity of the financial system and the public debt markets of those states reluctant to do so. This report continues along the line of the majority groups in the European Parliament that approve the bank's management and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the EU policy, which considers the redistribution of money to be the solution to the economic crisis. By taking money from one group of citizens, handing it over to another, and believing that politicians will redistribute it correctly, states are only leading to a deepening of the crisis. The only way to prosper is to cut taxes, make the whole system more transparent, and allow business without bureaucracy and regulation.

name: Dominique Martin (NI)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which opens doors by denouncing various problems of the euro, but only because they have become too obvious to continue to be concealed. This report suggests even more recourse to inadequate solutions for more Europe when this is precisely the cause of the problem. Finally, the very existence of the European Central Bank is contrary to the principle of monetary sovereignty that we defend.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that this report encourages the ECB to consider in its balance sheet expansion policy the buying of EIB project bonds, which fund some of the more productive investments in the euro area, particularly from those projects chosen by the Commission as having European added value after a cost-benefit analysis, especially TEN-T projects in energy and transport and projects related to the digital single market.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. In a context of such crises, despite high levels of unemployment, negative or zero GDP growth, a very low inflation rate with deflationary risks, the ECB's monetary policy has nevertheless succeeded in restoring a minimum of confidence in financial markets and investors in the euro area. Investment policies are therefore good, but we need a greater connection with the real economy to limit the fragmentation of markets and, above all, to support small and medium-sized enterprises that need a specific programme for access to credit. The report, for which I voted in favour, therefore welcomes the ECB's actions in a situation of low growth and low inflation, but warns that it remains vigilant about these policies.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a fairly critical economic environment of sluggish growth and persistent inflation, the ECB has promoted monetary and fiscal policies and structural reforms. By agreeing with these measures as a whole, I have decided to give my assent to the report on the Annual Report of the Central Bank. I believe that, during 2013, the European Institute governed by Draghi effectively fulfilled its prerogatives, and its mission.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Central Bank's 2013 annual report does not seriously assess the failure of monetary policy that the ECB has played. All forecasts for economic growth and inflation have failed roundly. All measures and instruments used to control inflation and inject liquidity into the economy have failed. Moreover, the ECB's report still does not respond to the political role that the Central Bank has, nor does it question its legitimacy.  The most surprising thing about all this is that, despite the immense failure, the report praises the ECB's role during the crisis and only refers to the "less positive" aspects of its performance. In the face of this political washing, we are voting against it.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2012 Annual Report on the European Central Bank highlights the progress that has been made towards improving stability in the euro area thanks to the ECB's rapid reaction, although it also points to some remaining threats that we consider necessary to tackle, such as the fact that economic activity remains too weak or the fall in the inflation rate , in addition to the high unemployment rate. My support, therefore, for the report prepared by Mr Pablo Zalba, who also recalls that monetary policy alone cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless it is complemented by appropriate fiscal policies and national structural reforms, on which we must all work.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the ECB was unable to achieve its specific objectives, which makes it impossible to assess these objectives. That is why I could not vote for or against the report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report in which the European Parliament evaluates the Annual Report of the European Central Bank and makes concrete proposals in the field of monetary policy and financial stability. These measures should help to maintain a strong and stable EU currency, the euro, prevent distortions of business conditions and depreciation of private savings and pensions, enable public and private investment in the euro area to revitalise and address long-term problems faced by small and medium-sized enterprises when trying to obtain credit.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report generally welcomes the ECB's action in 2013. And in particular the stabilization of Target II's imbalances, in other words its financial coup imposed on Cyprus.  The report even rejects any responsibility for the continuation of the crisis by urging us not to "overestimate the impact on the real economy of the unconventional monetary policy measures currently employed". This monetary policy is designed only in the service of austerity in order to "give Member States time to clean up their public finances and implement the necessary structural reforms".  Finally, if the report asks the ECB to "take on a less important role within the troika", it is of course to "increase its independence from political decisions". I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The ECB was instrumental in responding to the financial crisis. With its rapid reaction to a very difficult context, and the fact that its monetary policy aimed to reduce the level of tension in the euro area financial markets and restore investor confidence in the single currency. The ECB has made great readiness to do everything necessary to save the euro.   More needs to be done to reflect the ECB's behaviour in the economy as a general and to be responsible for starting economic growth and job creation.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because of its support for the European Central Bank’s rapid response to the challenging and changing economic environment. The European Central Bank’s measures to maintain investors’ confidence in the euro and its efforts to do all that it can to save the euro are welcome.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The policy of the European Central Bank plays a crucial role in the exit from the financial crisis that has affected the whole of Europe. It helps to maintain price stability in the euro area and thus stabilize inflation. It is responsible for the prudential supervision of credit institutions established in the euro area, thus contributing to the security and soundness of the banking system and to the stability of the financial system in the European Union and in each Member State of the euro area. It is worth remembering that Mario Draghi's plan to counter the collapse of the monetary union should be welcomed. Above all, it is a question of trying to return to inflation close to 2%.  Finally, it should be stressed that there is a real transparent dialogue between Parliament and the ECB. Indeed, the President of the ECB presents the institution's annual report in plenary session and takes part in a regular monetary dialogue with the Committee on Economic Affairs.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the main message of this report, which is that monetary policy alone is reaching its limits, even if we support the expansionary approach taken by the ECB, and that we need the right policy mix of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and public and private investments.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Fact: since Mr Draghi became ECB President in 2011, the ECB has become a much wiser policy tool for saving Europe from its worst nightmare. Things that were impossible beforehand because they were defying certain orthodoxies became ‘common currency. And it works.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution on the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report confronts with ruthless openness the problems of the European economy: low growth, rising unemployment (including catastrophic unemployment for young people), the threat to employment and welfare targets, the insufficient impact of interest rate cuts on lending, looming deflation, stagnant investment, fragmentation of European financial markets. Since, in my opinion, he favours one possible means of dealing with all these problems, the deepening of integration, I support the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (NI)
text: In writing. 2014 was a hot topic for the European Central Bank. It is therefore somewhat offbeat to formulate a political opinion on its 2013 report in March 2015. The Bidegain report itself is largely outside the framework and comments on the ECB's recent actions. He is insufficiently critical of the policy and the cost of supporting the single currency.  The ECB has exhausted the weapon of rates (reduced to historic lows in September), then unconventional tools (TLTRO and ABS launched in 2014, quantitative easing initiated at the beginning of 2015) without succeeding in reviving economic growth. In addition, within the framework of the banking union, the ECB has resumed supervision of systemic institutions, thus depriving states of their supervisory power. The euro area, which the ECB represents, is more than ever an area of macroeconomic divergence. The ECB has not only failed to revive European economies, but has not been able to fulfil its mandate of price stability (risk of deflation) and convergence of economies.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Central Bank (ECB) cut its key rates in May and again in November, reducing the rate of core refinancing operations to 0.25. The European monetary authority has also decided to start buying primary bonds, contributing decisively to the reduction of the long-term rates that Member States have to pay when isising bonds. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the ECB, in particular the team of governors led by Mario Draghi, did everything in its power to save the Single European Currency and bring stability to the Eurozone. I also see it as essential for the ECB to continue to carry out its debt purchase programme and should pay greater attention to the stability of inflation which is currently negative and affects the competitiveness of the European Union.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. The report welcomes the European Central Bank's willingness to sacrifice the economies of euro area countries to save the euro and is then surprised by the sluggish economic activity in the euro area. However, it is precisely the rescue of the single currency that leads the European and national institutions to adopt an "austere" legal framework, without any academic basis. It would be wrong to isolate monetary policy. Indeed, fiscal policy, which is conducted, itself fuels the risk of deflation since it contracts domestic demand.  A more expansive economic policy risks leading to a situation of "fiscal dominance" and the impossibility of getting out of it at the risk of causing a major economic crisis.  Moreover, the asset quality review did not test the impact of deflation on banks' balance sheets.  The economic inanity of the single currency must therefore be acted upon by providing for a transition to a common currency with annual adjustment of monetary parities.  So I voted against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it argues that we need the right mix of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and public and private investments. In addition, monetary policy alone is reaching its limits even if we support the expansionary approach taken by the ECB.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the ECB's 2013 annual report. The text welcomes the latest measures adopted by the ECB to promote the financing of SMEs and to boost economic activity in Europe.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the adoption of this annual report, we intend to underline the importance of the ECB's rapid reaction to an increasingly unstable and fragmented economic and financial environment. While we consider it essential to use this new monetary policy stance in order to reduce the level of tension on the financial markets of the euro area and to restore investor confidence in the single currency, we believe that the expansionary approach alone is not enough to resolve the situation.  It will be essential to promote a fair mix of fiscal consolidation policies, appropriate structural reforms and the stimulus for new private investment. We are also convinced that, given the prospect of further accommodative policies such as quantitative easing, and bearing in mind the current legal challenges relating to the MTO programme, it is essential to ensure clarity and legal certainty so that these instruments can be implemented effectively. Finally, we call on the Member States to create the necessary conditions for a resumption of both public and private investment, by implementing appropriate structural reforms capable of restoring a business-friendly environment.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it gives a fair picture of the economic situation in the euro area in the post-crisis period and the reforms needed to revive growth.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Central Bank submits an annual report containing the activities of the European System of Central Banks and monetary policy, both for the year under review and for the current year. This report reveals that despite the crisis situation, high levels of unemployment and zero GDP growth, the ECB's monetary policy has nonetheless succeeded in restoring confidence in financial markets and investors in the euro area. The report welcomes the ecb's actions, but is ready to remain vigilant on such policies. Unconventional monetary policy measures are a necessary but not sufficient condition for dealing with the macroeconomic problems facing us.  In the light of the above, I have decided to support Mr Bidegain's report because I fully agree with its substance.  I believe, in fact, that monetary policy measures should be placed in a broader context, in an appropriate policy mix focusing on investment policies, structural reforms and an ability to create budgetary consolidation that is not pro-cyclical, but effectively allied with growth.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this annual report on the work of the European Central Bank for 2013. The ECB has demonstrated its ability in recent years to manage the crisis and respond to the financial problems of Member States and/or the euro area. I hope that in the future the ECB's work will be even more sustained and creative in support of job creation and the development of European entrepreneurship.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI)
text: Writing. The Annual Report of the European Central Bank 2013 provides a good overview of the ECB's activities. In principle, the annual report contains good approaches, but the report is designed in such a way that the ECB's work is not sufficiently critically examined. I expect a more critical or realistic report in the future and have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report. I consider it important for investors to regain confidence in the single currency. However, low interest rates have not led to job creation and expected economic growth, and this fact threatens economic stability.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Central Bank's 2013 Annual Report recognises the ECB's work to achieve stability within the euro area and its reaction to the crisis. However, the report also highlights the lack of credit transfer to small and medium-sized enterprises. These have fallen in lending by about 35% between 2008 and 2013, so it is called for a better adjustment of its policies to the real economy. The proposal, while improved, seemed to me to be worthy of approval.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank 2013.  In particular, it is essential to ensure that monetary policy is an effective instrument to reduce tensions in euro area financial markets and restore investor confidence in the single currency. The monetary policy transmission mechanism and the euro area interbank lending market must function smoothly without any obstacles. It is necessary to facilitate the revital ity of public and private investment in the euro area.  It should be noted that the European banking system is still vulnerable. I believe that it would be appropriate to adopt European Union legislation that distinguishes riskier investment activities from traditional banking.  It should be noted that only a properly regulated Capital Markets Union can reduce the over-reliance of euro area economies on the banking system. I also believe that technical and legislative work on the risks associated with public debt should be accelerated.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the 2013 Annual Report of the European Central Bank.  Despite the states' joint commitment to a policy of fiscal consolidation, the economies of EU countries have seen only weak signs of recovery. The figures summarize a reality of unemployment, particularly for young people, difficulties in accessing credit for small and medium-sized enterprises, low levels of investment and low GDP growth. Faced with this critical environment, the ECB reacted quickly, not only through monetary policy aimed at reducing the level of tension in financial markets and restoring investor confidence, but by implementing innovative instruments to restart the state economy, such as the recent Quantitative Easing operation. These measures - unrelated to the ECB's original mandate - are the most tangible sign of Europe's commitment to its members. It is essential that the action of the European Central Bank is accompanied by appropriate reforms and structural policies at national level, in order to maximise the scope of interventions and achieve a significant impact on the real economy of the Member States.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that, according to the Commission services' spring 2014 forecasts, euro area GDP is expected to recover and the Commission services' autumn 2014 forecasts have revised down their growth projections; whereas unemployment in the euro area is expected to remain high in 2014, according to autumn 2014 forecasts; whereas there are significant differences between the unemployment rates of the different Member States and this consequently leads to growing economic divergences between Member States; whereas the reduction in passive interest rates caused by the announcement of the monetary operations programme should not serve as a pretext for Member States to avoid structural reforms aimed at increasing growth potential; whereas in 2013 the European Central Bank (ECB) lowered benchmark interest rates twice; given that the fall in real interest rates has not resulted either in an increase in credit to households and businesses or in GDP growth and job creation, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The euro fell by 0.4% in 2013. According to the autumn forecast, unemployment in the euro area rose from 11.3% at the end of 2012 to 11.9% at the end of 2013 and remained at a high level in 2014. There are significant differences between Member States in unemployment rates, ranging from 5% to 26%. Youth unemployment rates in some Member States reach up to 50%. Of particular concern are the significant fragmentation of lending conditions for SMEs (SMEs) in euro area countries, as well as the gap between SME funding rates and those for larger companies. The measures recently announced by the ECB to stimulate bank lending do not address these long-standing problems, so the ECB should investigate the fundamental factors that make access to SME loans more difficult. The existing flexibility of the Stability and Growth Pact rules can be used to address the weak recovery more efficiently and to make way for the cost of the necessary structural reforms. There is scope to achieve growth-friendly fiscal policies and to reduce the tax burden in a way that would not affect the budget. Complementary action at EU level would also be necessary to ensure not only an appropriate common position but also a programme for major public investment.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support a Bidegain colleague's report that is of high quality and comprehensiveness. On a positive note, the ECB has acted swiftly in very complex circumstances through monetary policy aimed at reducing tensions in financial markets in the eurozone and restoring investor confidence in the single currency.  It should be noted that there are significant differences in unemployment rates between Member States ranging from 5% to 26%, while youth unemployment rates in some countries reach 50%, as unfortunately almost in Croatia.  To combat rising unemployment rates, more attention should be paid to overall demand policy. While demand-side, monetary policy can and should play a central role, overall demand cannot be boosted solely by monetary policy, but must be accompanied by appropriate national fiscal and structural reforms and policies. I think it is important to create conditions for investment recovery, both public and private, and I believe that in this context the €300 billion package proposed by Commission President Juncker could complement the ECB's efforts to boost employment and growth in Europe in a certain way. As a major contribution to strengthening confidence in the eurozone banking sector and thus financial stability, I see the SSM becoming operational at the end of 2014.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the euro area has a major impact on the economies of all EU countries and we must therefore closely monitor and evaluate it. In particular, in view of the fact that the Czech Republic has voted in favour of adopting the euro in the medium term. The European Parliament's report analyses in detail the ECB's actions over the past year, both in the area of fiscal and monetary policy. From a financial point of view, 2013 was not ideal, with a decline or stagnation in all major indicators in the euro area. Unemployment in the euro area rose to 12% (around 25% in some countries), eurozone GDP fell by 0.4%, and inflation continued to fall, with inflation approaching zero or deflation in some countries. This trend is dangerous given the ability of the most indebted countries to adhere to debt relief schemes. Unfortunately, the ECB's forecasts published in 2013 did not expect the current 2013 2016 2016 of stagnant growth and very low inflation, and we need to take a more cautious approach to the current forecasts of stronger economic growth and higher inflation in 2015 and 2016. Furthermore, the ECB must re-analyse the conditions for SMEs' access to credit, as the measures to encourage credit increases introduced by the ECB have not worked. On financial stability issues, I welcome the fact that the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) has started to operate in its entirety.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the ECB has always reacted quickly and effectively to the economic shocks of the market, that its monetary policy has been effectively oriented towards reducing the critical issues of the financial markets of the euro area and that it has successfully implemented everything necessary to safeguard the stability of our currency. In order to try to stimulate the EU economy, which, to my regret, remains sluggish with very weak GDP growth and high unemployment rates, with the risk that the continuing fall in the inflation rate could lead to deflation, the conditions must be created for a recovery in public and private investment in the euro area, despite the action of the ECB, which has tried to propose favourable financing conditions. I also believe that the flexibility that exists in the rules relating to the Stability and Growth Pact can be used to push for recovery and to obtain what is necessary to pay for the costs of structural reforms.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 2013 was the second year of negative GDP growth for the euro area. Thus, the ECB's monetary policy was mainly aimed at reducing the stress of financial markets in the euro area and restoring investor confidence in the single currency. In my opinion, the monetary policy instruments used by the ECB since the beginning of the crisis represented relief to financial markets in difficulty. In addition to lowering key interest rates and increasing refinancing operations, the ECB has also adopted undeniably innovative instruments such as targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRs) and new communication strategies such as signalling future monetary policy. However, it is now essential to create the conditions for a re-growth of investment in the euro area, both in the public and private spheres. The ECB should therefore ensure that its policies better reflect the real economy, in particular as regards SMEs. I therefore add my voice to this report and support the proposed resolution.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution concerns the 2013 annual report of the European Central Bank (ECB).  Economic activity in the EU continues to be incipient, with negative and extremely weak GDP growth in the euro area in the euro area for the second year running for the second year in a row during the first three quarters of 2014, as well as a high unemployment rate, which is at levels that are undermining the stability of the euro area and undermining popular and political support for the European project. Equally worrying is the continued fall in the inflation rate in the euro area, which has been going on since 2011, and the possible risks of deflation.  On the other hand, it is verified that, although the ECB continues to take measures to maintain favourable financing conditions, the fact is that investment has not yet increased. It is therefore of the utmost importance that conditions be created for a resumption of investments in the euro area, both public and private. In this context, the ECB's reduction in its key interest rates and the increase in its refinancing operations, as well as the measures announced in June 2014, to strengthen the functioning of the monetary transmission mechanism should be welcomed. I voted in favour.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it congratulates the ECB on its monetary policy, although low interest rates have not translated into economic growth/job creation. We are aware that the reduction in the cost of indebtedness for Member States has been accompanied by an increase in public debt, which in many cases amounts to or above 100 % of GDP and although the ECB continues to take steps to maintain favourable financing conditions, it is important to ensure that this funding translates into an increase in investment (which has not been the case), especially redirected from the public to the private.  There is still a significant difference in lending conditions between SMEs and larger companies, and the ECB's recent monetary policy measures are not minimising this problem, but concentrating money on the banking sector and large enterprises (without risk). Nevertheless, I believe that the ECB is having an important intervention in the markets and in the Member States through its monetary policy.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite all the ECB's efforts to ease market tension and save the euro, it is certain that the social situation has worsened considerably, especially in countries in crisis (and subject to troika intervention). Since the crisis began, there has been an increase in social inequalities in two thirds of Member States. The risk of a Europe-wide recession remains as a result of unbalanced austerity measures and political crises, with obvious consequences for unemployment (mainly young). Still, a vote of confidence and hope for the ECB and for Europe.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this resolution since the final report contains the amendments tabled by the Spanish Socialist delegation which note the serious economic situation in Europe, particularly worrying about unemployment, and support for the shift towards a more expansive monetary policy given by the European Central Bank, which has helped to build confidence in the euro area and the single currency. The economic situation remains worrying, due to the combination of flat growth and very low inflation, even with signs of deflation, hence the need to create conditions for an uptick in investment in the euro area, both public and private in order to cope with the lacerating unemployment figures, especially youth. In this regard, the ECB is encouraged to take into account in its balance sheet expansion policy the acquisition of obligations for the financing of EI projects, which cover some of the most productive investments in the euro area, in particular those relating to projects which, having undergone a cost-benefit analysis, have been selected by the Commission for providing European added value and projects related to the digital single market.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report presents a systematic and detailed analysis of the activities carried out by the European Central Bank (ECB) in 2013, in particular with regard to the monetary policy instruments used by the ECB, its role within the "Troika", the exercise of its banking supervision functions and measures to encourage banks to lend. I have voted in favour of this report for sharing a large part of the rapporteur's considerations on Monetary Policy and Financial Stability, and it is necessary to interpret the economic growth forecasts for the years to come with due caution. On the other hand, I fully endorse the words of ECB President Mario Draghi on the flexibility of the Stability and Growth Pact, fiscal policies favourable to growth and reducing the tax burden, as well as the need for a broad public investment programme. Finally, I would like to highlight the ECB's efforts to adopt measures capable of creating financing conditions favourable to public and private investment, the adoption of innovative instruments, new communication strategies and the internal work of the Member States, with the aim of restoring investor confidence in the various economies.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text, which takes stock of the activity of the European Central Bank (ECB) during 2013; ECB is in charge of euro area monetary policy.  In this report, the ECB's work and determination in the rescue of the euro and its responsiveness in a very difficult economic and financial context should be commended. Nevertheless, the growth of the European Union has remained negative and high unemployment rates in some Member States threaten the stability of the euro area and the European project.  In this worrying context, it is essential to create conditions for investment recovery, both at European and Member State level. As a result, Member States are being asked to work towards structural reforms that allow for a business-friendly environment and for the ECB to ensure that its policies are better adapted to the real economy, particularly for SMEs.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report welcomes the ECB's actions, stressing the importance of having the right mix of monetary, fiscal and structural reforms is at the heart of the report. Europe is sluggish coming out of the crisis but it is still too early to lower the level of attention.

name: Matteo Salvini (NI)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against because the report, while identifying various problems of the euro, which have become so obvious that they can no longer be concealed, continues along the lines of 'austerity and reforms to save the euro at all costs' and therefore proposes palliative solutions that are in fact part of the problem itself.

name: Anne Sander (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes stock of the actions of the European Central Bank.
