The report welcomes the decisive action of the ECB, which, by reaffirming its determination to save the euro and starting a programme of "quantitative easing" has helped to calm financial markets and restore investor confidence.  The programme, which has been in operation since 9 March 2015, will buy back up to 60 billion euros a month of government securities in order to fight deflation and boost growth. This oxygen balloon should enable states to implement the structural reforms necessary to regain competitiveness.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI)
text: In writing. With the ECB's policy beyond democratic control and having questionable goals and methods vis-à-vis certain states such as Greece, I oppose this report. I am opposed to the independence of the ECB and I believe that employment policy must also be at the centre of the ECB. I voted against it.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the positive view of this report on the activity of the European Central Bank, whose monetary policy is deepening the economic crisis and disparities between EU Member States. The ECB develops a policy that considers only the interests of large financial corporations and speculative capital, in the face of the unanswerable need for real expansion monetary policy to give a boost to the European economy. The ECB continues to develop, in a totally discretionary manner, a policy that increases disparities in the EU, without democratic control from which we will not be able to emerge from the crisis. This report continues along the line of the majority groups in the European Parliament that approve the bank's management and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the report on the European Central Bank for 2013. The ECB must present an annual report each year setting out the activities of the European System of Central Banks and monetary policy. The report highlights the message that monetary policy alone is reaching its limits and that we need the correct combination of fiscal consolidation, structural reforms and public and private investments.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Central Bank's (ECB) 2013 annual report, a year that was not favourable to the European economy. Compared to 2012, unemployment within the European Union rose by 0.7 percent. Forecasts for 2013 expected unemployment to decrease by 0.2 percent and achieved it. Nevertheless, there have been significant differences in unemployment rates between Member States. One of the Member States with a high unemployment rate is Croatia, where it amounted to as much as 17.3 percent when joining the European Union in 2013.  The unfavourable picture is further highlighted by a very small decline in the youth unemployment rate. I am extremely concerned by the result of only a 5 percent drop in youth unemployment since 2008.  A major problem is also the lack of credit for SMEs in some Member States. Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy and its rapid recovery, and it is imperative that the ECB considers the possibility of launching a specific programme to support their access to loans.  This situation does not come close to achieving the employment and social objectives set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, and I call on the ECB to take measures that will contribute to achieving these objectives.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2013 annual report of the European Central Bank, in which I had the opportunity to participate directly as shadow rapporteur for the S&D Group, is the instrument through which the ECB's accountability to the European Parliament is explained. The European Central Bank, which is independent by its very nature, is in fact subject by its Statute to a constant dialogue with the European Parliament, which assesses its actions.  In recent months, the European Central Bank has taken on a central role in countering the serious effects of Europe's serious economic and financial crisis. The many actions put in place, some of which were considered "unconventional" for a Central Bank, although they did not lead to the desired recovery, avoided the collapse of the continental banking system and helped to create a climate of confidence in international markets with the consequent lowering of financing costs for the peripheral states of the eurozone. The report highlights these results, also highlighting the many challenges still to be faced, including the low inflation and high unemployment that still characterise the euro area. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The common European currency, the euro, proves its own success with its story. Compliance with the agreed rules, responsible budgetary management and the necessary structural reforms for development are essential for its further stability.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In the European Central Bank's 2013 annual report, I welcome the ECB's swift response in very complex circumstances and the fact that monetary policy is aimed at reducing volatility in financial markets in the euro area, and restoring investor confidence in the currency.  I welcome the positive step taken by the ECB by deciding to publish the minutes of its meetings, which will take place in January 2015, and I support the fact that the Governing Council of the ECB has responded to this request made to Parliament in its recent reports.  I also support the ECB's call on Member States to push for labour market reforms to improve competitiveness, increase potential growth, create job opportunities, increase inclusiveness and optimise job creation conditions in businesses.  I call on the ECB to ensure that wage recommendations do not increase poverty or wage inequalities within Member States, or harm low-income groups.  For these reasons, I support the European Central Bank's annual report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this annual report on the European Central Bank, which contains an important overview of matters, including EU monetary policy and financial stability. Such analysis is vital for the progression of the European market.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. - I support this report, as it represents the overall opinion of the European Parliament and the Employment and Social Affairs Committee on the activities of the European Central Bank in 2013. According to a forecast by the Commission services, GDP in the euro area in 2013 clearly fell by 0.4%, and unemployment, unlike the previous year in 2013, increased by 6%.  There is a risk that employment and poverty reduction trends will not achieve the national objectives under the Europe 2020 strategy. I welcome the Central Bank's willingness to do everything necessary to save the euro, although economic activity has still slowed with negative GDP growth in the euro area in 2013 due to the balance sheet adjustment process, and there is a high unemployment rate.  The Central Bank's mandate is aimed at preserving price stability and promoting sustainable economic and social progress and employment. That is why I think it is very important to create the conditions for investment recovery in the euro area and to dedicate itself to creating high-quality jobs, as there are rising youth unemployment rates that pose a major risk to the EU's economic stability.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Report on the European Central Bank's 2013 Annual Report because I support the ECB, which, in this very challenging situation, is working to reduce pressure on euro area financial markets and regain investor confidence in the common currency. I support the ECB's steps towards the preservation of the euro, which has been positively reflected in the overall decline in long-term domestic yields, especially in the most indebted euro area countries, to the lowest level since the beginning of the crisis. I also supported the report on the ECB's 2013 annual report because I agree with President Draghi that there is room for manoeuvre to formulate growth-friendly fiscal policies and to reduce the tax burden in such a way that this will not affect the budget.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report moves within the well-known neoliberal frameworks of EU economic policy, with market self-regulation being the main issue of ECB policy. The commitment to neoliberal austerity policies, but also to the completion of the single market, is expressed by repeated reference to the need for structural reforms in the Member States. The report calls for more market freedom and, consequently, more neoliberal measures of harsh austerity. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The granting of additional privileges of independence to the ECB and its intended disengagement from control mechanisms exacerbates arbitrariness in taking important (for the peoples of Europe) decisions.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on the 2013 Annual Report of the European Central Bank. There are a number of positive trends in the functioning of the ECB, which has been recognised in the report, such as the European Central Bank's commitment to improving the institutional framework for economic and monetary union. The ECB also stresses to the Member States the importance of responsible fiscal policy and investment, with which I agree. In particular, the Bank's ambition for transparency is to be welcomed by making available the minutes of the ECB's meetings from January 2015, thus fulfilling the European Parliament's request.  Clearly, the ECB intends to play an active role in increasing the competitiveness of the currency area and the Union as a whole. To achieve this, however, the ECB needs to pay more attention to small and medium-sized enterprises in order to increase the amount of bank loans available to them, since the competitiveness of the Union depends largely on them.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. However, I remain deeply concerned by the continuing apathy of economic activity, with euro area GDP for 2013 showing negative growth for the second year in a row, and weak growth in the first three quarters of 2014, with unemployment rates in many euro area Member States threatening the stability of the euro area and undermining popular and political support for the European project.  Moreover, I can only see the steady decline in the inflation rate in the euro area since 2011, which is accompanied by differentials in inflation rates between Member States. It is worth noting the significant gap today between the ECB's explicit objective of keeping inflation below 2%, but close to this threshold in the medium term, and current interest rates close to zero or even negative in several euro area Member States. The risk, acknowledged by the President of the ECB, that current deflationary trends will undermine the anchoring of medium- and long-term inflation expectations is real.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the European Central Bankʼs Annual Report for 2013. This resolution acknowledges the importance of facilitating SMEs access to finance as they have high gross job creation rates, and condemns the high borrowing costs SMEs are facing which slow down the recovery. I think creating the conditions for a rebound in investment is urgent. It calls on the Member States to undertake the appropriate reforms to restore a favourable business environment.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I think it sets up a good analysis and guidelines for the action of the ECB. Particularly, and taking into account that the ECB has started a program of quantitative easing, I hope that this institution will give more weight to buying bonds from the EIB that have a direct relation with the real economy.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (NI)
text: In writing. The very existence of the ECB is contrary to our principles of monetary sovereignty. The 2013 balance sheet is a reflection of the policy of confiscating our independence.  I therefore vote AGAINST this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The issues of monetary policy and financial stability are presented in full detail. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In March 2014, the European Central Bank (ECB) published its annual report for 2013. The report shows that, although the euro area economy emerged from recession during 2013, economic activity continued to feel the negative impact of the ongoing balance sheet adjustment process in the public and private sectors. The EP resolution welcomes the annual analysis published by the ECB, but notes that economic activity in the euro area remains very low, with a negative GDP growth rate in 2013. At the same time, high unemployment rates in several Member States have reached worrying levels that threaten the stability of the area.  Another phenomenon which, unfortunately, has not been adequately addressed until now by the measures taken by the ECB concerns lending conditions for SMEs in the euro area and the gap between the financing rates granted to these businesses and those granted to large enterprises. With the provisions of the resolution, Parliament calls on the European Central Bank to continue its efforts and actions to date and to work with other relevant institutions at Union level to ensure sustainable structural reform, ensuring a level playing field for financial services and ending subsidies for the commercial activities of large financial institutions.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted against this report as it intends to enshrine the austerity + structural reforms cocktail as the only economic recipe for Europe, despite evidence that it is a failed model, with serious social, environmental and economic consequences.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The resolution on the ECB's annual report does not contain a real critical analysis of how the monetary policy instrument was used to manage the eurozone crisis. The resolution fails, for example, to point out that the actions taken by the ECB have not had any significant impact on inflation and the recovery of the real economy. It also does not highlight the enormous risks that the wave of liquidity provided to banks through the various programs, from LOs to quantitative easing, will become trapped in the business of finance, fuelling speculative bubbles and financial instability. In the absence of precise constraints and conditionality, banks obviously find it cheaper to reinvest liquidity in government bonds and derivatives than to use it to lend to households and small and medium-sized enterprises. The solution chosen by the ECB was 'even more liquidity', but we propose a clear, simple and obligatory separation between traditional credit and speculative financial activity, a reform that is increasingly urgent and necessary to restore a healthy and prudent credit transmission mechanism. For these unacceptable shortcomings and the overly complacent assessment, I have therefore decided not to support this resolution.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted against this report because I do not share the positive view of this report on the activity of the European Central Bank, whose monetary policy is deepening the economic crisis and disparities between EU Member States. The ECB develops a policy that considers only the interests of large financial corporations and speculative capital, in the face of the unanswerable need for real expansion monetary policy to give a boost to the European economy. The ECB continues to develop, in a totally discretionary manner, a policy that increases disparities in the EU, without democratic control from which we will not be able to emerge from the crisis. This report continues along the line of the majority groups in the European Parliament that approve the bank's management and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The 2013 ECB report represents the fullest proof of the ecb's complete monetary policy failure. It failed in forecasts on economic growth and inflation. It has failed in all measures aimed at controlling inflation and injecting liquidity into the economy, whether in setting interest rates or in the various bank refinancing operations. Nothing is said about the growing power of the ECB, which largely goes beyond the mandate given by the Treaties. In other words, much more than controlling inflation, the ECB finances banking in the medium and long term and decisively and illegitimately influences the policies of sovereign states. No suggestion is made to question the legitimacy of this institution. We do not understand or follow the report's praise for ECB policy, nor do we follow the ecb's optimism about the Banking Union, which represents another step of concentration of powers in the hands of a single institution, which manages and monitors the EU's financial sector at the same time.

name: Harald Vilimsky (NI)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because the ECB has failed to achieve the objectives it has set itself. Because it is precisely for this reason that it is not possible to assess these objectives, I have not been able to decide either in favour or against them.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The Annual Report of the European Central Bank 2013 correctly states many things, assesses some things correctly and others wrong. It is not possible to reject it in its entirety or to agree to it in its entirety. I am therefore voting against it. The ECB's annual report was also presented in spring 2014. It has also been published a long time ago, so Parliament's assessment of the report is irrelevant. In principle, it is right that Parliament should control the ECB. No central bank can move in a lawless area. The legislator shall issue its rules on the content of the mandate. The problem is that the ecb's mandate has not been given by the European Parliament. Nor can the mandate of the ECB be changed by the European Parliament.  As a result, the ECB is subject to parliamentary sham control, which is neither currently effective nor can it take effect in the current framework. The ECB's control should lie with the eurozone contracting states. However, they refuse to control the ECB and to force the ECB, by legal action, to return its actions to the scope of the mandate.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the resolution on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2013. I believe that this includes a relevant analysis of the ECB's work and I appreciate the views expressed by the rapporteur on the measures that should be taken into account for a more effective monetary policy. I also welcome the attention with which the rapporteur has assessed the ECB's lending policy with regard to SMEs. The report points out that financial fragmentation remains a major problem in the EU, with some SMEs incurling much higher lending costs, particularly in those euro area countries that have already been affected by serious economic conditions, which creates distortions in the single market, slows the recovery and amplifies divergences between Member States.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ECB's 2013 report represents the fullest proof of the ecb's complete failure of monetary policy. It failed in forecasting economic growth and inflation and failed in all measures aimed at controlling inflation and injecting liquidity into the economy. Nothing is said about the growing power of the ECB which goes far beyond the mandate given by the Treaties. In other words, much more than controlling inflation, the ECB finances banking in the medium and long term and decisively and illegitimately conditions the policies of sovereign states. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against the report on the ECB's annual report for 2013 because it does not sufficiently highlight the critical issues of the Bank's work. The report contains many appreciations of the ECB's unconventional monetary policy interventions, in particular the LTRO programmes, the securitised assets purchase plan and the recent quantitative easing programme, as well as continued references to the need to continue along the path of structural reforms and fiscal consolidation, including the introduction of a section dedicated to financial stability. , in the light of the ecb's new single supervisory function last November. However, the total absence of critical reflection on eurozone crisis management and an objective analysis of the insignificant impact that monetary policy interventions have had on the real economy is unacceptable.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by José Manuel Fernandes, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on general guidelines for the preparation of the 2016 budget, Section III – Commission (2015/2008(BUD)) (A8-0027/2015).

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I greet the Commissioner, also all her colleagues. A word of appreciation for all the shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs who have collaborated on these broad guidelines. We are talking about the 2016 budget of the European Union and, more specifically, above all, about the 94 % of the budget that is dedicated to growth, which are dedicated to investment and which we also want to be dedicated to employment. In fact, the European Union budget is mainly an investment budget, only 6 % is administration expenditure. And a budget that has important added value in the European Union. We want 2016 to have as a priority what we call the three E: jobs, business and entrepreneurship. Employment and, above all, youth employment, and this means a focus on education, a strengthening of people's skills, the use of European Union funds and Structural Funds for this purpose, in particular the European Social Fund, not forgetting programmes such as Erasmus+, not forgetting programmes such as the Youth Employment Initiative, which we want to continue and which will have effective results in the coming years. Enterprises and, above all, small and medium-sized enterprises, is the other E. We must not forget that 99 % of enterprises in the European Union are small and medium-sized enterprises and are largely responsible for the employment that exists. A favourable environment is needed for small and medium-sized enterprises and priority needs to be given to programmes such as COSME. Entrepreneurship, because we need - it is the other E - also to support young people and all initiatives, all start up. We need entrepreneurship to have space, vigour and also a favourable environment in the European Union, and research, Horizon 2020 and programmes that can help this objective, including start-ups and COSME, which we want to be used for this purpose are directly linked to this objective. We do not forget the internal solidarity of the European Union, social cohesion, territorial cohesion is fundamental, aid to the most deprived is important, this internal solidarity which must pay attention to the Structural Funds but also in programmes centrally managed by the European Commission, such as the Social Innovation Programme or the programme within it, such as progress. Do not forget yet the external solidarity. The European Union must not forget its surroundings and external solidarity, the neighbourhood policy, we also help it to prevent the deaths that happen in the Mediterranean, aid to Ukraine must be in our concerns, all of which are for another purpose, which is to have a safe Europe. These broad lines have one objective: to influence the Commission's proposal which will appear in May, also assuming that the commitments that have been made in terms of the Multiannual Financial Framework in terms of the payment plan, that it must be respected in terms of the commitments that have been made with the Council, will be respected and, with this respect, the commitments , I am sure that we will be able to respond to the longings of the European Union and its citizens.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, many thanks to the rapporteur. We fully share the priorities he has outlined and we can sum them up with the ‘three Es’: employment, enterprise, entrepreneurship.  We should already in 2015 demonstrate that the priorities of this Commission regarding projects under the investment plan are put to work. This is in our DAB 1 (Draft Amending Budget No 1) i.e. that reprogramming of commitments is done in a timely manner so we can accelerate new programmes for the new programming period in the areas under shared management. As we worry about reinforcement of growth at home, we continue to be concerned about developments in our neighbourhoods, and therefore funding for actions we take on the external side must remain sound for countries facing humanitarian and civilian crises. We welcome very much the focus that the rapporteur has put on EU added valued and how our budget turns into an engine for growth and convergence. We are keen to reinforce – already in the 2016 draft budget – an approach that provides for measurable elements of results achieved, in other words, a strong focus on a budget oriented towards performance and results.  In terms of payment appropriations, we all remember the negotiations on the 2015 budget that ensured that, at the end of last year, the level of payments remained at EUR 24.7 billion of unpaid bills. I want to thank you for the efforts we have made together to prevent this level from going up even further and I can assure you that in the proposal for 2016 we will have a draft budget which allows us both to reduce the backlog and correct the pace of implementation for the new 2014—2020 programmes.  We are fully committed to the interinstitutional dialogue on the payment plan. As we promised, it will be made available by the end of March. On 30 March we will have our first trilogue, and that should also provide analytical documents that explain the payments situation today, how we expect it to evolve over time and what measures we are taking, so we can have a rhythm of absorption of the backlogs that by the end of 2016 brings us to a sound position.  We are committed to controlling administrative expenditure and staffing. Our 5 % staff cut is on track and we really hope all institutions will stick to the same administrative restraints so that we can demonstrate to our taxpayers that our focus is on what we do for them.  On timing, we intend to present the draft in late May so as to take into account the decision regarding reprogramming under shared management, the revisions of the MFF (DAB 2) and progress made on the European Fund for Strategic Investment (DAB 1), as well as actual implementation in 2015. I very much look forward to our strong collaboration in this process on the budget for 2016.

name: Jan Olbrycht
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We are talking about the next year's budget in a particularly precarious situation. In fact, we are talking about the next year's budget, when a few elements will have to be taken into account.  Firstly, this will be the third year of this financial perspective. We do not always remember this, because traditionally there was a slippage of one year, but this will be the third year (2014, 2015, 2016 – the third year of the perspective), which means that this will be the year in which, hopefully, all operational programmes will be prepared and all the work will start, that is, we will have to deal with the first major payments that will already be used. Secondly, this is the year in which we will have to try to deal (as the Commissioner says) with unpaid payments from previous years, and this will put on the situation of new investments, because we know very well that there are no two budgets – one old and one new – it all goes from one budget. Therefore, this is the third year and we are dealing with, hopefully, the second year of the new fund. That is, the third year of the perspective, the second year of the Fund and the issue of payments, and in addition, the revision of the multiannual perspective – we are preparing a very difficult year, and the environment is also very complicated. We declare full cooperation, but we need very precisely the exchange of information, current information.

name: Jens Geier
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Vice-President Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would very much like to welcome someone from the Presidency of the Council here this afternoon, because I actually intends to deal very intensively with the Council's position-building in the past in my speech. But maybe someone is watching on the Internet. Mr Fernandes, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank mr Fernandes for his excellent work and for the work she has I am sure we all share the interest that the budget should be used for growth and jobs as far as possible. But the Europe 2020 strategy also has a social and an ecological side. I am one of those who finds these objectives clearly too defensive. Our proposal as Social Democrats in this Parliament is therefore to emphasise more clearly the social and environmental dimension in the budget and to strengthen the corresponding programmes and instruments. We will also pay close attention to how the EU's unresolved payment problem is addressed in the context of the 2016 EU budget. Madam Vice-President, I am waiting impatiently for the Commission's proposal on this. So far, we have only been able to stabilise the level of unpaid bills, we have not reduced it. The Council seems to be relying on many programmes to be implemented late, leaving money unused, which can then be used to pay outstanding bills. I have strong doubts that this will be so simple. The Council should have learned its lessons from the last budgetary procedures. In the spring of last year, it cut the Commission's draft budget and in late autumn it had to agree to a supplementary budget of several billion euros. How about, dear Council, if we do not make any knee-jerk cuts this year, but to realise together that jointly defined political objectives also cost money? And because that is the case, the decommissioning of budget estimates, i.e. decommissioning, will not be a solution either. In the end, the EU budget may become smaller, but whether it can then achieve the political objectives can be called into question. The Council has some allies in this House, but we Social Democrats do not consider a small budget to be a political value in itself. We are concerned with solving problems. We should also consider the Stability and Growth Pact in the context of the 2016 budget. Ladies and gentlemen, if Member States cannot make sufficient contributions in a largely investment budget because they then violate the stability criteria, then I believe that we have a clear argument as to why this Stability and Growth Pact should be de-ideologised as a matter of urgency. Finally, the revenue situation is important to me. Smuggling is damaging the EU budget. Cigarette smuggling alone damages Member States' budgets by EUR 10 billion a year. That makes EUR 1 billion for the European budget. We have already been arguing with the Council for less money. I would like to make another point about the revenue situation: the EU's only real own resources are customs duties. Is anyone in the EU, especially in the Council, concerned about what the forthcoming free trade agreements with the US and Japan mean for the budget? In any case, we will therefore keep a close eye on the debate on own resources.

name: Bernd Kölmel
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Vice-President Georgieva, I too welcome you today in this almost overcrowded house. Apparently, it is not so important, it is only a few thousand billion euros. We would probably have to talk about trillions, then perhaps there would be more colleagues. We are talking about the guidelines of the 2016 budget. The report mentions four considerations which deal in particular with the importance of this budget for the Member States. We all agree on that. It contains 19 findings and claims. I am sure we are all concerned about the level of unemployment and the scandalous level of youth unemployment. We all want to create jobs. It also highlights the potential we have in the budget to improve all these things. We agree on this in principle. But the question is: how can we promote all this? Here we say, the ECR Group, quite clearly: only by accompanying measures, only by helping people to help themselves. We want aid recipients to be able to do so as quickly as possible and not need any help in the foreseeable future. We miss the clear signals in this report that this is the direction in which we are heading. We want a lean budget. We believe that this is an important value, both for the EU and for the Member States. We fear that we are going in the wrong direction instead, and we see a particularly bad signal in the EUR 315 billion investment programme. In our opinion, this is going in exactly the wrong direction, because it calls for more state governance and restricts free market forces. This cannot lead to anything good, as we have had enough examples in the past. One case is, for example, that German universities are not at all in a position to apply for funding from this programme in the future. At the same time, in the Horizon 2020 programme, we are cutting funding for basic research. These are completely false signals. That is why we, the ECR, reject this report.

name: Nedzhmi Ali
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we support in general the report by the rapporteur Mr Fernandes on the guidelines for the 2016 budget. The priorities are correctly presented as they have been discussed within the Budget Committee. Launching the guidelines for the preparation of budget 2016 we should have two things in mind. Firstly, the EU Member State economies are already in the 8th year of fiscal consolidation with visible lack of resources to bridge the gap of missing investments. Secondly, 2016 will serve as a benchmark of post—electoral multiannual financial framework divisions. The main directions alongside on which the budget should be developed are creation of favourable conditions for economic growth, an increase of employment, which will lead to economic social and territorial cohesion with any Member State left aside. In this respect, special emphasis should be put on policies towards growth, competitiveness and employment with the particular highlight on the role of small and medium enterprises and mid-cap companies and on ensuring the proper distribution of European funds. In 2016, the new investment plan proposed by the Commission, aiming at mobilising EUR 315 billion to stimulate public and private capital investment in Europe, shall also be fully operational. While it is expected that the EU budget will fund the biggest part of the guarantee for this European fund for strategic investment, I would like to stress that this EU contribution must not be made at the expense of existing EU multiannual programmes.  Last, but not least, the 2016 budget has to be provided with a sufficient level of payment appropriations so as to bring real results to the European citizens, to enable the budget to match EU political priorities and to allow the Commission to meet its legal obligations. The ALDE Group insists on the conclusion of a structural plan for payment before the presentation of the Commission of its draft budget 2016, as jointly agreed among the Parliament, Council and the Commission during the negotiations on budget 2015.

name: Pablo Echenique
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the scientific and academic field unanimity is practically total. Every week, a Nobel laureate in economics says: "Austerity doesn't work." What needs to be done, if we want to get out of the well, are demand stimulus policies through determined, sustained and strategic sector-oriented public investment.  At European level, this is a thorough review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, for ensuring a progressive income scheme without so many special agreements, and for eradicating tax evasion and capital evasion, with decision and courage. Perhaps starting by rethinking the opening of a parliamentary committee to investigate the LuxLeaks scandal involving Mr Juncker. All this is clear and obvious, but both the Commission and this House prefer to continue to apply the same failed recipes that have led us to disaster and deepen it today. Fortunately, citizens do understand decency as well as economics. Fortunately, a wind of wisdom and democracy blows from southern Europe. Fortunately, this austere madness has little left.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, many points in the text are certainly to be welcomed, especially the priority given to employment and the support of small and medium-sized enterprises. This year, however, we have a new element that we cannot overlook: I am referring to the Juncker plan, which will have a significant impact, especially on the European budget. Since I have been in this House, I have always heard that research and transport are among the Union's priorities, the very two programmes from which the investment plan draws in order to guarantee coverage. The return given by this fund is a mystery to date, but in the meantime the money for these programmes is disappearing. I therefore wonder whether Europe's budgetary and investment priorities and intentions are real or merely propaganda for its own sake, propaganda such as commitments not guaranteed by adequate payments. Here, too, serious consideration should be given, not only with words but with truly concrete actions. That is what the citizens are asking us to do.

name: Sophie Montel (NI).
text: (Start of off-mic intervention) for 2016 show a clear hypocrisy. Indeed, they consist of agreeing to the implementation of Member States' budgets while at the very least, while moving on to the economic consequences thus en implications. These detailed guidelines are a shambles. The European Union, on the one hand, deplores the collapse of public investment and, on the other hand, legally organises the austerity that is responsible for it.  According to the Commission's own research department, austerity cost France 4.8 points of GDP between 2011 and 2013. In the face of this, the resolution welcomes the implementation of the Juncker Plan, whose leverage of 15 is totally overestimated. The pact for growth and employment provided for a lever of 6 to finish in reality at 2. It has no new fiscal stimulus and does not meet the investment needs estimated at 235 billion euros per year to boost economic activity. The Committee on Budgets is also concerned about the fate of SMEs by touting the COSME programme, while their problems lie more in the gloom and economic sluggishness inherent in the euro area.  Finally, while the european Union's cold bureaucratic monster is giving lessons in good management, its unpaid debts amounted to 30 billion euros at the end of December 2014. Ladies and gentlemen, I ask you to return the full enjoyment of their budgetary sovereignty to the States.  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all let me warmly welcome the commitment of Commissioner Georgieva to a budget that makes sense. Let me also congratulate the rapporteur for his excellent work in drafting the guidelines for the 2016 budget. More than ever before, the most important priority is to create more employment in Europe. To put it in a nutshell, with employment comes political stability, without employment comes instability, and instability in Europe is always fertile soil for dangerous political development. So it should be clear to everyone that we need to give European enterprises the best possible environment for employing people. But this is nothing new and here we are again talking over and over about the same thing. It should be obvious that European political institutions alone are not able to pull the rabbit out of the hat. This is why we should not separate the 2016 budget from the Juncker Plan. The plan – not just the approval of the plan but the working plan that is implemented – is needed for economic growth in Europe. An EU budget is needed for the Juncker plan to take off. So in the big picture, the number one priority is to allow additional private investment to take place. As far as the budget itself is concerned, the priorities should go hand in hand with innovations.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, this report, which has been rinsed with lukewarm water from the EPP, unfortunately does not sufficiently express the great challenge of the European budget in these times of crisis, namely to become a stimulus tool.  Yes, it is imperative to solve the payments crisis in order to restore credibility and room for action to the European budget, and in this we will be particularly attentive to your proposals for a debt purge plan. But this issue of the payments crisis must not mask the dysfunctions of the Union, nor the gaping flaws in the budget, some of which are structural. I want to quote: the programming delays of the Structural Funds, to the point that we need to change the multi-year financial framework at a time when Europe is in dire need of investment; the Youth Employment Initiative, which to date has failed to meet the objectives that Parliament had entrusted to the Commission and member states; budgetary constraints, which deprive the Union and the States of the means to respond to the global challenges of the fight against terrorism, the Ukrainian crisis or the great climate challenge.  And, above all, there are our difficulties in financing innovation, energy transition, the fight against climate change, blue growth. In short, anything that needs to stimulate tomorrow's growth but which cannot find the means today either at EU or national level.  If investment in Europe is a priority, we must have the courage to give Member States room for action through greater flexibility in the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and Governance (TSCG), for example by removing contributions to the EU budget from the calculation of deficits.  Of course, there is Mr Juncker's plan, but as it stands, it would reduce funding for research and infrastructure projects to provide an extension to the EIB to finance frizzy projects.  Commissioner, I ask you sincerely: how can you accept your prerogatives being challenged? The question of the financing of the Juncker plan must, from our point of view, go back into the annual budgetary procedure and find all the necessary margins.  Finally, I will stress the last point of our resolution, the structural question of the budget: the Union's own resources. Commissioner, you have assured me of your determination on this issue and I thank you for that, but we must rush to start this work as soon as possible.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The debate on the 2016 budget starts at a time when most Member States are experiencing very low levels of economic growth, often even recession, high unemployment, increasing deflation and serious fiscal problems. In this situation, Parliament has high hopes of breaking these unfavourable trends precisely with the 2016 budget and the Juncker Plan.  I wanted to raise three serious concerns about these matters. Firstly, the Commission, the Council and Parliament do not appear to have been able to resolve the outstanding payments in 2015, despite previous assurances, and this undermines the credibility of all three institutions. Although the Union budget is primarily of an investment nature, it is wrong to hope that these investments will be a major part of the increase in investment in individual Member States if they are not prone to private sector investment. Thirdly, the hopes of the Juncker Plan may prove to be burning, as the lack of investment propensity on the part of the private sector is not at all due to a lack of access to finance, but rather to a lack of confidence in the development prospects of the EU economy.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I essentially agree with the general guidelines proposed in the report of my friendly colleague, José Manuel Fernandes.  Like him, I am totally convinced of the need to prioritise investment if we are to stimulate growth and therefore jobs in Europe. That is the biggest challenge right now. And this is a particularly good time to do so, as three complementary schemes will combine their efforts in 2016.   The first is, as you know, the quantitative easing programme put in place by the European Central Bank. In concrete terms, by September 2016, an amount of EUR 60 billion each month will be able to move sovereign bonds to productive assets. The second favourable arrangement is, of course, the Juncker plan. In this regard, I want to say that I totally agree with our rapporteur when he writes that the Union budget will have to make available to this plan the eight billion necessary to provide the guarantee. The third element of this scheme is, of course, the Union budget, which is, for the most part, as our rapporteur points out, an investment budget and which must also stimulate growth and innovation. In conclusion, I agree with all my colleagues that the problem of unpaid debts must be addressed. This bad scenario has gone on long enough.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, in the United Kingdom we have a game show on Radio 4 called Just a Minute in which contestants have to speak on any subject for 60 seconds without hesitation, deviation or repetition. Sixty seconds is not enough to do justice to a topic there and neither is it here. But the Committee on Budgets discussions show that the 2016 budget will be all about repetition.  This year, the European Union has learned none of the lessons from last year’s elections. There is no deviation from the previous course of centralising as much money as possible in the hands of Brussels and Strasbourg, disregarding the ability of Member States to spend their money better themselves, and the report envisages more immigration, not less. So I can say without hesitation that this is bad for Britain.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, as last year through this text called the 'guidelines' for the next budget, the lack of common political will of the three pillars of the Union is highlighted. We have the Council, which sets out a different policy each time, without continuity and without paying particular attention to the multiannual financial framework, the Commission trying to bring order to the continuing chaos created by the Council's differences and the European Parliament complaining that the previous two are not doing what they say. Is this the European Union we dream of? Is that Europe's driving force?  Every year in the same debate, on the same subject, we stress compliance with the commitments and legal obligations on the part of the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament, so as not to undermine, or delay, the payment of the persons concerned and then hypocritically, but with a aim, we are talking about investment, growth, employment, entrepreneurship, internal and external solidarity. So let us put aside the greetings and deal with the real problems. There are still countries plagued by crisis and poverty, Member States of the Union of solidarity and equality.

name: Siegfried Mureșan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, every year the early phases of the budgetary procedure are always a good opportunity to reflect on what we want to achieve through spending the limited resources of the EU budget which we have at our disposal. What will be the priorities for the next year and how shall we use our EU funds in order to achieve these priorities? We all agree that the EU budget should be a budget for growth and jobs. EU money has to be used in those areas which make the European economy more competitive, stronger, and more attractive for investors and entrepreneurs. In that sense I very much welcome the approach of the rapporteur to focus this year on entrepreneurship, enterprises and employment. Mr Fernandes, I welcome the focus in your report on research, youth employment and SME financing. Nevertheless, I also have to point out that the 2016 budget will have to address key issues such as the financing of the Youth Employment Initiative. The commitments of the entire envelope have been frontloaded to the years 2014 and 2015 so the Commission has to find additional resources to make this instrument work in the year 2016 and afterwards. In my view, the global margin for commitments is such an instrument and I really hope that it will provide sufficient resources to finance this project. All these priorities would have to be strictly tied to the obligation of the Union to pay its commitments to the beneficiaries, which is a matter of credibility. We look forward to the Commission proposal in that respect.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: – You, Commissioner, certainly understand the European Union budget as an instrument that will help kick-start economic growth and create jobs. We have shown in the negotiations on the 2015 budget that MEPs can be united. To date, however, the Council has also failed to fulfil its own commitment under the Treaties of Rome to support a system of revenue for the budget that will not depend on the current political or economic situation in the country. If we cannot resolve such a fundamental matter as the problem of unpaid invoices, if the situation looks like Parliament, the Commission and the majority of the Council understand the problem, but part of the Member States are hampering the solution for their individual reasons, then in the world we will be pulling the strings. The debate on how to create a smart European budget will take longer than the debate on the 2016 budget. The people of the European Union deserve the European Union to achieve its ambitions without increasing the overall tax burden.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, in expressing my full agreement with the guidelines presented by our rapporteur-general, José Manuel Fernandes, I want to express two wishes. The first is our procedures. The rigidity of the European budget runs counter to the need for growth and job creation. A capped, locked seven-year budget cannot be an effective and responsive combat budget that meets the expectations of our citizens as they expressed them in the May 2014 elections. Everything is so well locked up that no commitment could be made in 2014 on the new programmes resulting in a postponement of 21 billion euros on 2015 and beyond.  At the end of 2016, the Commission will have to chart a post-election review of the multi-year financial framework then promised by governments when the European budget was signed. We hope that the Commission, which proclaims itself courageous and political, will help the European Union to get out of these sterilizing procedures. The 2016 budget should reflect the expected inflections - I am thinking in particular of the actions to be taken to control migratory flows and prevent the Mediterranean from turning into a marine graveyard. My second wish, of course, is the debt relief plan. It is a question of solidarity and ...  (End of off-mic intervention)

name: Edouard Ferrand (NI).
text: Mr President, Mr Arthuis, congratulations, if you want to control migration flows, if you have been touched by grace, I congratulate you. Regarding my speech, we are told: "The budget has a lot of leverage". So, we could quote Shakespeare tonight: "A lot of noise for nothing", but also a "revealing silence". A revealing silence on the first European budget item, agriculture. Where are the aids that today can no longer even compensate for the low prices? What about the investment that has become increasingly weak as our structures suffer in the face of the needs of modernization and competition?  The whole text presented at the time of the manure of agricultural land is a matter of smoke and smoke. European farmers will appreciate being the big losers in this budget.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – Last year, for the first time, I participated in the conciliation process in the adoption of the European budget for 2015. It was tense, and I have learned a lot, including that we could have reached an agreement differently, less dramatically, if the negotiating positions, especially the Council, had taken due account of the European commitments made. I am strongly against the misuse of the debate on the European budget to collect national points. I really wish this year would be different. Let us not forget, the European Union budget plays an important role in promoting competitiveness, economic, social and territorial cohesion in the European Union, given its investment nature and, consequently, an important role in coping with and in reducing the uncertainty, mistrust and dissatisfaction of the citizens of the European Union. I therefore support the proposed guidelines for the creation of the European budget for 2016.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, a few weeks ago, as has been mentioned, we closed the very difficult budget negotiations for this year. What is presented for 2016, on the other hand, will be an even more difficult budget but one that could be an extraordinary opportunity; an extraordinary opportunity because we will have to see what the Juncker plan will be, how we will finance it, but we will also have to be able to hold together those actions that are within the budget and that concern what we are most interested in: young people, businesses, transport and research. We must be able to do this by trying to transform our work on the budget and make it an opportunity: no longer an exclusively technical instrument but the main political instrument of the European Union's policies. We must get out of the cloying relationship between the Council, which wants to give less money, and Parliament, which wants to give more money, because that is not the point. Instead, we must get down to work on having a Europe to which we are not only giving more money but also want to give greater hope. This is the work that awaits us, we have months to do it, the prospects are there.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear Cristalina! Dear Nadia! We are opening the 2016 budget procedure with full awareness of the backlog, i.e. outstanding bills from last year. These outstanding bills also apply to countries that are lifting out of the crisis. This, of course, sets a goal for 2016 – to stop the snowball effect. We all know this, hence the commission's expectation of an ambitious project that fulfils the ceilings of the financial perspective. 2016 is also the year that ends the so-called phasing in of the new financial perspective, or repaying old programs. We are starting a new generation of programmes agreed in recent weeks between the Commission and the various regions and countries of the European Union. This is a significant challenge. Another very important challenge is to deliver on those promises that have been made, which have their political and financial weight, namely the youth programme, the Youth Employment Initiative, which unexpectedly provided me with a growing down payment of up to 30% (I do not know how this will happen with these payment restrictions, but this is a significant challenge, because this programme is simply not working so far) , and the Juncker Programme using budgetary guarantees. These are important challenges that make 2016 such a year of budgetary stress test, including a certain test of the credibility of the European institutions.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the commitment to the three Es in this report, in particular to employment, but I echo the comments made by my colleague Jens Geier on needing to reinforce the social policies of the EU. We need to see more productive, effective and forward—thinking investment, investment in industries that will secure growth and jobs, investment in our young people and, crucially, grants for cutting—edge research.  With this in mind, I also welcome Vice—President Georgieva’s intention and commitment to assessing the outcomes of the spending of the money that we are committed to in these budgets. The EU budget does deliver positive impacts. I see this in centres of research in my region, and with that in mind, I look forward to working with colleagues here in Parliament over the coming months. We need the EU budget to drive the European economy forward, competing at the cutting edge of new industries.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this report, Mr Fernandes, on the lines he has set and to recall , as he himself also stressed, that, in the broad terms for the 2016 budget, it is very important — in line with Horizon 2020 — to promote and give priority, inter alia, to job training and business aid. It is particularly important to focus these aids on small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the engine of employment and training in our European society. But let me also tell you that the 2016 budget, in its general terms, must serve, among other things, to support the Juncker Plan seamlessly. So that, with this plan, bureaucracy is lost and effectiveness is gained and for containment in spending, yes, but at the same time, the money budgeted in the different allocated items is better taken advantage of. If we want to give credibility and confidence to that Juncker Plan, we must remove the problems that some, interestedly, want to put into this plan and this budget. These should be, above all, the general lines of the budget which we will support from the European People's Party.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Union must assume an ambitious budget for 2016 that corresponds to the real needs and agenda of citizens. That's why I have three proposals, three principles. The first direction is the strategy: the transition from a policy to promote austerity to a creative and constructive policy on job creation or innovation and development. The second direction concerns how we think, on the principles of this draft budget, of a budget of cohesion and reduction of inequalities, based on ideas such as the Youth Guarantee or solidarity funds for new entrants, such as Romania, Bulgaria or Croatia, or those related to the neighbourhood policy, and I would mention the Republic of Moldova here. The third direction concerns mechanisms, how we can allow everyone access to Union funds, but also how we can ensure that money is indeed used usefully and efficiently in the interests of the citizen. Commissioner, the budget is not simply a technical subject. It is, today more than ever, decisive for the future of Europe and, therefore, I can assure you that the European Parliament will support you in these directions.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Thank you for this report, which I consider to be of very good quality in general and the directions outlined in it, very good.  I think they reflect a little bit on the discussion we had in the 2015 budget, and I am glad, Commissioner, that as a politician you are keeping your word and we are now opening the debate for the next programming period.  I would like this plan and our discussions to be ambitious. To make the discussion even more ambitious than the previous one, to look not only at the 2019 or 2016 horizon, for which we now have a budget, but on the horizon of 2030.  Let us ask, dear colleagues, where we want the European Union to be in 2030 or 2031. I think that is the basic direction not only of this budget, but also of the other budgets that you will be preparing. I trust you'll find the strength to do that.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – In fact I would like to ask our colleague, Mr Zdechovský, about this forecast on the European Union budget for 2016. This is, of course, a question that the Commissioner and the Commission should have to answer as well.  What is his personal opinion concerning the budget allocated for the Common Security and Defence Policy? Is this a budget that is going to fulfil our expectations, especially after President Juncker’s declaration that the European Union should have to form an army?

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Thank you for this question. Of course, I agree here, and I think, as is already the case, that the money for joint defence is very low. I would prefer a greater emphasis on reforming, for example, agricultural policy and other areas, and focusing more on investment, development and strengthening policies, as well as European know-how or security policy.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, like swallows in the spring, the issue of the budget is once again at the heart of our news.  Having in mind the difficult negotiations for 2015, I say forcefully that Parliament needs to be listened to more, particularly on the issue of unpaid bills relating to the cohesion programme. We need to give the future budget a clear colour towards growth and employment - this colouring obviously requires investment. The investment of the future at the forefront of which is university research, investment linked to the energy challenge, but also investment in the whole issue of infrastructure, in the real economy in general and in industrial developments that will find the jobs that Europe needs.  For this, there is a great expectation of the Juncker plan, and I hope that it will succeed, but I will be clear: I believe that the Union's budget is already well shrunk and it seems to me difficult for it to intervene again as collateral. I therefore believe that the European Investment Bank must play a greater role in securing the Juncker plan.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I think that the guidelines proposed by Mr Fernandes for the preparation of the 2016 budget are a very well balanced proposal and an excellent basis for further work. I join all those voices that have been cast in this House today and much earlier in this House in order to develop concrete and lasting solutions to the problem of the accumulation of unpaid invoices. The Commissioner spoke of unpaid invoices of more than EUR 24 billion. I would also like to call for the envisaged cuts to Horizon 2020 for the Strategic Investment Fund to be sensible and fair in order to prevent research and innovation activities from being hampered.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union budget can and must also be an instrument of internal solidarity in support of economic, social and territorial cohesion, contributing to the fight against poverty and to the reduction of gaps between Member States and between regions. I hope that when drawing up the draft budget for 2016, the European Commission will take due account of these characteristics of the budget, which I personally consider to be political priorities for the European Union's agenda. The Commission must put its growth-oriented programmes, Horizon 2020, Cosme and Youth Employment Initiative at the heart of the draft budget. They must be provided with the necessary resources to unleash their full potential and have a tangible positive impact on citizens' lives, leading to job creation, business development and increased support for research. No less important is the incidence of fraud and tax evasion, which, as you know, have a major negative impact not only on the economies of the Member States but also on the Union budget. I therefore believe that the Commission is obliged to continue to step up its programmes to coordinate the actions of the Member States in the fight against fraud, in particular those relating to VAT.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, Europe is plagued by unemployment and poverty, even though EUR 1.6 trillion has been allocated in recent years to save the banks. However, we have 20 million unemployed in the European Union. In Greece the Troika and the Memorandums have created a huge humanitarian crisis. 40 % of the population lives below the poverty line. The unemployed have reached 1.5 million. The priorities of the European Union budget should therefore focus on creating jobs in entrepreneurship, strengthening social cohesion and solidarity and reducing poverty.  In this context, the European Social Fund and other European Union programmes can and must play an important role. At the same time, however, I have strong doubts about the supposed effectiveness of the Juncker investment plan, which has only EUR 15 billion in investment. It expects the new miracle to leverage EUR 315 billion. Euro.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Thank you, Madam President, first of all I would like to agree with the direction of the report as it notes the problems and at the same time points the way to possible solutions. Starting from the implementation of the budget so far, I would like to note that there are two important issues: delays in payments and unspent resources from previous financial programmes that raise important issues, especially in countries with reduced national resources. And delays in the start of the new programming period in cohesion policy automatically increase the risk of resource accumulation and reduce the chances of their absorption or even inefficient exploitation.  The report aims to create sustainable jobs. Can we study and discuss new initiatives here beyond the Youth Initiative, but also involving businesses? Can we see immediately the use of new financial instruments for small and medium-sized enterprises in a liquidity crisis?  Only two things must be rushed to normalise the payment plan, to immediately finalise the regulatory framework linking us to the Juncker package tool and all this to be done transparently.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Madam President, we need to put our hand on our hearts and tell ourselves that we objectively have budget problems. We have unpaid bills, huge billions, we have big ambitions.  However, I am convinced that without the great ambitions expressed by this Commission, including the Juncker Plan, but including everything we discussed today, there is no recovery of our economy.  That is why I strongly support all the intentions and ambitions that are being made, because I am sure that only that if we can move the economy, if we can really pull the European Union out of the crisis, and there are good indications, and optimism we need and need such ambitions, then all that we are doing here and our entire mandate will really make sense.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the process of drawing up the Budget of the European Union is marked by a complex framework, where the voluntarism of policies in speeches is not parallel to the contribution of the Member States. On the 2016 budget we will not accept cuts to the framework programme for science and research. We reject the funds to feed the neoliberal and militaristic policies of the European Union. Rather, we advocate that this expenditure be refocused on social and territorial cohesion policies. Policies to combat poverty and social exclusion that are growing in the eyes of Europe. We would like to see in the 2016 budget a genuine European-wide public investment programme that complements national programmes. To the three And we propose three S: social, solidarity, sustainability. We also believe that a specific programme is justified to compensate the countries that are victims of the Troika policies, which, as has been recognised, have been the cause of a number of losses that have objectively damaged these economies.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, it is often said in the media that the type of report Mr Fernandes has drafted will not attract a lot of attention, because it is only the first step in the budgetary process. I would like to say that the soothsayers are wrong, as Mr Fernandes’ report has already proved, and I advise them to pay a lot of attention to it, indeed primarily in the Commission, but furthermore in the Council, and especially the Ministries of Finance in Member States. In particular, in the context of today’s debate, I would like to underline recital C, and points 7 and 10, and I would like to thank Commissioner Georgieva for understanding those points. I wish you all success in drafting the budget and defending it, together with Parliament, against some narrow—minded and selfish instincts which may occur in the Council, and I do hope that this year’s budget debate will be even fiercer than the last one.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members, and I am sure we will have a very interesting time when we negotiate the budget. Today’s debate has been a very good illustration of the fact that we are keenly interested in a sound financial base for our economies.  Let me make four very brief points. Firstly, it is a crucial time to secure sustainability of growth in Europe. In 2015, for the first year, we expect positive growth everywhere. I hope that will be the case also for Greece despite some political changes there. Should that be the case, the economy of Europe would be finally coming out of a long, protracted crisis. But we will only succeed if we are fiercely determined to use the budget for that exact purpose: to help our investments and help growth.  This is why my second point is: yes, the investment plan is very important because what it aims to do is to draw private sector investment on a large scale to complement what we do on the public sector side; that is essential. This takes me to the third point; if we are to succeed it will be shown in employment numbers. We know SMEs generate most of the jobs, so of course attention to SMEs is necessary; but attention to our innovative centres, to researchers and to small farmers is also necessary. This would be a predominant objective for us. Last but not least, I would mention social impact and the equality that we aim for. Luckily we continue to be the most equal region in the world and, even during the crisis, the Gini coefficient – the most well—known measure for equality in the 28 countries – has gone down slightly from 30.9 to 30.4. But we all know that this is not across the board; that in many countries and many regions and many communities, inequality has gone up. That is why we have to be very mindful of how the benefit from our budget is spread so that it is as equal as we can possibly make it.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her words and for her commitment to meet our priorities in the first place and also to the commitment she has made here to the issue of the payment plan, namely its resolution in 2015. But we are talking about the 2016 budget, on the assumption that the commitments made will be taken into account, will be fulfilled. We are referring here to the Juncker Plan, which we hope will be resolved in 2015 in June, but there is a little confusion here, the European Union budget will not give any subsidies or funds, the European Union budget guarantees only and provides only an €8 billion guarantee for an investment, particularly private, of EUR 315 billion.  Still on the goal of employment, business and entrepreneurship, the high priority. We must never forget that employment has an added value and a very strong social component, but if we look at the report we see that internal solidarity is there, social cohesion, territorial cohesion, the call to strengthen programmes to combat poverty. All this is mentioned, the social, solidarity, sustainability, we can even say that, in addition to the three E, we also already have these three S.  I would like to thank all the colleagues and all the considerations, for the help they have given for this report. I am sure that with this report we will help to keep the European Union competitive, that sometimes we forget that we are only 500 million - 7 % of the world's population - but we have the largest economy on the planet and that this 500 million represent about 20 % of world GDP and access about 50 % of social expenditure and it is with this objective of strengthening our competitiveness , to further strengthen the quality of our lives, that we intend to approve these guidelines and succeed in the 2016 budget.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 11 March 2015. Written statements (Rule 149)

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The budget is the financial instrument for implementing EU policies and guidelines. Neoliberal policies and orientations, generating asymmetries and inequalities, economic dependence and social retrogression, external interventionism, interference and militarists. From our point of view, we need to break with these policies and, as well as a corresponding change in budgetary options, which provides for a significant strengthening of the budget and its direction for promoting economic and social cohesion, peace, social progress and environmental protection. Of course, the majority of this Parliament, and in particular the right and social democracy, is not available for this rupture and amendment. And that is reflected in this report. It is important to highlight some proposals that we have put forward and which have unfortunately been rejected: - The rejection of cuts in science (Horizon 2020); - Criticism of austerity policies and the defence of an investment programme for jobs and sustainable development; - The rejection of the Budgetary Treaty and the European Semester; - the establishment of a programme to support countries whose stay in the Euro has proved unsustainable in the context of a negotiated exit from those countries; - The creation of an emergency plan to support the countries intervened by the troika.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Georgi Pirinksi, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the Annual Report 2013 on the Protection of the EU’s Financial Interests – Fight against fraud (2014/2155(INI)) (A8—0024/2015).

name: Георги Пирински
text: Rapporteur. – We need to be aware that each Member State makes its proportionate contribution to the budget and therefore has the same interest in the most reliable protection of the Union's financial interests. The report of the Committee on Budgetary Control, which is in your attention, was adopted unanimously. However, the course of its discussion outlined two divergent understandings of what adequate protection of the EU budget consists of.  It is traditionally considered that the emphasis should be placed on restrictions and sanctions in respect of the infringements found. However, the point is that violations are of two different types – one is the result of corruption, fraud and criminal acts. But the far greater number and volume are violations as a result of errors, ignorance of the rules or overly complex regulations. Sanctioning therefore needs to be combined with active support from Member States, both to prevent premediation fraud and to decisively limit cases of non-intentional infringements.   The data in the European Commission's 2013 report are sufficiently indicative – out of a total of EUR 2 billion and EUR 140 million of financial violations, the largest part – eight hundred and forty are the result of unintentional deviations from the rules, while the damage from intentional abuse amounts to no more than 309 million.  In this regard, I would also draw your attention to the sensitive issue of interruptions and suspensions of payments in the area of cohesion policy. The text now contained in the report calls on the European Commission to strictly follow its policy on the implementation of such measures. In this form, this wording is half-hearted because it does not contain the fundamental meaning for the preventive role of these measures as a means of preventing and preventing infringements. Such are the meaning and the letter of Article 325 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which puts first precisely the deterrent side of measures to protect the European Union's financial interests.   It is very important that Member States report to the European Commission the cases of fraud and unintentional infringements detected. This information identifies where the problems are and can be searched for solutions so that such problems are not repeated in the future. However, information on detected fraud and irregularities should not be used to embarrass states. On the contrary, countries must be incentivised to report, be encouraged to detect and prevent fraud and error, punish and correct them, address shortcomings and gaps in their control systems. Therefore, if some countries are found to be struggling, then responsible European institutions and other countries must assist them through good practices, exchange of experience and information, through coordination and training. It is in this way that the Union's financial interests will best be protected in accordance with the requirements and mechanisms of good financial management and in response to the expectations and requirements of European citizens.
