In conclusion, Madam President, I would particularly like to thank those who worked with me on this report, namely my assistant Diana Popova, the assistant to the Secretariat of the Socialists and Democrats, Mrs Kudruzza, Philippe, and the Chairwoman of the Secretariat of the Committee on Budgetary Control, Carmen de Castillo, for her efforts and for the smooth running of the process.

name: Кристалина Георгиева
text: заместник-председател на Комисията. – Както за Парламента, така и за Комисията борбата срещу злоупотребите е ключова, за да имаме доверието на нашите граждани да можем да вършим своята работа.  We in the Commission have reviewed the report and I am very pleased that on a number of your recommendations we are already pursuing a positive follow up. Let me highlight some of these. First – irregularities reporting. We agree with your conclusion that we have to make a clear distinction between fraud and errors. Zero tolerance for fraud unquestionably, but with regard to errors we must invest in preventive action, simplification, and also in harmonisation across all expenditure categories, and this is work we are undertaking in a newly—established group of Commissioners that is dealing with the big spending areas.  With regard to our cohesion policy, we also agree with your emphasis on building up preventive action and also on taking stock, as requested by Parliament, at the mid-term assessment in 2018, of whether the new regulatory architecture of cohesion policy further prevents and reduces the risk of irregularities.  We have been very carefully reading the report’s views on public procurement. We recognise that it is still vulnerable to irregularities, to fraud, to corruption, and in this case we welcome the support you are giving to the transposition process of the new Public Procurement Directive. This is an opportunity for Member States to improve and it is also an opportunity for us in the EU institutions to carry forward the related changes to the Financial Regulation, which is currently under negotiation.  I hope that we will complete this negotiation swiftly. We recognise that the anti—corruption stand in our institutions is paramount. For that reason we will include an assessment of the implementation of internal anti—corruption policies – we are considering including it in the second EU anti—corruption report that is due in 2016.  With regard to the European Anti—fraud Office (OLAF), I have said many times that OLAF is a critical building block in our anti—fraud, anti—corruption stand. We are working for OLAF to have a sound interface with the OLAF Supervisory Committee. I have been personally engaging in working with the Supervisory Committee to make sure that we have the enabling environment for OLAF and for the Supervisory Committee to function. OLAF has been quite open to approaching the Supervisory Committee, including on the matter of statistical tools and the outcome of analyses, which is done on the basis of their application. We are also looking into how we can further strengthen the independence of the Supervisory Committee in their human resources and budget management policies. We will come forward with some advancement on this front soon.  We welcome the points that were made in the report on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and the PIF Directive. I would say wholeheartedly that we appreciate your support. We are grateful for it. We need a European Public Prosecutor’s Office that is able to add value to the protection of EU financial interests. So we want to be ambitious and we want to have an institutional set—up that produces significantly better outcomes in our fight against fraud and corruption.

name: Pascal Arimont
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In times of tight public coffers, and not only then, we must ensure that European taxpayers' money is handled correctly. Every single penny that we have at our disposal for European projects must be put to good use. This is a very important concern for me and for my group. Reports of waste and misspent taxpayers' money are damaging the reputation of the European Union and damaging the image of politics in general. We must not do these favours to the enemies of the EU or to the enemies of democracy. That is why enlightenment is needed. This is important, especially in my field of expertise, cohesion policy, that is, the use of structural funds such as the ERDF, Interreg or ESF. It is the EU's policy area, where the highest total irregularities have been recorded. That must give us something to think about. A total of 321 cases of fraud were reported during the period 2013, i.e. EUR 156 million. In the area of non-fraudulent irregularities, as many as 4672 cases were reported, representing a loss amounting to EUR 1.2 billion. That is EUR 1.356 billion too much! We must ensure that European funding is used more efficiently in the Member States. We need objective criteria for recording fraud for all Member States. So far, these uniform criteria do not exist. We have also noted that a number of irregularities have arisen as a result of excessively complicated procedural rules. Administrative simplification is needed here.  Real fraud, on the other hand, must be prevented in advance by means of an appropriate anti-fraud strategy in the Member States. This also includes, and above all, external controls and, probably, the idea of the European Public Prosecutor. As you have just said, European tenders are also a frequent source of irregularities. The recently adopted directives on European tenders will or are intended to help reduce the problems, which is why these directives must be transposed into national law as soon as possible. We can make it possible for criminal energy to be less opportunities to develop without any problems. That is why I repeat: every penny must be used wisely. We owe this to the taxpayers in the EU.

name: Monica Macovei
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, committee on civil liberties, justice and home affairs. – Madam President, in the Report on the Protection of the Union's Financial Interests we have tried to respond and include crucial issues for the protection of the Union's financial interests, namely the protection of our money, the protection of the money of every European citizen. It's our money, all together, whether you're a Romanian citizen, whether you're a German citizen or any Member State, and that's what we all need to understand: that we need to protect our citizens' money. European money is our citizens' money; their taxes and the national public budget are paid a quota to the European Union and these are the money for European funds. We have given this explanation to everyone, to make it clear that we are not talking about the financial interests of the Union in an abstract way, but about the money that actually comes from our citizens. And it is important to understand that it is a single basket, in which all the money is paid, and as such, if the protection of European funds is well fought in one Member State, but poorly fought in another Member State, everyone suffers because the money is together. So it is not true that if more is stolen in ten Member States, the rest do well because they are fighting their fraud at home. And we're still here because it's common money. As such, we very much want to focus on effective combat. I thank the Commission and Commissioner Georgieva for what she said. I want to tell you that this is the sixth year in a row that I have heard that the Commission is pleased that we recommend and demand the difference between irregularities and fraud. Yes, we ask, but this is not the first time we have asked this: irregularities are administrative, fraud is criminal, but this is an old theme. I am pleased that yesterday the LIBE Committee adopted the interim report on the European Public Prosecutor; I hope that this office with single rules to combat fraud with European funds will work throughout the European Union and lead to efficiency, that is, everyone will make inquiries, to end up with the confiscation of money and its return to the Union budget.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to join in the chorus of eulogies and also thank OLAF and congratulate it for its achievements. But I have massive doubts about the statistics. We must dissocate these doubts, and we must do so together. I believe that we in OLAF have a problem with the reliability of data. It can now be said that there are statistical ambiguities about the duration of the procedures and about the number or treatment of cases. However, these statistical ambiguities could also be called manipulations. The OLAF Supervisory Committee has made an important report on this and on other systemic shortcomings, but the Commission should finally take the reports seriously and react. We need a proper fight against fraud, but I believe that preventing controls on statistics and other monitoring measures of the Office is really the only thing that works reliably. I am also concerned that the truth always comes to light only in a piecemeal way. I would like to mention this explicitly here. This also applies to the investigators' conference at the Director-General's home. Your predecessor stated 50,000 euros in costs. You have now mentioned the real cost, namely EUR 136,000. I think this piecemeal editing of facts is an incredible thing. But what you did, Commissioner, was an important start. I would like you to continue with this.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, first of all I have the honour and satisfaction of congratulating the rapporteur on a comprehensive and reasonably raised report on the lights and shadows that these annual exercises on the protection of the Union's financial interests entail. It should be noted that the 2013 financial year is the last of the multiannual budget in which payments are therefore accumulated. Hence, some increases from 2012 go into normal if we consider that we are talking about literal data. I always say that multiannuality would have to be seen as such, instead of going year by year, which is another way of "sausageing" that usually hides reality. It is an exercise in which I thank the rapporteur for working thoroughly on the issue of income, because it is true that we have been focused for years and years on seeing how, in the expenditure section, it is best spent (I think we have been inducing at least a certain culture — and of interest — both in the Commission and , little by little, even though we find it insufficient, in the Member States); but instead we've been leaving and ignoring what was going on with income. That is, what happened to the inlet part of the money in the budget.  I think there are elements of concern there in 2013: the customs regime has not been sufficiently demanding and, therefore, there are elements to improve, and cigarette smuggling represents, as the figures show us, a total of EUR 10 billion. Look at the Juncker Plan and the EUR 10 billion in cigarette smuggling that we could still recover, even though , which I see Mrs Grule, is rapidly targeting OLAF - even though OLAF, in this regard, has achieved a number of important successes: the recovery and seizure of 68 million smuggled cigarettes , 124 kilos of cocaine and 140,000 litres of diesel fuel. In other words, OLAF must also be acknowledged for what it does well. We are also concerned that the computerised system for the movement and control of excise taxes identifies some deficiencies which we hope will definitely improve in the new procedure.  And there is a finding that year after year comes to us, which is that non-fraudulent irregularities, which are the largest number by which the budget begins to be a little undone and what should be emphasized, are usually due to the disrecognisement of the standard and overly complex regulations and requirements. I hope that with all the new Regulations we will have solved at least that problem for the period 2014-2020, which we will start to examine next year. I hope so.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The European taxpayer is very interested in whether EU money is being used properly and what is happening to it. If he hears that more than EUR 2 billion has been spent inappropriately (in diplomatic language), well, it really has to be – and stirs up – strong emotions, we have to reckon with that. And, of course, I am pleased that these are mostly issues of certain irregularities and not of deliberate fraud, although I note that the amount of fraud has increased by as much as 30% in recent times. However, whether it is a question of irregularities or abuse, it is perhaps from the point of view of our constituents, our taxpayer, less important. What is important is that this money is lost by the Union, and therefore all of us, somehow. Of course, we need to see olaf's successes. I agree with the speaker, although of course efforts to improve his work must also be supported. That is what we have been talking about for years in the Committee on Budgetary Control. I just wanted to commend OLAF for its cooperation with the Member States. This is important, it is needed. Above all, however, there is the question of the political will of individual Member States in the fight against corruption. This happens differently, and I think that here too we should not only talk about the European Commission, but also about our countries in which we are elected. Are governments there really fighting corruption everywhere only on paper, or are they actually fighting? I emphasize this differently, also in my country. (The speaker agreed to answer the question raised by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Mr Czarnecki mentioned that eur 2 billion of irregular payments could be charged to the European Union's financial framework, although he was obviously thinking about the corruption aisle here. I'm just asking whether he and his political movement agree that the European Union should also grow with a chief prosecutor who, by the way, could directly prosecute the Member States for the protection of European financial interests.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Thank you very much, Mr, for this important question. I am not entirely convinced, I will say this very frankly, or another institution that is supposed to deplete the competences of existing institutions that deal with the fight against corruption, such as OLAF and not only, will it be such a panacea, or will it be such a salvation? I would not be in a hurry here with the calling of the body, which the Lord is talking about, I would be rather skeptical here. I believe that we need to make better use of the instruments that already exist.

name: Michael Theurer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to begin by thanking Commissioner Georgieva for her work in the area of better financial management of European Union expenditure. We are in agreement. As rapporteur, I have presented a report on the performance base budgeting of the European Parliament. We need to move towards results-oriented financial management. Citizens expect EU funds to be well spent. The main focus must continue to be on this in the future. As the ALDE Group, we have insisted that the Commission also use its instruments, that is to say, that the interruptions and corrections should be used in practice to force the Member States to correct them in the event that errors are found. 80% of the EU budget is shared and managed by the Member States. And the fact is that the corrections and interruptions have meant that the Member States have paid more attention to the money. The error rate has decreased. At the same time, however, there are also fraudulent transactions. Although not every mistake has been made fraudulently, there are criminal practices. And they must be punished. OLAF, the anti-fraud authority, is important here. However, it must also be monitored under the rule of law. That is why the Monitoring Committee needs to be strengthened. We need a European Public Prosecutor. However, the rule of law must also be respected.  Let me also turn to the important issue of combating tax fraud and tax evasion. If more than EUR 1 billion a year is lost to public hands by tax avoidance schemes, tax avoidance and tax reduction, then action must be taken. That is why we Liberals have also requested the special committee on Luxleaks. We in the European Parliament should be at the spearhead of public education here, because the citizens expect action to finally be taken here at European level too. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I totally agree that taxpayers’ money is precious and must be looked after and that no fraudulent use should be made of it. But would you agree with me that there is absolutely no mandate whatsoever across Europe for a European prosecutor’s office? Indeed that would be taking away national sovereignty in doing so, and there is absolutely no way we could impose that. There is no mandate for that at all. Do you agree?

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The one question is: what is the Responsibility of the European Union? In fact, the EU does not yet have competence here. But the crucial question is this: there is a debate in your country about whether competences are being shifted back, for example in the area of internal security. But what is the point of this? Today we have cross-border crimes, we have criminal gangs operating across borders throughout Europe. We need more cooperation in this we need! And the whole thing must be governed by the rule of law. In this respect, the European Public Prosecutor is a good instrument. I call on you to promote this idea in the United Kingdom!

name: Martina Anderson
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. –  A Uachtaráin, go raibh míle maith agat. Given that fraudulent irregularities in 2013 involved EUR 309 million of EU funds, there is little doubt of the need to fight against fraud and other irregularities. Tá sé tábhachtach caiteachas poiblí a chosaint go háirithe sa ré déine seo. This is particularly the case now, more than ever, in the area of austerity. Unfortunately, the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020 represents the first cut to the EU’s seven year budget in 57 years. I am glad to see some recognition in the report of the need for administrative capacity in detecting fraudulent activity in order to detect and prevent financial irregularities and for the Member States and the EU to adequately train and resource people.  However, I have serious concerns relating to the establishment of the European public prosecutor’s office and the parameters of its remit. The rationale for the development of an EU criminal law is to combat transnational organised crime. The intention is, of course, to be welcomed, but not at the expense of subjugating and undermining the existing judicial systems of individual Member States to the interests of the EU. Article 26(1) is also particularly controversial as it could undermine both the common law system and criminal justice as a whole. Go raibh míle maith agaibh go léir.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, after a long and difficult discussion, the Green Group supports the current text of the report adopted in committee, which also includes our critical approach concerning OLAF. We support the strengthened text, particularly on the fight against corruption, which we consider one of the main battlefields in order to defend the EU’s financial interest, to ensure a high level of confidence in the EU institutions and to secure minimum risk to EU taxpayers’ money.  We are happy that this report also highlights the threat of cross—border VAT fraud that jeopardises not only national budgets, but also the EU budget. In addition to the report, we need adequate regulation on whistle—blower protection in numerous countries, including Hungary, my home country. The quality of whistle—blower protection is very poor, and in many cases the procedures in Hungary are conducted against the whistle—blowers themselves instead of those reported in cases of corruption.  Lastly, I would like to highlight the importance of the need for a European public prosecutor’s office. We need to fight further for the establishment of an independent and efficient institution like that. We have to convince not only the Council, but also the European citizens, that this is in the interests of taxpayers and that this is in the interests of all European citizens.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, everything must be done to prevent fraud, and all the groups agree on this. But I would like to draw attention to another issue, namely the clientele management of money, starting with the projects that will be financed by the Juncker plan. We will have to be very careful of the EIB so that the projects in question do not go to finance projects that are strongly desired by the infrastructure lobbies: I am referring to gas storage, unsustainable works, which obviously cause environmental problems but which, in the event of any loss of programmes based on overly optimistic studies, end up burdening taxpayers, with the risk of having to return the profits of very risky programmes to private individuals. As far as the Structural Funds are concerned, it is absolutely essential to ensure transparency because, here too, the Member States have a clientele management of money, especially on the European Social Fund: every euro spent under the European Social Fund on these programmes must bring jobs and not customer management of money.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI).
text: Madam President, the European Union is a source of fraud. We are not talking about VAT fraud, facilitated by the functioning of the European Union; for France alone, they amount to tens of billions of euros. The fraudulent irregularities detected - we are not talking about undetected ones and we do not even estimate them - amount to 309 million euros on the own budget. 160 million come from the policy of social cohesion. Thus, a noble policy serves corruption.  Can we fight fraud if the Union facilitates the free movement of criminal money without exchange controls and transfers at state level?  This text also promotes the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Is it still a question of taking over from the states a sovereign competence, namely justice?  Our European institutions are a machine that no one controls anymore. Long live the return to the democratic Europe of states!

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Transparency and integrity are values that we should respect and are as important a part of quality of life as freedom and democracy.  These values must be promoted for the effective functioning of the European Union. The financial interests of the European Union are threatened by corruption, money laundering, fraud and other illegal activities. Here it is important not only to criticise the European Commission and the European Union, but to reach into the conscience of the Member States.  The Member States must take responsibility and, if they do not take on this responsibility, the European Commission must be strong enough to stop any money from the European Union and not send it further.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You talk a good talk about the way in which European Union funding is not always spent on the right things. Can you give me just one example of anything which is currently dealt with at European Union level where you feel that the funding would be better returned to Member States to be spent directly by them?

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: "The answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I do not think that the European Union, if it were to work, should not have the funds. It is very important that the European Union, if it is to be a strong association of states, has its own finances and has its own financial policy.  I think your question is good, but it's sent in the wrong direction, towards me. I am a federalist and I want a strong Europe.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, can I thank the rapporteur for his report and in particular for highlighting the position regarding revenue. Quite often we focus on expenditure, but I also think we should not forget the revenue collected either. Although only 0.29% of our own traditional resources is subject to fraud, this does equate to around EUR 61 million, and it is estimated that the EU and Member States lose about EUR 10 billion a year as a result of cigarette smuggling alone.  When times are economically and financially difficult, I think it is absolutely vital that we get every euro we can so as to invest that money in jobs and growth. Therefore, I welcome all measures taken to tackle this problem – for example, the partnership agreement with tobacco companies, the EU’s signing of the UN protocol on illicit trade in tobacco, and the EU feasibility study on tracking and the tracing system for cigarettes. I hope that all these measures help us tackle this particular problem.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: – Commissioner Georgieva, corruption is present in slovakia for virtually every single project funded by EU funds. Since you come from Bulgaria, you probably know exactly what I'm talking about. The fact that political leaders are directly involved in this corruption from EU funds is a public secret not only in Slovakia, but also in many other countries. And that's why nothing's going to be properly investigated. Therefore, OLAF will not investigate anything together either. I have lodged 13 complaints with OLAF in the last year; from my own experience, I can say, these gentlemen sleep in winter sleep. If you really want to fight corruption in Eu funds, cancel the European funds. They don't bring anything anyway. Look at Greece, they got the most and look at how terrible they are. This is the solution. The idea of the European Union is not to redistribute money in a socialist way, but to the common market.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – This is a topic that will, of course, continue to be current in the years to come. The fact is that we are also facing fraud when drawing down and spending European funds, and the Commission receives no fewer fraud reports every year, but even more, and not only is the European Union programme developing, and behaviour and knowledge of how to cheat European Union funds is also evolving. And the fact is that statistics alone will not be able to combat fraud. It is, of course, necessary to build on greater transparency, on preventive measures, on the simplication of regulations and, of course, on the sensible application and drafting of laws to help, not to an obstacle to the use of funds. But I'd just like to briefly get the Attorney General's office. I don't think it's going to be an illusion that this is going to be the kind of superman that's going to save Europe from fraud and corruption. And because of this, before we decide to take this step, things need to be carefully considered, because the worst thing is to put back an authority, an office, which, of course, will have no clear powers, but above all very little and no vague assistance, so I appeal here to caution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the report on the fight against fraud is a damning indictment of the state of the European Union. On page ten of that report we see that the number of fraudulent irregularities is up by 30% since 2012. We are talking here about 1 609 incidences of fraud which cannot, must not and should not be swept under the carpet. But we still have no failure criteria and we still have no benchmarks so that, even when there is no fraud, our money could be being wasted and we would not have a clue. What is it that prevents effective reporting? Is it the culture of red tape? Or perhaps – as I believe – the problem is actually that it is the nature of taking decisions so far away from the citizen that causes such issues and causes them to be so difficult to highlight. When will this place recognise that Brussels is just too remote from its citizens to be truly accountable?

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Committee on Budgetary Control did a good job here, the report is critical of almost everything we can improve to ensure the regularity and accuracy of eu spending. As part of the improvement of the fight against fraud, olaf, the EU's anti-fraud office, is absolutely essential. But there's a lot of room for improvement in the way it works. The committee was well aware of OLAF's problems and took a developing, critical and consistent attitude to the problems. It is quite clear that olaf's independence must, of course, be respected. But that does not exclude the fact that we need more reliable and comparable information on OLAF's activities, so that we can really know why and how it works in terms of efficiency and the progress of qualifications. However, the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats wants to turn a blind eye to these problems, as is quite clearly seen from their amendments 12, 13 and 14, which they have reintroduced to plenary. This approach does not contribute to the eu's fight against fraud or to the development of OLAF as a monitoring actor. Finally, a few words on the means available to the Commission. I believe that the Commission should be tough and follow the line instructed by the committee. Suspending and cancelling payments are hard but important means that reduce the number of errors and improve the regularity of EU spending.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – I would like to congratulate my colleague on this report. In 2010, I was the rapporteur for the report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests, and I am therefore well aware of this issue. In 2013, the European Union lost €2 billion as a result of fraud and irregularities, and only 24% of fraud and 70% of irregularities were recovered from Member States. There is no doubt that much greater attention must be paid to the development of the principles of control and the correct use of European Union funds in the Countries of the European Union. In addition, one of the main problems that lasts year to year is that Member States have not provided complete and comparable data on irregularities and fraud. There is no clear framework for the implementation by Member States of the recommendations of olaf investigations and there are no penalties for non-compliance. This situation must not be tolerated, and I therefore reiterate my call for the Commission to take responsibility.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, the fight against fraud is the foundation of a regulated society and a very important instrument of fiscal consolidation in post-tax times. But we need to be realistic and accept the fact that the European political elite has cumulated the current alarming situation with its decisions. Unfortunately, many European governments have not been able to find a balance between the necessity of generating stable budget revenues and reducing the financial burden on citizens and businesses who have found themselves in an unenviable situation. Such a non-volatile tax policy practically encouraged the transition to a grey economy, further damaging already fragile national budgets. Huge budget money redistributed by politicians often according to unclear criteria will always be a lure for fraudsters. The solution does not necessarily lie in better control, but above all in tax cuts, decentralisation and respect for the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome my colleague Pirinski's report and would like to stress that fraud is not only a disease for the Member States of Eastern and Central Europe, but is present across the European Union.  A large number of abuses in the use of public money are technical in nature due to the constant neglect of the importance of administrative capacities and education.  It is important to emphasize that the number of abuses has increased, but their absolute value is lower.  Attention should be paid to anti-fraud coordination services (AFCOs). We should require harmonisation and standardisation of these Services throughout the Union.  I think it is important to preserve the integrity of cohesion policy with a view to preserving its credibility and success.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Pirinski's report is interesting, but a number of points need to be made. First of all, the fact that, for the first time, cohesion policy is the second area of budgetary expenditure where the greatest number of frauds occur cannot in any way make us rejoice or lower our guard. Cohesion policy has recorded 321 fraudulent irregularities and 4 672 non-fraudulent irregularities. These figures seem to me to be extremely worrying, especially when we consider that the aim of this policy is, or rather would be, precisely to reduce economic, social and territorial disparities. Italy, Romania, Bulgaria and Poland lead the way with regard to irregularities linked to European funds. For example, in Italy there were 72 cases of fraud or attempted fraud in 2013 alone and only in cohesion policy. While it is good that the authorities have discovered this fraud, we must ask ourselves not only about the level of criminal infiltration and corruption but also about the serious shortcomings of the control systems. I am therefore thinking of the work of the managing authorities and the audit authorities, both at regional level... (The President cut the speaker off) (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Mrs. D'Amato, I have listened carefully to you and working together on the REGI board I have one question for you. We have spoken seriously about the need to simplify procedures and thus allow it to be seen that many frauds registered as fraud are in fact mere confusions. Do you share the view that simplifying the procedure would help a lot?

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. It is recent news that in Italy, in regions with convergence or less developed objective – as we now call them – there are still cases of fraud. Regional operational programmes have once again been blocked in those very regions where these funds are most needed.  So what's the goal? It's understanding why audit authorities don't work, for example. We have recently met with the cabinet of the REGI Committee and the problem is at the root and depends precisely on the audit, management and certification authorities.  We are, of course, asking the Commission to monitor this even more.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the Commissioner for her speech and I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work he has done on this report, which we are debating today and which forms part of a wider debate on combating so-called PIF crimes. As highlighted both in the text approved in the CONT Committee and in the rapporteur's amendments, the protection of the Union's financial interests must remain a priority objective of the European Union's policies. The results achieved are encouraging. Anti-fraud office statistics are improving year on year, investigations are more numerous and the time it takes to issue a recommendation is constantly decreasing. Nevertheless, the percentage of funds illegally spent that have not been recovered is still very high. I believe that, in order to reduce this percentage and to combat so-called PIF crimes effectively, it is also necessary to set up the Office of the European Public Prosecutor as soon as possible, giving it the guarantees of independence, efficiency and speed of decision-making that are essential if it is to fulfil its primary function of protecting the Financial Interests of the Union, that is to say, taxpayers' money. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: blue-card question. – The debate is on the protection of European interests, not on corruption. Do you not think that we are losing much more money on the legal and official projects, when in my opinion – I do not know your opinion – 95% of the money spent on offshore projects is wasted and, moreover, these are harmful to the European economy?

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I believe – and I am replying to you very briefly – that the protection of financial interests cannot be separateed from the fight against corruption. I think that answers your question. One cannot ignore one another.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We all want to protect the Community's financial interests, but it is also a problem of fairness in public life, a problem of anti-corruption. And the fundamental element that ensures fair – should ensure fair – spending of European money is transparency, transparency. Any EU money that goes to any beneficiary should be transparent and should be publicly known on any matter, who has received any EU support and for what reason.  Unfortunately, this is different in practice. I have experience – when I tried to find out who in Poland received the money related to the help to fight E.coli bacteria, there were great difficulties in getting to these news, and they still are. I hope that this will be the past, that after the legal changes that have recently taken place, transparency will no longer be an unquestionable principle, because this is the basic instrument for combating corruption and embezzlement of public money.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the EU has been trying unsuccessfully to fight fraud for many years. I think it is 20 years in a row since the auditors were able to sign off the EU’s accounts. In the commercial world the fraud squad would have been called in long ago and the organisation would have been closed down.  The exact amount of fraud is unknown but must run into the billions. The two biggest areas of the budget open to fraud are the Cohesion Fund and the Common Agricultural Policy. The countries with the highest number of irregularities are Italy, Romania, Bulgaria, Poland, Denmark and Greece. There are few surprises there. If we make vast amounts of money available to countries that are institutionally corrupt, then naturally their criminals will take full advantage of it.  My constituency in London will be appalled that their taxes are subject to such a gigantic level of fraud. Fortunately they can do something about it by voting to leave the EU by voting UKIP on 7 May 2015.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: – As a representative of a Member State under a monitoring report in the area of justice and internal order, I am particularly sensitive to the topic of the Public Prosecutor's Office and the European Public Prosecutor's Office and corruption.  The Bulgarian Prosecutor's Office did not receive support from several Bulgarian governments, Mr Pirinski, who showed high tolerance for corruption. Olaf has so far detected fraud with the Funds, but has no powers and competences to protect the European Union and its citizens. The opposition to the idea of a European Public Prosecutor's Office must be aware that the reluctance to create one creates prerequisites for tolerating crime and fraud, effectively making the European Union complicit in crimes against itself. The influence of the governments of the 28 Member States needs to be reduced in the future European Central prosecutor's Office. This requires the appointment of a representative of the Central Prosecutor's Office in each Member State.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – The report before us is full of information on fraud and the mismanageing of European money. Because it's taxpayers' money, it's obviously a very serious matter.  I am only afraid that the European Commission and probably the majority of the European Parliament are refusing to see the cause of these problems. The reason for this is precisely the fatal conceit that money must be redistributed through the European Union in this way.  Why can't the money stay in the hands of the state to pay for the roads? Why can't they stay in the municipal registers to pay for the sidewalks? Why can't they stay in people's pockets so people can decide for themselves how to invest in their hotels, etc.? That's why I'm saying, let's cancel the funds, and that's going to eliminate the corruption.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Special attention to the correct spending of money from the European Union budget must accompany any financial operation. This is in the interest of both the European Union as a whole and individual Member States. Properly spent public money is better used to achieve the objectives set, but it also builds citizens' trust in public institutions. It is true that the diversity of legal and administrative systems makes it significantly more difficult to combat irregularities and fraud. Nevertheless, the nature of these negative phenomena must mobilise the introduction of effective prevention tools as soon as possible. However, the low recovery rate of amounts lost as a result of fraud is of serious concern. Although this ratio increased significantly in 2013, which undoubtedly indicates an increase in the determination of the institutions responsible, it requires the establishment of common rules for reporting and an in-depth analysis of negative developments to the detriment of the European Union budget.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against fraud is, together with the fight against money laundering and corruption, a priority for the political action of the Community and national institutions.  The data on the persistence of these authentic diseases of the system are alarming. It is a moral, legal and social defeat that they, in all their nuances, from the violation of the rules for mere irregularities to criminal offences, still afflict and permeate the European system. I am convinced that there is still a need in the structures and institutions to unite a united front, and that is why I hope that measures will be taken to further harmonise the approaches and legislation applied in the various Member States. It is desirable to strengthen cooperation between the Member States and the Commission, as well as the simplification of rules and procedures and the overall training of the authorities involved in the management of the funds. I will end with a focus on the issue of public procurement, which is so sensitive and so important for the recovery of the national economy and yet still so far removed from spontaneous compliance with rules and procedures, in need, as is, unfortunately, the crutch of external control in the fight against irregularities.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, protecting the Union's financial interests and hitting fraud is a particularly important action, especially at this stage of the intense economic crisis. Fraud against the European Union is a dangerous phenomenon and in some countries it is combined with the action of the capital mafia, mafia capitale as they say in Italy. Thus, fuel smuggling, cigarette smuggling, VAT fraud and Lux-leaks tax evasion are on the agenda.  Of course there are irregularities which occur not by deceit, but purely by negligence. Here we must intensify our preventive action in order to make good use of the limited funds from the European funds. The fact that fraud and irregularities are costing EUR 2 billion reveals the extent of the problem that we must tackle immediately, because European citizens will not tolerate any more fraud and irregularities in the management of European Union funds.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, without any desire to reduce the importance of this debate and the fact that we are talking about EUR 2 billion of various frauds and possible criminal offences, I would like to note, however, that I am in line with the fact that all criminal offences are severely punished and in this context I want to support the creation of the European Prosecutor's Office, as international crime knows no borders. What I want to emphasize by having experience as a man who has worked for many years in local and regional self-government – it is necessary to simplify procedures. We have aspurdes when we get into a situation where something has been declared a fraud, and it's about some people buying metal doors in relation to wooden doors, and the contract said it was a wooden door and it was said to be a mistake, which was recorded as a mistake, and they got better and cheaper doors. It's just one small example.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – We note the importance of combating fraud and all kinds of irregularities. Anything that can ensure the correct use of EU funds must be valued, as must all measures that can improve the collection of union-specific revenue.  We have seen a decrease in occurrences, although we have an increase in the funds involved. However, the easy temptation to fall into some sensationalism should be avoided, creating a criminal framework when, in fact, in round numbers, 14 of the 15,000 irregularities were already regarded as non-fraudulent.  Only those who walk on the ground have the scale of the complexity of all the application processes for European funds. Assuming that there are fraudulent cases that deserve treatment to be treated, we believe that the figures should give rise to our reflection on ways in which we can improve administrative and bureaucratic contours.  Another very different thing will be the European Union's own resources. In this field, the European Union, like most countries, are victims of the globalisation process they have created and which facilitate all kinds of schemes designed to evade tax payments.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to bring to the attention of this House the question of how europe's money is spent on the Member States and, in particular, on Italy. I come from an island, Sardinia, which is champion in the error rate on the communication of data on the use of social funds, a system so tried and tested that it has become a negative example for other regions as well and that covers most sorceress under the guise of privacy. Sardinian and European citizens have been powerless for years to witness the waste and mismanagement of resources that are scattered among the meanderings of local political corruption. I know that OLAF's task is not easy, but the situation is now untenable and something must be done to change this situation of fraud and corruption with European public money. Europe must start to be more vigilant, more incisive and in a different way from what it is doing now.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is scannalach i ndáiríre an méid airgid atá á chailliúint ag leibhéal na mBallstát agus an Aontais de bharr calaoise agus caimiléireachta de gach s agus caithfidh OLAF níos mó a dhéanamh faoi agus caithfimidne san Aontas nos mó a dhéanamh faoi chomh maith maidir leis na cláracha éagsúla atá againn.  Dúirt an rapóirtéir go bhfuilimid ag cailliúint níos mó ná EUR 2 bhilliún in aghaidh na bliana de bharr calaoise agus mírialtachtaí airgeadais. Maidir leis an gcalaois, is léir nach bhfuil na pionóis mór a ndóthain. Dá mbeadh siad nios airde, chabhródh sé sin chun deireadh a chur leis an gcalaois. Agus maidir leis na mírialtachtaí airgeadais de bharr botún, is léir go bhfuil géarghá le hoideachas agus simplíocht maidir le riarachán cláracha. Chabhródh sé sin go mór agus dá bhféadfaimis an dá rud sin a dhéanamh, b'fhéidir go dtiocfadh laghdú air na mírialtachtaí atá ag tarlú.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's report gives us a somewhat positive picture of the fight against fraud, because the number of irregularities has certainly increased but the number of amounts has decreased. However, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about important numbers: in 2013 alone, 1 609 irregularities in sectors considered to be very important, for example agriculture and fisheries.  And I would like to reiterate here, again today in this House, that we cannot afford to waste a single euro of Community resources on illegal and irregular behaviour. It is therefore essential to act on several fronts: that of prevention, that is to say, to act, by intercepting these illegal behaviors in the bud; that of the exchange of good practices, and I would like to point out here what is good is happening in Italy with the COLAF. What is happening in Italy has been a school year, not least in relation to the other Member States, and above all with regard to the fact that an action must be repressed and condemned, and it is therefore important to act on the European Public Prosecutor's Office and on criminal law. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask Mrs Picierno whether she was aware that controls on the Structural Funds are mostly carried out by the national authorities and then the Commission carries out further checks, because it obviously does not have the resources to monitor everything in all regions.  Given that you have been the governing majority in Italy and have governed Italy for several years and that these appointments are political, I wanted to know whether you were doing anything to increase transparency for citizens about the management of these funds.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I would like to thank Mr Valli for his question, which also allows me to emphasise once again that Italy – probably having escaped my colleague – is making a case in relation to the other Member States, compared to the establishment of the COLAF, which has been fully operational since 2007 and which coordinates all the activities that are important in the fight against fraud. So so much is being done, although certainly much more remains to be done: we are not here to deny the evidence. Of course, the level of fraud is still very important, but I believe that progress is being made which we must continue to make together.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Members for all the comments that have been made.  We have a huge obligation to our people to use their money wisely and to account for every penny they give to us. The facts are that fraud actually has gone down a bit on the expenditure side: it stands at 0.19% versus 0.21% the year before. But 0.19% is too much and we have to continue relentlessly to push this evil out of the territory of our European project.  There was a comment that our accounts have not been signed. Our accounts are signed. Every year for the last seven years, the Court of Auditors has signed off the EU accounts but we still have an unacceptably high level of errors. The errors, at 4.7%, far exceed the tolerance of 2% that the Court has established and the Court has also told us very clearly that we have to simplify the rules. Many of you spoke about this. Simplifying the rules is necessary not only because then we will have fewer errors but also because then we can have true transparency and people can find out and trace the money. If it is complicated then we cannot do that. We know that transparency is our best friend in fighting fraud and corruption.  So I just want to stress that this is the reason we look to Parliament as a partner to help us in simplification. We now have rules. Unfortunately, in the MFF we managed to start from simpler rules and actually make them more complicated in the end but, within the parameters of the MFF, let us try to have the foundation for transparency that can help us to use money better and to be more accountable.  I completely agree with those who have spoken about the significance of also addressing the revenue side. On the revenue side the trend is in the opposite direction. Fraud has gone up a little to 0.29%. Obviously we have to take this very seriously because this is foregone revenue for our countries and it is a crime not to be tolerated.  I fully subscribe to the notion that prevention is better than cure. Preventing fraud and preventing errors is much better than having to respond to them. But we also need to act when wrongdoing or fraud takes place. I believe that if we have a European public prosecutor’s office with the right mandate, which is also able to tackle VAT fraud, it will make us more effective, not less effective. This is a notion that I have heard from many here. That, of course, would help us to protect the interests of the European Union.  And what is in the interests of the European Union? It is to protect our taxpayers; and for that we have to be credible in our own activities. This is why OLAF has asked the Supervisory Committee to look into the credibility of data. It is very important that we trust our own office on the data that it provides. That is actually something I personally would follow up. This is not for me to act upon – it is for the Supervisory Committee – but I am very interested in a good outcome.  This is a conversation we will continue. It is an action which should never be stopped and in the end we will be judged by our deeds and not by our words.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I believe that the purpose of this exercise is to establish working and effective cooperation between Parliament and the Commission in truly tackling fraud and irregularities, because it is my belief that the Commission in the person of Mrs Georgieva today has given a very clear commitment to achieving these goals and I think that our overall objective should be to get every necessary support to that effort. I agree with Madam Gräßle when she says that we have to pay all due account of statistics and I would like to invite colleagues to consider the following data. Out of the EUR 1.7 billion in expenditure that is subject to irregularities, these represent 1.34% of overall expenditure, which means that over 98% of expenditure has been disbursed correctly. As to the own resources recuperation, EUR 380 million – you can find it in the report – are subject to irregularities, which is 1.86% of total traditional own resources. Furthermore, in 2013 the volume of irregularities committed decreased by 30% over 2012, and fraud by 21%. I am talking about the values. I admit that the number of irregularities has grown, which requires all our attention, but I do believe, colleagues, that whipping ourselves up into a hypercritical stance is not the best way of protecting the financial interests of the Union.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, March 11, 2015, at 1 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – In my comment, I would like to draw attention to some important factors in relation to public procurement procedures carried out in the framework of Hungarian road construction projects, because the European Commission has found the procedure used by the Hungarian side to be distorting and discriminatory. Although the Hungarian State immediately eliminated the contested practice, the level of the sanction proposed by the Commission is approximately HUF 90 billion (a 25% correction of the contracts concerned).  The irregularity of the practice was only reported by the Commission auditors at the end of the 2007-2013 period in December 2013. The Court of Justice of the European Union has no relevant case law and it cannot therefore be concluded that the standards applied by the Hungarian State are unlawful. The requirements imposed by the contracting authority were in order to facilitate the proper and timely implementation of road construction projects. Foreign and Hungarian applicants were equally affected by the requirements, with 35 out of 62 joint bidders or consortia with foreign members winning the tenders. The case is currently in the preliminary suspension phase.  The Commission should consider that the irregularity identified only at the end of the programming period and the protracted procedure impose a disproportionate additional burden on Hungarian public finances, which makes it considerably more difficult to close operational programmes in a timely manner and also has a negative impact on maximising the use of resources.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. – Two points should be highlighted. Fraud and errors are two different things, but both must be fought and not mixed up. The suspension of funds should not be automatic; it should be applied after all the existing measures for the protection of financial interests have been taken.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – In 2013, Member States reported 1 609 irregularities as fraudulent, totalling EUR 309 million in EU aid. The number of fraudulent irregularities reported by each Member State continues to vary considerably, which, according to the Committee's report, is due to the fact that Member States use different approaches to fraud detection and, in some cases, do not interpret the legal framework uniformly. However, differences in interpretation can easily support protectionist aid. With this in mind, I call on the Commission to make greater efforts to ensure a uniform interpretation of the legal framework, which could make the detection of fraudulent irregularities more transparent. But we mustn't stop here. Although some statistics show that we are becoming more successful in detecting fraud, there is still a lot of money going away without knowing where it lands. In addition to urging uniform regulation, we must also focus on successful initiatives such as the ROMULUK customs operation and continue to support organisations such as the European Anti-Fraud Office. In addition, we are excited to see what the EPPO will be able to do, which, if properly functioning, could at least partially remedy the shortcomings listed above.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Ladies and gentlemen, the annual report on the protection of the European Union's financial interests – the fight against fraud is an important component of the fight against corruption and misuse of European funds at European level. Indeed, it forms part of the package of reports and legislative proposals of recent years, including the proposal to establish the European Public Prosecutor's Office and the European Funds Fraud Directive. However, all these proposals and analyses will not lead to an effective fight against corruption and fraud unless they are backed up by concrete measures at European level and in the Member States. For this reason, I call for the establishment of a European anti-corruption strategy, covering fraud by European means. The aim of the strategy is to set a framework for synergies between the different instruments and policies implemented at European and national level and to outline guidelines on how Member States and the European institutions can combat these criminal activities. I believe that the strategy will also allow a clear picture of the state of the fight against corruption and misuse of European funds across the EU, which in turn will remove the unjustified focus on Bulgaria and show that there are the same problems in other countries.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE)
text: Writing. I take a positive note of OLAF's work so far in the fight against fraud. The performance so far in the field of anti-fraud is largely due to the many employees who, despite sometimes inaccurate data bases, try to uncover inconsistencies and fraud cases. Especially in non-transparent financial management, it is very difficult to detect incorrect data and errors. As a member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I see a large number of these statistical inconsistencies and manipulations. Unfortunately, the information to Parliament, particularly in this area, comes only in a piecemeal way. I therefore call for more transparent work with valid figures and data in the future. Olaf will have to improve a lot in the future, otherwise this institution will unfortunately be useless.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – I consider the fight against fraud and corruption to be one of the most important priorities at the moment, when we decide on every single euro, whether we prefer to support young people, the unemployed, or subsidies to underdeveloped or remote regions. The report assesses the results achieved, but also comes with concrete measures to ensure that European funds are not subject to corruption. Fraud knows no borders and its detection is becoming increasingly complex and taking on an international character. I therefore welcome the fact that, thanks also to the new rules, the anti-fraud environment has been significantly strengthened at national level over the last five years. I also consider it positive that, thanks to stricter fraud detection measures, the average length of investigations was reduced in 2013. I expect that the responsible institutions will continue their successful investigative work in the next period and that cooperation between the EU and its Member States will be improved, which, with the contribution of quality legislative measures, will step up the fight against fraud across Europe.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Council and Commission's statements on the 3 March 2015 High-Level World Conference on Ebola (2015/2606 (RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to date the Ebola virus disease has taken a heavy toll on life: almost 24 000 people have been infected and more than 9 800 have died. It is a global problem. No country in the world can feel completely safe as the Ebola virus disease does not respect national borders, and is a challenge that demands our highest attention.  The Presidency welcomes the High-Level Conference on Ebola from Emergency to Recovery organised by, and under the patronage of, the European Union, in close cooperation with the United Nations and the governments of the three most affected countries – Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea. The Presidency would like to convey its gratitude to High Representative Federica Mogherini and to the EU Ebola Coordinator, Commissioner Stylianides, and also to Commissioner Mimica and Commissioner Andriukaitis for an outstanding organisation of this event. The large number of high-level speakers and participants representing the affected region, the EU and its Member States, international organisations, UN agencies and NGOs, proved that the international community is greatly concerned by, and actively engaged against, the Ebola virus disease. We are cooperating in a joint effort to combat this dreadful epidemic.  Commissioner Stylianides will, I believe, go into much greater detail in the work and the outcomes of the Conference, but let me, for my part, share some thoughts from the Council’s point of view. This conference confirms that despite the stabilisation of the outbreak, the international community must ‘keep up the momentum’ and continue to provide the international aid, which is essential. We cannot afford to become complacent. We have to maintain our attention on the response to the epidemic and prevent any increase in infections.  Our efforts need to focus on the target of bringing the number of infections to zero because even a single case not identified quickly enough can pose a significant threat. The target of bringing the number of infections to zero, and maintaining that level, is ambitious, yet, by working together, we can achieve it.  The conference took place at a crucial moment as we are moving from the emergency response to the recovery phase. It marked a step forward, for participants to look ahead, discuss the lessons learned and start focusing on recovery and reconstruction of public services, enhancement of preparedness, alert and response systems, health, education, risk communication, social protection and reviving the economies of the affected countries and of other countries with a potential risk of outbreak of the disease.  All the participants shared the opinion that the crisis can only be solved with a common and comprehensive approach addressing critical gaps in essential services, allowing the affected countries and countries which are at potential risk to build long—term resilience and protect themselves from future shocks.  The Ebola virus disease is primarily a regional problem. Therefore, the Presidency welcomes the commitment of the Presidents of the three affected countries – Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone – to establish coordinated regional recovery plans together with roadmaps and coordinating structures. This conference has shown once again the commitment of the EU and its Member States in tackling the epidemic and assisting the countries in need. The EU reacted quickly. Several mechanisms were rapidly activated such as the EU Civil Protection Mechanism and the Health Security Committee. Starting from early September, the Council and the European Council provided political guidance for the EU response and worked on the basis of the ambitious objective of mobilising financial aid amounting to EUR 1 billion. We have surpassed that objective, and have provided also in—kind assistance and expertise, thus giving the EU one of the leading roles in the global Ebola response. Last October, the European Council nominated Commissioner Stylianides as the EU Ebola Coordinator.  Today and tomorrow, we must work along the lines identified by the Conference, notably, to ensure that funds already pledged are made available and maintain international support until there are no more Ebola cases. We must also make the response more mobile and flexible; promote regional cooperation; assist countries in West Africa on prevention, containment and preparedness and help them build resilient health systems; and we must also improve governance and accountability of local and national systems.  International engagement needs to be maintained, and I note that further high—level meetings will be held in Washington next month. The Council also welcomes the valuable support of the European Parliament in addressing the Ebola crisis. Discussions in different committees, debate in the plenary and the resolution adopted in September by the European Parliament gave an important signal to the international community on the EU’s dedication to overcome the epidemic.  The Council is looking forward to the report by Charles Goerens that will serve as an important element in further discussions on the lessons learned and on the strengthening of health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises.  Allow me to conclude by expressing our deepest tribute and appreciation to the constant dedication of health workers and international governmental and non-governmental organisations to tackle the Ebola epidemics, their exceptional courage, self-sacrifice and professionalism.  I would like to thank you very much right now for having this debate tonight and I also look forward to a fruitful discussion.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is very important that we are having this discussion today, only one week after the High—Level Conference on Ebola, as has already been said by the Presidency. It proves once again the interest of Parliament in our fight against the virus, against its tangible consequences on the ground. Allow me to share with you a brief assessment of the conference we organised last week in Brussels. First, the conference succeeded in bringing together all the key actors in the fight against Ebola. In a joint effort between the European Union and the three affected countries, their presidents played a central role in the proceedings, but also involving the United Nations and the West African region, as well as the African Union.  Why do I insist on this joint effort? Because everything we do in the fight against Ebola needs to be done with, and for, the affected countries, especially their people.  Second, the conference underlined the fact that our immediate priority still has to be to ‘get to zero cases’ in all three countries and sustain this for 42 days. You know very well the medical conditions and that we need to further adjust our response in the field. Of course, by shifting from big treatment centres to community—level response, out in the provinces, we have to work even more with communities. This was timely because, while Liberia may now be close to a sustainable ‘zero’, case numbers have unfortunately again been going up in Sierra Leone and Guinea. Third, the conference reflected the joined—up way in which we as the European Union have approached Ebola – as a collective effort between Federica Mogherini, Neven Mimica, Vytenis Andriukaitis, Carlos Moedas and myself as Ebola Coordinator, with the Commission and the EEAS working together to get things done, as we have been doing ever since the Ebola outbreak started. The conference also heard how an unprecedented research effort is helping in the fight to get to zero, and how the European Union, through fast—tracking very substantial amounts of research funding, is making a big contribution to meeting the research priorities identified by the WHO. The conference also agreed that a coordinated research effort both in the inter—epidemic periods and in emergency situations is a crucial element of preparedness. The Commission is actively working to achieve this. Fourth, the conference agreed a framework for recovery of the three countries. It heard how massively Ebola has hit their economies, which were on a path of strong growth before Ebola.  The co—Chairs’ conclusions from the conference set out the key sectors on which the recovery effort needs to focus: healthcare, certainly, to provide people with basic care, and to make sure the three countries are better prepared to deal with future epidemics; but also water and sanitation, nutrition, and social safety nets, with, of course, a particular focus on the most vulnerable. In the very short term, there is a need to vaccinate people, and provide primary care, clean water, and sanitation. If we do not invest in these things, it will be just a matter of time before another epidemic erupts. So we now have a common roadmap with strong support from the three presidents. The next steps will be a discussion on the fringes of the World Bank spring meetings, in April, and then a UN—led pledging conference at the end of May. Fifth, and very important, the conference provided a big boost for regional cooperation. This became one of my top objectives upon my arrival from the Ebola—affected countries last November. Over the last few months, the three countries have taken concrete steps in that direction. The presence of the three leaders in Brussels last week and their mutual commitment are very encouraging, and all actors agree that this is crucial for preventing and containing future epidemics.  As the European Union, we are already providing hands—on support for cross—border preparedness in the region. We will look at how to strengthen this further. In short, the conference more than lived up to expectations; but it is part of a process – not the end point, but the beginning. Finally, a word of thanks to the European Parliament delegation to the conference: Linda McAvan, Louis Michel, Charles Goerens and Michelle Rivasi. The European Parliament’s contribution to the discussion was greatly appreciated.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Madam President, the high-level conference organised by the European Union in Brussels was an important step to coordinate the international community's response to the Ebola pandemic. It was a unique opportunity to consider the current situation but also to reflect on the lessons we have learned. While we are currently witnessing some positive trends in the fight against the epidemic, we must continue our maximum efforts, not only to completely defeat this disease, but also to help the long-term development of the affected countries. Because with the exception of the current effects of this crisis such as the losses of numerous human lives, Ebola has left profound socioeconomic consequences in the hardest-hit countries of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.  In addition to direct humanitarian aid, it is therefore extremely important for the management to continue to use development assistance to help the transition and establish coordination between recovery, rehabilitation and development. We need to use development assistance to invest in the long-term development of sustainable health and education systems.  However, we must not lose sight of the broad picture. We need to increase investment and efforts to build the governance and institutional structures of the affected countries. At last week's conference, representatives of Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone stressed that they intend to build a regional recovery plan. The EU should certainly encourage regional cooperation, it is good to encourage the recipient countries of development assistance to participate in the creation and implementation of their own development programmes.  Ultimately, we must insist on promoting good rule, building institutional capacity and the rule of law to promote sustainable development.

name: Linda McAvan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, firstly I would like to congratulate the Commission. It was a good conference, Commissioner, and you got the whole world together to tackle the problem, so that in itself was very important. The lesson I took away was firstly that the crisis is not over. There are still new cases and we have got to stay on the ground and deal with them. Secondly, we need to plan for the future. How can we do that? I have some meetings with the ministers from the affected countries. What they are looking for in the immediate future are some quick wins – to get the children back to school and budget support for the health systems. They want people to feel that life is getting back to normal. Debt relief was another priority so that they have some resources to invest in their own education and health systems. I think that colleagues are perhaps not aware how small the budgets of these countries are. We were told that USD 550 million was the budget for Liberia. That is like a small town in the United Kingdom, the entire annual budget.  But the key lesson for me as well is that we have to invest in health for the long term. You both said this – the Commission and the Council. Last week, Save the Children published a report. That report showed that the cost of the emergency response is greater than the estimated cost of building health services in the three countries concerned. So that should be our lesson. We have got to have a health service that is free at the point of use and accessible. It is a scandal that we ask the poorest in the world to pay for their health services. We should get rid of user fees now. In September we go to New York, we have the sustainable development goals conference, and we have to put universal health care at the top of that agenda. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – To me the question on Ebola is not so much could we have done more, but rather could we have reacted quicker? A makeshift hospital perhaps in two days would be better than a state—of—the—art hospital in six weeks. My brother worked as an aid worker in Malawi and what he saw there on the ground is often so different from what we get in our, almost Western—centric mind set. I wonder, do you agree that perhaps, on a personal level as much as on a party political level, we do sometimes have that sheltered view in the West – every bit as much in the UK as in the EU?

name: Linda McAvan (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I think that is why it is extremely important to meet the countries concerned and ask them how they see us getting their systems going again. That is why we had a meeting last week with the President of Liberia, and I had a meeting with the Foreign Minister of Sierra Leone to talk about the issues.  We have to respond, get the systems working quickly, listen to the people on the ground, and the NGOs, like Médecins Sans Frontières, but we have to invest for the future as well. An emergency response that ends in April, and then nothing else happens, will mean we will have another crisis in years to come.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Mrs Kalnya-Luka-evica, Mr Stylianides, Beatrice Yardolo was discharged last Friday. He is, for the time being, the last person infected with the Ebola virus in Liberia. It's hopeful news, but we're a long way from singing victory. Until 2018, at least, we cannot expect zero cases of Ebola in the affected countries. We have three countries with a broken social fabric, eight million children de-schooled by the outbreak, a high level of misinformation that leads to mistrust and discrimination, and a worrying economic and political situation. The Ebola Recovery Assessment, for the recovery of affected countries, is more than welcome. Developing and strengthening devastated health systems to ensure access to health services for patients not affected by Ebola is key.
