I would like to conclude by congratulating the Hospital Order of St. John of God, the 2014 European Citizen Award, on its admirable social and health work in Africa for more than thirty years and for its exemplary fight against Ebola.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, the Ebola case shows how patents and licences hinder people's access to medicines. This limitation exists in developing countries – we see it in the case of Ebola and years ago we saw it with AIDS – but also in the European Union. In Spain, for example, 4,000 people sick with hepatitis C have died, due to the price of the drug, under the impassive gaze of an absolutely inhumane government. The current biomedical research model is a business that enriches a few to the detriment of global health. If you have money, you can pay for the medicine and if you don't, you have it very difficult, you can die, even if you're European. In addition, current incentives for patent research fail to raise enough for the development of new drugs needed, such as Ebola. Research into new medicines is often not guided by public health needs, but by the economic benefit of pharmaceutical companies. It seems, ladies and gentlemen, that investigating Ebola was not profitable. Alternatives that help the whole society and not just pharmaceutical companies or those who can afford it need to be rethred.   The European Union should take the lead in exploring new forms of biomedical research that promote affordable access to R&D outcomes, but also the creation of knowledge as public goods. We're talking about lives, so let's see which side we're on. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, let me speak in French.  I would like to ask our colleague, Mrs Sanchez Caldentey, who has given us many dates on Ebola, if finally, after all the efforts that the international community has made for the three countries affected by Ebola, you do not believe that we should fight for no cases of Ebola in the region. Only then will we be able to say that we are on the right track.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Of course, the priority now is to end Ebola in the countries in which it is being developed. And stop it. Yes of course. But let's go to the source of this problem. Because Ebola has gone out of hand because it is not investigated about it, because it is not profitable for pharmaceutical companies. And this can continue to happen with this disease and with many others that we don't even know when they can appear.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am very pleased to hear from the Council today that money and aid will continue to flow to these crisis countries, because it is, of course, absolutely essential to build up health systems there. We need to focus on controlling Ebola, but not only Ebola, but also other diseases such as malaria, hepatitis C and so on. Equally important, of course, is the construction of these countries in an economic way. For this reason alone, this conference seems to have paid off. The President of Liberia, Mrs Johnson Sirleaf, spoke of finding a Marshall Plan. Mr Stylianides, you spoke of having come up with a common plan for this economic construction, and that gives me great hope. Nevertheless, I still believe that we have made mistakes in this Ebola crisis, and we must learn from these mistakes. We need a plan for the future, also a kind of Marshall Plan, in order to be equipped, to have structures, to be able to intervene quickly and in a coordinated and targeted manner in crises of any kind.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Dear President, dear colleagues, the Ebola epidemic is a huge threat to the world, a threat to the people of our countries. We must take all measures to make citizens of both the world and our countries feel safe. Three aspects that we must pay particular attention to. The first is the expediency of the allocation of funds to combat ebola. I believe that we must ensure that financial support is also granted to those countries closest to the borders of the European Union and to the outbreaks of the epidemic. Secondly, the expediency of the use of funds to combat ebola. First let's install water supply, water supply, waste water, toilets, other elementary sanitary facilities. Let's not waste money anywhere. Only our joint efforts, the right priorities, are the guarantee of our success in the fight against the epidemic.

name: Joëlle Mélin (NI).
text: Madam President, one year after the first cases of Ebola, a first assessment is needed. It is clear that despite the warnings, local and international responses have been far too late and are therefore partly responsible for the scale of the epidemic - more than 9,000 deaths. That one of the major causes of contagion that is burials with local rites persists - so there are always pockets of cases listed. But despite everything, the epidemic was, fortunately, quickly contained.  However, we can add that the rainy season will cause opportunities for other fevers, including malaria, and new panics. That, despite our requests, nothing has been envisaged regarding the establishment of reception centres in the Member States, that the planned EUR 4.9 billion and the EUR 2.4 billion already paid have not been the subject of the establishment of control structures. We will see what happens in April and June at donor meetings.  For all these reasons, we will remain very vigilant not to relive 40 years of endowment to Africa which have resulted in bottomless wells, without benefit for the local people.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Today, more than a year after the start of the epidemic, we are still fighting for the one major goal of final eradication, the destruction of the Ebola virus. But that is not the only goal we have to fight for. It is essential to address the whole of the sectors concerned. We must have an inclusive, cross-sectoral, comprehensive and sustainable view of recovery measures. At the same time, we must meet the urgent needs that would be there: ensuring the care of children orphaned by Ebola and the social integration of Ebola victims, restoring and strengthening basic medical care, ensuring water supply, sanitation and hygiene development. The three worst-affected countries lost more than 200 years of medical expertise due to the death of doctors from Ebola. In this regard, it is important to develop an immediate medical training programme for doctors and nurses in order to overcome the shortage of local and medical staff. In parallel with the efforts of the EU and the international community in the field of research into Ebola vaccines, viable programmes should be established to vaccinate the populationinthe most affected countries. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Collin-Langen! You spoke of final extermination. In this context, I would allow the term to be used. What do you think of it: polio was almost eradicated. It has reappeared. Polio has developed structures that are unique, that can be easily adopted for pathogens such as Ebola. In other words, we should perhaps fund polio until it has really been brought to an end and eradicated, and then use the structures to build on it for other viruses, such as AIDS and Ebola. What do you think of it?

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I think that, in general, our aim must be to combat all epidemics – Ebola is one – and, of course, to adopt and finance meaningful structures so that we can deal with this issue on a permanent basis. Ebola is receding, but the first negligences are starting again. And so it is necessary to take precautions in this from the outset.

name: Norbert Neuser (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Thank God, the Ebola epidemic is slowly abating, but it has not yet been overcome. After considerable difficulties in getting started, the EU has done a good, committed job. I would like to express my thanks to our Commissioner for the remarkable and respectful work he has done there. But the thanks also extend to those who, as doctors and nurses, are the real heroes in the fight against Ebola. These were rays of light in a tragedy. This tragedy could have been avoided, or at least contained, had we not had three fragile states with difficult health systems. And that should be the lesson for the future: we must ensure that we build robust, strong health systems in development policy.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to add my voice to the thanks and congratulations that have been sent to you.  I have been rather proud, despite the few criticisms I have heard, of the European Union's role in dealing with this crisis. There was a rapid mobilization. It is true that there are logistical delays on the ground, which are mainly due to the lack of logistics and infrastructure capacity in the various countries.  That is why I would like to focus on the sustainable infrastructure plan and the improvement of human and medical resources on the ground. That's a first point. This was requested: the famous Marshall Plan was requested - requested, in any case - or requested by the various heads of state of the region. That's a first question.  Second question. I believe that, in the debates at this conference, a concept has also emerged that I am very keen on: the notion of universal health coverage. In other words, it is about helping the countries concerned to set up an embryo of social security, so as to have interventions and, above all, to eliminate social inequalities in the face of the disease.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this fight is a joint effort, as the Commissioner has said, and not a regional problem as Mrs Kalnya-Luka-evica mentioned. It seemed to me that the Council's words reflect some complacency which for too many months has not been justified on the ground.  There, Doctors Without Borders and other NGOs, also with the help of the Commission and some Member States, maintain a flexible approach to an even unpredictable epidemic. And I believe that this is one of the lessons that the European Union must learn from this crisis: more responsiveness, more aid and better adapted to the needs on the ground and the evolution of the epidemic.  I would like the European Union, as just announced by the World Health Organization, the European Union will also commission a group of independent experts to assess the Union's response to the Ebola outbreak.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, there are three conclusions at this international conference. First, a thank you for the Commission. I believe that all the heads of state, whether Liberia, Sierra Leone or Guinea, have really thanked both the United States and Europe. The second thing is that they are asking for help, because their economy is in a bad state - we are even talking about a war situation - and the third thing is to cancel the debt of the countries. They have asked for it, and I want to say it to our colleagues.  First and foremost, we have to be careful, Ebola is not over. Lately, I have had information that there are still a few outbreaks in Guinea and Sierra Leone. So we are far from a situation where everything would be over and we could leave as before.  The second thing is that there is absolutely no confidence in these countries in terms of structures. Now there are deaths from malaria and some women do not want to go to these structures as they have seen deaths coming out. So you have to rebuild trust and you have to plan. In planning, it seems to me that we need to think regionally and make sure that there are really hospitals, because contrary to what was said, before the Ebola virus, there was no health infrastructure; it was not the Ebola virus that caused this. We really need to think about mobile labs because the sooner we have diagnosed diseases, the sooner we can react. We also need to train staff and set up free education. You have to know that in these countries you pay for education; Liberia, it pays off. It is with all this that we will be able to bring these countries up.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Like many of you, I have had the opportunity to speak to members of parliament from Liberia, Sierra Leone and also Guinea, who have explained to me very clearly, as to all of us, that Ebola has had a truly devastating impact, not only from a health point of view but also and above all from an economic point of view. , meanwhile, completely eliminating a sector such as tourism. This in turn has led to a weakening of the health systems that are already weak in those places, a weakening of the infrastructure that allowed access routes to drinking water but also a weakening of all those infrastructures that allowed the information of the population and therefore of those infrastructures that would allow us to act to prevent certain practices or rites dangerous for contagion. The European Union has now allocated EUR 1.2 billion, but this figure is of the order of magnitude of the debt of all three of these states combined.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI).
text: Mr President, clearly neither the Commission nor the other international organisations have lived up to the dramatic challenge of Ebola. I had interviewed who's regional director for Europe and the Commission on controls of immigrant populations who came illegally into the EU - a migration flow up 153% in 2014. I was told that this immigration did not pose a risk of spread and that it was up to the States to carry out these checks at the Union's borders. Irresponsibility is always the rule in these institutions. The IMF and the World Bank also have a great deal of responsibility for this crisis. By providing loans to countries in sub-Saharan Africa, the new people's educators demanded structural adjustments that reduced the health budgets of those countries that had become incapable of dealing with the epidemic. Finally, migration policies have led to Africa being emptied of its brains and doctors. It is therefore by breaking the borders and the economic independence of states that the anterooms of globalism have fostered this scourge. You don't solve problems with those who created them.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Commissioner Stylianides for his intervention and commitment as European coordinator for the Ebola virus. He has done a lot of work and I wanted to congratulate him. I share his conclusions on the need for a comprehensive approach to our fight against Ebola.  All actors must be involved, because if a country remains infected, we will not be able to contain the epidemic. Indeed, it is only in close collaboration with the affected countries - namely Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea - with the countries of the region and with international bodies that the epidemic can be stopped. It is also necessary to reflect on the reconstruction period of the affected countries and to have a long-term strategy.  The European Union has played a crucial role in the fight against Ebola by mobilizing funds to immediately help victims, but also by allocating additional funds to Ebola research. EU funds for cooperation and development will also need to be mobilised in the coming months to sustainably strengthen health systems in developing countries. It is crucial today that we maintain our efforts and learn from this crisis from our mistakes so that in the future, both the countries concerned and the international community can respond immediately to this type of disaster. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr Ponga mentioned here the importance of mobilising aid for these countries and referred to various European Union programmes that could and should be mobilised to support these countries. We're in agreement. But it is a fact that today more than half of this international aid ends up returning to donor countries in the form of debt payment and the external debt service of these countries. And the question I want to ask you is whether you do not consider the imperative need to establish the cancellation of the debt of these countries, ending this garrote, with this bloodletting of resources, in which aid arrives but immediately comes out again, to pay a debt, which has already been paid several, but never stops growing.

name: Maurice Ponga (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Mr. Member, I do not understand your question about the return of debts. If it concerns developing countries, I cannot answer your question.

name: Victor Boștinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, let us not think that the problem of Ebola is solved and let us not drop our guard. Ebola remains contagious and lethal and we must manage to beat it before it can cause other deaths and perhaps change into an even worse, deadlier virus. I commend all international efforts and all the people who risked their lives in fighting Ebola, including civilian and military personnel. But, at the same time, my plea is to continue with renewed efforts. The EU and other international actors, including the World Health Organisation, need to learn from the Ebola case and make sure that conditions are in place to avoid something similar happening again. They need to be ready and to be able to identify potential emergencies, to be coordinated, to build up complementarity and compatibility, and to be able to give a prompt response including financial resources. It is fundamental that they cooperate with all those countries which showed deficiencies. We cannot allow ourselves to forget the case of Liberia – 4 million people with 51 doctors. This is the very cause of the outbreak.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Representative of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the cooperation efforts between the affected countries and the international community, we have managed to reduce the number of new Ebola infections in recent months. The European Union has played a very important role in this fight, of course. But this fight has not been completed and we are facing the beginning of a new phase no less important.  It is necessary to sustain the effort to combat the disease that we want to reach zero infections. This requires the maintenance of financial support, already committed, the continuity of technical and human resources on the ground and hard work to strengthen national health systems and local response structures. We must therefore continue scientific efforts to develop a vaccine and support and involve affected countries in the recovery of their heavily affected economy. I believe, therefore, that this is not the time to go through passivity, as this would lead to an even greater loss of human life. (The speaker agrees to answer a question asked under the Blue Card procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. "Mr. Faria, I have listened carefully to you and I see that you are speaking in a way that the fight is not over. We haven't gotten it yet.  I understand that the vaccine wins the fight, but my question is do you agree with me that there is a lot to talk about investing in prevention, education and education at this conference because it is the best way to prevent any epidemic right from the beginning?

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Thank you very much, dear Colleague, for the question you have asked me, I believe that, in addition to the human and technical resources that we have to make available to these countries and to the places where there are infections, we also have to point along the path of education. Educating local populations and, therefore, also goes through this aspect. It is clear that, without a complete and constant monitoring of the local population on hygiene issues, treatment, handling of the dead, without it of course we have not reached anywhere and the outbreak continues to persist.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I naturally welcome the objectives and results of the Ebola conference. It was also pointed out that there was a need to build public confidence in the aid organisations that are dealing with this disease on the ground. In my view, this is a very important approach. Commissioner, if we are to set ourselves the objective of fighting Ebola, it is also necessary to help the population to leave behind certain food-procurement traditions that have been shown to be directly linked to the viral disease. I am talking about the hunting, processing and consumption of meat from infected wild animals, such as .B bats, forest antelopes and monkeys, also known as bushmeat. It is therefore essential to include training programmes on the ground in order to educate the population about the health risks of bushmeat. Only then will it be possible to rule out another epidemic.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to point out that Europe has certainly done its part. We were able to respond effectively to the emergency but we understood that the lesson is another, that the high road is another. Although we must not lower our guard against the possible resurgence of the emergency, we have understood that we must be able to create a network of health infrastructures, sanitary facilities and sanitary facilities to improve sanitation, because experience shows us that where this network was there it was possible to prevent or contain the epidemic. So, Commissioner, I call on you to make this effort, which must also be made with protagonists who have been working on the ground for years: not only with the gigantic, traditional organisations, the large international organisations that are worthy, but also with intermediate organisations. I know about it in my own country: I am thinking of Cuam – doctors with Africa, not for Africa but with Africa – fatebenefratelli and colleagues could mention others. We have to work with these people, who have been on the ground for years and who work more in a more participating way with the local populations.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – The sense of relief at the apparent containment of the progression of the Ebola epidemic should not slow down the necessary vigilance, let alone forget this problem. It is time to greet and thank all the international aid and allow me to highlight the giant example of a small country – Cuba – which alone has sent more doctors and nurses to the affected countries than all other Western countries. But the big question remains to tackle the root causes that undercame the spread of Ebola. The revenues of the IMF and the World Bank, their famous adjustment plans, have devastated the already fragile health infrastructure in these countries, destroyed public services, health services and more, creating a situation of inability to cope with the progression of the epidemic. It is necessary to break with this submission. Unmask the hypocrisy of a certain international aid, in which more than half of the resources return to donors to pay debt and debt service. It is necessary to end this garrote. The cancellation of the external debt of these countries is therefore, first of all, a question of justice.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Eu ropean Union's financial aid to the countries most affected by the virus has enabled the epidemic to be brought to a rapid end, but it is not enough. The complete eradication of the disease remains a goal to be achieved, but it is equally vital to support the recovery of the affected countries through long-term planning. It is not just a question of rebuilding their health care systems, but of allowing these countries to rise again with their own strength. To do this requires a profound strengthening of their governance; we need appropriate policies on training, research and innovation; we need to invest in centres of excellence; we need the confidence of private investors who have fled in the face of the stigma of the epidemic; we need debt cancellation, as has already been said several times, because no aid from us can be said to be effective as long as this axe hangs over the governments of these countries. Solidarity requires decisive action on our part. We isolate the virus without isolating the countries affected by the epidemic.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I believe that we agree that the fight against Ebola on the health front must be accompanied by improvements in people's living conditions in these countries. That's why I don't think supports can be more indebted, they can't be via loans. Adjustment policies and budget cuts in public services cannot be forced. Aid cannot be linked to debt payment. They have to support the local peasant to produce their food. The land grabbing must be terminated. It cannot be explained that a continent with 65% of arable land has its citizens starving or malnourished. Aid must also serve to strengthen public and health services and for universal access to water and wastewater treatment. And the debt must be totally forgiven. Under these conditions, it is urgent that the World Bank does not charge the eleven million dollars by 2015 to these three countries.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, despite the mobilization - as was said earlier - of the European institutions in the face of this scourge of Ebola, we must nevertheless note that we have been below everything. The World Health Organization (WHO), in particular, told us that there would be no more than 20,000 people affected. However, 25,000 people have been affected and nearly 10,000 have died. As the Ebola epidemic is not over, it is important that the World Health Organization be able to take a number of urgent measures: rebuilding and strengthening national and international emergency preparedness and responses, revising the approval process for bringing new medicines to market, and strengthening WHO's response to emergencies.  The rainy season is coming. Therefore, I think we need to be prepared to avoid a second catastrophe.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since March 2013, the epidemic has affected more than twenty-two thousand people, killing more than nine thousand of them, almost all in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. Although international intervention has made it possible to reduce the risk of the virus spreading without control, the Ebola threat is still well present in West Africa and international engagement must remain high. The European Union and some Member States are accused of having realised the seriousness of the situation too late and of taking too long to organise adequate means and aid, very often leaving NGOs alone. We hope that this warning will serve in the future to be more effective in action in the face of situations such as this, perhaps by strengthening the Coordination and Speed of Response of the European Union. It seems that the European Union alone has invested EUR 1.2 billion to respond to this emergency and it would be desirable for the quality and effectiveness of this expenditure to be assessed positively. The World Health Organization has stated that the economic resources collected can guarantee the first round of vaccines, once they are made available. Therefore, the next step, on which I believe we will have to demonstrate the capacity to intervene, will be to draw up a programme that will help the countries most affected to get their national health systems back on their feet.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, recently in this Chamber we discussed the explosive problem of the deadly Ebola virus that struck Africa and I would like to congratulate you on your immediate reaction and on your important contribution to the successful organisation of the International Ebola Conference. Of course, the European Union's response to the deadly ebola outbreak has not been effective, with the death toll from the epidemic in West Africa surpassing 9,000 last February, according to World Health Organisation figures.  The main problem that exacerbates the weaknesses in dealing with Ebola in West Africa is the dismantling of health structures due to the demands of international lenders. That is why the debt of those countries hit by Ebola must be written off. At the same time, funds must be invested in research in order to finally find the Ebola vaccine.  Finally, I close by pointing out the hypocritical attitude of the West, which closed its eyes when the disease first appeared years ago, and now that the epidemic is knocking on the door of the West, the European Union and the United States have finally woken up.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, of course we must remain vigilant - as you know - because we are not yet at zero cases. But I would really like - you have not talked enough, I think - that we learn the lessons for the future of the international community's more than belated response. Five months before WHO really takes care of it and says it, there is a real problem here. This conference was a very good initiative. I congratulate you on that. We need to act in at least two directions. Everyone said that. We must actively support a research policy for vaccination, for medicines, for testing as well. This is extremely important. Then we need - this was the heaviest point of this conference, and that is good - to develop a common cross-border strategy that takes into account the development of health and health networks in these parts of the world, which also supports the economy because we obviously know that it has been extremely and severely hit by the Ebola virus. , and it's not over yet.  Therefore, we will simply have to continue to maintain the commitment of the international community and europe, as you well know. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. My colleague, you referred to research: I wanted to ask what you think of the creation of a public and European pharmaceutical company in order to counter the prevalence and power that private pharmaceutical companies have in this sector and also in other sectors.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. I think it is very important that the public authorities themselves and the European Union itself at the forefront invest in research. It's our job, it's our responsibility.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I was very pleased to hear so much enthusiasm and conviction in commissioner Stylianides' words following the Ebola conference. How can we disagree with the many comments that have been made in a transversal way a little by all the groups, by many colleagues, on the proposals to go precisely to address and solve the serious problem of Ebola and in any case to keep the focus on it. I fully agree with the debate on prevention and education but, above all, as Mr Pedicini said and as Mr Ferreira also mentioned, on the cancellation of public debt in these countries. Furthermore, one thing on which we should be careful when we go to help the affected countries with development projects would be to follow the cycle of corruption, both internally and externally, because I would not like what is an emergency to turn into a big deal for those few large multinational drug companies.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this is a very critical moment in the Ebola crisis. Firstly, substantial progress was made in slowing the epidemic as a result, mainly, of the international response. Secondly, we have to underline the fact, unfortunately, that the response was very slow. There are new cases of Ebola each and every day, especially in Sierra Leone and Guinea. Efforts have to increase. We cannot afford to allow such a deadly threat to mankind to be a secondary issue among our daily priorities. The first priority has to be to get to zero cases in the three countries, and the comprehensive recovery programme has to be implemented for all three countries as well. Last but not least, the world must learn lots of lessons from the Ebola crisis – mainly that a health crisis and a poor health system can very quickly become a huge development huge crisis, especially for the economy and education in those countries.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the international conference on Ebola held a few days ago in Brussels put on the plate the data of a virus that is still frightening: between Sierra Leone and Liberia, more than twenty-two thousand people were infected and nine thousand were killed. These are disaster numbers, because this is a catastrophe in all respects. Organizing big events on this issue is important but even more so will be doing something concrete to solve the problem at its root. Europe has the means to succeed, but they must be used in the right way, without putting the economic interests of those who only want to speculate on this tragedy.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am once again greatly encouraged by the level of engagement by Parliament on Ebola and by the interest you have shown in the conference last week, which was a major event for all of us. I have listened very carefully to your points. I particularly note the following: Firstly, regarding regional cooperation, this is a very critical point – as many of you have already mentioned – not only for tackling the virus transmission across the borders of the three countries, but also for the three countries to elaborate compatible national recovery strategies. The presence of the three leaders in Brussels last week was both substantial and symbolic.  Regarding funding, USD 4.9 billion has been pledged and an unparalleled USD 2.5 billion has already been disbursed. The United Nations has a shortfall of USD 400 million, so more might need to be pledged. The UN pledging conference of the Secretary General Ban Ki—moon is planned for the end of May. Regarding the European Union’s response, it is not a secret that the whole international community underestimated the crisis in the first stage, but I am sure we learned a lesson from it. We provided EUR 1.2 billion in assistance through various directions and co—funded over 100 flights of in—kind assistance, among other things. The European Union has already provided EUR 210 million of development assistance to assist the affected countries with their recovery strategy.  We have contributed EUR 138 million to Ebola research programmes, which Mr Ponga referred to, and to vaccines, treatments and rapid tests in an unparalleled example of public and private cooperation. With regard to researching non—profitable diseases, as I come from the medical profession, that is something I will raise with my colleague Commissioner Carlos Moedas. One word about resilience, which my colleague Mr Stier mentioned, we definitely need to help vulnerable countries build health systems, social systems and education systems – as Linda McAvan already mentioned – in a more resilient way. One such initiative is to create a Centre for Disease Control in Africa. This is something that I fully support. On improving our mobilisation capacity as European institutions, I fully agree and I think that we are learning many lessons from this crisis. Our thinking should focus on our future ability to deploy medical teams immediately after an outbreak. Some initiatives from Member States, notably the White Helmets proposal, are already on the drawing board and will need to be followed up.  As I said earlier, the Conference was not the end point of a process, but rather the beginning. We have important meetings coming up, first in Washington at the World Bank spring meetings, and later on in the form of the UN pledging conference. As the European Union, we will of course continue to contribute to the response and to the recovery of the three affected countries, adjusting our substantial existing effort as needed, on emergency response, on development and on research. I hope Parliament will continue to keep engaged in this very difficult effort and, as Ebola coordinator, I promise to keep up the excellent dialogue we have developed with you.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, the Presidency would like to thank you for your continuing involvement and support in the response to the Ebola virus disease crisis. Following our debate, I would like to underline three aspects. Firstly, clearly there is no room for complacency. We need to continue our efforts in the immediate response. Getting down to, and staying at, zero is our objective. The question is how to prevent a similar crisis in the future. I believe that during last week’s conference it was stated by all participants that the world after Ebola cannot remain the same if we do not want to be confronted with another epidemic of an even larger scale. First and foremost, advances realised in developing vaccines and effective treatment against Ebola and other neglected diseases. The participants welcomed the encouraging results of treating Ebola patients with Favipiravir that is undergoing the final stage of testing. Secondly, it is clear for us that, together with affected countries, we need to build resilience for the region. We need a comprehensive cross—border strategy encompassing health, education, public services and economic development. The Council therefore welcomes the Mano River Union Summit held in the capital of the Ivory Coast, Abidjan, on 15 February, and the commitments made by the countries of the region: a reduction of Ebola in 60 days, close cooperation, establishment of a regional centre for infections, preventions and control and the fostering of the economic recovery of affected countries. At the same time, the idea of creating a Marshall Plan for the affected countries or restructuring their foreign debt should be dealt with in appropriate fora, in the margins of the IMF, World Bank and other international financial institutions. The EU can use instruments that are at its disposal to strengthen the resilience and capacity of the affected countries while preparing for the World Bank meeting in April and the UN Ebola Donors’ Conference in May 2015. Thirdly, improved governance, accountability and transparency of national, regional and local systems will allow us to provide a more inclusive and effective result for citizens. Lessons learned from this crisis should be incorporated in the recovery and development plans. The Council will continue monitoring the situation. Together with the European Commission, we will continue to work with the countries of the region and international organisations in devising the most appropriate recovery and development strategies.  In order to reinforce the EU and global preparedness and response to health threats in the light of the experience to fight the Ebola epidemic, it is important that the Commission and the EU Member States take stock of lessons learned over the last month. There is a lot to do and we need to come to a zero—case situation.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García José Blanco López Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero (S&D)
text: in writing. – We must draw four conclusions from this international conference. Firstly, this Parliament will continue to work to ensure a thorough monitoring of the situation until the virus is eradicated and we reach patient zero. Second, aid remains more than necessary as affected countries encounter limited basic services, a devastated economy, and almost non-existent health systems. Yes, medical staff, mobile hospitals, are still needed, but above all they are given the hope of seeing their children return to school or simply have access to safe drinking water. For this reason, the Socialists support the cancellation of debt to the affected countries. Third, we must help them in their regional drive to improve their prevention and reaction capabilities to epidemics such as Ebola and others that continue to cause thousands of deaths on the African continent (AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, etc.), as well as to strengthen their health systems. Finally, we call for a reduction in the number of people affected not to result in a reduction in efforts to find Ebola treatment and vaccine. These will be the main socialist political lines in the report that this Parliament will issue in the coming months.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – At a time when it is crucial to move forward with the normalisation of relations between the EU and Cuba, we would like to welcome the example of Cuba and its humanitarian and cooperation policy with the peoples of the world. This small country alone sent more doctors and nurses to the Ebola-affected countries than the whole of all other Western countries. It was Ban Ki Moon himself who praised cuba's example, and World Health Organization Director-General Margaret Chan praised the role of ALBA countries in the fight against Ebola, including Cuba and Venezuela. This is how we see which countries truly defend human rights.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on montenegro's progress report in 2014 (2014/2947(RSP))

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, today we are having important debates on the Stabilisation and Association Process concerning four Western Balkan countries. Before we start the discussion on the individual assessment of the respective countries, I would like to underline that the Council continues to attach great importance to the credibility of the Stabilisation and Association process, which remains crucial for maintaining the momentum of democratic reforms. The values upon which the European Union is founded – freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights – are linked to the economic and social progress the European Union has achieved since its creation. In this respect we recognise that the preparation of economic reform programmes will support the efforts of candidate and aspirant states of the Western Balkans towards meeting the Copenhagen economic criteria. I would also like to underline that the ultimate wish to move forward on crucial reform issues cannot come from the European Union, but from the governments of the Western Balkan countries themselves. Cooperation is the common link that binds the EU and what strengthens our ability to deliver security and prosperity. It provides strength in unity and builds consensus and mutual trust, while taking into account the needs, challenges and assets of each country. This is why the Council underlines the importance of regional economic cooperation, sharing the best practice on economic governance and connectivity and inclusiveness within the region and with the EU. Let me now turn to Montenegro. It is clear that the Council broadly shares many of the views expressed in your draft resolution. I would particularly like to underline some points which we consider very important. In its conclusions in December last year, the Council welcomed the progress Montenegro had made in the past year, including the completion of the extensive screening phase. In line with the new approach, the focus has been on the chapters dedicated to the fundamental rights and rule of law: Chapter 23, Judiciary and Fundamental Rights and Chapter 24, Justice, Freedom and Security, as they are rightly at the heart of the enlargement process. Montenegro has demonstrated strong commitment to the reform process in line with European standards, which is an essential element of the accession negotiation process. We welcome the recent adoption of certain measures, in particular in the area of the fight against corruption. However, much along the same lines as the Parliament, the Council also stressed that a number of shortcomings identified by the Commission need to be addressed in a decisive and effective way. Montenegro needs to further intensify its efforts with regard to legislative reforms and their effective implementation, in particular in relation to chapters 23 and 24. In this light, let me take note of the recent adoption by the government of Montenegro of the revised action plan for both chapters. The interim benchmark for the rule of law chapters should continue to provide clear guidance for future reforms. Particular importance should be given to making up for delays and to further developing a solid track record in the area of the rule of law, including with respect to the fight against corruption, notably at high level. Further efforts are also needed to implement constitutional amendments, strengthen political inclusiveness, and guarantee citizens’ trust in public institutions. Furthermore, Montenegro needs to implement the public administration reform strategy and strengthen administrative capacity, tackle politicisation, increase transparency, and improve the business environment. A well-functioning public administration is not only necessary for democratic governance, but it also directly impacts on a government’s ability to provide public services and to foster competitiveness and growth. In this regard the Council welcomes the approach of the Commission to focus on strengthening economic governance and competitiveness. It should prove to be a valuable support to the efforts towards meeting the Copenhagen criteria. As you have highlighted in your draft resolution, further efforts are also needed to guarantee freedom of expression and of the media, including properly investigating and prosecuting threats and violence against journalists. Montenegro will require strong political commitment in order to deliver further tangible and lasting results. The Council will continue to closely monitor the progress in the chapters on Fundamental Rights and Justice and Security which will determine the overall pace of negotiations. The Council notes that Montenegro has continued to implement its obligations under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, and to play an active role in the region. The Council commends Montenegro for its strong commitment to regional cooperation and its constructive role in maintaining regional stability. In this regard, the Council welcomes the active participation of Montenegro in numerous regional initiatives in South—Eastern Europe and the good neighbourly and bilateral relations it entertains with other enlargement countries and EU Member States. I would also like to stress that the Council welcomes Montenegro’s full alignment with the Union’s Common Foreign and Security Policy. Now, let me say a few words about the state of play in the accession negotiations. Four new negotiation chapters were successfully opened during the latest Accession Conference, held on 16 December 2014. Overall, out of a total of 35 chapters, 16 have now been opened for negotiations, of which two chapters have already been provisionally closed. We plan for the next Accession Conferences at Deputy and Ministerial level, in March and June respectively, where we expect to be able to open further chapters, depending on Montenegro’s continuous progress in meeting the requirements for accession. Finally, let me acknowledge and welcome, on behalf of the Presidency and the Council, the Parliament’s work, and in particular the continuous engagement of your rapporteur, Mr Charles Tannock, regarding the negotiation process with Montenegro. I am looking forward to our discussion. Thank you for your attention.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for your invitation to discuss Parliament’s resolution on Montenegro. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur for Montenegro, Charles Tannock, for his draft resolution. It is a text that well reflects the assessment in the Commission’s 2014 Progress Report on that country. Let me start with a general remark: for the Commission, the enlargement process is not in doubt. We will work closely with the countries of the region to prepare them for their accession to the European Union. Montenegro was one of the first countries I visited after the start of my mandate and this was the message I delivered to the country’s political leadership.  Two and a half years after the opening of accession negotiations, Montenegro has made progress and has now opened the 16 negotiating chapters. It is also the first country to apply the new approach to the rule of law. Serious shortcomings identified in the progress report have already been addressed by Montenegro through intense work in the weeks following its publication and by the adoption of important legislation on the prevention of corruption. However, adopting legislation is not the cure-all. We have made it clear to Montenegro that the focus now has to be on implementing this legislation. This was also a message during the recent stock-taking on the rule of law which took place in Podgorica.  It is time to shift the focus from processes and procedures to ensuring results on the ground. Such changes should also be felt by individuals in their daily lives. To give you an example, let me mention the protection of persons with disabilities. Despite amending legislation, and making a budget available, access to public buildings for persons with disabilities is still not ensured in an appropriate manner. Legal identity, a functioning independent judicial system and fundamental rights like property rights are necessary – and not only for meeting the rule of law criteria, they are pre-conditions for attracting investment, improving competitiveness and stimulating growth and jobs.  We are also strengthening our economic dialogue with Montenegro. In January the country submitted its economic reform program. This will be the basis of guidance to be adopted by the Council later in the year. Turning now to Montenegro’s foreign policy, I would like to use this opportunity to commend Montenegro’s alignment with the European Union on restrictive measures in the context of Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea and events in Eastern Ukraine. Finally, I want to underline that, through the accession negotiations, and through IPA assistance, the Commission is committed to helping Montenegro reach new standards and meet the various criteria that will make the country ready politically, as well as economically, to join the Union. Overall progress in the accession negotiations will be determined by progress on the rule of law, but we should not underestimate the importance of economic reforms as well.  The Commission will continue to monitor progress in this area closely and report to Parliament and the EU Member States. We count on your support in helping Montenegro to continue on the reform path and deliver results for the benefit of its citizens.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Montenegro, now having opened 16 of the negotiating chapters and provisionally closed 12, is of course far ahead of any of its peers in the region as a candidate country.  These chapters include the all—important Chapters 23 and 24, key to the accession, as they deal with the Justice and Home Affairs rule of law areas of fighting organised crime, for instance, and fighting corruption and upholding generally the rule of law, including the issue of the judiciary; as well as, of course, Chapter 31 regarding foreign policy. In this context Montenegro, very much to its credit, has aligned its foreign policy position with other EU Member States in applying sectoral economic sanctions against Russia in response to Russian aggression against Ukraine. Similarly, Montenegro is supporting the coalition against ISIS in Syria and Iraq in proposing a law now to criminalise those of its citizens who join foreign terrorist groups. The Commission’s progress report highlights a number of other areas where Montenegro has also made progress and the joint resolution that I drafted echoes much of this, for instance, the election of Stankovic last year as a state prosecutor is very welcome. Overall, I am pleased as rapporteur that the resolution reflects a very fair picture of the current state of play for Montenegro; praising its progress where illustrated, and offering advice constructively where improvement is still needed. As one example, for instance, incidents of violence against journalists and media premises has continued this year, but has actually decreased in the terms of total numbers of incidents. So I am pleased that Parliament’s resolution this year has noted this fact. Ensuring a free press is not only of value in its own right in terms of human rights and democracy, but it is also vital in exposing public corruption, an area where we need to see more progress in Montenegro. Montenegro’s commitment to the EU Accession process is a strong one and it will be important politically to retain widespread domestic cross—party support in its endeavours.  The EU acquis communautaire sets very tough benchmarks for the membership of all future Member States but in my view, for now, Montenegro definitely remains on the right track.

name: Андрей Ковачев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I thank rapporteur Charles Tannock for his work on the report and for good cooperation. Montenegro is one of the countries showing progress in a number of areas and has recently opened new negotiating chapters. Work on Chapters 23 and 24 remains key, and reforms in this area will determine the dynamics of future negotiations. Over the past year, a number of decisions have been taken related to the appointment of a Chief Prosecutor, the fight against corruption and the effective work of judges and prosecutors. Montenegro has a vision and an action plan. We now expect concrete measures for the implementation of the legal framework, which will be important for the further integration of the country. Ensuring the rule of law is key to Montenegro's European future. Montenegro is also a good example of the involvement of civil society in preparing for the adoption of European Union law.  At the same time, I expect the authorities to do more to improve the media environment and to detect and stop crimes against journalists. Podgorica should not repeat the mistakes of other countries, where media concentration and business dependencies lead to distortion of information and meaninglessness of democracy. As for the other countries of the Western Balkans, Montenegro is very important to break with the shadows of communism's past and to walk the path of historical reconciliation and good neighbourly relations, which is the only possible option for European integration. Finally, I would like to warmly congratulate Montenegro for sharing jointly and severally the European Union's decisions on the common foreign and security policy, in particular, despite the pressure in the opposite direction with regard to the crisis in Ukraine, sanctions and the fight against Islamic State and terrorism.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the Socialist Group recognises progress in Montenegro's accession negotiations, and welcomes the reforms already implemented or planned by the government. The improvement achieved to date is noted in the fact that sixteen chapters of the negotiations have been opened, while two have already been temporarily closed. The government should first focus on reforms relating to the rule of law, improving public administration and increasing transparency in the political system. As was the objective of our political group from the outset, we urged the government to avoid reform fatigue and to continue its European course unabaalthough. We have called for further progress in the fight against inequality, social exclusion and high unemployment rates. We have intervened with amendments on the elimination of discrimination against women, the Roma minority and people with disabilities. With regard to the Montenegrin economy, we focused on the need to combat tax evasion, unemployment and poverty. The difficult economic situation in the Western Balkans requires the implementation of ambitious programmes that enhance competitiveness and modernise their production base. We did not overlook the government's attention to the importance of protecting the environment. Finally, in view of the current security challenges within and outside Europe's borders, we felt it right to commend Montenegro's positive attitude in the context of the Common Foreign Policy. We are satisfied with the final text of the resolution, which we support. However, we would also like to add an amendment on improving the labour market in Montenegro. The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament strongly supports the European perspective of all the countries of the Western Balkans. We believe that enlargement policy strengthens stability and democracy in the region and that is why it must continue.

name: Jozo Radoš
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Mr. President, colleagues and colleagues, I would like to congratulate and thank Mr. Tannock for his excellent report and good cooperation in drafting it. The ALDE Group strongly supports Montenegro's accession, as well as other Western Balkan countries to the European Union.  The report highlights difficulties and sets goals, but at the same time commends and encourages Montenegro to continue efforts to build an independent judiciary, fight corruption, strengthen media freedom and strengthen the role of civil society.  Montenegro is well ahead of other Western Balkan countries on the road to the European Union and can therefore be an example to other countries along the way, and the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission should, in the example of Montenegro, set uniform and objective criteria for other Western Balkan countries on their way to the European Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, we welcome Montenegro's intention to have a closer relationship with the European Union with the ultimate aim of accession. For us it is a position of principle that any country that meets the Copenhagen criteria and is the wish of its people to join, that we must support this effort.  At the same time, however, we think that the attempt to impose, particularly in a small country, economic or military options, that is, the conditions for a particular economic policy and much more the term for NATO membership are tantamount to bulling, the well-known intimidation, like the one that older students do to the youngest. The European Union must immediately change course so that it does not become in the end a black hole that swallows everything that surrounds it, so that in the end, even this light cannot escape.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tannock, for his very good cooperation and, also from our group, for a good report because it focuses on the fight against corruption and organised crime, the reform of the judiciary, media freedom, and all the things that are important – rights of minorities, gender equality and foreign policy. I also agree with what was said in the report, namely that Montenegro has made progress in recent years and I am glad that already 16 chapters have been opened. Nevertheless, I would like to state here as well what is in this report because it says that the fight against corruption and organised crime is, and will be, the litmus test for an independent, efficient and professional judiciary in the country. I hope we will see more progress here in the future. There are also positive things in the report and positive progress in the country with regard to an end to discrimination, where the Roma and LGBTI people are concerned. And yet hatred, hate speech and fear—mongering still exist. I would nevertheless like to say that I appreciate that the government of Montenegro has made very clear statements and also taken action in the fight against hatred against LGBTI people, and will be hosting a high-level ministerial meeting in Budva at the beginning of May on the fight against homophobia with European Union and enlargement countries. There is one thing I would have especially liked to see more of in the report, and that is ecology and the environment. Of course, Montenegro’s Constitution states that it is an ecological state, and we appreciate that. But nevertheless, more than 25% of Europe’s biodiversity is in the Western Balkans, and the last remaining free—flowing rivers in Europe. So I really would appreciate it if the government of Montenegro would stop reconsidering plans to build hydropower plants, affecting wild rivers, without having first implemented the sustainable hydropower guiding principles of the Danube River Protection Convention. Finally, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for his very clear statement that there is no doubt that the integration process will continue. For there is one amendment that we have proposed for all four reports where we regret that the now—President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, during the election campaign, said there would be no enlargement for the next five years. To conclude, I hope that we will not demotivate people in the region further, but really encourage them to go forward with the integration process.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Like many others in this House, I am certainly very much in favour of Montenegro's accession to the European Union, and we naturally take a very positive view of the progress already made by previous speakers in the negotiations.  However, I wanted to highlight two environmental points. Construction of an undersea link between Tivat and Pescara began at the end of January. As much as EUR 775 000 000 per 390 kilometres of cable: 25 kilometres will be not underwater but on the coasts of the two countries. In addition to the great environmental impact, major problems of lack of transparency and the risk of corruption have been raised on this project.  At the same time, just today, Tuesday 10, a demonstration took place in the coastal city of Budva by environmental organisations against the decision to exploit marine hydrocarbons, just as has been happening for several months in Croatia too, because they could jeopardise the very strong tourist vocation of Montenegro, Croatia and us Italians who are their neighbours on the other side of the Adriatic. We therefore fully agree with the doubts raised by the citizens of Montenegro: yes to tourism, yes to the protection of the ecosystem; the Adriatic into a polluted oil puddle.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Mr. Castaldo, I've wanted to ask Mrs. Lunacek that question before, but now you've taught me the end. Namely, here we are constantly talking about renewable energy sources, about the need for green energy and I agree that the big problem is too many possible dams in the Balkans. However, Montenegro can produce a lot of green energy that Italy needs, because Italy does not have good energy sources, and so I ask you if you agree with me that we need to find a good compromise between the exploitation of green energy in the Balkans that can be useful for EU members?

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, thank you for your question. Absolutely, but the compromise is good in my opinion when the environmental impact is kept to a minimum, because we must not forget that countries such as Croatia, Italy and Montenegro, because of their history, because of our culture, have an eminent tourist vocation that absolutely must be defended. So, as I said earlier, the development of renewable energies is absolutely important, we strongly believe in this energy model and we work together intelligently and without hasty choices, in order to reduce environmental risk to the lowest possible level.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Union continues to fund accession candidates at a time when many people are suffering the economic consequences of its policy. It's completely unfair and even suicidal, I would say. It imposes its directives, its dogmas to which we must not deviate. Uniformity is therefore in progress, you must even follow your diplomatic positions on Ukraine, among others. As agriculture is one of the funded sectors, it will therefore have to meet the standards set out by the CAP. In light of the criticisms in this report on good administrative management, we can ask ourselves questions about the application of standards as our farmers fall under control.  You are financing the development of an agriculture whose products will compete directly with ours in our markets. In this case, with Montenegro, it is wine and, of course, fruits and vegetables. Already last year, you organized unfair competition from the grain sector with your support for Ukrainian wheat.  You are therefore pursuing a policy of systematic destruction of our agriculture and the enlargements you are preparing will make the situation worse. It's just disgusting!  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
text: "blue card" question. Mr Loiseau, if I understood you correctly, you said that the project of integration with the Balkans is suicidal. We are here in Strasbourg, a city between France and Germany. Do you not think that the Balkan integration project complements the project of integration of the countries of Europe, in order not to know in the future wars as there have been in the former Yugoslavia?

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. "Madam, I am thinking first of all of French agriculture and French farmers. I am one of them, because I am a farmer myself. In France, we are under the full force of unfair competition from European and even non-European countries, since we are also talking about importing fruit and vegetables from Turkey, Moldova, Montenegro, today, and so on... This situation is becoming unbearable for our producers. I go to see them regularly in the field and that is what they tell me. It's unbearable for France. That is what I have to say to you, ma'am.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I would like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr. Tannock and Mr. Kovacev for their excellent work, and I express in particular my satisfaction that the amendments of the Croatian EPP delegation have been fully accepted, either as a compromise or as an individual one. We have also heard the Commission's opinion and the Council's opinion and I hope that everything is clear from this. However, I would like to make a few notes. As stated in the resolution, we from the Croatian delegation will continue to insist on preserving good-budgetary relations, resolving bilateral issues at an early stage of negotiations, with special emphasis on outstanding issues with Croatia. In particular, I would like to point out the call to speed up the resolution of border issues around Prevlaka, but also to do everything to protect the multinational identity of Boka Kotorska. We are sending a message that more serious efforts are being made to solve cases for punishing war crimes, so we expect the competent authorities to conduct effective investigations without delay and to condemn those who have committed crimes, all in accordance with international norms. Although it is impossible to compensate for the pain caused by torture caused only two and a half decades ago in Montenegrin camps, it is encouraging that the text nevertheless includes an appeal by the Society of Serb and Montenegrin Concentration Camp in Dubrovnik for adequate and emancipable indemnity for Croatian campers in Montenegro. That is why I encourage montenegrin authorities to take seriously the messages of the Montenegrin Parliament, while Croatia, on the other hand, will continue to support Montenegro's European path by sharing our experiences on accession negotiations.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as has already been remarked, Montenegro is a comparatively small country but it has a very big commitment to becoming the next member of the European Union, and you can feel that very strongly when you talk with Montenegrin civil society, with Montenegrin politicians from both the government and the opposition, and with the public in general. As chair of Parliament’s delegation to Montenegro, I believe we, as the European Parliament, also have to show a clear commitment to Montenegro’s future in the EU, provided it continues to undertake reforms, both on paper and, importantly, in practice. I think this resolution does send the right signals, and I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on it and his inclusive and thorough approach.  There are, of course, many areas of concern that remain, as are remarked on within the report. Some of these have already been mentioned by the Council around the issue of corruption, and particularly high-level corruption, but I would like also to focus on the issue of unemployment. Currently within Montenegro that is above 19% and it is particularly a problem for young people, as is the incidence of in—work poverty as well.  Just to finish, we also have to place the promotion of human rights and equality at the heart of the accession process, so I was very pleased that some amendments I submitted along with colleagues have made it into this report – firstly calling for the strengthening of institutions in charge of promoting human rights and anti-discrimination, like the Ombudsman, while also saying we need to have a greater focus on gender and LGBTI equality when we assess progress towards accession. Finally, we do need to strengthen the rights of people with disabilities in Montenegro. I was very pleased to hear the Commissioner single out this group in his comments. Colleagues, I think Montenegro is leading the way amongst EU candidate countries and with this resolution we send a strong message to Montenegro that we will continue to support it, provided that progress continues, and we will be watching it closely in the months and years to come.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, Montenegro is on the right track. We have all concluded this and Montenegro can become a great example to other countries in the Western Balkans, and how many accidents we had in the Western Balkans just a few decades ago – I don't think there is a need to talk about it specifically. I would even say that Montenegro is trying to act like it is a member of the European Union and I would like to emphasize that the topic I have put forward in the form of amendments and I am glad that it has been accepted is one of the key ones at the moment, which is: Montenegro is practically the only country that has access to the open sea in the northern part of the Mediterranean and is not a member of the NATO alliance. In this context, as much as this topic may not be up for discussion at the moment and here, but it is nevertheless a major security issue, I call on the Commission, all member states and all of us to do something in this direction.  And today I learned something new: the great France is afraid of Montenegrin agriculture. Colleague, I think you know very little about Montenegro and their agriculture.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: – At the moment, in my view, a further enlargement of the Union is not realistic. However, the states with which we are negotiating possible entry should receive a clear signal that the possibility still exists. All the more so when we talk about the region of the former Yugoslavia, from which some republics are already part of the European Union.  Of the group of states seeking to join the European Union, In my opinion, Montenegro is the most active in the negotiations. According to the available and comparable criteria, even the furthest. With some exaggeration, it can also be argued that Montenegro even uses the euro as its currency, but without a corresponding agreement with the European Union.  Despite the apparent progress, a number of persistent serious problems cannot be seen, in particular the implementation of the basic rules of the rule of law, the more effective reduction of corruption or the prevention of linking government with crime.  Our common task is to help our Montenegrian friends solve these problems, thus opening up a more realistic chance for eventual entry.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (NI).
text: Mr President, the Union wants enlargement at all costs. In fact, it wants, through enlargement, to obey the injunctions of NATO and the Americans. In this case, democracy, law, criminal mafias are forgotten, everything is forgotten! Mr Djukanovic, a communist and the new Prime Minister, is suspected by the European Anti-Fraud Office of various serious and even very serious frauds in trafficking of all kinds. Let's forget about it! We forget the systematic electoral fraud, the attacks on NGOs denounced by Transparency, we forget the murder of journalists! All this is normal in the process of European democratic cleansing. Our European institutions always use the dual language of morally oriented and manipulated pruritus.  Let us stop this European policy which, from Kosovo to Montenegro, legitimizes crime and mafias to create criminal states and mafia states!

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: Madam President, I greet Commissioner Hahn. The fact that in three years of negotiations Montenegro has 16 chapters open and 2 chapters temporarily closed, points to an excellent dynamic of reforms and changes in the state and society as a whole. I support the European Commission's demands to improve monetary and fiscal policy and to manage public finances as well as possible, as this is important for montenegro's quality, smart and strategic growth and development.  Only a good economic governance system required in Chapter 17 and a financial management and control system e.g. Chapter 32 are the cornerstone of successful integration into the European Union single market. In addition, the precondition for economic development and growth is an independent judiciary, the rule of law and the fight against corruption, and I support the continuation of reforms and harmonisation of legislation in these areas.  As a neighbouring country, we look forward to Montenegro's entry into the European Union with the emphasis that it is important to make efforts to prosecute war crimes, and to resolve bilateral issues as soon as possible in the spirit of good neighbourly relations - here I think especially of the border with Croatia in the coating section.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I obviously agree with the comments made in the report on Montenegro's progress in 2014, and I would particularly like to thank Mr Tannock for his timely work on this issue.  I recently visited the country, noting for myself the willingness of the Montenegrin authorities to cooperate with the European Union. The country's efforts to achieve full integration of the European context and the desire to take further steps in the fight against discrimination, corruption and organised crime are being sensed.  The 2014-2015 action plan for public administration reform and judicial reform goes in the desired direction. There are, of course, still many problems: Montenegro should strengthen the effectiveness of active labour policies, improve the quality of education and, above all, strengthen health and social health infrastructures. The next institutional visit scheduled for April will certainly give us the opportunity for even more detailed verification and will enable us to deepen the issues raised concerning the environment and energy.

name: Mario Borghezio (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission, the Council and the rapporteur give us a totally watered-down view of the situation: apart from a speech I did not hear just now, I have not heard the word 'mafia' in the whole report. Yet recently milo Đukanović's government was referred to by two Italian prosecutors who were experts in the international cigarette smuggling trade as 'to be careful'. And a recent report by the Italian secret services points to this country as a dangerous country, which could host Islamic terrorists. It is a country in which there is no rule of law if it is true, as it is true, that investors are being binned by the State, as in the recent, egregious case of the sale of a foundry, so there is no legal protection for those who invest. One billion euros is the credit of those who have invested in Montenegro: European companies that have invested in Montenegro have been scammed.  This is a situation of absolute lack of law; so you are crazy to want this state under these conditions in the European Union.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Montenegro is currently the fastest towards the European Union. It is the only country in the region to have opened 16 chapters in negotiations with the EU, including Chapter 24 on the rule of law. It has also already suspended two, including education and culture. When I was Minister of Education, I had the opportunity to work with the school authorities of Montenegro, which at the time followed modern trends. It is right that the Report of the European Parliament, prepared by Mr Tannock, highlights the positive aspects of Montenegro's rapprochement with the European Union. It is also important that we also know the poor qualities or shortcomings of this process. Above all, Montenegro will have to do more for the freedom of the media landscape.
