According to the World Media Freedom Index, it was 114th out of 180 countries last year.  The justice system should be more effective in the fight against corruption and organised crime. The reforms adopted must be translated into progress in practice. And thirdly, it will have to pay more attention to the revival of parliamentary work. Without it, there is no democracy. I believe that the pro-European and pro-democracy mindset and practice in Montenegro will win and that the country will successfully complete the process of integration into the European Union. I also wish them every success in their efforts to join NATO, which will certainly have a beneficial effect on the security situation and stability in the region. I am particularly pleased that security and foreign policy is already in line with the European Union.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by saying that I support Montenegro's efforts as a candidate country to become a full member of the European Union. As a Member for Slovakia, I also fully understand Montenegro's difficulties in fulfilling the difficult tasks of the accession process, because as a small country that in the past belonged to a union of several states of different nationalities, faiths or ethnic groups, it does not have a simple situation as a state with 600 000 inhabitants. I appreciate the progress made by Montenegro in 2014, the reforms adopted, whether in the area of the judiciary or the new law on the financing of political parties. But important challenges remain before it, I will mention some – they have already been mentioned: eradicating corruption, depoliticising public administration, increasing transparency at all levels of governance and more. The accession process is demanding and requires deep, often very unpopular measures for the population, but I believe that Montenegro will manage all this and become a credible partner of the other Member States.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam President, respected colleague Hahn, first of all I would like to thank my fellow rapporteur Charles Tannock for a very high-quality report on Montenegro's progress in the European integration process, especially bearing in mind the fact that Montenegro is a country that negotiates according to the new methodology of negotiations that was created on the basis of Croatia's experience.  The fact is that already at the beginning of the negotiations, chapters 23 and 24 were included among these 16 chapters, therefore 2 key systemic chapters that should give us confidence in the legal system and the functioning of Montenegro in general as a state by European standards, is extremely good.  In this regard, I agree with suggestions of a report on strengthening media freedom, democracy in Montenegro, quality dialogue between the authorities and the opposition. I particularly welcome Montenegro's accession to the EU's foreign policy positions, as this is on the line of the idea of Montenegro becoming a NATO member as well.  I also advocate for the multinational character of Boka Kotorska and respect for minority rights, especially croats in Montenegro. In any case, Montenegro will have our strong support on the road to the European Union.

name: Marek Plura (PPE).
text: – I would like to congratulate the Montenegrin Government on its progress in the accession negotiations. I am also pleased that the European Commission has improved the situation of people with disabilities in its report. This is very important, especially in terms of the government's implementation of its integration policy towards this group of citizens. However, like Commissioner Hahn, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the number of public buildings, including medical and educational centres, is still insufficiently adapted to the needs of people with disabilities. Similarly, legislation on the prohibition of discrimination against persons with disabilities still has gaps and the financial resources allocated to employers employing them are insufficiently protected against abuse. As the report shows, the Montenegrin Government still faces many challenges, but I am sure that this government will be able to achieve its objectives with its current determination.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as stated by the Commission, more efforts need to be made by the Montenegrin Government to combat corruption, fight organised crime, ensure transparent elections and reform the judiciary. Moreover, the Montenegrin Government must also ensure that recent attacks on journalists be promptly investigated and that urgent prosecutions follow. However, I believe, considering the progress that Montenegro has made since embarking upon accession negotiations, that these negotiations should not slow down if Montenegro succeeds in acting upon the recommendations of the Commission. I welcome last week’s statement by Prime Minister Milo Đukanović regarding the admission of Montenegro to the NATO alliance, the further progress made by the country in establishing a functioning market economy, and the Commission’s conclusion that Montenegro meets the political criteria for EU membership: all this has to be praised. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: blue card issue. – My question concerns Serbia, an important country in the region, which is itself a candidate country for the European Union. How do you assess the recent impact of Serbia on its neighbours? Is it supportive on the way to the European Union, or is there something else to see?

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I think that you should wait, because a little later we are going to speak about Serbia as well. In any case, I would like to tell you that we cannot afford, as Member States of the European Union, to leave a big hole in the middle of Europe. All of these former Yugoslavian countries and Albania in the end, step by step, have to become members of the European Union. We do not know when, but it is a yes.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, we welcome the negotiations between Montenegro and the European Union in order to implement Montenegro's accession to the Union. Greece supports Montenegro's European perspective and as early as 2011 signed a cooperation agreement to provide know-how on European Union issues.  Of course, within Montenegro there are political tensions with the opposition abstaining from specific parliamentary work. At the same time there is a negative climate in the economy, since we have increased unemployment, while there are very serious phenomena and problems of corruption, but also action of organised crime.  Finally, it should be noted that Montenegro's European course must also include solving problems that Montenegro has with its neighbouring countries, and this resolution must be done in a constructive manner and in a spirit of good neighbourliness.

name: Илхан Кючюк (
text: ALDE). – It is indisputable that Montenegro is closest to membership of the European Union among the Western Balkan countries. The progress the country has made over the past year is distinct. Already, 16 negotiating chapters have been opened, including chapters 23 and 24 on fundamental rights and justice, as well as Chapter 31 on foreign defence policy. Montenegro's foreign policy is fully in line with the European Union's foreign and defence policy.  Of course, the progress made carries additional responsibilities. Montenegro must continue with the reform process. The government and the opposition need to improve dialogue with each other in the name of nationwide themes such as the rule of law, the fight against corruption and media freedom. Welcoming the Efforts of the European Commission, I would like to state that the European project will not be civilly completed if the Western Balkans are not part of it. Full integration goes through the membership of all countries in the region in NATO and the European Union.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Indeed, the excellent report on Montenegro's progress balances all those aspects that we have already pointed out. From issues of corruption, crime, justice, freedom of the media, expression, minority rights, gender equality, foreign policy... And all these chapters that Montenegro has opened and many of them have already closed, it shows that integration and convergence in the European Union are also moving very fast. But there are still a few chapters to draw attention to. And one of these chapters is also – which is not explicitly written, but is visible – is attitudes towards the environment. Namely, attitude towards the environment, towards renewable energy sources, and I think that this will be one of the key things for the future of Montenegro, especially as we know that it is not a brilliant economic situation at the moment and that there are many unemployed, especially among young people. And I think that precisely this attitude towards the environment, and of course the protection of those pearls that Montenegro has, can guarantee it in the long term then also increase employability and reduce the economic crisis.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Commissioner, Council, the work done by Mr Tannock is certainly a good progress report. But I see some confusion on the subject of enlargement to Montenegro, because Commission President Juncker has said that during these five years there will be no enlargement: neither with regard to Montenegro nor with regard to any other state. There are those who are against Montenegro's entry, but it is for a united Europe; there are those who are for Montenegro inside but it should be against the other states of Europe, so I see some confusion.  Surely what many members have already said about the progress made by Montenegro is right, the situation of which is probably even better in terms of certain protections than in the Member States of the European Union. As far as the completion of a united, shall we say, united Europe is concerned, but on other assumptions which should be respect for the rule of law and also for the welfare state ( this also applies to all Member States). It is important that the Balkans are included and not just montenegro's outlet to the sea, because Albania is also on that side. So let's hope we get on with these processes quickly.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me conclude by reiterating my appreciation to the Parliament and especially the rapporteur Mr Tannock, for the work on Montenegro. Your resolution captures the basic elements of our policy towards that country and the acknowledgment of the achievements that have been possible, but it also sends a clear message on what needs to be done now. This year, Montenegro should continue working on rule of law issues and focus on delivering results. Results should include direct recourse in the fight against corruption and organised crime, as several speakers have said. At the same time, we expect Montenegro to continue working on meeting the opening benchmarks set in challenging areas such as competition, the environment, climate change and food safety. The opening benchmarks provide clear guidance on what needs to be done. For the chapters that have already been opened, we will work with Montenegro in helping the country meet the closing benchmarks. We have a challenging programme ahead of us and the support of this House will be instrumental in completing it. Next month our Joint Parliamentary Committee will meet again in Podgorica. This will be a good opportunity to take stock of what has been achieved in Montenegro since the last meeting in December and to present the challenges ahead. Let us be clear, it is up to each candidate country to ensure that there is progress in the reforms necessary for its accession to the Union. It is up to each candidate country to ensure that these reforms bring results that help improve the lives of its citizens. The Commission can offer, and does offer, its technical know—how, its expertise and, of course, financial assistance in meeting the challenges of the accession process. Strong political will and determination will be needed from Montenegro to make progress. This will be required not only of the government but of the whole political system. Montenegro’s cross-party consensus on EU accession is a major asset in this endeavour. I was reassured about this during my last visit to that country, when I had the opportunity to meet the European Affairs Committee of the Montenegro Parliament. This was further evidence that Montenegro and the whole of Montenegrin society is trying to meet all the challenges in order to make significant progress when it comes to the future accession of the country. Once again, and to stress it again and again, the announcement of President Juncker that there will be no enlargement during this period does not mean we are not following up on all the necessary negotiations. It is more about the process than about negotiations, and what we have discussed and what you have discussed today on Montenegro, and what we will discuss imminently with other countries, is proof that it is about the process and less about the negotiations. It is about helping countries catch up, to meet European standards and to be ready and mature enough to join the European Union at a given moment.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, our debate today showed general support for the European Parliament’s resolution on the Commission’s progress report. We seem to agree on the point that the work with potential accession countries should continue towards democratic reforms and closer European integration. I am pleased that the speakers, like the Council, praised the efforts by Montenegro to align with the common foreign and security policy. The Council also attaches particular importance to the area of the rule of law and fundamental rights and has urged Montenegro to tackle the issues of concern identified by the Commission, especially the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime. The Council thoroughly assessed the action plans which Montenegro prepared in order to meet the opening benchmarks for the chapters on the judiciary and fundamental rights and on justice, freedom and security. They were of good quality and allowed us to get to the next stage and open the negotiations in these two key chapters. The action plans were revised in February 2015 and re—worked to calibrate and adjust them, with implications for the interim benchmarks set for these chapters. We also agreed that freedom of speech and media independence is one of the fundamental values of the European agenda. It is essential that all attacks on media representatives be properly investigated in order to ensure freedom of expression and citizens’ trust in public institutions. As a Presidency, we are continuing the work on accession negotiations with Montenegro and are looking forward to opening new chapters during our Presidency. So far, the accession negotiations process with Montenegro has been quite dynamic. Nevertheless, in order to ensure the further opening of new chapters, Montenegro needs to deliver tangible results in the rule of law area. The Council, as already mentioned, now expects Montenegro to keep up the momentum and intensify its efforts to move forward with the reforms and their effective implementation. We look forward to further cooperation with the European Parliament and the Commission on this subject.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: in writing. – Montenegro is the leader in the accession process, and should be encouraged to continue the good work. This progress is recorded in the fact that 16 chapters are opened, two provisionally closed, and more to be opened this year. Furthermore we should appreciate Montenegro’s clear alignment with the EU’s CFSP and its positive role played in the region, especially with respect to good neighbourly relations. However, there are a number of outstanding issues that require our attention and work from our Montenegrin partners. We continue to pay attention to further advances in the rule of law, fight against organised crime and corruption and judicial reform. We should also strive to support the Parliament’s role in the EU integration process, especially its overseeing role. We should also continue to advocate a media environment that is free of political interference and one in which journalists can freely conduct their profession.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 2014 progress report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (2014/2948(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me first thank the rapporteur, Ivo Vajgl, for his work. Like the Parliament in its draft resolution, the Council, in December 2014, welcomed the fact that the EU agenda remained the strategic priority of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. But we note that it will require strong political will and commitment on the part of politicians from the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to continue the implementation of the EU—related reforms. The Council broadly shares the view that the country has achieved a high level of alignment with the legislative acquis. However, I would point out that the Council Conclusions of December 2014 emphasised serious concerns about an increasing politicisation of state institutions and growing shortcomings in relation to the independence of the judiciary and to media freedoms. Failure to deliver on these issues has damaged the sustainability of reforms. We will continue to emphasise that the rule of law, fundamental rights and media freedom are at the heart of the enlargement process and that it is essential that candidate countries take decisive, rapid action to address the challenges. As shown by the latest developments, political crises between government and opposition parties are recurrent. The Council shares the view expressed in Parliament’s draft resolution that a more constructive and inclusive political dialogue is needed. I would urge both the government and the opposition in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to demonstrate political responsibility and engage in a constructive dialogue in order to resolve all the issues that remain open and to accelerate the reform process in line with European standards. Concerning the inter—ethnic situation, greater trust between the communities needs to be built. The Ohrid Framework Agreement continues to be an essential element for democracy and rule of law in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. We would remind you that the review of the Ohrid Framework Agreement needs to be completed rapidly and its recommendations need to be implemented. The Council reiterates that maintaining good neighbourly relations remains an essential part of European integration. This includes a negotiated and mutually accepted solution to the name issue, under the auspices of the United Nations. We call for progress towards bringing the longstanding discussions on this issue to a definitive conclusion without delay. In the light of the overall importance of maintaining good neighbourly relations, it is essential to continue high—level contacts between the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Bulgaria, and to translate them into concrete action and results. Finally, let me add that the Council broadly shares the Commission’s assessment that the political criteria continue to be sufficiently met, on the basis of the cumulative progress achieved. The Council also took note of the Commission’s recommendation, reflected in Parliament’s draft resolution, that accession negotiations should be opened. With a view to a possible decision by the European Council to open such negotiations, the Council will return to the issue at some time this year, on the basis of an update by the Commission on the implementation of reforms. This will take into account the High—Level Accession Dialogue and the tangible steps taken to promote good neighbourly relations and to reach a negotiated and mutually accepted solution to the name issue. Progress in all these areas will be conducive to reaching a positive decision among the EU Member States.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to acknowledge the report which has been prepared by your rapporteur Ivo Vajgl, which to a large extent corresponds to the findings of our 2014 progress report on the country. I welcome the supportive stance the European Parliament has taken towards the country’s efforts in the accession process. In our progress report we repeated our recommendation to open accession negotiations but raised our serious concerns about selective justice, problems with the freedom of expression, politicisation and the lack of constructive political dialogue in the country. The current political crisis has further exacerbated all these issues. I will come to this in a second. As the draft resolution points out, the level of alignment with the EU acquis remains high, but decisive action is required from Skopje to address backsliding in several key areas. I share your concerns that delays in setting a date for the start of accession negotiations have added to the frustration of the population in the country and also affected the sustainability of previous reforms as well as the leverage of the Union as such. As regards the current political events in the country, I visited Skopje in February and expressed my very serious concerns to all political leaders. All of them must step back from the brink. They are all playing with the future of their country. In my frequent and on—going contacts with the political leadership and the opposition, I continue to urge political actors to engage in constructive dialogue within the parliament, focusing on the strategic priorities of the country and all its citizens. They have no time to lose. I also reiterated that investigations are to be conducted by the proper authorities, notably the judiciary, in a manner that is totally independent, transparent and rapid with full regard for due process and the presumption of innocence. In this respect, I welcome any initiative taken by European political party groups and individual MEPs to help overcome the crisis and welcome their willingness to engage further. The Commission will work closely with the MEPs in this respect. I would like to reiterate that the Commission stands ready to provide support, while fully insisting on the separation of powers. The Commission could support efforts to improve checks and balances and address failures, for instance through the assessment on continued concerns about the independence of justice.  Meanwhile, irrespective of the origins of the wiretapping, which needs to be investigated, any potential wrongdoing revealed, along with its disturbing content, must be investigated and appropriate consequences must be taken, especially if it fundamentally impinges on the rule of law and separation of powers.  At a time when public trust in institutions is low, all public figures must act responsibly and take accountability for their actions in their own interest. Turning to the issue of good neighbourly relations, I agree with you that it is an essential part of the country’s progress towards the European Union. While the country has good relations with its Western Balkan neighbours, relations with Greece and Bulgaria remain affected. It is of the utmost importance that there are continued efforts to improve the overall climate for cooperation and trust. Good neighbourly relations remain an essential part of the enlargement process and the EU’s own history shows that working out compromises on contested issues is the best way to enhance regional cooperation and move forward. I would also like to use this opportunity to highlight the importance of maintaining good inter—ethnic relations. They remain fundamental for the very functioning of the country and its EU perspective. To build on the positive lessons learned so far, the review of the Ohrid Framework Agreement is important and should be soon converted into policy recommendations. Finally, let me stress that renewed efforts from all sides are needed to improve relations and trust between parties, and these need to be friendly. Therefore, I urge all parties to respect the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary and freedom of the press.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – You have made it easier for me to appear in these two minutes as rapporteur, with very substantive and very, very gratifying views, ersy views on Macedonia's progress on the way to the European Union. With the resolution to be discussed today, we would like to confirm the continuation of the european Union's constructive enlargement policy to the Western Balkans. With the European perspective of the remaining countries of the former Yugoslavia, we want to contribute to the last stabilisation of the area where the last armed conflict in Europe, with tragic consequences, was raging before the current war in Ukraine. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs and all the colleagues who have proposed amendments and contributed to a politically balanced resolution. On the principle that each candidate country will be judged on its achievements and qualities, the resolution supports the following: the opening of negotiations for membership of the European Union, the lifting of the blockade in the Council and the resolution of bilateral issues, such as the problem of the name of the country, separate from the negotiations, but in time before the conclusion of the accession negotiations. The long-standing stalemate in the union is one of the reasons for the current severe crisis of trust between the political forces in Macedonia. This crisis also leads to obstruction of the national parliament and serious accusations of abuses, violations of laws and the constitution, human rights and freedom of the media. Macedonia will have to deal responsibly with the gravity of its political crisis, establish a system of parliamentary democracy that will work and a system in which the European perspective is guided and targeted. Honourable colleagues, I call on you to support the resolution.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Madam President, I understand the efforts of the Presidency, the Commissioner and the rapporteur of the report to help the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia on the road to democracy. However, I have to say that the rapporteur should be more careful. Do not use the name "Macedonia" first of all. And he should bear in mind, having seen all the documents, that his position on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is also related to the United Nations resolution of 817 of 1993, which defines the name of Skopje and FYROM as the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.  And it is not a bilateral issue, it is an international issue and the name issue is dealt with as an international issue. Now, I have the following comments to make. The European Commission, as the Presidency has said, is finding a setback in the areas of freedom of expression, the media and the independence of the judiciary. The Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe also notes the politicisation of state institutions, government control of the media even in the context of elections. There's the 25,000 eavesdropping scandal. There is the Ohrid agreement, and the Presidency has also mentioned, which does not respect minority issues.  Madam President, in these cases and situations, at least we cannot accept the opening of accession negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.

name: Richard Howitt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I have been proud to serve as rapporteur on the progress report for this country, and I want to make it clear that I, like my group, continue to support setting a date for EU accession talks to begin. We thank the new rapporteur, Mr Vajgl, for his continuity on this and other points. However, I am forced to use my speech now as shadow rapporteur to express my, and my group’s, deep concern about the impact that the current political crisis in the country is having on the prospects for realising the aim of opening talks. My group recognises that we ourselves have a responsibility to avoid adding to the polarising forces in the country, which is why I worked with my PPE Group colleagues to secure the 1 March 2013 agreement, and why I have expressed my willingness, if asked, to do so again now. In saying that, I am conscious that success would require genuine political will on both sides and that the long—term interests require functioning political institutions within the country, rather than reliance on external assistance. But let me make some things very clear: the announcement of charges and the threat of imprisonment against the leader of the opposition in the country – the leader of the sister party of the group of parties which I represent in this Chamber – is a dangerous moment for democracy in this country. For the charges to be announced by the Prime Minister personally only adds to the concerns generated following the evidence of tapes released in relation to apparent gross political interference in the country’s judiciary and media. Tonight, the opposition party is publishing further evidence – this time alleging electoral malpractice on behalf of the governing party – while the governing party has a simultaneous press conference alleging bribery on behalf of the leader of the opposition. We, in this Chamber, do not want to be drawn into a spiral of allegations and counter—allegations, nor into the conflicting explanations about the provenance of the tapes; but there is no doubt that mass surveillance has taken place and that at least some of the evidence produced is genuine. We cannot ignore that evidence and nor can the Commissioner. There is a sad history in this country, in this region and in other parts of Europe, of systems of surveillance and of charges being brought against individuals for political purposes. These practices have no place today, in this country or in Europe. If further promises of remedial judicial reform are made now – when the same promises have been made before and not fulfilled – there would have to be new elements of monitoring and review to create confidence within the country and credibility outside it. There must be political will on both sides to resolve this crisis, and this crisis must be resolved.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: blue card issue. – A few years ago, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia was one of the success stories in the Western Balkans. Everything developed well, only positive ratings and announcements came in, and then every year Macedonia's desire to join the European Union was rejected, even though it had long been a candidate. How do you estimate how much of what you have said now – that things have become worse – that the expectations of Macedonian society for the start of accession talks with the European Union have been deceived?

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I do agree with my honourable colleague and I say to the President—in—Office of the Council, that I have taken part in these debates over several years and heard the same speech from successive Councils. There are now 15 Member States in the Council of Ministers who want to move forward on this country. I do not accept responsibility here for what is happening today in this country, but we should accept that we have contributed to the conditions where this political crisis has been generated and I ask the current Presidency to do better than its predecessors in actually making good the words that she has shared with us tonight.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – There is no doubt that the perspective of our western neighbour is European, but what I ask and want you to pay attention to is the following. The Government in Skopje must be made very clear that European membership means European responsibilities. These European responsibilities mean one thing – respect for the rights and legitimate interests of all ethnic communities on the territory of the state, including the Bulgarian one.  I would like to draw your attention, however, that there is no good neighbourly treaty between our two countries, and it is key because it requires a few simple things – stopping Skopje's hate speech, stopping Skopje's distortion of history, recognising the rights and legitimate interests of all communities, including the Bulgarian language. , be able to associate with public organisations and their own political organisations. All these issues are key to the continuation of the European perspective of our western neighbour, which we accept as a brotherly state.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, on the occasion of today's resolution on FYROM, I wonder. Are we here to serve and defend the basic values and principles of the European Union at least, or are we simply ratifying even decisions that directly conflict with them? Today's resolution on FYROM confirms my concern but also offends our logic. While noting FYROM's undeniable regression in all priority areas in relation to the Copenhagen political criteria, such as the rule of law, democratic institutions, freedom of speech, the media, etc., what does it ultimately do? It sums up all those negatives that have gotten worse in the last year and calls them progress. The nomenclature, an international issue which remains, as it should, under the auspices of the UN and concerns regional security and stability in the context of good neighbourly relations, arbitrarily calls it bilateral. And the culmination of the absurdity is that all these negatives, which do not allow accession negotiations to begin, claim that they happen and get worse precisely because they are delayed. And he suggests they start. If it's possible! Ladies and gentlemen, beyond any political analysis and position, I ask you to vote against the text, at least defending our dignity and our logic. It is certain that policies of such discounts on the basic values and principles of the European Union, policies of two measures and stations, where appropriate interests, undermine the credibility of the European Union for enlargement policy.

name: Tamás Meszerics
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, first of all let me congratulate the rapporteur on this very balanced and constructively negotiated report. I appreciate both his work and the text that has come out of it. My group is going to support the resolution, first of all because we seriously believe that there is no real alternative in the Western Balkans to EU accession. There is no conceivable political alternative, and there is no conceivable economic or social alternative, if the region is to be what Europe is good at – at peace with itself and with its neighbours. There is, as the Commissioner rightly pointed out, a grave political crisis in Macedonia, which is real and dangerous. However, this real and dangerous crisis is just yet another illustration of the fact that a long—drawn—out negotiation process, with a large number of issues that actually polarise politics and societies in the region, is something we need to deal with directly. Macedonia needs our help to overcome this political crisis, and I wish that everybody in this Chamber were willing to contribute to the resolution of the crisis instead of making it worse. Macedonia may have been much more of a success story a few years back, but the problems identified in the progress report are actually common to all the Western Balkan countries under the accession process. The rule of law, freedom of the media, administrative reforms: all these are problems in all the other accession countries in precisely the same way that they are in Macedonia. As for good neighbourly relations, these are very important in the region traditionally, but they happen to be dependent on two neighbours. Good neighbourly relations are not just one country’s responsibility, and one of the countries concerned in this case could, for example, comply with the ruling of the International Court of Justice of 5 December 2011 – the symbolic issue might then become easier to resolve. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Meszerics, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia or as we who lived in the former Yugoslavia, simply call the Republic of Macedonia not wanting to hurt anyone in this home, because it is only part of our common history.  I ask you as a former minister for European integration of the Republic of Croatia, in 2000 Macedonia, together with Croatia, started the European path, you said macedonia should be helped.  Do you think Macedonia should have been helped more by the European Union and do you see our guilt in all this?

name: Tamás Meszerics
text: blue card answer. –  Well I can just repeat what I have already said, that good neighbourly relations depend on good neighbours, and there are at least two of them in each case.  On the other hand, this is a part of the world which has a long tradition of animosity springing out of a shared, but contested, history. We cannot help this. What we can help with is actually overcoming the traumas of the shared history. Let me remind you that if anybody 20 years ago had said that here in the European Parliament building we would be discussing the accession of Yugoslav countries, this would have been considered insane at that moment. Let us pause and think about that for a while.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I will deliberately call it Macedonia, as the High Representative Federica Mogherini did a few days ago, because I believe that this region is called Macedonia. It does not matter if the international diatribe causes the acronym FYROM to make it the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, because it would be like saying that the United States of America cannot be called America. I think that in 2015 it is a little absurd to discuss terminology and names. This accession process is emerging for years, because there is a sense of frustration among macedonian citizens which can cause – and Commissioner Hahn rightly said – a deterioration in the internal situation in the country. So I hope this situation unlocks. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: On the blue cards, I will only allow one for each speaker.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), "blue card" question. – Obviously the main colleague would have been in another place all this time, because otherwise he could not be so hypocritical and say that it is the name issue that prevents FYROM from joining the European Union. But if he believes that this name is the only element that prevents it, I would tell him why he should steal the name "Macedonia" from Greece and not mention it with the real name he had before it, namely "Vardarska", I think it is very good and sound.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I did not say that the name problem is the only problem that has delayed the entry or otherwise the start of macedonia's accession procedure. Certainly, however, Greece's attitude has been deeply difficult and I believe that in 2015 we cannot waste time on these nomenclature issues. For Yugoslavia it was called the Republic of Macedonia, they are called Macedonians: let us just call it Macedonia and let us unblock this situation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Madam President, on Thursday we are called upon to vote on the progress report on FYROM. A report full of references to the many internal problems facing the country in the areas of the rule of law, the economy, corruption of public administration, freedom of speech. A report that constantly urges FYROM to solve its problems. The point is that FYROM is far from reaching the criteria for accession to the European Union. It has a corrupt government that stifles every opposition voice and controls and intimidates public services, justice and the media.  I call on you to vote against the report. It is wrong to legitimise a document that tends to repeal all un resolutions, the European Council, Parliament on the name issue. Finally, I would recommend that Mrs Mogherini respect and honour international case law and decisions. This country is temporarily called FYROM. Such slips shall not be permitted to an official representative of the European institutions, unless a decision on the name is already in place.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Synadinos, it seems that because of the name of this country, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, we continue to keep this country in the Balkans in quarantine, not only with the European Union but with NATO as well. Do you not think that it might be time to start negotiations with this Republic, because it deserves at a certain point at least to start negotiations and to somehow have the prospect of joining the European Union and NATO in the near future?

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), "blue card" answer. – No, I do not agree and accession negotiations should not begin, because this country has been on the back of a 6,000-year history for years. Therefore, it would be good to join under the former name, the one before 1945. This name was given to that country by Tito. And everyone in this place knows, everyone who knows history, why that name was given.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it must be said that, unfortunately, 2014 was not a very good year for Macedonia in terms of political developments, in terms of the road to Europe. Macedonia has stagnated; unfortunately, it continues to stagnate today. What has been happening for weeks - the huge political scandal there - only reinforces this perception. We also know that freedom of expression is not fully respected. We also know the many interethnic tensions and I would also say that the level of corruption is very high. In short, political culture is far from open and enabling Macedonia to be committed to the European road. That is why I believe that the fundamental question that Macedonia's political elites must answer is: yes or no? Is there determination, is there determination to make this journey? From our point of view, we also need to give a clear answer. I believe that support for opening negotiations could strengthen the conviction of those who are fighting for our ideals.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mr Preda, there is a blue card for you from Mr Kefalogiannis. Yes, this is a question from the PPE to the PPE. (Mr Preda declined to answer a question from Mr Kefalogiannis)

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D).
text: – Madam President, discussing the progress report on the Republic of Macedonia, we can indeed say that there has been progress on a number of issues. However, the Socialist family is deeply concerned about the political climate in that country. Ever since the last elections in spring 2014, which the office of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) and the Commission heavily criticised, the opposition has been out of parliament. The problem is not just about the current, very sharp and dangerous crisis: the problem is that we have seen this before, in December 2012. Then, with mediation assistance by the European institutions, which involved many Members of the European Parliament, the crisis was overcome, but not for good and not in a sustainable way, because it has now been reproduced in an even worse manner. This time it is not only about political dialogue or its absence; it is a matter of upholding basic democratic standards, which are extremely important for the negotiations. We have to ask – when we speak about the allegations against the leader of the opposition – whether we can really trust the judicial system, which was so severely criticised by the Commission. It was the Commission which pointed out that this was a selective judiciary, and that it is the basic problem. We can assist and facilitate dialogue but the truth is that the majority party – the government – should lead, and continue with a normal dialogue in the country and with the political process. Otherwise the prospects for negotiating Macedonia’s accession to the European Union could be endangered. Lastly, I would also remind our Macedonian friends that good neighbourly relations are really important, and that they should show goodwill in order to achieve concrete results and to deliver.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, Skopje continues its provocative attitude towards Greece. Skopje's altruism is expressed by the counterfeiting of history and the burning of the name of our Macedonia. Mrs Mogherini, unfortunately, despite her experience, accepted Skopje's propaganda and a few days ago in an interview in Brussels called Skopje 'Macedonia' in violation of UN and European Union resolutions. The rapporteur did the same a moment ago.  That is why I call on both Mrs Mogherini and the rapporteur to make amends. Mr Hahn, I would like to inform you that the Greek people will not accept the name of our Macedonia from Skopje. Nor is it the name of Skopje to accept a complex name by any geographical designation. Finally, I am opposed to any future accession of Skopje to the European Union. After all, the dead ends of this process can also be ascertained by the report we have discussed.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, the European Union and for the people of FYROM it means an attack on popular rights. In particular, the participation of Greece and Cyprus in the European Union, the pursuit of the accession of other European Balkan countries based on the interventions of the European Union and NATO and the dismemberment of states, means their further involvement in imperialist projects with victims of the peoples of the region.  The alytic propaganda and the randomness of the name are dangerous. The High Representative's reference to the name "Macedonia" and the progress report throw oil on the fire. The JRC supports finding a mutually acceptable solution, with an all-purpose name, including the term 'Macedonia', only as a geographical designation, with mutual recognition of the inviobable borders, territorial integrity and sovereignty of the two countries.  Against the "divide and rule" of the European Union, NATO, the US, and the urban classes, peoples with their own power can determine their future in peace and beneficial cooperation.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am disappointed that, year after year, we are discussing practically the same situation in relation to the integration process of the Republic of Macedonia. The consequences of holding up this process are more visible today than ever before. I am quite disturbed when I look at the current political situation, since it overshadows the progress made in recent years. It is unfortunate that political stalemate has evolved into sharp confrontation between the opposition and the ruling party. Moreover, the wiretapping scandal is hitting the very basis of the political and democratic system in the society and, even worse, is undermining its citizens’ trust in politics. In this respect, we should be ready to help the country to get back on track. I believe that the most efficient way to do this is to stimulate the integration and reform agenda. Much as the country is becoming a hostage to its internal situation, I do not agree that it should remain a hostage to the bilateral issues. As a matter of fact, this trend is becoming popular all around the region, with the Republic of Macedonia as a very unfortunate precedent. This is a pity because it shows our inability to deal with the issues in the region in an efficient and constructive manner. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. – Mr President, as is implicitly apparent from the report, FYROM has established an authoritarian regime under Mr Gruevski, which does not fulfil the minimum conditions under the Treaty of the European Union for opening negotiations and which uses the issue of naming as a vehicle for infuse and indirectly contesting borders with neighbouring countries. So how is it possible to start accession negotiations with this regime?

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Dear colleague, the structure of the European institutions is such that it is the European Commission which issues the progress report on each country every year. The recommendations of the European Commission are to start the accession negotiations and, in previous years, this Parliament always supported it. For me, this is the most important report and it determines how I should behave on this issue.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D). Madam President, we support the European perspective of all the countries of the Western Balkans in order to strengthen the democracy, stability, economic development and social well-being of the wider region. However, FYROM has recently backtracked in many areas, particularly on issues of freedom of expression, media independence and justice. However, in addition to all this, there is also stagnation in the question of naming and good neighbourly relations. The Gruevski government must realise that there are no tolerable challenges of altruism stemming from stolen historical narratives. Nor can it hide its reformal inaction behind the failure to resolve the nomenclature for internal consumption reasons. The name issue is not a bilateral dispute between Greece and FYROM, but an international, open issue defined by the relevant Security Council resolutions.

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: – The authorities of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must mature for European values, according to which it is unacceptable to make a policy based on ethnic opposition and identity of the population. In order for Europe to have an active accession policy towards FYROM, governments in that country must satisfy the claims of the old members of the European Union, including Bulgaria and Greece.  We insist on a transparent census of the population in the republic, reflecting the Bulgarian minority, which in all likelihood will turn out to be a majority. I would like to remind that the last census was in 2002, when only 1417 people were declared Bulgarians, and at the same time 50 000 citizens had applied for Bulgarian citizenship. We insist on the dropping of any interpretations of the authorities in FYROM to the Bulgarian history, which is objectively part of the history of the territory of this country. The government of this republic steals identity from the Bulgarian, Greek and even, note, Egyptian history.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – I will start like this: the citizens of the Republic of Macedonia need not strong leaders, but strong and transparent institutions and deserve a European future now, not ever. Unfortunately, the Republic of Macedonia is currently in serious crisis. There are no steps to improve the political climate in the country, it is even getting worse. I am under the impression that the government and Prime Minister Gruevski are deliberately taking the country away from its European path, manipulating citizens by maintaining a dependent media environment that helps them win elections. This calls into question basic democratic principles. Skopje is also not taking the necessary actions to improve the situation of citizens openly declaring their Bulgarian ethnic identity, as well as to sign a good neighbourly contract with Bulgaria. Before that, I have called on the authorities to heed the recommendations of the European Parliament and break with the shadows of the past and the practices inherited from communism. Skopje must take a firm step towards improving relations with its neighbours, stressing this is also a regional problem.  And I will share with you a litmus example of my lack of desire for good neighborliness. For 7 years Bulgaria has been trying to obtain permission to restore some military cemeteries and monuments, such as colonel Kavarnaliev's tomb blown up by the Communists. There is no answer, although under the legislation of the Republic of Macedonia we must receive such a response. It is irresponsible to educate young people in the Balkans in hatred and distrust of those closest to them by manipulating history with methods of totalitarian past. This is not the path to reconciliation and a European future.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – I am sorry that I cannot be more than critical of the current political situation in Macedonia. Some time ago, the revelations by the leader of the opposition about the indiscrimial illegal wiretapping of various representatives of state institutions are, to put it mildly, very worrying. They testify to the principle of democracy, the moralims of the ruling forces and raise the question of the legitimacy of the rule of the current government. I regret the fact that Macedonia has been in the waiting room for the opening of negotiations for a very long time. However, the current relationships in the country – to which we point out in the resolution – show the urgency of change. Corruption must be eradicated, the conditions for media freedom should be better and, in general, a higher level of political culture and culture of dialogue must be achieved. Macedonia has unfortunately lost too much time, also due to a long-running dispute over the name. It is high time for action to be taken and for change to be achieved with a common political will. Otherwise, there is a danger of turning citizens against nationalist rhetoric.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (
text: PPE). Madam President, Skopje cannot under any circumstances start accession processes if they do not respect democracy within the country itself first, if they do not apply the rule of law and if they do not proceed with democratic reforms. Nor can accession talks begin unless they respect the borders of neighbouring peoples, without distortions and counterfeiting of history, cultural eavesdropping, provocations, altruism and expansionist tendencies.  The lack of progress in reforms and democracy in Skopje is not due to any difference in name, but to inherent internal weaknesses. Greece as a Member State of the European Union had helped in the past as few as the people of Skopje and the country's economy. Greece has shown all its good intention in resolving the issue on the basis of a name that satisfies all sides and allows normalisation in relations between the two states.  What we do not accept, neither from the European Union, nor from Mrs Mogherini, nor from Skopje is the interception of our history and the Skopje leadership maintains an unnecessary nationalism that damages the people and hinders democratic developments in the country.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Madam President, the report contains a paradox. While he rightly admits that we are talking about a country that does not have a parliament, that has huge problems with press freedom, corruption, organised crime, the hate speech of history books towards neighbouring countries, extreme nationalism towards minorities, he suddenly believes that all this will be resolved once accession talks begin. Was that the obstacle?  But they've been fighting it for nine years. And a gift to the government won't change the situation for the better. All the more so, as Commissioner Hahn has explained to us, there is no provision for any enlargement for the current five years. It's a gift, then. An accession that won't come soon. A cancellation which, if we follow the logic of the report, will further exacerbate domestic problems, but also a possible trans-Europeanisation.  So instead of making hollow promises, let us, together with the Government of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, see compliance with the Copenhagen criteria. Whether these are now covered, I leave it to your discretion. What is not allowed, however, is the burden on Greece of responsibility for what plagues this country.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Madam President, I disagree with the substance of the resolution because it contains a basic opposition. While acknowledging that FYROM, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, is facing a number of problems, which Commissioner Hahn described in detail just now, with regard to the functioning of democracy and respect for fundamental human and minority rights, at the same time argues that the only obstacle to a date for the start of negotiations is the bilateral problem with the name with Greece.  The problem is not bilateral. It's international. I grew up, studied, worked in Macedonia and I know exactly what's going on there. Imagine a candidate country that has a parliament where the opposition does not sit on its benches, but attempts to create a parallel institution. Imagine a candidate country where the prime minister is accused of being involved in a phone tapping scandal involving a close relative. Imagine a candidate country where the media is persecuted because of their choice to express other views. In this country the largest ethnic minority is not treated equally. Are you sure we want such a country in the European Union? I'm going to vote against it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as a member of the Committee on Relations with Macedonia, I strongly support those parts of the motion for a Resolution that clearly call on the Council to establish without further delay the start date for the negotiations that Macedonia deserves given the very high degree of preparedness, which this proposal for a Resolution confirms.  The resolution suggests in some of its segments certain weaknesses that have been observed and that Macedonian authorities need to fix. However, Macedonia should be commended for being the 5 least indebted EU countries and candidate countries. GDP is expected to grow by 3.8% this year, which is an excellent figure. Many members of the European Union could look to the commitment of Macedonian authorities to upheld the protection of universal human values, such as the protection of lives and families. Macedonia has been waiting almost 10 years for negotiations to open due to a bilateral name dispute with Greece, which is discouraging for the Macedonian people. I call on the European Commission and the Council to urgently find a solution in order to open negotiations to Macedonia smoothly, and continue to resolve the bilateral dispute in parallel with Macedonia's alignment with European legislation.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in a series of members from Croatia, from the European People's Party, I would like to thank my colleague Iva Vajgl first of all for the high-quality report and all those shadow rapporteurs who participated in the drafting of this document, as well as komisja on the report on Macedonia and another recommendation. We heard already in earlier discussions a few years ago, we are trying to get to the stage to start negotiations. I say this as a man who has spent many years on the side of the activities of the government and diplomacy of Croatia and we have looked at the integration process in parallel, together with Macedonia. Let me just remind you that back in 2000, during the Zagreb summit, that is, the Zagreb Summit, our friends then initialled the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. 2000 – therefore, three years before the Thessaloniki summit. It's been 15 years. Unfortunately, negotiations have not yet been opened, this is a bad example for the enlargement process, it creates frustration on the domestic political scene and therefore we are not surprised by the problems that several colleagues have referred to recently.  That is why it seems to me that we must separate the issue of finding a solution for the name with the process of negotiations on Macedonia's accession, because I think that in this way we will contribute to its development and economic stability, but also to strengthening the European project and a good neighbourhood.  (The Speaker agrees to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Rules of Procedure))

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), "blue card" question. – Mr President, within a minute you have said the name 'Macedonia' five or six times. Would you like me to invite you to Greece to come to Vergina, to come to Amphipolis, to see what Macedonia is? By making huge statues with Alexander the Great, you're not called Macedonia.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Fountoulis, like all of us who have mentioned Macedonia here as a state in a way that does not work for you, does not mean that we do not deeply respect Greece as a country, both as its culture and as a civilization. On the contrary, indeed. However, also make sure that there are certain members of the European Union, such as Croatia, which has recognised Macedonia under its constitutional name, and this is the main and only framework for how we communicate. Therefore, do not be offended, this is what is true in Croatia and what I as a Croatian citizen, and representative, will stick to. With all due respect.  (The Speaker agrees to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Rules of Procedure))

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" question. Madam President, my honourable colleague is right in principle to say that they have recognised FYROM as a country by that name and can therefore mention it that way. However, as chairman, when he chairs a committee, he cannot be referred to by the name that they recognised as a country. He is obliged to report it as FYROM. Also, two questions: does he know what altruism means?  And, because he referred to the issue of good neighbourliness, I would like to tell you something. If you were in my position, which I am Greek, and someone would come to your country and put a flag on a mountain, such as Olympus, which is a historic mountain to us, what would be your place in the matters of good neighbourliness that you mention to us in relation to this FYROM official?

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs. Sakorafa, I do not think it is an opportunity that such a debate that speaks to Macedonia's progress towards the European Union should be transformed into a re-debate of members of the name. I think what I said to a colleague earlier is quite enough. Let's try to make an effort that would be oriented precisely towards goodship, regional cooperation, the functioning of the European project. Because the way it is today - you will not benefit either as a neighbouring country, not us as the European Union, nor our Macedonian friends.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I thank my colleague Vajgl for a well-prepared report.  From 2005 to 2007, the 2006-20 Macedonia is making efforts to meet the preconditions for starting negotiations. These prerequisites are not nuclear physics. I know this very well, because together with my other colleagues I worked on preparing the Republic of Croatia for negotiations and negotiations. So other countries have met the preconditions, the fact is that Macedonia has also met them.  When the progress reports are read out, it is clear to everyone that the legal, political, economic and administrative reforms implemented so far are at a satisfactory level to start opening negotiations. Comments on individual chapters are even much more positive than the countries with which negotiations began. By postponing the negotiations, we are halting Macedonia's further progress, and therefore I urge neighbouring states, especially Greece, to help Macedonia further democratise and Europeanise society in a spirit of neighbourly relations.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: . – Following last year's country report, the European Commission is now proposing to start accession negotiations with Macedonia for the sixth time. The day before last, as a member of a delegation, I myself was on the ground to make sure that the Republic of Macedonia was ready for this. I therefore strongly urge the European Council to set a starting date for the negotiations without a time, regardless of the scandalous name dispute. Domestic political relations in Macedonia are deteriorating and the post-communist opposition is also hindering the start of the integration process. The Union itself is responsible for the current situation. As a representative of the former Communist region of Central and Eastern Europe, I fully support the accession of the nation-building new Macedonian state to Europe.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Madam President, what I have to point out is that those who know very little about the history of the Balkans know very well that Skopje, FYROM, was not and cannot ever become Macedonia, because it has nothing to do with the thousands of years of culture and history that come from within Greece and not through Skopje.  And I really regret that my fellow Members are ignoring history and are being seduced by Skopje's propaganda. I would like to know whether they themselves, for their own country, would sell out their history and culture so easily and hand it over to another country that has nothing to do with this history, and if they are indeed so generous about it, let them do so for their own country.  What are we asking for today? Greece is asking for nothing less and nothing more from this European Parliament than to respect international law and support a country under threat from a neighbouring country.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D). – Ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about progress and a progressive European Union, but this must be done on the basis of principles and solidarity of the Member States of the European Union. This name has not been recognised by the European Union. Let me tell you that I am elected as an MEP in Greece and I come from Macedonia, so I wonder if I should specify which Macedonia I am from.  This game of altruism is a game for commercial and historical reasons. Today's newly built monuments cannot be called Macedonian ancient monuments, they are replicas, and let me tell you that the Macedonian language is not spoken in Skopje. So there are many issues. Please keep your reservations about any progress report that follows and I invite you - and the invitation to all colleagues is open - to Macedonia and then Skopje and I believe that will be enough. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to answer some colleagues who asked why was I using the word Makedonija, that this is for the same reason as Mr Plenković did, which is that this is the name by which my country has recognised Macedonia. I would like to ask my colleague, do you not think that we should stop talking about history and we should speak about the future? Is it not true that a prosperous stable Macedonia is in the interest of its neighbours, both Greece and Bulgaria, and that you should show some solidarity to Macedonia in this moment?

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), "blue card" answer. – Dear colleague, unfortunately the problem is Skopje and not Macedonia. For our part, great efforts have been made. We will be at every dialogue table to resolve the matter. The reason they don't want it resolved is for their own internal consumption. The European Union should therefore protect itself by joining its own group, if you will, and its own dialogue table, in order to enable this issue to be resolved. Because it seems that while we are in the mood to solve it, there is not the same mood on the other hand. That is why I say again that other reasons are hidden, such as altruism, internal consumption, politicians, historians. And for my own future I wish to say that I come from Macedonia, without specifying which Macedonia I am from.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, 15 years ago I was minister for European integration of the Republic of Croatia and at the summit that was in Zagreb, when Europe celebrated changes in Croatia, Macedonia then signed an agreement on association and stabilisation. I must say that we were all looking forward to it and that as a minister I did everything to help the then government of Macedonia to embark on a European journey as soon as possible, together with Croatia. Today I have the honor to talk to you about European politics, sometimes agree more or less, and this country is far from the European Union. Of course, I don't think any of us here are guilty. First of all, the problem is untar of that state itself and they have to solve this problem themselves, but if I as a man from Serbia talk about Serbia wanting Serbia to become a member of the European Union as soon as possible, and my colleagues from Greece will be up for it with me, then I ask my colleagues from Greece to help your neighbour together.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (
text: GUE/NGL). – It is the inalienable right of each nation to define itself, its inalienable right to determine the name it wants. There would be no problem if it was also called Greece and New Greece and Democratic Greece and whatever else you want. The problem arises from the moment they steal twenty centuries of civilization and say they are their own. This problem is important when you steal another people's culture.  This is one issue, the other is that in their constitution they report on salting soils and they mean Greece, even Thessaly as a whole.  Do they or do they not respect Greece's national sovereignty? Undoubtedly the neighboring people are important. We can't kick the neighboring people out, they're close to us. Our wife may be separated, our child may be driven out, but the neighbouring people must respect him. So let's respect him.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take this opportunity to thank mr Ivo Vajgl most sincerely for the great work he has done in diplomacy and mediation, in this report together with the other shadow rapporteurs, on a sensitive dossier, as this debate has shown. As I said earlier for Montenegro, the clear prospect of integration for all the peoples of the Balkans, which certainly meet the Copenhagen criteria, cannot be called into question: it is an historic necessity. I do not wish to enter into the debate on the name and I will stick strictly to the internationally recognised name of FYROM, but I reiterate the need to start accession negotiations in any case, to be conducted in parallel with the name negotiations, if this blockade is not to cause further instability in the Balkan region.  I therefore call on both States to make a great effort to move closer together and to meet, a position which is, moreover, broadly supported in the report. The train to Europe can no longer stand still at the Skopje track if we do not want it to stand still forever.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If you will allow me, I would like to comment briefly on this discussion in that there is almost nothing to add to the last speaker. We are talking about the integration of the countries of Europe into the European Union, including the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. I would like to take this opportunity to make it clear that I was standing next to Federica Mogherini in the press conference, in which she twice did not use the correct term, but did not do so intentionally. It must be admitted that in a very tense situation, such as a press conference, a person sometimes uses an expression that is not 100% correct. Please do not make this a special story. It is legitimate for someone to be 100% correct. Secondly, I have the utmost respect for any parliamentary debate, and the name problem is a problem that needs to be resolved, because we should not doubt the perspective of the country. However, I would also like to say quite frankly that, on the one hand, Greece has other very serious problems, and that, on the other hand, FYROM is now facing a major internal political crisis that needs to be resolved and which, in my view, is actually the far more dramatic one. I believe that we should also have this discussion here in this House. Once again, I would like to thank Mr Howitt, Mr Vajgl and Mr Kukan in particular, who have agreed to intervene in FYROM in this very serious internal political crisis and to help overcome it so that the country can continue to have a European perspective on which I hope we will all work together. After all, that is the strength of Europe, that we have repeatedly managed to overcome our internal difficulties and achieve a common result. I hope that we will be able to do so in a joint effort with our friends on the ground on this issue as well. That is what I would like to ask you to do, and I would like to thank Mr Vajgl once again, and all those who have made a special contribution here, that we have been able to discuss this report here today.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me thank you for this interesting discussion on the basis of the excellent work of rapporteur Ivo Vajgl.  The fact that the EU agenda remains the strategic priority of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is positive. However, our debate today clearly demonstrated that we all share concerns about the increasing politicisation of state institutions and the growing shortcomings of the independence of the judiciary and of freedom of the media, which is damaging the sustainability of reforms. In this regard, we also count on the European Parliament support to call on all leaders of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to take decisive action to rapidly address the concerns. Mr Howitt called on the Presidency to be more proactive in setting a date for the start of accession negotiations. I can say that the Council is fully aware of recommendations by the Commission and we adopted conclusions in that context in December 2014. Yet with respect to the current political situation, the EU has expressed serious concerns. These are very serious charges that need independent and proper investigation and the High Representative of the Union and the Council has been clear on this. The Council will revert to the issue any time this year on the basis of an update by the Commission on implementation of reforms, including in the context of the high—level accession dialogue and on tangible steps taken to promote good neighbourly relations and to reach a negotiated and mutually acceptable solution for the name issue. I agree that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia needs EU support, but this support is conditional on the willingness and readiness of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia itself.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In recent months, the political situation in the Republic of Macedonia has deteriorated considerably and this is a major obstacle to the country's European and civilisational path. Shocking abuses, mass wiretaps scandals and a lack of political dialogue threaten the rule of law by even increasing the use of hate speech. Macedonia is an important factor for the stability of the region and the European project will not be completed as conceived without the membership of the Western Balkan countries. In this regard, I welcome Commissioner Hahn's decision to visit the Republic of Macedonia and involve the European Union in resolving the political conflict. The country needs our help and we must immediately propose a political team, on a successful model in Albania, that will bring all political groups back to the negotiating table and help find constructive dialogue. A public debate needs to be started immediately in order to restart the country's reform process. Political stability is needed to ensure sustainable cooperation that accelerates the European agenda of the Republic of Macedonia and leads to the opening of negotiating chapters on membership.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on the former Republic of Macedonia. Macedonia is required to move closer to the acquis communautaire by adapting its national rules and reshaping its social coexistence. But the European Union is at an impasse of over-regulation, centralisation and unification. Macedonia's supposed advances are therefore catching up in the wrong direction. If the direction is not correct, any speed is the wrong one. In this respect, it must be stressed that the omission is not the fault of Macedonia, but rather of the European Union. It should not currently accept any other members. Before enlargement is possible, the dream of a free Europe must be redreamed. Once the foundations for a free, united Europe have been re-established, the enlargement process can be resumed.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the 2014 progress report on Serbia (2014/2949(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, regarding Serbia, I would like to underline some points, which are also reflected in your resolution. The Council in its conclusions of December 2014 welcomed the launch of accession negotiations with Serbia on 21 January 2014, and the ongoing screening process. With the beginning of accession negotiations, Serbia has moved to a new stage on its path to the European Union. In this regard, the Council welcomed the high level of engagement and preparedness demonstrated so far by the Serbian Government. Strong commitment is a particularly important ingredient of any state’s negotiation process in moving towards EU accession, as it is linked to an often challenging reform process. Serbia’s ambitious programme of economic and structural reforms is an evident manifestation of its efforts in this regard. In line with the new approach, opening benchmarks have been set under the rule of law chapters, requiring comprehensive action plans. The Council positively noted that these chapters were being addressed early in the negotiations. The rule of law is a fundamental EU value.
