These chapters are rightly at the heart of the accession process as they have a cross—cutting effect on all the policy sectors covered by the accession negotiations. Therefore, progress under these chapters needs to be made in parallel with progress in the negotiations overall. We also welcomed the progress made in the past year, including in public administration reform, judicial reform and the fight against corruption and organised crime. Serbia actively participated in regional law-enforcement cooperation. This led to effective results in the fight against organised crime. The Council encourages Serbia to further intensify its reform process. Continued strong efforts are needed to ensure an effective, independent judiciary and to build a track record in the fight against corruption and organised crime. The promotion, implementation and full observance of fundamental rights must be ensured, including the protection of the most vulnerable groups, particularly the Roma. The legislation on the protection of minorities should be implemented effectively, and the treatment of minorities should be non-discriminatory. Particular attention also needs to be paid to tackling discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity. There are concerns about deteriorating conditions for the full exercise of freedom of expression. We will continue to emphasise the importance of promoting and protecting an environment that supports free speech and media freedom. The business environment and the investment climate should be further improved. Attention should also be paid to implementing public administration reform and to implementing the economic and structural reforms required to restore fiscal sustainability, and ultimately to support growth and employment. In this regard, the Council welcomes the Commission’s approach of focusing on strengthening economic governance and competitiveness. This should prove valuable in supporting the efforts towards meeting the Copenhagen criteria. An essential part of Serbia’s EU integration process is regional cooperation and good neighbourly cooperation. In this regard, the Council welcomes Serbia’s continued active and constructive engagement in further developing regional cooperation by participating in regional initiatives such as the South—East Europe Cooperation Process and the Regional Cooperation Council, as well as by strengthening bilateral relations with other countries of Western Balkans region. Serbia also needs to maintain active and constructive engagement in the normalisation process with Kosovo, which has seen significant progress. In this regard, let me welcome the resumption on 9 February 2015 of the High—Level Dialogue, as well as the finalisation of the agreement on justice and the judiciary in Kosovo. Advancement on the normalisation of relations with Pristina and full implementation of the Brussels Agreement, by means of the High-Level Dialogue, are directly linked to forward movement in Serbia’s EU accession talks. The Council will continue to monitor closely Serbia’s continued engagement in the process, including the implementation in good faith of all agreements reached so far, so that Serbia and Kosovo can continue on their respective European paths, while avoiding a situation in which either could block the other’s efforts. Progress in this process needs to be made in parallel with progress in the negotiations overall. The Council has also called on Serbia to align progressively with the EU Common Foreign and Security Policy. It is especially important at times like these for countries wishing to join the EU to show commitment to the common European values. Last but not least, Serbia should also continue to cooperate effectively with the European Union Rule of Law Mission (EULEX) and contribute actively to the full and unhindered execution by EULEX of its mandate. The Council looks forward to the next meeting of the Accession Conference and to the opening of the first negotiating chapters with Serbia.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate David McAllister for his resolution on the 2014 progress report on Serbia. This is a very balanced and comprehensive assessment of Serbia’s progress on its EU path, which is overall in line with the findings of our 2014 progress report.  I share the view that Serbia’s efforts and progress need to receive a positive narrative from the European Union and I look forward to the opening of the first chapters. Negotiations with Serbia are underway. The country has committed to difficult reforms and has come a long way on the normalisation of its relations with Kosovo. This is also key for stability in the region. The screening process is on schedule and should be finalised by the end of the month. Serbia’s negotiation team has shown impressive commitment and professionalism throughout. Discussions in the Council on screening reports are expected to continue throughout the year. Now Serbia needs to deliver on key areas, including the rule of law and the normalisation of its relations with Kosovo which need to be tackled early in the negotiation process in line with the negotiating framework. The resumption of the high level dialogue one month ago after a break of almost a year is crucial. The agreement on justice and judiciary in Kosovo has been finalised. This is a welcome development. Working groups are now meeting to take forward the work on implementation on which both sides are expected to continue delivering results. Once sufficient progress is assessed, we could move forward on Chapter 35. I hope this can happen in the near future. Serious work is also on—going on the rule of law issues. I look forward to the adoption of credible, comprehensive and sustainable action plans. I am also hopeful that this could contribute to the opening of Chapters 23 and 24 before the end of the year. The Serbian Government should also ensure that progress is not put at risk in such a way as being perceived as interfering in the work of the Ombudsman’s office or stepping back on freedom of expression. Media freedom is a non—negotiable fundamental right and a key condition for progress on the EU path. This is the message I constantly convey to my Serbian interlocutors and in particular to Prime Minister Vučić with whom I am in regular contact. At the same time, we should be careful not to add requirements not provided for under the EU acquis or the negotiating framework. In this respect it is important that bilateral disputes do not hamper the overall accession process. The Commission remains firmly committed to support and guide Serbia on its European path and I appreciate that the European Parliament is on the same page.

name: David McAllister
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, as the new standing rapporteur on Serbia, it is an honour for me to present the resolution on this 2014 Progress Report and I would like to welcome Ms Jadranka Joksimović, the  Minister in the Serbian Government dealing with European Affairs, who is with us tonight. This resolution sends out two main messages, firstly Serbia is on its path towards the European Union. Looking back, 2014 was an important year for Serbia; the formal beginning of the accession talks took place on the 21 January 2015. I am convinced Prime Minister Vučić and his government show commitment to the European integration process. They tackle head on the systemic and socio—economic reforms; this deserves our respect and support. In recent months, the Serbian Parliament has adopted important laws on whistle—blowers, media, labour, privatisation and bankruptcy; this is a positive development. Nevertheless, a thorough implementation of legislation and policies remains essential for a successful integration process. Secondly, ‘fundamentals first’ is key in the negotiation process. I consider as fundamentals: the rule of law, economic governance, the reform of public administration, aligning to our EU foreign policy and the normalisation of relations with Kosovo.  How long the accession negotiations will take primarily depends on Serbia’s ability to make sustained progress on the EU agenda of reforms. I am convinced this progress can be made. The train from Belgrade is on its track towards Brussels, let us encourage Serbia to stay on this European track. Finally, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their fruitful cooperation; it was our goal to present a realistic, fair and balanced resolution which I think we achieved.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Thank you also to the reporter David. That's the way it is today. I congratulate Serbia on the progress made, I welcome the important steps that have already been taken, and I remain optimistic that the country will continue to make progress. At the same time, I express my concern about the tendencies and pressures that have been felt recently on issues that are actually about Serbia's bilateral relations with neighbouring countries. I believe that the call for Serbia to reconsider the war crimes law is by no means part of this report. Universal jurisdiction in the field of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide is in line with international case law. Several European Union countries have a similar regime. And that is the Commission's view. What is more, the existing legislation allows for greater efficiency and trial even for those who, due to the lack of such legislation, could avoid punishment for crimes committed.  The European Parliament must not be used as a field to tackle or promote internal policy topics. Serbia bears a great responsibility on its shoulders. First, in the Western Balkans region, it has taken on the role of a kind of initiator for establishing better relations and accelerating regional cooperation. And secondly, there is an important period ahead of Serbia in which it will have to gradually resolve relations with Kosovo and fully implement the agreement on the normalisation of relations between Belgrade and Prishino. In this light, I welcome the recent resumption of dialogue, including the adoption of a judicial agreement, which is essential for progress. I believe that the most important thing at the moment is to create conditions that will enable all the people of Kosovo to live as much as possible. I join the calls for serbia's negotiations with the Union to be opened as soon as possible and for Chapters 23 and 24 to be opened. I will be in a hurry to visit Belgrade next week, and my message will be clear: I am convinced that negotiations must start as soon as possible. In doing so, we in the European Parliament will continue to pay attention to developments in Serbia, especially when it comes to the normalisation of relations with Kosovo, the rule of law and the free media. (The speaker answered a question raised by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs. Fajon, it is apparent from your presentation that you are unaware that this law you are mentioning, which has taken universal jurisdiction from Serbia, also applies to your citizens. I wonder if you will continue to consider that this law does not go beyond international and criminal law at the moment if it happens that one of the Slovenian citizens is arrested and judged under that law?

name: n/a
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – Thank you very much, colleague, for the question I was expecting. We are talking about the war crimes law in Serbia, and we have made it very clear to the European Commission and the other institutions that the opening of chapter number twenty-three is very clear, with Serbia having to change the law, it is a very dangerous precedent. There is a similar law in several Member States of the European Union. Furthermore, I can say that judges, war crimes, crimes against humanity and crime against genocide must never be the exclusive jurisdiction of the country on whose territory the crime took place. So I don't think such a complement falls within this resolution.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr McAllister, it is undeniable that your report is extremely balanced and objectively reflects the evolution of the situation in Serbia. And there is certainly progress, there is a desire to have conversations, but there are also many problems. Problems related not only to internal affairs in Serbia itself, such as freedom of speech, such as media freedom or the state of justice. Another significant problem is bilateral relations between Serbia and some of the neighbouring countries.  There is still an unclosed relationship with Croatia, there are still laws that are in theory adopted in the Republic of Serbia, but do not apply in practice, and this is the example of the non-application of the obligation to education in Bulgarian in the western Bulgarian outskirts. Commissioner Hahn, these issues need to be raised and Serbia needs to take its decisions on them if it wants to develop on the European path.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – On behalf of the ALDE Group, I support the resolution and the extremely constructive and patient work of the rapporteur, David McAllister, who has given good reasons for assessing Serbia's positive efforts to gradually qualify for membership of the European Union. Serbia's progress is obvious and gratifying. The reform process and screening are going through effectively. Serbia's European perspective is becoming achievable and realistic. The resolution draws attention to areas where more needs to be done: in the judiciary, in the fight against corruption, the opening up and stabilisation of legislation in the areas of the economy and legal certainty in this area, respect for minorities, the dignity of LGTB, freedom of expression, the media. These are values that are not possible. Serbia is an important factor in regional stability and I believe that, even as the Presiding State of the OSCE, it will prove this in the future.

name: Miloslav Ransdorf
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – I would like to stress that Serbia is the central economy of the Balkans and without the stabilisation of Serbia it is not possible to stabilise the Balkan countries as a whole.  I would also like to stress that this country will need macro-financial assistance because it has the largest number of refugees on its territory ever in the whole territory, 700 000. Furthermore, there have been floods that have flooded some mines, so Serbia has to import coal today. I think it is also important to help Serbia build energy capacity in the field of renewables. There has been a lot of progress in terms of hydropower, but I think there are large reserves and it could be promising for neighbouring countries as well.  I would also like to stress that we should appreciate Serbia's progress in the area of judicial reform, in the area of administrative reform and also in the fight against corruption, even though there are certain reserves that have finally been mentioned here.  I think it is a country that deserves our attention, and it is also important that we also help to exploit the potential that is there for the whole area.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – I, too, would like to begin by thanking Mr McAllister for the excellently prepared progress report on Serbia. Above all, excellent cooperation and openness, for compromises that have, of course, led to interesting debates. However, I think that the resolution is a good one, and I support it, of course. I must say that Serbia has taken a big step forward over the years. She's taken some reforms seriously. Because there is a sense of effort to achieve as much as possible a degree of independence in the judicial field, because of course this also strengthens confidence in the rule of law. The issue of corruption, which is, of course, not insignificant in Serbia, has also been on the agenda. It is, of course, a process that will take some time. Above all, it is important to be aware that corruption is slowly leading to the country's propath of power, and therefore it must be seriously tackled. I am sure, of course, that Serbia will continue to push for even greater transparency through its reforms. In doing so, I would particularly like to highlight the role of the National Audit Committee or control the use of public finances, as this is also one of the outstanding indicators and mirrors of the functioning of each government. And I think that in this way it can also direct the consumption of public finances, which is also important from the point of view of European funds flowing into Serbia. And through the Report of the European Court of Auditors, we can be sure that, in most cases, these funds are used, of course, correctly and in a proper way. That problem, which, of course, remains, is, of course, a high level of unemployment, youth, the economy, the media. I, too, am getting quite a few emails, drawing attention to the issue of media independence, and here, of course, I would like to point out that the authorities still have to take many steps forward. There are also some Agrobank shareholders and a few things that still need to be answered in the future.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I would say to those who support this motion that their neo—imperialistic bid for expansion into the former Yugoslavia has led them to lose sight of the bigger picture. This motion calls for greater alignment of Serbia to the foreign policy of the EU, specifically highlighting the current disastrous situation with Russia.  Yet you all seem to forget the close cultural ties that Serbia shares with Russia through their Orthodoxy, history and common values. Serbia is becoming another pawn in the wider struggle with Russia. If you had any sense of diplomacy or were to act out of respect for the Serbian people, then you would see the potential not for more competition or potential conflict, but for reconciliation and cooperation. Instead of making Serbia another colony of the Commission there is the real potential to let her act as an important mediator between the West and Russia at this crucially sensitive time for security in eastern Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – I would like to ask you: given that Romania is also an Orthodox country, should we also have new links to get out of all that is restrictions with Russia?

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – What I am saying is that we all appreciate the sensitivity of the situation with regard to Russia and European Union relations at the moment. This is a really good opportunity to use Serbia as a broker and I really do fear that by eventually bringing Serbia into the European Union you are actually playing into Mr Putin’s hands and giving him a chance to be even more aggressive.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – For me, this report on Serbia would be credible if it included in batches the individual and collective human rights that Serbia is obliged to grant to indigenous national communities on its territory, such as hungarians in the south of the country of 300 000 people, without which it would be said that there is no entry into the European Union.  What I mean is that, for example, as a human right, they are obliged to ensure full national self-determination, territorial autonomy under the South Tyrolean model– because, if it is a European Union, we should use European models and European values – full use of language. I do not know if The Commissioner and the reporter know that Hungarian-language radio stations, hungarian radio stations founded by the municipality, will be abolished, because they are being privatised. I call for something to be done on this, too, and to ensure full non-discrimination and equal treatment of Hungarians in the Southland. Here are your demands, I'll give them to the report officer and the Commissioner.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Serbia is making progress in the integration process and I am glad that the good, balanced and objective report by David McAllister recognises this.  It is important that there is a commitment to this process at high political level and I hope that it will be strengthened further in the government’s work and positions. Therefore, I think it is right that we are calling for the negotiating chapters to be opened. It will be critical for Serbia to continue the reform process. We have seen a difficult start to the economic and social reforms, and we expect continuing progress on reforming the judiciary. In this respect I would like to stress the importance not only of the independence of certain institutions, such as the Ombudsman’s Office, but also of resolving the issues related to cases of so—called abuse of office. Serbia has to continue its engagement and dialogue with Kosovo. Support from the government and political elites for this process is the key in terms of stability in the region.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Romania is a neighbour country of Serbia and I might say that we traditionally have a long friendship with this country and we support the European Union perspective not only for Serbia, but for all the former Yugoslav republics, for Albania and for the Republic of Moldova as well. I also believe that we need to be aware that work lies ahead for Serbia. Improvements are very much needed with regard to the rights of minorities, the freedom of the media, the lack of transparency and funding of political parties, the equal representation of men and women, corruption. I believe that in our negotiations with all the candidate countries we must keep our European priorities and values clear in our minds. The goal of achieving stability in the region is very important but we cannot forfeit our support and we have to defend the exercise of democratic values, rights and freedoms in the Balkans. I very much support this process of European enlargement in south-eastern Europe. At the same time, I believe that we must take a clear political position.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to thank the rapporteur very much for his very honest and optimistic report that Serbia is already on the road to European integration. For me, this is a question of our attitude towards European solidarity. I was pleased with Slovenia's accession to the European Union, I was very pleased with Croatia's accession and I believe that we should also open the door for Serbia with good will. This is a question – I repeat again – of European solidarity and the Union should be unequivocal on this point. And I cannot ignore the silence of what Farage's British party colleague said. There is no intermediate zone between Europe and Russia. If we do not open the door to Serbia, if we do not hold talks with goodwill, Serbia will be in the Russian zone. Unfortunately, once again Farage's party spoke with the voice of Moscow. We should speak with a voice of European unity and solidarity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the firm decision of the Government of the Republic of Serbia to persevere on its European path, because I believe that this really finally contributes to stability in the Balkans. Serbia's role has always been important in the Balkans and the last moves we see, primarily the dialogue between Serbia and Albania, Serbia's relationship with Bosnia and Herzegovina and other neighbours, I think they are excellent and if Serbia persists on this path, we should be ready to accept it as soon as possible into our society. What I want to highlight is certainly the need for further reforms in Serbia, all that is on the Government's agenda and what I would further propose is to seriously reflect on the potentials that Serbia has, especially on the energy front and to get involved in the programmes of the new Juncker Plan, because many of the energy resources serbia has can also be well used for Member States.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam President, respected colleague Hahn, respected colleague McAllister, I thank you for a well-prepared report on Serbia which I think is stimulating for the Serbian authorities to continue reforms on the road to the European Union. I am pleased that the report also toyed in a quality way with the issue of protecting minority rights, respecting agreements with neighbouring states and, of course, resolving the issue of missing persons. Today, in the debate, colleague Fajon mentioned a law that extended Serbia's jurisdiction to other former SFRY states, completely mixing classical universal jurisdiction with a single hybrid case of territorially selectively expanded jurisdiction that, according to my analysis and knowledge, has no precedent in other countries. Therefore, I call on Commissioner Hahn and the Commission to help solve this problem, and it is a problem that creates legal uncertainty among European Union nationals, i.e. Croatian citizens, and potentially Slovenian and others, in the months ahead and help Serbia make a complete legal reform of its system on the road to the EU. (The Speaker agrees to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the E.S. Rules of Procedure))

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Plenković, you mentioned this law that speaks of universal jurisdiction.  I want to ask you and give you another opportunity to explain, given that there is misunderstanding in Parliament and even from my colleague Fajon herself, what exactly is the difference so that our colleagues understand what we are looking for. There is no question that we want to hitchhike Serbia, we want to help Serbia, but we also want this issue to be clarified.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mrs. Šuica, I hope that the past two months, while discussing this report, have not contributed to us understanding the problem less, but to understand it better and I think we have achieved that. Most of the colleagues who weren't familiar with him now know what it's all about. Thus, the universal jurisdiction that exists as an institute in the numerous criminal laws of the Member States has nothing to do with this special law adopted in the context of the processing of war crimes in the territory of the former Yugoslavia by Serbia. We are not against avoiding impunity; Indeed. But we are against the fact that one law creates legal uncertainty for citizens of a member of the European Union in the way that was the case of Croatian citizen Veljko Marić and this is inadmissible in the future.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – For my part, I fully agree with colleague Andrej Plenkovic, if this report does indeed have very serious merits, because it lists very well the progress that the Serbian Government has made in recent times and expresses very well and accurately the expectations that the European Union has made.  I would like to draw the Commissioner's attention to two things in particular: one is that candidates must be required to join the common foreign and security policy already, including the expectation from Serbia that he too should join the sanctions against Russia. The other is Croatia, which Hungary neighbouring and multi-ethnic countries, as well as Serbia. Be kind, Commissioner, continue to make sure that there is an appropriate neighbourhood policy and that the rights of national minorities, including Hungarians in Vojvodina, are fully respected.

name: Ramona Nicole Mănescu (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome the progress made in implementing the EU-Serbia Stabilisation and Association Agreement. I also welcome the commitment shown by the Serbian Government in relation to the European integration process, and I believe that legislation needs to be implemented rigorously and consistently at all levels. In this regard, I draw attention to the importance of implementing legislation on education, access to media and religious services in the languages of existing minorities and the representation of these minorities in local, regional and national parliament bodies. I also encourage the Government of Serbia to draw up a concrete action plan on the position of national minorities in the action plan for the negotiating chapter 23. Serbia's presence within the Union's borders will lead to stability and prosperity not only for Serbian citizens, but also for European citizens, and good management of Serbia's relationship with national minorities and neighbouring states will support the accession process. I congratulate my colleague, David McAllister, on his fair and balanced approach.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE).
text: – Madam President, whenever we talk about EU partner states we cannot avoid mentioning that countries have to choose between liberal democracy or an authoritarian anti—liberal regime. There is a clear divide between the value system of Europe, which is based on international law and obligations based on democratic values, and the other system, which is currently ruining the European post—war peace order. I personally do not believe that it is possible to choose more than one system and to follow more than one road.  Serbia still raises a lot of questions about which path it chooses to be on. The decision not to support EU sanctions on Russia is more than just a pragmatic choice, it is a statement. At this moment, Eastern Partnership countries like Ukraine are showing more political will and eagerness to be closer to the EU than those countries which consider themselves to be on the EU’s doorstep. Therefore, I urge the Serbian Government clearly to decide which road it wants to take, since it is not possible to have it both ways.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Serbia started negotiations a year ago and has shown a willingness to go down the path of European integration. It is now crucial that this readiness is also expressed in concrete actions and political will for reform. It is important that Serbia jointly shares the common European foreign and security policy, as my colleagues have mentioned, and does not succumb to pressure from third countries. Therefore, Commissioner, we must also help as a European Union and as a European Commission of Serbia. The country has a solid legislative framework in the area of minority rights, but the implementation of the law is not always uniform and impartial. The Bulgarian minority still has serious difficulties in learning their mother tongue. There are all sorts of political obstacles to this, bureaucratic and financial excuses are sought why textbooks cannot be translated into Bulgarian. At the same time, I call again for Serbia, as also recorded in the report, to begin its reconciliation with its own history, to open the files of the communist secret services of UDBA and the COS and to make the relevant archives available to the former Yugoslav republics. It is also very important that Serbia's economic and integration policy also includes the border abandoned economic areas in which many minority groups live.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (
text: PPE). Madam President, we strongly support Serbia's accession to the European Union and I congratulate Mr McAllister on his excellent report. I believe that this country and the Serbian people need more support from the European Union, especially on the issue of the development of democratic institutions and reforms. Serbia is prepared to move in this direction. In addition, it has two main advantages. One is that it can become a stabilising factor in the Balkans and the other that having the experience of the past can become an industrial and rural centre in the region again.  Now, on the issue of relations with Russia, I do not think that for Turkey we cannot see that it does not follow the Common European Policy and has excellent relations with Russia, which is not due to orthodoxy, because one country is Muslim, the other Orthodox, while for Serbia this is a negative element. It can be a bridge of understanding with Russia.  Serbia has shown excellent co-operation with the special international war crimes tribunal in the former Yugoslavia, but also on the issue of disputes with Kosovo, a region that is the home for Serbs, for Serbian culture.

name: Andor Deli (PPE).
text: – We have already said a lot about this year's progress report and have said how balanced it is, and I would like to thank the reporter, Mr McAllister, for that. It includes praise for the annual work of the Serbian Government, but also the tasks that the EU expects Serbia to carry out as soon as possible. The EP's decision is also politically important because it is necessary to further encourage the Serbian Government in its determination to be part of a large family of European peoples. There is a great deal of political pressure on Serbia, and that is what we want to help from this Parliament.  Hungary a neighbouring country and has a multiple interest in serbia being an EU member as soon as possible. In addition to foreign policy, security policy and economic interests, good neighbourly relations between the two countries have developed rapidly over the past few years. What is also quite clear is that we are also extremely interested in the future of the Hungarian community in Serbia, for which it is essential to further improve the realisation of minority rights. This is important to me personally, because as a vojvodina, I am aware that the future of the Hungarian community there depends on it.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I, too, very much welcome Mr McAllister's report. I think it is very good, balanced, and a report that largely insouds optimism that Serbia is on the right track. I come from Slovenia, which first joined the European Union as a former part of Yugoslavia, so I know very well what efforts the Serbian Government must now make to improve the area of regional cooperation, to tackle the most robust reforms that were still a 'taboo theme' a few years ago in Serbia to improve the business environment, and to bite into a very challenging area of the rule of law : fight corruption, prosecuting crime. Serbia needs European solidarity so that the people of Serbia have the conditions that other Europeans have as soon as possible and that they enjoy as members of the common European Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Serbia has shown that it wants to engage fully in the process of European integration and that it wants to tackle decisively and directly the systemic and socio-economic reforms necessary to continue along the path of change and rapprochement with European standards.  The negotiations are undoubtedly having positive effects: I am thinking, for example, of the progress towards normalising relations with Kosovo and the increasingly constructive approach that the Belgrade Government is taking in its relations with its neighbours, also enabling substantial progress to be made both in regional cooperation and in the establishment of closer relations with the European Union.  Serbia is a key country on the Balkan chessboard and its entry into the European Union is to be considered strategic. It is therefore clear that it needs to align its foreign and security policy with that of the European Union. Serbia's alignment with eu decisions on foreign policy is a key element in the process of European integration and I hope that the Belgrade Government will be able to make the courageous choices necessary to successfully continue negotiations with the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, I welcome Serbia's accession negotiations with the European Union, but I must say that I would prefer that the citizens of Serbia have been given the right to have decided in a referendum on the negotiation on their future membership of the European Union.  Greece supports Serbia's European path and has concluded cooperation agreements since 2010 aimed at strengthening and speeding up the accession process. Some Member States of the European Union must not put obstacles in the way of Serbia's European path and agree to open up new chapters for negotiation.  At the same time, the Serbian authorities must step up their action to tackle corruption and organised crime. Of course, the adequate fulfilment of the political criteria shows that Serbia is implementing its commitments in the area of the rule of law, public administration and economic governance.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I decided to ask for another catch—the—eye procedure because I have a question for Mr Plenković. We talked in the break about your criticism and your amendment about universal jurisdiction and you have now explained it as well. In the meantime, I have tried to find out more about it. I found out that the law that you now want to abolish with that amendment was already abolished in 2003 and that everybody, including the Commission and the international community, has accepted that.  There was also the case of Mr Veljko Marić which was done under that, and at that time, before he was convicted, the Croatian State Attorney provided the Serbian war crimes prosecutor with the key witnesses and full legal and technical assistance in that case under that law. I do not really understand why you want to do away with that, and as far as I understood, it is also universal jurisdiction and not just for what is ex—Yugoslavia. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I see that Ms Lunacek has been partially informed about the issue. I suggest we have a short conversation for longer than the 23 seconds that are left so that I can tell you that just because the law was passed in 2003 does not mean that it was implemented until 2010. By the way, Croatia passed a law in 2011 that made all the legal acts based on this law null and void; so her partial information is very partial and partisan and she should please bear that in mind before the vote tomorrow.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as far as Serbia is concerned, the long and arduous road to EU membership has finally begun. I think it is very important to mention Mr McAllister in this report, which is, moreover – as many have pointed out and I fully agree with – very balanced and open, also in spirit, to all of us shadow rapporteurs who have participated, of the missing persons, a wound that is still bleeding in the heart of the countries of the former Yugoslavia. Twenty years later, you think, twelve thousand families still do not know the fate of their loved ones, which is why it is vital that Serbia continues to cooperate with its neighbours in the same spirit as the Mostar Declaration.  Finally, I would like to point out that Serbia has also assumed the presidency of the OSCE for a few months now. This is therefore a particularly favourable time to make it a bridge and a privileged mediator for dialogue with Russia, given the intimate cultural and historical ties that unite them. Let us hope that this will be a good opportunity to find a good political compromise, relaunch diplomacy and silence the winds of war.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this interesting debate. It reflects the great importance the Union continues to attach to the credibility of the enlargement process, which remains crucial for maintaining the momentum of reforms and public support for enlargement in the region and in Serbia in particular. I take note of the discussion on Serbia’s law on the organisation and competence of state authorities in war crimes proceedings. I fully understand the sensitivities of this matter and I believe that Serbia and its neighbours need to look to the future in a spirit of regional cooperation and reconciliation. I take this opportunity to underline that effective and impartial handling of war crimes, in line with international standards, features high in the accession negotiations with Serbia. It is covered by the specific recommendations in the screening report in Chapter 23 about the judiciary and fundamental rights, stressing the need for efficient deterrent and impartial treatment of war crimes, equal treatment of suspects, and proportionality of sentences and protection of victims. All these recommendations will have to be addressed in the judiciary section of the action plan required for the opening of Chapter 23. The Commission is actively involved in the preparation of this action plan and is committed to reviewing the measures undertaken by Serbia in this respect and in this framework. Once again thank you for this very interesting debate. I would also again like to thank the author Mr McAllister and his colleagues for this very balanced report.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, Commissioner, to conclude, let me express my sincere gratitude to Parliament’s rapporteur on Serbia, David McAllister, for his excellent work and his commitment. This has been a very fruitful and useful debate. We believe that Serbia now has a clear path for moving ahead in the accession process. Also, the first chapters have not yet been opened, but Serbia is demonstrating commitment and readiness to achieve swift progress in the talks. The Council agrees with the notion that the first chapter should indeed be opened soon. In this process, we are guided by the negotiation framework principles, in which it is stated that the achievement of the negotiations will be guided by Serbia’s progress on preparing for accession, within a framework of economic and social convergence. Progress on the rule of law and on the normalisation of relations with Kosovo is of particular importance at this stage of negotiations. In this regard, we welcome the resumption of the High—Level Dialogue on 9 February 2015 and we encourage both sides to use the momentum and to work together towards reaching agreement on the remaining issues. We will devote particular attention to monitoring progress on all the specific issues underlined in our conclusions and the EU common positions, before the next steps in the negotiation process can be taken. In this respect, I welcome Parliament’s commitment and its determination to encourage Serbia to push the necessary reforms forward. I would like to thank you once again for this debate, and I thank the rapporteur for preparing this report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – I would like to thank my colleague McAllister, who, as responsible for the report on Serbia, has shown an open mind to receive our amendments, which are particularly important for national minorities in Serbia, such as Hungarians in Vojvodina. The importance of national councils and their need for adequate funding, the provision of mother tongues in all areas of life and the need for a minority presence in public administration, justice and the police have been included in the text. This will be one of the strongest decisions on Serbia adopted by the European Parliament tomorrow.  The call for a minority action plan to be drawn up in the framework of accession negotiations is of particular importance. This would avoid previous accession experience: that candidates only temporarily consider the interests of these national communities until accession. I therefore consider it important that the application of existing legislation and its compliance be monitored by the Commission.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support Serbia's integration into the European Union. Serbia's European journey is a normal consequence and a right for the Serbian people. In this respect, I am true to the position of my country, Romania, on support for Serbia's European journey. However, I would like to mention the situation of the Vlachs/Vlass/Romanians in the Timocului Valley. In the Timocului Valley alone, according to the latest census, there are about 40,000 Romanians, and the actual number is perhaps even higher. This must not scare the Serbian authorities. The active protection of this minority, but also the support of its cultural and linguistic traditions, can only strengthen Serbia on its European path as a unitary and indivisible state. I recommend that the European Commission support the Vlach/Romanian minority in Serbia with the Serbian authorities.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the European integration process of Kosovo (2014/2950(RSP)).

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me first thank rapporteur Ulrike Lunacek for her work on Kosovo, and the Parliament as a whole for the opportunity to discuss this issue. I will start by recalling that the Council, in its conclusions of December 2014, noted the initialling in July 2014 of a Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) with Kosovo. The Council took note of the Commission’s intention to issue the proposals for signature and conclusion of the agreement as soon as possible, without prejudice to Member States’ positions on status. The Council also welcomed the end of the protracted political stalemate and the formation of the new institutions. It called upon the new authorities to engage swiftly on the reform agenda and on the High-Level Dialogue with Belgrade. We called on Kosovo to focus on implementation of the comprehensive reforms necessary to enable it to meet its obligations under the proposed Stabilisation and Association Agreement. Progress on its European path is of particular importance to Kosovo and the region in whole. The citizens of Kosovo deserve to see concrete results delivered and a number of the most urgent issues attended to. Strong political commitment will be required to address the challenges. Particular attention should be paid to improving the rule of law, including judicial independence, and to intensifying the fight against organised crime and corruption. We welcome Kosovo’s progress so far, but we would also point out that Kosovo needs to address shortcomings raised in the visa dialogue, including mitigating the security and migration-related risks of potential visa liberalisation. In this regard, the need for structural economic reforms, addressing the high level of unemployment, is becoming increasingly urgent. Important reforms, such as electoral reform and public administration reform, remain a priority. The protection of minorities must be addressed. The increased focus by the Commission on the national economic reform programmes also applies to Kosovo. We are hopeful that this approach will serve as an aid to Kosovo in implementing its economic reform package. The normalisation process with Serbia has seen significant progress. Kosovo must maintain an active and constructive engagement in this process. The dialogue remains essential in terms of advancing a European future for both Serbia and Kosovo. Therefore, the normalisation of relations should be one of the key tasks for Kosovo. In this respect, let me welcome the resumption on 9 February 2015 of the High-Level Dialogue between Belgrade and Pristina and the finalisation of the agreement on justice and the judiciary in Kosovo. This is a step towards full implementation of the Brussels Agreement, which we expect to be achieved as soon as possible. We also welcome the agreement between Prime Minister Mustafa and Prime Minister Vučić to work together to tackle regional concerns, among them the acute problem of illegal migration from Kosovo, which is also reflected in your resolution. The Council will continue to monitor closely Kosovo’s continued engagement towards visible and sustainable progress in the normalisation of relations with Serbia. This means implementation in good faith of all agreements reached so far, so that Kosovo and Serbia can continue on their respective European paths. This is an essential principle of the proposed Stabilisation and Association Agreement that will underpin the development of relations and cooperation between the EU and Kosovo. Lastly, Kosovo should continue to cooperate closely and effectively with the European Union Rule of Law Mission (EULEX) and contribute actively to the full and unhindered execution by EULEX of its renewed mandate. Kosovo should also, as a matter of priority, implement the political commitment to establish the special court to hear cases arising out of the investigation led by the Special Investigative Task Force, by adopting all the necessary legal changes.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome the motion for a resolution on the European integration process of Kosovo. The Commission and the European Parliament continue to share the same vision of Kosovo’s European future. We are grateful for the support of this House and look forward to continuing our close cooperation. We stand ready to help and support Parliament, and the rapporteur Ms Lunacek, over the next few months and years in advancing Kosovo’s European perspective.  In line with the motion for a resolution, during my recent visit to Pristina I emphasised the need for economic reforms to enhance Kosovo’s competitiveness leading to growth, job creation, investment in education and better living conditions for Kosovo’s citizens. This will help in addressing the root causes of irregular migration. Our progress report of October 2014 identified the key areas that need to be tackled by Kosovo. Emphasis remains on the rule of law, reform of public administration and strengthening socio-economic development. All three aspects are essential and progress in these fields will yield political and economic benefits for Kosovo. Last July we completed the negotiations of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) and initialled the text with Kosovo. As you know, the Kosovo SAA is EU only, not mixed. However, I should like to emphasise that it is both comprehensive and robust and that it covers all key areas covered by the other SAAs in the region. Once in force, I am sure there will be very few practical differences between it and other SAAs. Following the initialling of the SAA, the agreement and the draft Council decisions are now being translated. This should be completed later this month. I will propose to the college approval of the package early in April, after which we will submit it to the Council for approval. We aim for the Council to agree on the SAA signature later in the spring and as soon as High Representative/Vice President Mogherini and Kosovo have signed, the SAA will be transmitted to this House for consent. Parliament therefore has an important role to play in the approval process. If the SAA is to come into force in early 2016, which is what we continue to aim for, it will be essential that the dossier is processed efficiently. Of course we stand ready to provide support throughout the process. Once Parliament has given its consent, the Council will be able to proceed with the conclusions of the SAA. Given its EU only nature, ratification by Member States of the interim agreement are not required. Therefore, once concluded, the SAA will enter into force immediately. The coming into force of the Kosovo SAA will be a milestone in the development of EU-Kosovo relations. For the first time, there will be a contractual relationship between the European Union and Kosovo. This relationship provides for rights and benefits, but it also creates duties and obligations. I am sure both sides will need time to get used to this, but I am equally sure that implementation of the SAA will be to the benefit of both and I look forward to Parliament’s continued support for this promising process.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I should like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for very good cooperation in reaching a largely consensual text which I hope will have a good majority tomorrow. Let me start by describing the references to Kosovo over the last weeks and months in many of our Member States. It recently hit the headlines with thousands of asylum-seekers coming across Serbia into Hungary and then Austria, Germany and other countries. This is something that again raised the context of the situation in Kosovo. I am really happy to see that this has gone down over the last weeks because many people in Kosovo have realised that they have been given the illusion of promises through rumours, and that these are illusions. We demand in this report that both Serbia and the Kosovo authorities really clamp down on traffickers who feed into these illusions so that in the future we will not have these many asylum seekers in Member States. Let me also make one thing clear. In this report, as in many others before, I demand fast visa liberalisation for Kosovo. I am sure that if we already had visa liberalisation then people would not feel so locked—in in their country and would be able to go for three months to the European Union and return and would not have the feeling that they need to leave because this was not provided for them. I am glad that Commissioner Avramopoulous has just recently said that Kosovo is walking the last mile and he will soon have good news for Kosovo; so I hope this will come through very soon. Of course, the economic and social situation has to improve, especially for young people, and the fight against corruption and organised crime has to be stepped up by the new government, including in high—ranking parts of their own parties and organisations; otherwise the trust of citizens will not improve. I also welcome the fact that a government was formed after some six months of stalemate, but only two women in a government of 21 really is not acceptable. I also hope that the Kosovo Assembly will soon pass the law on the special court. Let me say one thing: this is not about KLA in general; it is about certain individuals of KLA who might have committed crimes. I am glad the dialogue between Serbia and Kosovo has resumed; there are still things that have to be implemented. For example, Kosovo MPs are still not allowed to participate in all regional meetings, for example in the SECP process of the Parliamentary Assembly, so progress still needs to go ahead there and I think Serbia also has to move on. One thing I also criticise is that five Member States still do not recognise Kosovo. This blocks progress, and I am glad to hear from Commissioner Hahn that the SAA will be put to the Council later in the spring; I hope there will be an agreement and that soon Kosovo will be on its way. I do not have any more time so please read the text. It is also about EULEX and about investigations on corruption allegations inside EULEX. These are harming the credibility of the European Union; we need swift investigations. I hope we will have a good vote tomorrow to make sure that this European Parliament stands behind an independent Kosovo.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Lunacek for his work, which has long been involved in monitoring the political development of Kosovo. The resolution before us seems to me to be balanced and points the way forward in the near future. Kosovo, it has been said, is in the midst of transition and transformation, and there is no doubt that we have welcomed the conclusion of political uncertainty after the elections, with the constitution of the assembly and the new government. There is now another piece of road to be taken: we must continue along the path of reform with commitment and determination, strengthening the role of laws and justice in a visible and concrete way and extending civil rights. It is essential that we finally engage in the fight against corruption and organised crime, and we need to put in place a policy that defeats unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, by implementing economic and structural reforms and sustainable development.  We must, in essence, test the new government and measure its ability to work towards these goals. There will certainly be support from the European Union and a stimulus in this direction, so that these objectives can actually be achieved. However, some concerns remain, concerning the independence, reliability and impartiality of judges and prosecutors. A justice that works is the essential element of a country that wants to be democratic.  Finally, with regard to the Eulex mission, the resolution expresses concern about the recent allegations of corruption and there is no doubt that we need transparency: the credibility of the European Union is also at stake.  In short, I believe that we need to work to move Kosovo forward in the democratic field, a condition of stability in the region, and we will support the resolution because it goes in this direction.

name: Karol Karski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In 2005, a german intelligence report described Kosovo as a large mafia network, and I quote that 'it prevents the creation of a politically and economically stable socio-political structure'. However, this did not prevent a serious part of the international community from recognising Kosovo's independence. I would like to make it clear that this was a serious geopolitical error. Independence was recognised not by a state meeting the requirements of the fundamental rule of law, but rather by criminal organisations operating there, whose conglomerate did not deserve to be called a state. Today, this system is ruled by dozens of mafia clans drawing on the gigantic income from the trafficking of heroin, living goods and human organs.  I would also like to remind you that the Union is conducting formal accession negotiations with Serbia. An equal commitment to Kosovo undermines the coherence of our external policy and may damage EU-Serbia relations, which is in Russia's immediate interest. Putin is keeping a close eye on the Balkans and will try to discourage Serbia from rapprochement with the European Union. If we lose Serbia, we will also lose the entire Balkans, putting them in russia's zone of economic and political influence. I therefore recommend that we be particularly careful and balance our European interests in the region.  The Commissioner pointed to another derogation that we are about to make towards Kosovo. One derogation was already premature recognition. At the moment, we are dealing not with a mixed agreement with the Member States, but for the purpose of simplification (because some Member States do not recognise Kosovo) with an agreement concluded exclusively with the Union. Once again a mistake has been made and mistakes are made once again.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, first of all, of course, I would like to thank Mrs Lunacek for the work she has done in bringing this excellent and balanced report into the world. Kosovo is very close to my heart. I have had the honour and pleasure of visiting the country three times, with our then Belgian king and with then Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt. That was immediately after the war. So I've seen the destruction, too. Our detachment did not return to Belgium until 2010. On paper, of course, Kosovo was moved closer to Europe in 2014, but in practice much remains to be done. The report gives a very good overview of both the achievements, giving the Kosovars courage in their reform process, and of the challenges that the country still faces. It is clear to myself and to the ALDE Group that Kosovo's path leads towards a fully recognised independent state that integrates into the European Union. That must be the goal.  Kosovo, however, is one of the poorest and most corrupt countries in Europe and has an unemployment rate of more than 35%. Prishtina must therefore urgently, with the help of Europe, work towards its rule of law and the fight against corruption and organised crime if it is to combat the exodus of its citizens. This exodus is estimated at 35,000 Kosovars in the last three months, an unlikely figure. That is why, as liberals, we fully support the call in this resolution for socio-economic reform. Let the citizens and the companies, the companies, undertake again. Make Kosovo the beautiful country it is again, because when you go there you see the beauty.   We are therefore very happy to support Kosovo, as an ALDE, in this process of reform and integration.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, 16 years ago a number of EU Member States together with the US decided to break the principle of not changing borders in Europe and to force a part of Serbian territory to turn it into a protectorate.  Since then, kosovo's administration has proved to be a permanent European failure, as can be seen from the European Commission's latest report. The region's Gross Domestic Product is increasing, but growth is being channelled into organised crime, while people's misery is getting worse and creating a wave of fleeing to Europe, with the population falling from 2,200,000 in 2009 to 1,800,000 in 2012. Exports are practically non-existent, unemployment - despite migration - is at 30% and corruption dominates.  The Union must recognise its failure and limit its involvement in Kosovo. We're doing more damage there than benefit.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our neighbours in Kosovo are faced with them in 2015 with a very difficult situation, painted by a Kosovan artist with a large black 'E' letter. "E" such as exodus, Europe, economy and Eulex, four huge problems they are facing. Unemployment is at incredible rates, 30 % in general, 56 % for under-24s: one in three Kosovars is below the poverty line. That is why four to five hundred people a day emigrate from Kosovo with peaks of up to a thousand at the beginning of February. That is why eighteen thousand went to Germany alone. All prey to false promises from ruthless criminal organisations of Serbian and Albanian human traffickers.  This must lead the political forces in Kosovo to a sense of responsibility for a determined fight against corruption, organised crime and a genuine economic and social policy, capable of lifting the country out of its crisis, because without its children working to improve its homeland, Kosovo will not be able to look to the future with optimism.  The scale of the challenge has also been well analysed in Mrs Lunacek's resolution and I welcome the excellent work that has been done so far. Let us remember that Serbia and Kosovo must continue in parallel on the accession track and we will work with them to ensure that this track is straight.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I was in Kosovo three weeks ago and i spoke to Prime Minister Mustafa, among others. The subject was also the present draft report. On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to express my thanks to Mrs Lunacek for her good work as rapporteur. A dominant theme in Pristina was the wave of asylum seekers from Kosovo to the European Union. This has been mentioned today, and Germany is particularly affected by this. First important measures, such as additional border controls, seem to contribute to short-term success. However, I would like to take this opportunity – because the ambassador of Kosovo to the European Union is following this debate this evening – to emphasise what previous speakers have already said: an information campaign on the ground is crucial. Kosovo is a de facto safe country of origin, and asylum applications from Kosovars have no chance of being recognised in Germany. In the medium and long term, however, the situation in Kosovo will only improve if the economic situation there recovers appreciably. The European Union is ready to play its part. There is much to be done in Kosovo. We should support this country together.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 2014 was an important year for Kosovo and its process of rapprochement with the European Union. The signing of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement has created the basis for the creation of a single economic area, but we must not stop there. We must go beyond the creation of a single market and create an area where everyone can fully enjoy their fundamental rights. From this point of view, too, 2014 was an important year for Kosovo. The government set up an advisory coordination group for lgbti people's rights and on 17 May the first National Pride was held in Pristina to mark World Day to Combat Homophobia and Transphobia. I am pleased to see that, unlike in other countries in the region, there have been no accidents and that the government buildings, international organisations and embassies of EU countries have displayed the rainbow flag and other symbols in support of the movement. I too would like to thank Mrs Lunacek, although there is still a long way to go for her excellent report, which I hope will receive as many votes as possible here in Parliament tomorrow.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I would like to initially congratulate Mrs Lunacek on the serious work we have done together. It was a real challenge for me to be her shadow rapporteur on this report. The report objectively reflects the situation in Kosovo, clearly outlines the problems, outlines the results achieved. There is no way not to mention the problems, there is no way not to mention the suspicions of corruption related to one of the European institutions, there is no way not to mention, of course, the high level of organised crime related to drug trafficking and other serious criminal offences. What worries me most, however, is the possibility and availability of shelter bases for fighters who travel from Europe to Islamic State and who threaten in some way by going back, and our continent. This should also be addressed.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – The past 2014 can be marked as significant for Kosovo's European integration. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement has been initiated and we expect this spring to happen. Elections were held in the country, which were defined as democratic and transparent by all international observers. Despite the difficult political dialogue between the main political parties, which lasted 6 months, a government was formed. It is now essential that Kosovo continue with key reforms that will help improve the economic environment. Professionalism and transparency in the judiciary, the fight against organised crime and high levels of corruption remain very problematic. Economic reforms need to be started to effectively combat unemployment. In this regard, I consider it timely for the Council to adopt a decision and to sign a framework agreement on Kosovo's participation in European Union programmes.  This will contribute to the country's economic growth and strengthen cooperation with the European Union in various sectoral policies.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – The euphoric joy of Kosovo's recent independence stands in stark contrast to what we are currently experiencing in the country. In the midst of the worsening domestic political situation, rising poverty and unemployment, and the multifaceted social problems, the inhabitants of the new State cannot really enjoy either the freedom they have been awarded or the support of the Union. That's why tens of thousands of people are choosing the route of emigration. The domestic political class is primarily responsible for the development of the hopeless situation. In this context, however, the community of nations that have created the country must also take greater responsibility and sacrifice in remedying the deepening crisis. The Government of Kosovo and the European Union, in the framework of integration cooperation, can only find a solution at home – kosovo – to stop the perilous exodus. Serbia, which is on the road to accession, should also be encouraged not to hinder, but to promote, the development of its former province, which is worthy of a better fate. Thus, in the cause of reparations and reconciliation.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: – In 2008, Europe allowed Kosovo to declare independence. The Balkan peace process could start and the balkan countries could also have the opportunity to membership the European Union at arm's reach.  However, the exodus to Kosovo in 2014 showed us all that what we have done for The Kosovans is not enough. How is it possible that one third of a country's population is about to emigrate from a country and head for Europe. Today, Kosovans have only two choices: either they suffer the poverty at home that can only drown, or they try to make a living in Europe from their own work. For this reason, Europe must take responsibility for all Kosovans, for those who stay at home, and also for those who are heading for Europe, today, unfortunately, in the European Union, we are faced with more than once extremist parties trying to capitalise on this issue, and even in Hungary we see the ruling party trying to describe Kosovo refugees as livelihood migrants. We see that independence has brought only hopelessness to Kosovans after the initial joy, so Europe has a lot to do and the Member States of the European Union have a lot to do: instead of exclusion, we must represent a policy of inclusion.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first let me express my appreciation and thanks to Ulrike Lunacek for her report and for her engagement in the issue of Kosovo.  Following the long pause after the elections, the new Kosovo Government needs to concentrate on substantial issues concerning the country’s development. It is clear what will be the consequences of failure in economic and social policies. Kosovo needs urgently to address the economic development and extremely high unemployment. The recent growth of asylum seekers is just one among many visible consequences.  For our part, we should be ready to adopt the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) and move on with visa liberalisation. On the other hand, it is crucial that the new government prioritises the issues of the fight against corruption and organised crime. Also we still await the results of the investigation concerning the allegation of corruption in EULEX. If we want to remain credible – and we want to remain credible – we should be able to shed light on this case.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to congratulate Mrs Lunacek on a really balanced report. With such great sympathy, I noted, in particular, Commissioner Hahn's last sentence that 'this is a promising process'. During this debate, we talked about all sorts of shortcomings, shortcomings and even one could say very negative developments within Kosovo, or, moreover, Mr Karski spoke very clearly.  The fundamental problem that we face there is the perspective for these people, the opportunity of who they are supposed to be, what opportunities they have in this small or even very small country. And what we are talking about when we talk about possible membership of the Union, association with it, is giving them perspective. I think we owe it to them as a European Union after all the experiences that this region has had.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – I would like to join in with mrs Lunacek's congratulations and thanks for a good report that really details the situation in... in Kosovo. We spoke earlier about Serbia, where the message and the report were more encouraging than it was from Kosovo, because the reality is also more difficult in Kosovo. The basic points that are in the report, which have also been presented here today, are crucial. The problem of unemployment, a problem that does not give many people in Kosovo hope and brings them so far that they are left in the hands of the illegal and criminal groups that trade in these people. Even in the country I come from, there are a whole host of people from Kosovo looking for a future. Because they explain how difficult it is at home, when there are no jobs and when jobs are also paid for with very low resources. I support the efforts to really rule the rule of law and to continue good cooperation with Serbia, because joint good cooperation is the guarantor of the progress of both countries.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the resolution approved in the Committee on Foreign Affairs and I believe it is a positive step forward. More efforts need to be made to strengthen the rule of law and the judiciary to combat corruption and organised crime, to reduce unemployment, enact structural economic reforms and promote sustainable development. I strongly support the amendments made by our group: the focus on the importance of transparent media, the role of women in government and progress in the negotiations with Serbia. We, from Romania, are following these negotiations very closely and we are going to take them into account.  We need to increase cooperation in the fight against terrorism and radicalisation. We need, regarding the role of EULEX, to have a broad and deep analysis in order to assess the overall effectiveness of the mission. A call for full transparency is crucial for the credibility of the European institutions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the action of extremist Islamic elements in Kosovo raises serious concerns in the region. There have already been mass arrests of suspects for involvement in combat operations in Iraq and Syria. The role of certain NGOs originating in Saudi Arabia and Qatar is also problematic.  The increased migratory waves from Kosovo to Union countries, with large Albanian minorities, are intensifying the concern of Union citizens. At the same time, the revival of Albanian nationalism is particularly worrying, as Tirana is pushing Kosovo forward with the redeeming idea of Greater Albania demanding a change of borders in the Balkans and territories belonging to Greece.  Finally, Madam President, I wonder how Kosovo can one day become a member of the European Union since five Member States of the European Union do not even recognise Kosovo as a state entity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there are major reforms ahead for Kosovo. We want to support Kosovo on its European path, we want to say on the other hand that reforms are absolutely necessary. I want to emphasize in particular what no one here has mentioned, which is the need to protect the rights of the Serb community in Kosovo.  I am one of those who stand up for minority rights everywhere, especially Serbs in Croatia, so I also want to talk about the need to protect Serbs in Kosovo. I want to point out that we are talking about the future of the Balkans here. That's what we were talking about today. In all sorts of ways, opposing each other. I would like to see the whole Balkans in the European Union one day, because I believe it is the only real future for that part of Europe.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, by virtue of my own Romany-Gypsy heritage I feel I have a duty to raise the long history of discrimination against the Roma minority living in Kosovo. There are huge issues with regard to healthcare, education, housing, poverty, unemployment and opportunity. The Roma are increasingly taking their chance, and heading west across the European Union. From my perspective, this long history of discrimination is not acceptable. The Roma should be made to feel more comfortable in their countries of choice. We have a perspective from the British traveller communities of a lack of provision for traveller sites. I fear, as more Roma head to the United Kingdom, that this puts extra pressure on our own proud travelling communities and could possibly lead to a wider anti—Gypsy backlash.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too wanted to congratulate Mrs Lunacek on her work, which is certainly a constructive report, because we are probably talking about the most difficult situation in relation to the other countries we discussed earlier, since Kosovo, in addition to being the youngest country, is also a country that is not recognised by five Member States of the European Union. , and that alone must make us think. The Stabilisation and Association Agreement is certainly a good first step, but I would not like it to become a step longer than the leg, because it is too fast, and so we risk interrupting what must be a natural process, which must bring all the Balkans into the European Union. We all know that there are problems with organised crime and the danger of terrorism, so it is good that we should try to look even more constructively at relations with that country in the future in order to bring it into the Union.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for their continuing support for initiatives on Kosovo. The draft resolution discussed today is a very constructive one and I would also like to thank Mrs Lunacek for her work, which I can imagine was not always easy. It quite clearly shows Kosovo’s structural problems, both with regard to the economy and the rule of law, but also points to the way forward. Therefore, I strongly believe that signing and concluding the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) this year will send an encouraging signal to all Kosovo citizens that Kosovo’s future lies in continuing its progress towards Europe. The SAA will help further consolidate the country’s engagement on European integration, provide an important stimulus to pursue necessary reforms and address Kosovo’s economic challenges. Let me also thank, in the presence of the Ambassador, the leading authorities of Kosovo, and in particular the President of State and the Prime Minister but also others, for the immediate, quick and tough reaction to the immigration flow we faced at the end of last year by communicating in the country itself that it does not make sense to leave the country to try to apply for asylum which is not recognised. All these efforts have led to a sustainable decline in migrants and this is proof of the quality the administration and the politicians have already reached in Kosovo. Please pass on my thanks to the authorities in the country itself.  Perhaps I can do this myself because I will have the pleasure of being there in two weeks’ time when we can participate in a Western Balkan Six conference hosted by Kosovo dealing with connectivity in the area of transport. I think this is already a very good signal of the fact that Kosovo is fully participating in all the activities in the region itself, trying to better connect the countries in the region and to contribute to peace and stability, to growth, to jobs and to prosperity in the region.  I wish you all the best and once again thank Members of the Parliament for this very constructive work and contribution in the interest of Kosovo and therefore in Europe’s interests.

name: Zanda Kalniņa-Lukaševica
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the EU will continue to assist Kosovo of course, including through its strengthened presence on the ground. However, the primary responsibility for progress lies with Kosovo, its leaders, institutions and civil society. The Council recognises the importance of concluding the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo as soon as possible. It will be an important contribution to regional stability, closely linking Kosovo to its European integration path, and creating an additional incentive for reforms in Kosovo. The Council now awaits proposals from the Commission to be able to proceed with the Council decision, with a view to concluding the agreement without delay. Reforms are crucial and will require the political leaders to live up to their responsibilities for the good of Kosovo and of its citizens. Key EU—related reforms are essential, not just to please the EU, but because they are in the interests of Kosovo and in the interests of its citizens.
